text: This is a promising pilot for a TV series. It has an early twist, so don't read any of the summaries if you don't want to be spoiled (it's not a big spoiler in the grand scheme of the show, but it's a nice twist). The actors are all delivering down to earth performances, making the story more believable and feel more real - which is a big plus because one of the premises requires a little bit of a suspension of disbelief for dramatic reasons. Of the characers so far, the grandma stood out the most for me. It will be interesting to see how they would do a full season and future seasons while keeping the story fresh and non-formulaic.

Dove soaps in general are smoother than say something like Irish Spring. More so with this bar, with the extra moisturizers. The bar is solid in the hand, with a good grip, and maintains rigidity. It has a distinctive non-subtle smell, but it is neither obnoxious nor objectionable, nor one of those marketing-inspired "man smells" (think Axe and such). I think many ladies would probably like it too.It lasts about as long as other 4oz to 5oz bar soaps that I previously used, so perhaps a mild advantage when comparing to 5oz bars, but then again, most people buy soap by the number of bars or the package, not by weight.As advertised, it is nice and gentle on the face (avoid contact with eyes), I couldn't really notice a difference between it and a basic facewash. The issue with face washing is on subsequent baths. How many people would feel comfortable using the bar on their face after it went through a full body wash? Sure, one could use one side for the face, and the other for the body. Still, many will still say "no", so another possibility is to use two bars. One designated for the face, and one designated for the body. At some point, you can always transition the Face to the Body (so it doesn't linger around for too long) and open a fresh bar for the face. But this adds more bathing complications or perhaps not enough space for multiple bars of soap.There is a long list of ingredients printed on the outer wrapper but not on the individual soap boxes. There's the usual avoid contact with eyes warning.Prices and promotions go up and down, so I can't compare those. Personally I am not picky on soaps, so if I was out of soap and had to buy an 8 pack, I would probably buy this if it was within 1.5x or less of the price of the typical brands (Irish Spring, etc). Maybe up to 2x if I was in a pampering mood :)

If you are looking for a non-refillable spiral notebook with a covered spiral, and you are willing to pay for the extra features, then you may find this quite useful. It has 150 college ruled perforated pages, three removable and repositionable dividers with two pockets each, and a penloop on the front. You cannot open this, so you cannot add more pages once you fill it up.One of the reasons this notebook is effective is because its spiral has about twice the radius (rough estimate) of a typical basic wired notebook, making it easier to flip through without intrapage snagging and resistance. The outer spiral is covered when the notebook is closed or when it lays flat on the desk. But if you fold the notebook under itself, the spiral is not covered. If you remove the pen from the penloop, it is pretty nice to write with when it is folded under itself. It takes up less space on the desk and brings out the page in front of you.The dividers are easy to add/remove, they hold on to the wire spine in five different places. They are in a 2-1-2 formation, so there is some leeway in case a couple of the connection points break (mine are working fine, but they are fairly thin). You can also reuse the dividers in other notebooks (as long as the pieces fit).One thing that is not included but may be useful is if you use a thin cardboard or some other glossy flyer or something else to put underneath the page you are currently writing on. This serves two purposes: 1) it won't scratch the page below,  or 2) when the page is near a divider, the shape and texture of the divider and its pocket interfere a bit with the writing (not a flat smooth surface).

This is the first book I read from the author and I haven't watched the movie adaptation of her book either. I liked the idea of reading a creativity inspirational book (I rarely read inspirational books), but I did not know what to expect. I was worried it might turn out to be a variation of SNL's Daily Affirmations. Thankfully, it was totally not like that at all!For a book that talks about "magic", it offers a lot of very grounded inspiration for artists of all kinds. The style is conversational, flowing, rolling, and jumping, an outpouring of the author's creative (and life) experiences. If you are the type who prefers heavily structured and organized books, perhaps consider reading this book as a creativity fostering assignment :) It consists of seven parts, with each part having multiple segments of varying length (from one to a few pages each). As such, it makes it ideal for reading in small bites, 10-20 pages per seating. It gives you time to think and absorb.Grounded inspiration as in (I'm paraphrasing/summarizing): you are not the center of the universe, but you are part of the universe, you belong here as much as anyone else. You are not entitled to anything or everything you want, but you are entitled to your creative life no matter what others are saying. You are not The Chosen One, but you have a lot inside you can unlock and cultivate and share with the world if you are willing to put in the work... I am not really doing the book justice here, there are hundreds of different ways this is expressed (and a lot more eloquently) in the book.But it goes far beyond that. It tackles some tougher issues with creativity, perfection vs good enough, creative compromises vs artistic purity, stubborness, ego's power, on giving up, dealing with reactions from others, our (creativity's) emotional cycles, measuring success, expectations and outcomes, creative careers and money matters and day jobs, authenticity vs originality, meaning and purpose, the suffering and tormented artists, dealing with disappointments, "between those bright moments", creative work is not a baby, and so forth.Although this is not a how-to or step-by-step book, there are a handful of direct and indirect tips, some very specific (for example, if you are stuck, do something different (eg if a writer, play music or work the yard or paint bicycles)), some more general. Among others, tips and ideas include Dress Up, fostering curiosity and inquisitiveness, having an affair (with your creativity), and on and on.As with arts and humans, there is a paradox in the book. Coming along for the ride with all the grounded inspiration is magic. In the gray area of just beyond metaphors and figures of speech, the author posits that ideas are self-aware entities ("disembodied, energetic life-form"), and cites examples of such, the most prominent being the Brazil Amazon book idea that "jumped" from one author to another at a specific point in time. The more I read, the more it felt like the author actually believed this: my last note in the Enchantment chapter was a puzzled "really believes it?"A number of authors, artists and works of art are mentioned within the book, along with stories (lots of stories) from their creative lives. Not just famous people, but also everyday life people, from Red Lobster to Winifred to Brene Brown to Tom Waits and many more). These may also be of interest if you are looking for things to read or discover or rediscover next (which could be as simple as reading the Wikipedia of the creative persons mentioned or as complicated going through their work).My favorite quote from the book: "I believe that our creativity grows like sidewalk weeds out of the cracks between our pathologies - not from the pathologies themselves".It is all text (no diagrams/tables/charts), so you won't miss anything if you read this on an e-book reader. Maybe a good idea to get both because this is a book you can read multiple times and share with friends and family.I found this book interesting enough that I have already began re-reading it out of my own free will - a measurable data point of the value and importance of a book.

Reading the Comments exists in the nebulous space between a pop-science book and a textbook. It is more readable than a research book but not as sing-alongy as a pop-science book. It takes a wide look at the ways people comment on the internets. You soon realize this is a lot more complicated subject than it may initially feel ("it's just online comments by random people") and books could probably be written dedicated to each form and type of commentary (eg Twitter, Blogs, Forums (okay, may be a trilogy for forums), etc).The writing style is straight-forward, the book is broken into seven interlinked chapters (plus a conclusions chapter) diving high and low into the various forms of commentary and their intersection points beyond the comment box. There's a variety of examples and anecdotes, including the "Saved our Son's Life - 4/5 Stars", the rejection bump of research papers, Reznor's "fragile" moment, "sleepwalkers", Godwin's Law and lots more.At the back of the book there are 34 pages of references (books, research, many websites and web articles), broken down by chapter. A pretty comprehensive list of reading materials, which would be of great value to anyone seriously interested in this topic. I looked at the publisher's website and within the book, but I did not find these available online (which can be handy for the web links). TIP: you don't have to type the full url, just search for the article name and website/author - the search engines are pretty good at finding them.The book content is more than the actual number of 187 pages of main text (228 total) would suggest because of a smaller font and economical line-spacing which translates to 37 lines of text on a 9x6 inch printed page. If you find the text too small, the e-book should be of help since you can zoom and zoom and zoom: the book is text only with occasional black and white internet comics (for which you can also use a tablet/computer/phone).

The first time I emptied one of these packs into a spoon, the first thing that came to mind was mayo. It turns out I was half-right, the third ingredient in a long list is pasteurized egg yolk. The approach here is to throw all kinds of different things to cover up the fishy taste (fish oil is the first ingredient, water being the second). Among the recognizable tastes, the strong orange flavor (4th item in list, "natural orange flavor"), the mayo-egginess, 10mg Stevia Leaf Extract (with its characteristic after taste), and menthol that kicks the afterburners attempting to cover it all up.Now if this was a dessert, I would not like the taste. But its purpose is to cover up the fishiness, and at that, it is very successful. I prefer these to the gummies which have all kinds of nasty sugars (even high fructose corn syrup). Not that this one is perfect but at least it has no artificial sweeteners, no artificial flavors, no sugars, no gluten/wheat/yeast, no milk/lactose. But it still has about a dozen other things to hold it all together (less than 2%).It is on the expensive side, one box has 30 squeeze packs, with the serving size per the box being two squeeze packs. In other words, if you want to take this as such, one box lasts 15 days. Definitely more expensive than the horse pills. The squeeze packs are inside in 15 pairs. Each pair is perforated. Could be handy if you put it in lunch boxes and such for the whole day. These become less expensive if you prefer a lower dosage, for example one squeeze-pack per day or every other day instead.The instructions say take preferably with food and could be added to cold food (such as yogurt or smoothie), but do not freeze or heat the packs.

This is my second Capital Teas loose-leaf tea that I tried, so I don't know if it is a house signature or just coincidence, but both were on the subtle and mild flavor side compared to other similar teas. Two reasons to consider this tea: 1) you prefer organic and are willing to pay a higher price, 2) you prefer a milder breakfast blend flavor. This is a blend of five teas, and it is not as Assam dominated as other breakfast blends. Their website describes the five teas used. It is marked as high caffeine, I did not notice a difference in caffeine impact compared to other breakfast blends.There are tea pieces of all sizes in this one, a lot of them are small. After infusion, I compared tea leaf sizes to a Tattle Tea loose leaf breakfast blend and I also cracked open a Trader Joe Breakfast blend tea bag. The smallest pieces of the Capital Tea were almost the same size as the Trader Joe tea bag (48 tea bags for $2, not organic). The Tattle tea did not have many small pieces as Capital, but it is not organic. I put the infused tea in separate water bowls, the size differences are much more obvious there than looking at them on a plate or bowl.Because it has more small pieces, you may want to use your smallest cell infuser or a tea sock, as there's more than usual at the bottom of the cup.The milder taste became obvious as I was switching back and forth between this and the Tattle tea and in a separate experiment, the Trader Joe breakfast blend. So it goes both ways, if you want a classic Assam-y breakfast blend, this is probably not it. On the other hand, if you want a milder breakfast blend but still get the morning tea-kick, and value organic, you may like it.

I was on the unsweetened coconut milk and coconut water bandwagon but I never got around to trying coconut oil until this one. And it exceeded my expectations. I haven't tried any other brands yet, so I can't compare it. I love how just 1-2 teaspoons of this can make a boring salad more edible. It doesn't really have its own taste signature, but it helps bring out the flavor of the various crunchy greens in the salad (for lack of a better way to describe it). I prefer it to olive oil or prepackaged salad dressings (which have sodium and other "bonus" ingredients).I also take 1-2 teaspoons of this as a snack as needed, curbing what would have otherwise been a much worse (nutrition wise) snack. When eating on its own, it has a bit of a soothing effect, no after taste, but more than 2 teaspoons at once, I get the "I ate too much oil" type of a feel.It smells coconuty when you open the plastic jar, and still does a few weeks later. There is a bit of oiliness in the area around the rim but I don't know if it's the way that I'm using it (I turned it sideways, upside down, etc like a curious monkey when I first got it) or not a perfect seal.The container says this is cold pressed, 100% raw, 100% organic, extra virgin. There is only one ingredient, "organic extra virgin coconut oil". Per the container, refrigeration is not required, and so I obliged and did not refrigerate it, and I kept it away from the sun. I put it in an empty nutrition bar 12pk container for protection and to test for oily leaks. At room temperature, it is mostly solid with a bit of liquid pooling.Per the box, the 18oz jar has 36 tablespoon (14g) servings. Each serving is 120 calories, all from fat: 14g total (12g saturated, 1g mono). Zeros on the other categories: Carbs, Protein, Sodium, Cholesterol, Vitamins/Minerals.Sideways next to the barcode, It says "product of the Philippines, packaged in the USA". It has a BPA-Free logo with a recyclable sign next to it.

This is a versatile and customizable system, but the combination of one's hearing and the equipment they use (TV, cable box, etc) make things slightly different for every person, and for something like this, perhaps the best way to find out if it works for you is to try it. There's no one size fits all answer.WHAT'S INCLUDED================The package is very easy to open with your fingers. An outer sleeve covers the white cardboard re-closable container that has all the items. You push the container up or down to free it from the sleeve. Then open it gently.The front half of the box has the earphones in a storage box and the portable receiver (handset) with protective tape. Underneath these, you have the AC USB adapter charging head, and a solid box with three eartip sizes, and a standard RCA audio cable (red/white).The back half of the box has the two user manuals sealed (Quick Start Guide and User Manual). The serial number is printed on the back of the manual. Underneath these, and protected by padding you find the charging base (transmitter), the USB charging cable (microUSB to full USB), and the neckstrap in its own bag with silica gel.FIRST TIME USE=============Both the User Manual and the Quick Start Guide (essentially a Visual User Manual) are very well done and make sense and are helpful in figuring things out. The font is small at some places,The manual recommends charging for at least 5 hours the first time you use it. Mine finished charging in less than 4.5 hours but I let it go on for 5+ hours - obeying the manual.The receiver does not lock in place when you put it on the charging base to charge it. If you move the base, it will sway, so it is a good idea to put it at a place where it is not going to be accidentally knocked over.You can unplug and replug the base from the power supply without needing to take any installation steps, which makes it a good idea if you use it in different rooms or at different locations. Just package it and plug and play.BASE (the Transmitter)==================This only works when it is plugged in to the wall using the provided AC adapter using the microUSB to USB cable. It has a big ON/OFF button upfront. Press and hold to turn ON/OFF. While ON, there is a red light surrounding the button that stays until you power it off. The base charges the receiver (handset). The back has the connection, power, and three audio input options. The most common is RCA (white and red) and this cable is included. It also has an Optical input and a Digital Coaxial (Orange) input. Cables are not included for these. There is a button that switches between Optical and Digital Coaxial. For Digital Coaxial audio (the orange input), if you don't have a  proper orange coaxial cable, per various A/V forums, you can use a standard yellow RCA video cable (sounds strange to use a video cable for audio, but the specs/physics of the yellow video cable make it a better bet than the red/white audio cables) .IMPORTANT for DIGITAL AUDIO: digital audio only flows if your TV or BluRay player or other source outputs audio in 44.1kHz PCM / 48kHz PCM. Many modern devices default to the fanciest audio output available (surround sound, etc). You may have to manually change your audio settings to standard stereo. Otherwise you won't get audio from the digital inputs/outputs. Once I adjusted the audio settings, both Coaxial (DVD player) and Optical (TV) worked fine.If you want to listen to sound from a 3.5mm source (TV headphone out, Conventional Radio, Tablet/Phone, etc), you can just use a standard 3.5mm to RCA cable (you can get them for under $5, search for 1/8" to RCA and make sure the male/female options are what you need). Mine worked fine with a couple of no-name generic cables of this type.Even in the summer, after running for 4+ hours straight, the base was just warm to the touch, not hot. I did not put it in a cabinet.SOURCE=======A very important factor to how well this may or may not work for you is the combination of your equipment and how you use them. For example, in some TVs (mine included) the convenient headphone out is an afterthought in terms of sound quality, so you can get better sound by connecting this to the Optical (TOSlink).A word on caution: different devices have different default volume, so start with a low volume and go up (for example, my DVD player is much louder than anything else I have). Put the earphones on only after everything is connected and the sound is playing. If it's too loud, you will hear it before you put them on your ears, so you won't risk further hearing issues.RECEIVER (HANDSET)===================It has a built-in non-removable rechargeable battery, charges on the Base unit. It is approximately 10 x 6 x 1.5 cm and weighs 3 ounces. It is slightly smaller than an iPod Touch 4 but decidedly thicker. A neckstrap is included, but you can also put it in your pocket like a smartphone or use exercise armbands for smartphones/iPods if you prefer that approach (check the dimensions).While operating, a small green light stays on and steady. If there are signal issues, it flashes. It has a power button and microUSB charging input on top.On the right side there's the yellow amplified sound switch (the user manual recommends not to use this "except under some circumstances" but does not elaborate) - probably because it makes things even louder while reducing sound quality. Below that, there's a standard volume rocker (up and down). There is a light next to the button that indicates volume. There is no mute option (workaround: unplug earphones or turn it off).On the left side there is one button, the Equalizer Presets. Each press switches to the next Preset. Unfortunately there is an annoying beep with each switch, which can get annoying real fast if you are going through the four options to see which one sounds better. There is no custom equalizer. Only four options. Option #1 is high frequencies, #2 is medium frequency, #3 is low frequency, and #4 is balanced ("overall optimized). This is where this may not be work for people with hearing difficulties that are not covered by the four presets. You cannot adjust the presets to better match the situation. You can change volume and turn on the Boost, but that's it.EARPHONES==========A set of earphones are included, in their own nice solid storage box. They have one pair of eartips installed and three extra pairs with different sizes. They are double flanged, so they can get a bit deeper in the ear and block a bit more noise. The blue is for Left and red for Right. There is also a very faint L and R on each side, but it's a lot easier to just remember bLue (left) or Red (R for Right).If you don't feel comfortable with this style, fear not. Since the Receiver (Handset) has a standard 3.5mm output, you can use just about any pair of headphones or earphones or even portable speakers or anything else that plays 3.5mm audio. You can try to pick headphones that are better match of your hearing and listening situation.MULTIPLE UNITS=============This is based on the user manual (I only have one base and one handset that is included in the box), but because it is a bit unusual, I thought I would mention it; you can buy additional receivers (handsets) so multiple people can listen to the same sound using one base unit (transmitter). However you must make sure they are the same color as your current Vitasound base because compatibility between base and receiver is based on their actual. For example, blue connects with blue, black with black, etc.If you want to use two base units of the same color, you have to make sure there is some distance between them. (if they are within 16 feet of each other, there will be interference). In such a case, you need to buy products of different colors or increase the distance between them.

This is a good idea, and the product is organized very nicely, however, very little information is available on the product and compatibility, and I could not find any website or contact info for the manufacturer, so this makes it probably not a good idea for first-time buyers of 3rd party power adapters. If this was a random computer accessory (eg mouse or keyboard), not as big of an issue, but a power adapter can cause serious damage to a laptop, so a higher level of scrutiny is a good idea. On the other hand, if you are a veteran of power supplies, you may not need any of that, and you may be happy with this.Of four laptops ranging from 10 to 13 inch displays (Acer, ASUS, Dell, Samsung Chromebook), only one of them had matching power output to this Powerocker, a 13-inch Dell inspiron consumer laptop. The numbers were very close, not an exact match (probably within rounding error), but close enough for me to feel comfortable using it. It powered and charged the laptop without issue, even during some heavy duty action sessions, a massive Windows Update, and a Windows 8 to 8.1 update. The brick was hot during this, but still comfortable to the touch.For the other three laptops, the power requirements were quite different, and I was not wiling to risk frying good working laptops on a product that does not have a tangible manufacturer.For laptops with big power bricks, this provides a double advantage, a smaller power adapter when you are on the go or space is at a premium, and a backup in case you lose or break your original adapter. But some of the smaller laptops have power bricks that are about the same size; in this case, the advantage is having an extra/backup power adapter.WEIGHT: this power adapter weighs 5.1 oz with the power cable on the scale. The power cable is not removable. When I weighed just the brick with the cable off the scale, it was around 4.1 oz on its own.UNBOXING: The best thing about this product is the packaging, which reminds that of a smartphone. A small compact cardboard box, measuring 5.25 by 3 by 2 inches approximate. Inside a reclosable cardboardy container you find the charger wrapped in protective tape and the nine charging heads. One is pre-installed, while the other eight have a storage bay where they clip on securely.  At the very bottom of the box, there's a drawstring pouch sealed in its own see-thru bag, and a 2.75-inch square folded paper that has the basic power specs and instructions on how to attach heads. Unfortunately there is no information on how to figure out whether your laptop is compatible with it power-wise, which is the most important thing. Also no information on the manufacturer. The charging heads fit comfortably in the pouch, but you may have to be a master at cable folding to get the charger and the cable and the charging heads all fit in the pouch. Still a pouch is better than no pouch.

I had ZICO Natural coconut water in my fridge (the 11.2 fl oz tetrapak), so it was a good opportunity to compare it to the 16.9oz CocoZia Original unflavored coconut water. The biggest difference is that the Zico is noticeably sweeter, and the difference is more pronounced when you switch back and forth drinking from these. Another taste difference, after I returned home from a walk in the sun, I found the Cocozia to be more refreshing than the Zico. The Cocozia has a bit more of a "salty taste" (a poor way of me describing the unique coconut water taste), probably because it does not have the overpowering sweetness of ZICO.The mouth of the container is wider with the Zico than the Cocozia. The lids are not interchangeable even though they have similar shape and technology.In terms of ingredients, the Cocozia is 100% organic coconut water, while the Zico is coconut water. TIP: the Zico coconut water in the bottles is usually from concentrate, while the Zico in the tetrapaks (boxy containers with ears/flaps) is not from concentrate.Nutrition wise, there are a lot of similarities, but Cocozia has more iron (none in Zico), magnesium, calcium and phosphorus. Even though Zico tastes sweeter, Cocozia actually has slightly more sugar per serving. The rest of the numbers are pretty close (calories, total carbs, sodium). No fat, no protein.

The Curel Daily Moisture Original Lotion (13 Ounce) comes in a mostly white container with a grey pump. The pump is easy to operate, and you can also use it one-handed (push with thumb while the rest of your palm collects the lotion). The pump feels sturdy and non-flimsy. The pump mechanism is removable and repositionable, just twist left or right and adjust position of pump head. A very gentle touch on the pump can get you as little as a raindrop (or lemon seed or something of that small amount).The container has a bit of "widescreen" shape, it doesn't have a big round bottom, so it maybe prone to tipping off if one hits it on the upper parts (might be of interest depending on where you plan to put it).The lotion is not fragrance-free, but to my nose, it is a mild and unobtrusive "lotiony" (for lack of a more professional term) smell. The lotion gets absorbed nicely. I can feel the moisturizer working. I haven't noticed any side effects or issues while using it.The whole long list of ingredients (17 or so) is on the back of the container. The directions are simple "use daily and reapply to dry areas as needed. For external use only".

The Hefty Storage Slider Quart bags come in a 100% recycled paper container which is rather thin and it can give if you press it. Inside you find the bags stored in an easy to pull out fashion. Each bag is around 8x7 inches and weighs 0.2 lbs empty  (measured with a postal scale that goes up in 0.1oz increments).The back side of each bag is clear. The front has a big Hefty logo but also an area with a white background in the middle where you can write on. The writing area is roughly 5.75 by 0.75 inches, shaped more ribbon than rectangle. The front also has Open and Close signs (aligned with the slider head), so you don't have to memorize which side is which. If you don't need to write you may find all the "decorations" annoying. I use a Sharpie to write on it if I'm storing non-food items.Opening and closing makes a distinct sound as the slider-head clicks on each side. The slider mechanism feels pretty sturdy, so it should survive multiple openings and closings other things equal.The box has instructions on microwave use for quick reheating or defrosting but warns against overheating and melting. Personally I prefer to heat food in microwave safe plates and containers, even if it's an extra step.

These are handy if you need ready to go cereal packs. Obviously you can save more by buying regular size cereal boxes, so one needs to value the convenience and portability to justify purchasing these. The flavored ones are satisfying to eat as is. Some may find some of the plainer ones (such as Rice Crispies, Frosted Flakes) too boring to eat on their own. But there is enough room in the cup to drop a few blueberries (preferably smaller ones) and makes a difference in taste (the cups are too small for blackberries or strawberries).I like these with unsweetened and unflavored coconut milk. Since the cereal is loaded with carbs and most of them have a flavor of their own, I find coconut milk to be a great match for them.. TIP: when shopping for coconut milk, do read the labels. Some of the "original" national brand coconut milks are not unsweetened or not unflavored (flavor typically means sugar added in some form).The 24 pack of Special K cereal contains eight the following: Original (top floor of the box), Red Berries (middle of the box), and Fruit & Yogurt (bottom of the box).The 24 pack of Classic cereal contains uneven numbers: 7 Mini Wheats, 7 Frosted Flakes, 5 Raisin Bran Crunch, 5 Rice Crispies.Calories range from 140 (Special K Original or Rice Crispies) to 280 (Raisin bran) on their own (without milk). One cup is one serving. There is enough room in the cereal cup for up to 8oz of milk/liquid. My favorite of this lot in terms of taste is the Special K Red Berries that comes with slices of freeze-dried strawberries. This along with Fruit & Yogurt (has small pieces of strawberries) result in a reddish milk when you mix it in. Overall, the Special K pack is my favorite over the Classic by a significant margin.Protein wise, they range from 2 grams (Rice Crispies) to 7 grams (Special K or Mini Wheats). Likewise, fiber ranges from 0g to 8g (Mini Wheats). None of the seven has Trans, Saturated or Cholesterol. They have Sodium ranging from 8% to 18% (K Red Berries). The only exception are the Mini Wheats with 0% sodium. They also have a variety of Vitamins and Minerals.The list of ingredients is surprisingly short for five of them (1 to 1.5 lines). The exception are the Raisin Bran Crunch (3 lines) and the Fruit & Yogurt gone wild (five lines of ingredients).At the outside bottom of the cups, barely visible without scrutiny, there is a recycle 5 sign.

There are benefits to this popcorn, it is smaller, tastes more natural than mass-market popcorn, not as salty or slimy, and doesn't get stuck as much or as deep in the teeth (the "virtually hulless" claim). However, it comes at a premium. As of review time, it's about $2 per popcorn bag, which is a lot more than mass market (grocery stores, warehouse clubs, etc) popcorn. I am an occasional popcorn eater, and I could see this as a special treat or reward on rare occasions, but definitely too expensive for regular consumption.On a 700W microwave (I think it's 700W), I used the popcorn setting, and stopped it ten seconds before the timer stopped, about two minutes total. Only a dozen or less were unpopped at this setting. I preferred this than when I let it go all the way.Ingredients per the box: popcorn, organic expeller pressed palm oil, salt, natural butter flavor (organic sunflower oil).The popcorn bags stress "no added diacetyl, no added colors, no artificial flavors". The package has the verified non-GMO logo and certified gluten-free logo. The allergen statement says: "may contain trace amounts of peanuts and tree nuts".One package has three sealed 2.5oz bags. Each 2.5oz bag is 2.5 servings per the nutritional label. One serving has 150 calories with 10g fat (4.5g saturated, 0mg trans), 0mg cholesterol, 300mg sodium (13%), 13g carbs (3g fiber, 0g sugars), 2g protein and 2% iron. Many people will probably finish a popped bag when it's hot, so multiply that by 2.5. The nutritional text on the box is in small print. Nutritional info only on the outer package, not on the popcorn bags.

This is an alternative approach to the general use stylus for use with touchscreen devices. Instead of the usual cone-shaped head, this one has a ball-point rotating disc-shaped head. I found it to be slightly more accurate than generic styluses in some situations. This is a stand-alone device, you use it just like your finger - no software, no battery, no bluetooth, no buttons.However, this is not a replacement for a touchscreen with a digitizer and its dedicated pen. The Samsung S-Pen for the various Galaxy Note devices or the Microsoft Surface Pen are much much more effective at handwriting or anything else that requires more fine-tuned writing or pointing or drawing.It has a screw-on cap that protects the head when not in use. The cap also screws on the other end of the device (while in use), so you won't lose it. It has a built-in clip, which I guess has the added benefit of not using as much material :) I am not fond of clips in general.In use, the stylus is around 9.6cm without the cap attached, and around 11.2cm with the cap attached at the other end. With the cap attached over the pointing ("writing") head for storage, it is around 9.6cm long. In other words, the cap completely covers the pointing head, so it is safe to put in bags and briefcases without any additional protection. The added benefit of the screw-on cap is that you essentially have two sizes, 9.6cm or 11.2cm (assuming you won't lose the cap if it is not screwed on all the time).Unboxing: it comes in a nice looking compact pen inspired package than can be opened by slicing the sticker-dot at the bottom. The stylus holder inside is made of sturdy material, so you can use it as permanent storage or display. Initially it is taped in place, so it won't move around before you buy it. The product information is on the back of the packaging, there's no user guide.Four stars for the device, plus a bonus star because of its unusual design. With hundreds of similar-looking generic styluses, it is nice to see someone try to do something different.

This is a review from an absolute beginners perspective. I never used a laminator before. In the past, I took things to be laminated to copy and print places. I am often clumsy when it comes to arts and crafts without an undo button, so I was pleasantly surprised that everything worked right from the beginning. The pages got laminated perfectly, no bubbles, no issues, no problems.The device has to heat up before you can use it, I didn't time it but it took about 1-2 minutes at the 3 mil setting. It is basically ready before I am ready (get everything organized and arranged and clear space for the laminator). The device is warm to the touch when heated and in-use, but the surface the device sits on does not heat up. I give the laminator space on either end that is at least the length of the item to be laminated.The lamination process is straightforward, align the paper inside the pouch (I don't know why they call them pouches, they are essentially two thin slides glued together at the top), feed it to the heated laminator using the markings on the laminator while holding it straight and parallel to the desk, and watch it come out on the other side. The laminated item is warm initially but cools off quickly. There is a smell during lamination, which is not a surprise.The device has a power button (ON and OFF positions) on the back. I am mentioning this because some devices these days don't have physical on/off buttons.The box includes ten free 3-mil pouches packed separately and resealable on their own bag. They are not as thick/heavy as the ones I had laminated at copy and print centers (they may have used thicker pouches). The bag has a sticky part that is grabby, so pay attention when putting them back in.There are many uses for this, book maps, recipes, poems, prayers, music learning cheatsheets, and so forth. But perhaps my favorite use is as to-do lists and checklists and task/chore lists, using dry-erase markers to write on them. The writing is easy to erase with a dry-erase eraser or cloth.UNBOXING: It is easy to open with fingers, no tools needed. The outer packaging is the customary colorful Fellowes style you may have seen in their other products. You have a visual Quick Start Guide (pictures, no text). Then a two page written user guide in English and French and Spanish. This user guide is not tiny, it is 11.5 x 8 inches. You also get ten 9 x 11.5 inch Gloss 3 mil pouches sealed in their own pack. And of course the laminator, in a see-through bag with its edges protected by eggcrate type of material. Also included is an Exit tray (a wide square-shaped U). And a couple of other pieces of paper (warranty, etc).

This tea brewing pitcher exceeded my expectations. You can brew as little or as much tea as you want, tea leaves or tea bags or both at the same time. I found it more versatile than a dedicated infuser like this one FORLIFE Brew-in-Mug Extra-Fine Tea Infuser with Lid(which I like, but only fits over coffee cups).There are two main components to this. The unibody 55oz pitcher, and the cover. The cover has the lid on top, and screwing on at the bottom of the lid is a three concentric disc filter mechanism. The filter is in the middle layer. The bottom layer has the base that screws on to the lid. The top disc is what keeps the cover from falling when you pour tea. The three layers are easily removable and cleanable on their own, and so is the lid. Unless you have big hands, you can easily reach the bottom of the pitcher and clean it.This is not a coffee press, the filter mechanism does not move up or down, it is fixed in place when attached, that's why you can use this to make anywhere from a drop of tea up to 55oz of tea. The lid rotates in place, and if you align the little symbol on the lid with the pouring side of the pitcher, you get liquid pouring out faster. The filter is very good at keeping things inside, it was more effective than my stand-alone infuser using the same loose leaf teas.The instructions recommend loose leaf tea but you can also brew tea bags or infuse anything else you want. For tea bags, I remove the tag and cut off the string with scissors before putting them in (beware of tea bags with staples). You can brew with boiling water or you can cold brew. The pitcher is a good fit for refrigerators (it is 11.5 inches tall, from the top of the lid to the bottom of the pitcher, 4.5 inches in diameter, with the handle extending up to an extra two inches out).The pitcher handles boiling water without issue. If you keep the lid closed, it can keep the tea warm longer than a coffee cup. I didn't do a side by side test, but I think it's not as effective as a specialized insulated container, but it's still better than keeping the tea in a closed-lid cup.Since most loose leaf teas can be rebrewed multiple times, if you don't pour all the brewed tea to your cups or teapot, you have to decide how to handle the tea leaves in between brewings. Especially for teas that can get bitter with over-brewing. It's easier to pour the liquid out than take the tea leaves out and then put them back in for rebrewing. Since the pitcher gives you total brewing flexibility in terms of quantity, the easiest way to handle this is to brew only as much tea as you plan to put in cups once it finishes brewing. Once you drink it all, brew it again, pour, and repeat later once again. Or use tea filter bags. (With tea bags this is not an issue since you can easily fish out the tea bags with a spoon).For warmer months, if you like to drink a hot cup of tea early in the morning and iced the rest of the day, you can brew a lot of tea in the morning, pour as much hot tea as you like, and let the rest cool off, and then refrigerate it.As the picture shows, this is clear material, so you can see the tea brewing inside. This is especially nice if you are brewing various tea blends with different colors and formations. If I want to stir things up while brewing, I use a circular motion parallel to the ground (not up and down), sometimes with a slight angle.The instructions (four page square in English and French) are well done, easy to read, simple and to the point and use pictures. The only thing that is perhaps not explained in detail is how to reassemble the 3-part filter mechanism. In case that's confusing, here's the order: the steering wheel is at the bottom (with the screwing part point up), the mesh filter in the middle, and the barbed wire thing at the top. The instructions say before first use, hand wash everything with warm soapy water and let them dry up. The filter part is very easy to clean once you disassemble it (only takes 10-20 seconds).Unboxing: it arrives in a protective cardboard box, and the packaging material can be recycled. Simple and easy to open.

This is a lightweight over-the-door hook rack, with six individual non-removable hooks.The design is nice, metal and see-through non-metal material. The OXO holds on to doors and other surfaces as seen in the picture. It is around 20.5 inches long (X axis, parallel to the ground), while the gap between the two feet on top that hold on to doors is a bit less than 17 inches. In other words, you need a door or surface that is at least 20 inches long. If you are hanging really fluffy items (such as ties), you may be able to get away with slightly less, but it depends on the situation.Each hook has two metal parts going into its base. Each hook is about one inch wide, one inch tall, and half inch thick. The top of each hook is not flat, but rounded in the X-axis (like a thumb is rounded up top). The distance between each hook is about 2.75 inches. The two outer hooks (left and right) can be just slightly angled towards the outside, this brings the distance between it and the nearest hook just under 3 inches.I use it to hang various lightweight items, it is great for hats, whether it is small hats (baseball, beanies, etc) that go on the hook, or longer summer or garden hats that you can hang either way (by the string or the hat itself). It is good for belts too as long as the buckle is big enough to fit into the hook or the belt is thin enough you can hang it evenly balanced, sideways on the book. It can also fit over the shower curtain rod if you want to dry out small items (eg hats or ties). Another use of this I like is as an organizer of the various reusable grocery and shopping bags.I am not fond of using racks on doors that open and close often, and I don't like to hang towels in this fashion (because no matter what, they end up on the floor), so I can't speak to how well it does there.Unboxing: it arrives in a cardboard box as is, without any packaging, with the instructions (14 x 8.5 inch cardboard) attached to the actual rack with three twisty ties. The twisty ties are made of material that reminds of paper clips, I had to use scissors to cut them because they did not untie easily like most twisty ties do (they were twisted too many times).

I love Kind bars, they won me over because I can actually see real food ingredients in them instead of a semi uniform paste of various unpronounceable things that may have once been food. So I was very curious to read this book from the founder!The best way to describe this nearly 300 page book is this: Part Inspiration, Part Business, Part Biography. All three elements are interweaved in the book, often in the same paragraph or sentence, making it an interesting non-formulaic read. You can read as much or as little at a time, this is not like a novel or a textbook. It's like the author wrote a book-long rap song about his life and career. There's even some dissing, eg the "authentic purpose vs shallow cause marketing" segment.The book is personal in nature, we get a lot of glimpses of the life and philosophy and personality of the author. You (and I) may not agree with everything the author writes and that's fine, we are not a choir of sheeple after all.Along the way we learn more about Kind bars and the business of nutrition bars, but this is not a Kind bar textbook, so if you are strictly interested in reading about Kind bars and nothing else, this is not so.If you are a Debbie Downer type, you may find some of the inspirational content annoying, but fear not, the author also points out several of his failed ideas and plans and projects, repeatedly ("the number of mistakes I made ... would require another few books") and without sugar coating them. In conjunction with that, the author stresses the value of analyzing and learning from them while not turning the failures into a self-recrimination spiral. So it's not a rah-rah-rah let's all sing along and save the planet and solve every problem and make lots of money doing it book, but it can get syrupy and unicorny on occasion.Almost everyone who starts a business or a project has something to build upon (skills, funds, energy, resources, network, etc), some more than others, and in this case, on page #55, the author mentions that he borrowed $100K from his parents in the 90s. Not a small sum for certain and certainly many entrepreneurs may never have this option.There's an important lesson a lot of companies need to pay special attention to: "inconsistency in a brand is like introducing a virus in your brand system".My copy is full of sticky flags, which is a measurable signal of an interesting book. I rarely bother to use flags if I don't find a book interesting.This is very e-reader friendly, it is all text, with the exception of four charts towards the end that show Kind bar performance in the marketplace over time.

This is a POS (point of sale) tablet stand but it has many other uses in offices and homes. It is solidly built and well-made and heavy. You can optionally bolt it (mounting hardware included). If you don't bolt it, treat it like any other heavy item - don't place it near the edges of surfaces and pay attention to kids and pets. The device is ready to use out of the box. You only need tools/hardware/assembly if you want to bolt it to a surface.The height of the device is not adjustable, but the main surface rotates 360 degrees, it can go from perfectly flat to perfectly vertical. You can use it in portrait or landscape, with the angle of view adjusting from perfectly flat to perfectly vertical, in all directions of the horizon.This is very versatile. The tablets are held in place at the two opposing corners as seen in the picture. One corner is fixed (no adjustments). The other corner is adjustable, both in width of tablet and height of tablet. The adjustments are made independently to factor for tall and/or wide tablets. The adjustments stay in place until you change them again.The design minimizes blocking of ports on the device, since you can rotate both the tablet (with the software) and the device physically. Unless your tablet has ports on three or four of its corners. A close-up of the pictures should give you a good estimate.It fits modern tablets that are 7" and 8". It also fits the original 7" Kindle Fire (the one that shares the same shell as the Blackberry Playbook and is thicker than most of today's tablets). Modern 8" tablets fit as well, such as the Galaxy Note 8. I doubt any 9" tablets will fit, the Nook HD+ is simply too big to fit properly. If you have really old tablets (older than the original Kindle Fire), they may be too big, for example, I had a prehistoric 7" Pandigital with 4:3 aspect ratio (running Android 2.1 or something like that) and it is too big.The sturdiness is especially welcome if you are writing one-handed on a tablet with a stylus, especially a stylus/digitizer tablet like the Galaxy Note 8 and others with similar technology. For example, taking notes while talking on the phone.As far as ebook readers, the only one that fits properly is the Kindle with Keyboard. The other ereaders I tried are too short (Nook Simple Touch, Kindle Paperwhite, the simple Kindle with buttons) for a proper fit.If your tablets are in protective backs or cases or folios, it depends on how well they fit. In general, the bigger and fleshier the case, the lower the chances of a good fit. The grips are just under 5/8" deep, so you have flexibility there.Adventurous Users: if you are a higher risk user, and your device does not fit properly because either too big or too small, you can still use this by balancing the device in. You don't get a secure lock, so it is important to have it on a stable surface without kids/pets running around. You can balance it on one edge and use either dimension of the other edge, along with the angle of the device to have a balanced hold. I used this approach for devices as small as smartphones and the iPod Touch, and as large as 10-inch tablets. However, this is a high risk scenario, and not the intended use of this device. Consider it a bonus for adventurous users.UNBOXING: this is in a generic sturdy cardboard box (can be reused). Inside you will find the Instructions (two 8.5x11 sheets), filler material for packaging purposes, and of course the device covered in a see-through bag. The mounting hardware are in their one small resealable bag, taped to the bottom of the device. The mounting hardware consists of three nuts and three screws (both #8). In the bag you also find two keys if you want to lock the tablet in place (can be handy at home/office if you have guests/visitors/kids)

This is a budget coffee maker that makes one cup of coffee (8 to 14oz) at a time, using ground coffee, and comes with a permanent filter. It is best suited for occasional use, not as a daily workhorse. I bought this because occasionally I want to drink just a small cup of coffee and using a 10-cup coffee machine with a carafe and paper filters felt like overkill and wasteful.I've had it for about a month now, with occasional use and it works fine. However, this is a budget-made appliance, it's a couple of levels above "hanging by a thread" quality, so if you are a shopper who prefers solidly made appliances, this is definitely not the one for you.Upon first open, it has a distinct plasticky smell. I run it four times through with 14oz of water (that I threw away) before making coffee. I haven't found any information about BPA on the packaging, that's another reason why I think this is for occasional use.The water reservoir has markings for four different drink sizes, 8oz, 10oz, 12oz, and the maximum of 14oz (which is the maximum size the included white coffee mug can hold).This has a reusable coffee filter that is part of the coffee machine and it is removable for cleaning. The filter goes into its own little contraption. So no need for paper filters but you still have to clean the removable filter after each use.There is a red power button at the bottom left side of the device. You can see the button in the picture (which shows the button on the right side). I double-checked, the button on mine is on the left side. The button lights up when you power it on. The machine does not turn off on its own, but you can tell it's done when you hear it run out of water and the coffee stops dropping.There is no heating element at the bottom, so you have to drink the coffee when you make it or put it in a thermos or insulated coffee mug. The bottom is removable and cleanable, so any coffee that drops off can be easily cleaned. The coffee drops slowly, so you can quickly switch cups if you want to start drinking before it's done.You can use the included coffee mug or any other coffee mug that fits in terms of height and width on the base. Since the bottom is not heated, you don't have to worry about that. The tallest cup that fits well is about 5 inches. You may be able to partially squeeze in tall skinny cups (eg the $1 reusable Starbucks 16oz cup) but you have to make sure they don't fall over when they fill up. The base is about 5 inch wide and 4 inch deep, so some of the giant soup-like coffee mugs may not fit.Don't expect miracles in terms of coffee taste. Because of the nature of the filter, this is probably not a good idea for finer grinds. One of the reasons I got this was so I could finish all the ground coffee I currently have, so I did not experiment grinding the same coffee beans in different ways to figure out the best grind option.UNBOXING: everything inside the box is in an unsealed see-through plastic bag. Inside you will find the coffee machine with the cord twisty-tied, the user manual at the bottom, and the coffee mug sitting on the coffee machine (as in the picture), sealed in a seethrough bag with protective padding to keep it in place.

This is a great Dry Erase marker set with one caveat, the included eraser is good at cleaning recent writings, but if something's longer than a few hours, it's not as effective as other erasers (including another Quartet eraser from a different kit). This is a fluffy type of an eraser, it's a bad attempt to mimic the Expo eraser (which is heavier and more effective at cleaning, but still not as effective as the 3M 3M Whiteboard Eraser for Whiteboards, 2-Pack which is a lot more effective than it looks).Other than that, this is a great kit. The liquid board cleaner is very effective. I even used it on an old dry-erase board that hadn't been erased in many months (if not years), and the spray cleaned it up very nicely and easily. I prefer to use thick kitchen towels instead of a soft cloth, that way you just throw them away without having to worry how to wash away the chemicals of this liquid from a cloth. There are warnings on the bottle of the spray about eye contact and inhalation and being flammable and such, so be sure to read them, especially if you have sensitivities in those areas. The description says 2oz, however this is a 1.68oz bottle per the packaging and the writing on the bottle.The markers are great and they remain my favorite Fine Tip markers, winning over the Expo Fine Tip on multiple counts. The Quartet are physically slightly thicker, the writing tip is more rounded while the Expo is more pointed. The writing is also bolder and more satisfying with the Quartet. You get five markers, two black, one red, one blue, one green.Note: if you are not familiar with dry-erase markers, Fine Tip is thicker than it sounds. If you want truly Fine Tip (thinking along the terms of pen writing), the only one I found are the Expo Ultra Fine line, for example, Expo Low Odor Ultra Fine Dry Erase Markers, 4 Black MarkersThis Quartet set comes packaged as seen in the picture. It says Made In China on the back. You can open it and re-seal it by slowly peeling off the edges (eg use a letter opener). If opened gently, the packaging can serve as temporary or permanent storage.

This easy to read and digest book makes the case for cheap and fast experiments as a valuable tool for innovators. It consists of two intermingled virtual parts, making the case for the 5x5 approach, and explaining how to put it to use. I read a couple of business books per year, and at this level, I found it educational. A more subjective metric on the usefulness of the book, I have dozens and dozens of sticky flags on many pages (I rarely use flags on books I don't find interesting).The style and tone is less consultant-y that you often find in this genre. While the author uses many examples of research and quotes, he avoids the constant name dropping of current and former clients that other authors do (which can make their books feel like glorified resumes). The "Raising Keynes" segment is quite visceral, a cross between a grudge and a vendetta and (regardless of where you stand on those theories) it's refreshing to see unfiltered opinions instead of having to read between the lines to find veiled hints of strong disagreement.There are some quotable lines to ponder and even occasional jokes that spring at you unexpectedly (Powerpoint presentations, strategic investments, etc). I don't know if this is a coincidence or an intentional homage, but at one point the author goes in Stephen R. Donaldson mode and drops an "inchoate". If I also noticed "puissant" or "excoriation" or "chiaroscuro" I would be certain :)Many of the examples used in the book, including the real world 5x5 examples and the Blockbuster story and Apple's antiperspirant mouse were great and helpful in understanding the concepts. The only one that stood out as not very helpful was the "eat less and exercise more". It felt out of phase. The book ends with a bibliographic essay which is a lot more helpful (than a list of references) for someone trying to prioritize what other books to read on the subject.The target audience are bigger businesses, not mom and pop shops or sole proprietors, but some of experimentation ideas could be helpful in some instances (after all, it advocates low cost experimentation before jumping to big decisions or making big changes).This book is all text, except for one simple diagram, which makes it a great match for reading on an e-ink e-book reader.Spoiler Alert: there is nothing magical or mystical with all the numbers being 5s (5 people, 5 days, 5 experiments, 5 weeks, $5K).

These are nice as an occasional dessert. They are not a replacement for raw or dry roasted almonds and other nuts. They have enough sugar to only consider them as a dessert. But the kettle glaze gives them a different taste from raw almonds, so bonus points for variety. I like this raspberry-ish flavor, it wasn't quite raspberry (as in the fresh fruit), but it was a pleasant taste. Sometimes you may get hints of strawberry too, and looking at the ingredients list confirmed it, it has "strawberry powder". It was different enough from raw and roasted almonds to add variety. I finished this in two days when my plan was to finish them in seven days, so it has scoreboard.Another good use for them, if you create your own mixed nuts remixes, you can a small amount of these in the container or bowl for more variety and randomness.One resealable bag has 5oz. A serving is 1oz, which is 130 calories, 9g fat (0.5g saturated, 0g trans, 2g poly, 5g mono), 4g protein, 13g carbs (2g fiber, 10g sugar), 140mg sodium, 0mg cholesterol, and tiny amounts of calcium, iron and vitamin C. Raw almonds have more protein, more fiber, more fat, half the carbs (and just 1g sugar), and no sodium.The ingredients list is another reason why I consider them strictly a dessert: almonds, sugar, clarified red raspberry juice concentrate, strawberry powder, canola oil, natural flavors (including raspberry), salt, soy lecithin, citric acid. These are manufactured on shared equipment so it has a variety of allergen ingredients.

The 5oz bag is sealed at the top, you tear at the top to open the bag, and then seal it using the built-in resealable mechanism. For bags with tea leaves, I also use a kitchen clip and put them in a tin or ziplocked bag. Upon opening the bag, it does not have a fragrant aroma. It is a subdued tea-ish smell. It is English Breakfast after all, not a flowery tea. It is different from their Tattle Tea Earl Grey Black Tea, which, still, five months after opening, has a nice bergamot fragrance. As expected.The package does not have an actual list of ingredients. It says it's just tea leaves. I don't know why they are not using a standard ingredients list.The package recommends 1-2 teaspoons for 3-5 minutes at 195 degrees. I brewed at 3, 4, and 5 minutes with 8oz to 12oz. I found the 3 minutes a bit too weak. I found 4 minutes to be the bang for the buck in re-brewing for me when using the same tea leaves. The first two cups are pretty good, the third and fourth are definitely weakener. The fifth is more colored water than tea.The benefits of loose leaf tea were obvious when brewing this in parallel with English breakfast tea bags (Trader Joe) and drinking back and forth between them. To summarize, the Tattle tea leaves had a three dimensional taste while the tea bags were two dimensional. Of course there is a higher price on the tea leaves, so it's up to the individual to decide where to draw the line on pricing.I also experimented blending this with other teas. Brewing them separately, and then mixing them in a separate cup. The biggest surprise was the Celestial Sugar Plum Spice, which has a rather obnoxious flavor (especially after the Holidays are over), but mixed together created an interesting flavor. The other experiment that I liked was with Chamomile tea.This is a straightforward black tea, so it may be a good idea if you are trying to cut back on Colas or black coffee, and don't want to deal with caffeine withdrawl headaches.

Even though there are hundreds of TV dramas out there, there's not a lot of action in the alternate history genre. This alone makes this a promising TV show. Alternate history presents a blend of the known and the unknown. World history is as we know it before World War II, but in this universe, WW II has a different outcome, which means, we don't really know what happened since the 40s (except for what the TV show tells us). The show is in the alternate 60s, and while it has plenty of similarities to "our" 60s, there are some differences, extrapolations based on what had gone before.I haven't read the book, so I only know what the pilot episode showed. Minor spoilers on the pilot below...The pilot did a great job of world building, showing us digestable but memorable glimpses of the three main territories. The characters introduced were easy to identify and separate as individuals (something not always so in pilots). Even though none of the characters jumped out as a "star" or a larger than life character, they all felt organic to the story, as if we were looking at vignettes of their lives. A plus if you like serialized gray world stories. We got snapshots of plots and schemes in progress, teasers of potential outcomes, and more.Given the combination of the known and the unknown, this has a lot of potential to tell some very interesting and fairly unique stories to conventional TV, and present situations and dilemmas that challenge the viewer.

This is a self-contained digital scale. No apps, no bluetooth, no wifi. Just a scale. When you step on, it first measures your weight. If you remain on the scale, it will then calculate the rest of your data. The instructions say it sends a tiny electric pulse to measure the extra data, but I haven't felt it, it must be very tiny. If you don't want the extra data, simply step off after the weight measurement is finalized.The extra data are in this order: BMI (a number), Body Fat (a percentage), Water TBW (a percentage), Muscle Mass (a percentage), and Bone Mass (in pounds).The Setup process asks you for height, weight, gender, and whether you are an athlete in order to determine how to calculate things. During Setup, you only have a few seconds to make selections, so you need to be ready to quickly press the buttons (which are on the scale). It is not a very patient setup process.It supports up to eight different profiles. If the different people using it have different enough weights, the scale automatically sorts out who is who. If the weights are closer, it will ask you to select which profile you want to use each time.The profile data you enter manually at setup (weight, height, gender, athlete) is stored on the scale and it is used to calculate BMI and the rest of the biometric data. The actual measurements (your weight, your BMI, etc) are not stored on the device. If you want to save it, you have to do it on your own. Perhaps pen/paper or take a short video of the measurements using your phone/tablet - if you don't have photographic memory.The instructions (in five languages) do a poor job of clearly explaining the scale's display, while they use up space on other less important matters. The user guide has small fonts.Before this, I was using this basic digital scale for about three years Omega Ultra Slim Digital Bathroom Scale, 400 lb. Capacity, Sense-On Technology. The readings from the Smart Weigh are about 0.2 to 0.4 lbs higher, I am assuming within the margins of error of each device.It has a button on the underside that allows you to switch between pounds, stone, or kilos as the measurement unit. The silver part is stainless steel and it feels colder on the feet than a basic non-stainless steel scale.The scale takes button cell batteries (installed at the underside), so no go if you are a fan of using rechargeable AA or AAA batteries. The batteries are preinstalled but you have to remove the protective plastic strip that prevents the batteries from draining while it's waiting to be purchased.The device is packaged in a pizza type of a box, with the scale unsealed in a see-through bag along with the user manual.Overall, given the budget price, this does what it promises to do. The setup may be frustrating, but you only have to do it once per user.

The Peeled Snacks Apple Clusters are a different way to eat apples. They don't look like apples, they are rolled up in little (slightly smaller than) marble-size airy crunchy clusters. The crunch is audible and satisfying but I felt no risk to my dental fillings because there's plenty of air in-between and the clusters break with fairly little effort.The taste is of course an apple taste. If you inhale them you may not notice this, but if you eat them slowly, you may notice, especially towards the end of the chewing, a sweetness that you don't get from eating regular apples. I would put this akin to apple juice, which is explained by the ingredients as these have not just organic apples but also organic concentrated apple juice. So if you are looking for just apples without the extra sweetening, this may not be to your liking.The expiration date is written on the back in normal human readable form. On the one I received, the expiration was 6.5 months into the future. The packaging says "five apples inside". One serving (the 2.1oz package has four servings) is 60 calories with 14g carbs (2g fiber, 10g sugars). Zeroes in all the other categories (fat, protein, sodium, cholesterol). It has nearly neglible amounts of Vitamin C (2%) and Calcium (1%). Unless you have a lot of self-control or pre-split the servings, more realistically, this will be gone in two, not four sessions.Labels on various parts of the packaging include Gluten Free, non-GMO, USDA organic, and All Natural.Pros: a different way to eat apples, handy and portable package, organic, non-GMO, simple ingredients list, better health-wise than almost everything sold at the checkout counter or convenient storeCons: price and the apple juice concentrate. Real apples healthier and cheaper than this.

The set includes five measuring cups and a scraper that also serves as a hanger for the set when it is clasped together. The whole set, clasped together, empty of any contents, weighs 6 oz. The measurements are written in a color-coded fashion on the side of each cup, and they are also engraved on the handle, right before the cup begins.One of the benefits of having a marker at the halfway point of each cup is that it effectively offers you two new measurements, 1/6th cup (half of the 1/3) and 1/8th cup (half of the 1/4) that are not included in the set. Thanks to the halfway point, you can use one measuring cup instead of two in some situations, for example if you need to measure 1/4 and 1/2 or 1/8 and 1/4.The actual snapping mechanism at the top of the handles has the same size, so you can snap as few as two together or as many as all of them. Because they are nesting cups, you always have to snap them from smallest to largest, whether its two, three, four or five.Vs Dollar Store Measuring CupsI have a set of measuring cups from the dollar store, and here are the differences between them:+ Oxo more heavy duty, thicker, more sturdy+ Oxo numbers color-coded on the side+ Oxo snap together+ Oxo has halfway mark in each cup+ Oxo includes a hanger / scraper+ Dollar Store: lower pricePACKAGING: this is very simple, customary Oxo packaging, just the cups snapped all together, attached to a colorful Oxo packaging (that has the product description) held together by two twisty ties.

This is a versatile zippered sleeve for 7 inch tablets and ebook readers. It unzips only on two sides (top and right), and there are no straps inside, you just drop in your device inside and zip it up. The front face has a 3.5 x 5 inch mesh pocket with velcro to keep it closed. The mesh is semi seethrough, depending on how much light there is and how colorful the items you put inside. The zipper handle is a nice size (around 1.25") with five stars engraved in it. A loop handle on the left side (about two inches) gives you another way to carry it.DEVICES: An 8" Galaxy tablet was just too tall for the zipper to zip. A couple of 7" tablets fit, a Kindle Fire and an old thick Android 2.x tablet. All the ebook readers I tried fit in comfortably, including the Kindle with Keyboard and the Nook Simple Touch and Paperwhite. These without anything on the tablets and ereaders. If you have a regular case on your device, it will probably be too thick to fit inside. However, if you have a slim fitting case it may fit just fine, for example, the Paperwhite in this type of a case Moko Amazon Kindle Paperwhite Case - The Thinnest and Lightest Leather Cover for Amazon All-New Kindle Paperwhite (Both 2012 and 2013 versions with 6" Display and Built-in Light), BLACK fits very comfortably. Another data point: the Kindle with Keyboard inside its official Amazon case almost fits, so close, but it does not zip.And that's I think a great use for it. An extra level of protection for your ereader, in case of rain, sand, wind, and other situations. A case on its own won't necessarily protect from water or sand, but an extra bag can decidedly reduce risk. This is also handy if you put your cased ereader in a busy or active backpack or briefcase or handbag.HACKS: inside the sleeve, there is a little white loop, just like linen and clothing have that says "Made In China". If you have a thin stylus or pen, you may be able to squeeze it along with an ereader. I can do this with the Paperwhite in the slim case I mentioned above, but there's not enough room for a 7" tablet.UNBOXING: The sleeve is inside a closed see-through bag which is inside the packaging that says Acco Brands and Made In China. The sleeve is empty, no throwaway padding inside. Empty, the sleeve weighs 2.6 oz on its own. This is a not a paper-thin sleeve, but it's not the thickest either. If you need a sleeve to survive harsh environments, this is probably not it.

The flexibility of the gooseneck and the wide round base and the clip that can attach to various surfaces up to 3/4 inch thick make it a versatile all around light. More than 3/4 inches I feel would put too much stress on the spring mechanism (but I could be wrong). It is small enough to take with you, or use in a variety of situations, such as a bed light or a small emergency light or small closet light or car light or computer light and so forth.E-READERS: This is usable with ebook readers, however, if you are planning to use this as a dedicated ebook reader light, you are better off getting a specialized ereader light. The way the two light bulbs are set up, you can't get the whole page (even on a 6-inch reader) evenly lit. I tried different angles and approaches, none got it evenly lit. There is plenty of light to cover more than a 6 inch screen, but it's not evenly distributed. The other thing to note for ebook readers, the base of this requires about 1 inch of space to attach. Most ereaders don't have a 1-inch bezel, plus I don't feel comfortable having something put constant pressure on the actual device. So I recommend attaching this on the reader case (a lot more surface and flexibility) than the actual device.BOOKS: With Paperbacks (mass market or larger), you have to attach this to more than just the back cover. You have to grab a handful of pages, otherwise gravity will pull it down. Adjusting the angle and position of attachment can cover most of the reading area. With Hardcovers, the back or front cover is strong enough to hold it on its own. But for larger hardbacks, it's hard to get both pages illuminated.MAGAZINES: most magazines have soft covers, so it's the same issue as Paperbacks - you have to attach it to a handful of pages, or use one your hands to support it so it doesn't move or flop around. This can be useful if you are reading individual articles, but if you are flipping randomly through the magazine, this can be frustrating. Plus you have the issue of glossy magazine page reflections and such.NICE TRICK: if you flex the neck in certain ways and angles, you can have it sit on a desk like a tiny desk lamp, without actually attaching it to anything (it obviously falls very easily if not attached to something).POWER: This takes button cell batteries, so you can't use rechargeables. The benefit is that you have a smaller and lighter device versus one that takes AAA or AA batteries. But you can't use rechargeables. This is a general trade-off, not unique to this device.UNBOXING: the package is easy to open. The light is the only thing inside. The batteries are pre-installed. The power button is easy to turn on and off and you can't turn it on accidentally. The instructions are part of the packaging, so bonus points for not using additional material unnecessarily.

SUMMARY: comfortable earphones despite their oddball looks, they insist on staying on your ears, and are perhaps best suited for consumers who enjoy a variety of modern music genres. Include zippered case and five eargel sizes. Buttons work on iOS, but sadly a mixed bag on Android, and nothing works on Windows Phone.SOUND: I listened to a variety of modern musical genres with a variety of portable devices and laptops. I found nothing offensive or objectionable in the sound. I was able to get lost in the music multiple times (for example, Rush, Sade's voice, etc), a sign of musical enjoyment. To summarize their sound signature, I think these are tuned for the average music listener in mind, one who likes to listen to different styles of modern music (rock, R&B, alternative, indie, pop, hip hop). Probably not for dedicated shake-my-foundation bassheads, and perhaps not for audiophile sound purists. This is not to say they are light on bass, for example, there is plenty of it in Sade's Solider of Love album (some audiophiles may say it's a bit too much), but on the other hand, they don't turn Rush into a basshead experience.ISOLATION: If you can get a good seal, they do a pretty good job of blocking out a lot of the outside world noise. They do not leak much sound either. In a fairly quiet room, volume halfway on a Clip Plus, I can barely hear them if I hold them two feet away from my ear. The earphone head is solid, no openings other than the speaker part, which helps with the keeping noise out and your own music in.COMFORT: As earphones, they are very comfortable to wear. I did not experience any discomfort or frustrations that I sometimes do with earphones that go inside the ear. I am getting a nice seal, and they stay on my head and don't fall off. I haven't used them for exercise, but while sitting on a desk, or walking from place to place indoors and doing light household chores, they stay put. Their unusual shape is perhaps what gives them these ergonomic benefits. Having said all that, head shape and size, sensitivities and preferences vary from person to person.CABLE: The 4 foot non-removable cable is fairly silent and tangle free. The only time I notice cable sounds is if I intentionally play with it. It has a 90 degree angle, with three rings. I don't use huge cases. Of the combinations I used I did not have any issues with the cable not fitting into the port/case. The buttons and mic are on a rectangular mini protrusion on the left side, they start about 7 inches from the top of the earphone, so for many people, it will be below their chin. The buttons and mic protrusion on the left side is the easiest way to tell the left and right side.BUTTONS (iOS): this is a Made for Apple devices product, so the buttons worked as expected with multiple apps. Volume Up and Down (self explanatory). The middle button one click toggles play and pause. Two clicks in succession takes you to the next track. Three clicks in succession takes you to the previous track.  Some apps, especially audiobook and podcasts may have different default settings for the two click and three click, so check the Settings if it is not behaving as expected.BUTTONS (Android): a mixed bag. The Volume Up/Down did not work with any of the three Android devices I tried (Nexus Lollipop, Galaxy Kitkat, and Gingerbread). Play and Pause worked with every device and app combination I tried. The Next/Previous function varied depending on app and device. Next worked more often than not, while Previous was the other way round. Apps I used: default Android Music app, Google Play, Poweramp, n7, Winamp, Amazon Music, Media Monkey and a few more.BUTTONS (Windows Phone): Nothing worked with four different apps. Tried a Lumia phone running WP 8.1 and an Acer Switch detachable (both Desktop and Metro side).INCLUDED: the headphones, a zippered case (roughly 3.5 by 3.5 by 1.5 inches; has pockets on each side on the inside), four sets of eargels in a small bag inside the zippered case (plus another set  preinstalled on the headphones), 1/4" adapter, getting started guide in multiple languages (covers two models, M100 (this one) and M200), and tiny QC note with a date. The outside box they come in looks nice and presentable for gift giving purposes.
