The Strong Kind bars are a new, different kind of Kind bars. They are savory and spicy, a departure from the 20+ "conventional" Kind bars. If you are a regular Kind bar fan, you are in for a surprise. If you are looking for a similar taste, you may not like them. It took me at least three bars before I finally started getting down the taste signature of these bars. As with other Kind bars, you can actually see real food ingredients, full size almonds and pumpkin seeds. I give them as a group a 4.5, averaged up for being bold enough to try something different.There are five different flavors, but they share the same core ingredients, almonds, pumpkin and hemp seeds, honey, non-GMO glucose, and pea crisps. Different spice combinations and additional ingredients are what differentiate the taste. Variation on a theme is a good way to describe them. Each bar has a spice meter on the back of the wrapper, but personally, I found the spiciness to be in the same ballpark. All five have some level of stickiness, some a little bit more than others (perhaps depending on the temperature too).All five are 0% cholesterol, 0mg trans fat, 15g carbs (3g fiber, 6g sugars), 10g protein,and a variety of vitamins and minerals.ROASTED JALAPENO: 230 calories, 16g fat (1.5g saturated),  6% sodium (140mg) sodium. First ingredients in the list: almonds, pumpkin seeds, honey, non GMO glucose, pea crisps and more. It has a 4+ out of 6 on the Spice Meter. This is not as sticky as some of the others. It is my favorite of the group.HONEY MUSTARD: I like the honey mustard taste, and it is distinctive in this case, so this emerged as my #2 favorite. 230 calories, 16g fat (1.5g sat), 5% 115mg sodium. First ingredients are almonds, honey, pumpkin seeds. It has 4+ on the spice meter. The spiciness has a little bit of a delay factor before it kicks in.HICKORY SMOKED: this is my favorite smoked flavor. It has 230 calories, 16g fat (1.5g sat), 5% 125mg sodium. First ingredients are almonds, pumpkin seeds, honey, etc. It has 1 out of 6 on the Spice Meter, and in this case, my taste buds agree, this is probably the least spicy of the group.THAI SWEET CHILI: 230g calories, 16g fat (1.5g sat), 15g carbs (3g fiber, 6g sugars), 5% 125mg sodium. First ingredients: almonds, honey, nonGMO glucose, pumpkin seeds, etc. It is at the halfway point of the Spice Meter. As the name suggests, it has hints of thai flavor. Its spiciness is slightly different from the group, but still falls under the same umbrella.HONEY SMOKED: 230 cal, 16g fat (1.5g sat), 5% 120mg sodium. First ingredients: almonds, pumpkin seeds, honey, non-GMO glucose, pea crisps, etc. Not as sticky as some others. There are hints of smoked flavor but personally I prefer the Hickory for the smoked taste. Its spice meter is 2 out of 6, but to me, it tastes similar to others in terms of spiciness. This is perhaps a little bit more dry than the others. This is my least favorite of the group.

Initially I thought I had received a factory lemon. Then I read some of the newer reviews pointing out that the directions on the underbelly of the keyboard were directing you to put the batteries in the wrong direction. I never had this happen with a product before, so it didn't even cross my mind. Thanks to the folks who pointed this out! Once I put the batteries in the other way, it worked fine right away.But the keyboard issues do not end there. There is no power button on the keyboard. There is no power light, no caps lock light, no num lock light. Darkness. It has two legs underneath to adjust the typing angle. It may look like the keyboard might be a slave to the mouse, however, the keyboard still works after you turn off the mouse. The keyboard is also a bit too fleshy (for lack of a better word). It does have a row of multimedia buttons at the top.The mouse has a power button at the bottom, and a red light underneath while it is powered on. It has two buttons and a scroll wheel that also works as a middle button click. Overall, I like the feel and ergonomics of the mouse. Compact enough but comfortable and usable. You can store the USB dongle underneath the mouse, when you open the battery compartment, which has a plastic tab that lets you easily pull out the batteries (two AAA). The batteries sit at a 45 degree angle inside the mouse.There are two risk concerns on the mouse: the battery cover has a horizontal slit, so if you are using it at places with dirt or dust, they may end up getting inside. The other risk item, the way the battery compartment closes, it makes me feel like it may break (the thin part above the slit). But I haven't had an issue with either one after a few weeks.In addition to working with a Windows desktop computer, these worked with a Chromebook and a Windows 8 detachable tablet. I even attached the wireless dongle to a USB OTG cable attached to the micro-USB port of the tablet, and both the keyboard and mouse worked fine.For a budget combo set, I would give the Mouse 3.75 stars, and the Keyboard 2.25 stars. The battery instruction issue eats up another full star from the combined total.IN THE BOX: you get the keyboard and mouse in their own unsealed see-through bags. They have tape on them for extra protection from scratching. You also get two sets of two single use AAA batteries (total of 4 AAA), plus some paperwork (including a user guide).Vs Logitech MK270 combo: they go for a similar price range. I prefer the Logitech Keyboard (has its own power button) and the AmazonBasics mouse (better ergonomics). For a few days I actually used these two, I had the two USB dongles on a USB hub, so they didn't eat up precious USB ports.

This USB 2.0 microUSB to USB cable charged every device I tried, charging about ten different devices (smartphones of various OSes, external keyboard, external phone batteries) on a PC. The color is a mellow-yellow, not shiny-yellow as it looks in picture #1. Picture #3 is closer to its true color. The color is a great way to color code your charging cable drawer or box. In this case, yellow means you have a long microUSB to USB cable.The cable weighs 1.7 oz, and is around 71 inches (approximate measurement) - it is a 6ft cable. This is handy if you use this on a tower computer on the floor or want to cross distances. If you have a USB hub on your desk, this cable may be too long (depending on your setup).It arrives in a sealed white bag, with the usual suffocation warnings. It is easy to open, pull at the perforation to open. Inside you will find the cable held together by two twisty ties and a little piece of paper pointing you to the Amazon page for more details on the product. That's what's included.

I was hoping to keep this a short and concise review. This is the shortest I could do :)TOP HEAVY: as a laptop, this is top heavy, which is not a surprise, since the screen is also a fully-fledged tablet, while the keyboard is just a keyboard and nothing else. Not a big deal, but it's something to be mindful when holding or opening it if you are used to conventional laptops which feel more balanced even at the 11.6" screen size. Speaking of opening, this requires conscious effort to open. A plus if you have a problem with laptops opening on their own, a minus if you like to easily and single-handedly open laptops.DETACHING: the attaching and detaching is easy, no special skills needed. Just align it and the strong magnet grabs a hold of it. When attaching, be careful not to get your fingertips caught between the tablet and keyboard part. It is a strong magnet. Mine didn't get caught but if you are not paying attention, it may happen. Detaching is simple as well... Sometimes when detaching/attaching, an on-screen message appears telling you to eject the device using the System Tray before you physically remove it. However, there is nothing in the System Tray for ejecting the keyboard. Not sure why you would need to anyway, since the keyboard is just a keyboard. Maybe I'm missing something... The Display Mode here is a bit different, the keyboard does not rotate all the way or sideways. Instead, you put the tablet backwards on the keyboard, so the screen is facing you, and the keyboard is behind the screen. Useful for watching movies, slideshows, reading books, flipping through magazines, essentially it's a tablet on a stand.KEYBOARD: for a 10-inch keyboard, I was pleasantly surprised with A-Z (letters) and numbers touch-typing. The letters are a decent size and with good spacing for touch typing. However, a lot of the other keys are small to smaller. There's only one CTRL (left side). The Escape is really tiny. The arrow keys occupy a tiny rectangle area on the bottom right corner of the keyboard. It has very tiny Page Up and Page Down buttons that don't need FN. With FN, those two become Home and End... There are no lights of any kind on the keyboard, caps lock changes show on the screen only. The virtual keypad is pressing FN and a few letters/numbers on the middle-right side. You are better off attaching a USB numeric keypad if you have to do any serious data entry... There are no dedicated music play/pause buttons, however, if you press the FN plus mute or volume up/down keys on the keyboard, it brings up the playback app on the screen which has play/pause (depending on which music app you are using)... There's only so much one can squeeze on a 10" laptop keyboard... The keyboard does not have legs, however, I never felt the need to prop it up. The further back you push the screen, the higher the keyboard angle gets, so you have some flexibility there... On clean marble type surfaces, especially when the keyboard is brand new, it has a tendency to glide a little bit, so be mindful of that... X-Files: there is a magnetic area on the rightmost side of the palm rest of the keyboard (it decisively grabs paper clips) - rightmost edge, below the right arrow. Not sure why.OTG PARTY: the micro-USB port on the tablet side worked with an OTG (microUSB to USB) cable. I was able to attach (one at a time) a USB keyboard, USB mouse, wireless USB dongle (for wireless keyboards/mice). The wireless keyboard and mouse also worked on the keyboard's USB 2.0 port. This worked with two different mouse/keyboard combo sets (Logitech MK270 and AmazonBasics). You can have a keyboard and mouse party, with multiple sets of them connected and working at the same time :)... Speaking of connections, the instructions that come with it suggest that if you are going to connect external spinning hard disks, to power the hard disks on their own (not use  the Switch's USB power)TOUCHPAD: the touchpad is nice for a small keyboard, you get an area of roughly 9x5 cm. The two finger tap (mouse right click equivalent) is pretty handy. What is sorely missing is the three finger horizontal swipe to switch tabs within a browser (ChromeOS). You have options for adjustments in the settings.Micro-HDMI: using a random micro-HDMI to HDMI cable, I connected it to a TV/monitor. You have multiple options, extend the screen, duplicate the screen, or use the TV only (the tablet screen turns off). When you duplicate, you only get a smaller window on the TV (if your TV is more than 1280x800). When you extend or use the TV only options, it fills up the whole TV screen (1080p screen in my case). It is quick and easy to switch between duplicate, extend, TV-only, tablet-only.BUTTON PRESS ROW: the Power and Windows buttons are both on the same side (right side) and depending on how you are handling or storing the tablet or laptop, you can easily press either one of them accidentally. The headphone port is nearby as well, another opportunity for an accidental button press while adding/removing headphones. It may take a couple of weeks to get used to it. After about 3 weeks, I no longer press them accidentally. Initially I was frequently hitting either the Power or Windows buttons... By the way, the Volume Up/Down buttons on the tablet side increase/decrease the volume by 2% with each press.WATCHING VIDEOS: only some of the major video streaming apps are available in the Windows Store (I used Flixster, WatchESPN), however, you can switch to the Windows Desktop side for a lot more options. I streamed videos without issue from Amazon Instant Video and M-Go using Firefox with Silverlight, and also watched iTunes TV shows downloaded (if you don't have to have an iPad, a Windows 8 tablet is an affordable way to watch your iTunes movies/videos!)... Speaking of WatchESPN, I watched a couple of basketball games, and it was pretty good. Despite the small screen, I was able to easily read the player's jersey numbers and follow the action without issues or distractions. The screen was able to handle the fast paced action... The tablet has front speakers, facing you in laptop mode and tablet (landscape) mode. As with most small devices, there's only so loud they can get. In noisy situations, headphones or external speakers are probably needed...BLUETOOTH: I did not have any issues with the bluetooth devices I connected (headphones and mouse).CHARGING: while charging, the light is orange. When charging is complete, it turns to blue. The charging light is on the opposite side of the charging port, which can be confusing because the headphones port and charging port are similar in size (but if you look closely, there is a marking on the charging port). Charging happens through the charging port using the included AC adapter. It is a compact adapter. Vertically, it only takes one spot on the wall (use top or bottom if you have more than two). The only removable part of the AC adapter is the charging head (only one is included for North America). It does not appear to charge via USB. I never saw a charging light when connected to a PC.INSTALLATION/SETUP: fill up the coffee machine. It took me about two hours wall time to get all the updates and upgrades through Windows Update. Lots of reboots. Lots of them! You don't have to stare at the screen for those two hours straight, but you need to glance at it every few minutes. You can use a local account or Microsoft account. You need a Microsoft account in order to get a free app from the Windows Store. You only need to add a credit card if you want to buy a premium app... Boot to Desktop is one of the options in the handy Acer Shortcut app that lives in the system tray and task bar... There are plenty of customizations and adjustments to make, if you jump into the various settings and options on the Metro and Desktop side.CASES: I haven't looked for a custom case for this, since I mostly use it as a laptop when I am on the go, and whatever worked for other laptops, works for this too. Of the universal tablet cases I tried for the tablet-only, this tablet was a bit too long for them.OFFICE 365: you get a one year subscription to Office 365. You don't get the Office software to own forever. A product key is included in the packaging that activates your subscription. It is "Office 365 Personal for Windows 8.1 with Bing for Small Tablets". It says you must redeem by 12/31/16.BLOATWARE: McAfee is the most annoying. You get a 30 day trial. It comes activate. Site Advisor is also installed. It is a two step uninstall. First uninstall as usual from Control Panel, then download (!) an uninstaller program from McAfee to completely get rid of it. Windows includes its own security software (Defender and Firewall), so it takes over within seconds after you get rid of McAfee.MEASUREMENTS: out of the box, the 64GB version has 46.8GB available... The processor is the Intel Z3735F 1.33 GHz (the last time I looked there were two different processor mentioned in the description)... It is 32-bit Windows 8.1 with Bing... Tablet weighs 1 lb 3.8 oz on its own. Keyboard weighs 1 lb 2.2 oz on its own. As a laptop, it weighs 2 lbs 6.1 oz. The AC adapter weighs 3.4 oz... Made in China says the included paperwork.DESKTOP SIDE SAVES THE DAY: as of review time, the Windows Store still has a big gap in the popular apps versus iOS/Android. Not just the number of apps but the features as well. For example, Evernote Touch and Kindle (no zoom!) are subpar on the Windows Store side vs their iOS/Android versions. What saves the day for those, and many others, is that you can simply switch to the Desktop, and either use the Windows Desktop app or use the Browser for the web interface. A 10-inch screen, and a nice one at that, is quite usable for many of the non-complicated Windows Desktop apps. Case in point, I prefer the Evernote and Kindle desktop apps over their Windows Store versions... Not all Windows Store apps are subpar. For example, the Amazon shopping app scrolls sideways at a blazing speed, and the WatchESPN app is pretty smooth...Vs CHROMEBOOKS: Chromebooks finally have competition. The SSD makes a noticeable difference in the usability of Windows versus Windows laptops with slow spinning hard disks. I end up using this more often than the Chromebook, which was not the case with my previous hard disk based Windows laptop. Of course you still have the usual Windows issues and annoyances and quirks and irritations, but you have more flexibility, for example you can install as many browsers as you want (an easy way for multiple people in the same household to keep their stuff separate without having to log-in and log-out all the time). Chromebooks now have Multi-SignIn which is an improvement, but not as flexible as separate browsers.AVID READER TIP: arrange the tablet in Display Mode (tablet in front of the keyboard), attach a USB mouse, sit back on your chair, and use the scroll wheel of the mouse to change pages in the Kindle reader app. Lean Back Reading!

The soap is gentle and soft. If you are familiar with the white Dove bar soap, it is quite similar in feel, smell and texture. If you spent a whole day rolling in the dirt, bar soap is more effective but other than that, it's all good. The practicality of the pump makes this more user-friendly, especially for anyone switching from bar soaps.The pump is touch sensitive, the softer you press it, the less you get. So the savings can add up over time depending on your showering technique and style and preferences. You can use the pump with your thumb pressing down and your palm collecting the soap, or if you are taking a bath, and you have to pump soap from a different/unusual angle, you can press with the fingers and collect the soap alongside your thumb.The container is reusable, when it runs out, you can open it and refill it with any soap you like or repurpose it. You just screw/unscrew it. The whole blue pump comes off naturally.One word of caution: this is, to borrow a Vitalism, a space-eater container. It has 34oz of soap plus the weight of the container and with a low center of gravity. You don't want this dropping on your toes, so if you are going to put it anywhere above knee level, make sure it is secured!

This is a simple, unibody, single color fruit bowl. The fruit bowl weighs 15.3oz on its own (empty). It has 11 inches diameter at the opening at the top. It is around 4.5 inches tall. The bowl sits flat on a surface using three glued-on ball-shaped legs. The distance from the center of the bowl at the bottom to each ball-leg is around 3 inches. The distance from leg to leg (triangle) is around 5 inches.I randomly put items in, up to the rim. The following items fit: five bananas, four medium to large apples, one lemon, one avocado, two small plums. You can obviously stack more items above the rim, and if you organize them, you can squeeze in some more.A tiny piece of paint (under 0.5cm) fell off while unboxing it. I don't know if this was an isolated incident or a shape of things to come.There is no assembly required. You get the fruit bowl in a see-through plastic bag which you can repurpose for other reasons (eg put recyclables in before taking them out for recycling). Nothing else is included.

The first ingredient in the list for the Oatmeal Chocolate Chip flavor (I haven't tried any of the others) are dates. So this sets the expectations in terms of sugar content. A typical date is around 55-65 calories, mostly sugar. The dates are prominent here, both in taste and in appearance. Initially (before I read the label) I thought the brown parts of the bar (intermixed with the oatmeal color) were from the chocolate, but it's mostly from the dates. Dates are a natural food but they are naturally very sugary.Overall, I liked the taste, but some may find it a bit too date-intense. One experiment I tried to tame the date taste succeeded: I dusted the bar with unsweetened cocoa powder (tumaco, the Trader Joe kind). It managed to mellow it down. The side effect of course is that there's cocoa powder everywhere, so that can get messy if you are at work or on the go or at school. This experiment may perhaps suggest that a dark chocolate version may taste better! I would rate it around 3.75 out of 5, but since ratings are whole numbers, it gets rounded up to 4.The packaging promotes that the bar has only ten ingredients, but unlike some of the Kind bars that have only natural foods, you still find some of the processed food favorites: the list, per the box: dates, soy protein isolate, invert evaporated cane syrup, rolled oats, chocolate chips (ev. cane syrup, unsweetened chocolate, cocoa butter), high olec safflower oil, whey protein isolate and of course natural flavors. So while they get credit for limiting the crapola, they are not exactly eliminating them.The "Use By" date is written on the side in human readable form which a plus (eg 1JUL2015). The box says these are "Gluten Free" but has the usual allergen warnings: contains soy and milk - manufactured in a facility that processes peanuts, tree nuts, egg and wheat ingredients.The standout nutritional elements are 10g of protein and only 4% sodium (105mg) per bar and 0mg cholesterol and 0mg trans fat. The rest of the numbers: 170 calories, 5g fat (2g saturated), 23g carbs (2g fiber, 17g sugars), and single figure percentages in potassium, iron and calcium. The nutritional information is both on the box and on the individual wrappers.They arrive in a relatively short box (5.75 x 10 x 2 inches) that is not sturdy enough to be reused. It has a perforated tear-up part so that you can easily open and reclose it.Versus Pure Bar Organic Chocolate Brownie Bar=============================================The above Pure Bar is currently one of my favorites (half dessert, half nutrition), so here's a quick comparison:* Pure tastes better* Pure has 0% statistical sodium (5mg)* ZonePerfect has more protein and less fat* Pure has more fiber but also 20 more calories* ZonePerfect has 3g of carbs less* Pure has organic ingredients* Pure has more natural ingredients: dates, agave nectar, brown rice protein, cashew butter, almonds, walnuts, cocoa

This is a great option if you prefer an athletic, tapered cut rather than the more conventional 514, but are not lanky  enough for the really slim 511s. The sizing is more regular Levi's sizing than the 'slim' sizing effective in 511s and previous narrow models.I have switched from 31wx32l 514 to 31wx32l 513 and while it still fits easily, it looks better and more modern.The color in the attached photos is "Jet" , the material is more suited for biking etc, but still looks and feels like a jean (i.e. not spandexy) I'm 5'11'' , around 190 lbs, mostly athletic with  really thick thighs and  rump (for a non-overweight person) and a slight tummy.I'm ordering another pair for good measure.

This was gifted to me and while initially I didn't see the point in  a mouse without extra buttons / gestures etc, I stand corrected.I use it with a Windows 10 computer with 22 inch screen, so lack of horizontal scrolling doesn't affect me.The touch scrolling is more precise and easier than wheeled mice I tried over years (I usually stuck with Logitech). The clicking sound that the mouse generates in response to your scrolling speed is also way more enjoyable than I'd expect, makes one do unnecessary scrolls at times, even.I've had zero connectivity problems since I purchased it a month ago (tried getting up to 6-7 feet away without problems).It does work quite satisfactorily on computer chair arm supports, clothing, desk (both a solid wood one and one covered with glass) etc.

Bought upon a gourmet friend's recommendation, and while I had a hard time seeing the point in getting a bulky hardcover cookbook (as I use various online recipe services, Allrecipes et al) , but after cooking some of the special recipes that I've never seen elsewhere (like Mousakka  la Grecque) , I couldn't be happier.They managed to fit 2-3 recipes on every page with clear, easy to follow instructions, and none of them are 'fillers'. It is worth it for the salad section (one of the most modest ones, btw) alone.Also, even though not marketed as such, it is vegetarian and vegan-friendly , with a decent amount of such recipes scattered in between.

Folds into a very small bunch for storing in your bikebag. Significantly reduces chilling caused by winds without making you sticky. Very good air circulation. The fit is also quite nice, tapered toward the waist and athletic looking, but not too revealing. Dries easily as expected

Provides enough (minimal) cushioning and doesn't get in the way. I wear men's size 8,5 and the fit is ideal.Doesn't cause any odor problems after long >40 mile rides.These are thin, minimal socks and for their class they're more durable than average, but they don't compare with the bulkier Asics socks.

Used for 15-20 hours total without a change of battery.*Comes with a spare holder, which can also be used to hold most small led flashlights should you lose/damage the original.*the red rearlight still does the infamous 'turn off by itself' that rear lights designed like that always do, but way less often than other similarly priced products I bought in the last year (quite a few).*The power of the front light doesn't compare to >30$ ones but it's still enough to make yourself visible and avoid the shards while riding on dark streets.*The batteries are included (3xAAA for the front, and the round one for the back

I bought two sets\ and I  suspect I received a different item than those sent to authors of negative reviews, the ones I received in Spring 2015 are thicker than average, ideally long (so that the end of the pillow does not bulge out\ as it often does with cheap cases)\ and they've washed at least a dozen times so far without any visible damage.

These are the same quality as a gazillion adidas / asics / puma etc. sweatbands I have\ but they cover half my forearm (I'm 5'11), so that I don't need to wear several sweatbands to make sure they last.

This case seems to me to be a hybrid between 'minimal' keyboard/cases produced most famously by logitech, and more protective cases that rarely feature a keyboard. Below are some bullet points and my comments. I also included photos next to an Iphone 6 to convey the dimensions, and a few in different angles.CONNECTIVITY/BATTERY USAGE (5/5): Had no problems since my purchase, only had to charge it with the micro usb cable once in over 3 months. My experience was identical to that with Logitech cases.PROTECTION & DURABILITY (4/5): I ended up testing the protective capabilities of the case, unwittingly, a few times (mostly 3-4 feet drops). The Ipad did not get detached, nor show any signs of damage. Even better, neither did the cage. While the moving joint part (grey) looks iffy at first, it was made to carry the ipad's weight many times, and still works as it did the first day.ERGONOMICS (4/5): By bluetooth keyboard standards, the keyboard is comfortable and painless. The key alignments are standard, no bad surprises there. The keys are just deep and clicky enough, though slightly hollow (then again, all bluetooth keyboards I tried feel that way). The case could ideally be designed to allow a wider spectrum of angles, but as is, it provides gradations between 90 and ~135 degrees.DESIGN (3/5) : Two issues holding me back from giving 5 stars are the bulk and the design/materials. While the extra bulk is inevitable for the added protection, the materials and design give a (probably unintended) 90s retro vibe by looking more like old pc-towers than a sleek apple accessory. .CONCLUSION: If you're looking for both protection and a headache-free bluetooth keyboard in one package, I can recommend this case without qualms. Unless you need  water or kid resistance, this case should offer enough protection for most use cases, at the expense of a bit of added bulk.DISCLOSURE: I was provided a free item for my honest review by New Trent.

*Great moisture wicking, as tested on >20k bike rides. Definitely matches comparable UA shirts I have.*It has that slightly elasticky engineered-polyester but it's not shinier than it looks in the photos.*On one arm it has an obnoxiously big "Calvin Klein". I hemmed and stitched that arm by an inch to block that.

*You can definitely feel the little amount of polyester in hot NY nights, compared to all cotton Penguin t-shirts. I assume it's not engineered (moisture-wicking etc.) polyester.*This T has a slightly tapered form (advertised as 'easy shoulder, relaxed at the waist). Overall, it's slightly more loose/casual looking than a regular Penguin. The waist is slightly roomier than the chest area. I know it sounds like a bad idea but it's subtle and works. No, it doesn't make you look pear-shaped.*The sizing is as expected.

I have huge thighs even though I'm not overweight (size 32-33), and NY summers always cause a lot of pain and suffering in my thigh area.ExOfficio doesn't solve that altogether, but goes way beyond other brands/models I tried.Chafing/slipping/itching is noticeably reduced with these/I haven't noticed any difference in drying time between these ExOfficios and other engineered nylon underwear (UA, Adidas and Champion), but without a doubt they're the most comfortable piece of underwear I owned (second and third would be UAs 2012-2013 model compression boxers which don't seem to be available anymore, and  CK's One boxer-briefs).I bought 2 more immediately after giving these a try, and have worn ExOfficios 90% of the time since then (excluding laundry-emergencies).

Minimizes sweat/odor problems and discomfort during long runs and rides, certainly recommended for sports or casual wear. My sets have been washed a good  40 times each since my purchase months ago and they show no significant sign of wear.

These are not the common, ubiquitous RAW papers that are wide and relatively thick.These are the smallest (Zig-Zag standard size) and almost transparently thin models, but I actually prefer smoking less paper, and the glue works just as good as (maybe even better than) regular RAWS.The 300-paper drawerlike thingie (5 of which you receive) is not optimal for carrying papers or getting a single one out, so I usually get a bunch and carry them in my wallet's pockets.I bought 1500 papers for  under 20$ and never had to thrash a single one for defects, so certainly a good deal.

We ordered this product using Prime Now, and we'll certainly be keeping it in stock from now on.The situations:1) Cat Litter: Greatly reduces bad smell, with minimal (almost no) clumping. Works significantly better than spraying Lysol in our experience after about a week2) Smoke odor: We occasionally let guests smoke in the room\ this product takes away the cigarette smell (that lingers after a good airing)\, better than Lysol, Febreze etc.3) Bath tube liners etc: Minimize that damp smell better than anything else, and by now we tried most products on market4) Cooking smells: Works great for reducing that burnt smell after heavy  microwave sessions. A few sprays into the microwave( right after an overheated cake was removed ) dramatically reduced the unpleasant smell.I'm certain that in time we'll find more uses for this. Def. recommended.

Been using this extensively with*Ipad mini retina (the photographed one)*Ipad 2 & Air*Kindle (7th and 4th generations, basic model),It can be used horizontally or vertically, and even though I was worried about loosening in time, it still holds everything securely. The hands are ideally small and don't scratch the screen.It's easy to make small angle adjustments without taking it off the device (by sliding the hands up and down the device's sides)

I love how this screen protector minimizes glare, it has a very matte look even after hours of use. I've never had this little glare with my tablets before. You do get the usual amount of bubbles, that is, minimal if you follow the instructions (I doubt that this varies brand to brand). Very detailed instructions.

Pair this with the crisp ryebreads on Amazon (I like Ryvita Multigrain best), and you have an insanely yummy snack that is also high on fiber and proteins.I have a very hard time consuming these in moderation (and I usually can stop when it's just dark chocolate or PB). They're always fresh to make matters worse.

Let me see if I can express this intelligibly: The upmost letter row is not misaligned, strictly speaking, but the absence of the 'tab' key before the Q makes it feel so, and if you're used to typing on a computer like I am, owing to the way you naturally place your left hand on the keyboard, your left hand will hit the key next to the one you were aiming for (R instead of E, T instead of R, etc.) on that entire row, whenever you're typing without looking, which I'd imagine would be quite often if you're a seasoned typer like me.Since I switch back and forth between a MacBook and this, every time I switch I need to get used to not relying on the natural alignment of my left hand  all over again. As a result, instead of typing faster compared to the onscreen keyboard, I end up typing slower.It's a pity since I've used the Logitech (full-size) ultra-thin Ipad keyboard for years with great joy, and expected this to be close, if not identical, to its bigger brother in typing comfort. I'm also quite comfortable on the generic Bluetooth keyboards.I should note, to be fair, that everything else about the keyboard seems to be quite optimal.Even after giving up on  this, I'll still be using Logitech products on my desktop and for the (fullsize) Ipad. I'd have never imagined being let down by a Logitech product after this many years.Oh well.

I've tried all the usual suspects, especially their  Sin Palo (without stem) lines over years, including Rosamonte, yes, and decided that Taragui is my favorite for its smooth yet strong flavor (Admittedly, it's a close and possibly personal call with so many good Mate brands).  I'd def recommend this to both mate newbies (since it's quite drinkable despite the boldness) and seasoned drinkers.I brew either in a conventional gourd, or (when I need mate in bulk to take outside)  in an AeroPress, concentrated, and then add water.
Typical supermarket loofah (though not a crappy one) attached to a stick. Does its job, not a disappointment.
Not as good as, say, Stumptown, but def. palatable coffee, and arrived quite fresh both times I ordered.With the attractive pricing, I'll be buying again.

Overall good product IF you apply it with added glue.Def. durable enough (4 months of daily use, no visible damage other than (inevitable) surface stains)The glue on the tape is not enough to hold it in place, but I'm not giving lowering any stars since all bar tapes I've used have this problem.(I assume it's because the application would be very unforgiving and/or sticky if they were to apply adequate glue).Lastly, I'm an oversweater  and the feel is ideal, haven't had any problems even during 3-hour July rides.

Quite comfortable, esp. if you use an insole for extra arch support (I have medium-low arches and use the Scholl sports insole).The feel of these are very similar to wider Camper shoes, which is pretty  much my ideal of comfort.I wear these mostly for biking, and they provide some appreciated extra traction when pedaling.A few months in they're holding well, for suede shoes, then again they haven't been subjected to heavy rain etc yet

SAFETY: While using a bottom-zippered laptop compartment is alarming at first, I've spent a lot of time with my Macbook Air 11.8" (an early version weighing ~2.4 pounds) inside this bag, both on foot and on the bike, and haven't seen the zipper move so much as half an inch during these trips. Can't  speak for significantly heavier laptops, but with mine I definitely feel safe using this bag. It's also water resistant, which I had occasion to test during a few drizzles, no complaints.FUNCTIONALITY: For a bag this size, it's hard to imagine more functional pockets fitted into this form. Keep in mind that the front compartment is almost full if the grid-it inside is stocked with items, but you can still slide in an ipad and a medium paperback behind the grid it. (Alternatively, you can slide an ipad or two next to the laptop). There is another pocket, with even  smaller pockets inside, behind  the front one, which is pretty narrow but perfect for less frequently accessed items A4 folders, change etc, and than there is the open back pocketBIKING: Since the bag is made up of two separate compartments (the one that holds the laptop, and the front part), held together by a clasp, you can put it on the bike so that the bar is between the compartments, and clasp it on the bottom for safety.I've ridden well over 200 miles in that configuration, and if anything I trust the bag more with each trip.

This saddle was certainly wider and firmer than I expected, but after hours of comfortable riding I have no complaints.The part securing the saddle to the post is somewhat harder to tighten than separately sold saddle-to-post fasteners, but not inconveniently so (I'm using it with the Redline Laid Back Seatpost 25.4mm x 16" , bought also on Amazon).The suspension mechanism is firm as well, but ideally so for the city roads.Shape of the saddle is quite ideal/ergonomic, thankfully, it's not one of those saddles that give you unsolicited prostate massages over long rides.If you're on the skinnier end of the spectrum, you may be more comfortable buying a saddle-cover as well, for the extra padding.The only thing I dislike about this saddle is the large "The Executive" text on its back resembling a tasteless bumper sticker.Overall a good value.

Used  3 times so far, with single speed bikes. It was easy enough to use (though I still needed a 2nd person's assistance). With a multi-speed bike, I'm sure it'd be even easier to use, and can be employed by 1 person.Almost all parts are removable, which makes the cleaning process quite easy.It's all plastic, but tough, ABS-ish plastic. Certainly didn't look like  it was about to get break at any point.The wheels/brushes are located very close to the bottom of the container, which minimizes the degreaser consumption. BTW. instead of overpriced, bike-specific degreasers, I'd strongly recommend Zep Citrus degreaser (available on Amazon for ~3$) for use with this product. I've read about it in bike forums, and indeed it's every bit as effective as the expensive alternatives I used in the past.For chain-cleaning, instead of choosing between the traditional approach (with rags and brushes) and cleaner-machines, I prefer to do a  combination of the two. These cleaners are quite handy to get 95% of the job done, but occasional speckles of grime/grease located in weird angles invariably escape the mechanism, thankfully those are easy to spot and attack directly with a brush/rag.
I handwash this  with a small amount of detergent after use, and after 3 months of heavy use, it looks as good as new. Saves a lot of time, I certainly don't miss cleaning the microwave every week.

These are still delicious cakes, and arrive very fresh and wet. However, the rum flavor is overpowering in my opinion. Coffee and chocolate flavors (haven't tried the coconut yet) offer a more balanced and interesting combination of flavors.

These are as strong as the next neodymium magnet, no complaints there, but they're too small to be practical with metal collar stays. Try something with at least twice the diameter, or better yet 1/2' ones. Still easily a 4 star product since there's no discrepancy in the description.

WARNING: These buds never fall below ~20$ on this side of the ocean, so be wary of super-low pricing, there are many fakes around.EDITED REVIEW :Upon extended (>60 hrs) listening, these sound way better than the average of their  price range, and are by far the best <50$ earbuds I tried. (And I go through several every year, owing to common running/ workout accidents.High, mid and lows are balanced and natural, with no ugly bass boost that cheap buds are infamous for. You can read a detailed write-up on Innerfidelity.com , an independent audio equipment testing and review site I've trusted for years. I still prefer (twice as expensive) Etymotic Research MC5, to give an example, but these Xiaomis definitely provide better sound than say,better known and more expensive Klipsch S4i set I had,The build quality, also, is surprisingly good for the price.CONTROLS: Only the play/pause button works for Iphone (which is clearly stated, no complaints here). However, the button is so small and hard to locate w/o looking at it. Even with practice, I rarely find the button in <5 seconds while walking. It is by far  the worst earbud control design I've tried.Overall, these are a great option for the price. I've lost my last Xiaomis, and I'm ordering another set right now, instead of buying 50-100$ buds as I used to do .

I don't own the author's better known H. Picking book, started directly with this one, and I'm very glad I did. The short intro includes everything needed to begin hybrid picking.  Following that, instead of tedious exercises, the book is filled with very imaginative lines, usually 2 to 8 bars,  that'd go well in various genres/idioms. For each line, short but adequate information is provided, together with an extensive list of chords it could be played over (wherever applicable).

This is still more hair-gelly than other texturizing products I've used (Jonathan Dirt & Sebastian) but gives more control. Equally long-lasting hold. More sheen, but not terribly so.If you want the 100% natural unwashed-hair look  I'd recommend the products above, this surf head falls somewhere in btw those and regular hair gels
Doesn't fit perfectly like the original, and does causes sparkles  each time it's plugged/deplugged.Haven't caused any harm to my MBA yet, but i was expecting better quality.

A bike mechanic friend suggested I order this instead of products marketed specifically as bike degreasers.I had an unusually messy chain before application (dirt + overapplied grease, dust etc)After spraying this, waiting a minute and rubbing the chain a few rounds with rags, the chain was all clean and ready to be greased.It works well with oven tops too, as I've come to find out.
Fits as expected. Slightly less bulky than regular (non-hip) CK briefs, yet not inferior in quality.
I don't take Pepto everyday, but on a bad day I take ~8 tablets on a single day. These are every bit as effective as the original brand, with a less prominent taste at that.

More convenient than Brita pitchers-Has a cover that fully encloses the top, and protects against- 11.5 in (height) to 7.5  in (diameter of the widest part, the top).-One bottle is filled at a time, when full, it switches to the next bottle.-As such, you can fill as many bottles as you want (1-4) at once.-It's easy to vacuum the bottles to the nozzles, you just press firmly, no awkward rotations.-Filtering speed is not particularly higher than Brita filters, it still takes 1-2 min to fill 4 bottles-Filtered water tastes slightly softer and better to me compared to Brita.-Bottles are dishwasher safe hard plastic, with decent twist-lids that don't leak when upside down. No plasticky smell.-Unit itself is easy to wash by hand (significantly easier than a Brita pitcher IMO, since everything is out in the open).

Perfect, gives you all the extra traction you need.They fit snugly over the temples;  they can be adjusted up and down the temple by hand (with glasses on), but once you stop adjusting them, they don't slip (because the holes are tight and are stretched by the temples). I like that they feel very flexible, yet provide minimum give once on. They're also very comfy, even after all-day wear.Using one pair with XL Rayban Aviators (because they'd slip down my nose during long runs),the other pair with prescription glasses (one of the hinges are damaged and loose, reducing traction).Wouldn't imagine getting so much utility out of such an inexpensive product. But with both glasses, I got all the extra traction I need.
Not as good as original Spibelts (not as elastic, and the zippers are significantly less sturdy and look cheap ). But haven't had a problem so far, and can't complain for the price

TASTE: Okay. Tasted more flavorful brands, but acceptable.APPLICATION: It's true that this is finely ground. However, being careful and keeping the container close to the plate/pan , you can apply it in your desired amount without any mess.

My wife bought this for me, here on Amazon. This product does a decent job at texturizing. Unfortunately, after an hour of (slow) daily biking, my hair returns to its pre-product state. Can't risk using the rest, since when I do grooming, I intend it to last longer.Was happy to find a cheap replacement for Paul Mitchell, Jonathan, Sebastian etc, products I regularly use, sad to see it fall short.
Perfect slim fit, ideal length and cut.I wear ~16.5 with shirts, am 5'11 and athletic and medium fits perfectly.

I mostly use these as a pasta-sauce alternative by adding some spice(w/o cooking).  It's usually hard to get the tomato taste from canned products, and Muir Glen surprised me with the  quite natural and yummy flavor, without any additives at that. I've changed my subscription to once a month right after tasting, and intend to keep it. I certainly taste more tomato than I used to with sauces like Ragu.

After 2 months of regular, suggested use, I've seen no positive effects on my minor depression, or my ADHD. Then again, the efficacy of supplements can vary greatly from user to user, so if you're fine with the lack of rigorous scientific research demonstrating the benefits of DMAE on such conditions, you may wanna give DMAE a try, as it is pretty innocuous even when there are no benefits.

To quote my shrink's two warnings:1 ) Def. to be taken on an empty stomach, and no eating an hour after taking SAM-e either. Not doing this nullifies the benefits.2) Only works for minor depression, major depression patients have not been shown to benefit from SAM-e.SCIENTIFIC VIEWS/DOSAGE: Among OTC supplements, SAM-e and St John's Wort are the ones the benefit of which are most reliably demonstrated by research (as a brief trip down PubMed articles will show you). If planning to go the natural remedy way, start with either. Adding some Omega-3 can't hurt too; while its mood-benefits are still contested, it has many other perks.As for dosage, there are some articles claiming that common SAM-e dosages are extravagant, and comparable benefits can be obtained by much lower doses, so start with 100 mg, and increase when necessary.MY EXPERIENCE: I've been inclined to minor depression all my life, and over years had good results with  Zoloft, Lexapro, Welbutrin, Prozac, among others.When my last episode started I (together with my shrink) decided to go natural and stick with SAM-e, and at 400 mg/ day, since the third week, I'm seeing results  comparable to that of aforementioned antidepressants.POSSIBLE ADDITIONS TO THE REGIMEN: Following my prev. shrink's advice, I also take 5-Htp, Tryptophan and DMAE on and off, but the effects have never been as dramatic as those of SAM-e or St. Johns. If you're fine with the extra expense, worth a shot, but keep your expectations minimal.

Bought this in spring since my go-to summer jean shorts, levis 51x models, have become hard to find lately. It can be a challange to find a slim-fit jean short that people with thick legs (who are not overweight) can wear fashionably.I usually wear 33-34, have thick/muscular soccer legs, and bought these in 34, they're slightly loose on tummy, and a perfect fit otherwise.The cut is very similar to those Levis 51x models I'd worn in the past, not a speck of unnecessary bulk / loose folds, they're comfy, a lot cheaper than said Levis alternatives , and an overall good deal.I'll be ordering another one, for rotation, this week.

Adding this on top of the strip-regimen I've been applying for a few months has made no discernible difference. I am not going to order again. I tt tastes like mint gum, and freshens your breath somehow, but that's pretty much it.

I have no complaints, qualitywise, this one is right up there with more expensive CK ones I've recently bought, unwillingly, before discovering these. Stays put, doesn't reveal your crack while biking, etc.FIT: I'm 5'11, ~ 210 lbs, athletic w/ a slight belly, and almost exclusively wear large underwears, medium would have certainly been a better fit for me, and will order another set in medium.

One would think it'd be easy to get a good fit when you go sleeveless, but most of the time it's not for me, unless I dish out ~40$ for UA etc.This shirt, despite being sleeveless, has just the right amount of shoulder-coverage to not look like a wife-beater, it's arm-holes are tight enough not to reveal your body, nor do they get in the way. It has a slightly slim cut that's just enough and not overdone.The neck is not too tight or too loose. (A big deal for me).It doesn't have advanced moisture-wicking properties, then again, it's at least cotton, and w/ this price, I couldn't expect that.I've ordered 3 more since I've first found out about this particular model, and expected to order several more over the summer.

This is a catalogue of casino rip-offs.  James Swain has been writing casino crime books for years, but none have this many scams in them.  Billy is a cheater.  A big time cheater with a crew.  He gets the tables turned on him and the fun begins.  He gets tied up in knots working for casinos and against them at the same time.  Every section of every chapter has him reliving or pulling another scam, so the reader gets a full education on ways casinos can be ripped off.  Billy tells all while in gaming agents custody, so the reader gets the current, immediate past and personal history.Billy is a fun roguish character.  Some of the other characters like the drug kingpin, casino manager and gaming agents are a bit stereotypical, but the fun in this book is learning the scams and watching a primo cheater get away with everything he sets his mind to.My criticism of the book is a mild one.  The descriptions of all the scams actually slows the book down so the plot develops very slowly. The last forty pages really pick up into a crescendo.I don't know if Mr. Swain can keep Billy fresh for another episode, but he left the door open at the end.  If Billy returns, I'll be right there to watch his "play".

This book might be better if all the characters are known to the reader.  I am not, so I felt as if I were an outsider.DuPre, a Metis in Montana is a problem solver.  From some references, he must have been some sort of official in the past, but he is now evidently retired.  His (step?) son goes to a sweat with another veteran of the Iraq war and the hear voices crying.  From the voices and a song, DuPre determines these are the voices of the souls of Metis killed in 1910.  The rest of the book is a rather slow search for the site of the massacre and graves.  Along the way, successor generations seem to be a tad over sensitive and try to block the search with violence and intimidation.  DuPre has, in additional to vast reserves of wisdom, very rich and well-connected friends.  That competition helps him to solve the mystery and put the souls to rest.I think if you know the characters and are invested in them, this book will mean a whole lot more to you.  As a stand alone, I found it lacking.  The writing is good and the characters are interesting, I just wish I had their background to understand them better.  If you have read these books, look for a review of someone else who has read them so you get a better idea of how they compare to the rest of the series.

This is a well researched history of Charles and Chuckie Taylor and Liberia's turbulent years.  It is a dense recitation of the events relating to those two "warriors" and their country.  Unfortunately, it is as dry as it dense.  Unless you have some over-arching interest in the country or the period, this reads like academic exercise.  I don't have such an interest, and there was nothing in the presentation to grab me or keep my interest.  I give it four stars for the information and two (being generous) for presentation.  I don't think anyone with a mere passing curiosity with the topic would find this entertaining or gripping in any way.

I've read and enjoyed all of the Duffy Dombrowski books.  I was a tad worried when i got this one.  i was afraid it would be filled with all the old "I hate Claudia" and "I hate paperwork" that was in the first four.  However, Mr. Schreck's writing continues to evolve and this book had much more depth than the prior ones.  The rote gimmick of the office politics was completely gone, while the mystery was just as good as always.  Duffy's relationships get full play - for good or for bad, as does his boxing career.The book opens with a high school age client of Duffy's telling him he's like to cut the throat of the football coach.  Yup.  Within a few pages, the coach's throat has been cut.  But this is not a typical clear the kid's name book.  There is much more going on and there is none of that.  The picture is too big for just one boy's possible crime.  Of course, Duffy gets into the middle of it.There is still good humor mixed in with the mystery.  Duffy is an excellent self-effacing narrator, but in this book, he shows a much less confident side.  Schreck has again turned out a good mystery with an excellent narrator in Duffy.  For followers of the series (this stands alone just fine) the fab four in AJ's again appears as does Al, the basset hound.  If you've enjoyed the prior books, you'll enjoy this one.  If this is your first, you will want to go back and read the others.

Every fan of Sherlock Holmes worries when faced with a Sherlock adaptation.  I was somewhat mollified by the blurb that this one was sanctioned by the Doyle estate.  Mr. Horowitz does a great job.  In addition to being a homage to Sherlock and his unique skills, he creates a great mystery.  Both Sherlock and Moriarty are central players without, for the most part, being there.  There is also some humor in the Scotland Yard perspective of Sherlock.It appears that before his untimely death, Moriarty was approached by the Moriarty of America about joining forces in Britain.  A Pinkerton had been chasing the American mastermind and joined forces with a Scotland Yard investigator to find him.  After that, "the game was afoot".  Investigator Jones was embarrassed by Sherlock Holmes in a case that had been memorialized by Watson.  Since then, he had adopted Holmes' ways, so teh book included a good amount of deduction.This is a very good mystery.  It captures the flavor of Doyles' Holmes without giving the reader the feeling that it was a Sherlock rip-off.  Highly entertaining and - once again - I am given another reason to return to the original Sherlock.  This was a reminder of that excellence.

In several places the Winter Family (band of thugs) were described as sadistic lunatics.  That is apt.  Violent sadistic lunatics might be even more appropriate.  The novel tracks this band of violent criminal from Sherman's March where they are all introduced through different forms of violence, to Chicago where they employ violence to swing an election to Arizona where they use violence to try and exterminate the Apaches.  They all, of course meet a violent end.If you noted the gross overuse of the word "violent" in the opening paragraph, it is because this book is filled with violence.  It seems to be the only theme.  The characters are not developed except in the way the different means by which they cause pain and death on others.  The leader of the pack, Augustus Winter, is not developed at all, except he has the uncanny ability to make grown men cry by looking at them.  Oh, and he is violent.  Not the most violent, but very violent.A few of the characters also have the rare ability - beyond their ability to react to everything with violence - to philosophize on their grand views of life.I kept looking for some redeeming virtue in this book, but really couldn't find any except is done seem to have some historical background in the settings of Sherman's March to the Sea and late 19th century Chicago.  I am not a weak in the stomach reader, but the ever-present renditions of violence got tedious.  Man's inhumanity to man is well-chronicled in this book.

This was a thoroughly enjoyable trip to the old west.  By the "old west", it means 1826 when civilization was essentially stopped at St. Louis and British and American trappers were trying to assert their country's land claims by trapping the heck of the land.  Mr. Burke uses very well researched trapping expeditions to set up his story of the friendships and love of his narrator, William Wyeth.  It is a rare blend of historical fiction and relationships.  Neither overwhelms the other.The characters have great variation.  There is the old typical trapper, the artist, the dandy trying to make good, thieves, gentlemen and, of course, a pretty woman.  They all have their reasons for going on a trapping expedition.  Wyeth wants to prove himself to his father, Landry wants to prove he is a better man than perceived, the artist wants to draw, they all want adventure, they all have the rambling bug.  The cast of characters are used well to draw the pictures of the times.  But this is not just a romance or feel good friendship novel.  There are also friends and foes of both European and Native American stock.  There's plenty of western action and daring-do.  What is unique about this book is how well Mr. Burke does both aspects in equal measure.

Hampton Sides can tell history like a story.  He captures the flavors of the times and the personalities of the participants in a unique way.  It makes for entertaining reading even of a detailed history such as this.The "story" is of one of the most notorious attempts to sail to the North Pole.  In the 19th century this was an unknown area of the world even less explored than the heart of Africa.  Bennett, the publisher of the New York Herald who had just sent Stanley to find Dr. Livingston, wanted another big story for his paper - like the first men to get to the Pole.  He sponsored the voyage of the U.S.S. Jeannette, a "Navy" boat and journey paid for by a private citizen.  Sides sets the journey off well by sharing with the reader the pulse of the times and desire for new exploration combined with the complete lack of knowledge of the North Pole.  Worse than the lack of knowledge were the surmising and assuming of the day's scholars.  Of course there was an open sea at the top of the world!The book plots the genesis of the journey and Captain DeLong's preparation, travel and travails.  At times it reads like thriller.  For me, who did not know the ending, the sense of foreboding was palpable.  I'd suggest if you don't know how the Jeannette fared, don't skip to the end.A fine piece of writing about a different time captured so well by Mr. Sides.

If you enjoyed THE AMBITIOUS CARD, the first in this series, you will enjoy this one even more.  There is the same humor, excellent main character, humor and a good plot.  Plenty of magic.  There are really no new elements, everything is just a bit better.  Most of the characters (the best ones, anyway) return, including Uncle Harry, Clive, Max and the Mystics.  Magic is prominent and Mr. Gaspard still employs the extremely frustrating but fun gimmick of almost revealing how trick are done and then falling back on the "magicians never tell" mantra.  He tells enough about the broad methodogy to give the reader a bit of education, though.In this book, Eli goes to his high school reunion, meets again his high school crush and performs a little magic.  The day after, the real "fun" begins.  A murder is committed while he sleeps.  He, of course, is brought in as a person of some interest by his ex and her new husband.  The mystery is a good one with murders piling on.  Eli falls back on magic to solve the crime and prevent an other.This is a fun novel that has all the elements: a good main character, an excellent supporting cast, depth and emotion in both, a good plot, good humor (without being overbearing) and an interesting background of magic.  Highly recommend for an enjoyable, warm romp of a mystery.  The book can stand alone just fine but, as is true with any series, is better read with the experience of the first just so you know the characters a bit better.  I'm looking forward to #3.

There are elements of this book that are excellent, good, fair and poor.  To me, it is more like 2.5, but I could see how some night enjoy it.  The spy story is good, maybe fair.  The spy craft element is excellent. The characters are poor.  There is not a one that conjures any emotional response either for or against.  They are all completely void of personality and flavor. This gets especially difficult when combined with the writing style.  The book - every page - is filled with minute details of everything.  Some may enjoy this style.  The biggest problem I had with it is that the style did not contribute to the book.  It did not add to any tenseness.  It did not add depth to the character of the setting.  After I while, I found it tedious,  I also found myself skimming through entire paragraphs of descriptions because I knew they would not add to my enjoyment of the book.The detail and lack of investment in the characters (and, really the story, too) made the book plod for me.  You want good contemporary international intrigue and spying?  Go to I AM PILGRIM instead of this one.

I found this novel to be disjointed.  There are many elements coming from several directions.  They never really coalesce.  Suddenly the mystery is solved and the book is over.  To make it even more disjointed, every chapter heading has a time.  Unfortunately, they are all in different time zones, so, unless you have a map of meridians around, it is difficult to relate the actions taken place in Washington, Mali, Europe and other time zones.Judd Ryker is a professor who gets hired (purloined?) by the State Department.  Suddenly, without any real experience, he is put in charge of handling a coup in Mali.  He detects hat there are people in the State Department going in a different direction and that Defense also is going elsewhere.  Out of no where, he has an all powerful Special Forces guy carrying his water.  There are drugs, terrorism, counter-terrorism, lobbyists, diplomacy around the world and, well, your head just spins.  The prologue is no help.  We know from the prologue that a young American has also been kidnapped but, for most of the book, that is a non-factor.  Within the last fifteen pages we learn that Judd has figured it all out.  What we also learn is that Judd is even more naive than we thought throughout.There is a lot of good spy stuff out there.  This one is okay, but nothing great.  It might be better if you have an interest in Mali or Africa, but I doubt it.

This is an excellent mystery with an excellent cast.  Eli Marks is a magician who learned his craft from his uncle.  Part of his uncle's craft was debunking psychics and seers.  The book starts with Eli standing in for him.,  From there the murder mystery takes off.There are a few fundamentals about this book that make it truly enjoyable.  Eli solves the crime; but he is just a normal guy.  No supernatural powers.  He is a human character who is pining for his fine-looking landlord, who becomes a fine character in her right.  His uncle is also a fine character who misses his late wife. His ex-wife and her new husband are also good as are all the somewhat offbeat psychics.  In short (too late), all the characters are good and none are cardboard cut-outs.  Next, the book is constantly moving.  There are no slow parts.  THere is also some nice wry humor throughout.  Lastly, although Eli lives by the magician's creed to never divulge a trick, there is a lot about magic in this book.  It adds depth and color.This is an excellent mystery and a great start to a series.  I look forward to joining Eli again.

Years ago I read a book about how to read Literature.  One chapter entitled: "Everything Comes from the Bible...".  The next was entitled "...Unless It Comes From Shakespeare".  It seems these days that every mystery comes from the good auspices of an author's estate.  Robert Parker's Estate even has two authors allowed to write in his voice.  Mr. Goldsborough has been authorized to write in the voice of Rex Stout and continue the Nero Wolf stories.  I can't say I was a huge Stout-Wolf fan, but I have read several.  It seems to me that not only has Mr. Goldsborough captured Stout's voice, but he has crafted a darn good plot.  Frankly, it was better than a few of the Stout-Wolf books.Archie, always the hand-maiden star is featured in the book, is not only the eyes, ears and feet of Wolf, but in this book he is also the target of murder.  Someone wants to do him in to get at Wolf who, of course, never leaves the house.  In the meantime, a rich heiress becomes a client and Archie has to go in two directions while protecting himself from a murderer.Like Stout, Goldsborough captures New York City in its Upper Eastside well-off glory in the nineteen fifties.  This is a fine book, of whihc Mr. Stout, I am sure, would be pleased.  If you've never read Stout, don't worry.  This is a fine stand alone.

This was a good solid start to a series.  Good enough that I've preordered the second book.  Jake and Laura are very good characters and their interactions add to the flavor and depth of the book.  The setting is 1932, right before FDR's inauguration.  Everyone knows Prohibition is on its last legs, but the Depression is overwhelming.  Their was dissatisfaction on both sides, but this book focuses on those who still have everything and might lose it.  An interesting perspective.Jake is a former private eye born and raised in Queens and NYC.  He fled to Florida a few years before the action starts.  He has turned into a writer of p.i. novels and returned to the Big City to meet with his publisher.  He goes to meet up with his old partner and all heck break loose.  Included in the heck breaking loose is the reunion with Laura, now a super-successful stage star engaged to a rich Gatsby type.  As you can tell by the subtitle, they end up teaming up.  This enriches the book as Jake is not quite a strong or unique enough character to carry the book alone.Perhaps the best part of the book are the cameos by real people of the age.  Mr. Murphy works them in with Jake and Laura flawlessly.The era is well-researched, the plot good, the writing good, but a tad bit of extra rumination throughout took it down a star.  Still a very good book and recommended.

The plot of this murder mystery is pretty good.  There are, however, two things that commend it beyond it's just pretty good plot - baseball and a familiarity with Providence, Rhode Island.  If either of those mean a lot to you, this novel is elevated to a five star.  That city is the setting and there are parts of the book that read like a newspaper account of a game - great for the baseball fans amongst us.Blissberg is an higher than average in intelligence Jewish professional baseball player with just above-average skills as a player. All of those assets make him different than the usual SortsCenter guest.  His roomie is found dead in the whirlpool and he can't let it go.  It leads him to intrigue that only really gets going in the last third of the book or so.  There is one particularly good action scene.  The baseball accounts are realistic.  Many of the supporting cast is also true-to-form, especially the ones closest to the team.  The author obviously knows the game, its players and its hanger-ons.A pretty good mystery made better by its setting.  This is a good light read.

Good, solid fun mystery set in NYC during Prohibition.  Jimmy "the Stick", the main character is a darn good narrator/star.  He has humor, is a former runner for the mob and now runs a speakeasy.  He knows all the bad guys and the cops - for good or for all.  These books (this is the second) capture the Prohibition New York world well.  Jimmy ranges beyond New York as he retells stories that set up the present.And that is what takes this book from a five star to a four.  Jimmy tells so many stories setting up the present plot that occasionally the real plot gets lost.But this is a character driven story and Mr. Mayo draws excellent characters.  Every supporting actor is unique and brings a different personality.  Most are nuanced.  This was a time when there was honor among thieves.  Speakeasies, although technically illegal, were accepted and found in all the best places  - even in the new, chic Chrysler Building.  In such a setting where the lines of legality and morality are so blurred, so also should the characters blur those lines - and Mr. Mayo lets them do that in a way that really gives the book a good flavor.The book starts with seemingly everyone thinking that Jimmy has something and he does even know what it is they all think he might have.  everything they think he has is different.  What he finds he does has, no one seem to want.  From that confusion, murder and chases proliferate.  All may be set up by an old love interest.  Jimmy always has one going and one prospect front and center.This is a good, fun book with a great narrator and very good characters.  The time is captured well.  The weakest part is actually the plot; but when you get to watch and enjoy such characters, that becomes less a short-coming.  I look forward to the next book in the series.

This is an excellent introduction to a new interesting character.  The plot is not bad, but not great.  The back story of Jimmy "the Stick" is what makes it good.  Mr. Mayo captures the flavor of Prohibition mobsters and their world very well.Jimmy was a runner and shooting trainer for the mob.  He is now trying to go straight - sorta', kinda' - if running a speakeasy is going straight.  When the Lindbergh kidnapping happens, he's enlisted by an old friend to guard a baby in New Jersey.  From there the plot unfolds, but his personal history is the best part.This was a very very good introduction to this character.  I was hoping I could go right into book number 2, but it looks as if I'll have to wait.  Alas alack.

This is the best book I've read this year.  It started slowly, then grabbed me, then grabbed my heart and then wrapped itself around my heart like a soft muffler with a just a bit of burlap.  Despite that sappy description, this is by no means a sappy book.  It has warmth and humor.Ove is a taciturn, possibly grumpy, man set in his ways.  He finds a new need to confront the changing world and he does not like it.  He does like the change in his life, the people who force them or need to change.  Like his Saab, he wants life to go on reliably and unchanging.  He battles the changes and also fights battles that only he has been waging for years.This is a great character study of a very unique character.  The writing (or translation) sets a pace and tone that is perfect for a "biography" of this character.  Like his conversation, the writing is done in a cadence that fits the man, Ove.  There are other characters, but they are purely supportive; background to Ove.  They are there to highlight him and to draw the eyes to his sharp corners.With the warmth and humor there is also wisdom and some keen insights into human relationships.  It would make great fodder for a reading group - entertaining, but still with a lot to talk about.This is a very different book, perhaps because Ove is so different while still being perfectly believable.  We've all met people like him, if not to this degree.  This book is highly recommended.  By the end, you might even want to buy a Saab.

In the past, I have compared Mr. Giammatteo favorably to John Sandford.  That comparison continues and it was nice of him to throw in an accolade to Sandford in this book.  Frankie "Bugs" Donovan and Nicky "Rat" Fusco continue their lives in this novel.  That is what Giammatteo and Sandford do so well.  Their main characters (and supporting ones like Ace and Mazzetti) all have real lives where they age, develop, grow, win, lose, have relationships, lose relationships -well, you know, they have real lives.  In addition to watching the characters' lives, we also get an excellent plot.In this book, there is a serial murder on the lose and Donovan has the case with stand-bys Mazzetti and Miller helping him.  It is difficult to explain how and why Nicky gets involved without a spoiler, so suffice it to say that he does.There is an area where Giammatteo may actually pass Sandford.  That is the way he places his characters face moral dilemmas.  He puts Donovan and Nicky in morally compromising positions (for them) in a way that gives the books exceptional depth without crossing into maudlin or (worse) dullness.  This attribute adds to the tension of the murder investigation rather than slowing it down.  I have read all of Giammatteo's books, and this feature highlights the Friendship and Honor series better than the others.All three of these books have been great.  Were I to rate them, I would say this one is as good as the first with number two a have step down, though still a five star.  If you read this one first  -  it can stand alone - you will be unable to resist going back to the first two.  If you have a long weekend with nothing else to do, hunker down and read them in order.  A caution:  you'll be so wrapped up in them you'll have to remind yourself to eat.  Great books, plain and simple.

This is not a war book so much as an elephant book and that is a good thing.  The first three quarters or so is all about Williams, his relationships with elephants in the jungles of Burma and the elephants themselves.  It is an amazing account of amazing animals as seen through Williams' eyes, who was enamored with the giant animals at his first sight.Ms Croke weaves a story through the animal and human aspects while being informative about the colonial life of the Brits in Burma.  But most of all, it is about the elephants and their capacity to amaze those who do not work with them on a daily basis - which, assumedly, is every reader of the book.  Eventually World War II breaks in on Williams' iconic life and he saves the elephants from the abusive Japanese (who also want them) to use them extremely effectively in the Allied cause to retake Burma.This is an interesting and engaging book.  Any lover of animals will truly gain a much greater appreciation of elephants and appreciate a man like Williams who treated them like members of his family..

In this coming of age novel, the 14 year old "Clever Trevor" is brought to the mansion built by his ancestors in the Pacific Northwest.  He explores the cavernous manse through secret halls, chambers, rooms and floors.  There is discovers ghosts, accounts of his family's abuse, alcoholism, homosexuality, pillaging of the forest, conservationism and whatever other hot buttons that can be thought of as he lusts (somewhat naturally for a fourteen year old boy) for his aunt.  It seemed all the issues in this family were contrived.  Of course, he is there because his father is trying to forestall divorce from his mother; one more hot spot.Mr. Stein can certainly put phrases together into wonderful sentences.  Unfortunately, I found the book to be like Trevor's exploration.  It seemed as Mr. Stein was writing without really knowing where he was going, so he kept throwing in new and different rooms to be explored.  Discombobulated comes to mind as a description of the plot.  Unfortunately, also boring.  It does not help that a reader is forc ed to compare this effort with Mr. Stein's absolutely wonderful RACING AGAINST THE RAIN.

I loved the first book in this series.  It is hard to tell what number this is as it seems to vary, but this one is not nearly as good.Alice and Snow have their detective agency and have gotten to be lovers as well.  It is hard to tell because the dialogue is so stilted and there seems to be a lack of rapport between the two.If the characters are not working well, you must rely on the mystery.  This one is mediocre at best.  The worst part is that Alice and Snow never figure anything out on their own.  The case is not solved by them at all.  It made me scratch my head.After the first book, PUNCTURED, I was looking forward to a series with good dialogue, humor and connected main characters in the interesting setting of Las Vegas.  This book has soured me on the series.

I'm an Ethan Gage fan and love the derring-do, swashbuckling action with the often tongue-in-cheek humor.  What made this series even better was the history lesson built into the yarn.  They are very reminiscent of the FLASHMAN series in all of those excellent respects.This one missed the mark for me.  Ethan (once again) is separated from his wife, the quasi-mystic from Eqypt, and is off after her.  She is after an automaton that can tell their futures.  They are not the only ones on this quest and thus the chase is on.  There is a great Napoleonic battle scene that is terrific for its historical base, action and Ethan's usual "aplomb".  Beyond that, the book is fairly repetitious.  It is told by Ethan and Asisza, his wife.  Her parts are very redundant and drag.Don't judge this series or Ethan Gage by this book.  Consider it the lull of 1805 in his life.

It is difficult to find the words to describe how good this book is.  It is a thriller unlike any other in that it is not only a great spy thriller, but also the saga of a deep undercover spy.  The spy (he has several names throughout) narrates the story and the reader sees what he sees, but also, since it is told as a retrospective, there are forebodings of errors and more darkness to come.The spy is an engaging character.  A super sleuth, he does not have the huge ego or extra special physical abilities of some characters in these types of books.The book takes the reader through America, Germany, Moscow, Turkey and the Middle East in what is obviously a well-researched book.  A fundamentalist wants to destroy Saudi Arabia by destroying its "protector", the USA.  His plot is ingenious.  Nothing in the book is unbelievable, which makes the very tight plot even more harrowing.The writing is excellent.  I cannot describe it as a "page-turner" because it is too cerebral to fly through.  The narrator takes the reader along through his thought processes.  Part of the book is not told in the first person.  Mr. Hayes tells the account of the terrorist in the third person, describing his motivations in an understandable way that puts the hairs on the back of your head stand up.
