One can only imagination there are thousands of such thinkers in the Middle East today taking aim at the "unbelievers.Here is, perhaps, the best compliment I can give this book.  I said the plot was tight.  This is amazing in a thriller a mere 607 pages long.  When I picked it up, I was leery that such a long book could hold my attention.  Not only did it hold me rapt, I yearned for more.  Unfortunately, it came to an end.  More unfortunately, it does not seem to set up a sequel.  This is a character I would follow like Bonds, Smiley and Reacher.Can't recommend this book highly enough.  There is some graphic violence, but none of it is gratuitous.

I'm a big fan of Mr. Benn's books, both those with and without Billy Boyle.  Every year I have looked forward to the newest Billy Boyle mystery.  I bought this one the day it came out.  Billy is a great character.  He started as an immature Boston cop, promoted there too young and rose in the Army too young.  We watched him mature, gain confidence and his intimidating boss, Major Harding, gain confidence in him.  Throughout he kept a sense of humor and bungled enough to be lovable without being a goof.The best part of these books were that they were historical novels that used a great engaging character with a decent crime mystery to tell the history of WWII.  Interesting, intriguing and informative - three big "I's".  I almost wished that that the war would go longer so there was more time for Billy to operate.This iteration of the series is an anomaly.  Billy has a stick...in him now.  He waxes philosophical about the big picture and depressive nature of war on too many occasions.  He is a know-it-all to young rookies in combat, which does not go with his personality.  There really is no central mystery until well past halfway through the book.  He and his pal, Kaz get sent to the British coast and wrap up a small mystery up in no time.  Then the book drags as Billy gets embroiled in the family mystery of the upper crust house of Sutcliffe and Pemberton where he and Kaz are staying.  Much of the book reads more like the screenplay for a PBS drama rather than a WWII historical novel.  Finally, a mystery tangentially tied to the military brings the household drama to an end.  There is a little history here, not nearly as much as usual.  The central theme was the family drama, which was not that interesting or unique, while the war lurked in the background. The drama was pretty standard fair.  Billy has lost his self-effacing sense of humor.  Two famous people have forced cameo appearances.Since I've loved and bought every one of Mr. Benn's books (he is also an interesting speaker), I will chalk this one up to a short slump and look forward to next September.

Early in the book, it is said that veterinary practice is no longer that of James Herriot.  This book shows that there is still a lot of that going on - only this time with a socially stilted nerd of a vet.  The set up is typical, yet good.  The vet returns to his small Vermont backwoods hometown to take over his father's failing practice.  He is falling in love with a woman he can't figure out.  So far, it is all pretty darn pat.  However, Mr. Trout rises above the typical and the predictable introducing interesting characters and situations.  There are nerds, hacking, strange pets, strange pet owners and things that seem as if they would be cardboard cut-outs, but they are not,  They are unique and have a distinctive and endearing quirkiness.  The vet's super-nerdy diagnoses are worth the price of admission.The book started a tad slowly, but picked up.  This is four stars for the reason that you would have had to read the first book (PATRON SAINT) to fully appreciate some of the background.  I, regrettably, did not and so I felt a bit out in the wilderness.  Even with that caveat - read the first book first - this was a thoroughly enjoyable warm feel good book with some good vet stuff thrown in to the mix.

It is clear Mr. McIntyre loves his topic.  He was as enthusiastic about the secret project "Operation Mincemeat" as were its creators.  You can tell by all the detail (sometimes a bit much) and the all the background information he provided on every character.The operation itself drives the book.  Mr. MacIntyre takes it from its genesis as a concept, to its inception, through its tortuous set-up, the operation itself and its aftermath.  It is the aftermath and the effect on the Germans that is really most astounding.  To make a clandestine operation work is one thing.  To have it effect, truly, the outcome of a war as large as WWII is absolutely amazing.I have read of this operation in other books, fiction and non-fiction, but this is the complete story.  It even includes the gaffes and errors that could have (and perhaps should have) scuttled the entirety.This is a good book about an incredible story.  My only criticisms is that, at times, the detail was too much and, if you are familiar with WWII, some of the background information was pretty basic.  All-in-all a captivating story.

This book was atrociously translated.  At first it was amusing with gems like: "My brain interpreted it to be the coroner" and in the midst of passion "she tried to detain herself".  As it went on it became obnoxious with, on several occasions, words used meant the opposite of the author's presumed intent being used.  The author at one point "fast paced" across the runway to get top a "grey leathered chair".  Syntax was not English and the author tried to use every adjective in his Greek-English dictionary and even some I had not thought of, like the "graphic blue and white houses".The book was also amateurishly written with pained attempts to describe Greece and its culture inserted regardless of flow or context.  The deliciousness of food being described in the midst of a grisly murder investigation?The plot is pretty good for a serial killer and had a good theme.  The end was amazingly childish that evoked a "Really?  I read this much for that?"  For Nickelodeon it might have been clever.All-in-all, this is a book to skip.  AN editor would have helped.  A different ending would have made it worthwhile.

If you're wondering how a book could be written about one man who stole a bunch of maps, the answer is to add lots of history.  That is what Mr. Blanding did and it is not a bad thing.  If you are a lover of maps, this is the book for you.  It is more about maps than true crime - which is not a bad thing.W. Forbes Smiley is one of several map thieves in the last decades.  He differs from the others by his brazenness, the fact that he was a respected map dealer and that he was/is such a colorful and flamboyant figure.  His methods were not much different from those who went before (or will follow).  That is why the addition of so much history, both of maps and related to amp and mapping make this book interesting.Truly for lovers of maps, this is an interesting account of the history of mapping (particularly of North America) and one's man's downfall.

I know hockey and am a mild fan, but I don't think even a great fan would love this book.  The main character, Brad Shade, is a former player for the LA Kings who is now scouting.  Hockey is in the background (with random yarns of other former players thrown in randomly), but is not a major theme.  The mystery is just ok. There is very little "investigation" besides the theft of a diary.  There is lots of driving and fights, seemingly without cause.  Brad brings another player along (Chief) and his only purpose seems to be to win the fights and be put out of his way by Brad.The best character is the murder victim who is found dead in the first few pages.  Unfortunately, he does not say much.  Brad Shade is a character I just could not figure out.  On the one hand he tries to be the hard-oiled P.I.  On the other, he philosophizes unmercifully.  He doesn't want to be a womanizer, but beds 'em easily.  This is in the first person and Brad drones.My biggest criticism of the book - which I enjoyed for more than the first half - is that it really dragged towards the end.  It came to a resounding halt with about thirty pages to go.  Then, of course, it wrapped up in two with a fairly unsatisfying ending.There are great mystery writers out there.  Too many good ones to spend time on this mediocre one.

If there were a Mt. Rushmore of current mystery/thriller writers, Michael Koryta would have to be on it.  This is just one more example of why.  Koryta never follows a formula in his thrillers.  This one is set in the wilds of Montana in a survival school.  A boy is a witness to a crime and must be protected, so he is sent to Montana from suburban Indiana.  Thus begins the wild the search and flee.There are a lot of twists and turns.  Reviewers of this book have criticized it for some of these turns.  Hellooo.  This is thriller fiction.  None of the twists were predictable, which I find to be one of the measures of good escape fiction.  Another good measure is the uniqueness of the setting.  Here we have a survival school with fire.  The reader gets an education is interesting aspects of both.Perhaps the best feature of the book are the bad guys.  They are absolutely chilling and unlike any I've encountered.  Their dialogue will stand the hairs on the back of your neck straight up.Like most Koryta's books, the emotional and psychological toll on the characters are a major element.  No one, good or bad, gets off easy.This is a thrilling ride through the mountains of Montana with chills and heat - literally and figuratively.  Highly recommended.

This will teach me to look at the publisher on these discount books.  You would think that even self-publishers would get an editor, but Mr. Wallace clearly did not.  The pacing is flawed.  The story inconsistent, varying from romance novel to graphic violence, WWII war story to a story that could fit anywhere.  There is obviously good research here with some very nice historical references.  These are about the only things that place the story in WWII as apart from an y other occupied territory.  Nothing much atall happens in the first 80%, then it all comes flowing downhill like river rapids in a flood. I found the characters incongruous.  Except for the cardboard cutouts of the gestapo officer and the rich do-gooder, none had any consistent development.Frankly, I am at a loss for all the rave reviews.  Sorry.  I found myself skimming to get through this way too early and then was disappointed in the ending.  The first twenty pages held so much promise, but from there nothing happened and when things started to happen they were rushed and implausible.  Let's just drive across occupied France shall we?  Twice?  Why not?I was very disappointed in this book.  Bottom line, it was amateurish and not worth the time.

This is a throwback to the great Cold War novels.  It is just plain terrific.  Spell-binding with real characters playing their roles to a tee in this novel.  There has been some criticism that the main character, a 19 year old "negro" student was not the proper vehicle for the role she played.  There may be validity to that.  On the other hand this was secret stuff and who better to fool the other side.Mr. Carter captures well the fear and anguish around the world during those those days in October of the Cuban missile crisis.  Better, he captures the historic context of the two super powers' real positions as well their perceived positions.  He placed well the various factions on both sides who advocated for their positions from positions of both personal self-interest and national self-interest.All the characters were well developed and believable.  Sure, the 19 year old may have been a wonder child, but she was still a good vehicle to get the story told.  Mr. Carter's historical note wraps up the fictionalization nicely.  His writing in the body keeps the tension rising throughout.This is a highly entertaining and thought-provoking old-fashioned (in a good way) spy novel.  It harkens to the early (and great) LeCarre days.  Highly recommended for readers of espionage, historical fiction and people who just plain enjoy a very good book.

I was never sure exactly what this book was.  I'm not sure Mr. Lashner was that sure either.  There are murders.  There is, of course, his fine main character, Victor Carl, and there is also politics in the form of bagmen and their corruption.  Often, I felt as if this book were Mr. Lashner's personal screed on politics rather than a murder mystery of any sort.  Carl waxes philosophically on virtually everything, at times sounding the know-it-all, but there is a special venomous cynicism with any political.  That is understandable in this day and age and all of America's frustrations seem to be unleashed in his diatribes.  But, I guess I came for a more entertaining mystery.The mystery itself is pretty good, but it eventually gets wrapped into the "everyone associated with politics is scum motif".  It rambled on slowly twisting and turning to indict as many participants as possible.  I would not call this a "taut" mystery at all.  I found myself rooting for its end more than its resolution.I've enjoyed other Victor Carl, but this one missed for me.  Too much negativity and cynicism.  I can watch the world news tonight for that.  Call me shallow, I did not find this entertaining.

Ahh the temptresses!  Three out of four, anyway.  This is an interesting and very in depth look at four woman who served as spies during the Civil War.  Two were for the north and two the south.  One, Emma, was a female who posed as a male soldier for the first years of the war.  Her spying was limited, but her story was, nevertheless, interesting.  The fact she was one of many such poseurs made her yarn even more interesting.Ms Abbott follows the women's triumphs and failures chronologically in a fashion that was easy to follow even as she switched from participant to participant.I have two criticisms of the book that do not overshadow its merit.  There was a lot of detail I found uninteresting that did not enhance the book for me.  Details like the colors of the wall, outfits, clothing and the like.  There were also times when Ms Abbott seemed to infuse her imagination as to the the thoughts and feelings of the participants.  Although the author's note said everything came from diaries, I doubt that was the case in all instances.  For instance, she included sensations felt while drowning - - doubtful that came from the diary of the deceased.All that easily put aside, this was an interesting account of Civil War spying, the way the men of the war found it difficult to fully deal with female combatants and spies.  The author did a fine job of putting it all in context of the war itself, inserting just enough background to appreciate the pressures being felt on both sides.

Slog.  The Pacific northwest is wet and it often requires slogging through thick mud without any redeeming quality - sort of like trying to read this book.  Set in a logging and harbor town in the last quarter of the nineteenth century the author treats the readers to an exhibition of his use of a thesaurus.  There is very little story.  Like the aforementioned mud, none of the characters have any redeeming qualities -- if you can get through all the superfluous words and verbiage to try and figure them or the plot out.  I do not enjoy having to decipher my books.  I like to read them.The story, such as it is, is told partially in the first person by several of the character.  There is no rhyme or reason as to when it is in the first or third person.  The first person narratives are told by a woman, a street criminal, a ne'er do well drunk fraudulent husband and an eleven year old.  They all read exactly the same!  You'll get a kick out of the observations and metaphors cast about by the eleven year old.  You will also be amazed at how rape and graphic sex scenes read in high-falutin' language.I couldn't get through this book and regretted the time I wasted trying.

This book had so much promise.  The reader learns that a bartender who seemed to be a loser has a lot more to offer and a past that had more depth.  This "coming out" is caused by his adopting a dog.  This is not a feel good dog book, Rocco only seems to bring him out a bit.  As Bob progresses, the pasts and present of other characters come to light.  Their lives intersect with Bob's either directly or in rumor and innuendo.  All that is great.  Add a conspiracy and a robbery of a mob-connected bar, and all the ingredients are there for a terrific book with depth of characters.Unfortunately, the book is over way too quickly.  Suddenly, in a clap of thunder, all the loose ends come together in a very unsatisfying way.  This is a short book.  Unfortunately, it is disproportionate.  The first half is dense, deep and thought-provoking.  The ending is quick and easy.The best asset of this book makes it worth reading.  That asset is Mr. Lehane's writing.  There were several times that I went back and read a passage again just to savor it.  That lifted the book to four stars.I wish the richness of the first half to two thirds of the book had continued on to the end.  This is actually a book that could have been improved greatly by an additional fifty pages.

Harlan Coben is one of the best mystery writers writing today.  For that reason, he is held to a higher standard.  This is a very high standard and MISSING YOU does not approach his best works.It is a very good mystery and his main character, Kat Donovan, is a NYC with a haunting past.  As she struggles with her father's murder of years earlier, she gets engulfed in the emotional maelstrom of finding her ex-fiance (18 years ago) on a dating site and being beset upon by a kid who thinks his mother has been kidnapped.  In the background is a creepy conspiracy in the woods of Amish country.  There is a lot of emotion in this book and not much of the humor that characterized Coben's earlier works.Coben is a master at bringing such seemingly disparate threads together and weaving them into masterful quilt.  He does so here, although I found the ending a bit shallow and a tad disappointing.All-in-all a very good mystery, but not up to Coben's very high standards.

I'm a huge fan of Mr. Giammatteo and have read all his novels. m This one fell short of the others.  It is the second starring Connie, the "niece" of a NYC mobster who becomes a cop and moves to Houston.  In this iteration, she is again set up against Cortes, the Mexican drug kingpin who almost killed her in the first book.This book is good, but not great.  Giammatteo's books have the quality of deep emotions and moral dilemmas confronted by the characters.  This one has some elements of that, but not to the depth of others.  They seemed mere after-thoughts rather than themes.  The ending is a bit a predictable, particularly if one analyzes the title.Ok, that is the bad news.  The good news is that the plot is, as usual a good one.  The characters are developed and not stereotypical.  The dialogue is realistic and, at times, amusing.  The killer is a great character from whom I wanted even more.  SO I should have tempered my criticism.  This is still a good mystery.  It just does not hit the A+ rating of this author's other books.  A B+ from an author of this talent is still a darn good read.

The subtitle reads "The Kremlin, the CIA..."  If you are expecting something with spies or significant intelligence intervention by reading this subtitle, you will be disappointment.  There might be fifteen pages devoted to the CIA's publication of a Russian language version of DR. ZHIVAGO and the places they handed it to people going into the Soviet Union.  The rest of the book is a detailed biography of Pasternak after he finished the books.  There are hundreds of quotes from those for him and against him.  For every conference, at least three or four speakers are quoted.  If you are a Pasternak fan and want a blow-by-blow account of how the Soviet government handled him after he wrote the novel, this might be a four or five star book.  If you are looking for something about the cold war and our propaganda efforts, this will be a one or two star book.  Thus my three star rating. I'm in the latter class so I found myself skimming paragraphs and pages that all read essentially the same after the first hundred pages.  Once the Soviet government read the novel and decided it was not to be published, they had all their yesmen and authors who wanted to be publish pillory him.  Somehow (it is never explained why) Pasternak was never imprisoned and they stopped short of exile so he would not get more publicity.  The west pushed the book.  The Soviets suppressed it.  That's the book in a nutshell.Unless you are passionate about Pasternak, skip this one.

If you ever played the game Snakes and Ladders, then you know the concept behind this game.  The object of the game is to get to the top of the board.  To do that, you roll a die, and move the number of spaces that are on the die.  If you land on a ladder, you climb higher up the board.  If you land on the head of a snake, you get pushed back down the board.The graphics are cute, which is why the app earns three stars, but the game involves absolutely no skill, whatsoever.  You just press on the die to take your turn, and then press on the die for the robot to take its turn.  The results are completely random. The second version (included) where the snakes and ladders move around the board is a bit more interesting than the version in which they stay in one spot.  Nothing other than luck is involved.  You go up and down the board.  You can press the die very quickly, so the game ends very quickly.Adults will probably find this app rather pointless. Very young children will probably enjoy watching the icons "climbing" the ladders and "sliding" down the snakes funny for a few minutes.  Ultimately, however, even young players will realize that no skill is involved, get bored, and move on to something more interesting.

If you are a Looney Tunes fan, as are most Baby Boomers (and just about everybody else), then this app seems to have just about everything you could wish for in a Looney Tunes fantasy app!  You get to live vicariously through your favorite Looney Tunes character.  Who wouldnt want to spend a few minutes taking on the role of the ultimate American Hero, Bugs Bunny in the app version of the classic cartoon shorts?The classical episodes, such as Wabbit Hunt, are there.  The classic visual and verbal stunts are there.  And the classic jokes aimed at adults are there, too.  You have up-beat music, impossible-to-kill characters (they just keep regenerating), and the bright and vibrant colors of the Looney Tunes gang.And yes, it really is free.  As you play the game, you run along the road, earning coins.  You can stockpile the coins you earn, or you can use them to buy boosts in the Looney Tunes store.  Everything you buy is purchased with money you earn for doing well when playing the game.  You dont buy the coins, you just keep playing the game and racking up the points, and the coins pile up.You can  and should- repeat levels to earn more coins by choosing different paths.  If you perform some special tricks, you will be directed off to an expert path, where the challenges and rewards are even better than on the normal road.  As you repeat levels, you improve your skills, thus adding to your ability to earn coins.Be sure the read the on-screen Helpful Tips.  They will give you clues on how to earn more points.  You also get to spin for additional prizes, and win additional coins for doing well. Im going back to the game now so I can finish enough levels to be the Road Runner!

The other day, I almost bought this "iestry" game, and almost paid 99 cents for it.  I just wasn't sure, and decided to think it over before buying it.  The IDEA of matching butterfly tiles seemed great the surface, but the photos of the game made me feel like something was off. I couldn't put my finger on why it seemed off, but it just didn't feel right.Today, the app was the Free app of the Day, so excitedly downloaded it.  Right away, I noted the pictures and just too similar in design and in colors for a matching game based on speed.  Additionally, there is just too much going on in each square, making it difficult to quickly focus in on one feature and recognize a match.  And why on Earth would the app designer crowd three butterflies into one cube panel?  The effect changes busy squares into disasters because you want to play quickly, but your brain doesn't want to process that much information so quickly.  And there's a huge issue with the butterflies.  There are thousands of beautiful butterflies in nature, but the ones in this app just don't have the beauty of the real ones.  Ironically, the backgrounds are more colorful than the butterflies.The music is lovely, and you can individually adjust the volume of the music and the volume of the flapping wing sound.  It is fun to watch the butterflies burst out across the screen and fly away when you make a match.  The user has a lot of control of the display of the cube, and can rotate it so that you can seen only one side at a time (flat), or more than one side (with a 3-D effect), so you can adjust the display to your own advantage.  But these features are common to all of the apps in this series.The "iestry" series is full of wonderful versions, but this one is not one of my favorites.  It's fine since I got it for free, but I'm glad I didn't pay for it!

Imagine you are a bird capable of flying, but only sideways.  Now imagine you can move upwards in the sky (with difficulty), but only if a helpful human (the player at the controls)  helps to give you some lift.  Now imagine you are trying to fly up a narrow shaft with "obstacles" poking out from the side walls of the shaft you're attempting to climb, and the obstacles are randomly spaced out.  The obstacles, by the way, are pointed - and they have eyes!  Awk!  It turns out the obstacles are other birds, trying to take a bite out of you!  Yes, it's a Bird Eat Bird world in this game.  As your human helps you climb the shaft, you work as a team to try to collect diamonds.  If you human doesn't continue to tap the screen to move you upwards, you will fall back down the shaft, towards the bottom.  Like a balloon, however, you fall rather slowly back towards the ground, as you continue to move sideways.  Trying to adjust your trajectory can be challenging.  Oh, and there isn't anywhere to rest, so you have to keep flying.  As you might imagine, with those conditions, this game is tricky.  But's it's wickedly tricky, and loads of fun!I've deducted a star because, when I was trying to learn the controls, I was directed to a screen, asking me if I wanted to purchase some help.  I couldn't exit from that screen, and had to shut down my Kindle to escape.

As an American, blackcurrent was not a flavor familiar to me; however, I thought it looked interesting, so I tried it.  The first glass tasted a little odd, but not terrible.  I had the syrup, so I decided to give it another try.  It tasted better every time I sipped it.  By the end of the fourth bottle, blackcurrent had become a flavor I liked.  I guess this is an acquired taste.  Now that I've acquired the taste, I have shopped for this flavor again.

The art in this version of "Hidden Object" is very beautiful.  It is amazing how the objects blend into the drawing, and trick the eye!  Sometimes it's hard to notice the object because it looks like it belongs in the photo.There are multiple ways to play the game.  You can compete with the clock, or you can take as much time as you want.  You can choose to search for objects via words, silhouettes, pictures, or have the computer mix up the options, randomly.  And you get to play the bonus round with whatever time you have left over after you've found the original set of objects.  The objects are rotated sometimes, and the small details sometimes make it hard to see the match.It's not as easy as you might suspect it will be to locate the hidden objects.  Each picture contains many more objects than you need to locate, and the objects that are included sometimes carry over from one picture to another.  Additionally, some of the objects look similar to the one you're looking for, so don't touch the screen too quickly or you may hit the wrong one.  Consequently, if you play multiple rounds of the game, you may be shocked when an object is not where you remembered seeing it.  These challenges make the game very fun.One star has been deducted from the rating because of a flaw in the design.  While you're searching for the objects, you can zoom in or out by pinching your fingers together on the screen, or by spreading them out.  Unfortunately, when you are zooming in or out, if you happen to touch an object while you're attempting to zoom in our out, points will be deducted from your score.  It's annoying when you have points deducted for placing your fingers on the wrong part of the screen.

This is an wonderful, high-quality summer sweater.  At work, I am very close to an air conditioning vent, so I'm always cold indoors. When I saw the picture of the sweater, the textured pattern made me worry it would be too thick and too warm to wear during the summer.  Since it was on sale, and I loved the beautiful pattern, I decided to take a chance and order it, figuring I could always wear it during the winter if it was too warm for the summer.  I bought a black one, which will match just about anything,  The color is rich. and it looks equally good buttoned all the way up or partially buttoned up,either from the top or the bottom.  I'm a very happy customer.

This playlist contains a nice variety of popular music, with most major styles of music represented within the collection.  It is nice, but it doesn't contain music that elevates it to the "love it" five-star level, overall.Additionally, I usually enjoy re-recordings of previous hits, but the rendition of "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds" presented here is a bit too edgy for my taste.  Everything else is good, and I'm glad to add the songs to my library.

This charger is a nice replacement for the charger that originally came with my 2nd generation Kindle Fire.  After a couple of years, the original charger would not seat correctly in the charging slot on the device.  When I saw this charger, I was willing to give it a try, even though it was not a Kindle-specific item.  Luckily, it works!  Now I can charge up either of my Kindle Fire (2nd and 3rd generations).The best feature of this charger is its portability.  Since the prongs recess into the charger and don't stick out, you don't risk damaging them in transit.  Now I can throw it into my purse and head out the door.  I only wish the cord were a little longer.

The 7D Train is absolutely delightful and a lot of fun! The app (version 1.5) works perfectly on my device, a Kindle Fire 3rd Generation.  I can see all of the beautiful illustrations, and even the gems.  Other reviewers have written they cannot make the app work properly on their Kindle; however, the reviewers did not explain what version of the Kindle they were using, or what version of the app they tried.  I almost didn't buy this app because of that comment, but figured I'd give it a try, and if it didn't work, I'd return it to Amazon for a refund.  But that wasn't necessary.This app is a feast for your eyes and ears.  The graphics are bright and colorful, and the details in the illustrations are incredible.  The backgrounds are frequently hilarious (there is a Loch Ness unicorn, for example), and the details are fantastic. The humor will appeal to all ages, and there are things adults will find funny that will go over the heads of the little ones.  The music is hyper-charged to match the pace of the mine cars as they go zipping through the mine, and the tempo helps to keep your reflexes on call so you can more readily beat the challenges.  Each dwarf's personality is developed nicely, and the dwarfs make character-appropriate comments as they experience their rocketing ride through the mine.  Some of the comments they make are hysterical!You get a lot of fun features with the basic package, and you do not need to purchase anything else to have fun.  If you want to ratchet it up a notch, you can purchase addition gadgets and consumables in the mine's shop.  There are also packages listed.  The purchase options get better - and more expensive, of course - as you complete challenges along the way.  With the prices, I think the company store owns the shop. ;)  If you don't like the basic cart, you can upgrade it.  Each dwarf's cart can be upgraded twice.You can't just memorize the hazards, either.  While some of the hazards and trophies are positioned in the same location for each run, others move around the screen.  For example, one of the dwarfs was sitting in a car on the top rail on one pass, and on the next pass, he was sitting in a car on the bottom rail.  That means you have to pay attention, and play the screen that is presented rather than the one you memorized. It's all fun, and it just adds to the challenge!  :)The game starts off with a menu screen.  From the main menu, you get to select which one of the seven dwarfs you want to drive through the mine.  Don't feel like the other dwarfs will be left out of the round because the other six dwarfs are sitting in cars along the tracks, and you can hook them up to your car as you speed along (if you have quick reactions).  You'll get a special treat if you manage to hook them all up into one train.  Plus, if you have one of them hooked on, and you make a mistake and fall off of the track, the extra car will fall off, but the main car will survive and proceed down the track.  Each dwarf has a special talent, and you can use it by tapping on the lightening bolt icon. Once used, it needs to refill before it can be used again.From the main menu, you can hit the television icon, and a little story will play to let you learn about the personality of the dwarf you are choosing to guide through the mine.  Some of the comments are very funny!  You can also access the shop and see the trophies you have earned.  As always, some of the trophies are easier to earn than others.  You are also shown an icon with a clip board, which lists the missions you can complete to earn additional gems; the gems can be used in the store to purchase gadgets and [power] boosts (also known as consumables).  You will also receive gems when you end a round by running your mine cart off of the track.  Depending on how well you play, the gems can add up quickly.There is an "adults only" icon on the mail menu.  From there, you can sign up on the Disney site to receive special offers and learn about new app releases.  From that screen, I learned there is a new series about the 7D planned for release in July 2015.  (I suppose that makes this app a promo.)  I was also able to access the settings (music, sound effects and voices), the credits, an e-mail icon for the developers, and instructions from the adults only menu.  The game starts off with a tutorial, but play is extremely intuitive, and you really don't need instructions when you first start.  It isn't until later, when you get better, and want to maximize your playing powers, that the instruction are helpful.  I'm not sure why the instructions are buried on the adults only screen, but they are worth reading.  You can also reset the tutorials from the settings screen, so each player can be given their own tutorial..All in all, this is one of the better apps I've seen, and I'm glad I paid for it.  Note that I am not a professional reviewer; I just stumbled across this app and thought it was fantastic.  If you decide to play, I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.  :)

I've been searching for this game as an app for several years now.  So I was elated when my periodic search actually produced a result that looked like it might be the game I longed for.  It was one of my favorite games when I lived in the upper Midwest, it seems most people in other regions of the USA just don't know about it.  (Too bad, since it's a great game.)  To keep my skills sharp, I thought it would be nice to play the game against the computer.BUT....  After playing it, I couldn't help thinking that it was a good start, but it sure does need a lot of work.  First, the bidding is a bit strange.  In the rule book I'm familiar with, a six is only an opening bid.  You don't ever actually play a hand with a six bid, but in this game, you do.  Next, there are only three cards in the blind instead of five, so all of the strategies that took years to develop quickly went flying out the window.Okay, so it's just a different version of the game.  Thinking I might have to refer to the instructions for this version and learn to adjust, I started looking for them, but this game doesn't have any instructions.  :(  Then, when I got a perfect nil hand, I couldn't figure out how to bid nil!  Instructions would have been very, very nice, especially when I later looked it up, and discovered that the reference to "misare," on the bid screen is a nil bid.  (Who knew there were so many version of 500!)One of the best features of the game is the quick card play.  You tap on the card you want to play, and viola! It is done.  It IS the basic game I'm familiar with, but I'd like to see options for selecting a different version, and instructions.  So, it's a good start, but it's not ready for a full launch yet.

This photo gallery contains some of the most beautiful and artistic photographs I've ever seen.  Several times while viewing the photographs, I became lost in their beauty. What I missed, however, was any type of explanation.  The gallery contained no identifying information at all, not even a title.  Where were the photos taken?  When?  this type of information would be provided in a gallery showing.  For the lack of explanation, I've removed a star.

This is an excellent game.  Amy is the little girl who cheers you on and encourages you as you play.  She is a toy maker, and she needs parts to make toys.  You have goals for the number of blocks, per color, that need to be obtained to clear the level and advance in the game.  Although this is a color-matching game, there are a lot of twists to the standard matching game.  The goals vary by the number of each color you need to finish the level to making the required matches within the time given.  There are also a number of special tools you can earn by playing well, and the tools get better as the number of blocks you color-match at one time increases.  The variety is always enough to keep the game from getting boring.It is refreshing to have a cute little girl cheer for the player instead of a minimally-clad woman.

Lost Bubble is a fun game, and the graphics are very good.  It's an easy game to learn; but it's also challenging because new features with more difficult challenges are added as you work your way up through the levels, so you don't get bored.The reason I rated this game with four stars instead of five stars is that you have to pay real money to access most of the "tools" (gems) that grant the player new abilities and that make playing the game more fun.  I certainly don't mind paying to purchase a game I enjoy, but I don't want to have to keep paying to keep playing.  And the amounts changed are excessive.  The other day, for example, I received a pop--up message with an offer of 40% off the normal price.  The package could be purchased for $25.99.  I thought about it, and realized that I would quickly run through the supply purchased through this offer.  Then I realized purchasing the offer was the equivalent of renting the game for a few hours.  The manufacturer should forget their "pay for the gems and coins as you go method," (or at the very least, lower the price to something reasonable) and just allow people to purchase the game outright.  Also, you should be able to earn the opportunity to purchase the items that will help you rather than requiring the player to purchase them.This game is fun, but if you want it to be more fun, you'll need a lot of cash,

This is an enjoyable game.  You get a free puzzle every day, and you have the opportunity to buy puzzle packs with 10 puzzles per pack if you want.  It provides a nice little logical challenge.  You also earn stars for playing well, and you can use those to buy more puzzle packs.The only thing that is disappointing about the game is that the amount of time listed for the goal of three-stars seems to be random.  You have to enter the letters one at a time, so some of the puzzles can't even be solved in the goal time listed unless you know the answer before you start the puzzle.  On the other hand, I've found some of the puzzles extremely easy, and the goal time listed was very long.  Oh well, it's free!  :)

Amoretti Premium Syrup, Coconut Cream is absolutely the best flavor of syrup I have ever tasted!  Since I've tried roughly 60 flavors, that says a lot!  With only 35 calories per pump, I can flavor a 12-oz soda for less than 100 calories, and the coconut soda makes the perfect afternoon pick-me-up snack.  The coconut flavor is smooth and pleasant without being cloyingly sweet.  Additionally, having a pump helps to control the portion used, ensuring consistency in flavoring from one drink to the next.  I'll be back for more.

This is a pretty puzzle, with cute and whimsical illustrations.  Additionally, the theme of the puzzle encourages girls to participate in team sports.  The quality I expect from Eurographics puzzles isn't completely there, however.  The pieces are quite thin, and some of them didn't fit together were well because they were a bit warped.  We left the puzzle out for about two weeks, and the pieces eventually relaxed into their proper shapes.

As a collector of jigsaw puzzles, it takes quite a bit to impress me, but this is puzzle is incredible!  First, the completed puzzle is beautiful and educational.  All of the 22 lighthouses included in the puzzle are named on the back of the box, a small detail that is very much appreciated.  Additionally, at over three feet tall, the puzzle is like a panoramic puzzle that has been turned on its side.  Next, the pieces are cut in many interesting shapes, some of which I've never seen before, adding to the challenge of putting the puzzle together while also making it a lot more fun than a puzzle with standard cut pieces.  Moreover, the shape of the puzzle is very fun, and the pieces that made up the edges sometimes surprised me.  Finally, this puzzle is a good quality toy.  I bought it used, and only one of the pieces showed any wear, and that was minor. (The edge of one of the pieces was starting to come apart, but just barely.)  All in all, I'm glad I made this purchase.

I don't usually like to wear slippers around the house because they either feel heavy and clunky or they are dangerous because they have a tendency to slip (no pun intended) on the carpet.  Usually, I just wear socks around the house to keep my feet warm.  These slippers are so warm and comfortable, however, that I purchased two pairs (one blue and one black).  The slippers, with their surface-gripping bottoms, give me stability while walking across slippery surfaces, and the nice and soft interior keeps tootsies happy! :)  Love 'em!

It took a while to get the necklace, but it was shipped from China.  Right out of the envelop, I was impressed by this necklace.  What impressed me most was the relative accuracy of the land masses on the globe.  Additionally, the globe is tilted on the axis at an angle that appears to be relatively correct.  The globe is a solid mass, and it is about as heavy as a shooter marble.  The colors are nice, too, with the blue for the ocean and the gold for the land. (China is outlined, so I suspect this necklace was originally manufactured for Chinese consumers.)Although this necklace is very cute, the quality just isn't there.  The first time I wore it, the chain came apart and the globe fell to the floor. When that happened, I examined it a little more closely, and discovered that joint between the two halves of the globe were not aligned correctly.  I put it back together, but it came apart again, the globe fell out and rolled away.  The globe rotates almost completely around, but the misaligned part gets stuck and prevents the globe from spinning around completely.  So I thought I'd try to correct that, and is was able to bend the metal with my fingers.  I didn't really expect all that much for the price, but it would have been nice if it lasted longer than one day.UPDATE: 2/1/2013I sent an e-mail to the company, notifying them of the quality issues, and received an automated message in reply.  The message said the office was closed to celebrate the Chinese New Year, and asked not to post a negative review until they had a chance to make things right.  So I will post an update if they correct the problem.  It's possible this was just a defective product in the batch.  We'll see.  Until then, it remains to be seen what they will do, and I do not recommend this product.UPDATE:  2/12/14 The seller contacted me, and we are communicating.UPDATE: 2/17/2014  The seller is shipping a new necklace to replace the defective product.  I will post an update when the replacement is received.UPDATE: 3/16/2014  The replacement necklace finally arrived, with the globe inserted into the necklace upside down. :) This necklace isn't as bad as the other one, and it hasn't fallen apart this time. The two halves are still not aligned correctly, but it's not as bad as it was before.  It's very pretty, but it's not great quality. Overall, this necklace is only so-so. I wouldn't bother to send it back, but I don't expect it to last very long, either.

The fit of this robe was odd.  In some ways, it was too large, and in other ways, it was too big.  There was too much fabric in the upper part of the robe, and I couldn't seem to pull the robe tightly even around my waist.  The length, however, was so short that it hiked up way too high, even when wearing the matching pj bottoms.  I expected it to be short, from the picture, but I didn't expect to feel like I was wearing a button-down shirt instead of a robe.  The long sleeves were the perfect length.  The fabric is warm soft and warm, but there isn't enough of it.Goldilocks wouldn't even like the way this robe fit me.  It's too big, it's too small, and it just isn't right.

The 2014 version of the Grammy Nominees is a solid album.  There are a lot of stand-out songs in this collection. "Brave," for example, is brilliant, and it has a powerful social message, too.  This year's collection includes some selections that are edgier and riskier than songs included in previous collections.  With great risks, the highs can be higher than normal ("Just Give Me a Reason"), but the lows can be lower than normal ("Retrograde").The songs selected for this CD seemed to represent the different types of music more equally this year than has been the case in the past; previous collections have been more heavily weighted towards the pop charts than those selected this year.  The collection also included multiple examples of blended genres ("Highway Don't Care" - country, pop and classic rock, for example), following a growing trend in the music industry.A short overview of each song follows."Locked Out of Heaven," has a 1980's style introduction, and segues into a more modern dance song though the use of sound effects.  The song is full of sexual innuendo, and some people (but not me) may consider the lyrics sacrilegious.  ***WINNER - Best Pop Album, "Unorthodox Jukebox"***"Blurred Lines," blends reggae with a 1970's disco beat and current day lingo, and then throws in some rap for good measure.  The topic covered here is sexual fantasies about a good girl.  The more explicit aspects of the lyrics have been glossed over, giving this song a bit of a blurry effect.In "Royals," the singers reject the materialism of everyday society.  They ( aren't into money or status symbols, and the music cleverly reflects that message.  It's very creative. ***WINNER - Best Pop Solo***WINNER - Song of the Year***"Radioactive" stats off in a peaceful manner, and the music changes dramatically when the singer wakes up to discover a nuclear bomb has gone off.  From the time the singer wakes up, the beat is heavy, and the tempo is slow.  The background music during the song sounds shaky, like a radio transmission being disrupted by interfering static.  The gasping breath, in and then out adds an artistic touch."Get Lucky" is a good electronica dance song.  The lyrics are sparse and could be interpreted as having a double meaning, the most obvious of the two meanings being the one with the sexual overtones.  ***WINNER - Best Pop/Duo Group*** WINNER - Record of the Year"*** ***Winner - Album of the Year***"Roar" is a fun pop song.  I love the use of Mohammad Ali's, "Float like a butterfly, sting like a bee," which was very appropriate to the message of the song."Mirrors" is a nice, slow pop love song.  Justin Timberlake demonstrates his potential as a songwriter, making me wonder what he'll be writing in ten years."Brave," is a soft pop song, with an important message about the power of standing up for yourself.  Sara Bareilles has an terrific voice that is powerful and full of emotion. Wow!"Same Love," starts with a simple piano introduction.  Profound words of acceptance are voiced over the piano lines in this rap song.  Mary Lambert sings each chorus, explaining that she is who she is, and that she loves her girlfriend.  The song fades out with a Biblical reference and a soft piano.  ***WINNER Best New Artist, Macklemore & Lewis***"Retrograde," with its heavy dissonance sounds is one of the riskier songs in the collection.  Do you like the sound of a balloon, when the air is being allowed to slowly escape from the value?  No?  Well, I don't like this song because the instrumentals sound like that squealing balloon to me.  They just make me cringe.  It's a funeral dirge that gasped its last breath and then somebody jumped up and down on it, trying to squeeze the last bit of air out of its lungs.  You get the point.  To be fair, James Blake sounds like he has a nice voice, but the quality of it is inconsistent in this song."Swimming Pools" is an original song, exploring the dangers of alcohol.  During the song, Kendrick's conscience "speaks" to him.  One of the singers has an extremely deep, bass voice."Lego House," is an easy listening song with a bit of a twist.  Ed Sheeran sings so quickly during portions of the song that it makes me wonder if he's had training as an auctioneer.  This is a beautiful love song."Just Give Me a Reason," a duet by Pink and Nate Ruess is one of the strongest songs on the albums.  It's not fun! but it's definitely a great song. ;)"Begin Again," allows Taylor Swift an opportunity to show off her singer/songwriting chops in this pop/country cross-over song about moving on and getting over an old boyfriend.In a traditional country song, a series of "What is your..." questions are posed.  Blake Shelton sings the question, followed by the answer, "Mine Would Be You."  That silken voice punches out the lyrics.It is amazing the number of ways 'Mary' can be used, as shown in "Merry Go `Round."  The style of this song is blue-grass, with the sounds of a banjo being plucked.  Kacey Musgraves has a sweet voice, softening the gloominess of the lyrics.  ***WINNER - Best Country Album***The song "Highway Don't Care" is another example of a great duet created by the collaboration of two mega-stars.  The use of a song within a song is very clever, and I love that electric guitar!Finally, "Take a Little Ride with You," is a good country song about enjoying the open road in your pickup and your woman.Take advantage of an opportunity to take a mini-break from the freezing temperatures, buy this CD, and put it on play.  With music this good, the temperature won't seem quite so bad.UPDATED 1/26/2014 with results and additional thoughtsWith a staggering number of nominees every year, the list of nominees who were not included on this album is always long. Although I've often wondered why some artists, who seemed like obvious choices were not included, I have always tried to rate the current year's album on the music that is included (which is almost always fabulous), rather than the music that is not included.  All of the winners can be seen at the official Grammy dot... website.In the spirit of recognition of those lost on the cutting room floor, some winners who were not included on the album, but who received their nominations live during the Grammy Awards include:WINNER - Best Rock Song "Cut Me Some Slack" by Dave Grohl, Paul McCartney, Krist Novoselic & Pat Smear.WINNER - Best Rap/Sung Collaboration "Holy Grail" Jay Z and Beyonc.WINNER - Music Educator Award Kent Knappenberger  1st Year awarded. A new and wonderful category!  Thanks to all music educators!  :)

For genuine fans of jigsaw puzzles, this little puzzle is quite a gem, but it is not a perfect product.  The reader is advised to take the word "little" quite literally in the case of this puzzle.  The entire assembled puzzle is roughly the size of a 3x5" index card (like the cards you used for tracking references when writing a research paper for English class back in the day.)  Be sure to take a look at the picture provided on the Amazon product page.The shapes of the pieces are quite interesting and unusual, and they fit together in a manner that is similar, but surprisingly different than a paper-based puzzle.  Many of the adjoining edges have extremely tiny linking details; this is a feature that causes the puzzle to be a bit fragile.  Because of this feature, however, I do not recommend the puzzle for children who have not yet learned to handle things with patience and a delicate touch.  The pieces do not lock together, so, to keep from having to chase the assembled portion around the table surface, I used one hand to hold the pieces together and the other had to add another piece.  Additionally, since the puzzle does not rely a standard straight-line grid that is used on many machine-cut puzzles, the reference provided by the relatively straight alignment of pieces.  The pieces in this puzzle are not aligned in any manner, which adds to the complexity of assembly.  :)The picture is very nice, with a lot of details.  The surface of the puzzle, with its matte finish, is glare-free.  If you like to use puzzle glue, it would make a nice picture to put in a frame.A little bit of the color transferred off of the puzzle pieces onto my fingers, so be sure to select your assembly area accordingly.  (I don't think it would be a good idea to assemble the puzzle on a white linen table cloth.)  The empty re-sealable plastic bag containing the puzzle piece has residue, too.  (The color washed right off my fingers with normal hand soap.)One of the most interesting features of this puzzle is the tactile sensation you get from holding the wooden pieces in your fingers.  It is very interesting, and it's much more similar to holding a cardboard puzzle piece than I expected it to be.  When all things have been considers, all jigsaw puzzle fans should experience assembling this, or a similar puzzle.  It's an interesting experience, and the difficulty level is much harder than would be expected for a puzzle with only forty pieces.

"Give the People What They Want," is, in a word, marvelous.  Sharon Jones has an incredibly rich and noteworthy voice.  She lays down tracks that sound like a cross between one of the best jazz bands you have ever heard, a soul group and a 1960's-style Motown group.  There isn't a sour note to be found on this album, and every song on this album is strong."Retreat" -As she belts out the lyrics to "Retreat," Ms. Jones' voice is tinged with the enjoyment and satisfaction she would feel putting the man in his place.  As incredible as her voice is, when she hits the high notes, she does so with class, her powerful voice fully supported by every musician's best friend, a strong diaphragm.  (If you're not familiar with the reference, the diaphragm is the muscle below your lungs that allows you to project your voice)  The saxophone countermelody and the echoing refrains of "Retreat" from the group add to the fun, giving the song a party atmosphere.  The lyrics and the music make this a song of retribution "Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned." You have, indeed, been warned!"Stranger to My Happiness" starts out with sound effects that resemble the sounds you'd hear from an alien spaceship.  A strong bass sax line starts up, and the song takes off.  The "alien" sound effects and the frequent repetition of "mystery" create the illusion that the singer doesn't know or understand how this man has such strong power over her, making her do things that are against her better judgment.The song, "We Get Along" is a soft song with a strong message on the importance of trying to get along with other people.  The message starts on a personal level, and is expanded out to the world at large with a touching verse about war.The rest of the album lives up to the high standards set by the first three songs on the album.  Each song is interesting in its own right, and for different reasons.  Don't hesitate.  Just treat yourself buy this album.  I did, and it's incredible!

There is a reverberating effect played on the keyboard throughout the song that seems to be the representation of a pulsar.  Taken along with the concept of a dark star and the vastness of the universe, this gives the song the overtones of alien origins from outer space.  Jaymes Young has a smooth voice, with a decent range, that is very pleasant to listen to.  I downloaded this song during a free promotion.

Ah, Life on the road, for the sake of your music.  While you're driving from coast to coast, playing gigs around the country, your vehicle is taking a beating.  The majority of this song is played in a positive and upbeat manner.  The guitars and the drums rock!  The song is very catchy, and the lyrics are interesting to listen to.  The ending of the song is different than the rest of the song, with an electric guitar note that reverberates for several seconds.  It has the effect of making you wait while you wonder what will be played next.  Perhaps it is meant to mimic the feeling of traveling endlessly back and forth across the country."Coast to Coast" is short (under two minutes), but it's long enough to get an idea of the talent behind the group, Waxahatchee. There's a lot of talent on display in this song, and it's very enjoyable to listen to. Thanks for the free download! I'm looking forward to hearing more.  By the way, there is a 10-minute video produced by National Public Radio (NPR) on Waxahatchee.  It's free on You Tube, and it's very enjoyable.  :)

A classic rock tempo (a la the 1970s), supported by great electric guitars, drums and lyrics, provide the frame for the story about an incorrigible childhood friend in Boston Square.  The singer has great memories of the friendship, and growing up in each others company.  They part ways, and the friendship is lost to the passage of time.  The singer, however, misses the friend a great deal.  That comes through strongly in the last verse, when the singer thinks he catches a glimpse of the friend.  The style of the song softens, changing abruptly and dramatically, but picking back up again when the singer realizes he has to be wrong.The lyrics left me with the impression that the friend had committed suicide, and that the singer blamed the devil for the loss of his friend.  The story was so sad that I searched the Internet to see if I could learn a little bit more.  According to a web site that lists song facts (dot com), one of the members of the band, in an interview with Kerrang! (an English magazine), said that Boston Square was a tribute to a childhood friend who had committed suicide.  That is very touching.  I downloaded the song during a free promotion, and appreciate the opportunity to hear the music of this group.

After looking at the picture, I expected the sleep shirt to be long.  However, I didn't expect it to feel a bit tight around the hips.  Additionally, when wearing the shirt, the neck line feels fine when you're sitting up.  However, it doesn't have any give at all, so when you sleep, it has a tendency to become a bit constricting, and it feels like it's too small, even though there is plenty of room (over 2", in my case) in the neck while sitting up.  I like sleepwear that isn't as tight.  It's not bad enough that I'm sending it back, but it's not a favorite of mine, either.

If this is supposed to be the Earth, then the manufacturer needs a very basic lesson in Geography.  To draw a representation of the Earth, you cannot just take a blue ball and plop green blobs on it; the green blobs of the land areas need to have some type of correlation with reality.  In this day of computers, it would seem to be a simple matter of duplicating reality, and printing it on the ball.  In a class I took once, we had to draw the Earth from memory as part of the final.  My drawing skills would not, even remotely, be considered to be marketable.  I can assure you, however, that I could draw a picture of the Earth that represents reality much better than the (so-called) globes in this package.Note that one of the pictures of this product showed longitude and latitude lines, and one did not.  I received a package that did not include these markings, which was fine.  But if you want those markings, they are not there.  Also be advised that the globes are just a little bigger than a golf ball, so they arent as large as normal stress balls.  Im a woman, and I wrap my hand around the world so that it is hidden.I had wanted to use these Earth balls as part of a networking plan with global outreach.  There is no way I want people to associate my name with these inferior products, so they are being bounced back to Amazon for a refund.

Soft strumming of the acoustic guitar introduces the song.  The vocalist joins in after a couple of bars, and begins singing in a voice that is wispy but crisp.  When the electric guitars and the drums jump in a couple of lines later, they do so with no reservations, briefly drowning out the singer's voice.When everyone joins in, the song becomes very energetic and fun.  The singer brings up the volume to the point where she can almost be heard clearly.  But the listener still needs to struggle to hear the lyrics at times, especially when she sings in the lower range of her voice.  Strangely, that unevenness simply adds to an overall effect that the band is just hanging out in someone's backyard garage, jammin' and having a lot of fun.As the song progresses, the distortion increases and guitars and the vocals become muddier and muddier.  This effect is especially interesting when it plays out on the electric guitar.  The music starts to sound wobbly, like a warped record that is being played on a turntable, and the sound waves are being distorted.  All in all, it's a very interesting effect."Dust in the Gold Sack" could just as easily have been called "Cracks in the Ceiling" since both phrases are repeated throughout the song.  Either way, the sentiment of the line is the same.  Things break down over time (seven years, in the case of this song).  I'm looking forward to figuring out what all of the lyrics are.  The ones I can make out sound very interesting.  Any song that includes phrases such as "crunch of the black ice" and "green alligators" is sure to be a lot of fun.

Black Widow is an exquisite song.  The dreamy music floats across the room on light and airy sound waves, entering the listener's ears and enchanting with a magical spell.  The lyrics are about a person from the singers past who lived a dangerous life-style, and is called Black Widow.The vocalist sings like she is lost in vivid and extraordinary memories from her past with Black Widow.  Her voice is reflective, wistful and full of longing.  She sings as if she knows she's incapable of resisting the allure of Black Widow, and she is resigned to her upcoming fate.The keyboards are perfectly understated, allowing the vocals of Sarah Chernoff to shine.  The very soft music is accented with ringing bell-like accents in the upper range that help to emphasize the range of Ms. Chernoffs voice. The precise timing of all of the musicians helps to maintain the ethereal feeling of the song all the way to the end.  Listening to this peaceful song, Im reminded of the clearest water in a mountain lake.  It's calm on the surface, but what's happening under the surface?Ms. Chernoff is a soprano.  She is extremely talented at singing in a high register, and her voice never breaks or becomes shrill.  She has a voice that is pure and flawless.  With a voice as exceptional as hers, youre sure to be hearing a lot more about her.  Thanks for the free download of a great song!

This is a great song.  It is very catchy and upbeat, and it includes some very interesting electronic sound effects.  Overall, the music tends to generate positive feelings in the listener.  (Yeah, I admit it, I was nodding my head to the tempo of the music the very first time I listened to it.)  Simply put, the song just sounds like everyone involved is having a lot of fun.That is, the song sounds like a lot of fun until the listener allows the lyrics to fully register in the mind.  It's then that the listener will realize that the words focus on a very serious subject - some of the types of mental disorders afflicting a segment of our population.  The subject is discussed in a very subtle way, by describing the behaviors.  While these serious conditions are being sung about, the peppy music, with the singer who sounds happy, continues.  This generates the feeling that the people who are being described (and perhaps even the listener and/or society at large) are in a state of denial about how serious their conditions are, and how their conditions are impacting their lives, and the lives of those around them.  The good vibes of the music simply lull the listener into thinking that everything is fine.Was this song written as a social satire, or as a commentary on the tendency of our society to allow too many people who are in need of mental health treatment to slip through the cracks?  It's hard to tell, and I'm not yet familiar with Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr.'s work; however, he has a very nice voice, and I plan to listen to more of his music in the future. Time will tell.  Meanwhile, I'll mull it over.

"Games" has a nice upbeat sound and a great dance beat.  I enjoyed listening to the music, and it has all of the elements that will make it a successful pop hit.  (It's catchy, it has a good beat, it has an upbeat sound, and the message will strike a chord with listeners.)  Consequently, I suspect it is one of those tunes that you're going to get stuck in your head and you'll keep hearing it over and over again. The lyrics are very strong, and tell the story of the effect the actions of a person who plays games can have on the other person's emotional state.The vocals, however, seem to be a just a bit off.  For one thing, they are strongly accented in some unusual places.  There are also some strange vocalizations in the background that sound like a sick crow cawing.  It could be that the sound effects are supposed to mimic a cry of agony from a tortured soul, but I'm not sure.  It just didn't translate well for me.  And finally, there were some places in the music when the singing seemed slightly out of tune.  Again, that could be intentional. None of these things were bad enough to ruin the song, so I'll assume they were intentional sound effects.As a whole, I like the song.  The strong points outweigh the weak points, so I'm rating it (on the lighter side of) four stars.  And I plan to check out other songs by Claire to see how they compare, and I'll update my review when I've had a chance to make some comparisons.Thanks for the free download.  By the way - I love that cover art!

To categorize "Defeated No More" as simply electronic and/or dance (or any other existing category) would be to understate the sheer novelty of the music.  The slow and steady tempo helps to keep the song from seeming overly long at six minutes, but that's not the only thing that keeps it from seeming like a song that lasts too long.  The song has a very unique and original sound, with new-age accents thrown in here and there.  It is fascinating, and it makes you want to hear what's going to happen next.  Although the song lasts for six minutes, the time seems to fly by, as you get lost in the music.The song is very laid-back, but the insistent rhythmic thumping of the padded bass drum pedal calls you to dance.  The percussions also include clapping (or keyboards made to sound like clapping), which is a good technique for engaging an audience.  To cap it off, the cymbals are played with brushes rather than drum sticks.  As the brush hits the cymbal, it has the effect of softening and diffusing that sharply precise <TWACK> that is more typically produced by drummers using drum sticks.The vocals are interesting, too.  The message in the lyrics matches the style of the music quite well.  The song is about a woman who broke up with a man and hurt him badly, and she wants to get back together.  Instead of allowing her to see that she still has an effect on him, he is taking it slow and easy, and allowing the fire to build back up, while always maintaining control of his emotions to see if she is capable of committing to him.  Both of the brothers have very pleasant voices, and one of them is even able to maintain the quality of his voice in the falsetto range.I'm so amazed this was offered as part of a free promotion!  Thank you!  Extremely highly recommended!

If you are a fan of hard-driving rock and roll guitars, you will probably enjoy, "The Swan."  Since the focus of this song is really on the guitars, the vocals seem to be a bit of an afterthought, but it doesn't seem to matter much, since you're listening to a band that is enjoying a jamming session.  I feel that the guitar notes are a bit too repetitive, and I would have liked to have heard more variety, but I enjoyed the song, nonetheless.

The first time I listened to this song, I liked it.  After listening to it several times, that like had grown to love.  The interplay between the vocals and the guitar is phenomenal. The blend of the softly stated electric guitar played by John Gnossis and the unusual voice of Katie Bernstein transform this song from a good song to a great one.  Katie Bernstein's voice has a bit of a twang, but not in an even remotely country and western style.  Instead, her voice is filled with expression, as are the guitar lines, which are played in quite an expressive and emotive manner.

The music is soft rock, and the voices of the "On an On" musicians blend very nicely.  The musical effects are soothing and ethereal, including the guitars, keyboards, haunting vocal accent echoes and soft drum rolls.  This song is light and dreamy, and very pleasant to listen to.  There isn't anything frightening about this dreamy and beautiful ghost song.  Thanks for the free download!

"Deficit" is a very dark and moody instrumental song.  It is very atmospheric, and is something that I would expect to hear playing in the background of a movie about ghosts, as the tension is building towards the climax.  The second half of the song is a bit more upbeat, with a quicker tempo and more metallic highlights, but it would still be quite at home in a ghost movie.  It seems to drag on a bit longer than what seemed realistic for a song of this type, since the tension cannot last forever.  The weakest part of the song played out in the last 10 seconds or so, with seemingly otherworldly transmissions that didn't seem to fit in with the rest of the song.  But it was offered as part of a free promotional download, and for that, I'll round the rating up to four stars.

"Coast to Coast" is a surprisingly short song (under two minutes), but it's enough to get an idea of the talented singer-songwriter behind the name, Waxahatchee.  The lyrics are interesting to listen to, and the drums and guitars rock.  The ending of the song in stylistically different than the rest of the song, and it has the effect of making you wait while you wonder what's next.  And then it abruptly cuts off, sounding like the needle was pulled off of the record, and the song is finished.  But I'm still intrigued, and I'm wondering what is next.  There's a lot of talent on display in this song, and it's very enjoyable.  Thanks for the free download! I'm looking forward to hearing more.

This ring is extremely beautiful.  I love the design (especially the middle portion of the band, with the stones), and the silver is the perfect metal for highlighting the cool beauty of the stones.However, I am heartbroken because the prongs holding the tanzanite to the right are sharp and pointy.  I'm torn between my desire to keep this ring and the desire to return it before it creates snags on my clothes.  I plan to exchange it, and hope that the replacement doesn't have the same flaw.  If it still has sharp and pointy prongs, it will be a good thing I have 30 days to decide...When I receive the replacement, I will update my review.UPDATE: 1/8/2013I received a replacement ring, and this ring does not have sharp and pointy prongs.  Note that, because of the individual prongs on the white topaz, the ring is just a tiny bit rough to the touch when you run your index finger over the stones.  It's not bad, and I probably only noticed it because of the sharp prongs on the first ring, but I would not want to wear this ring with extremely delicate fabrics.  Otherwise, the ring is positively delightful, and I love it! Since the issue with the sharp prongs has been resolved, I'm revising my rating to 5 stars. :)

The pendant of this necklace is very interesting.  The snowflake and the disk weigh different amounts (the snowflake is lighter), so when you move, even though they are hooked onto the same ring, they move at different speeds. As the snowflake dances around in front of the crystal disc, the appearance of the snowflake seems to change.  I know it's an optical illusion, and it's enhanced by the slight curvature in the crystal disk, but it's an intriguing effect.  When you look at the necklace, it looks like you are seeing different snowflakes, all with unique designs, dancing around in the wind.The necklace looks best when it is worn against a dark background since the crystals pick up the color of the top you are wearing, and reflect those colors back to you. Note that when I looked at the necklace straight out of the box, I couldn't see a lot of sparkles from the crystals, so I wasn't sure I was going to like the necklace as much as I do.  It wasn't until I put the necklace on that the crystals started to sparkle quite a bit.  The snowflake portion of the pendant is beautiful, and it would look nice as a stand-alone necklace, but you'd have to pry the necklace ring open to separate the two.  It wouldn't be possible to wear them separately because you'd ruin the symmetry of the ring the pendants are hanging from, so don't take them apart unless you want to leave them apart permanently.The chain on the necklace isn't too bad for a necklace in this price range, but I'm not impressed with the parts that connect the ends of the chain to the clasp to the clasp hardware  It is strange, and it looks like it may have been glued together.  I don't want to risk losing the pendant, so I'll switch out to my own chain.  Meanwhile, I'll keep dancing like no one is watching so I can watch the colors sparkle in the light.

If you think that Rod Stewart has earned his nickname of old gravel throat, then you should hear Lemmy Kilmister.  While I find Rod Stewart's voice pleasant, I cannot say the same thing for Lemmy Kilmister's voice.  It is so raspy that it's painful for me, and I just want to hand him a glass of warm water and ask him to drink it, please.  And was that MF at the end really necessary? The band is great, though. The guitars rock, and the drums are fantastic.For the rating:2 stars - I don't like it for the lead vocals.4 stars - I like it, for the instrumentalsSo that averages out to 3 stars.  Even though I downloaded it on a free promotion, that voice just grates on my nerves, and I just can't go higher than that.

Meredith Andrews has a pretty voice.  The song begins with alternating verses of "God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen" and "He Has Come For Us."  The music becomes fuller and more lively when "He Has Come For Us" is featured.  After the second verse of "God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen," the remaining song is devoted to "He Has Come For Us."  The song has a soft rock beat, and includes backup singers.  It is nicely done.  The fact that it was offered as a free download was just delightful frosting on the cake.

Since Amazon sells this product in a pack of four, I was taking a risk by purchasing it when I've never tried this flavor before.  But I like gingerbread, and I like most syrups, so I decided to take a chance.  When I opened the bottle, I noticed  the aroma is QUITE strong).  The first time I used it, I added just a tiny bit to my hot coffee.  It was good, but I was surprised that the flavor of the syrup came through so strongly, even after being diluted by the coffee.  It struck me that the thing that is missing is sugar, so I added a lot of sugar substitute and a lot of milk, and that seemed to do the trick.  After experimenting, I discovered that brown sugar complements the flavor quite nicely, but that defeats the purpose of buying the syrup in the sugar free version, doesn't it?  Every time I added a normal-sized portion of this syrup to a liquid, I regretted it, since the flavor of spices became overpowering.  So I'll add a drop here and a drop there, and maybe I'll use this up some time in the next decade.  :\

The Paper Kites is a good group.  From this product page, however, you can't listen to samples.  It took me a minute to figure it out, but you can listen to samples from the albums.  Under the drop down menu of MP3 Music on Amazon, type "Paper Kites."  You will see the icons for the two albums included on this set.  You need to click on each of the individual albums to hear the samples.  (The cover art on the individual albums is nicer.) It would have been nice to get the MP3 version included in this set, but for the price, I can upload it myself.All of the songs from the two albums, "Woodland" and "Young North" are including in this compilation album.  It's a good price (currently $6.49) because if you pay for the two albums separately, it will set you back $8.98 total.  Note, however, that even though the two albums are combined, you are only getting a total of eleven songs.  The style is indie singer-songwriter type of music.  You've probably heard their music before, and you'll recognize at least some of these songs.  It's very soft and nice to listen to.
