The speakers interferes too easily with the built-in mic and the mic is just too far to the point where I need to raise my voice enough so that the people on the opposite end of Skype, Curse Voice, Raidcall, etc, to hear me properly.Okeyn's mic is pretty well done as it arrives with a long cable and is just a simple plug and play away from being used right out of the box.The triple pod stand itself is simple to use and helps raise the mic to the ideal height on my desk. The metallic mesh material on the mic is durable and the grippy texture helps reduce the chance of me dropping the mic while in use. I did not have to tinker with the microphone settings too much, as it worked fine with the settings it came with.Overall, the Okeyn microphone works as well as expected and was simple to setup. Having a stand means I can just have the mic angled at me directly without the need to continuously adjust the distance. No issues with speaking into the mic from a few inches to a few feet away either.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

I bought these specifically for watching my backlog of many slice of life anime series that does a number on my kokoro. I've made the terrible mistake once when I watched Clannad: After Story and never would I watch another series without a box of Kleenex on hand to prepare me for the gut-wrenching feels. The tissue quality is soft and absorbent and is perfect for salty tears.I swear, by the end of Shigatsu Wa Kimi No Uso, I've already gone through an entire box of tissues. Thankfully, an 8-pack would last me through Summer Season of 2015 at the very least.

I've recently purchased the new Dell XPS 13 (2015) Ultrabook that uses the Mini DisplayPort as its primary output port. This effectively means that none of the HDMI cables I've purchased prior will work with this laptop without some sort of adapter or cable. Thankfully, Sabrent provides me with a simple solution in the form of a Mini DisplayPort (Thunderbolt) to HDMI converter cable.The 5 inch, white cable itself is made of solid and durable material that should withstand wear even after extended use. Functionality-wise, it works exactly as expected. I have successfully connected my Dell XPS 13 to the HDMI cable via this converter and the 1080P output signal on my HDTV was crisp and clear. I have not experienced any flickering or artifacts as with other third party converters.On the other hand, it should be noted that I did experience wifi signal drops completely while this adapter is plugged into the Mini DisplayPort, which is really weird. I've tried other adapter cables (that are not Thunderbolt) and those seems to work fine.In any case, I'll continue to monitor this occurrence and update it if I find anything new to report in this regard. Perhaps I'll borrow a Macbook from my friend and see if the same issue applies.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

Allreli's latest version of the Apple accessory comes in the form of a MFi certified Lightning charge cable compatible with all of Apples latest iPhone, iPad, and iPod products using the latest standard charge port. The Lightning cable itself comes in a generous 3.3ft length, making it compatible with the majority of computer USB ports, USB wall chargers, and external batteries. The cables durable material also appears to be sturdy and tangle-free, giving off the feeling that this will last me until my next phone update. I also like the snazzy blue on black pattern that sets the cable apart from its market competition.More importantly, I have not experienced any "not supported" error message when using this cable with my iPhone, so far.Charging rate is the same as my original Apple Lightning cable.An excellent, cheaper alternative Lightning cable that I'll keep in my office at work for emergency recharges.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

I have been using EasyAcc's basic portable battery charger for the past few days and it has definitely been handle on multiple occasions.Firstly, the EasyAcc 2nd Generation Metal model is an ultra-portable external battery with a whopping 6,400mAh charge capacity. For the most part, the unit has a smooth metal chasis that gives the unit a solid and high quality feel. On one end, you will find a single standard USB output rated at 5V/2Av (max) for charging most smartphones and tablets efficiently. Next to it is a surprisingly big power button, as well as a micro-USB charge port.Using an iPhone 6 for reference, I was able to get about 150% of power from a full charge on average.For reference, here are some common devices and the amount of mAh of capacity they have when they are fully charged:* iPhone 5 battery 1440 mAh battery capacity* iPhone 5S battery 1560 mAh battery capacity* iPad 2 battery 6,944 mAh battery capacity* iPad 3 battery 11,560 mAh battery capacity* iPad 4th (gen.) battery is 11,486 mAh 3.7 VDC at 42.5 Wh* iPad Mini battery is 4490 mAh at 3.72 VDC 16.7 WhThe simplicity and hassle-free nature of the units design and function is this products most underrated selling point. It is almost a daily occurrence where I or a close companion find ourselves out and about and is suddenly in need of a recharge for their smartphone. As most households usually carry at least one electronic device, such as a smartphone or tablet, this makes the device indubitably versatile and accessible in most daily situations.Items in the box includes:1 x EasyAcc Power Bank1 x Micro USB Charging Cable (20 cm)1 x User ManualNo AC wall adapter was provided, but most standard 5V/1A wall charger should work with this product.For the price and, the EasyAcc metal portable external battery is definitely worth it as an entry external battery model that is suitable for a wide variety of events and situations.

I have been using EC Technology's new compact Bluetooth speaker for the past few days and my general impression is very positive overall. The unit itself comes with a stylish brick-like design with rubberized finish. The red on black high-contrast color scheme gives the product an aesthetically striking and eye-catching appearance. Every button on the speaker are very accessible in the front, most notably the volume control buttons and Play/Pause button.The versatility of this speaker model is based on its ability to play my music tracks from a variety of sources. The built-in Bluetooth technology lets me connect to virtually all of my Bluetooth-capable electronic devices. There are a slight delay for them to register after each press, however. Manual functions will only respond when the speaker is connected to the media device via Bluetooth, naturally. I was glad to find that theres the alternative auxiliary port hidden under a water resistant cover along with the micro-USB charge port. The aux jack is mainly there for connecting to my smartphone, tablet, and Ultrabook with the provided 3.5mm audio cable.Despite the surprisingly compact design of the portable speaker, the unit does output very deep and impressive audio. Bass-heavy tracks retained most of the lows and high notes and does not suffer from the same noise distortion at high volume levels that are commonly experienced with smaller portable speakers. At higher volume levels, one can even feel the air vibration coming out from the speaker grill. Per my testing, the Bluetooth speaker maintained a stable wireless connection to my iPhone 6 from opposite ends of the office (around 20 feet or so). Even after my multi-hour long test sessions with this device, the speaker have yet to need recharging, and should have no problems lasting for around 6 hours before needing a recharge.One thing I would change would be a toggle option for the voice assistant built-into the unit that vocally sounds out when I turn on to connecting to Bluetooth devices. A voice command that's more subtle would have been much appreciated.I understand that the speaker is marketed as waterproof (or water resistant in the description), but I would highly discourage submerging the unit underwater anytime. Usage in the bathroom while showering in steamy mist should be alright. Again, the essential charge and aux ports are covered adequately with a rubber flap, as long as you are using Bluetooth to connect your devices.Packaging Contents Include:- EC Technology Wireless Bluetooth Speaker- An Auxiliary Audio Cable (3.5mm)- One Standard Micro-USB Charge Cable- A User ManualOverall, in terms of the products build and sound quality, functionality, as well as versatility, this product has exceeded my initial expectations and I will give it a 5/5 stars.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

I often have to get up to use the restroom late at night in the dark.With this motion sensing sensor light, I can rest easy, knowing that there's no zombie waiting for me down the hallway.Package Included:- iSolem LED motion sensing light- Two side tape- Some screws- A Lengthy USB charge cable- User manual

The hot summer holiday is here and there's no better way to keep cool than to make refreshing squeezed fruit drinks combined with crushed ice.Jumblr's fruit juicer is an effective device for separating the juice from an assortment of oranges, berries, lemon, and melons without making a mess out of the kitchen table.The transparent bowl is capable of holding up to 14 ounces of liquid. (Measurements are displayed on the side of the base.) Furthermore, the bottom portion of the base is rubberized and non-slip, ensuring there's no accidental spills from overly aggressive squeezing.All in all, this is a fun and efficient juicing device and I cannot wait to use this with even more fruits this hot summer.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

With a clean, yet vibrant chocolate bar design, EMIE Memo's 8000 mAh external battery charger is solidly built and weighs in at around just shy of 7 oz. I was able to carry the portable battery with me in my hoodie pocket or backpack effortlessly. All available ports are placed on the sides of the device, as well as a 5V/2A (max) standard USB output charge port that is compatible with an assortment of USB-chargeable electronics.When testing the battery on its functionality, I connected my iPhone 6 (as well as an assortment of other devices later on) to the battery device with the appropriate charge cable. Charging my phone from 10% to full took around an hour or so. I was able to get at least two full charges for my phone before the battery pack ran out of power. This is with the phone on, connected, and with apps running in the background.An LED indicator light lets me know how much battery life is left based on its color, with red being 60%-100%, blue 30%-60%, and green 0%-30% remaining. Strangely enough, I feel that the color indicators seem reversed in this case.Again, no Apple charge cable or adapters were provided, but the original Lightning cable that came with my phone was able to charge and recharge the battery just fine. A micro-USB standard cable is provided for me to recharge the battery once it was used up.Features:-8000 mAh battery capacity-Single USB port that detects the connected device and smartly outputs the specific charge rate to ensure there's no overcharging or overheating issues-No AC wall charger or charge cable was provided with this unit, but it is compatible and will recharge with any standard USB wall charger, including my Apple wall chargerFor reference, here are some common devices and the amount of mAh of capacity they have when they are fully charged:* iPhone 5 battery 1440 mAh battery capacity* iPhone 5S battery 1560 mAh battery capacity* iPad 2 battery 6,944 mAh battery capacity* iPad 3 battery 11,560 mAh battery capacity* iPad 4th (gen.) battery is 11,486 mAh 3.7 VDC at 42.5 Wh* iPad Mini battery is 4490 mAh at 3.72 VDC 16.7 WhAs noted, you will not be able to fully charge the latest Apple iPad with the Retina display, as this is only a 800 mAh capacity battery that emphasizes on a slim form factor rather than a charging power house. You must also consider the losses in the charging circuits of both the battery and the device you are charging. When using an external battery, one must take the heat transfer, voltage conversion, and the electronics of your devices charging circuits into consideration. Other contributing factors include running background apps on your smartphone/tablet, as well as its connectivity to Wi-Fi or the LTE networkThis product is solid, functional, and well-designed. I rate it at 5 stars and will encourage anyone who is always on the go and likes to fiddle on their smartphones a lot to give this product a try.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

Aukey's wireless Bluetooth speaker model brings a familiar tried and true compact tin can design to their latest wireless Bluetooth product. Material-wise, the majority of the speaker has a soft, matte finish to it. One pet peeve I have with this unit is that the manual controls such as Play/Pause, Forward, and Rewind are all located at the very bottom of the unit and cannot be accessed unless I physically lift the whole unit up. Not a big deal, however. To turn the unit on, a tiny On/Off button is located on the front of the device.Bass-heavy tracks retains most of the lows and high notes thanks to the enhanced bass boost feature and does not suffer from the same noise distortion at high volume levels that are commonly experienced with smaller portable speakers. I've played most of the jazzy tracks from my Kekkai Sensen official OST collection to great effect.Per my testing, the Bluetooth speaker maintained a stable wireless connection to my iPhone 6 from opposite ends of the office (around 30 feet or so). An auxiliary or headphone input port is also available on the Aukey portable speaker for those who would prefer a wired connection. I should also note that the battery life for this product performed admirably, lasting for hours (5+ so far) of non-stop audio playback from a full charge. Quick, simple, and efficient.I did not do any waterproof testing with this product, nor did I ever attempt to submerge it. At best, I brought this speaker with me to the steamy showers. The micro-USB and auxiliary port, however, ARE protected under a thick, rubberized cover, which definitely gives some peace of mind.Included in the package I've received:- Aukey Bluetooth Speaker- A standard micro-USB charge cable- An auxiliary audio cable (male-male)- A detailed user manual for highlighting all of the product's featuresThis is yet another solid entry Bluetooth speaker by Aukey with a waterproof feature in a tried and true form factor. I will definitely bring this with me for my upcoming summer trips and use it with my laptop and tablet.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

Lavievert's stylish bag is designed specifically for the smallest rendition of Apple's Macbook.The bag itself is made of water-resistant, nylon-like material that resembles the exterior of my down jacket. It is fairly lightweight and does seem like it will protect my laptop from scratches and light drops. Nothing too rugged, but does the job reasonably well.I should not that as I do not have the 11 inch Macbook, I've used this product with my Dell XPS 13 (2015), which has a similar footprint as most standard 11 inch laptops due to the shrunken screen bezel. I had no issue with the fitting at all. Additional pockets on one side of the sleeve also lets me store many kinds of smartphones, accessories, Apple Lightning cable, etc. The opposite side has a zipper pocket that is spacious enough for other small components, like an external battery pack. I am impressed with the overall flawlessness of the bag's stitching and zipper quality. A keychain hand strap can also be optionally attached to the side of the bag to ensure that the precious, expensive laptop doesn't get yanked away by surprise.Again, the sleeve isn't made of leather or some high-end material that you would otherwise pay a pricey sum for. Despite this, the interior material is soft and helps protect my laptop computer from scratches and light shock impact when I'm on the go. It should definitely not be considered as a rugged case. The downsides of having a sleek and compact design is that it will obviously not be as effective as a bulky and tanky full protective case. Regardless, it's just common sense for people to always handle their expensive electronics with care, no matter if they are in a protective sleeve or not. Personally, I'd prefer having a pretty looking case over a bulky monstrosity any day.Although the price is relatively competitive compared to some of the better known brands on the market, this sleeve is a very good value and will handily hold your laptop and then some.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

As someone with terrible sleeping posture, I've always experienced neck cramps once in a while. This U-shaped neck support pillow is ideal for long hours of car or airplane rides.The materials consist of cotton and polyester, with the interior microbeads giving off a feel of a beanie. It is fairly lightweight and I had no problem bringing it with me on vacation.From using this product, the strain and stress I impose on my neck from bad sleeping habits has become nearly non-existent. So far, I've not experienced any neck cramps in a while, but time will tell in the long term.Again, for those who absolutely loathe sleeping upright on airplane rides for hours on end, this pillow does make a positive impact.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

Myoho's version of the Apple accessory comes in the form of a MFi certified Lightning charge cable compatible with all of Apples latest iPhone, iPad, and iPod products using the latest standard charge port. The Lightning cable itself comes in a standard 3.3ft length, making it compatible with the majority of computer USB ports, USB wall chargers, and external batteries. The cables durable material also appears to be sturdy and tangle-free, giving off the feeling that this will last me until my next phone update.More importantly, I have not experienced any "not supported" error message when using this cable with my iPhone, so far.Also compatible with most of my iPhone cases, even the durable ones, thanks to its compact connector head.Charging rate is the same as my original Apple Lightning cable.Overall, a very normal and standard charge cable. Combining all of this year's Lightning cables in a drawer and you'll be hard-pressed to differentiate one brand from another's from a quick glance.I was provided a product free of charge in order to provide an honest review.

Some one-size items run huge, some run tiny, but this one fits her perfectly (5'2", 34C, size 6), and the look is WOW.  She said the lace is very comfortable and not itchy (and I thought it felt good too).
Batteries arrived fresh and quickly.  So far, the two I've used work, and I guess we'll find out about longevity and storage as these run down.  I'll post updates...

These bottles were sold by RGSellers, so be aware this review is for bottles from this seller only.Bottles are thick and lids appear to be sturdy, but they do not hold 4oz.  4oz = 118.3ml, and optimum"full"should be to the bottom-shoulder of the bottle, or at worst, to the base of the neck.  Filling these bottles with water... completely full (overflowing), and then measuring the capacity in a graduated cylinder shows these bottles to hold ~113ml if you fill it to the brim.  Filling to the base of the neck (so you can put the cap on) allows you to fill about 111ml (3.75oz), roughly.  So, capacity of these bottles (in ounces) is not 4.0oz!The bottles also arrived very dusty (inside and out), but I always clean and sterilize my glassware before use anyway... just be aware that you will have to clean these!All in all, not a bad purchase, but if you're looking to store measured volumes of liquid in these for retail sale, be aware they will NOT hold 4oz.  If you are using these bottles for retail sales, and someone (like me) measures the product... you'll NOT have a happy customer!
Works the same as OEM, and these actually have better, upgraded internal parts. Price here is nearly half what the local parts house charges!

For the price of this costume, it isn't bad, and it works well for couples.The dress fits up to a size 10, and is adjustable in the waist by a waist-tie which ties in the back.  She is 5'-2" and a size 6-8, and the dress looks great on her.  If you are tall, it may be a little short on you, because this falls above the mid-thigh on her.  The material is a little thicker than your traditional Halloween costumes, and it not see-through, but you may want to wear leggings, tights, or bicycle-style-shorts under it if you are concerned about showing off "the goods".  The key is not much, but not nearly as "flat" as some have complained about.  After it hung from a coat-hook for a day, it fluffed up and the creases (from shipping) came right out.

These TM-LTP-BB are great compression leggings, without all the decorative stitching down the legs.  I have several of these Tesla leggings with the added stitching, and they are great, but for when you need something without colored stitching, these do the trick.  Compression is light, not tight, and the material is not see-through, but if you're wearing them "in public", you may want to consider shorts over them or compression shorts under them, as they do not contain manhood very well or discreetly.  The waistband is the proper height on these (compared to some going to the belly-button).I wear these as a base-layer under jeans during cooler weather (50's), or for outdoor workouts when I need compression and wicking (even when it's hot out).  These wick well and don't bind-up when moving.  The ankle openings are a bit small and tight, so be aware of that when putting them on.

This really does help give body and life to thinner hair, and it actually seems to increase growth-rate as well.  She's been using it for a couple of weeks, and already her hair appears longer, fuller, and thicker.  Her hair is much more manageable in the mornings, and she says she's seeing fewer hairs in her brush (and the shower drain).I bought this as a gift, but she's already ordered two more bottles... one for her daughter, and a spare for her (when this one runs out).

The ring is very beautiful.  The setting is sturdy, and elegant.  Stones are snug and even, although you can turn the Emerald in the mount, slightly, if you really try hard.  The simulated Emerald is a deep forest green, not a cheap pale looking green like some synthetics.  She loved it!The only issue I have with the ring (so far) is that it is NOT stamped anywhere on the band with "SS" or "0.925" as indicated in the description.  If there is any wearing issues (turning skin green), I will be contacting the seller for a refund!!UPDATE:In less than a month of daily wear, the Emerald has become loose in the mount... not bad, but it can be twisted a full 360-degrees with little effort.  With a low heat, and light pressure with ceramic pliers, I was able to tighten it up somewhat, but it may require the skill of a seasoned jeweler to do it right?

I have a 33" waist, and trim build.  These (size M) fit as expected in the length and inseam, but are slightly snug in the hips.  So snug, that you can't actually put your hands into the pockets!  I prefer them to be a little more loose-fitting, but they are still comfortable.  The waist-band fits my natural waist-line, and they stretch enough to allow them to be pulled on.  The waist-tie is not too long, and is comfortable as well.  Even when tied, it is not uncomfortable to lounge or sleep in.  The material could be a little thicker, and the polyester content does make them static-prone.These retail for $32, but for $4 here on Amazon... they're worth every penny for a lounge-pant, but I only wish I had ordered up a size or two.

She is 5'3", and the robe covers to the knee.  The wrap-around is slightly large, but a loose-fit is preferred, as it is comfortable.  The robe is very soft, and absorbent, as well as warm (without being hot).  The tie is not too long.  She only wishes the pockets were larger/deeper.
Exact same as OEM Ford door handle at half the price.  Fits perfectly, works perfectly.

My gal prefers the scent of Silver on me, so I'm so glad I found this identical fragrance as an alternative to the higher-priced, hard-to-find British Sterling Silver!Very few cologne scents smell great on me, or last very long.  So far, only four fit this bill, and two of them smell identical... McGraw Silver and British Sterling Silver (which is discontinued or limited release, but pretty sure they are the same thing, lol).  BTW, the other two favorites are Twilight Woods from Bath & Body Works (which is now discontinued) and British Sterling Reserve H.I.M (black bottle).The scent is fantastic for evenings, but works well for a day-time scent.  It is VERY masculine, without overpowering or smelling like a barn.  It is the perfect blend of wet green leaves, sequoia wood, lavender, orange flower, vetiver, musk, sandalwood and saffron.  The woody undertones and musk are what make this a fantastic evening fragrance, and the lavender, saffron, and orange keep the fragrance light, fresh, and long-lasting.  I can spritz on a little in the morning, and the smell is still there into the evening.  A single spritz is all it takes to "rebuild" the aroma for an evening with my gal.Finding this on Amazon was a bonus because Walmart only carries this for the holidays, and the last bottle I bought was $15/oz.  Also, buying the 1oz bottles for $9 is FAR cheaper than buying the 1.7oz bottles for $30!!  A 1oz bottle lasts a LONG time, too, thanks to an efficient atomizer... I use this several times a week, and 2-3 bottles last all year.

Ordered two at the same time to replace a pair of cheap-o's that actually cost more than these, years ago.  Truly, the colors are random, one was grey/yellow checked, one was green, but they are perfect, and do their job as a stuff-able pillow for backpacking.They measure roughly 9x20 and are a good 4-5" thick after they fluff back up.  They're not your firm bed-pillow from home, but they keep your head and neck off the ground, and beat a rolled up jacket or sweatshirt any day of the week!  The compression sack is okay, but doesn't really compress them as much as I needed, so I roll them into my sleeping bags and compress them with the bag (in the bag's compression sack).  They take up very little room when compressed flat, and will fluff back up after a few minutes.These are washable, but I recommend air-drying, as heat from a dryer will damage the foam-fill.

Sub Sports has my outdoor-compression-layer business for life!I have arctic compression tops from other big-names, and these blow them out of the water!  The fit is perfect, compression is even and full-length (not quite semi-compression, much more snug).  They feel like second skin, breathe well, wick moisture well, yet retain heat like a wool blanket.  These are better than Mil-spec ECW poly-pro, even with a base-layer added!  They also don't have a strong rubber smell, nor do they retain odors like some of the other brands do.The zipper on the neck is excellent for venting heat from the body when being active outdoors.  Preventing sweat or over-heating is paramount to comfort outdoors in extreme cold.  I also love the way the sleeves cover the wrist and palms of your hands (with thumb holes for retention), as this locks in the heat better than a standard sleeve, and the thumb holes are reinforced.I used the size charts on the Sub Sports website, and got a perfect fit.  If you are an athletic-build, or even average, then follow their sizing and you can't go wrong.  If you are muscular-bulky or have a few extra pounds, go up a size for a better or looser fit.If you have long arms or wide shoulders, go up a size from their chart... you'll thank me :)A word of warning... do NOT DRY THESE IN THE DRYER, or you'll never fit a toe back into them (or they will rip apart)... they must be line-dried or hung from a hanger.  They dry quickly so don't think it will take all day.

Sub Sports has my outdoor-compression-layer business for life!I have arctic compression leggings from other big-names, and these blow them out of the water!  The fit is perfect, compression is even and full-length.  They feel like second skin, breathe well, wick moisture well, yet retain heat like a wool blanket.  These are better than Mil-spec ECW poly-pro, even with a base-layer added!  They also don't have a strong rubber smell, nor do they retain odors like some of the other brands do.They do tend to ride a bit high on the waist if you opt for a larger than necessary size (looser fit), so be aware of sizing before purchasing.I used the size charts on the Sub Sports website, and got a perfect fit.  If you are an athletic-build, or even average, then follow their sizing and you can't go wrong.  If you are muscular-bulky or have a few extra pounds, go up a size for a better or looser fit.I also got the zip-top to match, and following the size chart would have put me in a large, but my son has this in a large (which is too short/tight in the sleeves for me), so I opted for the XL for better fit in my shoulder/arm length (I have broad sholders and 34-35" sleeves), and the compression is still nice and snug top-to-bottom.A word of warning... do NOT DRY THESE IN THE DRYER, or you'll never fit a toe back into them (or they will rip apart)... they must be line-dried or hung from a hanger.  They dry quickly so don't think it will take all day.I wore a pair of these leggings kayaking last spring, and even though water was constantly getting me wet, within a few minutes of getting out of the kayak, I felt dry at the skin, and was NOT cold the whole time.

It is not as shiny as the pictures, but still has a decent luster for SS.  The lobster clasp seems sturdy, and the links are solid (no gaps or warping).  The anklet measures 10.1" from clasp to ring, and the anklet lays nicely when flat.  It is heavy, which is the only thing she's complained about... she's use to lightweight silver or leather, which don't tend to slide down onto her ankle/foot as much as this one does, but she really likes the way it looks (thicker chain), and it won't tarnish/rust or turn her ankle colors like some of the cheaper silver-fill or silver-plate chains will. And, she won't have to worry about breaking or losing this one because it is heavier.

The material is good, but the stitching and edges look like they were sewn by a 2nd-grader... overlapping seams, back-stitching, and not straight lines.  However, the cover is solid and sealed, and the size is exactly as described.  Even with the trunk, saddlebags, and tall shield, this cover still touches the ground, providing maximum coverage from the elements.  The first day I used this cover, it rained all day, and the bike stayed DRY.The major complaint is the bottom strap is nothing more than a strip of cloth and the hook was not even tied to it.  There is also nowhere to hook the hook to on the other side :(  I have a couple of bungee cords with spring-clips on the ends (instead of hooks), which will work well to secure the cover in wind/weather, but even for $10, I would expect someone to have sewn a loop onto the opposite side of the cover?  Oh, and there are no grommet holes around the front tire (as the description says)... no biggie for me, as I don't use those to secure the cover to the wheel, but for some, it may be a deal-breaker, even though the price is fantastic for the quality of material.If this were stitched a bit better/straighter, and a better underside-strap, you'd not know the difference between this cover and my more expensive Nelson-Rigg.

This is a replacement (and upgrade) to the 1TB WD Caviar Green that I've had in service for ~ 7 years?  The 1TB is still functional, and has experienced zero loss of sectors and zero issues... it's just time to upgrade for larger capacity in my media storage box.I do prefer Hitachi drives, but for the purpose of storage, these WD greens are the best bang for the buck, and should last many many years.I would not recommend green drives for you OS or main drive, but for archive or media storage, these do well for saving power, running cool, and just working!

First of all, it is 2010 technology, which requires 300W or higher to operate.  I also received a DOA card on the first order, but Amazon quickly shipped a replacement!  YAY, Amazon!The replacement card...  I was unable to get this to work on an HP tower, running OEM 250W power supply, even though the old card was a GeForce 1GB 9-series (with fan), and it worked fine, even though specs recommended 350W?  I was also unable to get this card to function (no boot) in a Gateway slim-series tower (with 300W PSU), but it did function just fine in my ancient custom-built tower running 550W PSU (where I wanted to put the 9-series).The card does get a bit warm, but at least the heat-sync is right next to a case-fan, so that should help.I would not recommend this card for heavy gaming or intense graphics, as it will heat up when overly tasked, but for basic use and light gaming, it should function well.  For less than $30, though, you get HDMI, DVI, and VGA ports, as well as greatly improved graphics over the standard 8Mb onboard video!

Well made cables, but I would like the SATA connections to be a little closer together, as it seems there is a lot of wasted space between them when connecting two HDDs which are stacked... But, they work as expected, and connections are correct, and fit correctly.

Hammock is sturdy enough for two (average) adults, and is quite comfortable.  The included hardware (carbiners) are of good quality and supported our combined 300-lb well, without any give or bending.  The included rope... was replaced with sturdier climbing rope, rated at 500-lb, and I cut about 10' for each end of the hammock so we could use it between many more tree options.  On the first use, there was a tiny bit of stretch of the material because it was never used, but after a quick adjustment of the ropes to take up some slack, the hammock worked very well for the two of us all weekend... we spent many hours cuddled up in it!Loss of one star for included ropes... too short for anything but perfectly spaced (8-9' apart) trees, and the ropes stretched horribly.

I had zero issues adding this card to my PC.  Other reviewers had issues with the driver-disk, but my OS (Win7 upgraded to Win10) recognized the card and installed appropriate drivers automatically.  I did not have to use the supplied disk.I've not tested speed of each port, but my PC does recognize them as USB 3.0 and they function as expected.The only additional need I had was to add a an appropriate dual/split SATA connection (I had plenty of those cables lying around) to one of the 12V supply lines, to free one up for the card.  So far, it is running perfectly.

I usually order my cables from PCH-cables, but took a chance on these, and they are very well made, with heavy sheathing, and positive-locking ends.  I was very pleased with the purchase, and will be buying more if I need them later.

First off, this welding helmet is ANSI certified, not some cheap Chinese garbage.  Yes, it is plastic, but it works well, fits well, and does it's job.Controls are easy to reach with gloved hands, and the interior controls for delay and darkening-level are easy to adjust.  This unit works on battery as well as solar-power, and batteries are easy to access for replacement.  This helmet also comes with several replacement screens for the front, and only one for the interior.  Replacements are economical and easy to find also.This is the same helmet (only in black) offered at the local supply store for 3x the price, so buying from Amazon saved big bucks!My son has only been using this helmet for a week, but so far he says it is far better than his old helmet, auto-darkening works well, and seems to be the correct level of darkness (per adjustment indicators), and he really likes the Flag/Skull design, as it makes his helmet stand out from everyone else's on the job :)

I despise a wood-block for storing knives.  Sure, they look good, but they harbor bacteria and molds, which you don't want near your knives, and they take up valuable counter-space!  This bar has a very good grip for even my largest butcher knives and cleavers, and holds a full set of knives used for food prep.  I could actually get all my knives on this bar if it were about 4" longer, but I think I'll purchase a second bar for steak-knives and utensils such as wisks, carving forks, serving spoons, etc.Hanging this bar is not the easiest thing, as the screws need to be 17.5" apart (outside stud-spacing), and it takes a little tweaking to get the screw-heads just right, where they will grip the plastic end-caps just right.  Still though, it didn't take more than 5-min to have it mounted and all my knives stored safely on the wall near the stove.

My son needed new welding gloves, and these are far better than the ones he was using.  They are heavy cow-hide, and lined for comfort and heat resistance.  Fingers and thumb articulate nicely, and he has no complaints on grip.  Actually, he says welding with these is easier than with his last pair, and his hands/fingers do not get as warm when using these gloves.  The bright blue color is nice too.His only complaint is he wishes the gauntlet portion were a couple inches longer... he likes them to cover more of his jacket, as most sparks/slag hit the wrist area, and longer gauntlets would protect the "expensive" jacket sleeves better.  He has already said he wants another pair as a spare set.

My son needed a new welding jacket to replace the heavy cotton welding "shirt" he had been using (which held out for 2-3 months).  This leather jacket is very heavy and thick, and serves to protect the upper body from sparks and slag.  Arms are plenty long enough for overhead welding, and Velcro cuffs make the sleeves tight and make it easy to tuck into leather gauntlets.  There is minor adjustment at the waist, and he wishes another set of snaps were on the back (to make it a little tighter), but they can be added easily since the jacket is leather!My son normally wears Large jackets (off the rack), and this jacket fits like an XL, with plenty of room for a sweatshirt underneath.  Arms are plenty long enough for his 34" arms.  Neck fits his 16" neck, and is comfortable and prevents sparks from entering the jacket.  Pencil/tool pockets are on each sleeve, and the interior pocket is huge, yet easy to access.  He likes this jacket far better than the all-cotton jacket he was using, and this heavy-leather jacket only costs $20 more?His only complaint on the jacket is the white powder that took several days to remove, and the light grey color does show where slag has made contact... but a stiff brush cleans the jacket up nicely.

Not a bad ring, much thinner than my other Titanium rings, and much lighter.What I like:ThinLightweightLooks greatGreat contrast between shiny outer edge and matte finish around the channel/stonesWhat I don't like:No inscription on the ring to say it is Titanium (or whatever metal it is)Gaps between stonesStones are raised above the channel, so they tend to snag on clothes, and I'm sure if bumped just right, stones will be knocked out.I've been wearing it every day for more than a week, and it is very comfortable, and I've gotten great compliments on it.  We'll just see how well it holds up to daily wear and tear.UPDATE:I've been wearing this for nearly 3 weeks, and noticed last night that one of the stones is already missing, and another is loose (about to fall out).  These stones are GLUED INTO THE CHANNEL, not SET into the channel!!  I have a different ring, slightly larger, which cost maybe $10 more, and those stones are set into the channel... spend more, get more!While the ring looks nice, and looks fantastic for "special occasion" wear, I cannot recommend it for daily wear or long-term wear, especially if you actually have to use your hands or move around.

I have Fosmon cases like these on all my family's phones.  They offer the same or better protection as Otterbox, without breaking the bank.  The soft inner layer absorbs shocks and make the phone easy to handle (no slips), and the lip around the front of the phone protects the screen when you lay it face-down.  The hard outer-shell protects against sharp blows, and works to evenly distribute shocks to the inner-layer.  The corner protection is fantastic at keeping a corner-drop from exploding the screen.  My wife and kids are HARD on phones, and these cases have kept us from replacements and insurance claims.  Actually, I've dropped insurance on ALL of our phones... that is how much I trust these cases.

This red one is my second purchase of a Syma S107/S107G!  I purchased a yellow one for my son last Christmas, and he still has fun playing with it indoors on a rainy day...  He has upgraded his with a larger battery, so it will fly closer to 10-14 minutes between charges, instead of 6-8 minutes, and the larger battery (only a few grams heavier) seems to give the toy more stability and control.  I will likely upgrade this one as well.I purchased this one for myself  :)These are very easy to fly, and virtually everyone who has tried to fly it has somewhat mastered the controls by the second battery charging.  They are very durable as well... even crashing into furniture, walls, doors, (or the dog) has yet to damage them, but even if you do damage them, replacement parts and replacement batteries are readily available here on Amazon... for cheap!  Be aware these are for INDOOR USE, and even slight currents from heating registers, A/C units, or fans can make controlling them difficult.  I couldn't imagine having any control outdoors.Be sure to adjust the trim (rotation) of the craft by hovering in place on the first flight.  Once you have the trim adjusted, your first flight will be much easier!  Happy flying!

I didn't think I'd like a ball forcing the head side-to-side, but I'm amazed at the control you have with this razor, even over tough spots (like ankles and knees), as well as more "delicate" areas.  This is my 3rd handle/bundle purchase (this one for travel), and I've been through probably a dozen of the heads... not one nick (yet), but I also use a good shaving cream, NOT soap, and don't rush the job!The handle allows movement "just enough" to the side to avoid nicks and cuts, and because it only moves side-to-side, it allows you to apply the right amount of pressure to ensure a smooth shave.  The 5-blade heads really make quick work of stubble in a single pass, and you can usually go an extra day between shaves (as compared to twin or triple-head razors (even the original Venus).  The handle is also less slippery than the Body handle or Original Venus handle.  These 5-blad heads also fit other Gillette handles, and the 3 and 4-blade heads fit this ball handle too.Some comments have been harsh about the lube-strips "melting" on the heads, but honestly, I've not seen this issue, but I also don't leave the razor face-down in a puddle after use... it hangs upright to dry (or lays blade-up on the shelf) after use.The heads cost a bit more, but I look for coupons and sales, and the heads do last considerably longer than the triple-blade versions, so cost per head sort of works out in the wash... If you're looking for a new razor for the shower, give this one a try, and I think you'll be pleasantly surprised... I was!

I love Puma and Adidas shoes, especially their soccer boots.  They fit as expected, which is narrow and snug, but they loosen up as they mold to your foot.  These were an excellent price (1/3 the local sporting-goods store cost).For a Jr player, just starting out, these have additional cleats for support and balance, and they work well on hard, natural-surfaces or turf, and allow for reasonable balance on concrete (walking to the field).As with all Puma and Adidas soccer boots, ankle cut-outs are low, which allow for greater range of motion, and  allow for wearing ankle-guards, without causing pressure-points or pain while running.  Arch-support is adequate.  Offset lacing allows for better ball control, and the surface of the shoe has great grip on the ball.

Excellent product!  My wife has been using this for several months, and it has taken years off her face... she barely looks in her early 30's, although she's taken good care of her skin for decades (she just turned 48).  I only wish this product were a bit cheaper, although it is much cheaper on Amazon than the local Nerium sales-gal... Buying locally from the Nerium sales consultants, you'll pay 2x the price that you find here on Amazon.

I recently purchased a single SK98 to test, and was so impressed with it, I had to purchase this twin-pack so I would have more of them on-hand.  Don't expect them to be StreamLights, but for ~ $8 each, you can't go wrong with them for a decent, reliable tactical-style flashlight.  These are perfect for the outdoorsman of the family, technicians, inspectors, or anyone needing a bright, inexpensive flashlight.This SK98 uses 18650 batteries (flat-top or button-top), and they recommend using protected cells, although as long as you are using a good name-brand cell from Sony, Samsung, LG, Panasonic, etc., and an Amp-rating of 10A or higher (discharge-rate), then you should have zero issues. I personally use Panasonic 3400mAh 10A and Sony VTC4 20A batteries in my tactical lights and have for years without issue. One thing to be careful of is to NOT leave rechargeable batteries in the flashlight, after more than 30-min of use, as this will damage the battery.  I rotate my batteries, and do not store a battery in every light, but do keep one in the light I use the most (swapping for a fresh battery at least once a week, even if unused). Also, do not drain a battery to the point it will not fire the LED, as this will damage the battery too. Once the beam is visibly weak, it is time to change the battery!If you don't use your flashlight frequently, it is best to store it without a battery installed.  Purchase at least two 18650 batteries for each light, and store each light with a pair of batteries (in a plastic battery case, for safety).  Then when you need the light, batteries are close-by.  If you store the batteries consistently with the (+) side to the left in a flip-top-box, it will make it EASY to install the batteries into the flashlight, even in pitch-black-dark.  Storing them outside the flashlight also makes it convenient to top-off the charge of the battery pair every couple of months, so the batteries are never dead or below full-charge, ready for action!Comparing the light against a higher-end light of known lumens, this light does not reach 1200lm, but is probably in the 900-1000lm range. It is definitely brighter than my 800lm light, but not nearly as bright as my 1200lm light.I do like that the flood setting is smooth and even in light and color (cool-white), but in spot-mode, the beam is square... at about 4-6', you can easily make out the entire shape and texture of the CREE LED.The body of the flashlight has a nice texture and grip, and the button push is solid on each click. The half-press of the button smoothly transitions from high-beam, low-beam and strobe.  Focusing the light is easy and not stiff, but still tight enough to hold the position you leave it in.  I find the light is actually brighter in full flood position.The belt clip is a bit cumbersome, but you get use to it in your hand. It does seem to be solid. I've only had one belt clip break on my previous versions of UltraFire flashlights, so I'm sure this one will hold up as well?I only recommend a bit of silicone lube (or Vaseline) on the threading of the tail-cap, because if yours is like mine, they will be shipped quite dry, and the lubrication adds to the waterproofing, as well as easy removal of the cap.This light appears to be better than my much older versions of UltraFires, so I like I said, I bought a couple more so I would have these better, upgraded UltraFire flashlights to replace my aging, underpowered lights...

Scale arrived quickly, and is a nice "clean" addition to my bathroom.  The scale appears to be "precise", which is what you want for daily weight monitoring.  The glass top is heavy, but not quite as thick as some of the premium scales I've seen/used, and I do wish the white around the view-module were black, like the pads, but white is not bad.As for accuracy, it is actually quite accurate.  I had just came home from a doctor visit when this scale arrived, so I immediately checked my weight against the Doctor's balance-scales.  This digital scale was accurate to less than 1/2-lb (reads 0.4-lb higher).  Precision was determined by checking the scale several times over the next hour, and each time, the scale showed the exact same weight.  I stepped on it once, while holding two 10-lb dumbbells, and the weight was 20.2-lb higher.  Stepping back on it again without the weights, and the reading was exactly the same as it had been 20-min earlier.For a "cheap" scale, I am quite impressed with the quality and precision.  I do hope the mechanism lasts longer than some reviewers have experienced.  Still, this beats the price of the cheap-o spring scales from the local stores... and looks 50x better!

I use these for performing auto-repairs, so I don't have to scrub the hide off my hands after changing oil or working on an over-haul.  These are pretty sturdy, and I've only had a few out of each box tear prematurely on me.  They provide excellent grip and tactile feel of small parts, and protect my hands from caustic chemicals, dirt, grease, etc.  A box of these is cheaper than gallons of hand-cleaners, scrub-brushes, and moisture-replenishing hand-creams/lotions :)

I've purchased three of these over the past year or so, and they all work very well, but do have limitations on range and speed... but that is a fair trade-off for their price.  I use these on desktops so I don't have to run Cat-5 cables to every room of the house.  They are very easy to set-up, and updated drivers are available on the Netgear website.  My Cisco router is centrally located in the house, so these have no issues connecting to it and functioning near peak speed.These are a great alternative to installing wireless cards, or a quick-fix solution to a failing built-in wireless card for an older laptop.

I purchased this for a cake-topper for my daughter's wedding, and it was the perfect size and design to put a spark on the top of her cake.  Now, the figurine resides on the shelf in their living room, and is a beautiful decorative piece between a pair of their wedding photos.The topper is only about 9" tall, and is not too heavy as a cake-topper, and is not so light to think it is cheap plastic.  It is a very nice piece!

First of all, I'm a guy... pushing 50, and with dark circles and puffiness under my eyes from genetics as well as long hours in front of a computer.  I tried this product on a whim, and after only 4 days of applying this product twice-daily, I can say it WORKS.  I have had co-workers ask if I recently had "work done" on my face, and people that haven't seen me for a few weeks/months tell me that I look in my early 30's.  This product has reduced the dark circles to near nothing, and reduced the puffiness considerably.  The skin under my eyes is much tighter/firmer, and the squinting wrinkles on the sides of my eyes are starting to disappear.I'll be ordering more of this very soon, because I want to keep using it every day to maintain this youthful look... and I don't want to run out.  This stuff is worth every penny!

Same brake pads as offered through my local auto-parts house, but at 1/3 their price.  These pads are ceramic, but also contain copper and other materials to promote better/faster braking and better heat dissipation from the rotors.  100% ceramic pads do NOT dissipate heat as well as these ceramic-composite pads do.  These are also the exact same compound pads as came on my car from OEM.If you have nice, fancy wheels and are tired of brake-dust turning them black, and want to restore "new-car" braking performance, install these pads, and replace or turn your rotors.

I've owned one of these since the 1980's, and still use it today!Not much has changed in the design, other than lighter materials in the tent body and floor, but the one I have looks basically the same (tan color, not green).  I've logged hundreds of nights camping, in everything from hammocks, and curled next to the fire, to 9-man cabin tents for a week+, yet I still go back to this "Scout" tent when backpacking and weekend motorcycle camping, and it sees at least two night's use per year, usually lots more.  I've always kept the tent clean, water-proof it with Camp-Dri every couple of years, and re-seal the seams at the same time.  I still have the original poles and stakes too, but I'm sure the ones made back then are much higher quality ;)The size is perfect for one-person and their gear, and two people can sleep comfortably in it (as long as one of you doesn't toss/turn/kick all night).  It is quite cozy for you and your spouse or BF/GF, and no-where near the sardine-can-feeling you get from other 2-person bivy or A-frame-styles.Condensation is a bigger issue in this tent than one with top-mesh and rain-fly.  One late-October trip a couple years ago, the weather went below zero, and the condensation froze the walls of the tent (solid) - removed the poles and it still stood-up, lol.  Another Early December snow-storm dropped several inches on us overnight, and we woke up sweating to death because the snow had insulated the tent (and with the mesh vents/doors closed, there was no air-flow to vent body-heat)!  I've never had an issue with leakage during rain or thunderstorms, although if I can, I try to put up a half-shelter tarp or other method of deflecting rain from direct-contact with the tent.As one reviewer stated, taking care of your equipment, and knowing how to properly use it make all the difference in how well they work and how long they last.  I've owned tents from Coleman, Eureka, Kelty, North-Face, Alps, Wentzel, Tex-sport, and others... and this tent, one Eureka, and a couple of Coleman tents are the only ones that have stood up to years and years of REAL use!

No, this watch doesn't make smoking-hot women want to be your clingy-girlfriend... it IS the clingy girlfriend :)  Explanation below:First of all, this is not my first Seiko 5 Automatic, so I'm basing this review against my older model's function.Pros:+ Excellent size / weight / thickness+ Smooth finish and flush-mounting crown (recesses into the case)+ Keeps excellent time (so far, as long as you keep it running, see Cons)+ Expect lots of compliments, as this is a very sharp-looking watch!+ Perfect watch for every-day, casual, or office-wear+ Slim fit and good weight (not too heavy) lets you know it is on your arm, but doesn't get in the way or feel like a brick+ Diameter is perfect for a smaller or mid-size wrist - might look small if you have 9" wrists+ Exhibition back is smooth, clear, and a nice addition to this watch, plus you can see main function of the watch and winder+ Dual language day-display is handy and functional, but not the most important feature.+ Day-of-the-week display is standard, weekdays are in black, Saturday in blue, and Sunday in red.Cons:- Band uses tuning-fork lock-pins which are a beast to remove for band-sizing - fortunately you normally size a band once...- Crown sits recessed into the case, and is difficult to catch it to extend the crown- Crown rotation is stiff, even when setting day/date or time (when crown is extended) - have to use my fingernail to catch the knurling.- Adjustment of the catch is 1/4 and 1/2 of a link, so if you need 3/4 of a link, it will be too tight or slightly loose based on the # of links removed.The biggest con of them all (and the reason I call this watch a clingy-girlfriend) is the watch MUST be worn daily, for at least 14 hours or it will not keep accurate time.  My older Seiko 5 can be worn as little as 8-10 hours per day, and it will continue to keep time (run) for the next 24-30 hours.  The older Seiko 5 is also MUCH easier to manually wind, and all it takes is a moment or two winding it daily to keep it running.  This watch (after wearing for 16 hours) ran dead in 6 hours the first day, and after wearing 14 hours the second day, it stopped running after 6 hours again!I will continue to work with it, and hopefully it will get it to the level of my other Seiko 5, or I will have to invest in an auto-winder... because I don't like wearing the same watch day after day.Update:After wearing the watch daily for two weeks, I took it off on a Friday night, and picked it back up on Sunday morning, and it was still running, and the time was still reasonably accurate.As with all automatic watches, some degree of inaccuracy is expected, but this watch is gaining roughly 70-seconds over the past week, or +10 seconds per day.  Also note, during that week, I only removed my watch to shower, so it was at never "at rest".  I will test again for a week by removing it for sleep, and see if the accuracy improves.

A watch box is an excellent way to keep your watches dust-free, scratch-free, and makes a handsome display.  Whether you have $10 watches or $10,000 watches, they should be stored separately and securely to keep them looking nice.The "glass" top is a high-quality plexi-glass or Lexan... very clear and smooth.The "leather" is actually a heavy vinyl with decent looking stitching... it looks very classy.The latch is so-so, almost cheap looking, but it is functional, and even has a lock with two-post key supplied.The "pillows" are not pillows... they are foam-filled ribbed velvet-ish material with rigid sides.  They are a bit small for the slots, but big for the average-size band (if you attempt to close the band around the pillow)... you have to leave the band loose around the pillow.  For this reason, I wish the pillows were larger, and filled the slots fully, as this would make the bands more visible, and would eliminate gaps at top/bottom of each slot.Overall, I'm pleased with the box, as it allows me to safely store six watches when they are not in use... and eliminates the danger of my quality watches from being damaged by laying loose in a drawer.  It also eliminates the clutter of having watches lying around, loose, on the top of a dresser!

Standard, small-profile (stubby) USB drive.I think these are made by PNY, but not really sure.  The read/write speeds are similar to PNY, and not quite as fast as SanDisk.  There are no flashing activity lights on the drive, which is good if you are using this with a car stereo, but an activity light is helpful if you want to know if a download is completed on your PC!For the cost and portability, this is a winner.  The mini lanyard/ring made it very easy to attach this to my badge lanyard for easy access at work to transfer files without using the network bandwidth.

For the price, I can't complain too much, but the MFG padded the package with "extras" to make you think you're getting a bargain.The pin removal tool works decently enough, but the one I received is bent out of the box (the tip of the pin is bent) - I straightened it with the supplied pliers :)Zero replacement pins for the removal tool are suppliedThe pin-set-block is okay, but should also have shallower sides for thinner or ladies bracelets.  It is unusable for smaller bands.The pliers are dollar-store equivalentThe hammer... is handy, actually, and decent weight and the nylon end is just hard enough to be usable without causing damage.The case-back knife seems okay, but appears to be cheap metal, not a good, tempered stainless steel... my pocket knife works better!I've not used the crab-wrench, but am leery of a two-prong wrench... prefer 3-prongs for stability and torque.The 5 screwdrivers supplied are useless... the 3 flat-head are all the exact same size, same for the 2 Philips-head... only difference is length.The three punches... all the same size diameter, and all too big for most of my bands.The spring-bar tool is highly useful... if it were sharper, and the pin-push were tapered like it should be....Tweezers... they could be made of Aluminum-foil (they're useless)Do yourself a favor... spend your $7 on a decent pin removal tool (with extra pins of different sizes).  If you need a good crab-wrench for screw-on case-backs, buy a 3-prong version (it will prevent slipping and give better torque).  If you only have to size a couple of bands and change the occasional battery, this set may be worth your effort and cost over a jeweler, but Wal-Mart will size a band and install batteries for FREE!

This is a great gift for a pre-schooler.  The best small suckers you can buy (everyone's favorites), and a cool bank to save their change!The price is a bit much for what you get... honestly, there is maybe $2 worth of suckers and a cardboard tube... but still worthwhile for a small child, especially if you can catch this on price-drop or sale for ~ $5.

I purchased this watch as a gift (not from Amazon) on sale, and it was far more beautiful than the images show.  The contrast of Stainless and Gold-tone, along with the champagne/beige dial makes it very classy looking.  If you are worried about fade of the gold-tone, don't be... I have a Bulova that is probably 30-yrs old, and the gold-tone stainless may be scratched, but it is still bright.The band is easily adjustable, and can be replaced with a nice leather band if you don't care for the Stainless bracelet.The ONLY thing I wish this watch had is the day/date function.  She has much cheaper (big-name-brand) watches with date function.  Like I said, "I" wish it had day/date function, but she pointed out that it's just one more thing to have to re-set every month with less than 31 days!  So, point taken :)Also, to me, the large numerals detract from the class of the watch (I feel it should have hashes and perhaps just a 12 or "Tuning-fork logo" at top), but as she put it, "it makes it easier to read at a glance"... so if she's happy, I'm happy!I cannot comment on how it keeps time (as I'm not the one wearing it), but she's not complained about it losing or gaining time, but she's only had it for a few days, too.Oh, Bulova watches being made today no longer have the "tuning-fork" logo on the face.  So, if you like the logo, now is the time to snag new-old-stock from the suppliers, before they are no longer available or the prices sky-rocket!UPDATE:  She's had this watch for nearly two weeks (I set the watch against my atomic clock when I bought it), and we just compared the time to the atomic-clock... PERFECT TIME KEEPING!  It is not even a full second off from setting it nearly a month ago.

I received this as a gift, and it is probably the second nicest Seiko watch I own.  The nicest is only due to sentimental value (belonged to my grandfather).  The only difference between mine and the one pictured is that mine has a satin-white dial, not black.The watch is flawless in fit and function.  The controls are intuitive, and the alarm is accurate (although not very loud).  I rarely use the chronograph function, but it is nice to have.  The watch keeps phenomenal time, on par with finer Swiss watches, and the solar function means a few minutes a day in direct sunlight (or a few hours a week under incandescent lamps) and you'll never have to worry about keeping it running.  10 ATM waterproof, so it's not suitable for diving, but certainly will be safe to get wet.  I have no hesitation if I forget to take it off before jumping into the pool or to wear when canoeing or on/near water.I've had this one for roughly 4-months, and so far it has kept perfect time... maybe gaining 1-1.5 seconds per month?  Which is far more accurate than my Seiko 5 Automatic, which tends to gain about 5-seconds per month.... Even a good Swiss watch will be +/- 15-60 seconds annually.This is simply an elegant, daily-wear time-piece, which looks far more expensive than it is!The only issue with the watch was sizing the band... the link pins are VERY snug, and it required using a jeweler's pin removal tool to prevent damage to the band.  Time will tell if the gold-tone on the case and band fade, although the gold-tone on my other Seiko has held up well over the past few years.... Hopefully this watch has the same quality!

So, this is nothing more than a green Venus (Mach3 blade-set with a wider head), marketed for men.  Gillette is taking advantage of the "manscaping" fad, and charging more for a Green Venus, over the Blue ones marketed for women.  Sadly, the Venus blades last much longer, probably because of the difference in the lubricating strips?Pros:It works (a few times)The wide-flat head works smoothly over body curves (preventing digging)No wire-strips covering the bladesCons:It works for about 3 shaves per headThe lubricating strips dry out after the first use and flake awayThe lubricating strips work to dull the blades faster by "coating them" with a soapy gunkBlades clog very fast, even if only shaving light stubbleCost per blade/shave compared to Venus or men's Mach-3 blades - Venus is twice as many blades for $4 moreI've thought this would work better than a "woman's razor", but this is nothing more than a green Venus (which are cheaper, as I pointed out). So, buy a Venus, and if you don't want the blades to dull as fast, use Mach-3 heads and go slower, being more careful over certain sensitive areas.

Well designed "suit of armor" for your Moto-X2I've had a similar case on my Nexus for more than 2-years, and it provided extremely good protection for drops, bumps, and bangs.This one is slightly different, slightly less armor on the sides (where it wasn't needed), and a bit thinner, which makes it far easier to hold the larger Moto-X2.The case is easy to slide on, and easy to work with.  The belt case is very tight and stiff, but if it is like the one I had with my Nexus, it will loosen up and be easier to holster and remove the phone in a few weeks/months.UPDATE:I've been using this case for nearly 10 months, and it has protected my phone well from several drops onto concrete!  The holster has loosed-up a bit, and is not nearly as snug as the first week or two of use.The only complaint I have about the holster is that the middle tabs which hold the phone in place also press the volume-down button as you holster it, causing the phone to move to vibrate-mode 3 out of 5 times :(  It does not matter if you holster the phone upside-down or right-side-up...  I do wish one of the tabs were slightly lower, so it would not press my volume button... but this is not a deal-breaker because the case itself is better than Otterbox!

Very nice copy in a "new modern English prose translation by R. M. Lumainsky".  Preface by Mark van Doren, illustrated. W913 at @ .75 cents. Quite a bargain at the time.This copy of mine comes from 1966 or 1967, was used in college.The new modern translation of Chaucer's Middle English is a great help to understanding.  I also have a hardcover issue from Houghton Mifflin Co. that is in the Middle English and it, for me, is a trail to read and understand.

I must state up front, I am not an admirer of Custer.  So I try to pick the books on my shelves about him carefully.  Almost anyone following this line of military history and/or the Indian Wars probably already has more about him than need be.So, when I saw this book concerning primary sources for The Great Sioux War I could not stay away from the book.  Very good that I did buy it a few years back,  as I feel it to be and will remain one of the more important books on this subject.  I would almost want to say that anyone interested in a period from 1874-1876 really needs  pay attention to it.  One of the main points I learned long ago during college days was:  read the primary accounts whenever possible.I thank the author for giving it to us and wish only more books could written in the same manner.

I now have a hard copy of this book.I wanted one mainly because back in 1967 while at Ohio State had to make a book report on it in a history class.Cannot say what people are looking for in a history book, but for me you can do no better than Garrett Mattingly's book on the armada and also on Catherine of Aragon.  They are both excellent..(Yes, I have both in original hardcovers. But used paperbacks in that same world history class of long ago.)

Mr. Cottrell was a British archaeologist writing from the 1950s through the 1970s.  His books were usually about ancient Egypt.  They could be categorized as "popular" versions of historical archaeogical finds and their activities.  I read most of them in the 1960s, and interest in his writings helped me to decide to attend college after release from the military, to follow a course in anthropology & history.  Mr. Cottrell died at 61 years of age in October, 1974.This particular book concerns the "drama" of the great pyramid exploration. These were to serve as "tombstones" for the burial crypts of the Egyptian kings.  The arabs termed them "Mountains of Pharaoh."This book published in 1956 would of necessity have to be considered well outdated.  However, if you like Mr. Cottrell's writings it still makes for interesting reading while some of it remains correct and up-to-date.

I have liked the "sidewinders" series since first hearing of it.  This particular book although rather slow in movement or plot at times,  has it share of action and good dialogue as do most westerns.  Another thing in the book that is admirable is the relationship between Bo and Scratch, they have grown up together and are now roaming the west together.  As sidewinders, they don't look for trouble, but it usually finds them. Standing tall they always seem to weather the storm.This series has a televison "Maverick" relationship supporting it, especially between the two main characters.  If you enjoy westerns, this series may be enjoyable for you also.

I had seen this movie when released 15 June 1966. I seem to recall it as "movie of the week" on television but can not verify that.  Anyway, I remembered it as so good or interesting that I have searched for a DVD but the price was always so high.  Finally I took the plunge and feel the movie is as good as everyone says it is.  I now have original the 1939, 1986, and the 1966 versions.None is better than the other for me, for they are all a little bit different in the manner they were put together.If I have to choose one though, it would be the 1986 with Johnny Cash, Willie Nelson,  etc., for it shows how good of actors they both were/are. Cash is so surprisingly good.

Years ago (1978) when I was a much younger man, I came across this over-sized volume on the fighting in North Africa in a 2nd hand book store. This book is a mixture of a well written book and one that offers many photos that until that time had never before been published. I still have this one in my personal library and still prize it highly.  For its time, even now, it is impressive.  Now, if you desire, you can own it too at a much lesser price than I paid for it "way back then".I have several other books on the North African fighting and the German DAK, but this one is still near and dear to my heart. (No, I'm not going to say how much I paid for it back then before Amazon, it seems ridiculous now)

This book of little more than 250 pages gives good insight into the British desert war years of 1941 through early 1943.  It offers first hand accounts from those who participated in the battles, and many photographs, both in color and black & white, from those years. Also included are a few maps equally both in color and black & white.Starting in 1940, the Italians were at it in North Africa, but by April, 1941, Hitler was led to assist his Axis partners there.  Sending the DAK (Deutsches Afrika Korps) led by Generalleutnant Erwin Rommel to North Africa, Hitler hoped to turn the fighting in the Axis favor.  Over the next two years Hitler both won, and lost, so that by October of 1942 Rommel saw the turning point at El Alamein and was forced into a withdrawal toward Tunisia.  One of the bitter pills for Rommel was that he could not receive adequate supplies, and as much as anything else, the fighting could not be supported as need be. Thankfully, we could and did intercept the German radio transmissions.  With good result that we sunk much of what was shipped to Rommel.George Forty (retired Lt. Colonel, past Royal Tank Regiment) has been writing on the desert war since the 1980s in past books such as The Desert Rats, but this newest book from 2002 sums up the latest of his 20 some years of research and study.  This new book tells in words and shows in color and black & white photos just what it was about.An interesting book, at a more affordable price than I got mine back in 2005.

The Ardennes offensive, also known to WWII history as "the battle of the bulge", has been the subject of innumerable books down through the years. The focus is of course the German attempt to break through the American lines to Antwerp hoping to not only defeat the British and Americans but also to throw them backwards away from Germany.  Hitler aimed to do that and by doing so gain time to come back with his 'wonder' weapons to win the war.  He ultimately did not get close to Antwerp, ran out of fuel for his beloved panzer units, and prolonged the war for at least another 6 months.The well known military historian, George Forty, here not only 'traces the whole story' but used U.S. documents to show how the American troops stood up to all of this.  He further provides not only adequate background information but data on "organization, equipment, and conduct of" all forces involved.This book will join the many others already on library shelves which detail and describe one of the last important battles fought by the ETO army in the second world war.Lt. Colonel (rtd) George Forty served 30 years in the Royal Tank Regiment, not only in Korea, were he was wounded, but other theatres before retiring in 1977 to put down the sword, and pick up the pen.  According to the dust jacket he has also written more that 50 books "specialising in armoured warfare".I have a few of his books, anyone reading his books will be rewarded with good, solid history from a man well versed in the subjects of which he writes.

A selection of The Military Book Club back in 1980s and  still a very good book I feel to have on your personal library shelves, I am glad to have acquired it back then.Perrett gives a good lesson in Hitler's Panzerwaffe and its leaders,  while offering a good, basic history and training of the armor arm that gave a fairly good account of itself in the war, and also gave us probably one of the better tanks of all time: the King Tiger.The Panzerwaffe, strength never exceeding one fifth of the German army, made an enormous impact in the second world war,  especially on the Eastern Front.Somewhat of a "basic" book for my library, even at this late date.

I have this movie coming in a boxed set from Amazon, in the meanwhile decided to look it up on U Tube and happily found it.  After all these years the music and plot hold up.  True the movie is a studio produced movie such as hundreds they were producing then, but it certainly is enjoyable. Great group of songs.It sometimes seems that Tex is singing in abundance, rather than having an action story plot.  But enjoying the movie so much I didn't care about that.  It also helps to like Tex Ritter movies as much as I do.  Along with the Tex Ritter boxed set on order is also a boxed set of Tim McCoy westerns.  I should be busy for quite some while.Can't get enough of these old movies, this one made in 1936, b4 I was born in 1943!

I'm not sure why in some other reviews people want to say this is "the first November man novel".  I understand after following this series from the 1980s that this book is #7 in the series.  No matter really, but newer readers should understand that.This book is as good as it gets with Bill Granger's series of November Man novels, and that is for me very good indeed.  For someone who grew up during the James Bond craze and later worked during my military years indirectly for NSA as a spy of sorts, though now much outdated, this series is like a breath of clear air.  These books more resemble "how it was" back then.Too bad that Bill is gone, but he certainly left us with much of value.

TOMBSTONE STAGE--WILLIAM HOPSONFor a 1948 western, this novel still reads very well. Not quite what I had expected but very good never-the-less. Plot has to do with smuggling of goods and people (Chinese) into Arizona from Mexico, and numerous attacks by Apache Indians.  It is the era of Geronimo and other raiding Apaches with the cavalry undermanned at Fort Huachuca.  Plot also concerns itself with the love triangle between and Army officer and a smuggler in love with the same eastern gal.  Would have made a good ole b-movie!A wee bit slow on the starting but with the first attack on the Tombstone stage, takes off like a bullet.

Very good movie, especially since you get to see  actress Nancy Gates.Don' be put off by the "bad" history, this movie is quite good.Bat died at his sports writing desk  in New York as a reporter, and I've read that it is questionable whether he ever killed anyone. That aside, Bat was a true stand out in the west and later in the east.

Stony Man is a series that combines the old Able Team and Phoenix Force with Mack Bolan, at times. Working out of Virginia's Stony Man Blue Ridge area they are a super professional group carrying out missions for the justice department that are so important/sensitive to national security that they can be entrusted to no one else. Sometimes to be successful they need to operate very close to the law or at certain time, outside the law.They take on jobs such as this one where "ecoterrorism becomes the perfect cover for a renegade Chinese and North Korean military group.". If you know what "ecoterrorism" is and you are interested, then this plot will possibly be plausible to you. Discrediting the Japanese whaling enterprise is of only passing interest to me.  I have been reading these Gold Eagle books since the early 1980s having quite a collection of them running into the hundreds while at times find them hard to follow as in "what's the point" of little interest to me.This one was written by Douglas P. Wojtowicz, an author who has written at least 12 other Stony Man novels and numerous others in the Gold Eagle series of books, an author I both respect, trust and normally like.  This book, however, doesn't get me involved in the plot as some others do.  I'm sure it's not his writing, just me.  I'm old and some of this higher today tech loses me.
