(I'm hardly able to do this review on a PC)  You may be quite different and find them enjoyable.I really find this stuff fairly enjoyable (I was during my military service a spy of sorts indirectly working for NSA, my role now much outdated) and generally like to keep up on this world and how it has grown and evolved.  But somehow, for me, I just couldn't really get interested in this one.

Rifle, ColoradoFort CrawfordFort GarlandColorado Territory was admitted to the Union in 1876, so this helps to date this story from a truly masterful writer of western fiction. Luke Short (Frederick Glidden brother of western writer Peter Dawson) also mentions Fort Crawford as being a "new post" raised to help "as a counter threat to (Chief) Ouray and his restive Utes who had declined to submit to reservation authority".  So this area is located within Ute country with the western Rockies mentioned at least once. The location and the approximate date of this story is given us by things the author knew and mentioned.This story does not, however, revolve around the Utes only the country, and centers on the horse trade or selling going on at that time. It is the story of a drifter, Frank Chess, who can not seem to settle down and grow roots, but has to see what is over the next hill.  This earns him the disdain of local people and he is seen as of no account.  He would possibly be seen as something worse if people knew of "his crooked errands" he is doing for his boss Rhino Hulst (J.J. Hulst, Horses bought and sold) .  Also Chess then proceeds to lose "his crooked money in the nearest saloon, the nearest poker game, and to the nearest girl in a spangled dress".But murder quickly brings him down to reality--he isn't the killer but all elements point directly to him as the killer of Rob Custus, with the local sheriff Buck Hannan very close to putting Frank Chess under arrest.A western novel that centers on ranching and horse selling and the greed, dishonesty and meaness of some persons  involved. It also has much concerning the lives of average people in a small western town going about their daily affairs. Be they doctor, lawyer, cowboy, or the couple of women in love with the same man.  This man or "easygoing saddle tramp" finds "he had something to kill for, die for--and live for!'.Not the "best" Luke Short novel I've encountered (like AMBUSH or SUMMER OF THE SMOKE) but one that holds your interest to the point of wondering just how Frank Chess will work out of the things that scare him and endanger him.  Also which one of these women will he come to see as really loving him.  More than a western novel and more a novel of some literature on the west.

This book is more-or-less a continuation of book 1, HANGING JUSTICE, not so much in story as in that the book is about as uninteresting, and again John Slocum is treated as a character who cannot or is unable to handle routine things.John is supposed to deposit $5,000.00 dollars at Wells Fargo and Company in Bridger, Colorado Territory, but through some truly stupid antics he ends up not going to Wells Fargo  and instead is arrested for rape and captured, and due to be hung by the local sheriff and local lynch mob. Before that can happen, he taken hostage by a woman named Greta. "She had shot Slocum, stabbed him, nearly hanged him and clubbed him half to death..." all for the $5000.00 he has on him.After awhile of this sillyness, one just gets tired of the inane plot and gives up to go to another Jake Logan, hopefully a better one.  At least this reader did, read this book if you enjoy seeing John Slocum treated as completely helpless, dumb, and inept. Again as in book one, it is difficult to recognise the real Slocum.

After the civil warBlindman, Colorado TerritoryEven in this first book of the series, John Slocum is in trouble, almost from the beginning. He has been forced by a sheriff into being part of jury, whether he wants to be or not.  Slocum is locked up in a saloon, given all the booze, all the food, and all the women he wants and is to be paid $1.00 a day.  But John Slocum wants to ride on to Pinos Altos, New Mexico Territory and he doesn't want to be a forced member of a jury for 6 weeks!  He wants to go now.Right from the beginning of this book it's difficult to make sense and follow, I agree with the other review here, this is a book that should have had a much better editor.  I, too, have read many Jake Logan books and have several hundred on the shelf.  As the other review states some are very good and some are not so good.  This book, however, should never have been used to start this series, some doubts that it should have been published.  Little wonder PLAYBOY eventually jettisoned the series.If you are wise, you will chose another Jake Logan book to read.P.S: don't where Amazon got the "#2 of the series", the listing I follow shows this to be the very first Slocum novel in the series.

Nevada Territorysouthern foothills Ruby MountainsShoshoni, Piaute, Nez Perce countryCalifornia & Oregon trailsFargo is looking for some time off:  whiskey, cards & women.  But it doesn't work out that way: Fargo soon gets involved with the trouble involving a 12 year old boy trying to get needed medicine to a nearby wagon train but certain outlaws are trying to stop Fargo's efforts to help the boy, they want to steal the medicine-holding it ransom to the wagon train.  Helping the boy only serves to  pull Fargo in deeper to their wagon train's problems to the point that he becomes their wagon boss leading them on to California.  Along the way Fargo must overcome many problems such as Indians and bandidos--seems someone on the wagon train has a map pointing the way to $10,000 and the word has gotten out.  At least a couple gangs of "badlanders" are looking to waylay the train to get the map.  Ole Skye Fargo may rue the day he got involved with this group.#20 in the Trailsman series of books from 1983..

1861Pointed RockFree territory of Wyomingbelow the Oregon TrailA very weak storyline here having Skye in pursuit of wife who is lying accusing Fargo of killing her husband.  Fargo spends most of the novel in a chase to catch or re-catch her to get to the bottom of her lies.  Chase takes up most of the novel and becomes involved with attacks of the Arapaho Indians.  Usual run in with crooks too also chasing the wife before we get to the reasons why she has been doing what she is doing.For a #2 of a beginning series this book is somewhat of a let down.  I have followed this series since its inception, having a few hundred books on the shelf, and this is one of less interesting books.  This series of books now stands at #393 and most of the books have improved to the point of offering a better plot line. The books now are also written by several western writers, not just by one man, such as Jon Sharpe back in the 1980s.  Sharpe probably went on write a lot of the first 100 books or so.It may seem I don't like this series of books, however, this has become my most favorite series over the years.  I have a majority of the books published since 1980 and while this is not literature in the classic sense of the word, some of the books are really outstanding.  This one just does not appeal to me as much as the later ones.Read on book-a-roos.  Let-r-rip, pards.

Morgan Price has been working for $30 a month for the Two Pole Pumpkin as a cowboy, but has answered an add for a ranch manager job that will pay him $150 per month. He is to meet a woman, Joyce Darling, at Orrison Hotel in a town down the stageline called Sunflower.  If the interview is successful he will get the job. Only Joyce Darling is using the name "Sloan", only one of the untruths that will be revealed to Price once he is hired.  Sloan or Darling has paid the back taxes on a ranch and will begin to fill it with white-faced cattle.  But unknown to Price, 3 other men are interested in this ranch and will stop at little to get it.  In fact they have already burned all the buildings on the ranch just for a start! Price will begin to regret what he has gotten into, and quick.The men are "ruthless mavericks" who will try to run the "red headed" "female boss" and her ranch foreman straight out of the country.But Price is determined to "protect the disputed ranch" and "match guns and wits" with all comers. He and the 'strawberry roan' are here to stay.A 1964 western from Nelson Nye and ACE books.

A crossroads New Mexico town called by name, Avalon, and nicknamed, "leadtown", is in 1872 a vast sinkhole of a place.  Yet Clint Adams has been there for 2 months to find the men responsible for the murder of his 51 year-old friend and past sheriff, Cal Colby. Cal and Clint had been deputies together about four years.  Cal was older than Clint, so Clint "kind of looked up to Cal."Clint Adams doesn't figure he has so many friends that he could have one murdered without "checking it out".  Once in Avalon (Leadtown), New Mexico, Clint even accepts the month long vacant job of sheriff to officially try to solve Colby's murder.Looking for clues and answers it doesn't take long to stir up tempers in Avalon in the form of flying lead.  All aimed at Clint.Another rip-roaring, quick shooting, adventure of the Gunsmith.  A very good read.

After 18 years serving as a deputy sheriff, Clint Adams has resigned.  He is now on the road with a wagon and his black, Arabian horse Duke, to earn his living as a gunsmith. He is at present in Lawton, California.He will soon meet up with a bodyguard of a Japanese ambassador, "and a prized statue of the Golden Horseman" (The Horseman of Edo)an art work of great value that has to be transported cross country to Washington and the president.  The body guard's name is Kaiju Inoshiro and he is a samurai who works in service to his master, Nagata-sama.  Now Clint is offered a job by Kaiju for escort duty.  After considering, Clint accepts.Clint joins the Japanese train traveling across country, and the handful of samurai who are guarding the golden statue.  They are in for quite a trip as the train will continually be attacked by both outlaws of the west and ninjas from Japan. The idea is to steal this work of art so that it never reaches the president.  Will diplomatic bonds between Japan and the U.S. be affected by this or not? Can Clint and his handful of guards carry this off successfully?  Only the outcome of the trip can tell.This is #43 in the Gunsmith saga; not a real "shoot-em-up" western in the normal sense, but a fairly good read of adventure set in the west. Somewhat of a different view of the Gunsmith than one normally gets.

I am of an age that I should remember this series but I do not.  I took a chance and ordered a copy of it a few week's back and must say I have enjoyed it very much.True it is in "living" black and white, but everything mostly was back then, and the series itself is pretty clear and well done.  It is good to see Audie Murphy and surprisingly I don remember Guy Mitchell other than as a best selling Columbia 45 rpm top ten recording artist.It is too bad that the series didn't last longer.  But we can still enjoy the 26 episodes plus "Medal of Honor:  The Audie Murphy Story" as well.Great bargain for the bucks.

How or why Clint Adams is in Lancaster, Texas, I'm unsure.  He has been shot at or bushwhacked by several persons wanting to make a reputation. One person comes to his aid, someone named Pat Garrett.  Pat is just a younger man starting out, and he very much wants to become a lawman-in this he thinks that Clint Adams can guide him.  Clint has recently given up his badge to become a gunsmith as a full time occupation, Clint doesn't want anything to do with the wearing of a badge, but he will try to guide Pat in the way to becoming a small town lawman in the west and surviving.No sooner than pinning on the badge, the past sheriff has resigned, Pat and Clint find out that the Chambers gang, nursing an old grudge against the town of Lancaster, is on the way and will try to burn it to the ground.  But will no doubt rob the bank first.Pat and Clint have their work cut out for them, as hardly no one wants to stand with them against the Chambers gang.First published in July, 1983, this is #18 in what has become a definite standard in western reading from J. R. Roberts (R. J. Randisi).  Series now stands at 388 books.Read on pards.

This is it.This is the very first one of a series that now stands at 388 books and growing. This very first in the series was published way back in January, 1982. The book has gone through at least 6 printings.  Also, the book is fairly difficult to find in 2nd hand book shops.This book is about average for the start of a new series, as it has nothing to draw from or build upon.  The Clint Adams of this book is not yet the one we have become more familiar with. The Clint Adams of this book is therefore more "cardboard" cut out or one-dimentional man than he has now become. For me the book suffers from that aspect.Clint Adams has recently given up his badge as a lawman roughly 6 months ago, bought a wagon, tools, and supplies to travel and work as a gunsmith.  In the town of Baxterville, Missouri, (until recently named Macklinville) Clint meets up with 3 women who are being invited, that is run out, of town.  They want to go to Mexico and need a trail guide.  Well, since Clint is pretty nigh broke, the $200.00 they offer sounds good.He leaves Baxterville next morning with the 3 women heading "on  the dirty and dangerous trail"  for Oklahoma, where he will break off the Shawnee Trail to the Chisholm Train. Thence he will stop for supplies at Anadarko, and then continue into Texas and down into old Mexico.  Along the way, Clint expects trouble with the Kiowa,  & Comanche tribes once in Texas, and later when in Mexico with the Apaches. He expects the trip to take 2 to 3 weeks.But a couple of things trouble him.  Macklinville was named for "Con Macklin" who they said was killed due to his tyrannical hold on the town. This is the same town Clint has just left, and he has heard enough to wonder if Macklin is really dead or this is just a scam.  Also, he keeps hearing about Macklin's Treasure and the women aren't saying as word, in fact they aren't really all that talkative and friendly now that they are on the trail.  Also, Clint believes someone is riding on their back trail, he can feel it with the hairs on his neck.  The are in for trouble for sure, make no mistake.In Anadarko, Clint sees Wild Bill Hickok and Wyatt Earp, one the more better parts of the book.  But once Clint and his party reaches Mexico, he finds that there is a lot the women have kept from him and it looks as if Clint may not get any money whatever, but may  instead lose his life.  Saying any more would ruin the plot for a interested reader.  I will only say it was good that Clint had some worries about all this along the trail, and some things he had already worked out by the time they reached Mexico. That just might be enough to save his skin.

Clint Adams has escaped 3 men trying to bushwack him, though he has been only able to kill one of them.  Also his Darley Arabian horse whom Clint dearly loves has been wounded, actually the bushwackers tried to kill the horse but missed both shots.  With one bullet wounding the horse.  Clint can forgive the men trying to kill the him, but not his horse, Eclipse.  For that he wants to see them dead.As the book unfolds, the information gained through this dead man and additional information Clint is able to find concerning the dead man's friends, Clint is able to get a fairly good understanding of the situation.  He begins to see and understand that Derrick Sands and Adam Dunn have recruited additional men and will not stop with this single bushwack. Some unknown person of money is after Clint's life.  Also the bushwackers now plan to distract Clint in a later attempt to steal Eclipse from the vet who is working on the horse.Through the aid of an able tracker, Clint is now able to move against these men.  Eight to two odds is not very good, so Clint and the tracker know they must somehow even the odds if they are to survive.Another great read in the Gunsmith series; "over fifteen million Gunsmith books in print!".Next one up: Mexico Mayhem, #387.

Having hundreds of Gunsmith paperbacks on the shelf, having read quite a few of them, I have to state with certainty that this one, #388, may be the strangest one of all, also maybe the best one of all.The "Magic Man" is one that we never figure out, one that Clint Adams never gets a good reading on either.  And at this book's ending it seems we may come across the "Magic Man" again, and for that I am truly hopeful.Clint originally comes on the Magic Man by accident, or was it.  Well, anyway, Clint begins to travel with this showman for a few cities and shows before they eventually part.  Clint heads on to Texas and the Magic Man continues onward west.  In between their meeting and parting, much happens.  It would be impossible and unfair for me to try to describe any of that.  All I will say is that to read this book is one of the most enjoyable things I've ever done.  I think J. R. Roberts (R. J. Randisi) has written one of the best novels I've ever read.  That is no exaggeration.It is one reason this series now stands at 388 books and his fans seemingly cannot get enough.  As I've said, I myself have hundreds on the shelves and I'm sure that number will continue to grow.#389, The Salt City Scrape is next, in May.  Could it possibly be better than this one?

Clint Adams, "after a few attempts  are made on his life", has decided to go to Mexico for awhile.  He is staying at Laguna Niguel, a sleepy, little town by the ocean.  While Clint finds an old friend, Avery Castle, and a Father Flynn living there, people he has known from previous times under different names, so can trouble possibly be far behind? Gun trouble that is. But the book is well written in a suspenseful manner that you never know which of these people, if any, or others,  will be sucked into the trouble. Again the cast of supporting characters is all that one can wish.This is another in the Gunsmith series, and as such helps move the entire series along.  The book ambles along pleasantly and J. R. Roberts (R. J. Randisi) is up to his normal inventiveness with good fiction.  Another book that a fan or occasional reader can enjoy. This is number 387 in the series

This movie is included in the 100 movie pak, disc 13, from Guns of the West by Mill Creek Entertainment.  Fairly good transfer, too.  At least 3 other Ritter films are included in this batch-and I am a fan of ole Tex.  On other groups from Mill Creek I have other films by Tex Ritter as many others as well.  If you enjoy these old "B" movies, don't be shy about getting them.This movie is a different kind of western, dating from 1937, in living black and white.  The plot of this one was reused several times in other movies as well: when you have a good thing, keep using it.  I do enjoy the older westerns such as this with say the ones with, Hoppy, or John Wayne. Here you have a crooked businessman who is stealing other people's horses, and if he signs a bill of sale, he eventually steals that back too. Leaving the buyer to be branded a horse thief.  Only he pulls it one to many times.Good ole fun in this western with Tex Ritter and Jerry Bergh, with many others.  Songs aren't too bad also and the cast and crew must have had fun making this one.

My wife has particularly sensitive skin, and has difficulty finding cosmetics and skin care products that don't cause irritation or even rashes.  She was very pleased to find that this Eye Serum caused her no trouble, but was disappointed to find little in the way of noticeable results.  The scent was mild and not unpleasant, and the product absorbed quickly, but there was no apparent tightening (although in fairness, there is not much need for any).  So, while the formulation is good for sensitive skin, and the sensations are pleasant, the effects are minimal, at least for her very fair skin.

It would be helpful to have some instructions for this kit, but it is doable.With the two black pieces, it's fairly straightforward to determine which end the wires come out of -- the opposite end from the sides that mate together.  The trick to figuring out how to assemble these is to pay attention to the yellow pieces -- they each fit in only one of the two black pieces, and each in only one orientation.Once you see which yellow piece goes in which black piece, it starts to fall into place.  The male pins are not round, but rather have a flat profile, and will only fit through one of the two yellow pieces properly in one particular orientation.  You cant test fit a non-crimped pin, because the crimping is necessary to fold the wings on the pin far enough that they fit in to the housing, but you can release a fully-inserted pin with a small flat-head screwdriver if you are careful -- it's like releasing a heavy-duty zip tie by pulling back on a plastic tab.The 20 blue gaskets are identical, and this is where I'm just guessing, but I thing are put on the wire before crimping the insulation crimp of the pins.  I was able to align the narrower portion of the blue gasket with the end of the insulation of the stripped wire, so that the outer crimp of the pin captures the gasket while grasping the wire insulation.In the process of learning how to do this all, I had some unsuccessful crimps.  There are exactly the correct number of male and female pins, with no spares, so I would have been pretty screwed, but I really only needed one complete connector (the kit comes with enough parts for two).  If you really need two complete connectors, be careful with those pins, or plan on buying a second set to have enough spare parts to make it through.
Great quality, strong hold.  Works great for holding the 1/2 PVC pipe used in the Reef Angel water level expansion.

I have always preferred to have a large, redundant storage server on my home network, to centralize access to commonly-needed files (e.g., video and music libraries to be accessed from any TV), and to act as a central backup server.  My first experience was with an Infrant ReadyNAS, which lasted a good four years.  Needing more storage and performance, I moved on to the Synology platform, first with a DS1511+, then more recently with the larger DS1815+.  This gives me a pretty good perspective for comparing the performance and feature set of this WD My Cloud, which is priced several hundred dollars below a similarly capacious Synology offering.The first thing to note about the WD offering is the variety of configurations in which it is available.  Diskless is self-explanatory (and the way to go if you want to populate the box with drives you already have lying around), but the 8, 16 and 24 TB configurations are confusingly labeled.  The 8TB version that I received, despite having four bays, comes populated with two 4TB drives, leaving two empty bays for future expansion.  The 16TB version comes fully populated with four 4TB drives, and the 24TB version comes fully populated with four 6TB drives.  This naming convention could be more clearly explained -- it's not even spelled out on the WD Store site.The user interface for this NAS is certainly better than some routers, but doesn't seem as polished as the Synology UI.  It certainly doesn't have the large community of third party app developers that Synology enjoys (and which provides a number of _very_ useful free applications for web hosting, surveillance, automating a lot of common media management tasks, such as SickBeard, Transmission, SABnzbd+, etc. etc.  Google these names if you're not familiar, they're great).  Despite that, the WD My Cloud does offer everything most small business or home users would expect to find in a NAS -- support for all the usual RAID formats (although no RAID 6, which, given the four bays, is essentially replaced by RAID 10).  There is support for all of the usual file sharing protocols (including TimeMachine targets for your Macs), access protocols, and administration features you would expect, and even a quietly-included torrent downloader.There are a few nice hardware features dedicated to improving reliability through redundancy -- there are two power supply inputs (so that a second connected external power supply can take over seamlessly if the first fails), two network ports (for link aggregation or failover support, but not for accessing separate LANs), UPS support via USB (so the NAS can shut down gracefully in a power outage), and cloud integration with Amazon S3 and something called ElephantDrive, with which I have no experience.The device seems to run no hotter nor louder than my Synology devices, and is certainly priced more favorably, although the feature set of this is lacking in comparison.  Synology is developing their NAS platform to the point its very nearly a full-featured OS, whereas the WD My Cloud is more of a storage device with a few extra features bolted on.

Before receiving this pair of Sennheiser RS 185 headphones, I had been enjoying both the Sennheiser RS 180 and the Sennheiser RS 160 for my television watching needs (in the upstairs gym near my daughter's room, and in the master bedroom, respectively).  I love both headphones, but this pair of RS 185 is even better!My two favorite improvements are the improved control interface on the headphones (the old ones located the power and volume too close together, and too difficult to distinguish by touch), and the automatic-on base unit.  When you're already in bed, and have the headphones and TV on, it's beyond frustrating to get out of bed, schlep to the media center, and power on the transmitter.  This pair alleviates that age-old problem ("problem," as used here, means my inability to remember to perform simple tasks).The sound quality on these (I've only tried connecting them with the optical input) is flawless, and like all my other Sennheisers, they're quite comfortable to wear, even for folks with heads as large as mine.  Also like my other Sennheisers, the use of industry standard batteries (AA) instead of some ridiculous $30 proprietary form factor is a nice design choice that demonstrates respect for the consumer.  If you forget to charge them up, you can easily swap in a new pair with no tools and in almost no time.

I was pleasantly surprised by the performance of this vacuum -- given its light weight, and that it's battery powered, I expected a dust buster level of suction.  But the suction compares favorably with a regular upright vacuum, and the performance of the powered brush roller is similar to other (lightweight) upright vacuums that rely on power cords.  The quick release of the canister from the handle / powerhead is a very nice feature, as is the quick release of the vacuum hose from the powered head (for quickly sucking up messes close to the baseboard.  The two included batteries each last quite a bit longer than I expected (more than 30 minutes of "turbo" mode vacuuming), and charge very quickly with the included charger.There aren't many drawbacks to this vacuum, and those that exist are fairly minor, but it's worth mentioning them:The brush roller has a hard time with longer dog hair, which quickly wraps it up -- our larger central vacuum powerhead does a much better job with our Bernese's shedding.There is no way to store all of the accessories on the vacuum - it comes with a crevice tool and a bendy upholstery brush -- only one of them can be stored on the vacuum, and the other has to just sit on the closet floor.The largest item that can be picked up, even with the crevice tool, is fairly small.  Where the vacuum hose enters the canister body, there is a fairly small passage, and things can get stuck there (impacting the suction of the vacuum until they are removed).  For example, I picked up a medium sized (yellow) wire nut with the vacuum, and it got stuck there, necessitating disassembly and emptying the collection canister.

This toy, while fairly nice, doesn't quite live up to the quality standards of some of the other T.S. Shure magnetic dress-up toys.  These are a little lower quality pressboard, and the container doesn't close securely, permitting the parts to fall out.  Nevertheless, there's a nice variety of clothes for the two children, and my nearly-four-year-old daughter enjoys playing with it, which is what matters most.

My nearly-four-year-old daughter loves these T.S. Shure magnetic toys (she has this set as well as the Wooden Farm Blocks Playset).  They have a high-quality, hefty feel, with bright and colorful graphics, and plenty of variety for both the horse and rider to keep a young child well entertained.

These wooden blocks are very high quality, with bright colors and smooth corners.  The board book is too short to hold her attention, but the wood pieces are a hit--my 3-year old daughter loves playing farm with them.  The only drawback is that the box which is supposed to contain them, is really just an open tray.

I purchased four of the 15W 1100-Lumen 2700K bulbs for use in our laundry room ceiling cans.  Within 9 months, two of them have burned out.  The cost and effort of shipping them back to the company (at my expense, naturally) to obtain warranty replacement is not worth the benefit (receiving more bulbs with a half-life of less than a year).Lesson learned.--UPDATE--Two months later, and a third of the four bulbs has now died.  Failure rate up to 75% -- what a disappointment.

These auger bits are definitely on the low end of quality (fresh from the factory, there are nicks and burrs in the cutting edges).  I would have guessed they were Chinese pot metal Harbor Freight loss-leaders, and was surprised to learn they were manufactured in Brazil.  At least mine don't appear to have any rust on them, however, unlike what I see in the product photographs submitted by others.The performance of the bits isn't terribly impacted by the poor appearance, however.  They bore straight, largely clean holes (varies between bits), which for someone with my skill level in fine carpentry (read: rank amateur)  is adequate.  With an average cost per bit in the double digits, it doesn't seem like the best value, however.

I received these bits for review shortly after buying and using the [[ASIN: B002BYUXIW Bosch DareDevil Spade Bits]] for some low-voltage installation work (running speaker wire and cat5 cable through the crawlspace and up into wall cavities).  When I used the Bosch bits, I was thrilled at how much faster they were than my old standard spades. But that was before I tried these Speedbors.These Speedbors pull themselves through wood so much faster than the DareDevils, it's almost impossible to believe.  They require a powerful drill (I use, probably inappropriately, an 18V Dewalt impact driver, so I don't have to worry about torquing my wrists around if the bits catch).  The bits are very heavy, and take up a lot of space compared to flat spades, but they do a fantastic job of making big holes, quickly.

This Fluke temperature and humidity meter gives consistent temperature and humidity readings, is enclosed in a sturdy yellow plastic body that gives the impression it would survive some pretty vigorous abuse, includes a helpful back-light for taking measurements in crawlspaces and attics, and can save measurements in an on-board memory for later recordation.  The sensor is protected by a somewhat fragile-seeming shutter, that must stay closed to keep the calibration of the device.  Cost is the only downside that I see to this well-made professional-grade tool.

Read all the bullet points in the summary at the top of the page. Then read all of the "detailed description." Did you see the word "string" anywhere? No. How may times do you see the word "fly," "flies," or "floats"? FIVE (and that's not counting the numerous instances of "flit," which according to the thesaurus, is a synonym for "fly").This toy is overpriced garbage that is foisted off on unsuspecting grandparents with criminally dishonest advertising copy. My parents purchased this on Amazon as a Christmas present for my daughter, who was less than impressed with a non-articulating doll with fragile tinsel wings that judder when the inappropriately large and obvious switch on her thigh is activated. The pair of large metal wires that protrude from the small of her back and act as a makeshift 'stand' against which to lean her are also fragile, unnecessary, and detract from the play value of the toy.But all of that (which would merit the toy one star unless it retailed for well under $5) pales in comparison to the implementation of "flitting," "flying" and "floating" -- IT HANGS FROM A GARROTE, excuse me, I mean to say IT HANGS FROM A STRING THAT ATTACH TO YOUR CHILD's HEAD. The 'magic wand' is just something your child can use to manipulate the garrote, errr.., string, to make it appear that the dangling fairy is reacting to the movements of the wand. Ugh.Thirty cents in manufacturing costs and blatantly dishonest descriptions do not a twenty dollar toy make. If I hadn't disposed of the packaging material, this would absolutely go back to Amazon in a gift return. As it is, my parents got the Christmas joy of seeing my disinterested daughter demonstrating, via video chat, the pathetic toy that they were tricked into purchasing by a dishonest description. Shame on the manufacturer, and shame on Amazon for not pulling this in response to the numerous reviews indicating the flaws in the product description.

My parents purchased this on Amazon as a Christmas present for my daughter, who was less than impressed with a non-articulating doll with fragile tinsel wings that judder when the inappropriately large and obvious switch on her thigh is activated. The pair of large metal wires that protrude from the small of her back and act as a makeshift 'stand' against which to lean her are also fragile, unnecessary, and detract from the play value of the toy.But all of that (which would merit the toy one star unless it retailed for well under $5) pales in comparison to the implementation of "flitting," "flying" and "floating" -- IT HANGS FROM A GARROTE, excuse me, I mean to say IT HANGS FROM A STRING THAT ATTACH TO YOUR CHILD's HEAD. The 'magic wand' is just something your child can use to manipulate the garrote, errr.., string, to make it appear that the dangling fairy is reacting to the movements of the wand. Ugh.Thirty cents in manufacturing costs and blatantly dishonest descriptions do not a twenty dollar toy make. If I hadn't disposed of the packaging material, this would absolutely go back to Amazon in a gift return. As it is, my parents got the Christmas joy of seeing my disinterested daughter demonstrating, via video chat, the pathetic toy that they were tricked into purchasing by a dishonest description. Shame on the manufacturer, and shame on Amazon for not pulling this in response to the numerous reviews indicating the flaws in the product description.

The advertising for this product is INCREDIBLY DISHONEST.Read all the bullet points in the summary at the top of the page. Then read all of the "detailed description." Did you see the word "string" anywhere?  No.  How may times do you see the word "fly," "flies," or "floats"?  FIVE (and that's not counting the numerous instances of "flit," which according to the thesaurus, is a synonym for "fly").This toy is overpriced garbage that is foisted off on unsuspecting grandparents with criminally dishonest advertising copy. The 'magic wand' is just something your child can use to manipulate the garrote, errr.., string, to make it appear that the dangling fairy is reacting to the movements of the wand.  Ugh.Thirty cents in manufacturing costs and blatantly dishonest descriptions do not a twenty dollar toy make.  If I hadn't disposed of the packaging material, this would absolutely go back to Amazon in a gift return. Despite a rough first impression, this is a great stapler.  If, however, you're curious to see how the pull force required to fire a staple differs from your old Arrow stapler, I recommend _not_ absent-mindedly driving a staple into a sheet of carboard that you're holding from behind.  I can, however, testify with acutely first-hand knowledge that the staples are driven with quite a bit of force: more than enough to reach the bones in your fingers!That shameful confession aside, this staple gun is easy to use and well made - the amount of force required to fire a staple does not increase dramatically as you get close to the end of the handle pull, meaning it will be much easier to use in awkward spaces where a solid grip is hard to come by.  Loading is also easier than the Arrow staplers I'm used to -- although it took a minute to sort out how to load; instead of loading the staples into the tray that slides out the back, you load the staples into the belly of the stapler once the tray is out of the way, and then slide it back over the staples.  There's a nice lock on the handle that holds it in the closed position (although you appear to have to fire a staple to get it into that position), and a belt clip that's a little too loose to be secure unless you've got a pretty thick belt to hang it from -- just  hanging it from the waist band of your jeans isn't enough to positively secure it.  Finally, the stapler is surprisingly light, but doesn't feel cheaply made despite the lack of heft.

This monitor is the envy of my coworkers -- besides boasting tremendous real estate, it enjoys nicely modern styling (thin bezel, attractive and functional stand), beautifully bright and saturated colors at an impressive 1440p resolution, and a very-well implemented anti-glare coating that is not too textured (some monitors in this regard look like they've been sprayed with a clear orange-peel texture spray), and works perfectly to eliminate reflections from the windows behind my desk.Some caveats -- there is no DVI nor VGA connections on the this monitor, it only accepts the more modern DisplayPort (also Apple's Thunderbolt, which uses the same physical connector) and HDMI.  Converters are available online, in case your computer (like the one provided by my employer) is archaically old.  Happily, it accepts both mini-DisplayPort (mDP) and full-size DisplayPort (DP) inputs, and includes a single cable with an mDP connector on one end, and a full-size DP connector on the other.  Whatever DP format output your computer has, you'll be able to connect with this single cable.

Some games are beautiful and intricate, almost works of art, but are tedious to play.  Some games are hilarious laugh riots, but are so badly made that half the humor is in how bad they look / work.  Far Cry 4 is both a work of art and hilariously fun to play.The world is beautifully designed and rendered, large and immersive.  The combat mechanics are intuitive and smooth.  The animal interactions are fantastic -- you can RIDE AN ELEPHANT INTO COMBAT, which is hysterical, and a skill upgrade totally worth pursuing.There are enough quests to keep you goal-driven for a long time, if that's your preferred play style.  And the world is so large and intricate that you can endlessly explore with no goals at all.  Good for weeks and weeks of fun, and a steal at twice the price.

First, these headphones are _comfortable_.  With many headsets, either the cups or the band start to get irritating within half an hour or so.  With these, it feels like my head is wrapped with a comfy pillow.  As this is a make or break issue for headphones, that'd be five stars all by itself.  Thankfully, there's even more to love.The sound quality is very good, even without the fancy USB sound card (which permits additional features, including useful ones such as Dolby support, and absurdly unnecessary ones, such as LED lighting).  The built in microphone is well designed, and folds conveniently out of the way (and turns itself off when stowed).  The dials on the headphones are very well implemented - no struggling to find small volume buttons that are flush with the cups.

This armband case fits very snugly around a bare iPhone 6 -- if you use a case, you'd better have one that's easy-on and easy-off, because it probably won't fit in this sleeve without removing it first.  The phone is easy enough to use once it's inside the case, although in bright sunlight, the combined glare from this case and the phone screen makes reading difficult.  That's not too much of a problem indoors, or if you run at night.  The strap is secure and keeps the phone right where you position it.  All in all, a good (tight) case.

This mobile keyboard is very well designed and built.  The cover cleverly doubles as a stand for your mobile device, and acts like an iPad smart cover does for switching the keyboard on and off.  The keys have a good tactile response, although they feel a bit crowded (which is to be expected for a keyboard as travel-friendly as this one).  The battery feels as though it will last nearly forever without being recharged, which is a nice bit of over-engineering.  The function buttons are well implemented for supporting multiple devices and operating systems.  I can't think of a single CON.

With pin-straight, fine hair, this iron doesn't see much use as a straightener.  But as a curler, it does a pretty good job, despite being a little on the too-hot side.  It heats up quickly, and is easy to use for curls in either direction.  For fine hair, there's not much hope for tight curls, but for wide curls or waves, it works very well.

This Mega Bloks table is a nice addition to our Mega Bloks collection, and really captured the interest of my 3-year old daughter.  The included castle- and princess-shaped pieces make the building experience more imaginative for her, as compared to just the plain blocks that were included with our original Mega Bloks bag.  By itself, this set would have pretty limited building opportunities, but in combination with a more numerous set of blocks, her creativity is unconstrained.  I like that the legs fold up for storage, as the other table toys she played with when younger are real space hogs (e.g., the musical table for babies).

Everything about this bassinet is wonderful:* it has a nice modern aesthetic that blends in with our bedroom furniture* its height adjusts easily to be level with the bed* it pivots easily out of the way to make getting into and out of bed simple* the side drops down to permit easy access to baby* the built in lights are dim enough to not disturb, but bright enough to work by* its sturdiness is confidence-inspiring

This ride-on toy is reasonably nice -- it's sturdy and attractive, and includes the usual noise-making buttons that parents so love.  The excavator arm on the back is a nice addition, so that the toy can be enjoyed even when not being ridden.  It should be noted that it doesn't steer at all (there's no linkage from the steering wheel to the front wheels), and therefore isn't the best for riding around a playroom full of obstacles.  Kids have to pick it up, turn it, and set it down (which is not uncommon for ride-ons, but not as nice as the Winnie the Pooh airplane we have with steering linkage).More confusingly, the "Mega Bloks" connection with this toy is tenuous -- there's a few small spaces where blocks can be attached (for no purpose that I can see, other than to create unwieldy extensions from a ride-on truck that will immediately fall off if they get more than a few blocks high).  The number of included blocks is low,  since there isn't much to do with them, other than scoop them into the arm and then dump them out, which you can do with any small object, and not just Mega Bloks.Still, it's an attractive and sturdy construction-themed toy that will entertain your little one.  Just don't expect to extend it much with more Mega Bloks.

This speaker hits all the right notes: it's compact, powerful, ruggely-built, and attractive.  It also pairs quickly and easily, with voice confirmation, and gets enough runtime for a long game of poker on a single charge.  Recharging is quick, although the included USB charge cable is not accompanied by an AC adapter - you'll have to provide your own or find a USB outlet somewhere.  The ability to take calls feels a bit unnecessary (when would I be using a bluetooth speaker for providing music to a larger space, and also want the ability to take a speaker phone call?), but no harm in including extra features, I guess.  All in all, this is a great little speaker for dining on the patio with music, or taking to the park for a picnic, or providing tunes for a garage poker game.

I'm very much looking forward to automating lights and outlets in my home, but have been holding off until a more mature and user-friendly solution is available.  Before receiving this lighting starter set for review, I had researched X-10 (antiquated), Insteon and Z-wave (a bit too patchwork and patent-encumbered) and ZigBee (too proprietary) solutions.  None of these seemed mature and future-proof enough to justify the time, money and effort it would take to fully automate all the functions I'd like automated in my home (lighting, climate, & security).The Belkin approach seems more user-friendly than these others, and the price not too bad considering the design philosophy: embedding the wireless controllers inside of the bulbs, rather than the sockets.  Since they're LED bulbs, with a diode that should outlast the other components far better than a filament ever would, that didn't seem like too bad of an idea.  Regrettably, the only light options currently available are Type-A bulbs in a medium-warm color (3000 K or so).  No other bulb shapes (BR30, BR40, PAR38) or colors (5000K) are currently available.  Still, we have a few fixtures that take bulbs of this size, and additional system components would surely be released if the technology catches on.Rather than including a more expensive WiFi chipset in each bulb, the system is built with a WiFi bridge (the "Link") that communicates with the bulbs over a less expensive wireless technology -- this necessitates enough bridges to cover all the areas where you want to put bulbs (which do not act as repeaters, as in the more flexible networks provided by Insteon and Z-Wave).  Unfortunately, the range on the Link is fairly small, and quickly drops off if any walls or sturdy furniture is in the way.  For a large home, to fully automate would require a large number of Links, which would rapidly become expensive.For a small automation project, this solution can still be quite nice.  I once had a combination lamp alarm clock (the Philips HF3470 Wake-up light) that would increase in brightness in the morning to wake me up gently (I loved it, but it doesn't work well for couples with different schedules in the same bed).  This set would easily replicate that functionality (assuming you had a backup audible alarm) without the ugly plastic bedside abomination.  Also workable with this set would be a front porch schedule for evening illumination you wouldn't have to remember to run off (although that could more cost-effectively be done with a hard-wired solution like the Honeywell Econoswitch).While this set could work for some small-scale automation projects, the limited range on the Link, together with the cost of additional Links and the limited selection of bulb types, keep this from being the automation  solution I've been waiting for.

This toy microscope is very well made (sturdy and attractive), and engages the attention of my three year old daughter.  She mostly enjoys holding up the eye pieces and looking through them, rather than using them in the microscope frame.I imagine that this would make an ideal toy for a younger child who wants to play with, but can't yet be trusted with, a fully functional microscope -- then they would have something to model their play on.  Even after showing her how to place the "petri" dishes on the microscope and how to look through the eyepiece, she still prefers to use the toy her way--who am I to argue?

This doll is a hit with my three-and-a-half year old, who loves playing tea with Sofia and hearing her spoken reactions to the various tea cups and cupcakes that can be held up against her face.  Sofia can stand, if carefully positioned, and articulates just at the waist and shoulders.  Her hands and elbows are fixed so that one hand can pass through the loop of a tea cup and bring it up to her face with a shoulder rotation -- this allows my daughter to make believe that she's drinking tea.  Placing either cup, either cupcake, or her bunny friend Clover up near her amulet prompts one of a few spoken responses, that are specific to the item held close.  Additional phrases can be prompted by pressing her amulet, which glows while she speaks (and while, confusingly, she generates the sound of Clover speaking).A few drawbacks: The included basket is not large enough to contain all the accessories (the cupcake stand won't even barely fit by itself, and the picnic blanket eats up a ton of room as well).  The cost is fairly high for what it can do (no movement, just  spoken phrases, and a few items that prompt interaction).  If not for these, this would be a five star set

Before receiving this Learning Train set, my daughter was fond of playing with her other Mega Bloks set (the standard building bag available [[ASIN B007GE75HY:here]]), which included just unadorned building blocks and one wheeled block.  This set has dramatically increased her enjoyment of Mega Blocks, because of the additional wheeled blocks (there are three train cars, each a half-height 2x4 block with wheels and a hook on one end and an eye on the other for attaching them into a line), and the decorative stickers that include numbers, number shapes (e.g., 4 circles on a green background, 5 something-elses on a yellow background, etc.), train paraphernalia (luggage, station lamps, etc.), and even a vaguely-train-engine-shaped piece with eyes.The large half-height 4x4 blocks that act as a lid for the included cardboard box make it possible to build large tunnel shapes, and could make the box useable as a container for the bloks (although, being fairly thin cardboard, it would not last long if played with).  We just dumped the bloks into our storage bin with the others, and tossed the cardboard.The included colors vary from those in the classic block set (which include red, yellow, light green, light blue and dark blue).  This set has purple, lavender, orange and dark green as well.  The wheeled blocks roll remarkably well on even very thick carpet.The only drawbacks to this set are: the stickers come on a sheet, and need to be applied (and peel off fairly easily); and the connections between train blocks are not very secure.  Neither of those would justify removing a star, so still a 5-star for me and mine.

No problems cutting 1.0" schedule 80 PVC for an aquarium project.  Cuts weren't always perfectly straight -- the width (pipe-length-wise) isn't quite enough to get the blade square to the pipe every time.  It's possible (but not at all recommended) to do 1.5" schedule 80 with this, if you open the jaws as wide as they can go and turn the pipe as you cut, but if I were doing it again, I'd find another way to make cuts in the 1.5" schedule 80 pipe.  Maybe an excuse to buy a cordless band saw?

This aluminum table is surprisingly lightweight, and really very attractive.  It also has a very small diameter base, and a high center of gravity.  A little nudge can send it right over, so beware of placing anything tall or heavy on it, and don't put it anywhere you might see foot traffic (or kids playing, or rambunctious medium- or large-sized dogs).  I hope to work out a way to get some lead weights into the base piece (there are three pieces that screw together) to improve this issue, but am otherwise very happy with the purchase.

We bought the mattress only, rather than the set on Amazon, so we could get the slim (4.5") foundation rather than the full-sized (9") foundation that comes with the set.  This review doesn't say "Verified Purchase," but you can see the one that does over on the mattress-only page.  I'm repeating it here to try to save someone else from making the same mistake I did.Despite being the very top of the Beautyrest Recharge World Class line, this is, without a doubt, the worst mattress I have ever had the misfortune to sleep on. Both I and my wife have been miserable since we took delivery, waking up every morning feeling worse than the day before. Eventually we were forced to sleep in our guest room on our previous (queen sized) mattress (also a Beautyrest), which I now heartily regret replacing. I've just scheduled a return to Amazon, although I'm certain that will cost me a fortune in shipping, because I can't live like this anymore.My wife prefers firm mattresses, whereas I like a bit more give than she does. This mattress, though described as "luxury firm," is neither luxurious nor firm. It feels like they covered a concrete block with seven inches of cotton candy -- there's no comfort or support from the foam layers, AT ALL (you can compress the mattress 5 inches with your hand, before ever encountering any spring pressure), and the springs just straight up don't compress. They're not springs. They're coil-shaped pocketed steel rebar designed either by a sadist, or a chiropractor looking to drum up business in bulk.Just awful.

I've had this 60" Vizio for nearly three months now.  For the first 30 days, my only real complaint was that the implementation of the active LED zones (64 zones on the 60" model) was somewhat flawed.  The halo of white light that surrounds a bright object on a dark background (the most obvious is with white text on black background, such as a movie title card) is not terribly noticeable while the bright object is still on screen, but becomes VERY noticeable when the bright object disappears.  There is a time delay between the content disappearing, and the backlight shutting down, that leaves a bright white blur on the screen for at least a quarter of a second, maybe even a half second, and it's really glaringly obvious.  From what I've read online, it seems as though my set either takes longer to shut down the backlight, or I'm more sensitive to it than most.  Either way, it's an unfortunate effect that I can't stop noticing.Thankfully, this effect is mostly limited to title cards and the like -- most actual video content involves bright objects moving against a dark background, and I don't notice any trailing blur of backlight behind a moving bright object.  It seems that the TV is caught off-guard when a bright object just completely disappears, and it takes longer to turn the backlight LEDs off than it should.It's not clear to me whether this represents a problem with my particular screen, or if its something experienced by other 60" sets.  I'd be happy to hear from anyone in the comments who has a 60", so I can know whether to exchange this one or learn to live with it.  For the record, I've implemented the same customization settings as were initially recommended for the 70" model (which also sports a Sharp VA panel), so I'm not overdriving the brightness setting at the crazy 100% default (42 is what I have it at, 2.4 gamma, etc. etc.).--- UPDATE AFTER 30 DAY RETURN WINDOW CLOSED ----The other problem that I noticed did not crop up until after the Amazon.com 30-day return window closed.  My setup involves a WDTV Live feeding both video and audio through a single HDMI cable to the Vizio tv directly, and the TV outputting the audio via a Toslink optical line to a Marantz NR1403 receiver. This setup allows me to use the receiver to drive larger speakers when I want to watch content that justifies them, or just to use the TV audio (usually the analog output to wireless headphones) when I don't want to use the receiver.  Unfortunately, the TV appears to have some compatibility problems with the audio content of some of my media.  Many local files will have audio "gaps" -- sporadic short silences that are glaringly obvious.  These gaps occur whether I output the audio from the TV to the receiver, use the TV speakers, or even use the TV's analog audio output to drive headphones.  It only happens with some file types, always in the same spots, and only occurs when the TV is relied on to process or even pass-through audio.  In reaching this conclusion, I've tried different hdmi cables (no change), different HDMI ports on the TV (no change), a different WDTV Live (no change), factory resets on both the WDTV and the Vizio TV(no change), every setting option under the sun on both devices, including bitstream and PCM formats (no change), playing the same content from the same WDTV device on a Samsung TV (works fine), outputting the hdmi from the WDTV to the receiver first, then passing it on to the Vizio TV (no audio gaps, receiver can decode the file flawlessly), and most frustratingly, scheduling a Vizio service call to replace the mainboard of the television (same audio gaps with the new mainboard).  Therefore, it doesn't appear to be a hardware problem unique to my TV, and it doesn't appear to be a problem with the audio files, rather it appears to be a design defect with the television in processing certain digital audio formats.If you don't need to route audio through the TV, this may never be an issue for you.  And setting aside these concerns (audio and halos), everything else about the TV has been really very nice.  The remote has a well-implemented (IR) keyboard on the backside to facilitate input for the streaming services, which thankfully doesn't interfere with operating the regular IR remote buttons on the other side (I haven't had any problem registering key presses on either side, or accidentally hitting buttons on the wrong side).  The keyboard works so well, I initially wondered if it might be an RF remote, since it seemed to work without pointing it at the TV; as pointed out in the comments, though, you can see the IR emitter when you remove the cover to access the battery compartment.  The upscaling of 1080p content is really very well implemented, and watching a quality 1080p feed on this screen reminds me of the first time I saw the Planet Earth videos on BluRay.  The wireless antenna has no problem picking up the signal from my router two rooms away.

I have been paying for razor cartridges for a couple of decades now, and would really like an electric shaver that could give me a comfortable, close shave without the recurring costs.  Regrettably, I've never been able to find one.  Even after trying this (admittedly well-built) shaver, I still haven't.I have fairly sensitive skin, I guess, because I have never  been able to keep up a shave-every-day regimen without causing a pretty dramatic breakout on my face.  For the longest time, I've been keeping a MWF shave schedule, and just accepting the TuThSaSu scruff as the price of avoiding bright red razor burn.  Thankfully, I can get away with a day's growth at my job, as  a day's growth on me isn't really all that messy a look.  Shaving a two- or three-day beard with a Mach3 and a wet face is a quick, easy, painless process, and I get good life out of my blades (around two weeks) just by stropping them on the bath towel around my waist as I go.When I first tried this shaver, it was a Monday morning, and I hadn't shaved over the weekend.  Although my beard doesn't come in very very thick, three days of growth will get me some pretty long hairs, and this shaver just absolutely couldn't handle them.  I started with dry skin (post-shower dry with a towel, but in a fairly humid bathroom), and could barely get a single hair cut.  I switched to the usual shave cream, which didn't seem to help matters at all, even making it a little worse (As though the shave cream held the hair flush against the skin).  I gave up and switched to the Mach3, although the few moments of struggling with the shaver had already left me with pretty irritated skin.I tried again on Wednesday with a two-day beard, and just with hot water right after the shower.  This time, it was able to catch and cut hairs, no pulling or pinching, but I had to keep circling over and over and over in the same spots to make any headway, and after five minutes of trying, had maybe thinned my two-day scruff by around 50%.  Giving up again, I got out the Mach3 and shaved away the rest in under a minute.I thought I'd try on Thursday, since the problem seemed to be with longer follicles, and it did seem to have an easier time with one-day scruff, but still would stubbornly refuse to cut down a noticeable amount on the more challenging jawline and lip spots.  I don't have a lot of confidence that a follicle I miss one day will be easier to cut the next, given how it struggles with longer hairs, but I couldn't just keep circling the same spot over and over indefinitely, as even on the slow speed, I could feel the skin growing irritated.In short, I just don't have a face / beard that plays well with electric shavers.  I'd wondered before if perhaps it was because of the quality of the shavers I'd used in the past, but given how nice a build quality this Philips has, I no longer wonder if that's the case.  If you're like me, and have been disappointed by electric shavers in the past, you may not want to place too much hope in this one working better for you.  If you do like electrics, then this one has a really high-quality build, attractive aesthetic, confidence-inspiring cleaning station, and quality travel case.  But as to the most important feature of shave quality?  Well, this one just doesn't work any better for me than anything else I've tried in the last 20 years.

This dock makes a really nice addition to the bedside, turning the iPhone into an attractive alarm clock.  The dock only comes with a (permanently attached) USB cable to provide power, so you'll need to provide your own AC-USB power adapter if you want to use the dock merely for charging from the wall.  The interior of the dock is lined with a rubbery soft material that protects the phone from scraping against the (admittedly sharp-edged aluminum), but the distance from the charging plug and the rear surface of the dock is so great that there is no real risk of rubbing (unless you are using a particularly thick case).  The dock is heavy enough that your phone will stay in place and not tip over (although the dock is not heavy enough, and the connector is snug enough, that it's challenging to remove the phone with one hand).

If I hadn't discovered the Sunbeam Therapeutic Heated Mattress Pad, I would have loved this mattress pad unconditionally, mostly because it's nice not to have my comfort level determined by how cold my wife's feet are.  Having a dual zone heated mattress pad is fantastic, right up until you compare it to a six-zone heated mattress pad (at the previous link).  This pad will (reasonably) quickly warm up to the desired temperature(s), and stay there for 10 hours.  All at a very reasonable price, and with minimal wiring fuss.For comparison's sake, the Sunbeam Therapeutic that we've since upgraded to allows you to have six zones (three for each sleeper - head, body, feet), and to keep them heated indefinitely, and uses a (single, unfortunately) wireless digital controller to adjust the temperature zones.  Well worth the (significant) additional cost for the ability to have one person warm their feet, without toasting their bum, while the other warms their bum, without roasting their feet.

I love love love my Fujitsu ScanSnap, so I was interested to see how well a device that retails for 1/3 less would stack up against it.  In short, the scanning hardware seems pretty comparable, but the software and Mac support suffers in the comparison.Both the ScanSnap and this WorkForce will quickly devour documents that you feed it.  With the Fujitsu, turning a paper document to a text-searchable PDF is nearly instantaneous (in Mac OSX on a recent iMac), and can be done with a single press of the button on the scanner.  With the WorkForce, the software titles (Epson Scan and Document Capture Pro) are clunky, slow, feel hopelessly out-of-date, and it's difficult to find where the PDF option is (not in Epson Scan), let alone the slow-as-molasses OCR.  I can't speak to the experience in a Windows environment, but for a Mac user, the extra money would be well spent to get access to the Fujitsu's much better software environment.  Should there be third-party software available that could benefit from the rugged hardware (I don't have Acrobat Pro, so I can't speak to this), then this might be a great deal.  Otherwise, three stars for Mac users.

If you're looking for a great monochrome laser printer with duplexing, this certainly fits the bill, although for less money, you can get a similarly great (and even slightly faster) duplex monochrome laser printer in the Brother HL6180DW, which I have been using for the past year or so.  With this Lexmark, you get the added benefit of scan / fax / copy functionality, although not in a flat-bed arrangement (sheet-fed only).  Considering the steep price premium you would pay for this added functionality, it might make more sense to purchase a more versatile flatbed scanner with the cheaper Lexmark, unless your scanning / copying needs can be handled by an exclusively sheet-fed device like this one.As a printer, this Lexmark is easy to set up (at least in the OSX environment where I use it), very speedy to print the first page, with subsequent pages coming out every 2 seconds or so, and doesn't bog down with big PDFs as much as some other printers (and the expandable memory should ameliorate this, for people that will be churning out lots and lots of graphics-heavy PDFs).As a scanner / copier, it does an adequate job, but can't hold a candle to the speed and convenience and quality of a dedicated scanner like the Fujitsu ScanSnap that is at the heart of my paperless home office.  If you don't have a scanner already, and don't want to splurge on a dedicated device, this will do the job (albeit much more slowly).All in all, a solid laser monochrome MFP (with duplexing, which once you've experienced, you'll never want to do without).

I have some serious reservations about this product.* the inaccessible internal battery can only be charged with a non-standard DC adapter.  Once it runs down in a power-outage, there's no charging it again until the grid is back up.* the flashlight handle is on backwards.  Look at the photo -- when you fold the handle down, the "grip" portion of the handle is oriented the wrong way, such that you'll be shining the lantern end outwards and the flashlight end in your eyes.* the lantern is pretty dim; much more so than the flashlight.  The configuration of the internal reflector for the lantern casts light out to the sides only -- and the overhanging "top hat" lid needlessly casts a larger shadow upwards.  With this amount of light, I presume the lantern mode should run for a long time, but you'd get nearly as much light from a candle.* if you wanted brighter light, you could shine the flashlight at the ceiling; but for unknown reasons there is a non-functional bump on the lid of the lantern that makes balancing the light in this orientation needlessly challengingOn the plus side, the dim LED emitter will probably last a good while, enough to get you through a less-than-one-day power outage.  And having this flashlight/lantern is better than having nothing.  But it's nowhere near as useful as having separate battery-operated LED lanterns and flashlights on hand.

The installation of this adapter ring is far more challenging than it should be.  The ring is actually two parts, and each must be installed with its corner tabs _behind_ the device you're hoping to adapt.  This requires some bending and flexing of the ring, and a lot of swearing.  Once the two parts are installed behind the top and bottom of the decora strap, you must secure them with fiddly little screws that are a challenge to line up.  Having done that, you'll find that the leviton plate doesn't _quite_ fit around the adapter ring without a lot of pushing and bending and hitting and more swearing.Some things to note:* the ring sticks up higher than the level of the decora device, and flush with the wall plate.  I used this adapter to help a single gang keystone strap (with network and A/V plugs) blend better on the wall with the other Renu power outlets.  The keystone strap looks "set back" into the wall plate (unlike other Renu devices, where the power outlet sticks out past the level of the wall plate).* the outline of the ring is visible between the Renu plate and the decora device - choose an adapter color that matches at least one of them.  I chose a white ring to match the white keystone strap, and it looks pretty good in the warm caramel plate on our tan wall.* I can't be sure (since I installed this on a single gang device), but it looks like the height of the tabs that hold the Renu plate is higher on this adapter than other Renu devices -- if you install it in a multi-gang setup, there might be some issues getting everything aligned at the same height.  That's probably why they require the corners of this adapter to sit behind the decora strap, but it looks like the mounting tabs are still a bit elevated (they can only sit so far back, based on the thickness of the decora device they're surrounding).Still, I'm glad I bought and installed this adapter.  If only Leviton would offer more colors / number of outlets for their QuickPort inserts, that would be better, but in the meantime, this is a good solution.

I tend to prefer the non-folding utility knives (with the blades that slide in and out), because they can be used one-handed.  But it is nice to have a utility knife that takes up less space for storage in a glove box or small tool bag.  This seems as sturdy as any I have used, and securely locks when open.  The inclusion of a small interchangeable-bit driver on the rear of the handle is a nice addition, for those occasional tasks where you need to do just a _little_ screw tightening or loosening (the shape of the tool does not lend itself well to screwdriving when closed, and it is unsafe to use it in that fashion when open).

Well after the return window was closed, and well after Amazon stopped selling these (only third party merchants, now), I noticed that I had two copies of "The Sonnets" and was missing "The Tempest."  I located someone else who had purchased this set, and they had two copies of "Twelfth Night," and were missing "The Two Gentlemen of Verona."These drop shipped from Penguin directly to the customer, so thank Penguin for the mix-up if you realize that you're missing a volume.In a related note, I'm looking for a copy of the Tempest, and have an extra Sonnets to trade, if anyone is interested.

As skeptical as I am of (alkaline-battery-powered) electronic locks in high-reliability applications, I've previously steered clear of gun safes unless they are mechanically opening (my favorite is the V-Line Quick Vault that's installed behind a picture frame suspended on a Hangman french cleat).  I once tried the ADG Sports Secure pistol safe, but was gobsmacked at how easily the door would pop open accidentally on that one.This Sentry Safe impresses with its small dimensions (it fits into bedside drawers that the ADG safe would not), its pry-resistant door design (the front lip is turned down to rob a pry bar of its upward leverage), and the speed with which the door opens -- after I programmed a combo, I thought I might have neglected to program the last digit, since it seemed to open before I finished pushing the final button, but it's just that fast.I was also pleasantly surprised by the reliability of the fingerprint programming.  I programmed my two index fingers, which took just a few seconds (the safe keeps re-scanning the same finger until it's satisfied -- it only took me four or five swipes for each finger), and then it reliably opened for those two fingers, and no others, every time I tried.  I haven't owned it long enough to know whether changes in humidity, temperature, or injuries to my finger tips (common when you're clumsy) will impact its reliability.My wife's fingers took quite a bit more training before they would register, and still resulted in a few false negatives (not letting her in) although thankfully no false positives, when we tried it on all the family members who were visiting for Christmas.Still, even if the fingerprint scanner doesn't let you in, there's the programmable buttons that you can use to open the safe (and, obviously, an override key).  My gripe with the safe is about how you interact with the buttons:  before you can input your key code (or scan your fingerprint) you have to "wake up" the safe.  You can wake up the safe by either putting your finger on the print sensor, or by pushing one of the buttons.  The first button that you push, however, doesn't count towards your code entry.So, if your code is 1-2-3-4-5 (please don't make that your code), you could not open the safe by pushing 1-2-3-4-5.  You would have to push 1-1-2-3-4-5 or 2-1-2-3-4-5 or X-1-2-3-4-5 (where X is the fingerprint sensor).  Unfortunately, you won't remember this until you've already pushed the first two buttons of your combo, and have to keep pushing buttons until the safe flashes a red light and refuses to open.  Then you can put your combo in again.I imagine this is a battery-saving function (BTW, 4xAA alkaline batteries only, says the manual), but it's a pain.  Why can't the first button wake up the safe AND count towards your combo?  This is enough of a pain that I can't rate it five stars.

As slide scanners go, this one is designed to be pretty user friendly -- no computer required, small color preview screen, and saves to (an included) SD card.  The "scans" (really, it's taking a picture of the slide with a small CCD above the slide/negative that's lit from below) are completed very quickly, and the auto-focus and auto-exposure that takes place during scanning seem to do a good job, although the auto-color balance leaves some color-balancing work to be done on a computer.  The image quality of the scans is about what you'd expect from something that works this quickly, at this price point, where the main selling point is convenience -- they're okay.  If you're mostly interested in being able to see the subject matter of your photos of family vacations and parties, then this will fit the bill.  If you want to capture all the quality that you can out of your slides/negatives, you'll have to spend a bit more, or consider other approaches.It's probably safe to assume that if you're considering buying a slide and negative scanner, it's not because you're still shooting photos on film.  Rather, you have boxes or binders full of old photographs that you want brought up to date.  So a slide scanner is the kind of thing you would buy for exactly one extremely labor-intensive project, and then get rid of.A more user-friendly approach to the box-of-slides-problem would be to utilize any one of a large number of professional slide/negative scanning services, which allow you to mail a box of slides/negatives and get back a DVD with high resolution photos that have been corrected in various ways (scratches, dirt, color cast).  Given the price of this dedicated slide scanner, and the low cost of scanning services (between fifteen and thirty cents per slide), the service might be a better solution (unless the photos you want to digitize number in the thousands).The quality of the resultant scans that this scanner produces is not that high - if you're looking to archive your treasured family photos, and determined to do it yourself, you might be well advised to purchase a more expensive slide scanner (possibly used) and to recoup most of that hardware cost by selling the scanner once you've scanned all your old photos.Alternatively, instead of a slide scanner, you could also use the same amount of money to purchase a reasonably good quality flatbed scanner with a slide/film tray (e.g., this nice Canon), and enjoy the additional features of a flatbed scanner.  The tradeoff there is between speed/convenience and quality/functionality -- it will take a lot longer to scan with the moving scanner head in a flatbed than it will with this speedy dedicated slide scanner, and you'll need an attached computer to scan, but you'll be able to get better image quality and enjoy the other features of a flatbed (document scanning, print scanning, etc.).Judging this scanner on its merits, it is undeniably convenient, fast, and easy to use -- which is exactly the feature set it promises.  It is, however, also a single-use device that will have no role in your house once you've scanned all your slides, and doesn't deliver the highest quality results.

For our first baby, we used (and loved) the Fisher-Price Deluxe Bouncer, which costs nearly 2/3 less than this cocoon.  That bouncer could vibrate and play music, and most importantly could operate like a foot-powered rocking chair that magically soothed a cranky baby long enough to let us eat a hot meal.This cocoon can also rock, either front to back or, by turning the orientation of the seat, from side to side.  The rocking is not as easy to do with one foot as the Fisher-Price model, though, since that one relied on the spring tension of the legs (you could push down, and it would bounce back, and it was easy to get a good rhythm going).This has a few advantages over the Fisher-Price bouncer, that may or may not justify the dramatic increase in cost.  Its material is easy to wipe clean with a cloth (the Fisher-Price was absorbent and needed dis-assembly and machine-washing), it can recline farther back for sleep and farther upright for playtime, and includes a canopy for shading a sleeping child (although this isn't likely to be as necessary for an essentially indoor product).As others have noted, this is a challenge to put together, but since you should only have to do that once, it isn't too big of a deal.  The price is a bit high, however, for what it is, and I would still prefer the Fisher-Price even if they cost the same.

Aoneky's jump rope is not just for kids. It works great for adults too. It's lightweight, tangle free, and doesn't hurt like a lash if you hit yourself while jumping. The rope is made of a foam type material that resists kinking and tangling. It still firm to keep shape while jumping, but has enough padding to keep it from stinging if you accidently whip yourself with it. The handles are padded and don't slip if your hands sweat.The rope can be adjusted by removing the end caps and sliding the metal clamps down to the length you need. I didn't even need to cut off the excess. I was able to curl it up back into the handle and cap it.Great rope. Perfect portability. Great for taking with you to the gym, travelling, or home. Yes, kids would love this jump rope for play, but I believe the adults would appreciate how comfortable this jump rope is for their workouts as well.

For a Halo Master Chief loving kid, these costume pieces are fantastic to feed the imagination with. Granted, it doesn't come with body armor, but this didn't stop my son from using it for Halloween.
