Kenneth Branagh's latest adaptation of the classic fairy tale is a sweeping, lavish and beautiful production. Unlike so many of the fairy tale themed movies of the last few years, this version of "Cinderella" is a straightforward, traditional retelling. It takes itself seriously. It's also a breath of fresh air for that very reason. Instead of fluffing the story with unnecessary forced plot lines,complicated back stories, villians that are are just misunderstood (boring)... Branagh's "Cinderella" is the story everyone knows, and it is told exceptionally well. This is a superb film for families and people of all ages. I can't imagine any boy, girl, man or woman NOT finding something enchanting about it.  Lily James is perfect as Cinderella, bringing a sweetness and innocence to the character that is at once sympathetic, and yet always bold and determined. Cate Blanchett is equally wonderful as Lady Tremaine, every bit as mean and vile as a Disney villain should be, while clearly hiding some pain of her own . I don't even know where to begin with the production and costume design...it is breathtaking. Someone in some department will likely be taking home an Oscar next year. The soundtrack by Patrick Doyle is very beautiful, as well. It is difficult not to get at least a few butterflies when the music swells and Cinderella's dress turns to a ravishing gown. I have to say, I didn't expect this to be as good as it is. I really didn't. I've found most of Disney's work these last few years to be extremely underwhelming (including Frozen and Into the Woods). This changes everything! I think it's important to note that the film never gives the impression that Cinderella just needed a prince to be happy. It's made clear that what she needed was to be allowed to be herself. I was very happy to see that. While nothing can ever replace Disney's original animated film, this is far and away the best live action version I've ever seen. See it on the big screen if you can. It is so worth it.

This movie....man. Let's get something clear. This movie is horrible in nearly every possible way. It's also pretty entertaining for that reason. Growing up in western PA myself, I can't help but laugh every time one these local "actor's" let their redneck dialect slip through. I'm not even convinced alot of these people can read. I'm serious. The acting is terrible, the writing is terrible, the directing is terrible and the only thing even remotely scary is that someone put up money for this. This is the kinda movie you watch with friends on a late night to laugh and have a good time.  You really need to see it for yourself, because there just are not adjectives to describe it. The blu-ray picture is adequate. It looks better than it needs to, and thats the best you can say.

I don't know what to say other than I followed the directions, ate healthy, and exercised while taking these. They did nothing for me that improved over my usual weight loss on that routine. After doing some research I discovered there is NO proof that raspberry ketones help people lose weight. They didn't even give me extra energy. I'd have been better off with a decent multi vitamin! It seems to me these success stories might just be the placebo effect. Some fads are just not worth following.

Okay, it sucked putting this up. It really did. I had help and it took us probably two hours. It is very difficult to get it flush against the the corner and ceiling. I ended up moving it about a half an inch away and you really cant tell until you focus on it. All that aside, it looks great. I agree when everyone says to cut it into smaller pieces. You really have to in order to make it manageable.  It's great when you need something on a decent sized wall and don't want to cover it with traditional artwork. I will say, for some reason, it appears larger in the pictures than it really is. It IS big, but not quite as big as I anticipated. Measure your space and know exactly where you are putting it beforehand!

I've tried just about every brand of lube out there over the years. This is among the best. It has a nice consistency, without all the stickiness that you usually find in water based. I prefer silicone, but this is a close second.

I'll just keep this simple. My partner and I are the most picky bedding people on the planet, we constantly look for high quality sheets etc. This is a perfectly nice set. We have washed them many times since purchase, and while some of their softness washed away, they are perfectly comfortable. We have not had any piling or some of the other experiences people have described. I think they're worth a try at the price.

Mill Creek has finally released a boxed set of Roseanne, including the uncut version of the first season. This has to be, far and away, one of the funniest, most honest, and reflective sitcoms ever on television. It never quite received the attention it deserved (Best Comedy series Emmy), and that continues today with this horrible packaging. As everyone has stated, the discs are in sleeves and piled on top of each other inside the box. You have to pull out a dozen discs to get to the one you want sometimes. The box has a slipcover, but its very flimsy and cheap. Regardless, you can occasionally find this on here for $25 or so, and it's worth every penny. I can't imagine there is anyone left in America that has not seen this show, butt if you haven't, drop everything and buy this. You won't regret it.

I was pretty excited to see this one. The trailer looked amazing. Unfortunately, I finished it feeling underwhelmed and slightly disappointed. I had never seen any of the shorts on youtube before, so this was all new to me. Out of the 3 short films in this, I really only enjoyed the last one. The others are overly simplistic and predictable. The frame story that showcases the other three is decent, but not at all original. One of the stories in the collection does not even take place on Halloween, and features someone so obviously in an Alien suit it comes off comical. I'll watch it again, but I don't think this movie is going to catch on as a Halloween staple. Not at all. I wouldn't write off the director, hopefully he can churn out a few more films as fun and creepy as "Terrifier". I wanted to like this as much as anyone, but the fact is...it's just not that good. I think it's worth a rental (some people really seem to like it, though i find some of the enthusiasm suspicious...i've seen the movie.) I'd definitely think twice about a blind buy.

This movie had to have been written in 15 minutes. It's so completely horrible from the first minute, it's hard to even make it to the end. How they got relatively big names to star in this...I will never understand. It could have been a rather effective zombie movie if they had kept it simple. Instead, it's an over the top cgi gorefest of ridiculous. Shirley Jones is particularly annoying, as well, doing nothing but wandering around whining. Asylum continues to put quality last on their list of priorities. How they continue to get funding to make this kind of garbage is a real mystery to me. Avoid this at all costs.

I have combination skin, but this works great for me. Remember to just dab it on each cheek and forehead, then blend into skin in small circles. Do not lather it on!! Even with combination skin, my t zone has absorbed this well and my skin feels refreshed and soft.

Works well at covering any red spots (you learn in makeup to cover red marks with yellow tints) but i bought it for under eye darkness, and for that...it's not so effective. It looks somewhat unnaturally light and draws attention to my under-eye rather than covering it. You can tell I have it on. I'm disappointed that it didn't work for me.

Based on the reviews you read on here you'd think this collection is amazing... It's not. I failed to noticed that the majority of the reviews are not verified purchases. These stories are mediocre at best, if not incoherent. Most of them are very predictable and are really more crime/suspense stories rather than horror. All of them have "ironic" endings that you see coming from a mile away. To be honest, there is really nothing special here. It's not really worth purchasing.

I've been reading this story since I was in 5th grade... 16 years ago. Ive, bought this book in several different incarnations, usually with a collection of other shorts I wasn't really interested in. I'm glad to just have the story itself on kindle. It's a very touching, funny, and well written coming-of-age story. I used it for an oral interpretation class when I was in College, and everyone loved the sound of it. I think I related so much to the story because I grew up in an area much like the one in the story. I've also always been interested in Diner's, a dying piece of Americana. This story is as warm and inviting as any great diner should be. It teaches an important lesson as well, excitement and opportunity is all around you, but you have to look or you won't see it. The world is a fascinating and adventurous place. As is growing up. This was so deserving of the Hugo Award.

I bought this comforter for a fashionable friend of mine. I knew she'd fall out of her chair when she saw how hideous they are!! It didn't disappoint. Lets face it, for some of us, nothing is more devastating than pink camo. She drags it out when she has company for them to use and everyone has a laugh. For those really interested in this set, The quality and price is on par with the prices you'd pay for bedding at retail stores, not awful, not great. The pattern isn't the most detailed either, the print looks a little muddled, but that made it even better for my intentions! I didn't exactly know how to rate this since it wasn't a serious purchase.

I love Baby Jane. I love drag queens. Should be a match made in heaven. For me, it wasn't. I turned it off half way through. The decent portrayals kept me interested for a little while, but it started to drag(haha). I just didn't think the inserted "modern" jokes were that funny, nor were their caricatures good enough to carry the whole movie. I just didn't see much humor in this. The original film was campier I think! It might have been funny to just do a few scenes from different movies, but it loses its luster when you're reenacting the entire story. The joke wears thin.

Plot: Horror fans at a convention are invited to an "exclusive" party at a farmhouse. When they wake up after, they find themselves trapped in the movie "Night of the living dead". Each playing parts from the original film.  I honestly think this could be one of the best ideas for a horror movie in years. Instead of remakes or attempts to reinvent, this movie simply puts "real" world characters into a famous film from the past. Might be the best scenario to answer the question of "what would you do?" if you were suddenly living in a movie you knew very well. The problem is that even though the film it's using for inspiration was made for next to nothing, this great idea could have used some more money and bigger talent all around. If this brilliantly simple idea had been in the hands of some experienced people...wow. But...it's not. Seeing a great idea turn out like this is a shame. There are plenty of problems all around. Everyone remembers the farmhouse in NOLD crawling with zombies. Not here. There are literally a handful, like 5, who spend all their time walking the lawn and making no effort to break into the house. Remember when the zombies in NOTLD just stood outside and did nothing? Me either.What exactly is scary about that? The writing all around tends to lack. The theme doesn't carry far enough. It starts to seem like a side note, while the characters walk around a lot and do boring tasks that have nothing to do with the original film (though the locations are good). Whats the point!? This is explained somewhat in the "twist" ( i guess you can call it that) but really, its just a huge letdown that we've seen before. Also, the acting is...well...poor. The actors have no sense of urgency, like the entire situation doesn't even phase them...and forget character development. Good thing we know who they represent from the original film because none of them have any personality. Sometimes people who can't pretend to be scared, end up in a horror movie. This would be a good example of that. The movie is just plain boring at times. I think it's worth a look for NOTLD fans, but I was disappointed. I don't think everything needs a big budget to succeed. Not at all. But I kept wondering what could be done with some more creativity and the budget of just one episode of "The Walking Dead".

"We wouldn't know normal if it fell on us."  "October Country" is the story of family, and how after one generation loses its way, it becomes difficult for the future ones to return. The subjects of the documentary are the Moshers, a working class family living in the Mohawk Valley of central New York. The family is headed by Don, a retired Policeman and veteran, and his wife Dottie. In the film, they reflect on the choices made by their children and grandchildren, which have spun the family into a depressing repetition of failed marriages, abusive relationships, teen pregnancy, poverty, and substance abuse.  Don, who is deeply scarred by his time in Vietnam and the gulf war, is emotionally distant and mentally defeated. His wife, Dottie, does her best to hold her family together, while trying to come to terms with the choices they've made. The town itself reflects the crumbling relationships of the family, with only one plant employing most of the population, and Walmart being the only place to shop. It's an area as depressing as the Mosher's story.  "October Country" addresses the question, When you are hurt or disappointed by those you love, what is left? Can a cycle of bad choices be broken? And when should you stop trying to fix other people? There is no real resolution to these questions in the film. It seems that all you are really left with is the fact that despite pain, people continue whether they want to or not. Ghosts of the past follow you, and sometimes the future doesn't look so bright either. While watching a year with the Mosher family, one can't help but think there are thousands of other American families experiencing the same thing. There is a light in the tunnel however, in the form of Desiree, the Mosher's spunky granddaughter, who seems to recognize the mistakes of her mother and sister, as well as the hopelessness of the area.  This is a difficult film to describe, because its beauty lies in it simplicity. There is a story there, but the story is somehow less significant than the result. Change is what is important. I don't know how this wonderfully filmed documentary has fallen under the radar. I found it completely engrossing and honest. I really love documentaries and I think this one of the best I've seen in years. It's as if someone just turned the camera on and caught a portrait American lives that some people would rather just forget. A lot of families have problems that last through generations, and there is a root to every problem. However, it's not always on the surface and easy to dissect. This movie is an honest attempt to examine a family in decline from all angles. You just have to see it.

I bought this for my friends baby shower. She asked that everyone bring a book to start a collection for her daughter. This was by far her favorite. The stories are not the full, detailed versions, but still very colorful and well written.

Everyone knows the movie is amazing. Just wanted to say that the BluRay is spectacular. The picture is crystal clear and the sound is polished. Never seen or heard it better. One of the very best transfers of a B&W film available. it's stunning and a must have for enthusiasts.

As an American, and Stephen Fry fan, I was intrigued to find out what this series would be like. I was not disappointed. It is one of the most fascinating, beautiful, and heartwarming trips across America that I've ever seen. Fry travels to every state in the Union (some seem to get the shaft) from one adventure to the next. I enjoyed very much that for the most part, he avoids major cities. These places have been covered so many times. Instead, he seems to focus on whatever staple each state is known for. Most Americans wouldn't be surprised by his choices, but for others it may be a learning experience of America's various cultures. In a lot of ways, Each state really is like its own country. There is a Sense of unfairness with the time spent in each state. Some he merely drives through, which leaves you feeling underwhelmed. I suppose it wouldn't be a problem, but some of the states that receive the most attention, are rather unworthy of it. His visit to Las Vegas, for example, was strangely boring and much too long. I have to take a star off for that, because much of the series is so good, being thrown a dud episode is depressing. I've already viewed this series twice, and can't wait to jump in again. What a refreshing and fun vacation, with a wonderful host, that you can take right in your living room. I wish the series would return and give more time to the landscapes and cultures of America.
If you're expecting a national geographic quality documentary on national parks, this isn't it. The whole thing looked very amateur and was really quite boring.
Looked great on my kitty, but even though she not very active, the clasp didn't last too long. She didn't wear it every day either.

I like the concept of a monocular with a 52mm objective because of its potential for use in low light conditions, and because of its smaller size for backpacking or motorcycle travel. With its simpler construction and protective rubber coating, a monocular should be more rugged in the field. However, the optics of this unit are subpar. Compared with a pair of Nikon 7x25 compact binoculars, and a pair of low-end 8x40 traditional prism binoculars:- Image contrast is low- Only the inner 1/3 of the image is in focus; sharpness falls off sharply toward the perimeter of the visual field- Barrel distortion and chromatic aberration worsen toward the perimeter of the visual fieldFocusing is somewhat confusing: The lower ring of the monocular is used to estimate distance and get a coarse focus, while the eyepiece is used to achieve final focus  which applies only to the center 1/3 of the image.Disclaimer: This product was provided at no cost for a fair and honest review.

I have been looking for an LED replacement for a 921 incandescent bulb for backup lights on a 2016 Honda HR-V to provide more illumination to the rear when backing up the car. These are much whiter (I'm guessing 6000K) than the incandescents, and appear brighter when viewed side by side, but they don't actually project as much light behind the car. Probably good for replacing running lights, license plate lights, etc., anywhere a T10 socket is used, but not for backup lights.

I have been looking for 921 LED replacements for the OEM incandescent bulbs for a 2016 Honda HR-V. The color of these LEDs was even warmer than the incandescents, with a somewhat unpleasant greenish cast. Worse, they did not project as much light to the rear of the car.

Possibly reflecting a maturing artist, Oriental Bass seems almost, but not quite as good as Garcia-Fons' 2011 endeavor, Mediterranees, which covers similar material. Consummately inventive musicianship with an unusual 5-string bass. Buy both albums!

I have been a student of user interface design for decades. There are so many horrible products, both hardware and software, but I think that design guru Don Norman ( http://www.amazon.com/Design-Everyday-Things-Revised-Expanded/dp/0465050654 ) would approve of the design of this phone. The CapTel phone user interface is brilliant, so simple that, as the old GEICO ads used to say, a caveman could use it. If you can see, you can use this phone. Big, well defined buttons, lighted for the number pad, make it very easy to use, and the screen prompts everything that needs to be done.The caption display shows not only current conversation, but also does voice to text translation for voicemail messages, and while the nature of voice to text is that the translation is never perfect, it's good enough, and generally does extremely well with telephone numbers, which are usually the most important information when making booking. It is good enough that you don't even need to listen to the headset. My mother used to replay the same message over and over and over to get the details; with the screen, all the necessary information is displayed. It's hard to describe what a tremendous improvement this makes.At age 94, my mother still runs a B&B in a 19th century building, but her hearing is not good, which is a terrible handicap when trying to handle calls for reservations. With her old phone, she would become frustrated, and just slam the phone down in anger. She is not only not technically inclined, she is adamantly and vocally anti-technology. Even she admits it's a nice phone. I can think of no higher praise.

Probiotics like vitamins and supplements in general, are one of those gray areas, with many claims, but ambiguous evidence as to their efficacy. Probiotics are live bacteria and yeasts that are good for your health, especially your digestive system. In general, probiotic supplements are thought to be safe, although mild side effects might include upset stomach, diarrhea, gas, and bloating, and they may also trigger allergic reactions. I decided to give them a try a few months ago, and I have experienced no negative side effects, possibly some positive effects on digestion. Medline and WebMD both indicate some potential benefits from probiotics, especially for people with IBS, or who are recovering from an infection that required taking antibiotics, which can kill off beneficial flora in the gut.General advice is to consult your doctor before you start taking a supplement, and stop taking probiotics and talk to your doctor if you experience problems.

Bluetooth headphones seem to multiply like coathangers in a closet, with three common form factors:- Over the ear: Usually provides the best sound quality, but bulky and heavy- In-ear: very compact, but controls, sound quality, and fit can be issues- Neckband headsetThese headphones introduce a new form factor that combines the best features of neckband headset with in-ear. Controls buttons are in a small module on the cord for the right phone, and are easily distinguishable by touch: a "multifunction button on one side, and two buttons to change volume or tracks on the other side. When not in use, or if you want to talk to someone, a magnet allows the headphones to be joined and worn as a necklace. This is probably the best control arrangement I have found for Bluetooth headphones. Also appreciated by someone whose near vision isn't so great is that it's possible to distinguish left from right by feel, rather than looking for a tiny L and R markings.The shape of my ear canals doesn't normally work well with in-ear headphones, but these work for me, providing a good acoustic seal, they are comfortable, and they don't fall out  about all I can ask for from headphones of this sort. Two bud sizes are provided: medium and small. Medium worked for me, providing a good seal. The buds have a small notch that corresponds with a raised bit on the headphone for proper alignment. Sound quality was much better than expected, rivaling that of my favorite in-ear phones, a pair of wired Klipsch with an oval profile.Eco-friendly packaging, all cardboard, no plastic. Included are a user manual (in rather small type), and a flat 12" USB-micro charging cable. Battery charge was nearly full when received, and required less than 30 minutes to go from red (charging) to blue (charged). No surprises pairing with a Chromebook and with a 2012 Nexus 7 tablet. Bluetooth range with the tablet was average, ~10 meters indoors (with intervening walls) and ~30 meters outdoors with no intervening obstructions. I do not use BT headphones for telephone conversation, so this function was not tested.Disclaimer: This product was provided by the manufacturer at no cost in exchange for a fair and balanced review.

My mother is 94, quite deaf, and runs an 1865 B&B. A Captel telephone that provides voice to text translation requires an internet connection, and the the existing Wi-Fi in her old building with thick masonry walls does not provide a usable signal to her desk. With electrical wiring of unknown provenance in a nineteenth century building, I had some doubts as to whether a powerline adapter would work. Since she had a NETGEAR router, I assumed that the NETGEAR Powerline 500 would provide the fewest compatibility risks. Wi-Fi signal strength of the NETGEAR powerline adapter is not remarkable, but a wired ethernet connection to the phone seems to be stable and allows the speech to text function to work as expected.

Unplanned, but this headlamp arrived on a day when I had to replace a leaky gasket in a toilet tank, and do some home network reconfiguration. Twenty-four hours later, I had to descend into the basement to find a tripped breaker.  It's incredibly useful to be able to direct light where you look, leaving both hands free.Three AAA batteries (not included) provide the power.First click = high powerSecond click = low powerThird click = blinking lightFourth click = OffPush/pull on the lens barrel to change the beam width (widest is very useful; narrow beam is a very small, intense spotlight)The elastic head straps are adjustable, so it's hard to imagine a head this wouldn't fit.Disclaimer: Product provide for a fair and honest review.
Genuine OEM replacement knob that fits perfectly on a 30-year old Whirlpool gas cooktop.

Some reviewers have wondered about the usefulness of a cloth packing cube. I travel a lot by motorcycle, and a packing cube like this is very helpful for organizing things for quick access. This bag is just the right size for my top case, and allows me to put everything needed for an overnight stay in one place. The carrying handle was an unexpected feature.Disclaimer: This product was provided by the vendor for a fair and honest review.
Pleasant herbal scent, with a nice balance between the component oils.Disclaimer: This product was provided by the vendor for a fair and honest review.

Nice capo, attaches securely, adjusts easily, and available colors suit both restrained and more exuberant personalities  buy different colors for different instruments. I especially appreciated the user-friendly packaging, which didn't require a knife and the risk of a visit to an ER to wound treatment.Disclaimer: This product was provided by the vendor for a fair and honest review.

Typically larger laptops run hotter and benefit more from supplementary cooling; cooling pads are awkward to carry, but this snap-on cooling fan is both small and effective. The little cylindrical silencer is not required at the lower speeds, but makes a noticeable difference at higher speeds, so if you find it provides enough cooling at lower speeds, leaving out the silencer is one less thing to pack in a laptop bag. Controls are minimal and require no documentation: Power, + and - buttons.Because this fan clips on to the base unit, it works best with a fullsize laptop, not a thin ultrabook or Chromebook (which usually run so cool they don't need supplementary cooling) as it requires a base at least 3/4" (19-20mm) thick to clip on securely. Soft rubber seals at the sides ensure a leakfree fit for maximum effectiveness, and soft tips on the spring clips prevent them from scratching the case.Disclaimer: I received this product at a substantial discount in exchange for a fair and honest review.

As a motorcycle rider, I have found that nothing beats wool ski socks for wearing inside riding boots. These are high enough, provide good support, and wool is never hot, cold, or sweaty. Worn inside boots, patterns and colors don't much matter. These socks are comparable with Smartwool or Thorlo socks at a more affordable price.

At 4" x 2.75" x 1.1" this is about as small a package as you can imagine for 6 charging ports. Unlike most small chargers, every port is rated for 2.4 Amps, something that I cannot measure, but confirmed by testing. Keep in mind that a USB device and charger negotiate the maximum amount of power that can be transferred, usually well below 4 Amps. For example, a 2012 Nexus 7 that was 50% discharged (4325 mAh battery) took approximately 2 hours to reach 100%, about the same time as with a dedicated 2.5 Amp USB charger. I don't have the patience to test charging 6 USB devices at once, but see no reason to doubt the manufacturer's claim, although the charger might heat up somewhat if all 6 ports were used to charge multiple devices simultaneously.The power cord is detachable, so it packs easily, and won't suffer an insulation break, as can occur with many similar devices that have non-detachable power cords. My wife and I will be leaving on a trip in a few days, with the usual 21st century assortment of rechargeable devices: 2 tablets, 2 phones, and 2 pairs of USB headphones, but we will need to pack only a single charger.Disclaimer: This device was provided by the manufacturer in exchange for a fair and balanced review.

If you have a lithium iron battery in a vehicle that isn't used daily (such as a motorcycle), and want it to perform and last as long as it should, it needs to be kept on a charger  preferably a purpose designed charger, not one designed to meet the needs of a lead acid battery. A bad trickle charger nearly killed my Battery Tender lithium iron battery. With this charger, I have reasonable confidence that it's being charged properly, and that the battery will last the 5 years promised by the manufacturer.  The normal charging cycle is:Solid red LED = Charging from ~80%Blinking green = Final charge to fullSolid green LED = ChargedAmber/Green alternating:  "Recovery mode" There may be a problem with the battery, but this can be a false alarm. Unplug the charger for 10 seconds. If the amber/green alternating pattern doesn't go away, contact Deltran customer service about a possible battery issue.Note that this is NOT the same as the Battery Tender Junior, which is designed for lead acid batteries. It's small enough to pack on a motorcycle.

Another great collection of Renaissance/Middle Eastern pieces by Jordi Savall and friends. I ordered the MP3 version rather than the (considerably more expensive) CD & 400-page book version. "Liner notes" doesn't begin to describe the contents of the accompanying materials for recordings in this series.

This is a money belt, not a fanny pouch. As such, it has limited capacity, but is very thin, and can be worn under clothing for greater security. The strap is elastic, so it can stretch with movement. Lightweight ripstop nylon is durable, but keeps size down. Multiple compartments allow segregation of travel documents, money, even a small electronic device such as a phone or iPod.Disclaimer: The vendor provided this product at a discounted cost in exchange for a fair and honest product review.

My old Y connector lacked a locking ring, so it had to be turned to a position where only 1 arm worked in order to be tight on the faucet, and after 30+ years, it was corroded in place. WD-40 and a heat gun failed to loosen it, and rather than risk breaking the faucet, I had to cut grooves on either side using a cutoff wheel. To prevent future lockup, wrap some Teflon pipe seal tape around the threads before attaching the connector. With a threaded ring, the Amzdeal connector went on easily, and could be oriented properly. Solid brass construction and precise machining make this a premium Y hose connector.Disclaimer: I was provided this product for review purposes.

I had followed Jordi Savall and Hesperion XX for years; didn't realize until recently that he has reached out to music of the Balkans and Near East. This is a wonderful collection (and performance) of traditional material. Much of it was compiled by Dimitrie Cantemir, Prince of Moldavia (twice), a fascinating historical figure and polymath who resided at the Ottoman court for many years.

Big enough to be used for self defense, bright enough to light things up at long distances. MagLite has a well-earned reputation for quality flashlights. Cheaper alternatives are available; none better, and they are made in USA.

Who would have thought a country music singer would put together an album of Catholic hymns in Latin? Nice arrangements, with multi-tracking with her own voice. There isn't a lot of variation in this collection. I am especially fond of the Salve Regina, which I first discovered through Pandora.
I have loved the Hesperus Early Music Ensemble ever since hearing them in a live performance at Agnes Scott College.

Comfortable to wear, reasonable sound quality, good Bluetooth connectivity and range, easy to operate controls on the right side. These aren't the lightest travel headphones, but they provide a good balance of features for the price.
Installed effortlessly in a 2009 iMac. Extra memory provides a huge performance boost. The next mod may be a solid state drive.
Flash memory has become a commodity; for making Chrome OS recovery devices, all that is needed is 4 Gb, and by having two cards, I can rotate them, so that I always have a backup backup.
Good wool socks aren't cheap. These are good socks, at a fair price, and will keep toes warm in cold weather, while providing good cushioning in warm weather.

This Guidebook is a good travelling companion, covering all the basics about these two historic cities, without taking up too much space. I know that eBooks are "in" but I still prefer print on paper for guide books.

As is always the case when switching from a spinning hard drive to a solid state drive, the difference in performance is night and day. Crucial has a good reputation for both performance and reliability. The drive is being used in a HP 17 laptop, partitioned to run both Windows and Linux Mint. Boot time for Mint is ~10 seconds.

This Tracfone comes with Android 4.4.2, but it is not filled with a lot of junkware. Setup was a little confusing, because it required installing software that was not pre-installed. Adding an 8 Gb micro-SD card provided storage for ~1000 music tracks. Range and battery life are about average. For the price, Tracfones are hard to beat.
Works very well with an LG 34C from Tracfone. The clasp holds, and the case provides quite a bit of protection, without calling attention to itself.

This is a nice little pendant, well finished, shipped in an elegant little purple velvet drawstring sack. It looks like it costs more than it does. Look closely at the photos  it's really not very big, so despite all the stones, it's not a gaudy or flashy piece of jewelry.

Given how thin Apple has made their latest generation iPhones, a protective case is pretty much essential for an expensive piece of technology. This case (plastic, not metal) fits well, and adds some protection; it should be especially helpful to protect against bending. It's not an Otter Box, but looks a heck of a lot better.

These spoons aren't quite as heavy gauge as they appear in the photo. The edges of the handles are rolled slightly, which gives them good strength. Nothing exceptional, but a perfectly serviceable set of measuring spoons.
Higher rated capacity than the OEM battery it is replacing. Seems to work as expected, but it's too soon to know about durability.
Fills gaps, sprays smoothly, dries quickly, which is about all you can hope for in a rattle can paint.

I used this paint (over VHT gray primer) to repaint a badly rashed alloy rim. The color is not very sparkly, which will work well with some wheels, not so much with mine (2016 Honda HR-V). It sprays about as evenly as any rattle can paint, and seems to be holding up well.
The clear coat leaves a somewhat yellowish cast when used over a silver base.

Inexpensive, easy to mount, looks good. These lights (I bought both 6 and 4 socket strips) are the best bargain I have found for this sort of lighting. I combined them with LED globe bulbs; had I realized how light the bulbs would be, I probably would have used 4 and 3, as the effect is somewhat going out in the noon day sun.

Ron Perlman is excellent; Dana Delany is good; the rest of the cast might as well be made from cardboard. With a little bit of subtlety, the premise of Hand of God could have been an engaging series, but it uses such a broad brush to create cartoonish characters that I won't be watching after the first episode.I am neither religious, nor particularly bothered by profanity, but this show goes beyond even what I find acceptable.

There are many Bluetooth receivers, fewer that can also transmit.In the box: BA-800 (51mm x 27mm x 11mm), 3.5mm patch cord (4" long), micro-USB cord (36" long), illustrated user manual (English/German/Italian). The manual, unlike many for products like this, is actually printed in a readable type size, no magnifier required, and covers everything necessary for operation. The case is a matte finish plastic that is pleasant to both touch and sight.The Receive/Transmit switch needs to be in the appropriate position before the device is turned on. Pairing was straightforward with both a Remix tablet (receive mode, Android 5.0) and two different brands of Bluetooth headphones (Etekcity Roverbeats, and Mediabridge Cadence). Claimed battery life is up to 8 hours TX; up to 6 hours RX (not yet tested). In receive mode, the 3.5mm patch cord provides output to another device (such as a radio); in transmit mode, it provides input from another device, such as an MP3 player.+++Pro++++ Bluetooth Receiver & Transmitter+ Small size, extremely portable, yet not so small as to be difficult to use+ Battery powered, can be used without an external power source+ 3.5mm input/output jack, allowing use of a patch cord of whatever length is needed.---Con---- May need to be paired again after being plugged into USB powerDisclaimer : This product was provided by the manufacturer for a fair and balanced review.

Replaced a similar CFL bulb, rated at 7W, the difference in light output is dramatic. I have no way of measuring, but subjectively, the 6W LED bulb seems 10 times as bright. Unlike a CFL, an LED bulb reaches full output immediately. Which is better? That depends on your need. Sometimes, it's nice to have a light gradually increase its output; others, you want everything at once.LEDs are still difficult to justify on price, but for locations, such as chandeliers, where access may be difficult, the much longer replacement interval is worth the added cost.Aesthetically, I would prefer a more subdued design with a frosted envelope, but these are hard to find.

A wine foil cutter falls into the category of "things that I didn't know I needed." There are a lot of similar devices, and I suspect that all of them work just about the same way. The Peak Reserve cutter is flat black and unobtrusive, and comes in an elegant black box.I have suggested to the manufacturer that changing the size of the "throat" could add to its functionality by making it possible to use the same tool to extract a cork from an already opened bottle of wine. Using a couple of layers of self-fusing rubber tape added to the inner surface, I tried this and it worked exactly as expected, removing a cork without having to reach for a pair of pliers.DISCLAIMER: This product was provided for a fair and balanced review.

I'm not sure what the use case is for this device. A build-in, dash-mounted display is generally pretty well shielded from glare by virtue of its location. A GPS on top of the dashboard and closer to the windshield may suffer from glare problems, but this sunshade needs to be taped to the GPS to stay in place. Overall, I would say this is a solution in search of a problem, overpriced for what it actually does.Disclaimer: I received an evaluation unit in exchange for a fair and honest review.

Up to now, a Soundfreaq Sound Kick has been my favorite portable BT speaker, although it's a little on the large side. For travel, I've been using a Sony BTS50 (discontinued) which is a nice size, but has middling sound quality. The DBPOWER portable BT speaker hits pretty much all of my targets at a very competitive price. Sound balance is good (great for this size device) with adequate bass response, and it's plenty loud. Plus, it adds support for USB flash drive, micro-SDHC card, FM radio, and alarm functions. If it had been available 2 years ago, neither of my other portable BT speakers would have been purchased, as it offers more functionality at lower cost.In the (nicer than usual) box: speaker, Micro-USB cable, 3.5mm patch cable, manual. Although most functions are self-evident, you can learn a few important points by reading the manual. Supported music formats include MP3, WMA, APE, and FLAC, but *not* Apple's M4a. Files in M4a format will be skipped until the next playable file is encountered. If you have a Mac with iTunes, you will need to convert M4a files to MP3 in order to play them on this device. If it supported M4a music files, I would have awarded 5 stars. After several weeks of use, including a road trip, I like it even more than initially; all it needs is a protective case.Bluetooth range is within spec: ~10 meters indoors with intervening walls; ~30 meters outdoors with no obstructions. Pairing was straightforward with both a Nexus 7 running Android 5.1.1 and a Chromebook Pixel.+++Pro++++ Excellent sound for a device this size and price+ Multiple functions, BT or 3.5mm input, plays music from USB flash drive or micro SDHC card+ Charges through micro-USB port, doesn't require a dedicated charger---Con---- Doesn't support M4a audio format- FM radio needs a strong signal (no provision for external antenna)- When turned on, always set to volume level 9 (about mid-range) there appears to be no way to change the default volume settingDISCLAIMER: This product was provided for a fair and honest review.

Most CD players are in the middle of the dash, which puts this mount at some distance from the driver's line of sight. A  "dog bone" extension arm would provide much greater range of adjustment, but I have been unable to find one for the Garmin 17mm ball. However, an extension would amplify the leverage of the GPS on the mount, so it would probably flex more.Despite comments from some other reviewers, mine was clearly labeled "MADE IN USA" and had soft strips on the lower portion to assist stability. I added a piece of self-fusing rubber tape to the upper portion, and it mounts very securely in my car's CD player slot. Used with a Garmin Nuvi 52, there is no sign of flex, and the location is generally away from direct sunlight.

In the same vein as Ali Farka Tour's collaborations with kora player Toumani Diabat, this recording is an extended improvisation between two masters. If you like this album, check out Ali & Toumani or In the Heart of the Moon.

In the first Crocodile Dundee movie, he is accosted by a gang of thugs, one of whom pulls out a knife. Croc says, "That's not a knife," pulls out a large Bowie knife, and says, "THAT's a knife."Same for this belt. At 1.75" wide, it may be too wide for the belt loops on most dress pants, but it's fine for jeans. The premium leather has a nice pebbled finish, and the inside around the belt holes is reinforced with another layer of the same pebbled leather. The buckle appears to be solid brass, not plated, with a matte finish; the section of the belt that wraps around the base of the buckle is secured with three rivets. 6 holes provide a range of adjustment from 34" to 40" (measured with a yard stick).This is a substantial belt that should hold up to any conceivable abuse and last for decades.Disclaimer : I was provided this product for a fair and honest review.

This is a basic collapsible lantern, with an opaque black plastic telescoping case. Pull to turn on, push to turn off; it's so simple that a 2-year old can use it, which makes it very useful for emergencies such as power outages  no fumbling in the dark to find a switch.There are many similar collapsible lanterns available on Amazon, in different colors, with nothing much to distinguish one from another other than price and the lighting element. This one has a vertical array of 3 panels, each with 10 LEDs; others have the LEDs behind a diffuser, with a reflector to further radiate light. I have a slight preference for the more indirect design, which produces less glare. Brightness is controlled by opening/closing the gap between the two halves of the case, but this doesn't affect battery life, as the lantern is either on or off  nothing in between. Expect ~8 hours at full brightness, after which it will continue to shine at a reduced output for a much longer time.At $9.99, it's hard to beat, and if you don't need the added features of more expensive lanterns, don't spend the extra money.
Works as described. Pretty simple to operate, although if you have never used an oil diffuser before, reading the instructions is a good idea, especially for controlling the LED lights.

Quilted cotton and Nomex gloves and mitts are not the best around hot liquids, which can soak into the cloth, and leave stains that can be difficult to wash out. CLoth gloves are also prone to developing holes and snags with use. Silicone rubber offers a different approach, completely waterproof, and easily cleaned.These gloves are large enough to fit a man's hand and, considering that the main layer is only ~1/16" thick, they insulate surprisingly well, mainly because of the heart-shaped raised dots, which add another 1/16" inch, while allowing air to flow through the gaps. With a bright orange color, they are difficult to misplace while cooking (trust me, I can misplace just about anything while cooking).

BA-700 ReviewIn the box is the receiver, which has a Y cord, with USB type-A connector for power, and a 3.5mm jack for output, a circular base plate with adhesive, and a car charger with 2 USB type-A ports  handy if you also have a GPS, as both devices can be powered, or you can charge a phone or tablet. The base is cleverly designed, with a magnetic attachment, and two small notches around the perimeter, which mate with the receiver, preventing it from rotating, or moving in any direction. For this application, where road bumps and such may prevent a steady hand, this is a nice design touch.The round knob controller is unmarked, but intuitive: * Push = On/Off * Jog left = Rewind to beginning of current track * Hold left = Volume down * Jog right = Advance to next track * Hold right = Volume up. A beep indicates maximum volume* A blue light around the perimeter blinks in pairing mode, solid when connected.Pairing is automatic. Not tested, but this receiver can connect to 2 devices, so it should be possible to switch from, say a tablet for listening to music and a phone for calls, or a passenger could use a phone without distracting the driver. Sound output, even at highest volume level, is modest, and the volume on your car's sound system may need to be cranked up higher than usual.+++Pros+++Compact+ Easy and secure to mount, attach and detach+ Intuitive controls don't require taking eye off the road to operate+ Included car charger with 2 USB type-A ports---Cons---- User manual is printed in nearly microscopic type, requiring a magnifying glass to read [I have asked the vendor to make the manual available online in PDF format]- Modest sound output, may require cranking up volume on car audioBottom Line: Because of the control knob, this is the best BT receiver I have seen for use in an automobile  no distractions!Disclaimer: Product provided in exchange for an unbiased review.

I wanted to like this power bank because of its incredibly slim dimensions and aluminum case. Charging performance was good, but after ~6 months, and only 2-3 uses, the lithium ion battery failed, with the case dangerously swollen

It's difficult to get 5 stars out of me for a review, but I can find almost nothing to fault about this little lantern. It comes with a nice protective case, the usual micro-USB charging cable, and 2 orange plastic carabiners. A folding triangular carabiner in the base can be used as a sidestand, or to hang it from a support, and a magnetic base allows it to stick to a steel surface for use as a light source in tight quarters, such as working on a car or motorcycle. The illustrated instructions are in a readable size, although operation is so self-evident they are hardly necessary. Build quality and heft (due to the 3300 mAh Li Ion battery) feel very solid; there are a lot of shoddy products in this category, but this isn't one of them.Aside from the compact shape, I appreciated the blue LED charge indicator on the bottom of the lantern, the relatively large battery capacity, and the 3 light levels (plus flash). The lowest light level is claimed to provide 110 hours, which should be adequate for anything but hiking the Appalachian Trail. Unlike many devices with covers for USB ports, the Type-A, and micro-USB port covers are easy to access  it's a small detail, but a cover that is nearly impossible to pry loose can drive people crazy  especially in the dark. Another small detail is the magnetic base, which makes it usable as a spot light source while working on a car or motorcycle. The next time I take a long motorcycle trip, this is going in my luggage.Observed performance:- Charging time (0% > 100%) : 7 hours @ 1 Amp; ~4 hours @ 2.5 Amp (claimed 4:30)- High : 7 hours (claimed 8)- Medium : 10:15 (claimed 12)- Low : Claimed 110 hours, didn't have patience to test- Charge 2012 Nexus 7 tablet (4325 mAh battery) 50% > 100% : 3:15, which suggests >1 Amp, a good performanceDISCLAIMER: This product was provided by enKo for a fair and honest review. Based on my experience, I would not hesitate to buy this product.

OVERVIEWThe small box contains headphones, a 32" charging cable, 2 pairs of spare earbuds and two pairs of hangers (large and small) so they can be fitted for most ears, and a small printed manual. For me, the medium buds with the small hangers offered the best fit. I have always had a hard time with earbuds, which rarely fit my ear canals, and don't stay in place. Many vendors offer what appear to be identical headphones of this type, but the hangers make all the difference between being usable and unusable.The micro-USB charging port is one the left phone; all controls are on the right side:* Power on/off, hold down on start to enter pairing mode; when device is on, click to start/stop play* Volume up/down rocker, hold down to skip forward/backwardPERFORMANCEOut of the box, the headset reached full charge (LED changes from red to blue) in less than an hour, and paired easily with a 2012 Nexus 7 tablet running Android 5.1, as well as with a Chromebook. Indoors with intervening walls, connection holds to the Bluetooth spec of 10 meters; outdoors, with no intervening obstructions, connection was maintained ~30 meters (~100 feet) before starting to break up. The spoken prompts for power on/off, and pairing/connected are useful, as is a spoken "low battery" spoken warning. Playing music at maximum volume for the headset, and ~60% volume for the tablet, the headset ran for about 7 hours, exceeding the claimed run time by 40%. Bluetooth telephone performance not tested.+++ PROS +++- Very compact. This is about as small as a device can be and still have usable controls- Ear hangers keep the individual headsets in place, without forcing the buds to be jammed into ear canals- Sound quality somewhat bright, and is decent for this type of device, but one shouldn't expect the tonal range of a good set of over the ear phones--- CONS ---- User manual is not illustrated, and is written in less than perfect, but understandable English (only)- The only marking to distinguish left from right is a very small gray R, almost unreadable against the black plastic- When turned on, the volume appears to default to a middle range, rather than to the last level set by the userBottom line: Of many seemingly identical Bluetooth sport headphones of this design, the hangers make the Vtin Dew Series Wireless Bluetooth Headphones stand out from the crowd.Disclaimer: I was sent the Vtin Dew Series Wireless Bluetooth Headphones for an honest review.

HARDWAREAs a device with a form factor very similar to that of the Microsoft Surface, the Remix has most of the advantages and liabilities of that design. The kickstand makes it quite usable on a flat surface, but the magnetic coupling of the keyboard, and top-heavy nature of this design make it less stable on a lap. The Remix (and Surface) is NOT a laptop. It's something entirely different.The Remix is well provisioned with 2 Gb of RAM, 64 Gb of flash storage, and a micro-SD slot cleverly hidden under the kickstand, supporting up to 128 Gb. I am storing about 30 Gb of videos on a 32 Gb micro-SD card, which integrates seamlessly with the File Manager. Overall performance is good, and everything works well; the only nits are relatively weak sound from the side-firing speakers, and a touchpad that is not as responsive as the touchpad on a good laptop. The Remix pairs easily with a Bluetooth mouse, which is a good alternative to the touchpad. The keyboard has good feel, and because keyboard and RemixOS were designed to work with each other, there are some function keys that add special capabilities, such as accessing settings, disabling the touchpad, and searching for apps. My only real complaint is that the tablet does not wake up when you open the keyboard cover. Jide developers are aware of the need for a better way to wake a sleeping Remix other than hitting the physical power button at top right of the tablet.If you want to protect your Remix, most cases made for the Microsoft Surface will fit. I use a ProCase Wallet Sleeve Case for Surface 3http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00L6620G4, which fits like it was custom made for the Remix.SOFTWARERemixOS is an Android variant, but is compatible with almost every app that I have tried to install from the Google Play Store. RemixOS does NOT support widgets at this time, which may be an issue for hardcore Android fans, but is not for me. RemixOS introduces some fairly dramatic improvements to "pure" Android in the form of a Windows-like taskbar at the bottom of the screen makes frequently used apps more accessible, and makes switching between apps far easier. Jide provides several dedicated apps for Mail, Calendar, Notes, and an office suite. I prefer some of them (such as Mail and Settings) to their generic Android counterparts. The other major enhancement that RemixOS adds to the Android experience permits some apps to be run in "phone mode" with a movable and resizable window. Phone mode can be very handy for having multiple app windows visible for what I will call "information" apps, such as Calendar, Google Play Music, and Pandora. The only Android feature that I really miss is the ability to create multiple, independent user accounts on one device.CONCLUSIONThe Remix Ultra-tablet and RemixOS are a very good release 1.0 effort, and in the long run RemixOS may be more important than the hardware, as it breaks new ground for Android. The Remix is a productivity tablet, not just for games and social media.

My first Friendly Swede purchase was the rubber tip version, a few years ago. They were a little short, and the rubber tips (like all that I have used) tended to drag on some screens.The microfiber fabric covering on this model solves that problem, and the length and balance feel "just right" to my hand. However, the fabric covering the tip is inherently delicate, and I can be rough on things, so the replaceable tips are well worth the small added cost.I received these as replacements for a set of three 7" fixed tip microfiber stylii, which were less durable than I expected. When I mentioned this, Friendly Swede customer service contacted me within hours, apologized, and sent me replacements with next day delivery. This is truly outstanding customer support, especially for an inexpensive item like a stylus.After 3 years of searching for the "perfect" stylus, this one is awfully close.

All things considered, I prefer over-the-ear headphones to on-ear (less isolation, less bass) or in-ear (almost none fit my ear canal). They are generally more comfortable and provide better music quality, but the tradeoff is that an over-the-ear set is usually heavier, and more isolating (a plus for some uses). The Soundpeats A1 Bluetooth headphones are very similar in design to the Nakamichi Over the Ear Bluetooth Headphones BT304 (which seem to be discontinued), but cost about 25% less than the current discounted price for the Nakamichis. For the cost, this is a very nice set of cans, with some features that the Nakamichis don't have, and performance that is close, if not quite as good.Testing was done with a 2012 ASUS Nexus 7 tablet, using Google Play Music with locally stored music. My main test track was "Cervantine" by A Hawk and a Hacksaw, a track that includes bass drum and other percussion, a variety of brass from tuba to trumpet, strings, and accordion, with a wide tonal range. Bluetooth pairing was straightforward, with alternating red and blue lights on the left side indicating that the device was in pairing mode. Indoors signal breakup began around 45 feet, with several intervening walls, and outdoors with no intervening obstacles, connection maintained out to about 150 feet; both are very good performance, well in excess of the Bluetooth spec of ~10 meters.Included in the packaging:- 1 M USB charging cable- 1.6 M 3.5mm audio patch cable (nicer than usual, flat ribbon cable with an L and a straight connector)- Soft cloth carrying bagControls are well separated, with previous/next and start/stop buttons on the left; power Volume +- on the right. Both a micro-USB charging port and a port for a standard 3.5 mm patch cable are under a rubber plug cover (which isn't as fiddly as most). Unfortunately, the previous/next buttons do not work as expected. With most Bluetooth headsets, pressing and holding the previous next buttons does fast back or fast forward within a track. With this set, they only support click to start from the beginning of the previous track, or to advance to the next track (in fairness, this was not described as a feature in the user manual). Other than this, all controls worked as expected, with good separation and tactile feedback.Especially noteworthy is the right headphone, which has a user-replaceable BP-6X lithium ion battery, a feature I have never seen before on a rechargeable BT headset of this type. With most such units, the battery is sealed, and if it dies (they all do eventually), you are out of luck, unless you want to try surgery. Claimed battery life is ~12 hours. The BP-6X battery is a very common size, used in Motorola Droid phones, and is available on Amazon for just over $3. The manual lists battery capacity as 450 mAh, while BP-6 batteries for the Droid are rated at up to 1390 mAh. Assuming play time is linear, the higher capacity battery should deliver about 36 hours of listening on a single charge.Both the headband and the earphones are amply padded, and extremely comfortable; the Nakamichi phones might have a slight advantage because their padded covering is perforated. Weight is nearly identical at a claimed 200 grams for the Nakamich vs 210 grams for the Soundpeats A1.The Soundpeats A1 delivers slightly less volume, and slightly muffled compared with the Nakamichi, which also has more "presence." Except when compared with the Nakamich headset, the Soundpeats A1 beats every other Bluetooth headset I have ever used.+++Pros+++- Very comfortable- Excellent controls- Good sound quality- Can be used wirelessly or with a patch cord- Fold flat for travel- Inexpensive user-replaceable battery- Good user guide, printed in a size that is actually eye readable- No frustration packaging---Cons---- No fast forward/fast rewind capability- Slightly muffled sound (but only when compared with higher spec headphones)===Bottom Line===The Soundpeats A1 Bluetooth Headphones are better than average at this price point, with decent (if not outstanding) sound, comfortable, and with quite a few extras not found in the competition.Disclaimer: I received this product free from the vendor in exchange for an honest review.

Etekcity RoverBeats F1 bluetooth on-ear headphones are mid-size, with a hard plastic band. The user's manual covers the operational basics, which are similar to other BT headsets. All operational controls are on the right side, using the standard marking conventions (volume +-, |<<  >>| with a concave start/stop button in the middle. A micro-USB charging port is at the bottom of the right headphone.Testing was done with a Nexus 7 tablet, playing music downloaded from Google Play Music. Bluetooth range is middling, barely meeting the minimum requirement of 10 meters (with intervening walls) indoors. Most other Bluetooth devices that I have used maintain connection out to about 40-50% greater distances before breaking up. I did not test the built-in microphone.These are "on-ear" not "over the ear" headphones, so there is relatively little isolation from the outside world, which is either a plus or a minus, depending on one's preference. Claimed frequency response, 20-20kHz is optimistic; 100-8kHz seems more realistic. Low bass was lacking, and more noticeably treble when compared with a more expensive set of Nakamichi over-the-ear headphones. Sound quality and volume are fine for "easy listening" but these are far from audiophile headphones.++ Pros ++- Relatively light weight.- Build quality feels solid, and fit and finish are good.- Paired easily with 2 different Android tablets, 2 Chromebooks, an iMac and a Macbook.- Decent battery life, ~10 hours.- Start/Stop button is easily identified by touch- Acceptable sound quality for the price-- Cons --- The plastic band has very little no padding on the underside. Even though it provided plenty of tension, the band tended to slip back and forth.- Limited adjustability. Standard in/out with about an inch of travel on each side. The headphones themselves can be rotated about 15, but there is very little movement in other planes. I wear glasses, and even with thin temples, these headphones were not terribly comfortable. But head and ear shapes vary tremendously, so what is uncomfortable for one person may be fine for another.- While the start/stop button is very easy to find, the volume +- and forward/backward buttons are stiff, with almost no separation, and no tactile differentiation. Worse, the "click area" is where the buttons almost touch, so it is difficult to change volume without inadvertently skipping a track.- This is not a folding design, and is not particularly well suited for travel.== Bottom line ==The Etekcity RoverBeats F1 bluetooth on-ear headphones provide decent value for the price. If they fit your head, they should be fine, but adjustability is fairly limited.Disclaimer: I received this product free from Etekcity in exchange for an honest review.

== Pros ==- Compared to CFL globe bulbs, LED technology delivers full brightness instantly.- Claimed color is 2700K, which seems accurate; the light balance seems neutral, neither yellowish nor bluish.- Light distribution is very even, without any hot spots.- BRIGHT. These are much brighter than expected, more like 60W equivalent, rather than the claimed 40W. As a result, a bathroom remodeling project ended up with more illumination than needed. The dimmable bulbs cost more, but may be a better choice.== Cons ==- Plastic packaging is difficult to open, requiring a knife (dangerous if you slip) or large shears. Single bulb packaging was not problematic.- If you are accustomed to the slow start of a CFL (a useful feature in the middle of the night), the instant-on nature of an LED can be startling.

The size of a typical USB flash drive, this is an incredibly tiny device, considering what it does. Turn it on, wait ~15 seconds for the red LED to turn blue, start recording. To stop recording, turn it off. The 15 second delay is useful, as it allows positioning the recorder before recording starts.Each clip is limited to about 4 hours of recorded sound, and a 20 minute clip occupies about 2.6 Mb. Although this is a voice recorder, even music plays back with a surprising amount of bass, but high notes were very muted (probably no more than 5 kHz). To minimize picking up extraneous sounds, hang it from a cord through the loop at one end.+++ Pros ++++ Tiny size+ Surprisingly good sound for voice+ Space for 150 *hours* of recording time+ Claimed 15 hour battery life (I don't plan test this)--- Cons ---- Not intended for recording music (hardly surprising for a device measuring  70mm x 21mm x 9.4mm)- User's manual is in 5 point type, which is virtually impossible to read without a magnifying glass. This could be resolved by including a PDF version on the device.- Only encodes in Windows .WAV format, using an ancient codec, ADPCM (developed in the 1970s at Bell Labs for voice coding), which is not universally supported. ADPCM is OK for voice, but according to the NAB Engineering Handbook, "ADPCM predates MPEG... [and] unless there is no alternative, it should be used only for voice feeds."- Not compatible with Apple's QuickTime Player 10.3. To play recordings on a Mac running OS X 10.9.5 (aka Mavericks), I had to install VLC Player. To play on a Chromebook, I had to upload the WAV file to an online conversion service, and convert to MP3. No additional software was required to play on a Chromebook running Ubuntu 12.04 (Linux)== Recommendations ==- Include User's Manual on device. The User's Manual is available online: http://blog.etekcity.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/USB-8GB-Voice-Recorder-Manual.pdf  The manual is only ~256 Kb, so it takes up an insignificant amount of space, and can be copied to the device without interfering with its functionality.- Support MP3 or a more modern codec for WAVBottom line: Great little voice recorder IF you have a Windows PC. Otherwise, be prepared to jump through some hoops.DISCLAIMER: This product was provided to me for review purposes. I have tried to write a thorough, fair, and balanced review, and have sent recommendations for improvement to Etekcity.

Rechargable power packs have become so common that I almost expect one to show up in a cereal box "Free Power Bank Inside!" They all do essentially the same thing, and all other things being equal, you need to choose between capacity, weight, and speed. Generally speaking, the greater the capacity, the heavier the device, from purse size 2000 mAh units to 20,000+ monsters packing enough juice to start a car. Within those parameters, vendors distinguish themselves by design and extras.At 10,400 mAh, the Foxnovo is in the midrange of what is currently available, and distinguishes itself by elegant packaging and extras, including a flat ribbon hydra power cable with USB micro type-A, USB micro type-B (aka USB 3), "classic" Apple 30-pin, and Apple "Lightning" connectors, covering the majority of contemporary USB devices. I don't have any iOS devices, so while travelling, I prefer to carry separate cables with USB mini and micro connectors. The matte finish aluminum case complements most devices from Apple.Four small blue LEDs indicate the state of charge; mine arrived showing 2 LEDs (<50% charge), and took approximately 5:15 to reach 100% charge (4 LEDS, no blinking) on a 2 Amp Nexus USB charger. In the enclosed documentation, self charging time is listed at 8-10 hours, presumably for a fully discharged unit. A small push button, labeled ON/OFF, is just right of the USB-micro charging port. Using the 2.1 Amp port, a 2012 Nexus 7 that was 50% discharged (4325 mAh battery) took approximately 5 hours to reach 100%, with the power pack still showing 3 LEDs. The aluminum case never got warm to the touch while being charged or while charging another device. Based on this charging test, claimed battery capacity seems accurate, but the 2.1 Amp port is delivering less current than claimed. For comparison, a Patriot Fuel+ rated at 9000 mAh completed the same charging test in 1:55 using its 2.5 Amp port. The Patriot Fuel+ remains my favorite among this class of device; although the Fuel+ chunkier and not as elegant, performance is important, and the plastic case is tougher than aluminum.Other minor points: a nicer than usual plush carrying case is included, with an outside pouch for the charging cable. Packaging is a simple cardboard box with a closed cell foam liner  easy to open and recyclable. Documentation (in English, German, French, Spanish, and Italian) is sparse, but covers everything that needs to be covered.A card in the box proclaims a "lifetime" warranty: "If you have any problem at anytime with our products, we will replace it. Done and Done." However... in an answer to a customer question on June 2, a Foxnovo representative provided contradictory information:"The product includes 30 days refund and 90 days replacement return policy, as well as.We will cover the return shipping fee of defective products within return policy."All in all, this is one of the nicer power packs that I have used; it's not the smallest or lightest, but offers a decent amount of power in an elegant package that is pleasing to the eye as well as to the hand. It's going into my travel bag. Four stars because of conflicting statements about the warranty, as well as slower than expected time to charge a 7" tablet.Disclaimer : I received this product for free, in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I stumbled on Mandolin Orange through a Prime Music e-mail. Delightful stuff; Andrew Marlin reminds me a lot of another NC singer/songwriter, Jonathan Byrd  also from Carrboro, NC. What is it about this place? Wonderful duo, great album; I am looking forward to hearing them in person. In the meantime, I can listen to "Such Jubilee."

The different strengths it takes to pull the four looped, broad bands (green-light, blue-medium, red-heavy, black-extra heavy) are quite noticeable without even pulling on them. The bands thicken as the levels advance from the lightest to the heaviest. They fold up very nicely to fit in the provided, tiny 5" x 3" bag for stowing in purse or luggage, so you can keep in shape while traveling.The exercise DVD provided is divided into chapters (warm-up, upper body, abdominals, lower body, ending stretch). You can do all chapters at once (1 hour duration) or pick specific areas to view. The the visual quality of the DVD is good, and Linda Woodridge gives helpful hints throughout on how to adjust the exercises to one's own capabilities without being belittling or overly perky. Her voice is pleasant and kept to a moderate level-neither too soft or too loud. I found it thoughtful of her that she only used the green and blue bands to encourage beginners and prevent strain injuries from trying to keep up with the heavier bands. There are quite a lot of exercises, many of which I've done in the past without the bands. Doing all the exercises along with her for an hour is exhausting and maybe too much for beginners, and as she advises stop during an exercise if too tired. You don't have to work through the entire DVD in one session.It would have been helpful if she had given recommendations for the number of repetitions in each set of exercises. She only counted at the last 5-8 repetitions of each exercise. With so many exercises to do in an hour, it would be hard to memorize the full workout to enable one to do it without the DVD or a download of it.Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.

UPDATE 2: Friendly Swede customer support is top notch. With hours of my update about the problem I had with the fabric covering coming off the tip, the contacted me, apologized, and offered to send a replacement. Such responsiveness for a low-tech item like a stylus is surprising, and they have earned my customer loyalty.UPDATE: The fabric covering the rubber tip is not well-secured by the retaining ring; I suspect this is a quality control issue, with the cloth being cut to closely. As a result, the covering of one stylus started to come off after only a few weeks of light use, and another is visibly not well attached. Stylus behavior and feel is good, but durability is not, and the replaceable tip models are a better choice.I've been using a pack of 3.5" Friendly Swede stylii for some time, and found that the rubber tips do not work particularly well with a Remix Ultra Tablet, so I decided to give these a try. The tablet responds instantly, and the fiber tip glides much more smoothly.Since I found the 4.5 inch stylus a little short, I decided to try the 7.3" model. It's a little too big for my taste. Fortunately, the cap is a simple press fit in a thin aluminum tube, so I removed the cap, shortened the tube, and ended up with a 5.5" stylus which feels "just right" to my hand. You can always cut down a stylus that is too long, but you can't lengthen one that is too short.

Unless you are backpacking, where every ounce counts, 8X40 may be the sweet spot for non-stabilized binoculars: Neither too heavy nor too light 40 mm objective gathers more light, allowing a larger exit pupil 8X magnification is easier to hold steady than higher magnificationAll controls on the DBPOWER 8x40 binoculars operate smoothly. I did *not* test to see if they are truly waterproof, but I would take all such claims with a grain of salt. The rubber covering makes them comfortable to hold, and should provide some impact protection, if dropped.Not an apples to oranges comparison, but I compared these with my old set of Nikon compact 9x25 binoculars. The 8x40 are, of course, larger and heavier, but the larger exit pupil provides more freedom of movement, and the larger objective makes them much brighter. The image was sharp, with good contrast, without noticeable change in either illumination or sharpness from center to edge. Closest focus with the DBPOWER is about 6 meters; Nikon focuses perhaps a half meter closer.My only complaint is the relatively flexible yoke that holds the eyepieces, which makes it difficult to achieve and retain the same focus from both eyepieces. Other than this, the design appears to be quite substantial. I appreciate that the rubber cover for the eyepieces has a slot for the strap  no more lost cover.These binoculars appear to be identical to the Bestek 8x40 binoculars, also sold on Amazon.Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.

UPDATE: After several months of usage, run time, whether plugged in or operating from battery has dropped to about 30 minutes, which  limits the usefulness of this lamp. I still love the design, but it isn't aging well.My 15-year old clip-on reading light uses a small flashlight bulb, which illuminates only a small field, and that not terribly brightly. The power switch is fiddly, and increasingly unreliable. Pardon the pun, but the difference between new and old is like the difference between night and dayThe DBPOWER light had a decent charge when received, and charged fully in less than an hour (a red charging LED shines through the base while it's charging). A minor nit, this light uses an uncommon power cable, USB Type-A on one end, with a 3.5 mm right angle barrel connector on the other end, rather than USB mini or micro. So, if you want to travel, you pack its power cable, rather than use a generic USB cable or cellphone charger. If you lose the cable, search Amazon for "3.5 mm barrel to usb"  replacements are available from $0.99 upward. On the other hand, the barrel connector doesn't require aligning with the socket, and is probably more rugged than a USB micro connector, so ultimately, the charging cable has no bearing on the performance of the light.The headboard of my bed won't accept a clip-on lamp, and the base of this lamp is rather light, so the neck can't be moved very far off center without tipping; I solved this by putting a ~1 oz weight in the base.A mere brush of the finger is all that's required to turn the light on (lowest; tap again for middle, again for brightest). The brightest level is quite bright  possibly too bright for reading in bed, something I haven't tried yet. Despite a linear array of 14 LEDs, the light  field is roughly circular, so orientation doesn't matter. The light is a relatively "pure" white, neither yellowish nor bluish. After turning the light on to high, I let it run until the battery was exhausted, about 4 hours. After plugging it back in to the charger, the light was immediately usable at any of the brightness settings.Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.

I'm between 3 and 4 stars for this Bluetooth mouse.== Pros ==I like the shape, the matte finish, and most especially the fact that it's rechargeable  no extra batteries to carry on a trip, and I always travel with an array of USB cables and chargers. Tracking action is fine, the left and right buttons provide reasonable feedback, and the scroll wheel has a nice feel.== Cons ==The instructions are terrible. After trying, and failing multiple times to pair by pushing the (unlabeled) pairing button, I succeeded by tapping it several times. The tracking light is red, and when in pairing mode, as with many Bluetooth devices, a blue light flashes on the underside. After some initial pairing issues, it paired successfully and identified itself as "Bluetooth_Mouse" with a desktop iMac, 2 different Chromebooks, and a Remix ultra-tablet.I expected the multiple DPI selection to be more useful than it is, but the the only way to tell which resolution is in effect is to move the mouse pointer in a circle: big circle = low DPI; small circle = high DPI. Click the small button just behind the scroll wheel to change DPI, cycling through all 3 settings. Instead of a button, a 3-position switch, indicating which DPI has been chosen, would be more useful.On a completely subjective basis, I prefer the heft of a heavier mouse, such as one with 2 AA batteries, but if you like a lighter mouse, this may be a good choice.So, 4 stars for functionality, 2 stars for documentation. You only set up a device like this once, and probably soon lose the documentation, so in the long run functionality trumps documentation.Disclaimer: I was sent this mouse as a review unit.

== Pros ==Where I live we have more power outages than I would like, so it's a good to have an emergency light that is easy to deploy in the dark. This is a basic collapsible lantern, easy to turn on by expanding the case  no switch to hunt for in the dark. I recruited my neighbor's daughter as a test subject; she proved that it is literally so easy to use that a 2-year old can turn it on and off.Not obvious from the photos, but the envelope surrounding the LED array is frosted, providing diffused light; also, the case itself is translucent, so some light passes through it. You can vary the light output by sliding the top part way down, but this just reduces the size of the opening through which light is transmitted, rather than reducing the amount of power used by the 120 lumen LED.
