To test battery life, I sacrificed 3 AA batteries (Eveready Gold, expiration date 12/2024) by letting the lantern run until the batteries were exhausted. I gave up after 48 hours over the course of 4 days. By that time the light was about as bright as a night light, but it was still visible.Although I did not observe the transition from full bright to a lower level, I wonder if power is reduced automatically after some period to extend run time.I had no need to test it, but I was impressed by the seller's promise they they "...will ALWAYS replace a faulty product or refund your purchase!" Few products come with that sort of guarantee.== Cons ==As other reviewers have noted, there is a strong plastic smell when the package is first opened; placing the lantern in strong sunlight for a full day should eliminate most of the smell.I'm not convinced of the usefulness of the unlighted compass, which seems like an add-on gimmick.Disclaimer : I received a free coupon for providing an honest and unbiased review. I have no financial or personal connection with the manufacturer, seller or their employees.

Due to the sensor technology used in these devices, I suspect there may be wide variations in accuracy. In my case, I seem to have gotten a good one, and while setting it up with both the indoor and outdoor sensors in the same location for over an hour, each reported almost identical temperature and humidity readings, with the temperature corresponding with an instant read digital cooking thermometer.My only real complaint is that the clock isn't an atomic clock, so it has to be reset periodically against a known time source.The display is quite readable in normal light, and the blue backlight works fine to get a quick read in the dark.

These work as described, and are good for lighting a deck, but beware that each bulb uses 40 W, so 24 X 40 = 960 Watts. Packaging is protective, but somewhat inconvenient, as each bulb has to be unscrewed from its socket to remove it from the cardboard carrier, an action that has to be repeated 24 times. I managed to break 3 bulbs while extending the string, but they are wired in parallel, so the light string continues to work, even with missing bulbs. Replacement bulbs are not easy to find, and run about $2.50 each.

HARDWAREAs a device with a form factor very similar to that of the Microsoft Surface, the Remix has most of the advantages and liabilities of that design. The kickstand makes it quite usable on a flat surface, but the magnetic coupling of the keyboard, and top-heavy nature of this design make it less stable on a lap. The Remix (and Surface) is NOT a laptop. It's something entirely different.The Remix is well provisioned with 2 Gb of RAM, 64 Gb of flash storage, and a slot cleverly hidden under the kickstand supports micro-SD cards up to 128 Gb. I am storing about 30 Gb of videos on a 32 Gb micro-SD card, which integrates seamlessly with the File Manager. Overall performance is good, and everything works well; the only nits are relatively weak sound from the side-firing speakers, and a touchpad that is not as responsive as the touchpad on a good laptop. The Remix pairs easily with a Bluetooth mouse, which is a good alternative to the touchpad. The keyboard has good feel, and because keyboard and RemixOS were designed to work with each other, there are some function keys that add special capabilities, such as accessing settings, disabling the touchpad, and searching for apps. My only real complaint is that the tablet does not wake up when you open the keyboard cover, nor does tapping a key reliably wake it up. Jide developers are aware of the need for a better way to wake a sleeping Remix other than hitting the physical power button at top right of the tablet.If you want to protect your Remix, most cases made for the Microsoft Surface will fit. I use a ProCase Wallet Sleeve Case for Surface 3http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00L6620G4, which fits like it was custom made for the Remix.SOFTWARERemixOS is an Android variant, but is compatible with almost every app that I have tried to install from the Google Play Store. RemixOS does NOT support widgets at this time, which may be an issue for hardcore Android fans, but is not for me. RemixOS introduces some fairly dramatic improvements to "pure" Android (my only previous Android experience is with Google Nexus 7 tablets, running both KitKat and Lollipop). A Windows-like taskbar at the bottom of the screen makes frequently used apps more accessible, and makes switching between apps far easier. Jide provides several dedicated apps for Mail, Calendar, Notes, and an office suite. I prefer some of them (such as Mail and Settings) to their Google counterparts. The other major enhancement that RemixOS adds to the Android experience permits some apps to be run in "phone mode" with a movable (but not yet resizable) window. Phone mode can be very handy for having multiple app windows visible for what I will call "information" apps, such as Calendar, Google Play Music, and Pandora. Not all apps (including most of those from Jide) can be run in phone mode. The only Android software feature that I really miss is the ability to create multiple, independent user accounts on one device.CONCLUSIONAlthough Jide is working on a 2nd generation Remix, this year's model is an excellent start. Software evolves, and early in this product's life, one should anticipate frequent updates. RemixOS 1.5 (based on Android Lollipop) will start beta testing in June, and should be released this summer. The Remix Ultra-tablet and RemixOS are a very good release 1.0 effort, and in the long run RemixOS may be more important than the hardware, as it breaks new ground for Android. The Remix is a productivity tablet, not just for games and social media.
My daughter had an outpatient procedure recently for calcified tendonitis in her right elbow. She reports that this device makes it much easier for her to drive to work.

For thousands of years, combs were made from natural materials, such as bone, tortoiseshell, ivory, rubber, wood, and metal, but in the 19th century cheap plastic all but eliminated traditional combs. We have lost something with the transition. I have never used a horn comb before, so when asked to review this item, I decided to give it a look.I wouldn't call this a pocket comb, but otherwise it's quite nice. The teeth of a new plastic comb have rough ends and scratch my scalp, not so with this horn comb. My wife has long hair, so I had her give it a try. No static! Advantages of horn combs include:* No static electricity* The comb seems to slip better through hair* Hair seems shinierUnlike a plastic comb, a horn comb can dry out, and requires some maintenance, so it should be oiled once or twice a year, using lanolin, almond oil, coconut oil, jojoba oil, olive oil, etc. Take care of your comb, and it will take care of your hair.Nos peignes respectent la natureOur combs respect natureHorn is a natural, renewable and fully biodegradable material. The residues from the manufacturing processe are used to make buttons or are crushed into powder and used as natural fertilizer by farmers and local gardeners.Grinding is natural, using a mixture of pumice and water. Combs are polished mechanically with a cloth. The manufacturing process does not use any solvent.Fabriqu en France

As a Kickstarter backer, I received a pre-release version of the Jide Remix Ultra Tablet last week, and since the Remix is a pre-release device, there are no accessories designed specifically for it. The ProCase fits like it was custom designed for the Remix, which measures 189 mm high, 295 mm wide, and 15 mm thick (with keyboard cover attached). Fits like a glove (for purposes of illustration, the Remix in the photo is intentionally not fully inserted in the case).

Initially, I was  somewhat skeptical of this product, mainly because the ropes that attach the handles to the actual cutting chain seemed to provide no control over its alignment. However, once a cut is started, it cuts in a straight line. The plastic handles provide a good grip, but it began to jam about half way while cutting the 2.5" trunk of a small dead shrub (which was slightly tilted from the vertical, so I was making the cut in a way such that the gap would open while cutting). The teeth really are quite sharp, and in the right circumstances, such as cutting brush for a campfire, this is a useful tool for a camper or backpacker, and it stows easily in its cloth carrying pouch.In some ways, this is like Dr. Johnson's comment about "a dog's walking on his hind legs. It is not done well; but you are surprised to find it done at all." Since operation requires 2 hands, not as useful as the saw blad on a Leatherman for cutting off one's arm, as "127 Hours" rock climber Aron Ralston had to do.

The vinyl tool roll that came with my 1999 motorcycle was long past its expiration date, and the under seat space on my motorcycle is limited in width. The CruzTOOLS roll-up tool pouch is one of the few that will fit there. Well made, with pockets of multiple sizes, and generous ties. All my tools fit, with room to spare. Especially appreciated is the little flap pocket, for securing small items.

I've been hooked on memory foam pillows for over a decade, and when asked to review this one on the eve of a trip that would include a stay at a B&B that I knew had thin, soft pillows, I eagerly accepted the offer.The SmarterRest pillow is packaged nicer than most, and the bundled sleep mask and ear plugs are appreciated (we have been staying next to a restaurant/bar for the past week). It's slightly thinner and firmer than most, but has a feature I haven't seen before: there is a slight depression in the middle of the pillow, where your neck and head rest. Some other reviewers have noted an odor; I detected none (but my sense of smell is not the greatest). I'm sleeping better than at the beginning of my trip.If you like memory foam pillows, this one is worth checking out. Like mattresses, a pillow should be replaced every few years, although memory foam seems to hold up longer than synthetic fiber fill, probably less than down.
We live in a location where it is quite common to have 40 or 50 days of over 100 degree weather. This Synthetic lubricant keeps my motorcycle cooler, extending engine life.

November 18, 2015 UpdateI really wish Braven would not have designed this speaker with a special power supply cord requirement. I've spent almost two hours scouring through my various USB cables and power bricks trying to locate the one Braven power cable. I haven't found it yet. I'm taking another star off of my review due to this design. It's really irritating.Original ReviewBraven makes high priced and high quality Bluetooth speakers. This one is no exception. It is a very nice product.We already have another Braven Bluetooth Speaker, the BRAVEN BRV-HD [Water-Resistant][28 Hour Playtime] - Black]]. It has great sound but is large, heavy, and quite expensive. While it is battery operated, fully portable, and Bluetooth I would hardly call it portable. We keep the BRV-HD in the kitchen in a permanent spot. When I saw this smaller, lighter Braven Balance I thought it would be a truly portable unit. And a good one given that it comes from Braven.I weighed it with my digital scale at 29 ounces. Quite acceptable to carry in a backpack if you want the type of sound quality this Balance produces. I also have an LG Music-Flow with quite good sound quality that weighs just over 25 ounces and I carry it around the house for morning shaving, painting a room, or working in the garage. I expect I'll be using the Balance for most of those events from now on. A small increase in weight over what I've been using is a very small price to pay for better sound, and the Balance has a USB port to charge other devices. The Balance provides much better sound than the LG Music-Flow.The IPX7 waterproof rating means it's good for being submerged for 30 minutes down to 1 meter. To me that is good protection for an accidental drop into our spa, or if it's forgotten out in the rain. It also means it can be used on the beach because sand won't get into it and wet hands won't bother it.Now to the sound quality.- Treble is very good. I am very fussy about high sounds since I can hear up to 18KHz.- Mid-range is very good. This is not only good for music but I listen to a lot of audio podcasts.- Base. For a speaker of this size the base is quite good. There is still a slight muffling to the base but not much. I like the base of the Balance more than the larger Braven BRV-HD. This muffling seems to be a Braven trait because even the much larger BRV-HD exhibits more muffling in the base. It is a circuit designers choice how to tweak sounds and Braven seems to tend toward this characteristic.I like the shape of this speaker. It is easy to fit in my hand, and it seems quite well proportioned for the largest speakers in the smallest package. The outside is all covered in a soft rubbery material that, with care, looks like it will wear well.  The end caps act as a sub-woofer. The caps are almost like a speaker themselves as they flex quite a bit with a little finger pressure. I'm sure this adds to the base quality of the Balance. The bottom is flat and about 1 1/2" x 7" so it sits firmly on a shelf. They designed in four small feet on the back so it can be laid on it's back.My biggest complaint with this speaker is the very loud female voice that come in to announce status changes like being connected via Bluetooth. It is very loud and pays no attention to the volume buttons.Pros:- Battery check button and 5 LED lights to show charge state.- Easy to pair with my two smartphones and tablet. It even paired easily with my 5-year-old's kids tablet.- Reasonable weight for the size, sound quality, and features- Good sound quality- USB charge port- Can be used as a speakerphone.- Built in Boost EQ setting- 18 hours of battery life (untested by me). Battery life will be reduced if the Balance is also used to charge another device.- I had no color choice as this was a free product. Fortunately for me this purple color is way over on the blue side.Cons:- The Braven Balance comes with a wall charger. I would really prefer that it would use a micro USB input to charge it. Micro USB is certainly capable as it is used in my 20,000 MAh Anker external battery, so charging 4,000 MAh battery would work well. Since the Balance has an ac cord with a brick on the end I'm forced to take it with me if I travel with the Balance.- The A/C Brick on the charge cord for the Balance has a snap in connector for United States A/C outlets. There are three more for overseas outlets. I would have preferred, since I'm forced to carry the brick, a folding U.S. compatible plug arrangement. For travel I'll remove the protruding AC adapter and have to make sure I carry that separate piece along as well.- As far as I can tell it has a non user-replaceable battery. This is a hot button for me as with most electronic products these days the battery will fail long before the rest of the product.- When the Balance is connected a room filling loud female voice says "Audio device connected" I find this rather annoying. This means I won't be able to use the Balance in our master bath while my wife is sleeping in the next room. I actually had a small inexpensive Bluetooth speaker that did the same thing and I gave that device to someone else just because of this same feature. A blinking light is sufficient.- When turning the Boost feature on a quite loud female voice says "Enabled" There appears to be no way to turn this voice feature off or turn it down. I had the speaker playing music at a low volume when I attempted to try the Boost feature and was unpleasantly surprised by the very loud voice announcement. I consider this a quite negative feature of this Braven product.Comparing three Bluetooth Speakers I have...The LG Electronics NP7550 comes in at $148 and, while a nice speaker with good sound, doesn't hold a candle to the Braven Balance. The LG advertises up to 10 hours battery life but I get about four.The Braven BRV-HD comes in at $300, sounds better, but I consider it not to be a truly portable device due to the size and weight.From these three I'll choose the $130 Braven Balance every time. I reduced by one star due to the very loud status announcements. I sent an email to Braven support regarding this feature, asking if it could be disabled or at least change the volume of the announcements.As long as you are okay with the loud announcements I highly recommend the Braven Balance.

Sound quality 4 out of 5Comfort 3 out of 5Features 5 out of 5Pros:- An included 3.5mm to 3.5mm cord allows use with devices that are not Bluetooth, or to use the headset if the battery is low.- 10 hours (not fully tested by me yet) of battery life with only 1.5 hours of charge time.- Volume up/down, Next/Previous track, Stop/Start buttons nicely designed into the right side of the headset- Built in microphone for- Bluetooth straight line tested to work out to 30' from source- Easy to pair- Light weight- Answer/hangup phone control- Price is midrangeCons:- Rigid earphones do not allow the headset to adjust to ones specific ears.- Music quality is just okay but base is muffled- Non user replaceable battery. If it goes bad or deteriorates there is no recourse but to revert to using them wired. It could be so easy to design in replaceable batteries.These will be great for my five-year-old son. He has gone through 4 sets of inexpensive earphones, all because the cord has broken. Keeping these charged will be an extra step but at least the cord won't be a problem. To me the sound quality isn't good enough for my use.For the price these are okay headphones. If you desire high quality sound you may want to look elsewhere. If maximum comfort is a concern these might be okay for short periods but to me I wouldn't wear them for more than an hour. These are on-ear rather than over-ear headphones.
I ordered this for our five year old son who got caught up in it just like the little girls do, even though he didn't think all that much about the movie.

Five stars given the price. This is actually a decent cover for this price.The leather isn't real but nonetheless it is a very nice leather looking material with a soft protective cover for the vitalASC tablet. The cover fits the vitalASC quite well, but as another reviewer said lining up the cameras with the openings in the case is problematic. I believe if the openings were made larger that would be a non issue.After inserting the tablet there is a nice flap with Velcro on the end to hold it firmly in place. The case does not overlap onto the screen. There is a loop to hold a touch pen. A magnetic latch is built into the cover to help keep the front cover in place.  There is an opening on the rear for the speaker.I'm not sure why there are two 1" size holes on the back. I can't imagine what purpose they serve. Perhaps heat relief? If they were willing to put those two large holes in the back they should have no problem making the camera openings a bit larger.The cover folds back to make a stand. There is no way to adjust the angle of the tablet on the stand. But just having the tablet on the stand will be great. I have a Bluetooth keyboard to use with the tablet but really needed the cover/stand.If you own or are purchasing a vitalASC 9" tablet I recommend this cover.Now I wish I could find a screen protector for the vitalASC...

I believe in the quality of Meguiar's products. I've used them for years. This Marine Wash-N-Wax promises cleaning of salt spots, and adding UV protection, among others. I used it to wash our boat within 15 minutes of receiving the product.I really liked the thickness of the product, and how it made a nice head of foam in the wash bucket. I followed the directions which were just a little odd.1) Wet the boat hull first2) Apply the M42323) Wash off but not with a spray but rather a flow of water.4) Don't let it dry but use a cloth to polish and dry the hullIn my case I didn't notice any appreciable increase in the shine on my boat hull, but I rarely do. My boat is shiny all the time and is rarely water spotted or dirty. Also we boat in fresh water so we don't have to deal with salt spots. Not that I'm a stranger to salt spots.For over 20 years we lived near the Southern California ocean and had to deal regularly with salt spray. At that time I learned there were few products better than household vinegar to deal with dried salt spots. I also used Salt Terminator or SaltAway which worked well. But then I would still have to follow up with a wash soap of some kind. Having a Wash-N-Wax product that removed salt spots would have been a huge time saver. So for those that deal with salt spots I'd give this a try.Don't hate me but our boat always comes home from our two local lakes washed clean. The lakes here are so clean, basically as good as the fresh water that comes out of our taps, that the boat is being washed while we use it on the lake. We don't even have water spots after we let the boat air dry because of the low instance of minerals in our lakes. Still I'll appreciate this product for those times I do wash the boat. It can get dusty and pick up some dirt on the short drive home from the lake.I especially appreciate this product having UV protection in the mix.The finish was indeed streak free which was much appreciated.The only reason for not giving it five stars is I can't test the salt spot removing capability.

Update 16 October, 2015I've now received email from LeapFrog stating they are aware of the problems with the Weather App and are working on a fix. They also stated that the two apps of ours, Jack and the Neverland Pirates and Hot Wheels Raceway Reading, are targeted to work on the Epic.It is good to have this rapid feedback from LeapFrog.I plugged in a 32GB microSDHC card today. Now the Epic has 48GB of memory, enough to load quite a few full length movies for a two week vacation coming up soon. The Epic is turning out to be a great little product.Original ReviewWe received the Epic today and I must say this is the first LeapFrog tablet that I think is a very good one. I will expand my review when we've had more time on it but here is the initial report.Pros:- Crisp screen and good viewing angles. It is actually a very nice viewing experience.- Decent brightness, we've used it exclusively outside in the shade thus far and it is fine.- Good volume although the speaker is on the back so easy to cover with a hand or by laying it on a table.- Much heavier than a common 7" tablet but not unlike a LeapPad Ultra or LeapPad Platinum. My five-year-old has not complained about the weight.- Home screens (there are several) are fun and full of features. Much better than the other LeapPad products.- The green bumper around the edge is firmly in place but can be removed.- There are only three buttons; power, volume up, and volume down- Lots of parent control options.- Bluetooth. Finally my son can use a bluetooth headset. We've gone through 4 headsets, each time the cord has failed.- The microSD card slot allows an additional 32GB of storage to be added to the Epic. Good job LeapFrog on this one!- LeapFrog Epic does not work with the computer based LeapFrog Connect. I guess that is a good thing. Apparently all that is needed is a WiFi connection for all downloads.- Full unrestricted browser available to parents only. Lacking some functionality though, for example if you download a .PDF file there is no reader (perhaps one could be downloaded?)- LeafFrog finally converted to a micro USB connector on the Epic. That make it compatible with most of the USB cables in our house. I always had to go looking for a special cable for the LeapFrog products.- I already knew that app cartridges won't work so that isn't a negative for this one. I don't consider that a big problem because I never liked the game cartridges in the first place.- I copied some of our son's favorite movies to the Epic. Finally he can watch movies on road trips. Yea.Cons:- Like so many other products these days the rechargeable batteries are not replaceable. That means the battery will slowly deteriorate over time and I wonder how we will be able to put in a fresh rechargeable battery. This is a big hot button for me.- App prices from LeapFrog are way out of balance with other apps on tablets and smartphones. They claim it is due to how much they spend developing the apps but other apps costing much less also have had a great deal of cost to develop as well. I've noticed a slight shift downward in app prices. Perhaps LeapFrog is getting the message.- Some apps hide the "back" and "home" buttons on the bottom of the screen so it seems there is no way to exit the app. I've learned hitting the power button twice quickly brings it back to the home screen.- The weather app seems to work for others but not for us. I've sent in a trouble report to LeapFrog.LeapFrog says hundreds of apps that run on the LeapPad series will work on the Epic.Apps that are not compatible in our case:- Hot Wheels Raceway Reading- Jake and the Neverland PiratesI'm a little bummed about those two apps not working on the Epic. They are both great games and some of our son's favorites.Apps that are compatible in our case:- Letter Factory Adventures: The Letter Machine Rescue Team- Letter Factory Adventures. Counting on Lemonaid- Sammy Submariner.- Get Ready for Kindergarten: Stretchy Monkey's Super DayIn general I strongly recommend the Epic. I definitely recommend the Epic over any other LeapPad that has been produced by LeapFrog. I think they have a winner on their hands this time.

Better than the cushions I've been using but too thin or too soft.I weigh about 220 pounds. When I sit on this cushion I can feel the chair seat under the cushion. So it is either too thin for someone of my weight, or the foam is not sufficiently firm. I think the issue is the foam is not firm enough. Just gripping it between my thumb and forefinger it is much too easy to compress.The material, stitching, and bead that runs around the cushion are fine.I'm now using one of my old cushions under this one which seems to be working.

I must say evaluating a router isn't easy. I spent over 4 hours, making changes, doing tests, and writing this report.There are two things I'm interested in with a WiFi router. 1) How easy is it to setup. 2) How fast is it.If you don't like reading long detailed reviews here is the synopsis: The setup was easy, the signal strength was good, and the data transfer rates were good. I recommend this router.If you like more detail read on...SETUPThis is the easiest to setup router I've ever used, and I've had perhaps 10 WiFi routers over the years. I disconnected the previous router, connected all of the cables to this router, and powered it up. With a browser I went to address 192.168.1.1 and logged in (using the username and password from the documentation). I selected the automatic setup and went through a couple of steps, renaming the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz and setting my own choice of password. That was pretty much it. All of my WiFi devices just worked as did the 1TB hard drive I plugged into the USB port. I did have to map the 1TB drive to our computers which was an expected extra step.SPEEDThis is a much more difficult thing to test. There are many variables and signal issues to consider. There are "channels", "bands", signal strength, and data transfer rates.In the end, to give you the short version, I found this router to be better than the relatively new TP_Link AC router it will replace. But it isn't magic. It might take some experimentation to squeeze the best behavior out of this Linksys.When using the 2.4GHz band other devices such as cordless phones and baby monitors can be on the same band and reduce the signal strength. When running WiFi tests on my smartphone one of the weakest channels is always the channel I'm on. That's because my phone is using a lot of the bandwidth on that channel and mode. That alone reduces the measured signal strength on that channel. Of course all of the neighbors have WiFi and several devices such as tablets, laptops, smartphones, ROKU, and other devices that can interfere with the available signal strength.We are on a cable modem, not a DSL line. DSL offers slower data rates but the data rate is constant. With DSL you're not sharing the bandwidth with your neighbors. With cable we share the bandwidth with many other people so the bandwidth increases and decreases as other people in the neighborhood use the internet.So trying to evaluate one WiFi router vs another isn't easy because so many things can cause signal strength and data rate variations during testing. But there isn't much I can do about that so I just went ahead and ran the two tests at my disposal. One is an app on my smartphone called WiFi Analyzer, and the other is the widely known SpeedTest.My test method was this: I first ran tests using my old WiFi Router. I went to the four corners of our tract home lot. At each corner I ran both the WiFi Analyzer and SpeedTest, recording the results. I then replaced the old TP-Link AC1200 WiFi router with this Linksys WRT AC1900 Dual-Band Smart WiFi Router and ran the tests again. We live in a single story detached wood frame home. The WiFi router is mounted somewhat off center of the house on top of a 6' high wood cabinet.I ran most of the tests on the 2.4GHz band because I have some devices that only run on that band. I did do one test on the 5GHz band and the results were good, but as the old TP-Link router didn't have a "B" mode 5GHz WiFi option I could not run comparison tests. I have zero devices with the new AC mode so could run no tests at all for that mode. I suspect most people have no or few AC mode devices. AC devices have been out for a while but I have not had a need to replace any of our devices and many new devices still don't come with the AC mode. We've installed two WiFi printers recently and both only have the 2.4GHz band.The results were far less than positive for the Linksys in terms of signal strength at first. So I fiddled with two variables.The first change I tried was to install High Gain antennas on the Linksys replacing the four small antennas included. I had previously installed the new High Gain antennas on the TP-Link, which at the time made very little difference while running the same tests. I took the High Gain, much larger, antennas off the TP-Link and installed them on the new Linksys. The results were worse than the stock antennas. Length of the antenna isn't an indicator of a better signal. I have a background in electronics and spent 4 years on military radar so I understand antennas are tuned. My advice to myself and others is don't waste your money on high gain antennas.The second change I made was to the channel. The TP-Link router had automatically chosen channel 6, but the new Linksys had automatically chosen channel 1. So, after achieving poor results on channel 1, I modified the Linksys to also use channel 6, and then reran the tests. This was more like comparing apples to apples. In this case the Linksys was superior, but I have to wonder why it would have selected channel 1 which was weaker. I will post photos of the screenshots showing the signal strength comparisons.The next test was SpeedTest. It's important to note that signal strength and data throughput are linked but somewhat independent. It is quite possible to have a weak signal but fast upload and download speed.In almost all cases the new Linksys router provided faster download speeds than the TP-Link. So the new Linksys came through in my case.Before going on to other features of the Linksys, what would I choose? At this point I favor the new Linksys for better signal strength and data speed. I will post a 'photo' of the small spreadsheet I put together from the data I collected. But here is a brief limited comparison. These results were with both routers on channel 6.Location 1: TP_Link download 14.04 Mbps, signal strength 3/10.  Linksys  download 17.76 Mbps, signal strength 3/10Location 2: TP_Link download 12.24 Mbps, signal strength 1/10  Linksys  download 22.56 Mbps, signal strength 3/10Location 3: TP_Link download  8.38 Mbps, signal strength  2.0/10  Linksys  download  5.06 Mbps, signal strength  2.5/10Location 4: TP_Link download 17.51 Mbps, signal strength 0/10  Linksys  download 21.04 Mbps, signal strength 3/10OTHER FEATURESBoth my old router and the Linksys are gigabit routers. However in our house we keep a 1TB hard drive connected to the router so we can have central access from multiple computers. We've done that by plugging a small hard drive into the USB port of the router, creating a cheap NAS. The old TP_Link has only a USB 2.0 port while this Linksys has a USB 3.0 port which is a big improvement, being 10 times faster. This is huge for us. It will provide faster access for all files, and much faster backup to that drive.So the bottom line for us is, in most cases around our house, we will have faster download speeds, and better signal strength, with the new Linksys. Also we will have much faster access to the data on the hard drive connected to the router.I would guess if you have AC mode WiFi devices you'd be quite happy to have this router. Sorry I could not do any tests on that mode. For any devices we buy in the future I'll be looking for those with the AC WiFi feature.I also like the Guest WiFi account which gives my guests access to the internet, but not to our home network. It is password protected so not just anyone can use it.

I read this book years ago. It changed my life. I can't now help but think about the devil and his cohorts when I think of the influence the devil tries to exert on me.I've recommended this book to others so I finally decided to buy another copy and give it to one person, asking him to pass it to someone else after he has read it.This book was so powerful to me that I couldn't finish it. I got the message quite clearly by 1/2 way through the book and just couldn't take it any more.

Having just ordered 40 Eneloop batteries I wanted more cases like the one I already have, so ordered these. They snap closed and stay closed, hold 4 each AA or AAA batteries. They are great for trips, or just for storing charged batteries in our "battery box" where we keep all household batteries.

It's not really possible to report on the long term behavior yet, but there are certainly things to excite me about these Eneloop batteries. I had heard the name Eneloop for quite a while but had not looked into them. CostCo was offering a package with 12 batteries and a charger so we picked that package up to give Eneloop a try.I hate batteries, always have. They are expensive, and drain much too quickly. For a few years we had tried a variety of AAA and AA batteries which worked okay but never as well as regular Alkaline batteries. They lost charge while sitting on the shelf, and drained very quickly.When we came home from CostCo I decided to see what other users said about Eneloop. Well other than a few who had apparently received a few bad batteries the general user review was very positive. They said these batteries last as long as Alkalines, had a long charge shelf life, and could be recharged many times. I was so pleased at the promise of these batteries I ordered  quite a few AA and AAA Eneloop batteries.Some reviewers complained the batteries did not come fully charged. I tried putting a few in a flashlight and they worked just fine. But I am putting all of them through the charger, and they all need about 20-30 minutes of charging before the charger indicates they are 100% charged. I don't care. I wouldn't have cared if they were 0% charged to begin with. Assuming they will last many years I'll be charging them many times so one more time doesn't seem like a problem for me.I will be using the Eneloop exclusively over the next few weeks and will report back here to indicate how these batteries have done.

The closet pulls in three bedrooms had all become scratched and blemished over their 17 years. Popping the old ones off was easy as they were tension mounted only. When I inserted these they wouldn't stay in until I drove nails trough the supplied nail holes. So they were the correct fit but just a little different design than the old ones. No big deal.

Oct 10, UpdateThe cushion is leaking air. I've had to blow it up twice last night. Today when I sat on it I had to blow it up again. For me this is the kiss of death. I'm reducing the review to one star and I'm going to toss it in the trash.Oct 9, 2015 UpdateI've found two negative things. 1) I can't sit on it for more than an hour without it becoming uncomfortable. I've found if I sit on the smooth bottom it is a bit more comfortable.  2) It doesn't breathe like a cloth covered cushion so my but feels wet after I've been sitting on it for a while then stand up. I'm reducing by one star.I've let out most of the air so it is almost flat now. I'm sure that defeats the purpose of the cushion but it is much more comfortable this way.Original Review:I can certainly use some body toning as I am overweight. Also I tend to sit in front of my computer, on a rather hard chair, for 3 to 5 hours per night . This cushion seemed to be a good solution for both issues. I only have been sitting on it for a short time but I admit it is keeping me moving to sit on it which has to be good for my torso. Also it is much more comfortable to sit on than the chair with two thin cushions I've been using for over a year.I've also had sciatic nerve problems in my left leg for 4 years. I'm hoping this cushion will exert less pressure on the leg which might relieve the pain.I will have to give this a week or so at which time I'll report back here.There was no evidence of the little inflator tool in the package. I already have a couple of those though.

Update Sept 30, 2015I used this projector for about 6 hours today. I am pretty pleased with it. The video is bright, sharp, high definition, and the color reproduction is very good.I was able to use a portable Bluetooth speaker for sound connected to my laptop, rather than the not too bad speaker of the projector. This feature depends on the capability of your laptop.In my original review I had a paragraph about the projector fan noise level. It is pretty hard to describe the volume of a sound so I thought I'd use my smartphone app which measures sound level in dB's. I measured the sound in the 10' x 10' room with the door closed so it was pretty quiet. There were no other sources of sound, such as my laptop which was turned off for this exercise. I took these measurements at 3 feet in back of the projector.  Room with the projector turned off = 30 dB (very quiet)  Room with the projector turned on = 55 dBOne table I found on-line indicated conversational speech is about 60-65 dB, a whisper at 30 dB, and a refrigerator at 50 dB. One site suggested "comfortable hearing levels" were below 60dBOf course I don't know how accurate my smartphone is as a dB meter but this should give an idea of the relative noise.Original Review:This projector is going straight to our private school once I've used it for a week or so. There it will be used five days per week and the school may have some more feedback that I will then share.Once unpacked I connected the projector to my laptop using an HDMI cable. I started a youtube video, switched the projector on, and immediately the sound of the video was already coming out of the projector's speaker. I pushed the Source Search button on the projector and it took three seconds to find the video stream on the HDMI input. So within less than 30 seconds after powering up I was watching the youtube video output from the projector. Having used many video projectors over the years this was by far the easiest set-up I've ever encountered. The settings on your own laptop my require some things that were automatic on my laptop.These projectors put out a lot of heat, almost all due to the lamp, and that heat has to be carried out of the projector so high volume fans are necessary. Fan noise of these projectors can often be too loud. Many times these projectors are set up on tables in the middle of a classroom or conference room where the noise is in the worst possible place; right in the middle of the viewing audience. When I first turned the VS340 in the fan noise was apparent but really not too loud. There is a low whine from the fan, the rest of the noise is the fan blade and air flow. I doubt if the designers could reduce the noise much at this point. Once the sound from the youtube video (at half volume on the projector settings) came on, the  noise from the fan was no big deal. The fan noise certainly would not cause a presenter/teacher to raise their voice.The speaker of the projector is on the rear which seems practical. How many times have you seen one of these in use where the presenter/teacher is in the front of the room and the projector is near them. Also the fan output is on the front, so opposite side away from the speaker. Overall I thought this was a smart design as far as fan noise and speaker output is concerned.The video image was bright at the default 50% setting, and it was pleasantly bright with daylight streaming into the room. Cranking the brightness up provided a very nice picture which I'm sure will be suitable for the classroom where it will be used. There are brightness and contrast settings in the menu. Color reproduction at the default settings was a replica of what was being shown on my laptop screen.A simple knob above the lens is used to focus the image.Behind the focus control is a zoom control. I was disappointed in the range of zoom which had a range of 56" to 67" in width when the projector was about eight feet from the wall. There is also a digital zoom in the menu system, but that is better used for situations where the video image does not fill the window of the projected video.Keystone controls are on top of the projector. The keystone adjustment is in small enough steps you will be able to adjust the image to a fairly exact rectangle shape. The projector has automatic keystone which seemed to work well as I tipped the projector up, but not so well when tipped down. In any case you have the manual keystone control.All projector controls can be adjusted from the top of the projector, or from the remote. The menu system is very easy to understand and use. I found the simple controls on the top of the projector to be a bit easier to use than the remote because the remote has quite a few more keys and some that required me to look in the user manual for the intended function (I had never heard of an MHL Device). Ignoring the special keys on the remote though it too is easy to use.By the way the 255 page user manual comes on the included disk. There is no paper copy of the manual shipped with the product. The good news is if you want to know more right now, before you buy, you can easily find the Epson VS340 user manual in PDF form online on the Epson web site. The manual indicates there is a "Wireless" option available to allow this projector to be used wireless over a LAN network. This projector has many more features than I've outlined here. Check the manual to see if this projector has the specific features you need or want.Without a manual or much effort at all you just plug this in, connect it up, and it's ready for use. I believe the way I use it is likely the way 95% of buyers will use it, connected to a laptop with an HDMI cable.On the remote is a button labeled "Pointer" which switches on or off a small arrow over the video image. You then use the rocker keys to move the arrow around. I suppose that would be useful in come cases but I'd rather have a laser pointer that would move with my hand. There are no "Pointer" controls on the top of the projector. In the menu system there is an option to change the shape of the pointer. One advantage of the Epson "Pointer" is students won't be shining a laser beam in each other's eyes.There is no carry handle on the projector. So it is more likely a two handed job to carry the VS340. A handle would have been nice but this projector will likely be carried in a box along with the cables and remote.In the past the lamps of this type of projector might last 100 hours or less, and they were expensive to replace. Epson suggests this lamp will last 10,000 hours; likely as long as the projector itself. This is a welcome improvement. However I looked up the replacement lamps which are only about $80. This projector uses what Epson calls 3LCD light source which is solid state so, while they do output heat, they are much cooler than the older lamps. A big advantage, other than long life, to the LCD lights is they do not require the fan to run for a long time after you power the projector down.A nice feature is provided with the lens cover. The lens of this projector does not protrude outside the body of the projector. There is a slide-over lens cover to protect the lens. If you slide the cover closed while the projector is operating the LCD light is turned off and the projector goes into a stand-by mode. It comes out of stand-by, back into full operation, as soon as you slide the cover open.There are other less expensive projectors on the market, but if you match price and display brightness (expressed in Lumens) most of this quality and brightness would be priced higher than the VS340.I highly recommend this product.
These refills aren't too expensive and provide a fun target for plinking. If they are hit in the center they shatter nicely and make a satisfying spray of material.

Cute, lightweight, comedy. Harrison is always good.A demanding woman pays a pilot to take her on an airplane trip. The plane crashes on a deserted island. They start to depend on each other and get along after a rocky start to the relationship. Slowly they fall for each other, all the while wondering if they will ever get off the island. They get chased by bad guys, shot at, and manage to patch up the crippled airplane.It's a fun little movie for adults.
Not too much more of a price and these are printable. The white surface makes these disks printable on my Epson or Canon ink jet printers. Nice. Now I can make my burned disks look more professional.

We just installed this faucet today. So far I like it a lot. The finish is exactly what we were looking for. The stainless steel should hold up for a long time. It isn't shiny like chrome so it won't show water marks easily. The magnetic spray head is really nice. Our previous faucet was  pull-out but it wouldn't say in place when it was retracted. It drooped and didn't look nice.My favorite feature is one that other people don't like. That is this faucet does not automatically return to stream mode when it it turned off then back on. I searched for a faucet that didn't do that. I like to use spray mode most of the time. It really irritated me that I couldn't get our previous faucet to stay in spray mode. The way this Delta works is there is a switch on the spray head for stream or spray. Turning the faucet off and on doesn't alter the switch setting.I cleaned up the dishes after dinner this evening. I really liked the extra height of the faucet because I didn't have to manipulate the larger pan under the faucet, it was tall enough to make that operation easy. Also the arm of the faucet swivels easily; something our previous faucet resisted.Installation was relatively easy. We have an advantage of our sink being installed on an angle in the corner of the counter top. That means there is a large area for my hands to fit where the faucet works are installed. Sinks that are up against a wall don't offer much space. The good news is Delta supplied a neat plastic wrench which helped with the most difficult part - that being running a nut up several inches under the sink to secure the faucet in place.I was a little concerned about the height of this faucet, easily twice the height of the one it replaced. Before ordering it I stood by the sink with a tape measure in hand trying to visualize what it would look like. My fears were for naught. The faucet looks great, especially against the backdrop of the potted plants behind it. I'll post a couple of photos.

Oct 1, 2015My wife and I find this little pump a bit difficult to push down, and the dollop of soap dispensed is small. We will keep it because it matches the faucet, but we are disappointed with it overall.Original Review:It's okay.I was disappointed that this dispenser titled, "Delta Faucet RP50781AR Soap/Lotion Dispenser, Arctic Stainless" is plastic rather than stainless.Really these things aren't rocket science. There's a container under the sink, and this little pump with a hose going down into the container. We had a soap dispenser already. I just ordered and installed this to go with the new Delta faucet so they would match.

Our son is just about to cross over the 40 pound milestone so he can start using a booster seat instead of a full car seat. This isn't all that important for around home but we are taking flights and renting a car in a couple of months. This is small enough and light enough to use as carry on.He really wants to start using this booster seat. We are all happy to see the dual cup holders. He has cup holders on his car seats but when we fold down the 60/40 other seat in the back seat of our cars we have to remove the cup holder. With the booster he'll be able to use the opposite side cup holder for his water.The quality seems very good. This booster was the highest rated on several review web sites. We feel confident our child will be protected and comfortable in this booster seat.

We recently obtained a LeapReader pen which I believe is one of the better products from LeapFrog. I don't mind paying reasonable prices for these books because they are assisting our kinder gardener's reading skills. Reading is the foundation for all other academic life skills.The trick now is to get him to focus on the phonics rather than to bypass that aspect and just have fun with the pen and books. That will require we parents to sit with him and encourage him to use them properly. There are five books for the vowels, a, e, i, o, u.

October 11, 2015I'm changing my review from 5 stars to 3 because the cable, right where the end plug is, has lost connection. They are less than two months old. I can move the wire around to make it work but it is intermittent. This may be due to my son's habit of playing with the cord, wrapping around his fingers, etc. Or it may be due to poor design or quality. I'm not sure. If it failed because my son was playing with the cord then perhaps these won't work with us. We are headed on vacation in three weeks so I just ordered another pair of headphones.Remembering that our son used the Kidz Gear headset for years before they broke I'm switching back to Kidz Gear. When the Kidz Gear (two pair) broke it was the volume control in the cord that went bad. The new Kidz Gear headphones no longer have a volume control in the cord. I just ordered another Kidz Gear headset.Original ReviewGood headphones for the price. The best thing I can say about these is my five-year-old likes them. They sound good, fit good, and I'm hoping the no tangle cord lives up to it's name.We had purchased two of the Kidz Gear headphones. The first pair lasted about two years, and the second about 18 months. That is pretty good service for a headset that is used often by a child, but... Both Kidz Gear headsets had to be tossed out due to the volume control in the cord which ceased to work. From what I can see Kidz Gear seems to have eliminated the volume control from their latest offering so they must have had too many complaints. However these Sentey were quite a bit less expensive so I thought we'd give them a try.

Sept 2, 2015 UpdateI've attached two additional photos. One shows the 1.250 two sided printouts. The other shows the ink level after printing those 1,250 pages. Since they are printed on both sides consider that this is the equivalent of 2,500 single sided printouts. It looks to me that about 10% of the ink which would scale to 25,000 pages until the ink runs out. I'm a believer.When we need a printer I will definitely consider one of the Epson EcoTank printers such as the 4500 or 4550.Original Review:This is a great printer. So fast! I print a lot of things for our church. The first thing I assigned to this printer queue was 200 two sided bulletin inserts. I was quite surprised at how fast the pages started spitting out of the machine; even duplex printing was quite rapid. The prints are crisp and look very good.You should have two people to un-box and lift this printer onto the place it will be used as it is heavy. Pulling off all of the blue packing tape, loading the ink, and loading the paper took about 15 minutes. Then the printer did some automatic setup which took another 12 minutes. The ink is actually quite easy to install. I have no idea how the printer gets the ink out of the ink bag, but then I really don't care. What I do care about is the quality of the printout and the cost of ink. In both cases this printer is a winner.I set the printer up using WiFi which was quick and easy. I used the push button method which means pushing a small button on my router, then selecting that mode on the printer. It took less than two minutes.I stuck the included disk in my computer DVD reader. The whole software setup took about 10-15 minutes (I walked away so it my have been quicker if I was present to answer questions). Then after about an hour it automatically searched for and downloaded some more software and updated drivers.I couldn't fit a whole ream of paper in one drawer, so I put the rest of it in the second drawer. My guess is it will hold about 800 sheets in the two drawers, which is really great. Tons of ink plus tons of paper means I won't have to service the printer often.Printing:Printing simply just worked. With three printers in the house I just selected the WF-R4640, and sent my duplex 200 bulletin insert job to the printer. It started printing within a few seconds after I pushed the Print button on my computer screen. I didn't time how long it took to print all 200 double sided sheets but it was something on the order of 20 minutes or so. It would have taken two hours on my Canon printer.There isn't too much more I can say about the printing feature except it is really fast, and the resulting printout is very very good. Knowing I have an enormous ink supply really makes me want to print a lot more often in color. I've fallen into the habit of printing a lot of things in grey-scale to save color ink.Scanning:I have another Epson printer and it will scan but it was a pain to use. In fact I never could get the little Epson XP-420 to scan from the front panel and had to do it from the computer. Then the window used for scanning from the computer would close after every scan operation. I finally gave up and use my Canon for scanning.The WF-R4640 scan has lots of options including scanning to email, the cloud, FTP, and more, but I couldn't find an option to scan to my computer. Huh? Thats the main thing I want to do with my scans. Again I had to revert to using my computer to execute a scan as I could not figure out any way to scan from the front panel of the printer and send the image to my computer. If I had to scan several things I could put them in the document feeder and scan all of them easily. But if I was scanning pages out of a book I'd have to walk back and forth between the printer and my computer.One mode is to scan to a thumb drive which I did. It worked fine but was not ideal. I could also display the contents of the thumb drive on the printer LCD screen.One thing I wanted to check was how many small photos I could lay on the platen and have the WF-R4640 auto crop them each into their own .JPG file. However I could not find any way to do that at all. It isn't a matter of how many photos, rather it's a matter of no auto crop being available at all. I was really hoping for a faster, better, scan than my Canon. Finally after much poking around I stumbled on the Thumbnail tab in the Scan Preview window which was smart enough to discover there were four photos on the platen.  It worked but was far from obvious.Of course scanning multiple photos isn't a normal office need. I was hoping to combine all of my print, scan, and copy jobs into this one printer to take advantage of the faster speed. There is some good news. The scan results were superb. I scanned at 600dpi and the resulting images were exactly the same colors, brightness, and sharpness of the original photos. In fact the results were better than my flatbed scanner. Really the best I've seen and I've scanned a lot of photos.CopyMy only complaint about copy and scan is the lid (which is also the automatic document feeder) over the platen doesn't have a hinge mechanism that holds the lid in the open position. I have to lift it (it isn't heavy) all the way up until it is about 95-100 degrees from it's horizontal position for it to stay open. There is nothing to keep the lid from slamming down either; no hinge mechanism that will act like a shock absorber. It's not bad but my other printers do have such a mechanism. I'll have to be more careful with this one.Copy has a set of features. Of course you can place a single sheet on the platen to copy it, or you can stick one or more sheets into the document feeder. The feeder works perfectly, picking up one sheet at a time as it should. The document feeder passes a sheet over a window which scans the document in before printing it. The platen on the other hand moves the scan bar under the stationary document. No big surprise here.Copy quality is excellent. As with most copiers these days it isn't easy to determine which was the original and which is the copy. The quality is that good.Here is the one thing that this printer simply can't do; border-less photo printing. There is a thin line of un-printed white all around the edge.Do you want to lay a book on the platen to copy something? Well certainly you can open the top and lay the book on the platen. But if you want to close the top over the book it had better be a thin book. The top (which is the auto feeder) only expands about 1/2". My Canon expands more than twice that height.FaxI couldn't test the Fax feature. To tell the truth I haven't had to fax anything in over 4 years. Every time someone tells me they are going to FAX me something I just ask if they could email it instead. They always can and do. Then I print the form that was mailed to me, fill it out, sign it, scan it back in and email it back. We don't even have a land-line.NoiseThis isn't a quite printer. It isn't a particularly noisy printer either. The printer makes the usual noise picking up a sheet of paper to print on, then there is the relatively quiet noise of the print head going back and forth. I wouldn't want my desk to be sitting next to this printer if it is to be used by an office staff all day.There is a Quiet Mode for printing but I didn't find one for scanning or copying. I also didn't notice much of a difference between Quiet mode On or Off.Touch ScreenAs neither of my other printers is touch screen it took me a few moments to recognize this one was. The strange thing is some screens have a back arrow to go back one screen, while in other cases you have to depend on the physical back button next to the screen.The menu system isn't particularly easy to use. I found this also to be true of my other Epson printer. Part of the problem is this printer has a ton of options, all of which make sense for their respective operations. The other part is the menus sometimes make perfect sense, while other times I had to walk back to the computer to read the user manual. (I am a very experienced user)The one thing that kept getting my attention as I tried out many of this printer's functions is how fast it is. It didn't matter if I was printing an 8x10" sheet of paper or a 4x6" color print; the thing is just noticeably fast.Conclusion...This is a very nice printer. If I focus myself on the fact that this is intended for a small office I can overlook the photo shortcomings. For an office this is very fast, very practical, very cost effective, and low maintenance. The print/copy/scan quality is top notch.Now that I have had it in hand and understand that it's strengths are clearly small office oriented, and it won't do everything that I want it to do for a home printer, I will be seeking a small office to donate it. It will go either to our private school, a local homeless organization, or my church. If I donate it to our church I'll be able to do the printouts that are my volunteer job for the church, I'll just have to do them at church instead of at home.I'm including a series of photos I took as I set the printer up for use. You'll see 1) The size of the box it cam in. 2) some of the blue tape that had to be removed. 3) The size of the printer next to my 20oz water bottle 4) Opening the black ink compartment. 5) Pushing the release to open the black ink receiver 6) The black ink receiver open 7) black ink bag 8) ink bag in place 9) latching the black ink 10) same deal for the color ink bags 11) the business side of an ink bag 12) color ink bags installed 13) the printer auto setup screen 14) My attempt at making a copy of a 4x6" photo 15) the rear (3rd) paper tray with a sheet of 4x6" photo paper.I will donate this printer but the next time I need to buy a printer it will be one of these bag ink types. I hate spending $20-$50 for a 1/2 shot glass of ink.I highly recommend this printer for a small office. The printer itself is expensive but then it is a serious printer with many features and blazing speed. The ink bags will cost $100-$200 each but they should last 20,000 copies each so will save tons of money on ink.

September 13, 2015 UpdateMy 5 year old son was very excited about the LeapReader. He brought it with him everywhere, even in the car on the way to school and back. He used it for about five days, then put it down and lost interest in it. I even bought theLeapFrog LeapReader Learn to Read, Volume 1 set but he didn't get interested in those books, even after I tried to spend time with him. It seems the novelty of touching words and having the LeapReader wore off.I still think this is a great product, but it is a learning tool rather than a game. He is in a good private kindergarten five hours a day and I think that is simply enough for him. When he gets home he wants to play.Original ReviewI have been quite positive on the quality of LeapPad products over the past couple of years, at the same time being very critical of the premium prices they ask for their apps/games. In my opinion the LeapReader may be the positive exception.Much of the LeapFrog system including the software for the various tablets are WAY too expensive for what they provide. We simply do not buy titles because they are so darn expensive. This LeapPreader and the books are a different story.First the pen itself is nicely priced in the $50 range. It has a built in battery (too bad it isn't user replaceable though), speaker, microphone jack, Home, Forward, Back, Play/Pause, and power buttons. It has something on the order of several hundred megabytes of storage which is a lot for audio only.We home schooled our three children all they way from K-12. Teaching them to read was the single most important skill we could have taught them. All other educational skills have as their foundation good reading capacity. There are many reader teaching tools on the market, this is just one of them so don't think it is head and shoulders above some others. But for what it is it is pretty good.Paying $25 for some of the titles on a LeapPad is pretty steep, especially for the limited learning many of them provide. But Paying $14 for the Paw Patrol book with audio included that teaches a child to learn reading is quite another thing. Next I will be ordering the six volume set Learn To Read Volume 1 for under $18 total.My five-year-old learned to start to read in pre-schol, now he's just started kindergarten. He already can sound out many words and is rapidly going down the path of reading quite well. Still he can benefit from the Learn To Read Volume 1 set.My only concern is the LeapReader is a mix of Whole Word and Phonics. Touch a word in the book with the pen and the word is spoken. By touching the yellow diamond the tool switches into a sound-it-out mode. But kids can ignore that mode. Frankly what kids want to do is have the story told to them and listening to the phonics isn't very much fun. So if they skip the phonics approach all they are getting is the While Word teaching style.Whole Word is quite controversial. We first started home schooling our children when we learned the public schools in California were teaching Whole Word. At that time we pulled our daughter out of first grade and taught her to read using phonics. In 2005 the country of Australia, "endorsed the teaching of synthetic phonics, and discredited the whole language approach." It is a system we were not pleased with.Whole Word means the child learns to recognize what a word is simply by seeing the word and learning it by sight. In the 1970's the State of California taught early grades to sight read about 1,000 words but those children were doomed when they had to move on to other words because they had no basis for sounding-them-out (phonics). The grades of thos students suffered when they hit Jr High and High School. Many of them had to be taught to read using phonics at that late date. It still remains controversial to this day. We do not endorse or encourage whole word teaching methods. In time we all do read that way, in the beginning of reading it does not equip children properly. Since our child attends a very good private school that teaches phonics, and we can lean towards the phonics tools available on the LeapReader we feel we can proceed with this utility.This brings up an important aspect of the entire LeapFrog ecosystem. The way LeapFrog tools are created, with spoken instructions, children can happily go off and user their LeapPad or LeapReader all by themselves. As a baby-sitting tool this is great but it leaves the child to explore on their own, perhaps bypassing some of the more important parts of the tools you spent so much money on. We do allow our child to play with the tools by himself but we make certain to also sit with him to encourage him to work through the proper steps of learning with the LeapFrog products. They are both a blessing and a curse.So as we, as a family, step into using the LeapFrog LeapReader we are pleased and encouraged to provide our son with this aid to supplement what the school is teaching. It will be interesting to see how long he continues to use the LeapReader. He only sticks with the LeapPad for a short time, then gets bored with it.Of all of the LeapFrog products we feel this is the best tool they have produced. We tried the iMagicCard system but it was mostly a gimic and we won't be purchasing any of those titles again. On the other hand we may very well purchase a number of the LeapReader products.

October 1, 2015Today I cleaned a whole 10' x 10' room without having to refill the cleaning solution tank, or emptying the collection tank. I ran the cleaner on the Express Clean mode in a room that did not have a very soiled carpet. The carpet was pretty clean when I started, and perhaps just a little more clean when I finished. While it was nice not to have to deal with the tanks several times I really don't think the express mode cleans very well. I think the only realistic mode is the Deep Cleaning mode.August 24, 2015As promised here are my comments after doing some carpet cleaning today. I cleaned about 180 square feet of high traffic area in our house.The Bissell 1548 worked fine, however my concerns were warranted. The fresh water tank, and especially the dirty water collection are too small. Not unlike other home carpet cleaning systems. I found that on the Deep Cleaning setting, following the instructions to make two "wet" passes and two vacuum passes, I had to refill the clean tank, and empty the dirty water tank, every 40-50 square feet. To me this is annoying. The back and forth to the sink simply happens way too often.The collection tank is small to begin with. Then the automatic shut off system turns it off when the tank is less than 1/2 full. I will include a photo.If you don't mind changing the water four times in a smaller than 15 square foot room then you may be pleased with the Bissell 1548.I tried it on the Express Clean mode (much less cleaning solution applied) which would seem to last through a whole room, but I didn't think that did a good job of cleaning. Bissell recommends using the Deep Cleaning mode.I can say one very positive thing about the Bissell 1548; the dual brush system works very well. I'm comparing it to the 7 year old Hoover F5880 we have. That Hoover's brushes were simply to little and too soft to do much scrubbing.Other than the brushes I don't see anything that sets this product apart from other home carpet cleaners.Now a few comparison comments between this Bissell and our old Hoover. Both seem to do an equally good job at cleaning the carpet and depositing dark dirty water in the collection tank.- The old Hoover has better vacuum suction. It returns more water from the carpet than the Bissell.- The old Hoover has a large cap for the clean water tank. Invert the cap, fill it with cleaning product, and dump it into the tank. This is easier than the Bissell which requires me to fill the hot water to a fill line (hard to tell when there is a foam in that tank), then fill to a second line with solution.- It is easier to rinse the dirty water tank of the Hoover than the Bissell.- The Bissell brush system is far superior to the old Hoover system.- The overflow shut-off system for the dirty water tank works much better in the Bissell than the old Hoover.I recommend this Bissell for those who don't mind exchanging water often. Still I find very little, other than the brushes, to differentiate this from other systems on the market. The Hoover Power Scrub Deluxe Carpet Washer, FH50150 is less expensive and receives high reviews on Amazon.com.As for me I intend to donate my old Hoover, and this Bissell, to my offspring for their homes. I will be ordering a Bissell BISSELL Big Green Deep Cleaning Machine Professional Grade Carpet Cleaner, 86T3/86T3Q for twice the price but way over twice the tank sizes.Original ReviewFirst Impressions after unpacking, assembling, and reading the operating instructions.Pros:1) Easy to assemble.2) The tanks are easy to remove and reinstall.3) I really like the two rotating brushes - this was a key point for me selecting this product.4) Not that this is all that important but it is a nice looking machine.5) Long power cord.6) It has a bare floor mode7) Hose and fittings to do stairs and furniture, or car floors and upholstery.8) Light weightCons:1) The fresh water supply is only one gallon.2) The dirty water tank looks to be about one gallon too but the "fill" line is much lower and the dirty water tank will shut off when it is less than half full. There is a float in the dirty water tank that will shut off dirty water collection when the tank reaches a very low line on the tank. Having to change the clean and dirty water tanks was one of my big complaints about our old rug cleaner. I hope this is better than it looks.I intend to clean some carpets tomorrow and will return with a report on that outcome.One thing I was curious about was this is called a ProHeat cleaner so I assumed it had some sort of built in heating system to keep the water hot. It does show HeatWave Technology. I guess you have to trust it because there is nothing that is visible to the eye related to heating the water. There is no switch to turn the heater on or off. There is no "warm up time" specified in the manual.Amazon encourages us to compare products. The carpet cleaner we've owned for several years is a Hoover F5880 SteamVac Ultra. I must say that product produces no "steam" so it too seems to be a bit of false advertising to me.There are three things that bother me about our old Hoover.1) The four soft small brushes on the bottom rotate side-by-side but there is a small gap between them. I've never felt they offered much scrubbing action. They are like four 3" disks with a soft brush around the edge of each disk laying flat on the carpet and rotating.2) Both the fill tank and the dirty water tank are small. The clean water tank is 1 gallon (same as this Bissell) and the dirty water tank is perhaps also 1 gallon. However "full" means quite a bit less than full for the dirty water tank.3) There is a "float disk" that shuts off collection of dirty water when the dirty water tank is full (or less than 1/2 full). The float disk will rise just based on the foam in the dirt water (I'm always careful to buy the carpet cleaner marked "low suds or low foam). Also the float disk will rise and shut the collection of dirty water off if I move the machine a bit too abruptly which can jostle the float disk. Then I have to turn the machine off and wait for the float disk to drop before I can restart.All of this means the Hoover carpet cleaner will clean far less of a room's carpet and I have to shut down to refill the fresh water tank, and empty the dirty water tank. I just did an 11' x 11' room last week and had to fill and empty the tanks FOUR times for that rather small carpet. Very annoying. I would say it takes me twice as long as it would with a machine with larger tanks, and a properly operating dirty water shut off system.The amazing thing is I've been so unhappy with the Hoover that I researched carpet cleaners and actually thought I had ordered the Bissell Big Green Deep Cleaning Machine ($400). I then checked my Amazon Vine (free products to review) queue and wonder of wonders this Bissell was there for the asking. I went back to see if I could cancel my Big Green Deep Cleaning Machine but in fact I had not hit the last button to order it so it was not actually on order. Wonderful. This Bissell 1548 ProHeat 2X Revolution has the same brush system as Big Green Deep Cleaning Machine so I thought I'd struck it rich.At this point I have the new Bissell with much better brushes, but it seems the tank size issue I've had with the Hoover may still be the same. In fact other than the brushes the Bissell 1548 and the Hoover F5880 seem to be rather equivalent machines. It is entirely possible that I will try this new Bissell 1548, give it to one of my children for their home, and order Big Green Deep Cleaning Machine when all is said and done.

At Last!I recently purchased an Echo clip for my helmet. I was tired of threading the strap through the D rings. The Echo worked and was strong, but it was not easy to align the two parts to clip them together, nor was it easy to unlatch. As I used the Echo, spending a few moments trying to figure feel if the parts were aligned properly, I kept wondering if I might have threaded the D rings quicker than using the Echo. I actually had it misaligned once and it seemed to click in place. When I went to take the helmet off I couldn't get the Echo unlatched because it wasn't properly latched in the first place.This RydeWear is just the opposite. It is easy to install, easy to latch and unlatch. I highly recommend this product.

For about $2.80 each these are pretty decent glasses. I normally buy my reading glasses at CostCo but they continuously change the style they have on hand for purchase. I was looking for half-eye style frames and couldn't find them. This 5-Pack was just what I was looking for.These glasses are all steel frame, no springs on the ear piece. They can be bent to suit. All heads are not shaped the same so I do find it convenient to be able to bend the glasses to fit my self. That is why I prefer steel frames and ear pieces rather than plastic. The nose pieces are large and soft. Overall I like the fit.I ordered, and received, 2.00 strength. The only flaw I can see is at the very top of the lens, adjacent to the top frame, there is a distortion in the plastic lens. It isn't very wide so it doesn't bother me.They are so cheap if I scratch a lens I can just toss it in the trash. I believe these will hold up quite well. Cheap reading glasses tend to last between six months and a year for me. But that is the reason for taking one star off.I do recommend these glasses.

Imagicard is a software process that uses a camera to pick up a code from cards supplied with the game. The game can run on any LeapPad because it is not hardware dependent, other than the need for a camera which to my knowledge all LeapPads have. There is nothing magic about the cards, they are just cards like a deck of playing cards, but thicker. The white stripe around the edge with notches, is what the software reads.There are a few games within the Teenage Mutant Ninja app that use the cards. For example asks the child to provide two numbers that add up to a sum number such as #X + #Y = 5. Some of the TMNT cards have numbers in the upper right hand corner. The child is to locate two cards that sum to the value 5. For example 0+5, 1+4, or 2+3. They locate two cards, point the camera at the cards one at a time, then hit a Checkmark to validate their answer. This is a little ahead of my five year old. It could also have been accomplished by putting a few numbers on the screen and asking the child to tap on the numbers.BBP gave a good 4 star review with a lot more details so I won't attempt to duplicate all of that.Our five year old (I've had six kids) is pretty smart for his age. Capable in many ways. He regularly whips me at a game of concentration, matching pairs of 48 cards laid face down on a table. His vocabulary and comprehension is well beyond his 5 1/2 years. This game is rated for ages 5-8 but I think 5 is a stretch. He is able to play all other LeapPad games without assistance. He could not use more than 40% of this app by himself.In general I find nothing very exciting about the Imagicard part of the software. It could have been left out and accomplished other ways without the cards and camera. It is a bit novel though and I expect it will hold my son's interest for a day or two.I also agree with most of the other reviewers that cards will get lost, spread all over the house, bent, and thrown away inadvertently. I've already found myself collecting cards and putting them back into the tin they came in.As I said there are a few games within the TMNT app. One of them deals with the TMNT characters and their characteristics. You have to have a well working knowledge of the TMNT characters to begin to play that game. We never let our children watch Teen Age Mutant Ninja Turtles because of the violence in their TV shows. So our children can't answer the trivia questions. I thought the app would be void of the violence, unlike the TV, show.
