Even though he couldn't watch the show he was still interested in TMNT I didn't know he would have to have such a detailed knowledge of the Turtles to play that aspect of the app.It seems LeapFrog got carried away with their new found ability to use the camera to scan an image on the cards and make something happen in the app. I rather doubt that any other implementation of the Imagicard process, in another app, will be any more interesting than this one. At $25 it is hugely expensive too. At $5 this might be more interesting as a short term novelty.I'm being generous by giving it three start, perhaps it only rates two.

I find it hard to decide how many stars to give the Platinum.On one hand it is a very sturdy product, kid friendly, some parental controls. So on the physical attributes I would give it five stars. I also don't think $100+ is out of line considering it has a 7" screen, 8GB of memory, two cameras, and it can play MP3 music and shoot video. But the previous product, the Ultra, is available for well under $100. I'm tempted to take a star off for the high price of the Platinum which isn't any better than the Ultra. There's something strange about this company. They take an existing product, repackage it a little, give it a new name, and bump the price way up. We had a LeapPad 2 then got a LeapPad Glo; same product repackaged. You'd think they would follow the general market of electronic devices and newer products would be less expensive.The Platinum is a slightly different shape, more rounded, whereas the Ultra is more of a rectangle. The Platinum diffidently weights less at 19.3 oz. The Ultra weighed 22.9 oz. The weight difference may be the best or only reason to choose the Platinum over the Ultra - if the prices were equal. The lighter weight will be much appreciated by the little ones that have to hold it.I have a smartphone (Nokia Lumia 635) I purchased for $70 (full price). It has a 5" screen, much faster quad processor, and there are over 500,000 apps available for it. Tons of the apps are free, another huge quantity are $0.99, and the really expensive ones are about $5. This is what I have to compare with the LeapFrog devices. Based on that phone, which has a user replaceable battery and a microSD card slot, the phone is a much better buy. In fact buying one of those for my five year old may make perfect sense. The phone also has a thing called "Kids Corner" which protects them from getting onto the internet, changing the phone setup, or making purchases.On the other hand it is basically a repackaged LeapPad Ultra. We now have both an Ultra and the Platinum. I ran them side by side and couldn't find any reason to spend the extra cost for the Platinum; they are pretty much identical with buttons moved around from one to the other. The memory is the same, screen is the same, speed of operation is the same, but the Ultra battery life is longer. Go figure.ONE STAR OFF FOR NON USER REPLACEABLE BATTERIESI despise built-in non user removable batteries. We also have a LeapFrog LeapPad Glo which has user replaceable batteries (an option we purchased), and you can run it off of 4 AA batteries in a pinch; very nice. I don't understand why LeapFrog would abandon the Glo battery design and build the battery into the Ultra and Platinum. All batteries deteriorate. Do you own a car? Have you ever had a 12V battery in your car last longer than about 5 years? From the moment batteries are manufactured they begin to deteriorate. Most built in lithium ion batteries will have lost between 20% and 50% of their charge capacity after two years. Even Apple publishes the schedule of how their iPhone batteries deteriorate over time. Lithium batteries also have the habit of some that simply die an early death, it could happen in a month or a couple of years. My iPod Touch 5th Gen battery only holds a charge for about 10 minutes - it was less than 2 years old when it went bad. The Platinum, for some reason I can't determine, is specified to have a shorter battery charge life than the Ultra. Huh? At least one star off for the built in battery and shorter operating time. When the Glo rechargable batteries die I can just buy new batteries and pop them in. What do I do with the Platinum when the battery dies?To tell you the truth my five-year-old tends to play with my smartphone or 9" tablet (which I bought here on Amazon for $65, with a microSD card slot!) more than he does the LeapPad products. I think the main attraction of the LeapPad products is they are his own, rather than having to borrow one of my devices and get permission to use it.If you are ready to spend a ton of money on LeapFrog apps, and like this Platinum I suggest you buy a much less expensive Ultra/XDI.ONE STAR OFF FOR VERY EXPENSIVE APPSAcross the board these LeapFrog products have one huge marketing problem. The apps/games are very high priced. Many of the apps, the good ones at least, sell for about $25!!! Don't get me wrong the apps are quite good, but I can find very good games on my Android tablet for $0.99 to about $5. LeapFrog seems to have a marketing strategy to attach premium prices to their software and limit their market volume, instead of dropping the prices into a reasonable range and dramatically expanding their market. Yes we now have three LeapPad devices but it is rare for me to purchase an app because they are so darn expensive. One star off for high priced apps. Buy a LeapPad and then five or six apps and the app cost could easily exceed the price of the LeapPad.LeapFrog if you drop your app prices into the under $10 area I'll buy a lot of them.

Update October 24, 2015I actually unscrewed it, took the batteries out, and tossed it in the trash. If this had put out 300 lumens it would have been useful. At 50 lumens it just isn't. It's such a shame that this light was designed, likely prototyped, manufactured, shipped multiple times, installed, removed, and ended up in the trash. What a waste.Original ReviewThe title "Super Bright" should read "Way Too Dim."I should have trusted many reviews that said it would be dim. I thought the area where I wanted to install it is so dark it wouldn't take much light so it should be okay - Not! I think the 7 watt night light in our bathroom puts out more light than this thing.We have a deep sink in our laundry room. There are cabinets over the sink that create shadows making the sink area dark. There is no AC outlet in the area so this seemed like the perfect solution.It actually works fine. It is motion triggered as promised. It switched off in 15 seconds. I'll have to put a piece of black electrical tape on the sensor to narrow the field of view because it turns on when we just walk by.This light says "50lm" on the sticker on the back. Why they would design a light with 14 LEDs that collectively only output 50 lumens is beyond me.I can not recommend this product. I should have purchased another brand for 1/2 price.

Perfect. I normally buy my reading glasses at CostCo. But CostCo rotates the style of glasses so you don't always get the same thing from time to time. This time I didn't pay enough attention, too fixated on the strength and shape of the glasses, and didn't notice that the CostCo selection were all this light weight soft plastic material. The CostCo glasses don't have the bendable nose pieces, rather the nose part is molded into the plastic and they slip down my nose.Thes Gamma Ray brand glasses don't have spring loaded ear pieces, but they fit snug and don't slide around. From now on I'll be careful to select metal frame glasses that can be bent to better shape them to my face. The weight is certainly much more than the light weight CostCo glasses but to tell you the truth the weight just doesn't make a difference to me.I recommend these glasses and will buy them again.

I've never watched MacGyver before. I certainly knew about the show. The term MacGyver has found it's way into the public vocabulary almost as a verb.For a show that is over 30 years old it stands up quite well. This is a very light production, you can't take it seriously. Great for casual viewing, and it is okay for young children for the most part.I'm into season two and plan to binge watch all the way to the end. I'm watching 4 to 6 episodes a day on my computer in a window in the corner of my screen while I work on photographs. Perfect.

August 15, 2015 UpdateI've now used the Sonicare for two mornings. I'm reducing my review from 4 stars to 2 stars. The Sonicare simply does not have enough power in the water stream off the tip, even when set to three pulses, to act as a flosser. I've also discovered that while I could use it away from a sink I'm better off to hang over the sink so water doesn't accumulate in my mouth which gets in the way of the flossing action. So portability isn't what I thought it would be.To be fair I did look up cordless Waterpik flossers and I see that they receive lower scores than the AC models. It seems when these manufacturers try to make something battery powered they have to give up too much in terms of the intended function. They simply can't produce a small, battery powered, yet powerful unit.I simply can not recommend this product. One of the many WaterPik products that has a base with an extendable tube and constant pulsing is a much better choice.Original Review:I accepted this free Vine product thinking we would use for our 5 year old son who hates to have us floss and brush his teeth. It didn't turn out well for him.- He hated the taste of the mouthwash that came with the Sonicare even though I just put in a few drops with the rest being water. Okay I emptied it and just used fresh water.- The instructions make it clear it is to be used with your mouth closed, pretty much killing the idea of using it on our son because we need his mouth open to see where we are pointing the business end of the product.So much for using it for our son. Next I will try it. I already use a Waterpik Waterflosser (about $90 today) and have for several years. In the Amazon guidelines they suggest comparing products so I will. The Sonicare is about $82 so pretty close in price.- The Waterpik provides a constant pulse whereas the Sonicare pulses one to three times then stops.- The Waterpik is AC operated whereas the Sonicare is rechargable in it's own special charging base.- The Waterpik has a small wand on the end of a spiral tube whereas the Sonicare is self contained and portable.- The Waterpik has a large reservoir appropriate for the constant flow of water. The Sonicare has a thumb sized reservoir appropriate for the intermittent pulses.- The Waterpik has a dial to select different strengths of the stream whereas the Sonicare has no adjustment.So they each have their pros and cons.Waterpik Pros- No battery to wear out or recharge- Constant pulse is (in my opinion) easier to use and perhaps does a better job.- The wand is light weight.- The tip of the wand can be rotated to reach different areas.- The strength of the stream can be adjusted with a knob marked 1 to 10Waterpik Cons- Due to the high volume of water flow it is pretty much necessary to hold my head over a sink while using it.Sonicare Pros- More portable. It is a self contained unit- Able to be used away from a sink due to the small amount of water/mouthwash used due to the pulsed operation.- It can be set to pulse once, twice, or three times until it shuts off for about 1 1/2 seconds- The unit will stop pulsing if you take your finger off the trigger. That allows for an even longer time between pulse bursts.- A single charge will last between 11 and 33 days depending on the pulse setting.- The self charging method is inductive so there are no metal contacts.- Simple to use charging stand. Just set the wand on the stand.Sonicare Cons- Anything with a built in battery will deteriorate over time. In two or three years this might not work well and you can't replace the battery.- The intermittent pulse method may not work as well as a constant pulse.- Lack of adjustment of the power of the pulses.- The unit is rather large to hold. I suspect it could have been designed smaller. I don't know why it had to be this large. It measures 6 1/2 inches long not counting the 3 inch tip. The length isn't too bad. The circumference is about 5 1/2" in the center. I have large hands and I can not touch my thumb and forefinger when my hand is wrapped around the unit. This becomes an issue when the whole unit must be rotated to direct the end of the wand to different areas of the mouth. The wand itself does not rotate, you must rotate the whole Sonicare device.I do intend to try this for several days. I will return here to update this review.As of this moment I would recommend a Waterpick over the Sonicare HX8331/30. The pros outweigh the cons for me. Perhaps you might feel differently. Certainly the portability factor might be a big positive for some people.When reading the user reviews of other Sonicare floss devices I see they have been quite unreliable. Many failing within the first few months. This is a completely new device. Perhaps Philips has addressed the reliability issues and this one will be reliable.

August 20, 2015 UpdateI'm going to reduce one star and have to agree with other reviewers on one point. Many buy these for running or other sport activities. They are, after all, advertised as SoundSport. I am not a runner but today I mowed the lawn which makes a lot of noise. So I used these Bose earphones. First, as I said in my original review below, they do not block ambient noise. I had to turn the volume up quite a bit to overcome the sound of the (electric) lawn mower. Then while simply walking around pushing the lawn mower one of the ear buds fell out.No question the sound produced by these earphones is superb. But if you are buying something for sports I'd look elsewhere.Original ReviewI use earphones for perhaps 3 to 4 hours every day. My choice for the past year or more has been the Apple (no I'm not a fanboy but just those earphones) EarPods. They have good sound and fit very comfortably in my ears. I've actually given away or thrown away almost all other earphones in my collection and mostly use the EarPods. I was skeptical about any other earphones. But when I saw these were from Bose I requested them.I don't know why they are called headphones by Bose. To me headphones denotes earphones attached to a device that goes over your head. To me these are earphones.These in-ear earphones were very nicely packaged. I guess if you have a name like Bose, with a premium price on the product, you must create this expensive packaging to convince people the product is superior, or to let them know they really are superior. I see these are priced well over $100 so they should be well packaged, and they better be good.How good anything sounds is subjective. What I think is good others might have issues with. All I can do is say how they sound to me, and they sound very good. As soon as I took them out of the package I immediately plugged them into my Samsung Galaxy S3, played one of my favorite tracks. I was very pleased with the sound. It was almost shocking how good they sounded. The same music that I had been listening to earlier seemed to have more sound, more instruments, clearer voices. These earphones seem to cover a wide spectrum of sound evenly, good base, good midrange, and good highs. The sound is bright but not brash. The base is good but not overpowering. Even when I turned the volume up too loudly these earphones didn't sound over-driven. Very nice.The cord mounted controller can be used to increase or decrease the sound, and to pause or play, skip forward or skip back, on my Samsung Galaxy S3. You can also answer a call by pushing the center button on the cord. A nice improvement for me personally as the Apple EarPod cord controller does not communicate with my S3. My only complaint about the SoundSport is the cord control is mounted too high, about 2" too high in my opinion. There is a cord mounted clip that can be repositioned. The clip will keep the cord from swinging away from the body when leaning forward.These are sold as In-Ear which I find is partially true. I have in-ear earphones that I use in very noisy environments such as an airplane. They cut off external sound by sealing off the ear canal from ambient sound. These have a soft silicone protrusion that fits in the ear but they do not cut out ambient sound. So they are partially in-ear.The earphones are sold with three sizes of the silicone portion that fits into the ear. In addition to the protrusion there is a silicone loop that fits in the folds of the ear holding the earphones in place. The whole thing is very comfortable. The driver portion of the Bose SoundSport protrudes enough that they won't be comfortable for me to wear in bed and lay my head on either side on the pillow. The Apple EarPods are much better for use in bed as they are quite a bit smaller. Obviously the difference in sound quality between the EarPods and these SoundSport is significant.There is a very nice soft zippered round 3" pouch included for storing the SoundSport earphones. The pouch has about a 2" carabiner which is a nice touch.The best complement I can give for these earphones is they make me want to listen to more music. These are the best sounding earphones I've ever heard. They are out of my price range though, I'm an under $50 earphone buyer.

I wasn't looking for a fast card, I was looking for a microSD card that was 32GB and cheap. It is going into a very cheap 9" tablet I just bought where high speed wasn't needed. This card surprised me. I paid only $11.99 for it on Amazon.com with free Prime shipping. Yet it tested to easily beat it's UHS-1 Class 10 minimum speed class requirement. So much the better.I did with this card what I do with all the memory cards I buy (and hard drives too). I ran a speed test on it using CrystalDiskMark 3.0.4 x64. The results were sequential read speed of 36.26 MB/s, and write speed of 15.75 MB/s. The packaging says Read speed up to 85 MB/s but that would be with a higher buss speed than I have. My interface is capable of up to 36.49 MB/s only. So this card may very well be capable of speeds faster than that which I can test. In any case it is fast, especially for the $11.99. It is also the least expensive (of the nine microSD cards I now own) per Gigabyte than I've ever paid for a microSD card, regardless of size or spec.I remember the early 1970's when we were waiting for semiconductor memory to fall to $0.01 per bit. The concept of a 1 GigaBit anything was beyond comprehension, and 1GB would have cost $10M which is pretty hard to swallow too. In the early 1970's I once paid (with company money) $7,500 for a memory card holding 288,000 bits of semiconductor memory, and that was a bargain as the price had recently been $15K. In the early 1980's I paid (with company money) $20,000 for 384 Mega Byte hard drive that took four strong men to carry into the building. This card only cost a ridiculous 37 cents per GagaBit, and if I drop it on the carpet I need a flashlight to find it.In many years of SD card use I've never had one fail so I expect this off-brand to be just as reliable. All of the non-volitle memory chips come from the same three factories around the world.Looking for a cheap but fast card? This might be the right one for you too.

Works perfect in our Prius. I plug this in, pair it with my 9" tablet. Run the Torque app, and can diagnose the reason our Prius has dropped from 45-47 mpg average down to only 35 mpg average. There are knock-off Bluetooth OBD2 units on the market for about 1/2 the price of this one from BAFX. I didn't want to take the chance of wasting my money so I bought this one and I'm glad I did.The OBD2 scan tool has some lights but I didn't pay any attention to them. All I wanted was for this unit to interface with the ODB2 on our Prius and transmit that information to my 9" tablet. The "Torque" app on my tablet does all of the real work by connecting up to this scan tool using Bluetooth.So far this tool has worked flawlessly. We leave it plugged in all of the time. Our ODB2 connector is under the dash and is located above the gas pedal. It is a bit long but it's not in the way and we don't notice it for bump into it.It was totally simple to use. I just plugged it in and it started working. It has stayed connected through Bluetooth without dropping the signal at all. All of the information that we set up on the Torque app is able to be delivered by this BAFX scan tool. I have no complaints.I highly recommend this BAFX tool.

This tube is the right size for my bicycle. I had a flat and noticed I had already patched that tube a few times. I used my spare tube to repair the flat, and then ordered this one to be the new spare.

We've had a Uniden system with 5 handsets for 15 years. The sound quality was great, battery life was great, but it simply wore out. We had to press the keys very hard to make them do their job. I took the phones apart and cleaned the contacts which used to fix the problem but that no longer works. So it was time for a new system. Unfortunately Uniden does not sell cordless phones in the United States any longer.The main things we wanted are a different list than many of the user reviews here. Our wants are simple. Basically we want the system to have the features of our 15 year old Uniden system.- Handsets with belt clips- Handsets with speaker phones- Handsets with backlit keys- Handsets with backlit information screens- Handsets with long battery life- Handsets with earphone jacks- Handsets with replaceable batteries- Handsets with a mute feature- Speed Dial- Long range- Good voice qualitySurprisingly there are a number of (non Panasonic) handsets out there missing one or more of the features listed above. Not only did this Link2Cell system have all of those features, it has a lot more. The best feature is people like this system as evidenced by the high ratings here on Amazon.com.One complaint, voiced by many others, is Panasonic really messed up the phone system design by forcing the use of numeric codes to access some features. An extended menu system without codes would be much better. With codes you must keep the user manual, search through it to find the feature you want to program, look up and enter the code on the phone. We have many electronic devices in the house, none of which require us to keep the user manual on hand to use the system. Panasonic should rethink this design.Some of the much appreciated features of this system are features we won't likely use including:- The answering machine- Bluetooth connection to our cell phones- The intercom features- Call blockingWe use an Ooma Telo VOIP system (less than $4/month). It has an answering machine with all the features we desire, so we don't need the answering machine of the Panasonic.I doubt if we would bother to link our cell phones to the Panasonic. We've not had that feature for years and we are happy to use our home phone and cell phones as is without linking them. If the system used WiFi instead of Bluetooth it would make much more sense to me. WiFi has a much longer range than the 30 foot range of Bluetooth. I do carry my smartphone with me at all times. There would be many times I would walk out of the 30' range of Bluetooth so the connection would be dropped. I'm more likely to be close to the cell phone than any of the five handsets. I did find it useful to transfer all of the contacts from my smartphone to the Panasonic system, but I then disconnected the phone from Bluetooth. I can certainly understand the benefits of the Bluetooth connection for those who set their smartphone down and leave it charging, then depend on the Panasonic system to make or receive calls.Our Uniden system has an intercom like the Panasonic but we've perhaps used it less than 5 times in 15 years. Those were times when one of us was confined to bed or were otherwise immobile due to medical reasons. We could have easily gotten along without the intercom. I do think it's a great feature for other households that perhaps are multi-level homes or very large homes.With our Ooma Telo system we simply do not receive robo-calls or other soliciting calls so the call blocking feature won't be used. We might get 4 or 5 of those types of calls a year.The Panasonic system, with 5 handsets, does match all of the features of our old Uniden system. The price wasn't too bad. The reviews are quite positive. The Panasonic system more than meets our needs. The handsets are significantly lighter than the weight of the old Uniden system, and the shape and size isn't much different than the Uniden handsets either.One improvement in the Panasonic system is the contact list is shared by all handsets. The Uniden system had a contact list per handset and it was a pain to keep them all the same.The Uniden has one very nice feature that I could not find in any other system. One of our Uniden handsets is submersible.  In a previous house we had a pool and spa so the submersible phone was ideal. In this house we have a Jacuzzi so we take that phone outside to that location too.Since no phone systems offer submersible handsets I am keeping the Uniden base unit for use with the one waterproof phone. I have daisy chained the Uniden and Panasonic base units and tested it. When I answer either phone system the other will stop ringing. We will toss out all of the other Uniden handsets that have begun to fail.My hope is this new Panasonic system will work as well, and as smoothly as our old system. I have every reason to believe it will.

Update August 5, 2015,I was pleased by the battery life today, the first day I've been able to use the tablet for an extended period of time. I easily got four hours of battery life, with 30% left when I plugged it in for a recharge. During that time I watched perhaps 20 minutes of video from various news services, Facebook, and Youtube. I loaded and tested several apps, read news stories, read and responded to youtube, read and responded to email. So, other than watching a lengthy video, pretty normal use.Batteries do "season" over the first 10 or 15 cycles (then they begin to deteriorate over the life of the product) so I expect to get even better battery life in the near future.The display is visible in 1/2 shade (not full sun but at the edge of full son) but by visible I mean I can see it if I work at it. It is quite usable in full shade, and actually quite bright indoors. Still the display is the weakest part of this tablet. As this is just a toy for me mostly, I won't be using it on a regular basis so it will fill my need and curiosity.I'm not a fan of tablets, but I do appreciate that the virtual keyboard on tablets is so much larger than my smartphone and I have much better accuracy typing on this 9" tablet than I do my smartphone. Swype does work on it and I've used it but it will take some getting used to the much larger keyboard while using swype.Original Review...I just received this tablet about two hours ago. It is the first tablet purchased for this house, although I am no stranger to high tech equipment.My first impression after taking the tablet out of the box is, "You get this for only $65!" There is little to suggest this tablet costs a fraction of a high end tablet. Sure it is heavier and thicker, but not so much that makes a big difference really. It has a nice non-slip back that doesn't show fingerprints. There is a screen protector on the front which I will leave on as long as it isn't a problem. I won't be buying a screen protector just yet. Turning it on I quickly see that the screen is a weak point.The viewing angle is very narrow, just tilt it 30 degrees in any direction and the screen does not look good. Holding it parallel to my face isn't perfect either. I find I have to hold it tilted slightly up and to the left for the best viewing angle, and even at the best angle the display isn't crisp and it seems a bit washed out. I can see pixels, but the small text labels for the apps are very readable. It's not horrible, it's not great, it's somewhere in between. I found the brightness a bit too bright for my dark living room and turned it down. Turning the brightness all the way down I found it was a bit too bright to use in bed next to my sleeping wife. I'm sure I can find an app to cut the low end brightness. Is the screen usable. Yes.The touch screen sensitivity is perfect. It seems to be accurate. One bonus of the 9" screen is I can type better on the virtual keyboard than I can on my smartphone. The tablet also supports swiping on the keyboard which is a big help. I have a couple of Bluetooth keyboards which might come in handy with this tablet. I bought them for use with my phone but it seems silly to carry a keyboard 4X the size of the phone so I don't use them.On the right side I find a small hole which is the microphone input, a Back button, the micro USB charge port, HDMI port, earphone jack, a reset hole, and the power button. All are labeled on the back of the tablet. A 2 Amp charge brick and five foot long USB cable came with it. They also included a 6" USB cable but it has a female connector on the end which I'm not sure what it would be used for. On the back is a microSD card slot.I didn't pay much attention when I bought the tablet so I was surprised to learn there is a front and back camera. Neither one is very good. I don't plan to walk around with a tablet taking photos anyway so no big deal.PLAY STOREAt least one other reviewer said there was no Play Store app on the tablet. There is. Touch the up-arrow in the lower left corner of the display to bring up a bar along the bottom of the display. Then in the lower right corner there is a "More" button. Clicking the More button brings up a screen full of apps, one of which is the Play Store. Touch and hold the Play Store icon, then drag it to the bar along the bottom so it is easy to access the next time.I used the built in Browser to load the Chrome browser, then I moved the built in Browser to the list of apps in the More screen. That way I won't even see the built in browser. Yes the built in browser started showing ads along the bottom but I could just ignore them. Now with Chrome installed I won't have to be bothered by those ads.The tablet easily connected to my WiFi router. Just to try the Bluetooth I connected my little Bluetooth speaker and played a youtube video which worked fine with the sound coming from my Bluetooth speaker. It sounded great. Actually the Jay Leno's Garage video looked pretty good too. Turning off the Bluetooth to return to the internal speaker the sound was hollow, tinny, and not as good as either of my smartphones. Usable Yes but not great. The volume on the internal speaker was good enough for a quiet room.Trying the FM radio I plugged my earphones in. I did a quick search for a station and it worked as expected. I can also leave the earphones plugged in to act as the FM antenna, and then switch to the built in speaker or Bluetooth speaker. We don't get many FM stations here and I usually listen using the Tune-In internet radio app.Using the Maps / GPS was much more interesting to me. To be able to use this WiFi only tablet in the car for turn-by-turn directions I downloaded the excellent Nokia Here app with it's free offline maps.Everything went as smooth as silk. I now have a map for all of California loaded, and I have not yet inserted a microSD card. I can find nothing that indicates this tablet actually has GPS built in. I'll have to prove that by using it for navigation away from the WiFi of the house.SPEEDWell this tablet is no speed daemon, but it isn't all that bad. Just browsing or going through the actions to download apps there are some delays but that's just it - some brief delays. I can't say the speed is quick, or too slow, it is acceptable.I'm finding that if you take a cheap but reasonable tablet and run Android on it you have a lot of features and software available.Now to get down to the real reason I purchased this app. We own a Prius Generation II. The car has 152K miles on it and we've had it since it was new in 2008. Our average MPG over these 7+ years is about 45-47 mpg. Recently it dropped to about 35 mpg. Now 35 mpg isn't bad for most cars but it sucks in a Prius. I took the car to the Toyota dealer but all they did was look for engine codes and test drove it 7 miles; both of which I had already done. That was a waste of money.I purchased a Bluetooth ODB2 adapter for the car to broadcast data from the car to my smartphone. Then I purchased the Torque Pro app which has tons and tons of data that can be displayed. The trouble is the car has 14 banks in the High Voltage battery and there is more than one parameter that can be displayed per bank. Very quickly I ran out of screen space on my smartphone. Torque also wants to work with a GPS, although I don't think that is important for my needs. So I went looking for a tablet for more screen space. Let's see the vital Air 9" has a lot more screen space, GPS, it has Bluetooth, it runs Android, and it is amazingly only $65! Wow that is a winner.Tablets have been on the market for years but I've never bought one. I just didn't see the need or usefulness of them until this particular application. They won't fit in my pocket like a smartphone, they don't have a keyboard so in that respect they aren't better than a smartphone. But for this price I can swallow that pill.Two to Four hours of battery life isn't very exciting but I can live with it. I hope it is reliable.I'll come back here for an update if I find anything interesting to add.For $65 I can recommend this tablet. It is sort of okay in several areas, rather than good, but okay in this price range isn't bad at all. So far I'm pretty happy with it.
I have several RAM mounts. They are all heavy duty, work very well, and are reliable. I've attached this ball to the back of a cell phone holder so I can use it on my motorcycle.
Much stronger than Velcro. Even the sticky back is much better than Velcro brand.

It's summer and NCIS is taking it's break. We are starved for episodes so we've purchased seasons 1 through 10 so we can use them to fill in over the summer.We've been binge watching only NCIS one or two episodes per evening. We are stunned by the number of episodes we can't remember watching, or that we actually missed over the years. In many ways it is more fun watching the second time through than the first because we know the characters so well.Great acting, directing, stories.

As far as my wife and I are concerned there simply isn't a better TV show on the air past or present as good as NCIS. The humor plays a huge part in our enjoyment of watching the show. The episode scripts are varied and interesting. The acting is first rate, as is the direction.NCIS is just the best.

Mechanically this socket is fine. The wire is heavy gauge, the socket works well, and the cap stays in place. I mounted this on my motorcycle, attached to a key switchable 12V power source. I have RAM mounts to be able to mount my Garmin GPS, Nokia smart phone, or Samsung Galaxy S3 smartphone.Plugging the Garmin into the charge socket seemed to work perfectly.Plugging the Nokia Lumia 635 smart phone worked but the phone reported it was connected to a "slow charge" port. This didn't make sense because the motorcycle 12V source is rated at 2 Amps, and this 12V to 5V converter socket is rated at 2.1 Amps. That should be plenty for the Nokia to be rated at full charge.Plugging the Galaxy S3 into the socket shows a red X on the battery icon of the phone. A red X indicates again a Slow Charge. What really worried me was when I saw the red X I thought the phone was damaged because I had never seen that red X before. I took the phone into the house and plugged it into a known high power source and it still showed the red X. I was very concerned that the charger socket permanently damaged my phone. The good news is later that evening the red X went away and the phone seems to be working normally.All indications are that this charger isn't putting out the advertised 2.1 Amps. I'm not sure if the charge will be able to keep up with the battery drain if I use my smartphone as a GPS.I will report back on the results when I have an occasion to use this charge socket for an extended period of time. At the moment all I can give it is 3 stars.

I previously used Velcro to attach a small gauge to the steering column in my SUV. The hook and loop held okay, but the glue did not withstand the heat. The Velcro strip would shift and left a glue mess on the steering column.I used the same size strip of this Scotch 5731 Outdoor fastener which works much better. Not only does the glue on the back side of the fastener work well in the heat, but the way the product locks together is much  more solid than Velcro. My small gauge now both stays in place, but it is also rock solid rather than the rather loose feel of Velcro.Velcro is fine for many applications but where I need something stronger, or able to withstand heat I will use this product.

When I purchased my first (and only) GoPro Hero 4 Silver camera I didn't think I would need or want a camera case like this. Little did I know how many little pieces of attachments and options are available for these cameras. There are remotes, clips, tethers, batteries, SD cards, suction cups, tripod mounts, frames, microphones, lens covers, battery chargers, and more. The list goes on and on. So I did learn that I'd need a case, or rather more than one case.Like the other options there are many cases available. Cases to hold more than one GoPro camera, cases large and small, internally adjustable cases, fixed format cases, shoulder cases, travel cases, and dozens more.I now have three cases, one for a whole pile of GoPro attachments and accessories, one for longer trips like one week vacation trips, and this smaller case for day use. You're not likely to carry your small tripod in this case, unless it is a very small tripod. But you certainly can fit the camera in it's waterproof case, a couple of batteries, a couple of mounts, a battery charger, some memory cards, a tether, and a few more small items.Case Logic makes quality products. I have several Case Logic cases for my four digital cameras and they are all top quality. This case measures roughly 9" x 6" x 3". It has one of my favorite features which is dual zipper pulls so it can be zipped from either side. I like to zip from both sides so the zipper pulls meet in the middle (yes a bit obsessive compulsive).There is good padding all around, about 1/4" thick on the top and sides, but the bottom is thicker with a very firm rubber like construction.Inside there are four compartments as it comes from the factory. There are three dividers, one which is the full width, and two which reach from the back to the center where they meet the full width insert. These dividers have Velcro on the ends so they can be repositioned, but I would say the amount of adjustment is limited.  I'll include a few photos showing what I mean.This case has a hand strap, not a shoulder strap. There is a thin zippered pocket in the lid which is about the full size of the lid. There are also four mesh pockets for small items such as memory cards.So if the selection of things you want to bring along for a day will fit into this space then this case would be a great option. That is exactly what I'll use it for to keep my GoPro items together and safe.

Aug 15, 2015 UpdateI had a warranty issue and contacted Contigo. There was a problem with the top. They sent me a whole new water bottle and top. Great service. This is the kind of service that brings me back.Original Review...I bought a two pack like this today at CostCo. I already own a Contigo Autoseal West Loop Stainless Steel Travel Mug which I have been very pleased with but I bought these mostly for the handle, and a different color.1) This has a flip up handle that makes it easier for me to carry. The West Loop requires me to grip it in the narrower portion which can get tiring.2) My previous water bottle is black which gets so hot in the sun that I can't handle it. I selected the silver (there being no white model) hoping that it will be cooler to the touch in the sun. I put my water bottle between the handlebars and the windscreen on my motorcycle where it is easy to drink from at a traffic signal, but it is also in direct sunlight most of the time. I wish Contigo made a white model.3) The mouth of the Contigo Autoseal West Loop Stainless Steel Travel Mug is just a bit larger. The size of the ice cubes from our refrigerator door front dispenser tend to clog up at the opening of this new bottle.4) The button to open the drinking port is larger on the Contigo Autoseal West Loop Stainless Steel Travel Mug which is about 2 finger size. I'm sure I'll get used to this smaller button.These Contigo water bottles keep water cold for many hours. They are leak-proof, and they don't have condensation on the outside. Any negative comments I have made should be taken in the context that they are just very minor. I just wanted to inform others who my potentially be comparing these two models.Pros:- Keeps water cold for many hours. I often leave the Contigo on my desk at night when I go to bed, and in the morning there is still ice in the bottle.- Quality is top notch with Contigo.- The one hand operation, using the button on the back side, is simple and works well.- No straw to deal with, lose, or to go bad.- Cap can be used to cover the drinking port to keep it clean. The cover can be permanently kept in the open position.- The handle smartly clicks into the closed position so it doesn't swing freely when not in use.Highly recommended

High quality materials make this a nice looking bench that I expect to last for years. The powder coat paint on the metal looks like a heavy coating. I don't know what the Faux wood is made of but most of these new manufactured products hold up very well. Our bench will always be in the shade so I don't expect any fading of the Faux wood.It took me about 45 minutes to assemble the bench. It would have been more like 20 minutes with help but I did this while my wife was away.Everything was nicely packaged and labeled. Two tools are included, not as good as our own tools in the garage but I actually did use the little wrench for all of the nuts. The only improvement I would recommend to the company is for bolts with a hex head rather than a Phillips head for the seat and back. I felt the Phillips head screws were a bit hard to drive given that the nuts are of the lock tight type.The swing action is a bit short, not like the bench we replaced which would swing much further.If desired you could leave the swing portion off and just use this as a fixed position bench.It's a nice bench for a decent price.
Fit my Yamaha FZ-07 motorcycle perfectly and it looks exactly like the original. It only took about 5 minutes to install.If you need a lever I highly recommend this one for your FZ-07.
This mount fits the Garmin 1350 perfectly. Be aware that it does not come with the RAM ball on the back; that needs to be ordered separately.

Case Logic makes high quality bags and backpacks. This KDH-101 is right in line with the high quality I've come to expect from Case Logic. I already have a Case Logic camera case similar to this KDH-101. The one I have has two pouches on the side large enough for a small tripod or an extra lens. It's a nice case but I rarely use it because it is too large. That is why I accepted this bag from the Vine program. I try not to accept anything from Amazon Vine unless I intend to use it. I was pleased that my standard configuration of camera, lens, and hood fit so well in this bag.This bag is padded on all sides, bottom and top. It is not too thick, keeping the bag dimensions small, yet it provides good protection for a day carry bag.The shoulder strap is gratefully long. It adjusts easily and stays in place after I adjusted it. The clips on the end of the shoulder strap swivel. There is also a substantial hand strap on top of the bag.The bag is designed to fit against the body, with a firm flat surface on that side making it comfortable. There are three pockets on the sides, but no pocket on the side against the body so no zipper or zipper pull to irritate. The three small pockets on the sides and front are small but sufficient for a couple of lens filters, SD cards, and an extra battery or two. The zippers all have a metal pull but there is a small black strap threaded through the pull which allows for an easy comfortable grip to open or close the zippers.The top of the bag opens away from the wearer which is great so the flap isn't trying to close as I am putting the camera in or taking it out of the bag. My one and only complaint about this bag is there is a single zipper pull for the zipper which goes 3/4 of the way around the bag. I would prefer two pulls as are so often available on zippers. First that would make life easier for both right and left handed users. Second I would prefer to pull from both sides, closing the zipper in the middle. That's just a habit of mine.Inside the top of the bag there is another small zippered pocket, again perhaps large enough for a couple of SD cards in their plastic containers.The inside business part of the bag opening is roughly 5 1/4" wide (a little wider at the side nearest the body) x 5". The depth is 9" close to the body, and 8" where the top flap is hinged. That is just about perfect for my camera, with my walk-around lens, and the lens hood attached. My camera from the rear edge of the view finder to the outer edge of the hood measures 8 1/4" so it fits great. My camera's body is 5" wide.The bag is advertised as a Zoom Holster bag. That is a pretty loose term as there certainly are a wide variety of sizes of zoom lenses. I have one that definitely would not fit in this bag, even without the camera body attached! So pay attention to the dimensions. My camera is a Sony A65 mirror-less model. It tends to be smaller than many other cameras. The average DSLR camera body is larger than the Sony A65. I don't have the width of those cameras but anything over 5 1/2" may not fit.One of the main features of the bag is that it has a suspension, or hammock, system. It consists of a cloth insert Velcro'ed to the sides of the case. There is a hole in the middle of the insert with three neoprene flaps. You drop the camera in, the lens pushes the flaps back slipping through, and the body of the camera rests against the cloth insert. With the insert adjusted properly, if the lens isn't too long, the camera will hang inside of the bag. The lens won't touch the bottom of the bag. Great system. The 16-50mm f2.8 lens I am using as an example is a large lens. Adding to that is the lens hood. That combination on my camera makes it a little harder to push the hood and lens through the bag's insert. Then pulling the camera out of the bag the lens and hood tend to catch a bit on the hammock insert as well. The average lens and hood are likely smaller making those operations easier.I will use this bag. That will allow me to have my hands free until I want to take photos. It is a good addition to my camera equipment.The 48 second video at the top of the product page is quite good.

We've had one of these for four years. I'm not sure if it's still waterproof but it is otherwise in very good condition. I guess I should treat it with some 303. Any cloth will give up it's waterproofing after 4 1/2 years in the California sun.This is a heavy duty cover. In fact ours can almost stand up on it's own when we take it off to use the grille. It has kept our grille looking almost like new all these years.I highly recommend this cover.

I actually ordered this, then quickly cancelled it. I realized if I attached it to my camera the cloth would not reach the lens for cleaning unless I detached it from the camera. Too much trouble.I'd rather the cloth be detachable. When I realized the cloth is attached to the bag I cancelled my order.
I've had one of these for over a year. The top keeps coming open. I finally lost the cleaning cloth. I'm here on Amazon looking for an alternative product.

My wife and I think NCIS is the best TV program ever put on the small screen. We, of course, watch every new episode during the regular season. But to fill in the summer we've been buying the NCIS season DVDs and watching between 7 and 14 episodes per week. They are even better the second time.Watching the second time over is great because we know the characters and longer term story lines already so we can appreciate little things that may have escaped us the first time. Following almost every episode one of us declares, "This is a really good show."The mix of smart detective work, good story lines, excellent dialog, character interaction, and humor simply isn't duplicated anywhere else. We hope NCIS continues for at least 20 seasons.We never could get interested in NCIS Los Angeles, too much flash and not enough detective work, bad dialog, and poorly cast.However, after giving it a chance for several episodes, we really like NCIS New Orleans. We really like Scott Bakula. Lucas Black is good but I find him difficult to understand sometimes. I'm not crazy about Zoe McLellan.Back on NCIS every member of the cast is perfectly cast. Who doesn't love Abby. Ducky is wonderful. Gibbs sets a new standard for subtle while being right. Tony provides the comedy. Siva is great but I wish the director/writers would make use of her fighting capability more often. McGee does a great job as the technical guy and it's good to see him pushing back on Tony. McGee seems to be coming into his own in the later seasons.
Fits my 2006 Yamaha SX-210 twin jet (twin engine) boat fine. K&N has a good reputation. Having the hex bolt head on the top of the filter makes it easy to remove should it be installed too tightly.

July 31, 2015All we've found are a couple of dead cockroaches in the garage since we put these bait stations to work. We are pleased with this product.Original review...Seems to be working. We were shocked to find three 1 1/4" long cockroaches in our kitchen recently. We have a very clean house and have never seen a cockroach in any of our houses over the past 32 years together.We completely emptied our pantry, vacuumed out all of the shelves, and vacuumed under the refrigerator and stove. We then set out about six of these Dupont stations. The only roach we've seen since then is one on it's back dying on our garage floor. We can only imagine it is the Dupont station that caused this roach's death.We also put one station on our bathroom windowsill where we sometimes have a stream of ants. Since putting the station there we see about 2 dozen shriveled up dead ants on the sill near the station.

July 12, 2015All of the poison ivy bushes I sprayed with the Ortho 0475010 are DEAD. Now to wait over the next winter to see if they come back. This product works.July 8, 2015Well this product seems to be working. I sprayed five or six Poison Ivy bushes and they all appear to be about 30% dead. So far so good.Original ReviewWe received this product several days ago. The Poison Ivy bushes we have are down in a small canyon behind our house. The hill is quite steep and I'm reluctant to go down there. I finally gathered the courage today.There are six poison ivy bushes down the hill. We've tried killing them but they are very hardy. The two bushes we thought we had killed came back after a year. So I liberally sprayed all six bushes this morning. We'd like to be rid of them because from time to time we do go down the hill to fetch a ball, or to weed whack the growth as a fire prevention step.I am hopeful after reading so many good comments on this product. I will report back in a week or so telling of the success or not on our property.Three stars until something happens...

My boat cover sprung a leak over the winter. When I unfurled the Bimini it, along with some life jackets, the throwable, and ski flag, all had very visible mildew spots over large portions of their surface. I used this product liberally, waited, scrubbed with a brush... Nothing. There was no change whatsoever.I then returned to the hardware store and bought another product which worked in minutes with no scrubbing. Stay away from this product.I've used CLR for years with great success but this particular product does not work.

These HP printers keep getting smaller, better, and cheaper. The setup was a breeze. I barely had to look at the manual. And, happily, getting wireless printing going was not a problem. Switching from printing to copy mode or scan mode is simple and intuitive. I suppose being able to load more paper might be an advantage...but that's my only complaint.

I was really dreading pulling this out of the box. I have never used a range extender before, and the reviews on Amazon all made this one sound excellent except for one very negative review -- and that reviewer really sounded expert.Therefore, imagine my relief: this works wonderfully and was easy to set up. Streaming is so much smoother now and, based on my pacing around different areas, I think I have about 5,000 square feet of improved wi-fi and a good 2,000 where there used to be no signal. Following instructions was easy. I am sure that there are sophisticated ways to tweak this one way or the other to optimize results, but I was very happy with what I got doing the most basic installation.

I love this watch. As you would expect, being an Invicta, it is a high quality time piece.The design here is so bold and so...athletic. The watch is huge but it manages to look practical and sporty. It is not an effete and jewelry-ish watch. The main colors of black and gold are bold and perfect together. The leather band is rugged and has solid decorative and practical stitching. In fact, the whole thing looks incredibly practical.Of course, practicality isn't really the thing here. I don't care about the practicality of the three dials. I think they are there to direct the eye to the watch face. And, yea, ok, this watch doesn't light up or glow. I don't particularly care about that either.

They're fine.I love the colors and like the simplicity of the pattern. However, they're a bit small. And thin. And not too absorbent. I'd never pick these up at a store because I make a mess, and I need dish towels to be more substantial. These feel a bit more like napkins than they do dish towels.

I'm very happy with this product.Considering just how big and heavy this thing is, it is actually something that can be shipped to you without being unwieldy. Mine showed up in this rugged, strapped-together box with corner protectors that weighs about 175? 225? and is a rectangle that is about 5.5 feet tall. You can move it by yourself, but you have to bear hug it and stagger around a bit. Assembly was fine...time-consuming, but of course it takes time to assemble this thing, and the instructions are good.This is a very well-designed, classic bench which is carefully designed and of high quality. All of the welds, joints, fittings -- all the points of interaction -- are made of quality materials and appear to be carefully thought through. I think if I injure myself, it will be my fault and not because some flange is sharp or some element is poorly designed.The seat is great with just the right amount of support and just the right amount of comfort. I love the leg developer (such a dumb name) and getting it in place and putting it away is no hassle.

This appears to be a very well-designed, high quality unit which gives very uniform results! (By way of comparison, my only other experience with hydrators involved this admittedly janky and low-end unit...) You probably will be happiest if you have a dehydrating how-to and recipe book because the documentation that comes with this one is not terribly impressive.I like the fact that you can pick two modes to dehydrate foods. There is Fast and Raw. With fast, the unit quickly removes initial moisture by cycling about the set point. Then it automatically sets itself to the second and more thorough mode. The alternate mode, obviously, bypasses the intial step. There is some fan noise while the hydrator is operating, but it isn't like you are listening to the microwave.

This is the perfect Jerky for me. Reasonably priced, always the right amount of moisture, and big chunky pieces. I need a big salty hit of meat flavor and I get it from Jack Links Peppered. What I don't want is the imposition of some goofy, strong added, borderline chemical-y flavor...so the pepper flavor that is here is welcome. Happy customer!

This is a very warm, very soft blanket with a smooth yet cuddly surface texture. A few things:- the color reads as cream from a distance, but take a look at the pictures...there is this beige zigzag pattern- this thing is heavy at over 5 pounds for a Queen so if you like the feeling of some weight on you, this might be a good choice- I know there are some synthetic fibers in here, but it feels pretty lux and soft -- sort of like this pillow I have that has bamboo in it- If you are looking for something that isn't wool, but has that "real blanket not just some lightweight throw" feeling, this is it- This feels well-made enough that it won't be pilling or shedding on you

Tons of info here at a reasonable price! This is from Kaplan who I have valued in the past. No big surprise here, this book is all about the questions. You don't start out with theory. You start out with questions. And you get a ton of them. And once you settle down and really do, say, 30 or 40 in two different categories, you will automatically know where a lot of your strengths and weaknesses lie. I have to praise this book because the analysis of why certain answers were right or wrong in the quant section was really quite nicely handled.

There's a lot to like here -- it is very light, has a great look to it, and doesn't take any time to figure out. The balance between weight handled by the shoulder pads vs. weight handled by the hip strap is absolutely perfect. It arrives assembled which is nice. Apparently, my baby thinks it is very comfy since she has already fallen asleep in it three times in the past week.

This is a perfectly adequate For Dummies book that covers much of QuickBooks Online that is really much too advanced for the basic accounting functions we need. I found well over 50% of the book simply didn't apply to me. This might not necessarily be a problem with the book but might actually be the fault of my less-than-stellar skills.

An engrossing and satisfying family tale, this is the second book in Smiley's series and begins the 1950's. She seamlessly delivers character moments and family drama while interweaving the fates of her characters with significant moments in American history.

This a a fun, surface-y, and well-illustrated book. With a little cruising and skimming you could probably polish it off in 30 minutes. This is not a bad thing! There's a lot of basic information in here, perfect for a tween or teen who is ready to expose herself to different flavors of nerd culture. And those who are ready to move into deeper levels of geek, there's a lot of practical information about cons, cosplay, and media.The big question with a fairly brief book like this is -- does it have to be a book or would it function better online? In this instance, I wholeheartedly feel that this is a book. It is well-designed, punchy, and satisfying in this format. It is engineered for quick access to different sorts of info. It is leaf-throughable. It will happily sit on the foot of someone's bed for months and be picked up and referred to in a haphazard fashion dozens of time. So, yea, a book not a site.

This is a great, basic economy stroller.It has 439 fewer features than other strollers -- but with a retail price of below $80 with shipping (right now, at least) there isn't much to argue about. When it comes to a basic stroller, I'm interested in just a few things: how well does it handle?, how heavy is it?, is it sturdy?, is the carriage comfy, and can I fold it up without an advanced degree? This stroller does all of these things rather well! It handles nicely, pivots well, and has a pretty smooth ride. I can lug it around with one arm easily. The carriage -- so far -- seems comfy and secure. This thing seems rock solid! Finally, the folding apparatus is smooth and idiot-proof.These are my impressions after only a couple of days of use...maybe some other reviewers will be able to weigh in about how it holds up over time.Finally, I like the dots.

This is a tight and engrossing novella about a hitman and the internal gymnastics he must undergo to do the job that he has chosen. It is set in a very cold 1970's crime world and has much of the intimacy and darkness you would expect from Nesbo. That being said, this is a rather brief book and doesn't provide the sort of rich and enveloping experience that a longer crime novel can. If you wanted to, you could probably polish this off in one sitting, but that would deny you the opportunity to ponder some of the moral and psychological quandries the book puts forward.

Too weird to be believed, this is a surprisingly arresting true crime story. It provides all sorts of insight into things that I didn't know I cared about (South Korean and North Korean movies) and, perhaps most importantly, gives a portrait of Kim Jong-Il before he became dictator. This book demonstrates that part of being a show-man, having a producer's instincts, is part of the formula of success for a megalo-maniacal dictator.

If you are looking for a decent, no-frills, bed frame at a decent price, I think this is an excellent choice. This thing is solid. Really. I find it much more solid than those old 20th century rectangles on wheels designed to hold a box spring.Now there is no provision for a headboard or a footboard. Therefore, you're going to have to be creative if you want to incorporate one or both of these with this bed frame.As far as assembly goes, it took longer than I thought it would. Well over an hour of work. And it required a little strength. I think this is one of those jobs that is fairly easy with two people and sort of a headache with one person.The package is a pain to lug about. Long and heavy (40 pounds? 60 pounds?)

Anne Tyler weaves another spell-binding family saga -- this one a multigenerational tale.As one would expect in an Anne Tyler novel, the character work is exemplary, often taking precedence over the mechanics of plot. And her prose is a wonder: smooth, almost gliding, and gentle...deceptively gentle until it grapples with some truly unpleasant things. If this is, indeed, Anne Tyler's last novel, then that will be a loss to readers everywhere.

This is a peppy, intelligent, and well-structured introduction to providing customers with excellent experiences.Consistent with the 21st century's focus on fully-integrated customer service, this book is not simply a list of "things you should never do" and "ways to handle the angry customer." Sure, this sort of information is important -- and the book does specifically handle strategies for placating the angry customer -- but the thrust here is much more positive and proactive. For example, how one actually creates a customer-centric culture. To no one's suprise, this is a For Dummies book which means that it has relatively simple prose. However, I was impressed by the extent to which this book actually avoids the constant repetition of buzzwords and corporate-speak.I do, however, wish that the section on customer experience teams was beefier and had some more real-world examples.

This is my first exposure to an all memory-foam / no box spring mattress. I've come away very pleased. I'm a convert.To begin with the value is absolutely extraordinary. One hunk of foam, one surprisingly small package, one small price. No more box spring, no bulky coil mattress, no pillow top, no bells, no whistles, no bs-spouting mattress industry to deal with. I'm never going back.At first I found it a bit...weird. A different experience. However, I am sleeping better and I've got zero soreness. The memory foam does "hug" you a bit and moving around on it is...weird. However, I do find the foam cool. And this mattress works for me if I am sleeping on my stomach, my side, or on my back.

This is a quality product -- well-designed and attractive.- Putting it together was fine -- not super easy but not super annoying.- It is sturdy AND comfy.- The two little animal characters are adorable. Is that a big selling point?- The music is annoying, oh so annoying.- The vibrations and nature sounds are very relaxing.- The price is reasonable.- I think you could do a lot worse than this bouncer!

The basic idea behind the Manhattan Prep series of test-prep books is that you don't really need some 400 page monster of a book. Because, really, who actually manages to work their way through that many pages? Thus, what we have here is a book with some focus -- that looks at one set of skills -- and it does so with authority. I believe that the practice questions have value, but, of much more help was the part of the book which gave me test-taking strategies, tips, and which generally informed me of what sort of things I should expect.

This is somewhat high-priced coffee maker that makes an excellent cup of coffee. Perhaps it is the "blooming" feature that primes the ground beans with hot water before the dripping begins. Perhaps it is something else. But we're very happy with the flavor.Since this deposits the coffee in a thermal carafe, you don't have do deal with cleaning off the stupid burner or dealing with not-very-hot coffee. Very nice!I don't think this is going to win any design awards. This is a surprisingly bulky machine. Everything seems heavier or larger than it needs to be. Replacing the detachable lid on the water reservoir requires trial and error. They should have just hinged it. And the whole thing looks like a piece from a turbine from a factory in 1936. That might be a plus. I think it looks clunky.If you plan to launch your coffeemaker into outer space or if counter space is at a premium, look elsewhere. Otherwise, this is a well-made machine that delivers a tasty cup.

Initially, I was drawn to the "face Mom or face the day" feature -- that allows you to point the child fowards or backwards. Switching from one mode to the other is really quite easy. But, as it turns out, this stroller has almost never been used in the "face Mom" position. Oh, well.This is a basic, well-made stroller that is quite sturdy. It is big. But not big and bulky. I find it big and reassuringly solid.This thing is truly mobile...easy to handle, great at turning. When you're pushing it it feels like it weighs (almost) nothing. There are three positions for the main bar when you are driving...and this is a life-saver. Really gives your body some variety. Set-up was easy -- it literally is a process of just snapping pieces onto other pieces.

This headset fits the bill -- well-designed and comfortable with a high level of audio. It gives me what I want -- an immersive experience. I definitely appreciate the variable bass boost because a little bass goes a long way for me. I tend to value clarity in the sound over big sound and after a few adjustments, I found that this headset gave me just the clarity I wanted. A bonus was that setup was very easy.

This is a very well-constructed and practical over-view of gaming sound design. Logical and nicely organized, there is a little bit of information devoted to the history of gaming, but the majority of the book is very much about today -- including how you might get employment in the gaming industry.One of the core ideas in this book is a good one: applications and hardware will change. All the time. However, the process one goes through in game sound design is eternal. Thus, the book attempts to provide perspectives that won't be out of a date a year from now.

Great little cable at a great price. I've stepped on it twice and crushed it with a 25 pound book -- on the connectors! -- and no problems. I think it is well-made. Also, colored cables are a real time saver. If every cable is black, I have to stop and think. With colors, not so much.

I'm very pleased with this mattress pad.It is softer, fluffier, and more sturdy than many I have bought in the past. And there is this annoying thing with some beds where, no matter what you do, one corner of the mattress pad wants to pop off -- particularly when you are making the bed? Well, this mattress pad doesn't do that. The corners are well-made, the right size, and really "grippy."Is my bed really softer because the padding on this mattress pad is thicker? No. I can't say that. Honestly, I don't think that matterst to me. However, I'm really happy with the pad and it is a definitely quality product.

This is a splendid, detailed, intelligent, helpful, and beautiful book.The book itself is both beautiful and practical: a sturdy, square-ish, hefty thing with a strong binding. You can prop it open to any page -- even get a little rough with it -- and you will do no damage. The quality of the illustrations here puts earlier painting instruction books to shame. The images here are clear, vibrant and expressive. They're loaded with texture. They teach you stuff.However, the joys of this book are not merely those of layout or design -- this is a masterfully complete resource for working with acrylics. There are something like 50 "Technique Files" which show you in a very detailed fashion techniques you can use to produce certain effects. And the work here is highly acryllic-based, telling you what you should and shouldn't expect of this medium.

What we have here is a well-designed, cool-looking, headset where superb sound is matched by solid ergonomics. The comfort level is really high -- doesn't feel bulky at all. I'm generally a fan of blue & black so I like this color scheme a lot and, ok, this may be stupid but I like the way they glow. Set up was very easy. You get three modes with these headsets: Dolby 5.1, "Pure" audio, and immersive.

Creative, fascinating, and, on its own terms, comprehensive, this book takes you step-by-step through the robot conceptualizing and building processes. I'd characterize this a mid-range to advanced level book; it certainly isn't meant for beginners. The instruction here is structured so that you can either develop your own ideas or, for a more basic user, follow the plans to execute projects. There is a natural scaffolding built into the sequencing of this book, which takes you through processes and provides step-by-step reinforcement if you need it. I have to say that I agree with other reviewers that the lack of color images is a real drawback.

The first thing to set aside is the idea that Ian Caldwell's religious-based mysteries are The DaVinci Code Mark II. This is a different animal. Yes, there are plot twists, yes, the Vatican sits at the center of things, yes, "you can't put it down," but this is a much more measured, more literary, and less cliche-ridden novel. The pace is oddly deliberate at times. Caldwell is interested in much more than plot and takes time to explore his characters. Perhaps the most satisfying element of this book is that characters' decisions are examined from a moral perspective. And a great deal of research and thought seems to have gone into even the most page-turning suspenseful elements of this book.

A quality home theater system that yields rich and robust sound and particularly bright and satisfying highs.Bose apparently decided that it wants to create small-sized speaker systems that blow you away with how much volume they produce -- and the Cinemate 120 does not disappoint. Personally, I'm fine with big-sound-out-of-small-size, but what makes me very happy about this system is that it is only 3 pieces plus the remote. I think the days of 5 speaker systems might be ending.I've had Bose systems with an Acoustimas Module (a wireless subwoofer) before and there was one Bose characteristic that I thought was a problem -- a difference in timber or tenor between the sound coming out of the speakers and the sound coming out of the Acostimas Module. It wasn't as if there wasn't a mid-range, there was simply a difference in the "character" of the sound from the two sources; and, depending on set-up and where the listener was physically located, you could feel the different locations of different sorts of sounds. Well, with this Bose system I'm getting none of that. Everything sounds fully integrated. It is all one big, rolling highway of sound.

This is a well-constructed and lively book. The approach taken here is actively multidisciplinary -- what areas of knowledge that are not taste and smell impact the enjoyment of food? The authors cover visual design, a bit if color theory, the impact of light, and general restaurant interior design issues. Cultural contributors are considered as well.The tone of the prose here is expert and enthusiastic...clearly the intent was to release a book that would work for both culinary academy students and for the general public.

This is a very well-designed pillow that I will never sleep with. It is just too big and hard for me. There's no "squish" to it and it keeps my head up too high.Now I think it is a quality pillow with a nice big ridge on the top, a smaller ridge on the bottom, and an indentation where you can place your head. It is quite big and quite formidable. The memory foam that has a lot of resistance. I'm not certain if the holes in it actually cool the head at all.I have already tried using this pillow to hold my head up when reading. That might turn out to be of some value. But sleeping with it? No thank you.

The last time I read Alice Munro was... I don't know. Why on earth have I been denying myself the work of Munro, surely one of the great prose masters of our time? These are dense, well-crafted, stories that appear to meander, that appear to be full of the incidental, but which eventually reveal themselves to be astonishingly well-crafted. The work here is memorable, and adult. In terms of length, depth and authority, calling these short stories is inadequate. Perhaps they should be classified as novellas. At any rate, while I certainly could have collected these works myself, I was very pleased to have them in this one package.

Wonderful toy.My cat wouldn't play with it, but she is a special case.Simple design: some nice soft feathers on the end of a rod. The base is a ball. When turned on, the feathers move about on the rod in an irregular and tempting manner. Since the base is a ball, that moves a bit too. If the cat starts to attack, you get moving feathers plus a moving rod on a roll-y ball. Tons of activity! And there is NO ANNOYING MOTOR NOISE. Seems to me like a very safe toy.My cat won't hunt something like this. She needs her toys to be more animal-y. And she distrusts movement from any motor. However, I could see a lot of cats going nuts over this thing.

This is an adequate and well-assembled textbook. Published in 2013, it is still fairly up-to-date. CRC has taken materials from other CRC authors and combined it into this Reader which means that some of this data was collected long before 2013.This is a comprehensive, detailed, and somewhat uninspired collection. It begins with about ten pages of terrorism definitions and a brief history of terrorism. Then it has some list-y chapters outlining the different sorts of domestic and international terrorism. The book really hits its stride in two detailed and comprehensive sections: a detailed examination of the structure of terrorist organizations and a discussion of terrorist organizations' Attack Cycles and general modes of operation.While much of the prose is adequate, this book does provide rather wide coverage of the topic and will certainly be of use in a number of college courses.

This book gave me just what I wanted. I wanted a comprehensive and scientific look at teenage brain development with an accessible tone. Jensen's book is full of science -- real science --  but is aimed at the general reader. The tone is a little breezy but still authoritative. This author wants to communicate and does so with aplomb. Teenagers are fascinating and aggravating. They're conundrums! This book goes a long way towards explaining why this is the case.

This is a well-priced, efficient, decent all-in-one printer. And you know what? This is a heck of a lot of printer for not a lot of money.All I care about, really, is: 1. Is Setup Easy? 2. Is Operation Easy? 3. How much space does it take up? Setup was veeeeeery easy. I barely had to look at any of the documentation and did not have to access the manual. Printer started working with my laptop running Windows 8 instantly. No fuss, no problems.Operations easy as well. Don't have to think to do basic stuff.This takes up A LOT less space than the last two Canon printers I bought. I mean, it still is a heavy bulky little monster, but the footprint is nice and small (for a cheap printer.)Now, heads up. There is one reviewer who says that this printer burns up ink quickly. I don't know if that is or isn't the case with this one yet. So be advised. That would be really bad.

There's an excellent collection of recipes here, covering a wide gamut. Another reviewer touted the strengths of the Herbed Hummus recipe and we tried it -- it is superb. Rich, savoury, and with lots of brightness as well. The Peach Yogurt Quick Bread sounded good and is good with a very nice interplay between the sour yoghurt and the sweet fruit. We have yet to journey into any of the flour mixes, but I think this might actually be the most important part of this book.

I love this thing.In certain parts of the house, I can listen to podcasts or music if I blast the sound system. Really blast it. But this never works if I am doing dishes and the cat hates it when it gets too loud. And sometimes I just get sick of the earbuds. Too insular.This speaker -- efficient, well-designed, and adorable -- solves all these problems. Simple bluetooth device. Played out of the box for me in about 90 seconds. It is water-resistant, has a big hook which allows you to hang it or prop it up. The sound is great. It is basic sound. Great volume for up to 15-25 feet away, very nice middles, decent lows, not much highs. You can play sound engineer by placing it up or near different surfaces. That's your graphic equalizer.And it looks like a...speaker...from 1961...with cool highly-integrated buttons. I love all the design elements.Really, I cannot believe I lived on earth for so long without having one of these.

This book isn't encyclopedic. However, it is huge. Also colorful, punchy, kid-friendly, and graphic. Really, really graphic.And, happily, it is chock-full of real science: it consists almost entirely of big two-page spreads on a certain topic of human biology. For example, the skin is Body Armor. The stomach is an Acid Bath. There are a lot of lovely illustrations with excellent color and quite a bit of texture and detail. In other words, this is an illustrated book -- it isn't just a bunch of info-graphics.This book is designed to appeal to a wide range of ages. Early readers can use it as a picture book.
