Middle-school kids could find content in here to use on reports or presentations.Did I mention that it is really big? I think the size and pure graphic audacity of this book are part of the appeal! Honestly, I can't see how this book would stay closed very long if it were left in a room full of kids.

Easy to set up, easy to use, nice small size -- a very nice piece of work.The sound quality is about 10 times better than I need and the quality of image in dim lighting is superb (go infrared!) Battery life is terrific: over three hours (and that is if you're using everything at once.)Pan and tilt works perfectly with some ergonomically-pleasing controls. It is fun to play with.There are lots of features here which I'll never use. The thermometer? Really? On a baby monitor? No thank you. Couple of small complaints: recharging took us over 10 hours! But you can use it while you're recharging. As far as range goes, in our house we were out of range at 150 feet.Cuteness Factor: 8.75 out of 10 It has a very cute, space-age mini-robot-y feel to it.

Small, intelligently-designed, easy to set up and use...this is a quality baby monitor.The sound quality is good enough and the quality of image in dim lighting is really quite extraordinary. Not grainy or security-camera-y at all! The batteries last a long time. The zoom is excellent. Everything about the design of this product is intelligent and user-friendly.There are lots of features here which I'll never use: play the baby one of 7 (5?) lullabies? No thank you. Set up 4 cameras and look through all of them at the same time? Crazy. Well, if I ever have 4 babies in 4 different rooms.I think the only thing you'd need to figure out is if this price is competitive with other comparable products.

Quite a good value here -- a nice big set of knives at a reasonable price. I really appreciate the fact that the knife block is designed to hold the knives while not taking up too much space. It is made to do a job, not to look impressive. These knives are not top of the line -- they just don't have the weight or the heft of higher end stuff. However, I like the grips quite a bit and the knives are very nicely-weighted. The bread knife feels particularly good.These would make a great gift for someone who is setting up a kitchen for the first time.

This is a well-built and easy to use solar charger. Genuinely plug and play. Not having to plug it in is, obviously, a plus. The whole thing is sturdy and the glass is heavy. Rugged construction! The convenience makes it well worth the cost. Pop it in sitting on the dashboard and leave it alone. No more having to worry about a dead battery.

We've been a Miele vacuum family for a long time. This vacuum has everything I would expect from Miele -- powerful suction, well-designed attachments, and a light weight. Somehow Miele keeps managing to make their vacuums lighter and lighter without losing functionality! It is also remarkably quiet.Here's what I don't know and here is what you might want to fiture out -- this is, essentially, a $600 vacuum. Is it really $200 better than the cheaper-priced Miele S-series models?

The Femen -- once of Ukraine, now apparently based in France -- are a small collective of performance artists/rabble-rousers who want to re-make the world. This is no exaggeration! They aim not simply at generalized issues of women's rights, but at large targets. They wish to topple dictatorships, change the lives of marginaized women sex-workers, and undermine religion, and . Their starting point in simple -- the woman's body. For them text, confrontation, and nudity are one. This is a book by 4 young people which has ties to generations and generations of protest movements.

This is an eminently practical book. It tells young engineers what to expect in an interview and how to knock that interview out of the park. This is a near-perfect melding of the theoretical with the practical. Some readers will probably cruise through this book saying "oh, well I know emphasize that" or "I know that's important." However, Dorr's book expertly situates the knowledge and skills within broader frameworks, providing the ideal sort of undergirding for a novice engineer.

Burdened with a really rather dreary subtitle -- "Seven Principles for Business Transformation" -- Wackman and Stutsman's book is a brisk, intelligent, and inspiring look at functional aka vertical integration. There are certainly some buzzwords tossed about here, but for the most part this book admirably combines the theoretical with the practical. And it is NOT simply another book about embracing the digital. What is demonstrated here is how (just about) every aspect of a company can enrich the consumer's brand relationship.

Pierce's perceptive and sensitive book identifies and defines the older and more traditional governance models which are increasingly unsuited to 21st century. She essentially believes that the older "shared governance" models are stodgy and moss-grown. They reinforce institutional norms and are particularly ill-suited to more dynamic periods of change. And this is, indeed, a time of dynamism, Pierce argues: governmental doubt and lessened funding, the introduction of potential game-changers like online education, changing employment opportunities, for graduates, and a growing political distrust of higher education are all present. Governance Reconsidered provides opportunities for the stakes-holders (Boards, Executives, the Administration, Alums, Faculty, and Students) to streamline their approaches and pivot quickly while still retaining institutional identity.

Truly an impressive study guide. About 3 pounds lighter than the similar product from Kaplan, this LSAT Reading Comprehension guide is smart and (relatively) lean. The idea here is to give hints on how to use your innate reading comprehension skills AND how to tweak those reading habits to successfully and speedily navigate your way through the test.The initial part of the books is about reading and identifying key information in a block of text -- particularly the sort of argument-driven prose that exists in law (obviously.) To be honest, this part of the book didn't do much for me. I've always been good at this.The 2nd section was much more valuable to me -- it is about gaming the LSAT a bit by identifying question formats and using pat strategies. The 3rd section is a summation plus practice.

Intelligently-assembled and easy to use, I found this guide really quite helpful. It is structured into short little sections. It allows you to focus in on precisely the sorts of questions that you need to practice. And the explanations here -- explaining why a wrong answer is wrong -- take a lot of the mystery out of the LSAT. (The converse applies as well. Even in those instances where you pick the right answer, the book allows you to really zero on what factors contributed to the right answer being the right answer.) There's a whole lot of information to be had here for a reasonable price.

This is an intelligent and compassionate treatment planner that begins with 35 (why 35?) behaviorally-based presenting problems.This is, as you probably would expect, a desk reference. This book serves that role admirably. The overall structure gives you ease of access -- and it is rather remarkable how much information the editors have managed to include here. (The book's blurb claims that there are over 1,000 objectives and interventions.) And the book contains a great quantity of clinically-valid and insurer-friendly language. That is a time saver.Moving from the rich messiness of human behavior (and patient reporting) into the more structured world of goal-based care can be a daunting prospect. This book aids that process.

This book certainly won't provide you with the solutions to patients' problems, but it can be a great time-saver, offers quite a bit of structure, and is all drafted in clear and clinically-apt language. The authors should be credited for providing a planner that meets the requirements of the paying-entities (insurance companies) while still allowing the mental health professionals quite a bit of latitude in structuring treatment options and their outcomes. (There are literally hundreds and hundreds of interventions and outcomes from which to chose.) Formulaic? Of course. However, this book is never proscriptive and is intelligently structured.

This is both a history of one institution's (Virginia Mason) experiences implementing a program called Lean and a call for other health care providers to follow their lead. Thoughout the book, the theoretical is admirably buttressed by the real experiences of health care professionals, patients, and patients' families. And do not believe that the implementation of concepts from Japanese manufacturing which is described here means that the delivery of medical care is in any way less humane or compassionate! This book argues that substantial economies can occur side-by-side with improved, and even life-saving care. All in all, this was a largely jargon-free, clear, and inspiring book that (though a little inclined towards proselytism) could be a great help to those who administrate health care.

Lonely Planet continues to issue some of the best and most user-friendly guide books in the business. With the primacy of on-line ratings for things such as hotels, the lodging recommendations here are helpful but certainly not exhaustive. Honestly? I think books with hotel reviews are simply outdated.Some of the highlights here include:- a wonderful, big map of Dublin- very interesting and intelligently-assemble itineraries; if you are a big planner, these will give you a lot to chew over- pretty recent updating: the last edition was only two years ago- nice illustrations and a ton of smaller maps- an economical and eye-friendly layout that manages to cram a lot of info into a small packageThe following elements struck me as fine but not great:- history and cultural background of Ireland- surprisingly skimpy coverage of some of the southern counties

This is an incredibly detailed examination of the processes of analyzing data in biomedical research, specifically the methodologies employed to study patterns of gene activity. More generally, this is an up-to-date look at the sort of statistical analysis that occurs at the juncture of medicine and statistics with a particular interest in the steps that can be taken to identify correlative patterns among huge data samples. The authors state "Our focus is on the analysis part," explaining that data does not equal knowledge, particularly when dealing with experimental models that examine thousands of genes at a time. Nonetheless, developing computational, visual, and statistical tools that can be applied to microarray data is both the present and the future. Some of the analytics that receive a close look in this book are ABC clustering, biclustering, ensemble methods, and partial least squares.

This book is a highly professional, caring, and comprehensive examination of the ways in which services can be provided for individuals in the home environment. Stated very simply, the central proposition here is that those who need services in the home are best-served by multiple helpers -- professionals and non-professionals -- who collaborate.However, providing such care is rarely simple and the book embraces these complexities. There's an admirable mix of the theoretical and the practical here. The book provides broad perspectives and then elegantly narrows in on specifics. This isn't a book of "case studies" per se, but the authors recognize the human dimension in this topic and provide many vignettes of home-based services -- involving both care-receivers and their families -- that I found quite illuminating.A great deal of attention is paid here to visualizing, devising, and managing a "map" of services. And a map such as this will, over time, change, and the authors discuss the importance of adapting care to changing situations.The entire tone adopted here -- both in the prose and in the ways in which services are provided -- is positive and life-affirming. So welcome!

This little book is a series of essays that are particularly well-illustrated. The essays are all focused on the employment of incredibly accurate digital metrology technology in architecture and in, well, hypothetically any process that involves the manipulation of forms in three dimensions. While I welcome a detailed discussion of these methods in practice (with some theory thrown in for good measure), this isn't so much a "book" as it is a magazine. The essays are free-standing. The worst thing that can be said about the prose here is that it has a marketing/promotional/public relations tone. There's a fine line between praising a technology or a company and hyping it, and there's more than a little hype to be found here.Bottom line: if you want an update on some inspiring examples of high definition technology right now, pick this up. If you want a larger perspective, this "book" is not for you.

This well-argued little book paints a fairly bleak view of the efficacy of social movements and activism at this time. While there have been some incredibly powerful and well-covered activist movements (Occupy and the Arab Spring come to mind and one can certainly add The Tea Party to this argument as well), all fueled by social media, the results from these movements are lackluster at best. However, the pessimism that this book puts forward is not simply that of a social movement that generated more heat than results. Corporatization of activism is weakening the very core of that activism and the people on the front lines of the struggle lack the perspective to see their efforts within that larger picture. The book is to be commended for the fact that it uses actual "case studies" and wants to focus on specifics rather than couching the whole thing in theory or larger social science perspectives. Because of this, the book manages to be a popular read while still grappling with complex issues.

We're in the midst of an "arms race" of shaving technology. As a long-time user of Gillette products, the big question here is...Is this latest product (more expensive) an improvement from the previous iteration, the Gillette Fusion Proglide Power razor? I did a side-by-side comparison of two and concluded that I prefer the older power Proglide razor much more BUT that the newer blades ("our thinnest, finest razor blades") are indeed an improvement. Some thoughts about this new product, the Fusion Proglide Manual Men's Razor with Flexball Handle Technology...1. This is a remarkably ugly razor. It is a cross between a muscle car and R2-D2. This is the sort of product design that will appear comical to us in 30 years.2. The Flexball Handle really does flex all over your face. There's an awful lot of movement on this razor. I found I didn't like the sensation at all and it didn't give me any more control. (And I need control -- I shave my face really quickly.)3. I think the vibrating power razor is always superior and paying more for a non-power razor seems like a step backwards.4. The new blades really did have less drag than the older generation. Quite smooth and efficient.There are a lot of choices out there and a lot of excellent products -- many of them made by Gillette. This is, as I expected it to be, remarkably well-engineered and not cheaply priced.

Ching's classic book has been released in a new edition. In this fully comprehensive book, Ching demonstrates his ability to visually convey the complex inter-relationships that occur in every construction project.While I don't think the font and the coloring used in this new edition are horrible -- there is an appealing airy quality to the graphics here -- I do agree that what we have in this printing is less than ideal. The visuals here are just too light and make the eye work more than it should.

i fully expected this Ching book to be Ching-like: elegantly designed, sophisticated and yet crystal clear in the way that the visual information is presented. However, what is particularly strong about this book is that it can be used as a reference book while still possessing "narrative" qualities that allow it to be "read" from start to finish.What do I mean by this? The organization and layout of the book allow it to be used on occasion to answer a question or provide clarity on a specific issue -- therefore making it a reference. However, the sequencing of this book is very logical and pleasing in its own right. It begins with large and even somewhat abstract issues of design, then progresses into site-related issues, and then tackles very specific areas of construction. Thus, it pleasantly moves from the semi-abstract to the very concrete.As you might expect from a book from Wiley, it is well-designed and sturdily bound.

Ching's clear, carefully framed, and distinctive graphic style is used to great effect in this well-designed book. The framing of the images is excellent, only in a few instances did I think the information was a bit too over-exploded since the signature Ching vertices communicate a lot of information.It should be stressed that this book is very heavily-grounded in U.K. construction techniques. I imagine that many of the U.K. best practices carry over to the Continent but the book does not really address this issue. Thus, if you have don't have a a strong background in British building construction methods vs. other European schools of construction, the book may not meet all your expectations.

The last time I purchased a projector was about four years ago, so I expected this model would be an improvement -- and indeed it was. I'm no professional, but I have been very happy with just how strong, bright, and clear the images from this projector are. And the colors really pop while remaining true, to my eyes anyway, to the original source material.Factoring in a quite well-designed carrying bag and very easy setup and this turns out to be an excellent unit.

This is a comprehensive and intelligent book that delivers lots of information in a clear format.There's nothing revolutionary about this book: it is focused approach to Sketchup for interiors with a textbook-y feel and lots of screen caps. It devoted to teaching some very logical ways to "flow" through the program and, though I am no Sketchup expert, seems to cover an awful lot of material in not too many pages.I thought the sections on model furniture and things like cabinets were particularly well-handled. There are also something like 40 video tutorials (which I haven't looked at.)If you are already a SketchUp expert, then you probably don't need this book. However, the beginner and medium-level user will find a lot to love here.

Here is a beautiful book, full of inspiring illustrations, that demonstrates the close relationship between green technologies and beautiful design. This is comprehensive book that is not afraid of complexity.(I also liked the fact that it is ring bound and therefore is happy to be flat on the desk.)

This is a highly catholic approach to the relationship between architecture and drawing. It is not, per se, a book about architecture, but rather a book about how various ways of "drawing" (including computer-assisted forms) can be used as forms of expression. I was very excited to get my hands on the book and initially was pulled in by the general design and the many historical examples from a wide group of draw-ers. However, reading the book from the beginning was a bit of a slog.

This book is exactly what is advertised -- a straightforward, helpful, science-based, and fairly inspirational guide to achieving your goals. The illustrations are very helpful. The author doesn't give you a one-size-fits-all approach, but allows you a couple of possible routes you can follow. I thought the section on strength training was excellent (but I wish the coverage of body shaping was a bit more detailed.)

This is a high-flying and intelligently structured text. The R models are very useful indeed. One of the great strengths of the book is the manner in which advanced regression is presented -- both the explanations and the examples.

I found this to be a "classic" For Dummies book -- easy to use, nicely-organized, up-to-date. More importantly, it provides you with quick access to all the basics while actually containing content that isn't just beginner stuff.It can function as a reference book that you pick up on occasion or as a book you work through from beginning to end. It is also something you can chuck at one of your employees and say "read chapter 5."

This book provides, in a comprehensive manner, information about just about everything one would need to know to thrive in the business. Marketing, estimating, staffing, choosing product, design processes, safety regs, employee management, and how to stay abreast with the competition, choosing vendors, and more. This is all provided in a graphically-attractive and easy-to-use format bound in a sturdy book which will survive bouncing around in the back of a van. Not a cheap book, but it seems as if it would pay for itself in a thrice!

There are a lot of books out there about dyslexia and other sight-related comprehension handicaps but this little book appears to have touched a chord with many readers. While it is certainly designed for use by teachers and administrators, it seems to me that the primary audience is parents of students with dyslexia (or other family members or friends with a dyslexic about whom they care.) This is an eminently practical book that explains complicated concepts with ease and which is loaded with information about the sorts of strategies to help dyslexic learners learn.

This book is a model of clarity and efficiency.Zeynep Ton looks at a complicated system -- the connections between how employees are utilized and the bottom line in a retail setting-- and draws some simple and elegant conclusions. As you've probably already figured out, the principal conclusion is that intelligently investing in employees increases profitability and organizational health. This book elegantly persuades the reader that a capitalistic system need not suck an employee dry -- that intelligent "care and feeding" of employees helps a company thrive. And while we might be accustomed to hearing this when the employee is, oh, say a graphic designer or an IT specialist, viewing less skilled employees as real organizational assets is refreshing. Finally, I was so pleased to see that the balance between theory and practice (great case study examples!) in this book is superb.

This is an excellent and thorough program for whole novel teaching. I was impressed by the wise balance here between teacher-direction and student centering. The book presents a very step-by-step approach, but I believe that a lot of the strategies and methods in Sacks' book could be used within a teacher's pre-existing modes of teaching. This book is probably most valuable in that it is contained and focused.

This book takes a long-range historic view of how societies of different types adopt and inculcate it. It is part history lesson and part analysis of dynamic and static systems. The author has certainly done his homework, but I found both the prose and the less-than-ideal organizational structure made me reluctant. At times I felt I was working my way through this book rather than experiencing it.

The "organizational drift" in the title of this book is carefully plotted by author Mandis as a drift way from values towards an environmental where "can it be construed as being legal?" becomes the primary question. Mandis is an academic who did substantial research for this book, but he also shows his skills here as, well, simply as a storyteller. The prose here is engaging and brisk and I respect the fact that he managed to avoid turning this book into a 450 page paving stone.

While there's substantial theory underlying this book, it struck me as being extremely practical. In a multiple teacher environment... Who does what? When do they do it? How might they do it? (And what should be avoided!)I was pleased that this book looks beyond the boundaries of special ed, considering all sorts of situations in which more than one teacher is driving the bus. This is a lively book that is certainly not a slog to work through.
My wife loves her husky socks, and so does my Siberian!  Nice light cotton for summer days at the dog park.

This is another in the series of books on cutting edge physics of the future and how we might arrive there in the next few hundred years. Michio Kaku is a professor of physics, and has the ability to present surprising  information about cutting edge research that has not found its way into the popular media. Kaku is a well published author of several other books that would interest those who want to look into the near future with a first rate mind. Kaku deals with ESP,  telekinisis, remote viewing, and many other topics of interet to science buffs. Highly recommended.

Kondo's suggestions are very practical and quite different trhan most of this genre. Smacks of zen, but without any new age connotations. There is a reason why this lives on the Bestseller lists for so long. A very interesting read on many levels.

This is an excellent product. I only use it to keep my beard in trim, and the shaving heads supplied are good for ear hair, nose hair, (ahem, not that I have any use for those functions) and trimming of the head. Set the beard trimmer at "7" and wqork your way down to "5" or so and you will likely find your setting.

Interesting tale of one person's experiences on the strange and legendary Skinwalker Ranch. While you may have to suspend disbelief, it is an interesting story for fans of the unexplained. Nothing gross, and just possible enough for you to find yourself searching for an explanation.

OK, the font is way too small, but given the amount of information included in this effort, and the utility of having a one page guide to the new OS, I have to give it a pass. As a "Quick Reference Guide ' it dies the job, ordering just the essential information in an orderly fashion and in the sequence in which it is needed. Would it have been too much to ask to give us two pages? I think not, but I found this useful as long as I have my trusty magnifying glass by my side. The irony is that this would have been great for seniors if it were in large print. If a senior, try Windows 10 For Seniors For Dummies.

Gary Zukav has presented us with a deeply moving exploration of the limitless boundaries of human consciousness. Having recently lost a loved one, I found a great deal of comfort in this book, and recommend it for anyone in the stages of grief. Above that, I found his view of human consciousness intriguing.
Nice to have finally a set of apps specific for Kindle Fire and easily accessible. The Kindle Fire is a nice tablet, and not Amazon specific.

All of the "For Dummies" books are well done, but going from Windows 7 to Windows 10 is a bit of a leap for me because although the new OS is very user friendly it is a new look and feel. The breakthrough here is that this new system is a big step in the direction of a full touch interface. The problem is the flexibility; those of us who are not computer savvy can easily activate functions that we do not understand and may find it difficult to return to the original state. This book has features such as large print and many clear illustrations, and most will find it a most helpful aid in setting the desktop up and making some choices about this versatile operating system. I really like the "to do this, do that" approach.

An excellent and detailed introduction to all of the background events presented in the series. A groundbreaking story on many levels, this guide will enable the viewer to understand the greater context of this complex story.

This book fills a gap in the general discussion of Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security as it addressesthe real world problem that lurks just beyond the reaches of insurance and Medicaid. Given that one maybecome sick and require treatment is the focus of Medicare and Medicaid, but whatever the treatment, theresulting  problem of survival during treatment over the long term for perhaps decades is a very practical one.This book explores the various possible combinations of solutions to the problem of long term treatment andliving arrangements.

While the coverage of Part D is broad and in-depth, the book was published in 2008, almost seven years old.Obviously this prevents coverage of ACA related questions...a real problem. The topic is one that needsexplanation but must be edited for current information.

This well designed book provides in-depth coverage of a complex subject. Medicare provides coverage for many medical conditionssubject to a variety of circumstances. This book is the top seller in this topic at Amazon, and a quick look at the Table of Contentsdemonstrates why. Comprehensive and well explained.

Well organized reference book that covers all aspects of the SS Program. A handy reference for those who dispair of ever fully understanding the complexities of the program. Useful reference for those situations when you really want to check on something right now and don't want wade through a lot of extraneous material. You would be unlikely to actually sit down and read this book like a novel, but perfect for those times when you need an answer.

As a volunteer at a senior center who assists other seniors with some computer basics, I suggested the center buy this set tohelp those seniors who visit and are not comfortable with a structured class setting, or who wish to simply explore on their own.They did so, and it has been something of a hit. My only problem is that the index should be to ALL volumes and designed specificallyfor the DVD to include all volumes seamlessly. All in all, a hit of sorts, for those who are comfortable with electronic media.

While this book implies that it is focused on Facebook and Twitters, it covers the entire landscape of internet social media possibilities This exhaustive examination of social media is of necessity descriptive rather than instructive.  A senior reading  this book may not master all  of the how-to's, but will certainly be well acquainted with the various tools and applications. In fairness, Facebook will no longer be a mystery to seniors after this book, but some of Twitter vagaries may be les clear A nice reference for seniors in one book may reduce the number of phone calls from your confused seniors

This book was a hit with my 92 year old father in law. He was an aircraft mechanic in WW2 and was always very handy around the house, but the newer electronics were quite a challenge for him. He was the kind of man who would test the vacuum tubes in the TV, but solid state electronics were something he had to learn about in his eighties. Because we had provided him with a Dummies book to help him with his first laptop, he was comfortable with it, learned the Internet, and had even decided to try his hand at digital photography,  When we finally convinced him to give up his flip phone, he did a lot of reading and ordered an IPhone As soon as he received it, he began carefully reading the instructions, but he had a tough time because he had no knowledge of the terms involved. Since we had given him a copy of one of Nancy Muir's Dummy books last year, and he liked it, we surprised him with this one as well. The attention to large color pictures, one to a page, and the clear step by step instructions were perfect, and the way the book I organized, he could decide what he wanted to learn each day and go to it, as each topic is largely self contained.  We were very happy to see him learning again at his age. I would recommend this book to anyone, senior or not, who is having difficulty.
Love these with a hot salsa dip while watching the game. The taste and crispness gives a nice snap to the garlicky flavor and the bag goes fast

As a retired Corporate Trainer and Instructional Designer, and a senior myself, I set high standards for books designed for seniors. In the past, Nancy Muir has always been my personal favorite for the senior audience, and this time is no different. For those who began using the Android operating system on their phones and tablets, the iPad can be challenging; and that is due mostly to the different look and feel of the entire portfolio of Apple products.. The irony is, that once you are familiar with any Apple product, you have unlocked the key to the entire range of phones, tablets, and pcs. Seniors owe it to themselves to have a book like this at their side to explore their new Apple iPad one feature at a time, and Nancy Muir has made this easy in this book. No wonder this is the Number One seller on Amazon for iPad instruction books, and it is aimed squarely at seniors and their needs and learning styles.  Needless to say, I recommend it highly.

We replaced our super expensive coffee maker after ten years with this much more reasonably priced Mr.Coffee model, and have been very happy since getting it. It was a top rated model from a well known consumer group, and we can understand why.

These chews are made in Nepal by yak farmers, and while it sounds like a wild tale, I've checked and it appears that this is the truth. More , this is the only chew that my Siberian Husky has ever hidden under her bed becaue she could not finish the large in one sitting. Check the ingredients and you will find that they are "human grade, which means that you and your dog can both enjoy them if you are so moved. Our dog is quite fussy, but goes bananas over these!

We are all aware to some extent of the climate of hate in Dallas that existed at the time of JFKs assassination, but this excellent overview of the climate and major characters in the Dallas of 1963 is eye opening to say the least. . The author illuminates the web of connections linking some of the major player in Dallas in 1963, and describes the linkages among them. This is the broader canvas upon which the events of November took place. An eye opener.

This is an excellent addition to any collection on the JFK assassination, especially at the give-away price. Hornberger quotes extensively from AARB testimony that I for one, have never read from the transcript. While there are several book devoted to the autopsy, this is an excellent update on the current state of affairs with regard to the still evolving  description of the  participants.

I must admit that until very recently I was unaware of the differences between Paul, Peter and James with regard to early Christian doctrine. I am not qualified to comment on the scholarship underlying the books thesis, but this book has led me to develop an interest in learning more about Christian origins. I have to say that this was not a difficult read for someone like myself  who has little background in the subject.

This book provides much background material on the life of Cmdr. Fetzer and that is welcome and interesting information for those of us interested in some of the more arcane information on the assassination. It does contain a lot of what I have to consider to be hearsay material on Lt.Marvin, who maintains that he was offered a "contract" on Fetzer by a superior, which he turned down. There is a lot of nebulous connection material linking CIA etc. to the death of Fetzer, but little of substance. In summary, I did feel that the material on the personal life of Cmdr. Fetzer was worth the small investment in the book.  ,

I've been looking for a digital clock with a read out that is visible to both my wife and I from a distance without use of glasses (which I rarely wear to bed!) and we were pleased to find this Westclox model which has a cellphone charger as an integral part of the clock. I often forgot to set my phone to charge when going to bed, but having the charger with the clock makes it a natural habit to just plug in my phone when retiring to bed, and unplugging it when I arise. The readout has large numbers and a pleasant red glow, but just as important it has a large base which prevents tipping and gives this a more substantial feel than many others. The alarm is easy to set and use, and does not sound like a fire or smoke alarm, which is important. I am more than satisfied, I am quite pleased.

An exhaustive book on the chaos of 9/11 from the point of view of air traffic controllers, pilots, and the military. The author has spent years interviewing the civilian and military involved, and provides a minute by minute account of what took place on that day. This book reads like a novel, and the reader comes away with admiration and respect for all of those who acted outside of the box that day.

...If you can't perform like a twenty year old at 70! Testosterone fueled passion that lasts for 4 minutes is nothing to brag about anyway. We men are never taught that our sex lives must evolve as we age and hopefully become more sophisticated and aware of the nuances of sex, and the needs of our partner. In our youth, as men, we tend to ignore the emotional side of physical love in favor of performance (because that's what the ladies want, of course). Joan's book was a real eye opener for me, helping me to understand that there is a broad spectrum of intimacy, much of which does not involve penetration, and as men age, they can evolve. Her suggestions are insightful and practical, and will be of value to any man over the age of 50, 60, or 70. This is one of the best books on sexuality for men (and the women they love) of any age. Written not by a doctor with a sure-fire cure for ED, or a psychologist who assures us that " it happens to everyone", Joan Price is a woman of a certain age who is willing to tell us what so many are not: the ladies get it, and they are willing to  show us a few cool moves if we are willing to listen. Buy the book and leave it where your SO will find it.
I've tried all of the many Snapple flavors and this is my odds on favorite flavor.

Love this bed! MY 13 year old husky has joint problems and no longer lies down anywhere else but this bed, which we set up in the living room. Excellent buy, and my vet approves. It seems to be very difficult for her to get her hind quarters down on a bed without pain, but I notice that she now selects this bed when relaxing...we have several beds but she now only sleeps on this one. This is a dog that slept on my wooden deck for years.

We've all seen the "reality" TV shows many times and wondered what goes on behind the scenes. Well, thanks to Caitlyn Duffy's excellent novel, now we do! As an ancient grandma, I never expected to be so enjoying Young Adult fare, but I am thoroughly enjoying this series.Allison sends her video entry to the reality singing competition not expecting to get through, but of course she does. At the auditions, she comes across Elliott Mercer, a moody, enigmatic youth with an incredible voice and presentation. She thinks he is the one she has to beat,but little does she realise that her conception of reality is somewhat different to that of the show's producers!Caitlyn Duffy has written a suspenseful novel, during which this reader grew increasingly concerned for Allison's safety. Someone very nasty is sabotaging her performances - is it horrible Robyn? Or is it actually her mentor, a superstar who really should be coaching her group and not running around assisting a famous rock star to cheat on his wife? The ending was a complete surprise and a pleasure, as I was wondering how the author was going to satisfy the hopes of the reader.I just loved this well-written story, was fascinated by the various shenanigans of the characters and can assure readers of all ages that they will too  :)

This was a disappointing read. I got this book and was looking forward to it, but I couldn't believe what was going on! The characters were unbelievable. The husband was a monster who never bothered to explain himself and was alternatively loving and then totally horrible.SPOILER ***********************The wife had everything that could possibly go wrong happen to her. She runs from the house, pregnant, after being verbally abused by the husband, he chases after her and has an accident which over the course of time, she is apparently too sick to find out about despite it being all over the news and the internet. She tries to ring his work and they won't put her through, so then she falls sick - over and over - has a terrible birth where she nearly dies and although she gives the hospital the husband's details, it appears that no one rings him. He can't find her even though he knows she was pregnant but doesn't even think to ring the hospitals or check birth records.The heroine goes back to vet school - but she hardly does any study and certainly doesn't do any practical work. The family doesn't even have a pet while she is studying vet science - though it's probably for the best considering this unstable household.I lost patience with this pair - the kid was a pain in the bum as well - and in view of the appalling stats here in Australia - 65 women and several children dead from domestic violence this year alone - I couldn't cope with the abuse in this book.I am sorry to have to write a review like this, but really, it was too much.

The island of Guernsey is the main character here. I liked Jeanne, the heroine of the book, and the characters were reasonably interesting, however, I don't think the reader gets to know Nick very well. The romance never seemed to light up the pages.The pace was extremely slow and there was a fair bit of unnecessary details like eating, showering, cleaning, packing etc. The main points of the story got lost in the details of everyday life. I picked the villains in the story very early on.I really do think the author lost the pace for a mystery in this one as for me it only had a few areas of quiet suspense. I did look up the island of Guernsey after I finished, as there was enough history in the plot for me to be interested in that.

To be honest I can't remember whether this book was written in the first or third person. Unfortunately, I didn't like the characters - that of Ellen was a total write off. I found her to be a whimpering doormat with no "go" in her. All she could do was deny what was staring her in the face. I think the part about the husband's teenage mistress was supposed to be "zany" but it came across as plain loopy. The daughter was a dreadful little piece of work and Ellen's friends were not much chop.Just couldn't enjoy it one bit. The best character was Asia, the cat!

I got this book from our local library and thoroughly enjoyed it. Beginning with a murder and ending with a suicide - well, it's the in-between that is riveting. Robert Rotenberg makes a good job of presenting interesting and likable characters. He tries hard to make the wife of the victim unlikable, but actually I was sorry for her!An excellent novel and well recommended.

It would be hard to find as engaging a heroine as Venkataraman's Jamie Quinn, lawyer and all round good egg  :)  I thoroughly enjoyed this Jamie Quinn mystery, involving high-powered sleazy lawyer, Martin Glasser and his wife, who is intent on getting a divorce no matter how much her husband threatens anyone who tries to help her.Jamie and her best friend, Grace, take on the establishment to obtain Nan's divorce, but after a tiff, Grace decides not to speak to Jamie. This means that Jamie is left alone to fight for Nan's rights and investigate the accident which killed her next door neighbour's twin sister, Sara, and her husband. Drug lords, money laundering and murder are right up there in this exciting novel. Fast-paced and well written, I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys this genre.

Holly Love is not the first girl to be ensnared by the dastardly Andrew McNish. Blithely accepting his stories of being in finance and accepting his proposal, she chucks in her job and heads for the Blue Mountains - yes, this is an Australian novel set in Australia - a great treat for an Australian reviewer! Of course, Andrew has flown the coop, taking Holly's money with her. Shocked, she engages a rather seedy Private Investigator, O.Brien, who promptly gets himself...well, dead...The adventures of Holly, as she gathers new friends and a cockatoo along the way, are bright, sparkling and funny. I thoroughly enjoyed this novel and would highly recommend it to anyone who comes across it. I would love to read another Holly Love book and hope that the author saw fit to write one. If not, she should have!!!

I have never read a Dick Francis book that I didn't like! This one is a beauty and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Young Felix, writing with his father, would have been more than ready to take the flag on when Dick passed away.I liked the hero, Tom Forsythe - a familiar figure in the Francis skylines, the heros all have some sort of a problem, physical or emotional, but I don't mind that. I love the horses, the plots and the villains.Good stuff!

I pretty much a pushover for "cozy" mysteries, particularly ones with dogs in them. Shell, having discovered the body of her art professor lying dead tries to find the killer, having realised that it has to be one of the people in her own art class.  Myriad characters waft their way through the book, each contributing something to the solution of the mystery, which of course Shell manages to solve.The characters are likable, the plot twists suitably and the writing is fine! I enjoyed this novel and will read more from this author.Recommended!

For me, this book doesn't live up to the author's reputation. An intricate plot, but a messy lot of characters made this hard to read. I didn't enjoy the babies mix in it, the homosexual mix, the film star mix, the belligerent cop mix, the hot SEAL mix and the serial killer mix...it came across as though the author threw everything she could think of into the plot and the result was a mishmash of happenings. I wasn't sure who was with whom, there was too much domesticity in the plot which kept getting in the way of suspense. I didn't have any beef with the homosexual mix, only that it was one more thing to get my head around.The pace was slow, with a lot of - IMO - unnecessary side-stories which didn't allow for tension to get through. The final part of the book the pace picked up, but it could have been a ripping thriller if the author had allowed it to be.

An excellent novel, full of action and well written. Kate Reid is a likable character, but I must admit Nick annoyed me for jeopardising Kate's FBI course with lots of demands on her time, albeit with the main case in the plot. The characters of the crooks and the victims were well drawn, and there some nasty twists toward the end the plot.A highly recommended read and I am looking forward to reading the next Kate Reid book.

The book overall was a surprise in that it was so dark - although the cover should have indicated some nastiness. The animal abuse almost put me off so that I almost stopped reading it, however I persevered. The depiction of small town spite and gossip rang very true. The corruption in the administration came through loud and clear, the atmosphere and "saving ones backs" rang true.A good effort - apart from the animal abuse which I don't think is necessary in any book. We can tell the type of character without horrific details. Certainly, I know it is "only" a story but only too true. This type of thing is all too prevalent. I am giving this book four stars because it had more going for it than my one complaint which I've covered.

There have been, and undoubtedly will be, thousands of novels about female friendship being published. Liz Byrski's Last Chance Cafe is - in a nutshell  - warm and moving. That she has chosen to work the plot primarily around women in old age, is interesting and she adds in their daughters and nieces as well.For Margot shopping malls are a necessary evil. Tramping through one, on the hunt for a new dress to wear at her sister Phyl's fiftieth wedding anniversary, she hears a commotion coming from the escalators. Imagine her astonishment, when she sees an old friend, in every sense of the word, chained to the escalator, screaming about the manipulation of women and girls by the media and fashion gurus. Dot is supposed to be meditating in India, and when the security guards cut her free with bolt cutters, much to her disgust, she admits that demonstrating is getting a bit beyond her, but that for a moment there, she'd felt the old fires burning.The story revolves around the two sisters - Phyl and Margot - Margot's daughters, Emma (who is having problems being a mother) and Lexie who has been made redundant by her employers and is left bereft. Her so-called love life has ended as well.Dot - who has some well kept secrets and Vanni - also keeping some whoppers - are drawn into the circle and fire up the new generation to protest about the exploitation of women. In the process, some interesting things come to life about Phyl's marriage - the 50th Anniversary party ends dramatically - Dot's past and all their futures.I enjoyed this novel and thought the way Liz Byrnski wove her plot in and out of the women's lives was expertly done. Yes, there was political matters in there, but being of the age where I lived through these, didn't find that they detracted in any way from the story.

Back in the early 1900s when the main part of this story was set, women were treated appallingly. Lily, now in a nursing home, reminisces auot her childhood and speculates on what happened to her sister, Violet.This is a beautifully written story covering many aspects of women's lives at that time. To say there are some surprises is not exaggerating. I don't want to give any spoilers so I will just urge anyone who comes across this relatively short novella to read it. You will not be disappointed!

This book started off with great promise. I had the expected negative response to the main character, Vincent, and his shenanigans with women and I really enjoyed Annie and her backstory.To be honest, I think the author missed a great chance here to turn a good story into a great one! There seemed to be large gaps between events in the character's lives - e.g. Vincent leave the manuscript for awhile and suddenly reappears after Annie gets her own vet practice. I liked the part where Annie's husband leaves and about Annie's circumstances, but she suddenly turns up in Little Creek with her own practice. I liked the way Vincent picks the dog off the road and takes it to Annie's surgery and so they meet. Any books with animals in will always get me in.The story moves along at a rather rapid pace for someone to get used to Vincent's changed circumstances, and Annie seems to have no thought in particular about that. Her mad decision re Vincent is, quite frankly, ridiculous and seemed to be just in there to create a dilemma for the characters. I'm trying hard here not to give spoilers!Perhaps I'd better just say that I was disappointed that the story was wound up so fast. I felt as though the author was intent on writing a short book - perhaps because apparently people seem to like short books these days - but I think that if this was the case, it short-changed what could have been a real "humdinger" of a story. Depth of character is what drives a book for me, and this one could well have had me cheering Vincent and Annie on and it did to a certain extent, but the brevity of the ending fixed that.

Without a doubt, Caitlyn Duffy is the finest author writing for the Young Adult market. I thoroughly enjoyed this latest of her books about young people coping with life. Cassie, lonely and jaded by having to move around frequently with her mother who is an Airforce officer, is puzzled whne her teacher singles her out and coaxes her to join the theatre group. She has not played her guitar for some time, so if ambivalent about putting her name down in the music section, but having met Elliott at the group, Cassie decides that maybe things might be looking up.Unfortunately, Cassie is not used to making friends and mistakes the overtures of Melissa's - the rich girl in the theatre group - for a snide type of communication, not realising that indeed Melissa wants to genuinely make friends with Cassie. Nor does Cassie trust in confiding in her mother and almost gets herself into strife because of her lack of communication.This well-written and delightful story is marred by only one thing - it ends abruptly! I would love to have learned what happens and suspect that this might be addressed in another book further down the track. Let's hope Ms Duffy gets to and immediately writes the next in this series or - alternatively - adds a few chapters to this one.

This delightful story written by a raccoon intrigued me mightily, so when I got to read it, I dived right in. From the start, I was on edge wondering how this little person would get through his trials - the winter, no food because he was lazy...What I particularly liked about this story was the way the raccoon told the story of how he came to be living with a human and learned human ways.Highly recommended and I hope there will be more stories from Francine Zane  :)

I always enjoyed Allie Babcock books, but this time I was a little confused. I couldn't work out exactly why the murder was committed. Perhaps I missed something somewhere at the end.The character of Alie Babcock is the best in the book, the other characters, including her boyfriend were a little lame. Unfortunately there were also errors in the editing which threw me. I would read another Babcock mystery purely for the lovely dogs and Allie herself.

Like many, I had no idea what went on in Germany while the Cold War was in play - but now I know!Doug DePew has an engaging style which is easy to read and to understand how things were from his perspective. This memory of a bunch of hormonal madmen loose in Germany is delightful - one storyof note - the Lt Colonel in the hotel (No, you have to read it yourself!) -  will stick in MY memory for a long time!What I particularly liked about this memoir is the joyous and funny life those young men led. Oh yes, there was fighting and lots and lots of drinking (they could have almost been Australians - but not quite!) but at heart they knew what they were there for and when the chips were down, they faced their fears and responsibilities with courage. I am sure that eventually they all evolved into normal "ordinary" (for they certainly were not so) husbands and fathers  :)Very good!!!
A charming short story which I enjoyed very much. I am always a sucker for cats and Raziel is no exception. Will read more of this writer's work as she posts it.

This is not a book for the faint-hearted.Firstly I liked the way the chapters were sectioned - Prelude and Theme, Beguine, Love Song, Trio for Trumpet, Flute and Soprano, Sonata Appasionata, Jamm'n the Blues, Finale, Reprise and Coda thereby setting the phases of Carrie and Stan's love affair. This made the dips into the past very easy to read and didn't sidetrack the plot.Basically, Karen Morgan, Judge, is no longer Carrie Moon, but when Stan phones after 12 years of silence, her heart is awakened once more. Trapped in a loveless marriage, Karen cannot prevent Carrie from rising from the ashes of the past. There were many occasions when I wanted to punch Stan out and many times when I wanted to say to Karen - forget it, give him up and find someone who is worthy of the love you have to give.I don't want to give any spoilers, so I will be content with saying that the author is brilliant at wringing the heart of her reader as hard as she does that of Karen Morgan. I don't think I've read of a heroine who is so deeply in love to the point of obsession that she would forgive a man so many times and through so many humiliations.The title fits the story superbly!

I enjoyed this book for the most part - the exception being the cat and I can't stand that in a book.The role of Victim Advocate is not familiar to me here in Australia, though the service may well have them. Domestic violent is a sticky subject to write about and I think the author has done well here. The characters were well developed, though I thought the romance between them was not totally believable.Overall, a good story, well written.

This book was good in places and not so good in others. The heroine was very negative and there was no real attempt to flesh out her relationship with her parents or her brother. Some inconsistencies, but the tone was good-natured overall. David, the husband, was very lax with Evelyn, particularly where the lawyers were concerned, but other parts of the book where they hooked up emotionally were good. A little too much explicit sex for my taste and the obvious Australianism's in a book set in the USA were out of place.Overall, the book didn't set the world on fire,but neither was it awful. Summing up, I think the writing lacked passion, as in commitment.

I was asked for a review of this book and though I was a little wary when I realised that the characters are apparently what is termed "young adult" I soon settled into the plot.Fast-paced, this well-written book didn't let up for a moment. The nasty plot to destroy a company and it's staff sends Tulsa and Liberty hunting through cyberspace for the perpetrator. The backstory - Tulsa and her partners in Scandals Investigations are half-siblings who have actually just met after their father died - is interesting but I found it a little confusing as to which characters were the siblings and who were their partners. This did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the novel. The descriptions of the technical aspects of the hunt - Tulsa is an IT expert - were not hard to follow - thank you, author - and the revelation of the mastermind behind the cyber attacks and some rather nasty real ones was well told.What I really liked about this book was the energy in the writing and the naturalness of the characters. It didn't hurt that the love interest was gorgeous (he always is!) and I liked the background of the main character, Tulsa.Well done!

Having read The Christmas Violin, I was eager to read this book, so duly logged on and purchased it. However, it didn't have the charm of Violin - well, it was a dark subject after all - but unfortunately it did not have many light moments either, being pretty much all about "Poor Sarah."The character of Sarah is weak. She has a dreadful father who disowns her, but she has a loving grandmother who gives her everything she can and still Sarah chooses to allow herself to be hurt - constantly.The problem of bullying looms large in this book and it is a salutary lesson for readers, particularly for young female readers. Sarah is continually cowering in front of the chief bully and I found that a huge downer as far as this book is concerned. If she had stood up for herself and made her grandmother proud of her granddaughter's backbone, I might have liked this book more.The ending is well told and no, I didn't really cotton on to what was going to happen until around 3/4 of the way through, but there was an unfinished piece of information right at the end - the last paragraph. I do wish the author had rounded out the explanation of what happened to Sarah's boyfriend. An unfortunate omission.

Okay, I admit it - I got the book from the library because I saw it there on the returns shelf. I totally loved it.From the opening pages, Crais lets the reader into Maggie's head, instilling a deep sense of foreboding. This cannot end well for either Maggie or Pete - well I read the synopsis, so I knew that - but reading it and then getting pulled into the story are two different things. Maggie is beautiful - sensitive of course, her nose is her fortune - but sadly, she is suffering PTDS. Her new handler, Scott James, is no better off. This is shown in stark reality when Scott and Maggie pretty much collapse when the officer in charge of the K-9 squad fires a starter pistol behind them.How Maggie and Scott survive their training and bring down the killers of Scott's former police partner, Stephanie, injuring Scott as well, makes riveting reading. I do hope Robert Crais brings out another Maggie and Scott book in the future.The twists in this novel are brilliantly plotted and the suspense is constant. I found myself tensing with every chapter, wondering if Maggie - or Scott - or both, were going to be hurt. The supporting cast are strong, there are no weak links, but make no mistake about it, this is Maggie's story!I checked the mood as "hopeful" in the lead up to this review, because in spite of the subject matter, hope shines through every moment for both Maggie and Scott.I just LOVED it.

I can't begin to describe how much I enjoyed this beautifully written and presented novella. The characters pulled me in and wouldn't let me go, from the elderly homeless woman to the heartbroken mother and the grieving widower.The author could have written a sweetly sentimental man/woman romance here, but no. She gave us a story which ultimately lifted the spirit and which managed to wreak havoc with my emotions. I totally loved this work and would read more in a heartbeat from this author.Congratulations on a gentle, heartbreakingly lovely story.

I was delighted when Google Alerts advised me that there was a new Dave Mason novel available, carefully crafted and presented by Mar Preston. The subject matter, a private high school, sounded intriguing, so I hastened to purchase the book.I was not disappointed! The characters are well developed and their back stories blended well into the action. What was really quite fascinating was the attention to detail in the mannerisms of the detectives and perhaps to a lesser extent, the members of the staff of the school. Sights, sounds and smells are variables drummed into the aspiring author via workshops and there was no limit to the amount of these in this novel. The suspense was cracking, only letting up for the reader to catch - in this case, moi - breath and then relentlessly pulling me into the undertow of deceit, fraud and murder.I particularly liked the ending of this novel and no, no spoilers!Well done indeed.

This was a different take on the usual romantic second chance plot. Zoe, whose friendship with Robbie - a rock star in a band - has lasted since they were little kids, discovers that she is about to undergo the fight of her life. Robbie - a delightful character - come back to support her.I don't want to give any spoilers, but this novel is heart-warming and interesting and in some places sad. I liked the characters and felt concerned for their future. There are some flashbacks which explain Zoe and Robbie's close friendship and gradual falling in love but these work very well without being intrusive.I enjoyed this novel!!

Wayne Zurl's Sam Jenkins series has always been a favourite of mine. Sam is the quiet, laid back and unassuming Chief of Prospect Police Department. Aided and abetted by his sidekick, Bettye and his team of officers, Sam enjoys great success. There's an old saying - "There's nothing as queer as folks!" and indeed the folks in this collection are unique!The stories, written in the first person for the most part, are funny, deep, sad - every aspect of human life is covered - and I thoroughly enjoyed every one. I am so glad I bought this collection and they will be staying on my kindle!If you haven't read any of Wayne Zurl's Sam Jenkins novels as yet - do! You will be delighted  :)

I felt a little ambivalent about this one. I liked aspects of it, such as the gorgeous Gavin, but the negativity of the heroine put me off. Her violent reaction to something which she assumed to be the case was way off base and the character of Vanessa just appeared to be in the story because "the other woman" needed to be there. Sometimes I felt Gavin could have done better for himself than Aubrey.It was okay but only that.

This novel was so disappointing. I had it on my kindle for some time and decided I'd better read it, but I wish I hadn't. Second chance romances are always a risk, but this one was really unfortunate - to put it mildly.SPOILERS.**************************************************************************************************************************************************************************The heroine is a seemingly sensible woman who got dumped by an immature old playboy of a husband, who at no stage apologises for breaking up their 20 year marriage or it transpires, made any effort to tell his wife that he was unhappy. In time honoured fashioned, he leaps into bed with a younger woman and then comes home one day and says, "I don't love you any more. I'm leaving you." No explanation, no word of regret.The couple meet for their daughter's wedding on an island in the Bahamas where - wait for the first cliche - there's a mix-up over the heroine's room and she "has" to share a room with her ex-husband. We quickly find out that he is about to divorce the young woman (second cliche, she's a gold-digger) he dumped his wife for.Their daughter colludes with her father by not moving out of the cottage with her finance and sharing the room with her mother and not only that, this young madam chides her mother for making a fuss. It might upset the wedding.Clare's husband, Jim, comes across as an arrogant pig, flirting with waitresses and being everyone's friend as he tries to get back into the heroine's good graces and she of course, after a few cranky words, giggles and enjoys  his company. Really? A lot of winking and laughing and we are supposed to believe that this man will settle down and sincerely love the heroine again? Or could it be that he now knows that she is well set up financially as her business is doing well?The ending was expected but a disappointment and what a cliche. I would have expected more of this author, quite frankly.

I've never been disappointed in CJ Lyons' work, and this book was no exception. I enjoyed "meeting" Lucy again and was quite riveted by her daughter Megan's actions. I did think the story dwelt a little too much on the trauma of a previous book to Lucy's family, but this was a minor whinge.I am looking forward to more of Lucy in the future  :)

This novel had a couple of disappointments in store for me. I know modern romance novels have explicit sex in them and expect that, but this was over the top. Pages and pages of explicit sex - I don't know how the main characters got to know each other again, because they were going at it like rabbits most pages after the first episode of connecting. I am not a prude and I do like to read sex scenes - who doesn't? - but when the plot appears to be there just to connect the sexual scenes, it gets boring pretty quickly.The other disappointment was that there was no ending. I sat through pages and pages of erotica with minimal characterisation except for the main female character, and no real depth to the story - and then for it not to finish...well, I won't be reading another in this series as they are obviously not standalone novels.

When you are busy bullying someone at school or denigrating a person's appearance in college, you need to be sure that person doesn't come back and "get you." A group of college students who think they are God's Gift to the opposite sex, make the mistake of playing a cruel joke on Lila Carmichael. Overweight and viciously repressed by her mad, religious maniac father, Lila is desperate to belong and to be seen as the incredibly talented actress she truly is. Her friend, Milli, knows how talented she is and persuades Lila to try out for the big play. Lila shows her talent and is cast in the lead role, something which doesn't sit well with Della the other female member of the theatre group.It all goes downhill from there...Fifteen years later, Lila is a huge star, a comedienne who has the world at her feet, fabulous wealth and a seemingly enchanted life. However, Lila has carried hatred and revenge in her heart all this time. Woe betide the "friends" who were in the theatre group! Each of these people has something they want from Lila, and they've all hit hard times. Surely Lila's invitation to the reunion of the theatre group at her house on a remote island means that she will help each one of them? Each with his or her own agenda, they arrive a the island full of hope, conveniently forgetting how they treated Lila in the past.It is amazing how a clever author can take a group of thoroughly horrible people and make a reader feel sorry for them, but C.S Lakin does just that. By the time the reunion is over, there is a lot of meaning to the saying (in essence) that if you seek revenge, you'd best dig two graves."I was fascinated by this story and very interested in how it turned out. No spoilers, but this is a book worth reading for its clever writing, it's macabre denouement of the hapless group and the ultimate effect on them and on Lila.Well done indeed!!!

As an adoptee who has known all along that I was adopted, I just had to read this well written story.Forced adoptions were rife in Australia and only came to light in recent years.The story of Lilly, Megan and Sabina - now 37 and pregnant for the first time, only just learning of her adoption - is heart-wrenching and all too true.Right now on TV there is a series on the forced adoptions called Love Child and every bit of it is authentic. If you have seen the movie, Philomena, you will seethe at the injustice of the religious groups and government organisations who were involved in adoptions. Having read the story of the orphanage where I was parked in 1946 - well, the matron running that place would have had a lot to answer for if she had been alive today.Unfortunately, the revelations of people's original identities have come too late for most adoptees of my generation, but now that the official apology has been given, any adopted child has a right to approach his or her birth parent on reaching the age of 18 - if the parent is agreeable. Likewise, a parent is able to contact their child if the child is agreeable.The story of Lilly, Megan and Sabina is sad but up lifting. I could understand and sympathise with all parties in the "deal,"  knowing that sometimes reunions do not always pan out amicably. Does Sabina find her birth mother? And does it all work out?You will need to read this interesting and well written novel to find out!

I thoroughly enjoyed this mad little novel! I enjoyed the romance, the background story and I particularly enjoyed Thomas Cash Riley as the cat! In fact, I hope the author is going to give us another novel so we can find out what happens to him  :)The writing is easy and flows well, the romantic attachment between the two main characters is excellent and not sentimental beyond what is necessary.Good stuff!!

When one considers the millions of people in the world and the chance that a person can miss their soulmate, it is fortuitous that Vanessa Morgan could meet hers. While driving down the street one night, Vanessa sees a white cat with ginger markings sitting in the street. She and her partner at the time, Stephan, stop the car and take him home. So Avalon moves into their lives, a never-to-be-forgotten feline.From the moment they bring him home, it is apparent that Avalon, like his Vanessa, suffers from abandonment but Avalon takes it a step further, leaving no one in any doubt that he is a needy animal. Two other cats and a guinea pig are forced to move over and allow the Turkish Van cat to take over - and that he does much to the horror of the couple's friends and family, the landlady and the neighbours.This is a wonderful story of love, of compassion and of stamina - Avalon is not an easy housemate or indeed, soulmate. Eventually when Vanessa moves into her own apartment, Avalon reigns supreme. He becomes famous when he stars in the films made from Vanessa's books, but never does he allow her to forget that she is his.I cried and I laughed as, riveted by Avalon's story, Vanessa recounted her life with this remarkable animal. This is not just a "cat story" - it is an account of a true meeting of souls, a partnership beyond that of human to human. As a Spiritualist, I truly believe that Avalon was an old soul from one of Vanessa's former lives.A terrific read which I shall not forget. I will now be looking for Ms Morgan's other books.

I bought this collection yesterday and read - and continued to read - the books every chance I got. Griff, a young man whose development has been stunted because of a ten year old secret, becomes an animal expert in that he convinces everyone that he can talk to animals - specifically dogs and cats. He does this through learning their body language and observation of their surroundings. Before too long he is embroiled in several murder investigations which he manages to solve. In the background, a running sore in his life, is the knowledge that his sister, Susan, disappeared a decade ago, his mother is a reclause, his father died an alcoholic and his brother left home and barely considers himself part of the family. Griff's stunted social development is a direct result of his mother teaching him that he has to be wary of everything in the world and that he must hide himself in case he too is kidnapped.Griff meets Sheila Green, a detective, and starts to form a relationship with her, even though he doesn't know how a relationship works. As the on-going plot unfolds to Book 6, Griff finally gets to find out what happened to his sister and all is revealed, including a startling ending. This was the only aspect of the set I was disappointed in. The abruptness of the ending was a shock and leaves the series up in the air as far as I am concerned. There are some typos and a few inconsistencies but these aren't bad enough to worry me, because each of the murder mysteries were fascinating.I hope we get a final followup book to show us what happens to Griff! I think the author owes that to the reader for the abrupt but clever ending.

From the first moment, this book pelts the reader headlong into a frightening chase. Lasting only one night and into the early morning, the plot concerns Allie, whose sister Carmen was murdered ten years previously and Beckard, a serial killer. Allie plans for ten years how to take Beckhard down. Finally she manages to lure him into her trap, but then things go horribly wrong...I loved this story. The incredibly fast pace, the confrontations between the adversaries all make for a wild ride. Here's hoping Sam Sisavath has written another Allie Krycek novel and of course, included Apollo and Harper, the quiet, pleasant cop who - IMO - is a perfect match for Allie.Great stuff!!!  You'll never forget this one!

This book came across as though the author used religious characters to make the explicit sex presentable.. The whole story just didn't ring true - even for romance which frequently mirrors fantasy. The use of swear words belong in the erotic side, they certainly don't seem to match up to the religious leanings of the main characters.

A most unusual novel, well written, which documents the lives of four people, three of whom knew each other at school and then meet at the end of their lives. The fourth, the wife of one of the couples, is just meeting the other couple.This is delightful in that the plot shows that romance and passion is not absent from older people's lives, it's all there simmering underneath the white hair and liver-spotted hands. The author was 79 when he wrote this, so he was in a good position to understand the problems and hopes of the elderly - and the well-kept secrets!!!This is a sensitive and humorous work and I just loved it. NO SPOILERS, you'll have to read it for yourself!I LOVED IT!!!!

The beginning is pitiful and dark. The reader knows that things can only go bad in the long run. A little boy is forced to accompany his father - a well known actor - when he goes for a "massage" and a homosexual encounter. This happens regularly and sets the scene for the future.The characters are well drawn; the detectives are likable people in whom I invested concern. Mr Wickard expertly shows their private lives and how frustration impinges on their relationships. The characterisation of the serial killer's victims are brilliantly portrayed, three of which the reader gets to know intimately. As their stories unfold, there is an inexorable sense of dread in the manuscript. I wanted to yell, "No, don't go there!" The families of the victims are expertly shown - the pain and anguish of some upon the realisation of their loved one's secret lives.Such is the skill of this author that I became sorry for the killer, in fact one couldn't but be aware of why the person is committing these vicious and sordid crimes.A truly terrifying and well crafted novel.Congratulations, Mr Wickard.

I didn't know anything about this author or his Dismas Hardy character until I got this book at a local market. Intrigued by the cover and synopsis - judging the contents by them as any good reader would - I delved into the book almost as soon as I got it home. For the next 24 hours I was riveted by the shenanigans of Dismas, his wife, Frannie and the carry-on of the political animals around them. Well, I shouldn't insult animals - these characters were go-getters of the first degree - ruthlessly ambitious..John Lescroart weaves a twisted tale of greed, lies and betrayals which had me reading in bed until the small hours and again until ten o'clock this morning. Dismas Hardy is a likable lawyer (yes, really!) whose wife is thrown into jail for contempt of court and insulting a judge. She is keeping a secret which is not hers, but which involves the safety of others. Hardy, of course, sets out to solve this mystery and find the murderer of three people.Needless to say, Lescroart has written a skillful, winding plot which culminates in satisfaction all round. The courtroom scenes are a riot, resulting in my wanting to cheer Hardy on.I see there are more Dismas Hardy novels available so I shall be looking for them in due course.

Ilsa Evans' work is always good value and this one was no exception. Sisters Emily and Jill change places for a day, which just happens to be the Melbourne Cup - a sacrosanct occasion in Australia. Jill scuttles over to Emily's beautiful, undefiled-by-children apartment and sinks into the bath and then the bed, reveling in the silence and the knowledge that she can do as she pleases for once.Emily, self-righteously scurries to Jill's house where she is greeted by chaos - sulky teens and a foul-mouthed toddler. How could Jill have allowed her home to get into this state, she wonders, and just what does Jill DO all day?Into the mix is the elder sister - Corrine - who normally hosts a family party on Melbourne Cup Day, complete with competitive games. This year her father in law is desperately ill, so Jill has to have the party at her house. Several boxes arrive with the games and instructions.
