The stage is set for a great time!Things go downhill from there!A wildly funny novel, well written and not even slightly exaggerated family life, even when ones factors in Jack, Jill's husband (yes I know) and his parents and the parents of Jill, Emily, Corrine and Adam, the Broadhurst children and the supercilious daughter of Corrine - Charlotte - and the stage is set for a riotous time.Thoroughly enjoyable!!!

I quite liked this novel. It was light and easy to read in spite of several characters anguish about their situations.The ending was resolved fairly easily - almost too easily - but that didn't detract from the fact that I was looking for a pleasant read and this was it.

The only bear I have seen in the wild was in the Smokey Mountains in a National Park in Tennessee and it was up a tree at the time, sleeping. All I saw was it's bum! That was on a great visit to the USA from Australia in 2012.I thoroughly enjoyed this most informative book about bears. I certainly didn't know anything about Spectacled bears and Ms Child's included a lot of information of which I was unaware.A lovely book with great photographs of all kinds of bears which will be marvellous for parents and grandparents to read to their families.Good stuff!

There's not much honor going around in this mob of characters. When I started this story, I immediately felt a deep sense of foreboding. Things were not going to end well for someone - and of course it didn't! The saying "We reap what we sew" springs to mind as I cast my mind back over this plot.Ben Taylor, a handsome, college boy - lustful, callous, seeking the main chance and a user - attracts the attention of a young, plain college girl, who becomes obsessed by him. Emotionally dependent, she makes friends with Ben and then allows herself to be used when he has nothing better on offer. Her friends hate him, understandably, and he is quite happy to take advantage of everything he can get.Finally, he experiences heartbreak and turns to Paige for consolation. She persuades him to meet her parents and then comes the surprise. Initially, torn between furthering his college education and the employment Paige's father offers him, Ben rather obviously comes down on the side of the money. However, to do him some credit, he knuckles down and honestly makes a go of the job. It isn't long however, before he reverts to type.The character of Ben is as horrible and go-getting as the character of Paige is manipulative and co-dependent. Neither of them are people whom I found hard to dislike. Then comes an even nastier piece of work - Cousin Evelyn - who of course is after Ben and needless to say, succeeds.The question which springs to mind, is Paige herself a victim or a predator? Evelyn is definitely a predator. So what's Ben? Well, he's definitely a licentious reptile who can't keep it in his pants, but how much prey is he, firstly to Paige's and then Evelyn's predatory schemes?There are a few redeeming features about Ben - he loves his daughter and feels sorry and guilty about his betrayals of his wife, but ultimately I believe the ending of this riveting novel - the ultimate betrayal - is justified.John King weaves a dark and cruel tale so skilfully that one forgets it was written by a man - but then why shouldn't it be? The book is written in the first POV - that of Ben. I felt just a little sorry for Paige, but kept wanting to shake her until her teeth rattled. I would definitely read another book by this author  :)

Move over Lara Croft - you have competition!At first I thought this book was a little mad - well, that's okay, I like mad - but it took a chapter or two to get into the action and work out what was going on.  After I'd worked it out, this book was good fun.What woman doesn't wish she had super powers? Actually most women do and use them everyday, but stopping bullets with one's body is something most of us aspire to but can't achieve. These women do!  As a result of a medical experiment, two women, Megan and Trisha, attain super powers. They can fly, move in the blink of an eye, read minds, stop bullets - these women are invincible. Of course, where there are heroines, there has to be a baddie and this comes in the form of Malinkova and her mentor, who want to use one of the women's bodies to release a baddie from prison. This baddie is going to set off a bomb, so it's very important that he is out and about. Unfortunately, Malinkova - whilst in Megan's body  - falls for Megan's husband. Oh dear...How it all pans out is like a highly colourful cartoon-movie - one of those one sees the shorts of on TV and in the movies - all fire and lightning characters.Gary Henry has released the modern woman from everyday life and given her - and her daughters - a future of which we can all be proud. The husbands...well, they're not doing too badly. After all, who wouldn't want a "real" superwoman for a wife?

Perhaps only a dog owner or lover could appreciate this book. I am not owned by a dog any more but I do love them and well appreciated the anguish experienced by Tricia and Josh. How they persisted in their searching and on the way picked up a tiny desperate rescue make - for me - emotional reading and renews my faith in people. I don't know if I could have handled the trolls as well as they did.Good for them!

I thought I would like this book, but honestly - all the heartbreak and angst put a stop to that. This book had nothing in the way of joy or lightness.Inconsistencies in the relationship between Kyle, Jess and Colton were a stumbling block. Wilder couldn't have put more dramas into the novel if she'd tried. Drugs, cage fighting, inconsolable grief which results in alcoholism, miscarriages...and then there was endless pages of explicit sex.I cannot understand why books which are not labelled "Erotica" need to have such explicit details, endlessly toted out until I was skipping pages wishing it would all end. I don't mind a bit of sex in a novel, but oh dear...it almost seems as though modern romance authors put in pages of the sexual act when they can't come up with another part of the story - I'm talking about many romance authors here, not just Ms Wilder.Disappointed.

Unfortunately, in spite of the interesting cover, I didn't like this book. The characters - for me - are selfish, demanding and in the case of Sappho, so totally stupid as to be deserving of the ultimate betrayal by her husband, Gavin, her horrifyingly degenerate stepdaughter, Isobel, and her husband's former mother in law, the gloating, greedy, horrible Gwen.Arthur, Sappho's stepson,  is the only redeeming character in the book and it's a case of now you see him, now you don'tI won't go into the plot of the novel because that has been laid out in the synopsis and by other reviewers.The opening chapters are good, as Sappho arrives at her mother's house and leaves her diary and pages from her novel, then disappears physically until the end of the book. The mother and her boring boyfriend, Barnaby, swap opinions on psychological aspects of Sappho's and her step-family's lives in a long ramble, most of which I didn't understand or care about. Sappho's mother. Emily, of course reads the diary (it's a mother's duty, she says) written as a novel by Sappho -  and recounts it to Barnaby, whom she can''t decide to marry and spends most of the book debating whether to or not.As soon as Gavin moves into Sappho's house, stupid Sappho and helpless Laura (her secretary and as it is pointed out, only her employee) are undermined by the relentless Isobel, conniving Gavin and greedy Gwen.The whole plot might have worked if Sappho had a brain or a bit of gumption in her body, but as the author has chosen not to give her either of these attributes, then things went downhill from a few chapters in and never picked up.

A short, beautifully illustrated and well-written children's book about Maggie, an urban fox in the UK. The cats are incensed when Maggie moves into the garden, in spite of the fact that the owners put out food for the fox every night.How Maggie reigns supreme and is finally accepted by the more aggressive of the cats, is a lovely story and I just know that children from around 5-8 will relish this little story.Well done indeed!

I could hardly wait to get my hands on this thriller, starring Louis Kincaid again.Fresh from the Michigan debacle, Kincaid is invited to Florida to investigate a strange murder. Kincaid arrives with his cat - Isobel - in a cat carrier and stays with his friend, Dodie - a retired investigator - and his wife, Margaret who loves to look after her men.It soon becomes apparent that the strange murder is one of many  - a serial killer is on the loose and the local police are desperate to solve it before any more victims come to light. Louis is tagged onto the station by the local chief, Dan Wainwright, as an investigator consultant. All is well - the usual politics come into play because the victims spread into different jurisdictions - but imagine the men's surprise when the FBI agent requested turns out to be a small, nerdy woman!Louis is a delightfully complex character, the plot is meticulous and the identity of the killer quite a surprise!

Louis Kincaid is a thoroughly engaging hero, one for whom I felt concern from the first moment I "met" him.The plot begins with a bang and escalates from there. Kincaid is bewildered by the personalities he meets when he joins a small town police force in Michigan after a problem at his last job in Mississipi. The police chief, Gibraltar is - quite frankly - a weirdo as is Jesse, Luis partner in the force. The mysterious Zoe, who comes on to Louis and with whom he has a fleeting relationship, has a lot to answer for.The twists and turns in this novel are riveting, I was worried about the uncertain but brilliant Louis's future with his colleagues.  Pj.J Parrish has done a marvellous job with this character and I am looking forward to reading the next in the series.

Rarely have I encountered and read a book which gets into the minds and hearts of the characters as well as this one. I am in awe of the author's skill in laying out an intricate and sensitive plot in which the characters are likable in spite of their obvious flaws.The character of Jack, the husband, is well drawn and strangely sympathetic when the back story reveals that he and Emmy have been trapped by their circumstances when they were too young to cope.That Jacks' solution and the result forces Emmy stand up for herself and fight for her marriage made me hate Jack for bailing out in such a manner - no spoilers!However,  in spite of the bad light in which this places Jack, the situation has resolved itself by the time we meet the couple and the gorgeous, supposedly laid-back Duncan Grier. Duncan has his own demons to put to rest, not the least of which is the restriction he feels in his personal, social and professional life. Wanting to break out of the mold into which he has settled is bringing Duncan's past to light, something with which he cannot cope without help - Emmy's help.The ending, where Emmy makes her choice, is dramatic and ultimately satisfying  :)I couldn't put this novel down and would love to read more by this author.Congratulations, and very well done indeed!!!

Overall, I liked this novel and thought it was a pleasant read. The characters were likable - perhaps too perfect in some cases - and the main character very prone to jumping to conclusions. The hero - as per tradition - was gorgeous, but I would have liked him to be a little harder to catch! I thought his occupation was delightful and full marks to the author for bringing something different to the plot.The writing could have been much tighter and the author or editor should have cut out some of the repetition - there were instances of Tracy going working the same thoughts over and over - and over - which is understandable but she flew off at tangents very easily -  and there could have been a lot more tension generated. IMO, the author could have made a lot more of the plot with more depth and mystery. The solution - no spoilers! - came almost too easily, but I did like the ending and what it implied for the relationships between the characters.

Well, to be honest, I bawled my way through it - for Hannah, for the deer, for her husband and of course, for her dog.Well written and emotionally draining, this book had me riveted from the beginning.Excellent writing, excellent characterisation  - all in all, well done!!!

This is a hard review to write, because although I enjoyed most of the book, other parts put me off completely.  At first I laughed at the one-liners even though many were sarcastic, but after awhile I began to get tired of the supposedly light-hearted comments. I realise that the character is trying hard to cope with being left with an Asperger's child - and I couldn't imagine how difficult that must be - but in the end I don't think she liked Merlin much even though she couldn't let him go and try to be a little normal - and the "twist" toward the end was totally expected. Well, it was in the synopsis anyway.I have read Kathy Lette's work before and enjoyed it, but this one I feel ambivalent about.

Bea Abbott and Ellie Quick - whose stories I love reading - have a lot in common - even Bea has a recalcitrant adult too. This is one of the better "cozies" around and set in the UK a country I love. I confess I got this book at our local library - just as well because the kindle version is pretty pricey.It was a little hard to fill out the survey at the beginning of this review, particularly the mood. I picked "hopeful" because it seemed the best to describe the plot. Okay, so there were things happening that were dark but because this genre - for want of a better word - is "cozy" they don't seem half as bad compared to a really murky murder mystery.Winston was the sanest, apart from Bea, who seems to have an endless supply of biscuits, coffee and tea to feed everyone who arrives at her door. The house is like the Tardis, a room available whenever anyone needs one!I liked all the characters, although a couple were a little stereotyped, realised what was happening to Briscoe about halfway through, but felt the ending could have been wrapped up with less telling rather than showing. However, that is a small point and hardly worth bothering about. There are splashes of humour throughout which I enjoyed.A good, easy read.

We live in a rural location, so we keep a can of regular whole milk Nido (basically, whole milk with some extra iron & vitamin C) in our fridge to mix up when we run out of milk & the one local shop is closed. It's rich & creamy, with the right flavor and mouthfeel--certainly better than a Parmelat backup. My toddler is happy to drink it & I'm happy to use it on cereal or cook with it.This stuff is different. I was hoping for regular Nido with a fortification directed at toddlers. Instead, it's your basic overly sweet fakey-tasting formula. While it's not as overtly metallic tasting as your average American formula, I tastes nothing like milk. My 3-year-old asked "What is this?" after taking a sip, then asked for water instead. She's not overly picky: she's consumed everything from whole pasteurized to raw farm milk to ultrapasteurized lowfat to dry milk with equal gusto. But even a 3-year-old can tell this is "not milk." And a quick glance at the ingredients confirms it's the usual junky formula stuff: notfat dry milk with oil, sugar, conr syrup & a host of other make-do junk.I've had a good experience in the past with the Nido brand, and so mistakenly assumed this would be actual (if dehydrated) food, not an over-engineered food-like product. Oh well.If you kid likes formula and sweetened milk, they might like this. If they drink regular milk & not a ton of sugar-processed stuff, they'll probably find it off-putting. I sampled it, and while it was noewhere near as gross as toddler enfamil, it still had a weird, overly-sweet flavor & greasy mouth feel. Luckily, at least this stuff isn't terribly tinny, so we can salvage it a pinch on cereal.

I happened to have some regular kisses on hand to compare with these. Physically, they're much larger (see picture), and they're almost twice as heavy (9g ea vs. 5g for the regular). The Deluxe ones are wrapped in textured gold foil with a tan and brown printed tissue paper.The flavor is completely different. The standard Hershey's chocolate has it's place (namely, s'mores, peanut butter kisses, and trick-or-treat bags), and I've certainly eaten my share, but let's face it: it's the bottom tier. Sure, if it's WWII and a bunch of them fall from they sky, you're psyched; but you don't go seeking it out in modern life. It's the chocolate of last resort, fine if you need a fix & only have access to a gas station or vending machine.The chocolate in Kisses Deluxe is much nicer--creamier, and none of the hard waxy texture of a Hershey bar, nor the chalkiness of a Kiss. Besides the toasted hazelnut classing it up, it's got crispies that look and taste like the shell of a Ferrero Rocher. In fact, that's the overall flavor profile her, but with a bit less of the airy crunch and more chocolate--a good thing, in my book.The price is decent (about $4 bag at current price). Btw, my bag had 14, not 15. I'd put them in the same product category as those little bags of Ghiradelli squares--the packaging & product quality are about the same. Not ultra fancy, but nicer than the candy bar aisle, more nice adult candy dish than trick-or-treat bowl.

This size is great in the freezer for bulk fruit & veg, bought cheaply in season then frozen in a single layer on a silpat-covered baking sheet, then transferred to large bags for use in the winter when prices climb. Ditto pre-making hors d'ouvres or cookie dough balls for make-ahead convenience.The seal is liquid-tight, making these bags excellent for freezing soups and batters flat for freezer storage efficiency. Use one of these--love it & it works for sandwich to gallon size bags--for hands-free bag filling: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0040LU3Y8. I'd recommend no more than 3 quarts batter or soup--using the full gallon capacity makes filling and sealing pretty dodgy, and makes flat freezing less efficient, because they're puffier. Fill all your bags, remove as much air as possible, then freeze a stack of them on a baking sheet (stack no more than 3 high for max stability). You can label near the zipper seal and face them all the same way for best orientation for reading a nice stack in the freezer.The slider style bag is critical for liquid ingredients, keeping filling and sealing tidy and convenient--you don't want to be fumbling with a bag full of soup. The Hefty brand is much better than store brand sliders, and is sturdy enough to be reusuable (rinse well in hot water with a little soap for greasy contents, and dry on a rack dryer--mine is made of tinker toys).  If you're reusing for liquids, test the seal first with a quart of water and save yourself a mess. These aren't engineered for a lot of reuse/abuse, but they're certainly reusable with a bit of care.The bulk price on Amazon (currently $14.99, with a 15% off coupon) with or without coupon, is comparable to my local Target & better than the local grocery store. Prices fluctuate wildly on Amazon, though, so it's best to keep an eye out and make sure the value is still good when you order.

This is basically a silky Hoisan-based sauce that could probably be easily produced yourself, but I like the mindless convenience of it for a quick dinner with whatever meat & veggies I need to use up in my fridge. I typically use 3x ormore the volume of veggies called for on the packet--whatever I have on hand--but I always include a can of water chestnuts, which give it the right texture. You can use raw meat, ground or diced or leftover cooked meat (pork, chicken, beef & shrimp are all good), and it comes out nicely no matter what. It's also good without meat at all, though it's less filling, so extra chopped peanuts will help beef it up. We prefer to use interior nappa cabbage leaves over lettuce, as it's sturdier with better crunch. We also like it with brown rice, on the side or in the wraps.I feel a little sheepish about using this kind of product, but it's a time saver, inexpensive & is an easy way to add a lot of veggies to your diet or use up rando odds & ends in your fridge that aren't enough for a meal on their own

True to its "intensive healing" claim. Without a good cream, my hands are a wreck year-round, and especially bad in winter. Most drugstore brands are a waste of time or require too-frequent application. This (like the Kiehl's I normally use) is a once-a-day cream, even with frequent handwashing. It keeps my dry hands smooth and soft, and saves my dry feet from their natural, scaly monkey-foot appearance.It's definitely a quality cream. My only complaint is the slightly coated feel your hands get about 10 minutes after application. I don't notice it on my feet, but on my hands, its distracting enough to rinse them (which fixes it immediately without reducing its overall effects). This is a small thing, but annoying, especially if you're driving or otherwise without access to running water.Just a side note, the "exfoliating" descriptor made me expect a cream more like the old Pretty Feet and Hands, a cream used to loosen and rub off dead skin. This isn't like that, though it does soften calluses on the feet for much more effective exfoliation.

This went together quickly and intuititively with the enclosed hex wrench and simple instructions. 7 bolts total. Do remove the cover off the large, bottom trunk piece for fastest assembly (not mentioned in instructions, but velcroed for easy removal). Frame is rather thin MDF. IT's fine for our 10 lb cats, but I think it would strain under larger animals and definitely would not take the abuse our toddler dished out to our other Armarkat tree (which it handled pretty gracefully; but she was banished from that one when she was about 28 lbs).The covering is plush rather than carpet, so some cats may not use it for their claws. Ours tend to prefer bare wood to carpet anyway, but the sisal-wrapped posts of the Armarkat tree do get some attention. Upholstry loving cats may actually prefer the loosly covered plush fabric "trunks;" so far, this tree mostly gets lounging and stalking use, not scratch duty.We have two 10-lb cats & they love their new hangout.Like most non-$300-500 ultra modern, fancy cat furniture, this ones on the fugly side, but it  the cutesy aspect makes it pretty comparible with playroom furniture and toys, so it will feel at home in many a den, kid's room, family room, or rumpus room.

I've been using two ScoopFree boxes for 5 years with very few problems, so the Scoopfree box is my benchmark. We refill the "disposable" trays for several months, so the major expense is the litter and/or trays, but frankly I've been pleased with crystal littler over clumping. I know YMMV by household, but with our 2 small cats, the crystal litter works great. We've only had this one in use for 3 weeks, so I don't feel confident with that 4th star just yet, but I'll update after a year if it's still going strong.This box is easy to assemble but not easy to move (the waste basket won't stay attached), so assemble where you intend to use it.Here are the things it has going for it over the Scoopfree (Mostly it boils down to the litter itself, not the box, which is why I can't rate this a clear winner yet)--You can use any litter, a huge plus for some people, and I haven't done a side-by-side comparison (usage rates and time are different), but I suspect clumping will be much cheaper, as there is much more market competition. You could also use flushable or natural litter, which is a definite benefit in my book--While still ugly, the colors aren't as obnoxious as the Scoopfree's purple (though they did come out with neutral replacement accessories)--No trays, so easier to clean if you don't toss the tray--the collection system is also tidier and less prone to spilling, without or without the liners (I haven't been able to find them)--quieter, at least initially (3 weeks isn't really a workout). If your box is in your bedroom, this may matter to you--Better odor control for a shared box. We have one box per cat in our home, but I've been using this at my mom's house while my dad's undergoing chemo because there's already so much more to do without worrying about the litterbox, so her two smallish cats have been sharing the box. She had them share a scoopfree in the past and thinks this does a better job with the smell.--May do a better job with urineDownside vs. Scoopfree-Doesn't automatically rake after each use. Instead, you can select various time frames for it to rake. Hourly is an option and would probably be sufficient for most cats (though less so for the humans stuck with smelling their stinky poop until it's raked)-Needs to be topped off and emptied way more frequently, because the clumping litter really adds to the overall volume of the waste. But this will still be WAY better than a traditional box if that's what you're used to.-Unknown product life. This is a newer product without a long-term use history.Bottom line: So far, this seems to be a thoughtfully designed machine with some real benefits over the ScoopFree. Time will tell how well the motor and overall integrity holds up. Since the initial price is close, I would need to see at least a year of product life ($10/month) for it to be a good value. (With 5+ yrs of use, my ScoopFrees have amortized to about $1.50 a month and counting.)UPDATE (reposted from a comment question)You have to clean out is one a lot more frequently than the Scoop Free--probably once a week or more with one small cat vs once a month with the scoop free--because the clumping liter means you're scooping pee as well as poop. But it is way easier to clean out, since you're just dumping the waste instead of the whole box, and the little trash can just unhooks from the frame. On ours, the liner has stayed in place and I've just dumped the waste into the outside garbage.So it requires more day-to-day attention (much less than a traditional box, and none of the gross sifting), but it's not a terrible chore.The regular clumping litter also seems to track a LOT more than the crystal, which is a huge downside to me. The scoop free requires no day-to-day attention, but the end of the litter's life is stinkier, I think.I think ultimately, you have to weigh whether the mess of tracked litter is a bigger deal to you or a somewhat stinky week at the end of the litter's life (which you could avoid by being less lazy than I about changing the litter) is a bigger deal. We have a large home and out of the way boxes, so less tracking and less attention beats better overall control and more attention. If you have a smaller home or apartment & the box is close to your living space, this box might be a better fit (or changing the ScoopFree at 3 weeks instead of 4).My mom prefers this & clumping litter to the Scoop Free (which I encouraged her to buy in the past & she has since abandoned). From what I've seen, I'm still happier with my Scoop Free, however.In the end, this box (easier to clean) with crystal litter (empty less often because it's not scooping pee, as it is with clumping) could be the perfect machine for us--but I'm reserving judgment until I see how long it lives.

Based on other reviews, perhaps there is a lot of variation in the batches (read: flaky QC). But mine were inedibly bland. I suffered through 3 pointless jars, then chucked the rest in the garbage. Seriously bland. With other brands, even Kraft, which is not exactly known as a powerhouse of bold flavor, I typically use prepared horseradish 1:3-4 with ketchup for cocktail sauce and about the same with mayo for roast beef sandwiches for a medium zip. With this stuff, even 1:1 had no bite, and trying to use more than that gave an acrid flavor and yucky mouth feel.I'm a cheapskate, so tossing 9 jars into the garbage with no regrets (except that I didn't do it sooner) shows how disappointing this was.

These are perfectly good cupcake papers, and the colors do stay reasonably bright (not very opaque, so the light ones look much better with light cakes than chocolate), but contrary to the description, you do need to use a muffin tin unless you're making a pull-apart cupcake cake and you want a mostly continuous shape--or you don't mind misshapen or very flat cupcakes. They won't just collapse, but they're not rigid enough to maintain a tight cupcake shape and form a nice crown without a tin.I baked them on a sheet pan, spaced the distance apart of a typical muffin tin, and got the results picutured. I used exactly 1/4 cup batter (I use a level disher scoop) and the new  Pillsbury Purely Simple cake mix that's basically just pantry staples without all the chemical additives--makes great tasting cake, btw. I didn't take pictures of the earlier batch, but the same batter in the cups in a muffin tin looked lovely and nicely crowned, so the batter is not the culprit.For a pull-apart cake, I'd space them so the edges are just touching, and you should get a nice solid mass.Pics show baking without tin, and chocolate cupcakes baked in the 2 colors.Overall, nice cups, WAY  better than the pastel grocery store cups, not quite as hood as Wilton or other specialty cups.

Setup (download the app, follow the onscreen instructions) was easy on my iPad. While I find most of the extra info (bmi, water weight, etc.--and bone weight? can't seem to find any useful and consistent parameters for this anywhere) extraneous, I do love that every time I hop on the scale, all my deets are getting recorded and sent up in the ether for me to review later. Will this amount to weight loss? Probably not for me, since just knowing my weight doesn't help much if I'm still overeating, but it's fun and allows me to track weight to life situations with zero effort on my part.If you're within about 3 pounds apart, the scale will automatically see a second person as a different use and prompt setup, tracking them separately, which was pretty cool.It totally looks like an Apple product, or something from Sleeper or 2001. You don't see the display until you activate it by stepping on or tapping it.I also love that you can nudge it and get the temperature and humidity in the room, as we're in an old building and our sole thermostat is 100 feet away down a long hall.Word to the wise, on the app: if you're a stocky male with a few extra pounds, odds are good it's going to call you obese. My partner, who is far less overweight than me, but short and stocky (and also a dude; so the bmi parameters are tougher), was called out as obese by the app, which put him in a bad mood for the next day. :) I don't think anyone human would call him obese, but the app sure did. Pro tip: if the app calls your partner obese and he's not, especially if you're the fatter one and it generously pegged you as simply overweight, do no laugh and laugh and laugh. It will not improve his mood.One tech quirk that may have been a fluke: I did notice a lag in my records when our DSL failed for about a week, even when I repeatedly synched. The next day, all the old results magically appeared.

I'm not a huge jerky eater, and I often find the specialty flavors overly-sweet, but I was totally into this. I didn't know what to expect of pork jerky, but this really tasted like bulgogi! Obviously, it's not a juicy steaming charred pile of meaty wonderfulness, but for dried meat, it's a pretty darn tasty approximation!I gobbled it up in 2 servings that seemed pretty modest, so I think the 3 servings the package alledges are wishful thinking. But at 270 calories for the whole bag, not too shabby (though the 24g of sugar for the whole bag is a little less thrilling--I'm not a sugar counter, but my dad's diabetic, so I always keep an eye to sneaky sugars).The meat itself was thick, lean, moist, fairly tender and nicely chewy.

While this book's main focus (an of course the author's own area of expertise) is on high-achieving professional women, it also addresses many more universal issues that contribute to the awkward struggle between family and career, and differences in expectation and treatment of women and men.I'm a feminist who downshifted my career ambitions (or rather, realized they were more a social construct than my own genuine ambitions) well before starting a family in my early 40s, but the work/caregiving/partner struggle has still been a genuine challenge. This book demonstrates how the women's career/family balance problem really is fundamentally a care problem, a more significant social problem outside of simple workplace sexism. It also really opend my eyes to subtle shifts in view and language could really help address the issue, and how my own gender biases and presumptions have probably worked against me. I can also look back with a little shame about my past treatment and views of co-workers with family obligations when I was a child-free.I really like that the book addresses the broader problem of care generally, including elder care and sick loved ones. I'm getting to the age where my friends and I are beginning to worry after and care for our parents, and care of older family members is something the current generation of workers will really struggle with.I do wish there was more on offer here for working class women (as a very small business owner, I'm not quite working class, but the virtues and pitfalls of corporate or professional life don't really resonate with me), but the author is wisely sticking with the world she knows, and pointing out that even the limited flexibility of many career women is a luxury far out of the reach of poor and working-class women (and, I might add, the growing body of self-employed, contactors and freelancers with a more comfortable life but little or no social or economoc safety net).I especially appreciated the practical points in the end chapters about starting conversations and examining your own biases.Personally, as someone off the driven career track, much of the book's specifics don't apply to my current situation, but I found it a worthwhile read for the overall thoughtful message and the shift it brought to my perspective. I wish I could get my dad to read it. :)

I'm generally disgusted by canned dog food (my parents feed canned and I want to barf whenever I encounter it), but this is far less stinky than your average canned food, and I have to admit it is nice to have a little something to offer my good boy as an easy doggy junky treat on occasion. These come in pulltop cans and the contents (big stable cubes with a scattering if rice and thin gravy) slide out willingly without the aid of a utensil to wash, so you don't have to deal with throwing up a little in your mouth to feed it. Consequently, the can also rinses easily, so it's simple to recycle the can without a big production or the guilt of throwing away a recyclable.I can't get on board with feeding cans as primary food--my 50 lb Shorthaired's recommended dose is 2 cans, way too expensive (and messy, and packaging-intensive) vs kibble. But it's a nice treat or stopgap to have on hand when you accidentally run out of kibble.

Smooth lightweight cream that's not as greasy feeling as most anit-fizz gels. Lightweight and reminds me more of a silky conditioner. I use lightly it on dry hair to smooth witch hairs oe give a casual, messy updo a more polished appearance.

Great for "beach hair" or messy Frenchy buns. Brings out the wave and gives hair definition for tousled hair, and gives some definition and refinement to a messy French bun or updo. I like to apply it to dry hair, then tousle or scrunch and let dry. The updo works best if you apply, scrunch, then go ahead and put your hair up before letting it dry. Once dry, it's a bit stiff and hard to work with, and if you brush it out, it looks dull.I think this is pretty much just rebranding mousse (though this is not as dull as mousse--unless you brush it out after it's dry)

Excellent for smoothing witch hairs (coarse grays that pop up and look all crazy) or taming ragged looking split end when you don't have time for a trim. A little goes a long way--a pea-sized squirt rubbed between the palms and smoothed all over combed hair was enough for my medium-length, medium-thickness hair. If you use more, can get a little heavy and greasy looking by the end of the day. For split ends, rub it first into the ends, then smooth your hair with whatever's left on your hands.Also very good and sleeking up a sloppy ponytail into a more finished looking do, and for touching up dry or oversprayed dull spots if you've used a "beach hair" product for a nice messy bun, but it made your hair look a bit dryer than you wanted.

Although I love Diet Coke, I'm not a big fan of artificial sweeteners in coffee or sweets. But I was looking for a good treat to have on hand for my diabetic dad. He uses fake sugar in his coffee and likes this just fine. For me, it's flat and synthetic tasting made with water, but much better made with milk. That's always true of cocoa mix, but makes an especially big difference with sugar free.

These came in September in Kansas. It was a bit warmer than usual (highs in the low 80s) but this was delivered to a shaded back door. The chocolates were still melted into a single glob at the bottom of each package instead of the 4 small nuggets. I've had other chocolates delivered in warmer weather, but I think the upright tube packaging makes them more suseptible to melting. The melted and reset chocolate wasn't horrible, but the texture and flavor were a bit off. The Payday bites were fine (in that they were still distinct nuggets; of course, they still have the misfortune of being Paydays, candybars that I'm pretty sure are only favored by vanishing Greatest Generation grandpas and people who have given up chocolate for Lent).

These labels are cute and fairly easy to use--but be sure to check your paper setting before printing & make sure you select postcard and/or uncheck "fit to page" if your default comes up as letter size. I used the online printing tool at avery.com and was pleased with the results.The kraft paper gives rustic/old-timey/green look to product or favor labels. But like all of the small-format Avery labels, the per-label cost is high, and it's easy to misprint and waste the (very expensive) sheets. In general, I find the letter size products to be easier to use and more economical.These print fine, and the print-to-edge/bleed gives them a good, finished look.

These labels are cute and fairly easy to use--do check your paper setting before printing & make sure you select postcard--with the online printing tool at avery.com. They're nice for semi-rustic product or favor labels, and the pre-printed outline gives them a more finished look. But like all of the small-format Avery labels, the per-label cost is high, and it's easy to misprint and waste the (very expensive) sheets. In general, I find the letter size products to be easier to use and more economical.

Like the other Avery chalkboard labels, the package shows these in an inappropriate, single-use application. These are more useful in a situation where you want to be able to change the label wording as needed, and be able to remove them readily if necessary.I like them for labeling snack and pantry jars--they adhere well but remove if necessary, and readily accept both regular chalk and bistro chalk pens. In both cases, there is a bit of faint ghosting when you wipe off the writing, but it's so subtle that you can't readily see it when you write over it. However, this shape isn't as handy or attractive for container labels as some of the other styles. This shape is a very tricky to remove without deforming the edges, so the "removable" part applies less here than with some other shapes (yes, you can remove it, but you may not be able to reuse it).They have a nice texture to grab the chalk (especially nice with the chalk markers, which like to smear or smooth surfaces), and they're thicker than chalkboard Contact paper (which I still prefer slightly because it's blacker, cheaper, and can be cut into whatever shapes you like), which is nice both for application and removal.My main problem with the Avery labels is the price, currently almost $2 per label--5 - 8X the price of other die-cut chalkboard labels sold on Amazon and twice the cost of a roll 18" x 6-foot Contact chalkboard sticker paper.

The package shows these in an inappropriate, single-use application (gift tags--unless you're planning a long life of regifting--then it's ideal). These are more practical in a situation where you want to be able to change the label wording as needed, and be able to remove them readily if necessary.I like them for labeling snack and pantry jars--they adhere well but remove if necessary, and readily accept both regular chalk and bistro chalk pens. In both cases, there is a bit of faint ghosting when you wipe off the writing, but it's so subtle that you can't readily see it when you write over it.They have a nice texture to grab the chalk (especially nice with the chalk markers, which like to smear or smooth surfaces), and they're thicker than chalkboard Contact paper (which I still prefer slightly because it's blacker, cheaper, and can be cut into whatever shapes you like), which is nice both for application and removal. The shape is a big tricky to remove without deforming an edge a bit, but it's doable if you're careful.My only quibble is that they're a bit spendy (Currently almost $2 per label)--worthwhile if you're not crafty/limited for time, but a pack of 8 stickers is twice the price of a six-foot roll of 18" Contact paper. Again, this is thicker, but the math is hard to swallow. The color is off-black, for a chalkboardly look but slightly lower contrast than the true black Contact.

Looking at the ingredients, it's a mild irritant with a scent that is unappealing to animals like dogs with 50x our scent power (it's rather bland to the human nose). Seems to dissuade our persistent dog from fussing too intently where it has been applied, at least when it's pretty fresh (we haven't had any rain to test it & the forecast is dry for a while yet).I wish they made a product that turned off dogs but not cats, to keep the dog from chasing rabbits into the hay shed, but left the cats contentedly mousing in the same spots. As it is, I'm reluctant to use it everywhere I'd like to discourage the dog.One caveat: if you have chickens, keep them in while you apply it. I don't think they'd gorge on it, and I don't think it would do more harm than mildly irritate them, but I discovered my chickens getting very excited and running towards me when they saw/heard me sprinkling the shaker can. It does sound/look like you're scattering scratch grains, so they could accidentally ingest some and/or irritate their eyes/membranes with the granules and dust. Luckily, mine were running from a distance, so I was able to stop and distract them before they got into trouble.

I have medium length wavy hair, and this product is excellent for smoothing out frizz and gray witch hairs. I prefer to use it sparingly on dry hair (vs the recommended wet hair instruction--the product extends drying time, so it takes too long to dry if you don't use a blow dryer) to smooth frizz and define soft waves. It's especially nice if you have split ends but no time for a trim--you can apply it lightly to ends and it softens them and makes them look smooth and finished.Also great to apply lightly all over before making a messy bun or ponytail updo--gives it that relaxed messy look but with softness and definition that still makes your "no-effort" updo look finished.Use very sparingly on dry hair or it will be heavy and greasy. A pea sized amount is enough for the ends and light smoothing of my medium-length dry hair.

Good enough mid-range coffee, neither objectionable or remarkable. I found it to be marginally better than the Sam's Club Donut Shop coffee my mom usually buys for her Keurig. No problems with the pods.

Took just a few minutes to assemble. Rolls smoothly and feels sturdy, with a nice height range and a good bar for your feet at high end of the heights if you're a short person like me.Just a caveat: if you're not very heavy, just using your weight to seat the pieces (as the instructions note) may not be adequate as directed. The shaft felt a little loosey-goosey at first, so I inverted the stool (onto the cardboard packing) and stood on the crossbars of the base, making sure my weight was even and lightly bouncing. This fully seated the shaft and made the stool stable.Good looking stool at a cheap price. Not the fanciest in the land, but at under $50 bucks, I'm not expecting a $300 work stool, either.

If you've tried dry shampoo in the past, you'll find this product MUCH better at controlling oil. I don't like to wash my hair too much, as it tends to get dry, and I find my hair generally looks better & styles much better when it's dirty. However, my bangs tend to get oily much sooner than the rest of my hair, looking stringy and gross just when the rest of my hair is at its dirty-hair peak of awesomeness.I don't like the dulling appearance of dry shampoo, but this stuff is awesome, with one caveat: it takes forever to dry, and until it's dry, your hair will just look even more greasy, or like you've got a bunch of gel in it. A blow dryer would speed up the process, but I don't use one, since my hair tends to be dry overall. I use this on my bangs and occasionally roots only.As long as you have time to let this dry & comb it out, it does a great job delaying shampooing so you can enjoy the benefits of dirty hair without the grease.It does have an Axe-y scent, but it's not so overpowering that you'll smell like a teenage boy after gym class, and it dissipates pretty quickly. Fyi, I'm a 45-year-old woman with medium thick, medium-length slightly wavy hair. So, not a dude and not up for smelling like one.

This is decent mid-range chocolate, inoffensive but unremarkable. The current price on amazon ($24, or nearly 5 bucks a bar) is outrageous.I like the old-fashioned lettering and the golden paper wrappers, which make me think of Charlie & the Chocolate Factory. However, the paper wrappers pose a problem if you're ordering when it's hot. If the chocolate melts (mine did), instead of just getting a deformed bar like you would with a plastic sealed wrapper, you get a mess of chocolate embedded with metallic paper, not awesome if you have fillings and you miss a piece of the foil while you're picking it out. My package was sitting sideways as it melted, so all the bars were deformed and mushed down to one side of the box, looking pretty ugly (important since this is a gift box) and leaving a big gap that made it look like someone had filched a bar from the box.Some chocolate survives melting and resetting well, but this does not. Not only was it blobbly with no discernable squares, but the reset chocolate was permeated with--let's call it "chocolate rust"--that white stuff that forms when chocolate melts and resets, or just sits for a long time--in a strange globular pattern, and the texture was crumbly and unappealing.Hershey's chocolate is not exactly "the good stuff" but it's usually good for a respectable chocolate fix. But this product is exceptionally poor in shipping, so I'd be very reluctant to send it as a gift, as the results under stress are very poor. Combined with the high price (~$30/lb), I'd opt for a different product if you're shipping anywhere near the warm months. I'm in Kansas in September, so it's not typically dangerous weather for chocolate (I've had other chocolate shipments in the last week or so with no deterioration, though maybe they got luckier with overcast days or a cooler spot on my porch), but since you can't predict the heat of a mailbox or porch, I'd avoid this until mid-fall thru early spring--or an even shorter window if you're shipping in the southwest.

This product is easy to use and seems to put off my dog. I'm skeptical about its ability to last through much rain, but the weather hasn't put that to the test yet.I'm trying to keep my German Shorthair away from my sheep and their hay shed. He's after mice and rabbits, not the sheep, but he makes them anxious; and he often hurts his feet pursuing critters into wood piles.The hose end sprayer is much handier than a handheld sprayer for a large barrier, but I do wish they had a hose-end product without fertilizer--the areas I need to spray are not garden areas, but places where weeds are a problem, so I'd rather not feed the weeds (or add excess chemicals to the vegetation-free areas) as I try to repel my dog.

This is a nourishing mask that's great for reviving dry hair while you soak in the bath. It doesn't have the heavy perfume of some of the other Dove products, and it's rich enough to stay in your hair and not drip all over you while it soaks in.It's not miraculous, but does give a good, smoothing boost to try hair, and helps temporarily tame spilt ends if you don't have time for a trim.
Hair feels clean and moisturized, but I can't get past the heavy perfume. If you're sensitive to perfumy products or only like light or natural scents, this won't be for you.

I don't blow dry my hair, and I found using the product on wet hair extended drying time too much. But used liberally on dry hair, then tousled a bit, gives hair perfect hold and volume for a perfect messy bun or toussled French-girl updo. Great for adding texture and bite for hairpins when your hair is just too clean and slippery.When you comb it out, your hair may look dull and dry, but if you wet your hands and tousle your hair you can quickly refresh the look and shine.Only drawback is thar it was somewhat drying on my dryish medium length hair.

I love this cleaner generally for my concrete floors & vinyl tile. The cleaning pad is roomy, the cord is nice and long. I like that you just use water for a neutral clean, or you can add a scent tablet if you like a clean laundry smekl. The removable steamer pod is excellent for cleaning gross shower corners and yucky deep cleaning tasks.It especially impressed me when I brought it to my parents house. Their dogs are what a generous person might call "imperfectlyDespite my mom's contant cleaning, there's often still a faint whiff of dog pee, I'm guessing the grout kinda locks it in. But the steam mop wiped it out, yay!It's easy to use and easy to clean, and being able to steam clean random weird surfaces (and places where the mop doesn't fit) is awesome.

If you already wash you hair every day, this gets an A. It's fairly light going on, not as slimy as a lot of anti-friz products, works in evenly, and definitely keeps down the frizz. I have medium thickness, medium-length, slightly wavy hair that gets super frizzy and witchy in humidity, and this kept it nice and smooth all day.However, in the morning after I use it, my hair feels and looks a bit heavy and greasy--it's actually fine if I'm wearing it up but too greasy to wear down.Normally (without product, or with lighter products), I only need to wash my hair about once a week.

I have several brands and different garments of anti-mosquito fabric & this is my favorite fabric. It's thin and light, with synthetic fabric to be wicking with enough cotton to feel good without being that bulk "beefy T" type stuff. This has the softness and drape of an old worn in T, but still has structural integrity.In heavy mosquitos, you'll still want to use spray on your bottom half if you have bare legs, but in very light mosquitos, it's been enough to keep them at bay.

The easy align self laminating labels are such an improvement over past-self laminating labels that require you to pisition the first label, then try to carefully place the clear plastic cover by hand. It was hard to get it perfectly lined up on the first try and impossible to reposition if you screwed up. These ones make it super easy to make a perfect, even lamination, with a thin, crystal clear cover and no bubbles.The label is perforated to make the alignment easy. You print your sign, half the page, then peel off the backing from the laminated side, then use the perforation to cleanly and evenly fold the lamination right over the printed label. Perforating instead of just scoring means it folds down very flat withoit resistance.These are large labels, so they require a little more care than the little ones. To get a perfect seal, I held up the outside edge of the laminating side as I slowly pressed down from the folded side, smoothing back and forth across the releasing the edge once it's smoothed out a little past half way.These stick well and are great for door signs and labeling equipment in technical and utility rooms.

For me, this was a little more spendy than making a DIY book with your own scans and snapfish or walgreens or one of the other book sites (especially since they always seem to have coupons), butbif you don't have your own scanner, it's a great option. It includes WASHABLE (yay!) markers, plus sheets for all the pages, plus good (if a little involved) instructions, along with a prepaid envelope for sending it all off.It's also cool collaborative project with multiple kids, parties, or kids/grandparents, etc

Okay, I honestly didn't think this would do anything more than soften my hair, and I certainly didn't expect any results after 1 use (as the bottle claims).BUT IT TOTALLY MADE MY HAIR LOOK YOUNGER AFTER ONE USE. Seriously.I'm 45, have very dark, medium thick, slightly wavy hair with a sprinkling of gray--not a huge amount, but it really stands out against my near-black hair. Somehow, this conditioner made the gray almost invisible. I don't get why--it's not colored, just looks like normal, off-white conditioner. All I can guess is that by smoothing the texture of my hair (which is dryish and kind of frizzy in the current humidity), it makes the coarser gray stand out less? I don't know. It's a mystery. But an awesome mystery.

Virtually the same as the original & works great for my Fitbit Charge. The connection can be a bit fussy, but that's true with the original as well. In fact, this one's if anything a bit more secure than the rather flaky original cable.

I've used different Self-laminating labels before, but they were fussy and required you to line up the laminating cover by hand--hard to get them perfectly centered, and easy to mess up the adhesive with your fingers. These solve both problems. Each sheet is half printable labels, half clear laminate covers. The center of the sheet is perforated to easily fold precisely down the middle and perfectly align the covers over the printed labels.Using a printer, you must print a full sheet at a time, as the paper isn't meant to withstand repeated trips through the machine. But you can laminate the labels equally well either all at once or individually, so if you were hand-printing, you could use just those you need.They print crisply and wipe clean, and look nicer than generic label maker labels. They work well on handwashable containers like spice or pantry storage jars (I wouldn't risk soaking, though), and I'm even using them inside my fridge on shelves and door cubbies, in hopes that others will observe my organization efforts if my "system" is clear. :)With the washable surface, they's also be nice for labeling homemade cleaners or beauty products in plain containers.

I live in an old reinforced concrete high school building, so I'm using several extenders to get wifi into the building's numerous dead zones. So far, this is the first non-Apple extender I've tried that was fast and breezy to set up, and required zero fiddling or workarounds to make it function perfectly.The setup process is basically: plug it in halfway between your router and desired signal location, connect to Linksys network when it appears in your list of networks, go to the setup url and either relocate the extender (I needed to.move it over one plug) or proceed with the setup, which is just selecting your network and entering the password. In minutes, I had a strong signal and could stream movies is a spot in the building which was formerly an wifi black hole, and a good strong signal extends rooms away.I also like that there's a passthrough plug, since extenders are usually space hogs, and there are never enough plugs.It's roughly the same price ($7 more at the moment), but I feel, a better signal than my Apple Airport Express units. The Apple might be a better choice if you are really strapped for plugs--even with the pass-through, it's bulky and it's shoulders will block other plugs in a 3-prong adapter, for instance. But in spots where I'm not trying to shoehorn an extra 3-4 plugs into my outlet, I think I'd pick this instead.

I'm just a casual camper, so this is definitely the nicest sleeping bag I've used. It's lightweight and really well made.I'm a chubby 5'3" and it was plenty roomy for my fat butt. It was also long/roomy enough for my 33-lb toddler to cozy in at the foot end--a nice bonus--and the excess fabric under the zip made a perfect pillow for her, too. In a pinch, this bag could work as a double-ended tandem sleeper for two small kids (or a toddler and a short adult--just as long as neither of you is a kicker. ;))I love the foot zipper--cools you down quickly if you get overheated, and at about a foot from the bottom, it's positioned high enough to be useful for shorter people. And it also really does let you walk around without getting out of the bag--I can see this being great for cold nights, migrating from the campfire to the tent.I found it a bit awkward to zip from the inside due to the draft tube/flap (designed to block air leaks) that runs the length of the zipper, but it's not a huge hardship.Kept loose, the hood is roomy enough to feel cozy but not constricting, or on warmer nights, to serve as a pillow. Super light, just a couple pounds, and I think a compression sack could make it half its size (which is already pretty compact).And this is goofy, but I LOVE  the little phone/ipod pocket inside at about chest level--very handy to have phone, keys, etc (or stash or cigs, if that's your persuasion) , secure and at the ready--and no zipper to fiddle with, but an overlapping flap (kind if like a pillow sham) to keep stuff from falling out.

Aside from the strange regional divisions (more on that in a moment), this is a wonderful, fun, educational and beautiful game. You might be able to push the lower limit of the age bracket for kids who are bright and enthusiastic about animals, but it's definitely fun and engaging enough for much older kids & adults.I love the board--a gorgeous, oversized board (6 folding panels instead of the usual 4) on linen textured stock, featuring a topographical world map, with a numbered track around it for keeping score, and little panels for betting on different aspects of the various animals' features and habitats. I love the simple, colorful wooden markers used to bet and keep score. The animal info cards are oversided, attractive, and ample. And while the rules are a bit involved to get a handle on, they make sense and are easy to follow once you get going. I love that there's a gambling aspect as well as pure knowlege--that makes it great fun to guess, and easier to keep the scores close if one or more players aren't really knowledgeable about animals, but are good guessers/strategizers.The only thing puzzling about the game are the very strage geographical divisions on the map. I can't speak to the other continents, but the divisions for North America are strange, both in areas they encompass--which cover a weird swath of unrelated habitats--but also in name. "California" covers the whole West Coast; "Central America" includes a good chunk of Mexico; "Missississippi" is everything south of the Great Lakes on the Eastern half of the US (so: Florida and Michigan in the same region); and New England is in "Newfoundland." The southwestern desert seems to be lumped in with the Rockies (two wildly different habitats). So that all seems pretty weird to me, but I'm too ignorant of regional geography outside of North America to know if the whole map is as, let's say, quirky.

Nice cheery color and huge, easy to read numbers that you can read from anywhere in the yard. Can't speak to the freezing temps yet, but it's definitely accurate in the warm end of the range.The packaging includes a punch-out template for mounting, a nice feature.The only downside I can see is that you have to get pretty close to read the Celsius. Practically speaking, doesn't matter much to me, but it would be handy when you want to report your weather to friends out of the US.

My go-to hand cream is Kiehl's, which I still prefer to this, because of it's lighter, medicinal scent.This cream has a dimethicone (silicone polymer) base that gives it that characteristic slippery-but-not-greasy feel as you rub it in.  After a few seconds, it absorbs, giving you skin an emollient barrier that makes your skin feel immediately softer and slows drying.I feel it softens as well as Kiehl's and lasts as well, but it does give my hands a slightly shinier appearance that, in my opinion, makes them look older. That might just be a personal association with gradmas and hand creams; I don't know.What I don't like is the very strong, long-lasting floral scent. In its defense, it is actually a very NICE scent--not cheap or synthetic smelling; just not what I'm looking for in a hand cream (neutral to herbal is my preference). It is a pleasant, old-fashioned scent. Almost reminds me of rosepetal jelly. I think  wouldn't object to it in a perfume or flowers; I just don't want every (or more accurately, any) skin product I use to be strongly perfumed.

I love this pressure cooker with a couple of caveats. My points of comparison are my other Maximatic electric pressure cooker (8qt, love love love), my giant Presto 23-qt pressure canner (conventional stove top) and two other conventional pressure cookers I've been using for years.For everyday use (I use my electric cookers 1-3x a week; the stovetop ones only get hauled out during canning season), you can't beat an electric pressure cooker. You can cook things so freaking fast (tender pulled pork in 75 minutes, a roast in an hour, dried beans--without soaking--in under 30 minutes, chicken in 10 minutes, brown rice in 23 minutes, and lots of other dishes you wouldn't think of pressure cooking--get the America's Test Kitchen or Hip Pressure Cooking cook book), without having to hover around and fiddle with the burner or risk overcooking. I almost always use the time settings instead of the preprogrammed settings. I seriously could not manage without this appliance. Before I got an electric pressure cooker, I only used my pressure cookers to can and for the occasional stew. I'm just too easily distracted for them.Vs. my larger Maximatic, this machine is prettier and better suited to standard pressure cooking recipes (almost universally written for 6qt cookers. The only things I dislike (I'd really rather give it 4.5 stars) are that the cover comes off completely (the cover folds open on the larger machine, so you don't make a mess on your counter or have to struggle to find an open spot on a cluttered counter--could be a PITA if you have a tiny kitchen; and that the bowl tends to slide around inside the machine. This doesn't matter when you're pressure cooking, but I typically saut aromatics or brown meats in the pan to build flavor before pressure cooking; or finish sauces, etc., after pressure cooking. So I'm almost always stirring at some point in the preparation. And when you stir stuff in the bowl, the bowl wants to spin around in the machine. The good news is that you can actually hold the edge of it in place without a potholder--the heat is all at the bottom, and the edges of the top stay rather cool, probably because it's such a tall pot.I've been using my other maximatic machine weekly for almost 2 years, so the nonstick pan is pretty far from nonstick now, though still perfectly serviceable--no flaking or scaling. But the stainless pot on this one will give it a much longer life. It is very heavy gauge stainless and has the measuring marks stamped into the sides, very handy. The lid is also heavy stainless--it reminds me of a conventional pressure cooker lid more than the larger machine's lid, which reminds me more of a rice cooker (both in the weight and that it folds open).As for pressure canning, this pot will hold 4 pint jars, somewhat less than the bigger machine, but still very handy for small batch canning--I love it for pressure canning leftover soups, stews, and chili (saving freezer space), canning dried beans (instructions here: http://amatterofpreparedness.blogspot.com/2010/02/i-dont-have-time.html), and canning small batches of produce (usually something in my CSA share I won't have time to eat). You can also use canning jars to render fat (tallow, lard & schmaltz) without the stink and mess and splatter.

I prefer the 3M fastener to velcro for 3 reasons: it stays tidier (the loop side isn't fuzzy and therefore doesn't get as ragged and worn as velcro), the sound (the 3M type kind of clicks together and has a quieter, less obnoxious sound when separated (I know this sounds crazy, like Jerry Seinfeld's dad, but having a sleeping baby has made me more aware of surprisingly loud sounds :)), and the adhesive is better. They're also easier to keep clean in dusty situations, and the rolls are more uniform (there are always weird bumps and wrinkles in my adhesive backed Velcro rolls).3M knows adhesive.  I've never found a velcro adhesive I really liked. Either they were too gummy and had seepage along the edges that made everything dirty and gross, or they didn't adhere as well to certain surfaces (particularly fabric--and sew-on is not always practical).I like that the 3M fasteners are targeted to specific applications (read the description to make sure you're getting your best adhesive), as I usually have a specific project in mind when I buy a roll. I have several half-rolls of Velcro brand that didn't work out for the project I had in mind, so I like that I can get a better idea up front with the 3M. As with velcro, the rolls are a *much* better value than the chintzy little cardboard backed hang-tag packages also on offer.

This memoir is hilarious, incredibly candid and self-aware without being obnoxiously self-effacing. It covers both the highlights and serious lowlights of a young Jewish kid's coming of age in an orthodox community. The subject matter can be weird and raunchy (in that what's on a preteen's or teenager's mind is probably always pretty weird and raunchy) it's always oddly sweet--his sex fantasies are as apt to include marriage and family dinners as porn-fueled banging.I loved getting a glimpse into a totally different world (and that he explained it so well--for instance, I had no idea that the bar mitzvah Torah readings were from scrolls without punctuation or vowels--give you a whole new appreciation for the performance). But I also loved that in the end, kids are kids, and while Eytan's childhood experience would be pretty much the opposite of mine (non-professional middle class/suburban/public school/lapsed Catholic/only child/school-loving/female/with a working mom--and a decade earlier), teen angst and idiotic ideas about sex and romance are universal.

So far this season, I've been happy with this instead of my usual DEET-base Off. While the scent is really strong, it's not quite as obnoxious as regular Off (but much less pleasant than Off Skintastic)--it reminds me of baby aspirin, actually. I like that it's not as greasy, and I hope it's gentler for my toddler (I always feel a bit skeptical of mainstream brands' "natural" products). The scent lasts way longer than I'd like. While it's annoying, I does encourage me to wash it off my hands after application, and it reminds me to wash it off the kiddo when we get back inside. (I don't think it's strictly necessary, but seems like a good idea with chemicals.)The substance is just too viscous for the pump it's in, but the pump seems to loosen up after a few weeks and be easier to use. Initially, it was really, really hard to pump. I had to hold the pump with one hand and pump with the other. After about a quarter of the bottle was gone, it was easier to pump, though a bit stiff.It is a bit messy, as you'll need to spread it around, as it's a thick milky liquid that comes out in heavy drops instead of a fine mist, so best to apply it indoors so you can wash your hands.

This is fine for cookies, but has ruined the texture of everything leavened (be it with yeast, eggs, or baking powder/soda) I've made with it. Anything leavened will be too moist and gummy. Sweet (sticky) brown rice flour & tapioca starch are the first 2 ingredients, which explains the awful gumminess.Since cookies & brownies are easy to make gluten-free, and pretty much any non-wheat flour, including just plain old oats zipped in the food processeor, will work, I can't really give it any credit for producing acceptable cookies.

The only problem with this cooler is that the water spout opens when you pull on it (versus the type where you push down to release water), so if you're used to the othe type, you may be in the habit of pulling it to the edge of the table by the spout. With that type, no problem; but if you do that here, you'll get water all over the place.Theoretically, it's a nice design, and it does take less effort than the other type of dispenser, but since the handles are high and on the sides, the spout is the natural place for people to grab, so unless you put a little sign on the spout, you may find yourself cleaning up a lot of water.

We also have a big 17" commercial scrubber for the big jobs in our building, but I wanted something I could bust out for light jobs and small rooms. As long as you go slowly, this does a fine job.I like the smell of the cleaner that came with it, but it also does well with plain water. easy to clean, but I did find I had to empty the dirty water before I finished the clean reservoir. It will start sputtering long before it's full, a bit annoying.

Nice little magnets, but hold nowhere near nine pounds. I'm ignorant how those numbers are calculated, so maybe 9 means something else, like it takes 9 lbs of force to remove them? Either way, the only hold a couple pounds, even when suspended from above.I just wanted them to hold up signs in my shop and aprons in my kitchen, so I'm satisfied. From experience, I look for a rating that's about 4x my actual need.

If you like a spongy waffle with a soft crust, you'll be happy with this "complete" mix. For my part, after a lot of experimenting with additions, I'm satisfied with this mix because of the convenient size for a large batch, but I do add whey for half the water (milk would work, too; I just usually have extra whey from cheesemaking), cornstarch, butter, oil & vanilla. I'm just lazy enough (and I've never found a homemade recipe that I just loved) that the convenience and being able to successfully doctor it without adding eggs (as most mixes need), make it wothwhile.Also, because you can get away without added eggs, the batter doesn't separate for at least a week, so you can portion out a werk of waffles in your fridge. Pancke mix doctored with eggs separates within a day or two, as does homemade.

We have very hard water & I love that these don't show water spots or fingerprints thanks to the pebbled surface. They're not glamorous, but can take a lot of abuse. We use the clear because I like to be able to see they're clean & feel the colored ones hide tea or soda residue.

Compared to the full range of aprons out there, these are about a 3, average size, on the thin side, decent manufacturing. For the price, they're a shiny 5 stars.And since all-cotton aprons are getting harder to find (most commercial aprons in this price range are a bit roomier, but usually 70/30 or at best 50/50 poly/cotton), if you want something to dye or paint (or dye or paint in--so it will get satisfyingly stained with your efforts), this is an excellent choice.If you want a cooking apron, the poly blend options are probably a better choice, as 100% cotton gets dingy quickly, even with bleach.

If your main objective is to get more protein into a picky toddler (or adult), and you stick with just saucing freshly cooked pasta, you'll probable be happy with this pasta. It does not take abuse very well, so it won't hold up as well as traditional pasta in dishes that need a fair abount of stirring or baking (mac& cheese, baked ziti). The texture is a bit more like the older versions of gluten free pasta, a bit more crumbly and with a less elastic bite. I suspect that, like whole wheat pasta, over time I may object to it less, or even come to like it, as I now really like whole wheat pasta and brown rice (as long as they're used appropriately).But since the whole reason I bought this was to see my toddler through this pasta-centric phase she's in, and she doesn't seem to notice a difference (we do eat whole wheat pasta around here about 30% of the time), I'm happy. But it won't be replacing traditional pasta in our pantry for general cooking.At a playdate lunch yesterday, 3 toddlers gobbled it up--including one picky eater who ate hers plain. The rest of us had it in homemade mac & cheese. The adults weren't wild about the texture & thought the flavor a bit beany, but declared it passable.

Part memoir, part love letter to the traditional farming of the Lake District, and part practical guide to raising sheep, this book gives a gritty but beautiful view of a way of life that is invisible to most. It has a stream-of-consciousness feel to it, drifting around in time and place, with anecdotes about personal life and family, technical aspects of shepherding, breeding, showing sheep, and what life looks like surviving or struggling to survive in a very specialized world on a very particular piece of geography.Though some of the shepherding is peculiar to the Lake District, anyone, anywhere, with an interest in sheep or wool (or, more generally, where their fiber or food come from) should really enjoy this book. If you're a shepherd yourself, from a tiny hobby fiber flock keeper like myself (who doesn't feel up to the hefty title of "shepherd") to a real shepherd with a large commercial flock, you'll especially relate to the weight of responsibilities, the heartache, the joy and failures, the muck and beauty of The Shepherd's Life.I loved the cultural/geographical viewpoint and family perspective, but I also heartily appreciated it from a practical point of view. As a backyard sheep farmer (a handful of sheep on 10 acres), you can read a lot of guidebooks to raising sheep, but there's a no-nonsense gutunderstanding that those books just don't provide. I think if I'd read this book back before I'd started, I would have had a better understanding of 2 things that are really hard to get from a sheepman's manual; 1) just what a serious threat garden-variety friendly neighborhood dogs can be; and 2) that complacency with your flock and system, dropping your vigilance when everything's been going swimmingly for ages, is an equal peril. I've yet to read any book or get any spoken advice that captures those concepts as vividly and eloquently.Good stuff.

This is a really clever idea, but it does have a few problems. First off, I don't think the one-hour cure time allotted in the direction is ample to fully set the adhesive before hanging the boards. And if the adhesive isn't set, the board will fall of the wall within a few hours; once it's been removed, you won't be able to get it to set properly again. I had no problems with the command strips that I let cure overnight - 24 hours, but the one I tried after about 1 1/2 hours fell off the wall a few hours later. It's fairly humid here, but it's fairly humid a lot of places, and the instructions really should cover all normal contingencies.To the instructions to clean with alcohol, I would add: if you're trying anywhere near a kitchen (where you may have residual grease you can't even see/feel), I would highly recommend cleaning the area with all purpose cleaner, followed by a Magic Eraser, a clean rag wipe, then the recommended alcohol. I've had trouble with command strips near my kitchen in the past, and this did the trick.Finally, the built-in levels, which are a very clever idea, aren't well executed. Of the 3-pack of boards I received, one of my levels was cracked and empty, one had a bubble so big that it was useless (extended all the way to both sides--so maybe it had a slow leak as well) and one was perfect and handy. On the other hand, because you have a LOT of leeway in positioning (the gripping surface area on the back of the mount is about 10x as large as the command strip, so you have a lot of wiggle room in positioning), the level isn't altogether critical--since this isn't a one-shot application.I also know from experience that newly-mounted (24-48 hours) Command strip products do not work well in direct sunlight. I think when they've had longer to cure, they fare better; but otherwise, a few hours of sunlight will heat up the adhesive and they'll fall right off the wall.Each tile consist of 3 pieces (plus an optional riser than lets you overlap tiles or get more of a 3-D effect): 1) The Command strip, which has removable adhesive on  one side and a velcro type surface on the other. This adheres to your wall. 2) The black plastic mount with built-in level. It has a large patch (almost 5 x 5") patch of velcro on the wall side, and a built-in level and magnetic mount on the opposite side. This piece attaches to the command strip and holds the wall tile in place. The level (theoretically)  helps you get it set just right . 3) The lightweight tile itself, which comes in dry erase, chalkboard, art/pattern & picture frame styles. It attaches magnetically into just the right spot on the mount. The mount holds it about 1" from the wall, giving it a nice museum/canvas mount type appearance. If you use the optional riser, it is a 5x5 plastic square that attaches to the center back of the plastic mount and pushes the mount out from the wall another inch. You can easily remove and switch the face tiles around; I'd be a little more hesitant to be moving the plastic mounts on and off the wall too much, for fear of putting a strain on the adhesive strip. But you can take it off and fine-tune it a bit. If you want to use them in a new location, you can buy additional strips for under $5 package her on amazon or at Target, craft stores, etc.I'm using these for changeable signing in my business, and they do a great job. I love that you can remove them to write out your sign (for a much neater sign) and then replace them easily.

My criteria for dog foods are 1) good ingredients; 2) reasonable price, in the neighborhood of $1.50/lb, or about $45-50 for a 30lb bag; 3) dog likes it; and 4) doesn't cause farts.
