This book is seemingly based around that short, where Elsa throws a birthday party for Anna, and if your kids like it - or just like the Frozen characters in general, they'll probably love helping plan a Frozen birthday party.Personally, our family tends to choose a theme and then buy ready-made supplies and a cake and be done with it, but this book offers a series of creative ideas for a do-it-yourself endeavor. I think we can still go that route and yet use this book to add a few homemade embellishments, such as the Arendelle Spring Nectar and Flower Coasters. More creative folks, with more time on their hands, can enjoy utilizing the templates and creating their very own invitations, decorations, (cup)cakes, and party favors.Beyond that, there are a few party games everyone can utilize, but some may require familiarity with the Disney short to understand and play properly. All in all, I'd say that I f you're into creating parties from scratch, then buy the book and have fun. For the rest, there's not a whole lot here and it would be easier to get a few (free) activities online to enhance a party.

This was my first Maggie Hope mystery, and I really enjoyed it. I often hesitate to jump into ongoing series because I fear being lost, but I was able to navigate "Mrs. Roosevelt's Confidante" without feeling as though I was missing some big piece of the story.  There are clearly some ongoing character issues, particularly involving Maggie's family, that I was unclear of at first, but most everything was explained by the conclusion.  I was drawn to this actually because I enjoy seeing how presidents are characterized in historical fiction, and a mystery surrounding the Roosevelt White House was an exciting prospect.  I say "mystery" because that is how the novel is labeled, but I felt there was just a tiny bit of mystery.  I think "A Maggie Hope Adventure" would have been a better subtitle because it was all about the thrill of the chase rather than guessing who the criminals were (as they were identified from the start).Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt are not central figures, though at least Eleanor appears numerous times in the novel.  Prime Minister Winston Churchill is a far more central figure, although I found that most of the real-life figures were secondary or background characters.  And that's just fine because this novel really seems to capture the spirit of the time even with the fluid and descriptive writing style.  This would be a terrific television series, I suspect.  It was engaging and enjoyable throughout as the action took place in and around Washington, D.C., for the most part in weeks following Pearl Harbor.  And despite being set in 1941, it does an excellent job of bringing to life current real-world issues like political scandal, government wiretapping, homophobia, and racism.  One can learn a lot studying the figures of this time period and applying some of these lessons to our world today.Although I was drawn to this by the promise of a fictionalized Franklin Roosevelt, I found myself wrapped up in the novel's heroine and her friends by the end, to the point that I very well might seek out the previous adventures in this series.  Easily recommended for a quick, fun, and historical intriguing read.

I have given my daughters, currently 7 and 3 years, Hyland's products before, including the tablet allergy medicine in the past, so I can attest to it's continuous effectiveness. I like that Hyland's uses ingredients found in the "Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States," and that there is a wide range of symptoms that Complete Allergy not only helps but also prevents.Unlike a well-known allergy medicine such as Claritin or Allegra, however, Hyland's does not promise relief in 24 or even 12 hour spurts, but one dose a day tends to do well for my children.  The good thing about that is if there is a sudden attack, I don't feel bad about giving another dosage, and have even used the tablets as a "placebo/sugar" pill in the past when they whine about questionable aches and ills - it usually does the trick.I may have to stick to the tablets rather than the liquid form, though, as my older daughter declared that Complete Allergy in liquid tastes "gross." My younger one, however, said it tastes "yummy."  I think it tastes just fine, but everybody enjoys different things. All in all, it's worth a try either in liquid or tablet form.

I was eager to try this holistic cat food for my 14-year-old tabby. He is picky about a lot of things, but he tends to love his food. And this was by far the shiniest, prettiest packaging I have ever seen for cat food, and the cat loved the packaging too, pawing at the sparkly multicolored foil on the front.The ingredients list tells you immediately but this is a healthy, all natural food. The first few ingredients are chicken meal, potatoes, canola oil, peas, chicken, ocean fish meal, and dried eggs. Further on down the list we have carrots, pumpkin, apples, cranberries, blueberries, broccoli, and sesame oil. The food is 42% crude protein and 20% crude fat.Unfortunately, my cat did not seem to like this food. And it was very disappointing for all of us. He did try it at first and we mixed a little bit with his current food to ease the transition. But after a while he started picking out the old food nuggets and leaving this new holistic food behind. Perhaps it was "too natural" for him and just too unlike what he's been eating for years. That makes me think it might be better to start a younger kitty on this food rather than a fourteen-year-old. All in all, I am pleased by the nutrition I see in this food and its holistic approach to health, though reluctantly I'll rate it "just ok" because my cat simply did not take to it.

If you're shopping for a school-boarder, or anyone else who uses a public shower on a regular basis, then this DII mesh caddy is a good choice for toting all those shower essentials.  There is a main basket with smaller pockets of various sizes for organization (razors, creams, toothbrushes, various sized tubes/containers, etc.), and since the mesh bag is already light-weight it won't be overly heavy.The caddy can sit on a cabinet or hang from a knob or hook, and you don't have to worry about water accumulating at the bottom since it drips right through the thick mesh.  Even though it doesn't have a solid form, which is great for packing when not in use, it remained upright even though I didn't have it filled with products.I placed 4 containers of various sizes, a poof, and razor, and still had plenty of room for other items that may be needed. You'll appreciate the convenience of this caddy, as will anyone to whom you may gift this.

For what essentially equates to a menstrual pad, these Always Discreet incontinence pads are surprisingly comfortable, but make no mistake - you will notice their presence.  They come individually wrapped for on-the-go needs, or just traveling, as one lasted me all day, but of course everyone's needs are unique.As for the odor control, it works well, although you may notice it when you're using the restroom.  As long as no one else can tell, though, right?  Unlike Always bladder control undies, these allow you to use your own underwear rather than full disposables, and the padding is thicker.  Also, since it's just an insert it's much more convenient and smaller than dealing with bladder control underwear.

We have used Huggies pretty much exclusively for both of our daughters. And in short, I love my Huggies.  They hold a good deal of liquid without leaking, are easy to put on and off, are comfortable for my babies, fit well and everyone in the family likes the Disney characters.The only problem I have with this particular product is the amount in the box.  Forty-eight diapers may seem like a lot, and for a child in a size 4 it probably is--especially if you think that child will be potty-trained soon--but I prefer to buy my diapers in bulk. That saves money in the long run. If you're short on room, however, this is a good choice. All in all, Huggies is the best brand around.

I was pleased to try out this Playskool Dressy Kids doll for my three-year-old daughter who is eager to do everything on her own.  She is moderately good at managing her own Velcro sneakers, and this doll offers the opportunity to practice that skill, along with a button, a zipper, a shoelace, and a buckle.  The doll also comes with a plastic clip so it can fasten to a bag, or even a belt loop, for travel.  The doll itself is a colorful patchwork kiddo, and my daughter was instantly taken with it (even though it was the boy doll instead of the girl doll).  While it is not quite as soft and cuddly as her most favorite stuffed dolls, and she has no real interest sleeping with it at night, it is a companion at home and the little button and shoelace features just beg to be played with.  And by playing she is (hopefully) developing those skills that she'll eventually use to tie her own shoes and button her shirts.As another reviewer pointed out, in the end this is a toy and does not offer a complete tutorial needed to master any of these skills.  For example, the zipper is pretty basic and just moves up and down.  It is permanently joined at the bottom of the jacket, so the hardest part of the zipping process is not really part of this.  The shoelace, on the other hand, offers the ability to actually practice that skill, though one might argue that it's bad to learn the skill backwards instead of on one's own shoe.  However, despite all of this, I find this to be an educational doll for curious youngsters who will play with it without realizing that they are learning in the process.  Recommended, especially for those kids old enough to want to do things on their own.

I approached this Sony HTST9 7.1 Sound Bar as someone who was still using a Sony 5.1 surround sound system purchased around 2004.  The difference is obviously night and day, and I was blown away by not only the sharpness and clarity of the sound but also by the relatively easy setup and its minimal footprint in our living room compared to what we had previously.  Our 5.1 system, which was pretty much top of the line in 2004, had a receiver, five wired speakers, and a wired subwoofer.  Cables ran along walls and under carpet, and the quality was great for a long time.  We had a short in our subwoofer a few years ago that changed that, but I was nonetheless very pleased for the better part of a decade.  In stark contrast, this system comes with a wireless subwoofer which is fantastic.  And I had a hard time accepting that the sound I was getting for a long sound bar was better than the strategically positioned speakers wired all around my living room.  In all honesty, it took far longer to take the old Sony system apart than it did to set up this fancy younger sibling.I have a family member who is skilled at electronics, and it took him only about half an hour to get this installed right out of the box.  (After we spent a hour or more pulling up wires and unhooking speakers to make way for this.)  We went through the software setup with ease, got everything set up with wifi, and I was able to use my iPhone to play music.  We tried out a handful of Blu Ray discs as well to test out the full spectrum of sound.  I am not an expert by any means, but I am a typical consumer who enjoys - with my family - a quality home theater experience in my living room.  There are likely much fancier units out there, but this one is sheer perfection for us.  We have long trusted the Sony brand since our very first, very large Sony DVD player way back in 1997.  This compact unit packs a punch and is light years better than what we had before.  Thus, this is highly recommended to folks looking for quality and clarity, wireless connectivity, and sleekness in a small unit that is very easy to setup.

I have used a lot of AmazonBasics products, and whenever I need something, well, basic, I tend to search for the Amazon brand first. This is a standard lightning charger for my iPhone, and it works just great.Ever since Apple introduced the lightning charger, I have been wary of non-Apple brands simply because I never know if they will work or not. Even some "certified" chargers give my issues, especially in the car. This AmazonBasics charger works just fine, and I've had no trouble connecting - so far - an iPhone 5S and an iPad Air. This cable is longer than a typical iPhone cord, which is helpful also. This one I use in a dedicated multi-device charger in our bedroom. No problems, no complaints. Works well and arrived protected in a double padded envelope. Recommended.

This Black & Decker LED desk light is great for a dorm room or a relaxed office. I say "relaxed" because it's sleek but not fancy, made of shiny black plastic that would not really go well with, say, a nice oak desk. I would not say it looks cheap exactly, but it's far more functional than aesthetically pleasing.As far as functionality, it really works well. Despite being a thin, lightweight desk lamp, the brightness of the LED fills up the room. You can read or work by this in a totally dark room without any difficulty. For me, it's perfect in our family room where I often escape to read while the kids are at play or in bed. The charging port for my smartphone is an absolute bonus. I attached a short six-inch lightning cable for my iPhone and I know have an accessible charger in my den.The phone stand is, well, less impressive. My iPhone 5S would fit just fine if I didn't have a case. If your phone is bare or protected by a super-thin back case (not a thicker wallet or certainly not an Otterbox), it'll fit fine in a vertical position. Otherwise, like me, you are out of luck and just have a little pool for paper clips or rubberbands instead. Seems like most people would want a stand to watch their phones horizontally but I don't see that as a real possibility here, but maybe with some maneuvering it would work. And speaking of maneuverability, this lamp is extremely adjustable.The off/on switch is super sensitive. I accidentally turned it on and off three or four times getting the light adjusted. It's a minor thing, but I tend to like more solid switches as opposed to these virtually invisible buttons that are barely marked with a small power icon. All in all, this is a great addition to a dorm, office, or comfortable, informal space.

These are considered "Little Boys" jeans, but my seven-year-old daughter, who loves to wear boots, really enjoyed these.  She was "amazed" when these arrived as they were greenish in color, being forest denim.  She had apparently never seen green-tinted jeans before.  To her, of course, that made them even more cool.  She is seven and small for her age, yet these Wrangler boot-cut jeans fit her nicely around the waist.  We did roll them up at first and may eventually get them hemmed because they are longer than she needs at the moment.She has worn these on several occasions now, with and without her boots, and she has had nothing but positive comments.  She is a bit of a tomboy and these work well for her on the playground and around the house.  To me, they are soft to the touch yet clearly tough and sturdy - a very good quality product.  And I should point out that my daughter really likes the stitching on the rear, the stylized W for Wrangler.  She calls that "sassy," though since these are made primarily for boys, I doubt that "sassy" was in the designers' minds.  All in all, these are great for tomboys as well as actual boys.  Recommended.

I have never worn a Wrangler shirt, and I decided to try this one out because I really liked the color.  When it arrived I was struck by the rugged quality.  This is a nice-looking shirt that can be worn to the office, but it also be easily used for intensive outdoor activity on the weekend.  I guess that's what sportswear is all about.  As impressed as I was, my spouse took one look at it and suggested that I not wear it to work because of its size.  I always wear extra-large shirts and have for many years.  This extra-large was, unfortunately, larger than I expected.  I feel I could have easily worn a large instead, and ultimately that's the main downside to ordering any clothing online.I wore it to work regardless and received no feedback.  Tucked in, it worked just fine although the sleeves ballooned a bit because they are too long and too big for my frame.  In the future, I will definitely go with a large in Wrangler clothing instead of extra-large.  That would make a great deal of difference.  But in terms of quality and durability, I was very impressed.

This is a very beautiful and well-made sleigh and doll set from Mattel. My two daughters, ages 7 and 3, were extremely obsessed with "Frozen" all last year, and if they had this set during that intense period - back when the movie was on on our house every single day without fail - I suppose they would have never stopped playing with this set. A year later, their "Frozen" fever has cooled, but they still go excited when this arrived. Out came all the compatible Mattel dolls from last year to play with it. And that's one downside to a set like this. If you don't already have a couple of other dolls, or at least an Elsa doll, be prepared to pick one up. It makes no sense to include only one of the sisters here, though I do recognize that Elsa never really rode in the sleigh in the movie.The Anna doll is very nice and basically identical to the one my daughters already had on their own. Sven is a plastic character, not dissimilar to the various plastic horses or large dogs that accompany some of the more elaborate Barbie sets. The sleigh is richly detailed and was their favorite part. It can hold about three characters, or more depending on their size. Or in my daughters' case, a bunch if they just lay them down stack them up in the sleigh in true Monty Python style. Clearly they were having a blast.This is an easy recommendation for Frozen fans. It is worth noting,  for potential giftgiving, but this it does come in a brown cardboard box with the "Frozen" logo as opposed to the standard Barbie-type box, or at least that is how our set arrived.

I have been a Sherlock Holmes fan for decades, reading both the original stories and novels and subsequent portrayals by other authors (including the full works of youngest son Adrian Conan Doyle.) Here, though, is something completely different. "Mycroft Holmes" shines the light on the enigmatic older brother, minimizing Sherlock pretty much to a single, amusing chapter where we see him as a mediocre college student. I really enjoyed this book, despite a few shortcomings, and I really hope we see more of these from Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and co-author Anna Waterhouse.In a sentence, here we see young government up-and-comer Mycroft set off on a historically-based mystery/adventure involving the Caribbean slave trade with a Watson-like companion, Cyrus Douglas. The characterization is vivid and the plot interesting, even if no one would ever mistake this for an original Conan Doyle novel. I have to say that the sixty-page stretch on the ocean liner was top notch, a set of thrilling and atmospheric chapters full of deduction and intrigue. Unfortunately that stretch comes before the novel's halfway point, meaning that it's a tiny bit downhill from there. The action-packed conclusion, a sort of Victorian era Rambo II, was exciting but also a bit much. It was satisfying, however, and left me eager for more.If you're a Holmes fan, this is worth a read. Even though Sherlock himself is little more than an extended cameo, it's wonderful to see brother Mycroft young and vulnerable, deftly and arrogantly using his mental abilities, as we readers smile, knowing what adventures lie in store.

I have been using the Slendertone Abs toner for a few weeks, and I was eager to give this Arms 7 muscle toner a try as well. I figured that it would be pretty much the same and easy for me to set up right out of the box. I was mostly correct.Unlike the Abs toner, which includes a trio of batteries, the Arms 7 requires a couple of hours to charge it's built-in battery unit before using. So while it wasn't quite ready to go straight from the box, it was ready as promised within 90 to 120 minutes. It's a little trickier to set up than the Abs toner. You're dealing with two arm units obviously, each of which contain two small gel pads to connect your bare skin to the unit. This is exactly like the Abs toner, but they're harder to accurately position I discovered. The Abs toner is pretty basic, and I got it first time (and every subsequent time) without difficulty. Here I struggled to put the arm bands on the first time. A partner would've helped initially. Then I had to readjust them twice, leaving my skin sore from all that peeling abs reapplying. The instructions offered tips to avoid tingling in the lower arms but regardless of my adjustments, I felt that mild-ish tingling about 8 of the 10 minutes. The sensation, just like with the Abs toner, is unique and takes some getting used to. I can feel it contracting my muscles, but after a couple rounds, I have to say it just wasn't quite as comfortable and emotionally satisfying as the Abs toner. I'll continue to use it, of course, as it takes weeks to see results.A couple of notes worth mentioning. The Abs toner recommends using it about five times per week, and I have been averaging six or even seven just because it has become a comfortable part of my morning routine. This Arms 7, however, should only be used thrice weekly, and 48 hours apart, according to the instructions. That surprised me, but honestly, since it is less comfortable and a bit more involved to set up, I am fine with that. Also, with the Abs belt I am free to walk around and do stuff. This unit offers less mobility because it's most comfortable, I found, to raise your arms or at least bend at the elbow. Also, the battery/control unit is handheld on a fairly short cord so that limits you as well. It's best to use this, I found, while sitting, maybe watching TV. (I'm active with the Abs belt, making the family breakfast and other morning stuff.)All in all, Slendertone is awesome. No doubt. This is my third product, and while it's not perfect and my least favorite of the three, I can feel it working and I feel good about myself in the process. If you have to choose, go with the Abs 3 toner. If you want the full package, give this Arms 7 a try as well.

I have been actively using the Slendertone Abs 3 for several weeks with good results, so I approached the Abs 5 primarily interested in what was different or better. I found that it delivered the same quality as the Abs 3 with only a few minor enhancements that will only affect experienced users (and even after a few weeks, I'm not yet "experienced" enough to benefit from these additions right out of the box.)The Abs 5 offers a total of 10 toning programs, compared to the 7 found on the Abs 3. This is great for long term users working their way up, though I am currently in the middle of program 3 do it'll be a while before I get beyond the maximum offered by the Abs 3. Additionally, the Abs 5 offers a maximum intensity of 130, compared with 99 on the Abs 3. After several weeks, I can say that I hit the 99 max only one time, usually stopping between 85 and 90. I can say that 99 is a powerful sensation, and I can only imagine the intensity of 130.Beyond these two minor differences, there's nothing at all differentiating the Abs 3 from this Abs 5. So if you're just getting started, as I was a while ago, the 3 is just as good, though this 5 is a better option for trainers or folks who are committed to the long haul, persistent daily use for the foreseeable future.The Abs 5, just like the 3, is easy to set up, and it even comes with a trio of batteries so you can get started right out of the box.  The device remembers your current program and advances automatically, so it's a no-brainer kind of workout, though it's up to you to increase your intensity each time as desired. The sensation is unique and indescribable, though once you get used to it, it is a comfortable yet intense feeling. And best of all, you know when it's working. If any of the three pads are misaligned, you feel it right away. Overall, I'm thrilled to have the Slendertone system in my life (as I also have the Arms 7). It's an incredible device that's changed the way I work out each day and impacted my goals and self esteem.  And while there is not much difference between the Abs 3 and the Abs 5, either of them are five-star and highly recommended products.

In addition to occasional leakage I've taken to wearing "bladder protection" during my monthly cycle, and to me that is a perfect test to the claims of odor control. I must say that Always gets an A there.  These are not my favorite, however, because of the fit.  When I first put them on I thought I had them on backwards since they felt funny, mostly with the front feeling higher than the back, but after checking the packaging I found that the purple waistband was in the back as directed.  In addition, the "Advanced Triple Layer Core" section seems a bit bunchy - it's not thick but long, and just doesn't seem to fit well.  I tried a small, so size wasn't a problem for the core.  It could have been for the legs holes, however.They feel a bit tight, despite the S/M claiming to go to 190 lbs.  The L is for 170-260 lbs, and I might be at the lower end of that range, but I'd fear that they would be too big if I tried the next size up.  The elastic around the legs seems to be tighter than other brands, so choose wisely when deciding on size.  Unlike other bladder protectors, I noticed this one throughout my day more often, just in the feel or uncomfortableness of it around my waist, hips, and thighs.  So for that I'd give these a C.  That said, I was perfectly comfortable where it matters most - never felt the slightest bit wet or sticky, so there's another A.  They are slightly nicer looking than the plain gray or pink plastic protection offered, but still not attractive by any means, so I'll give that a B. They still deserve an A for discreet, at least as far as keeping the fact we're wearing an adult diaper hidden from public.

The first thing I noticed about this mild Benzac Acne cleanser is that, unlike a lot of other anti-acne washes, it actually worked. Very well. Usually I'll have a pimple or two crop up while I'm trying a new product, but I was pleasantly surprised that, despite stress in my life at the moment, this did not happen.That said, after a week or two of using it regularly I did get a small one, but it was in a crevice where I probably did not rub it in well, so that was completely my fault.  I was also pleasantly surprised that it did not dry out my skin.  Granted, I only use it once a day, but I tend to have sensitive skin that quickly feels the effects of harsh cleansers.  Furthermore, this did not irritate my mild Rosacea.  I may have found my new facial cleanser. Recommended.

Although this Benzac Skin Refining Mask is said to include "calming and soothing...Sandalwood Oil," I honestly thought it smelled pretty bad, even after rinsing it all off. That pretty much eliminated any calming or soothing effects for me.  Also, since it is a mask it made my skin feel tight and slightly dry while on, but that sensation ended upon rinsing.I used this with the Benzac Acne Eliminating Cleanser and was free from acne where these products were applied, and despite my sensitive, dry skin, with a mild case of Rosacea, this product did not do any noticeable damage to my skin.  If you don't mind the smell, go for it.  As for me, I think it will be used only in an emergency.

This Pyrex Easy Grab 28-piece set was well packaged with cardboard between pieces, though I had trouble digging out one of the lids. A few observations: the four smallest, more decorative pieces do not include lids, and the largest casserole style ones are not airtight like the others. I do like that those pieces have slits your for fingers, however.As with all Pyrex, these pieces are on the heavy side because of the thick glass, but they are definitely worth the weight. Two fell out of the box while I was unpacking them, onto wood flooring, and there was not a scratch or chip on either.The kids have washing/cooking reminders which are nice, and there are other accessories (cooling packs, carrying cases, etc) that can be purchased for potluckers. These will take up a lot of room, but they will help give current cookware a break.All in all, this was a good first experience with Pyrex. I have seen these at other houses but never had any for myself. Now I suspect I won't be able to get along without them.

This book totally lived up to my hopes. The recipes are easy and mostly quick to prepare, and all the ones I've tried have been very tasty. For each one, the authors explain what it does from a Traditional Chinese Medicine perspective (e.g., strengthens the kidneys, drains dampness) and which health issues you can use it for (e.g., losing weight, or recovering from illness). You can use the index to look for a recipe by ingredient or by health issue. They also give you variations on each recipe. I have even made up my own recipes based on the information/ingredients presented in the book.Ancient Wisdom, Modern Kitchen is written from the perspective that food = nutrition = medicine. You can enjoy it simply as a cookbook of East Asian dishes, or as a component in a healthier lifestyle (the recipes are mostly quite low fat and feature lots of veggies, herbs, and whole grains), or as therapeutic for specific conditions.The only drawback--and this isn't a problem with the book but with trying to eat an Asian-style diet in the USA--is that some of the ingredients can be hard to source and rather expensive. The authors do their best to help by giving you pictures of ingredients that may be unfamiliar, as well as showing their names written in Chinese so you can recognize them from the packaging. I happen to live in a city without a good Asian market though, and have found it difficult to get some of the herbs locally. They can be ordered online, but some (like ginseng) can be really pricey. However, this is your health we're talking about, so it's up to you whether that's worth the cost. Most of the recipes can be made without hard-to-obtain ingredients and they'll still be tasty food, albeit maybe not as medicinal. I just gradually add things to my pantry, one at a time.For Westerners who might be wondering how these Asian medicinal ingredients will taste, the ones I've been able to get my hands on have been mild and pleasant tasting. I routinely add astragalus root, jujubes (Chinese red dates), maitake and/or shiitake mushrooms, pearl barley (Job's tears), and goji berries to my soups and stews now, and no one who has tried them thinks there is anything weird about the taste. I think they add good flavor, but in a subtle and not overpowering way. Ginseng is also very tasty. If you already like Chinese, Japanese, or Korean food I don't think you have anything to worry about.

This is the book on Egyptian cosmology I have always been looking for! I've been interested in Egyptian (and other) mythology since I was a kid, but after a while I got frustrated because every book was just a bunch of pretty pictures and lists of So-and-so was the god of Such-and-such. Sometimes you get some interesting tales, but there was never anything about the theology, the cosmology, the philosophy, and the worldview that held it all together.That's where this book differs. It is all about that stuff that knits a culture together. It sounds a little cliche, but it really did bring the ancient Egyptian mind to life for me. As it stands, I found Temple of the Cosmos to be very well-reasoned, well-researched, and a pleasure to read. Although it is not an academic work, it is certainly scholarly. Naydler supports his arguments with specific ancient texts and/or images. He strikes the right balance between (apparently) accepting that mystical experiences and phenomena are real, without bias toward the "truth" of any one worldview, Egyptian or otherwise. By comparison, the "methodological atheism" required in academic writing means that an author must discuss spiritual beliefs/phenomena as if they aren't real, regardless of their actual opinion on the matter, and that means they can't really engage with the deeper levels of the topic; on the other hand, for an author to accept "transmitted" information as accurate a priori would be without intellectual, philosophical, or scholarly rigor. Naydler does not succumb to either pitfall.Temple of the Cosmos covers stories of creation, the Egyptian concept of magic as both a cosmic force and a skill set which overlapped with pretty much every aspect of life, Egyptian concepts of time, space, cosmos, and geography, the understanding of the individual spirit/psyche/soul, and the afterlife journey. If you are a student of Western magic you will recognize a lot of the themes here. While it is clear that the Egyptian worldview was very different from that of the 21st century West, you do get a feel for Egypt's massive influence at the very roots of our civilization.I would highly recommend this book to anyone with an interest in: Egyptology, history, anthropology, and archaeology; ancient Egypt generally; Egyptian mythology; Kemetic reconstructionism or Kemetic-inspired paganism; Western philosophy; and/or magic and the Western Mystery/Magical Tradition. If you are looking for someone's unverified personal gnosis of Egyptian deities, this is not the book you are looking for (but I would still recommend it).
Not a fan of this particular blend. I know there are different recipes for garam masala, but this was more like a mixture of baking spices. Not recommended.

I got this tea because it is supposed to help support the spleen. According to Chinese medicine, my spleen qi is weak. It's also supposed to help you lose weight (weak spleen qi can lead to obesity) which I wanted to do.This tea seems to give me lots of energy without any caffeine buzz feeling, and in turn that has allowed me to get more exercise.The taste is like a very bland tea, much like what you'd get as the default tea at a Chinese restaurant. I find it very easy to drink. Among other things, bojenmi tea contains hawthorn, which supports the heart, balances blood pressure, and reduces cholesterol. I have read that bojenmmi can be laxative, but in my personal experience it has not had that effect.I've been drinking the tea for about 2 months now, during which time I have lost 8 lbs. I am eating better and exercising a bit more so this is probably not due to the tea alone, but I do think it has helped. It's recommended to drink 3 cups per day and I usually only drink 1 or 2, so I might have lost more if I had drunk more tea. If nothing else, I would drink it just for the energy it gives me.

I found this book to be quite interesting, but in terms of getting what I was looking for, I didn't quite live up to my hopes. I got the book because I'm interested in taking a Chinese medical approach to some chronic health issues that conventional medicine has been unable to help me with, one of which is weight loss. If you're thinking of buying, here are some things you might like to know:The book claims to be "the Asian diet secret," but it's not really Asian. It's a fusion of Chinese and Western approaches to diet, with a little Ayurveda thrown in. The energy types symbolized by animals (dragon, bear, crane, tiger) are inspired by Qigong, but are actually categories created by the author. Hadady explains how they fit with Chinese elemental theory, and says she chose animals as more relatable than elements like earth, water, metal, etc., and I do think that was a clever way of categorizing the types.I also like the way this book takes account of the fact that people have differing motivations with regard to food choices, and differing energy levels, etc. (for example, bears crave sweets, dragons crave salt and have poor adrenal function, cranes are prone to addictions) so that they need to take different approaches to weight loss. I love that she suggests menus specifically for each type. I thought it was cool that she suggested homeopathic remedies (although I tried the one she suggested for people with my issues and it had no effect that I could discern), though I was surprised she didn't recommend more Chinese herbal formulas--perhaps because they would have to be more specifically tailored to the individual? I don't know.Where the book falls short, for me, is in the following:- I wanted to see more Chinese medicine theory to explain how obesity develops and is treated, and why certain foods are chosen or avoided. There really is no "Asian diet secret" here at all, just a blend of non-secret Chinese approaches and non-secret Western ones.- Sometimes the author doesn't explain very well. For example, in Chinese nutrition theory, salads and raw veg are not considered good for you because they are cold and stress your spleen and digestion. Hadady mentions this. Yet in her daily menus, she suggests everyone eat lots of salads. So, which is it? She also says that you should only eat one type of protein per day, and every kind of meat is a separate type. So if you eat dairy at breakfast you can only eat dairy as your protein for the rest of the day. She says that mixing proteins is bad, but never says why. I'm left wondering if there is some basis for this claim, or if it's just superstition.- The "baseline diet" is just an ordinary calorie- and fat-restricted diet with some added idiosyncracy like the thing with only one type of protein per day, and in fact it's pretty restrictive. It does suggest a lot of tea which, if you drink as much as is recommended (more than 64 oz per day), will leave you with little room left for actual food. So I'm sure that diet will be effective in helping you lose weight, but I am not at all convinced that very many people can maintain it long term.- A lot of the recommended foods sound, not to put too fine a point on it, unpleasant to gross. I mean, if you're trying to lose weight you know there's going to be some "rabbit food" involved. Also, in Chinese medicine it is understood that a person who is out of balance (e.g., overweight) will tend to crave things that throw their body even more out of balance; however once their health is balanced, they will crave things that tend to keep it that way. So I expected that I would be advised to eat some things I don't really want to, and be advised against eating things I feel instinctively drawn to. But warmed-over pumpkin puree from a can? Plain cold tofu? Hadady's idea of dessert is a spoonful of coconut oil. I like coconut and I use the oil in cooking, but the mere thought of choking down a spoonful of raw oil makes me queasy. (I did actually try it. Will not be making that mistake again.) If these are my choices I honestly would rather not eat at all. (Maybe that's the plan?) There are recipes included in the book and there are a few I think I'll try, but none was particularly inspiring.- The author is really into laxatives and "cleansing." Cleansing is all the rage right now but is not necessary for most people and can be dangerous. In Chinese medicine, one of the causes of obesity is weak digestive qi and as I understand it--I'm not an expert but have been doing a lot of research--these cleanses could actually diminish your qi. It just seems like this should have been reserved for a different book.- Depending on where you live, some of Hadady's recommended foods and supplements may not be easy to find. I live in a town with one small Korean grocery that has only a few recommended things. This means I have to order things online and with shipping costs that puts them out of my reach.BOTTOM LINE:I feel confident that if I followed the baseline diet and guidelines in this book, I would lose weight. I feel equally confident that I will not be able to follow the baseline diet. It isn't so much because of what you're NOT supposed to eat that I would fall off the wagon as because of the things you ARE supposed to eat. However, I did learn from the book and I applaud the author's ambitious attempt to create a synthesis of Chinese and Western nutrition. The book did help me get a better handle on the imbalances in how I eat and what I need to do to correct them, and inspired me to drink more herbal tea. I think if you are serious about losing weight, this book can help you, but will probably not be enough on its own.If you get this book, I would also recommend getting the cookbook Ancient Wisdom, Modern Kitchen by Yuan Wang, Warren Sheir, and Mika Ono, which has recipes selected according to Chinese medicine which are quick, easy, and tasty (no canned pumpkin required!). Almost all the recipes in the cookbook are designed to support the spleen and digestion which, in Chinese medicine, is supposed to help you lose weight. They also explain why each ingredient is recommended, and suggest variations, so you could even figure out your own recipes once you get used to the Asian ingredients.

I'm very happy with this mouse. The blue color is nice, everything seems to work perfectly, buttons not too stiff but give a good "clicky" feel, the price was right, and as some other reviewers have mentioned, I have small hands and it fits me better than larger models. I haven't had it long enough to wear out the battery yet, but then I also turn it off when not in use.

This is a very small book. It's 93 pages (not counting a list of merchants in the back), with large margins, fairly large print, lots of large illustrations, and the pages are only about 5 or 5 and a half inches square. It's sort of like a novelty child-sized coffee table art book.The content is fine, and the book was priced inexpensively, but I wish I had realized just how small and brief this book was. I read it in one short sitting, and though I consider myself a beginner where natural perfumery is concerned, pretty much everything in this book I had already found online. There is a section on the history of solid perfume which is ridiculously brief.That said, there's certainly nothing wrong with the book's contents or the quality of the editing and binding, and I will check out Mandy Aftel's other books in hopes of getting a more substantial meal. And it's my fault that I didn't pay attention to the info on dimensions, page count, etc. that Amazon provides. But I think this just should have been published as a pamphlet or an e-book. If you literally know nothing about perfumes and are averse to using the internet, this book will be good for you.

1. There is no such thing as vanilla essential oil.2. There is no such thing as "therapeutic grade" essential oil (except as a trademarked label applied by certain companies to their own products). There is no standardization of essential oil "grades."3. So whatever this is, it's not therapeutic grade vanilla essential oil.

This book was loaned to me by a family member who really loved it and thought I would really love it too. I have never read anything else by Elizabeth Gilbert but reading the back cover blurb I thought the book sounded right up my alley.Highly intelligent female protagonist? Check. Historical setting in a time of huge social and technological transformations? Check. World travel? Check. Encounters with the "mysteries of evolution" coupled with "the spiritual, the divine, and the magical"? Check, check, check. Botany? Check. Heck, it even had moss! I actually LOVE moss!The writing is not great literature but is page-turning and engaging. The background historical setting was very interesting; in fact, the most brilliant thing about the book was having its protagonist born in 1800 so we could travel through the 19th century with her. (In spite of what the gadget-sellers want you to believe, the scientific, technological, and social changes of the 19th century were far more momentous than anything since. Some of those changes, of course, have led us down dark roads. But I digress.) As a female nerd and plant lover, I initially identified with the protagonist, Alma, and was really hoping to see her have worldview-changing insights from which I too would learn. I even put up with that hackneyed old trope, the Manic Pixie Dream Girl (Retta). The promise of learning more about botany within the context of 19th century history kept me reading even through the subsequent appearance of a Manic Pixie Dream Boy (Ambrose).In any other book, I would have chucked it at that point. It's weak to use one Manic Pixie Dream Person character, but TWO? That's just lazy or condescending or both. But it seemed like maybe this MPDBoy would be developed into a real character, one that would finally push Alma to experience real growth and transformation. I mean after all, the author had gone so far as to switch up the usual gender of the MPDPerson... maybe that would be a good sign?Alas, it was not to be. The MPDBoy remained a cardboard cutout. Even worse, although we are repeatedly assured of his incomparable artistic genius and his beautiful soul, in the end we're told that his mind was "weak" and "fragile" and it is even implied that such people can't hack it under the conditions of natural selection. This felt like a cynical trick--at least in most stories with an MPD character, he or she (well, she) is portrayed as wondrous and magical throughout. Here it's like we're promised wonder, and then told it's just mental instability after all. I mean, the entire reason authors fall back on MPD characters is to allow their main characters to have insights and become liberated without having to do the difficult inner work, so what was the point here?Speaking of cynical, when Alma finally has her big scientific realization, it's so cynical that I felt like a lot more explanation was needed to show me how she could remain so blithe about it. I mean, nowadays such views are dominant to the point of being normative, but in the mid-19th century most people found them shocking. So perhaps Alma wouldn't have been shocked, given her life experiences, but I would have expected her to be depressed, frankly. There is one aspect of her hypothesis that she just can't make sense of (the Prudence Problem) yet frustratingly, we're not even given a peek into what the protagonist THINKS about it. Surely she has some guesses? Some further hypotheses? No.There is a very problematic meta-narrative as well, according to which large and homely women are unlovable, undesirable, morally complex and ambivalent, while beautiful people (Retta, Prudence, Tomorrow Morning, Ambrose) are virtuous and good even when (as in TM's and Retta's cases) we're told they have done stuff that maybe isn't all that virtuous or (as in Retta's and Ambrose's cases) we are told they are plumb loco. I think this meta-narrative is a side effect of the fact that only the protagonist is developed enough to have any complexity--the rest are more props to the story. But sometimes messages find their way into a story without the author's full conscious intent, and that's what bothers me here. Besides curiosity, the dominant emotion in the protagonist seems to be shame. Other characters even shame her further, sometimes about things she couldn't possibly have known or done anything about. Pretty = good, ugly = morally suspect and shameful, over and over. Like THAT concept needs any reinforcement in our society. Even the ugly dog is kind of a jerk (although I had more sympathy for him than almost anyone else in the story.) It all left an icky taste in my mouth.In the end, the insights and transformations I was hoping for in Alma just never materialized. Through the entire course of her life, her worldview remains largely unperturbed, even through culture shock, bereavements, and a supposedly deep involvement with a character who seemed--at least until we are told, never mind, he's just delusional--to be blasting through the boundaries of that worldview. But in order for a character to experience such insights, the author has to have had them. And it seems like Gilbert hasn't. Because of this, Alma's unquestioned devotion to scientific materialism felt less like a commitment to rigorous historical accuracy on Gilbert's part, and more like an unreflexive backwards projection of what has become the normative and paradigmatic worldview of OUR time. (To be clear, I was not hoping for Alma to have an out-of-character religious conversion--but I would have liked a little ontological crisis.)BOTTOM LINE: The writing is pleasant, but the story failed to deliver on its potential. I found the setting more engaging and realistic than the plot or characters. To write what I consider a really good novel--the kind that I will keep and re-read--an author has to have traversed some "dark night of the soul" and be willing to revisit that in various ways through their characters. Either Gilbert hasn't been there, or she didn't want to go back there, and as a result her characters didn't go anywhere. I'd give this book 2.5 stars if that were an option.P.S. On a positive note, in part because of this book I was directed to the works of Robin Wall-Kimmerer, which look very promising.

[Note: Some of this review is paraphrased from a comment I left on another review.]I love everything I've read by Murakami, some books more than others. Hard-Boiled Wonderland is one of my favorites. I respect the many and varied opinions of the deeper meaning of his texts, but I don't subscribe to any of these interpretations. To me, his stories read like an unusual individual exploring all the weird corners of imagination, without being bound by the conventions of linear storytelling--no more, no less. A lot of it reads like an acid trip.I believe that to fully enjoy Murakami's books, it's best not to bring any expectations to them. Don't believe the hype, don't expect him to be representative of "Japanese culture" (haha good luck with that), don't expect to find the same "meaning" as other reviewers (or indeed any meaning at all), don't expect them to be like typical Western novels, don't even expect the plot line to be wrapped up at the end or the mysteries to be solved. Just go along for the ride.Regarding Murakami as some kind of representative of Japaneseness (which seems to be a common belief among Americans), this is a ridiculous expectation to begin with. First of all, how would you generalize or boil down a culture that produced the tea ceremony AND their variety shows? Hello Kitty AND harakiri? No culture can be fully represented by a single writer, Japan even less than most, and Murakami isn't even trying to do that anyway. However, his books are very popular in Japan so it's clear that they do resonate with people there. Murakami's books are Japanese to the extent that their author happens to be Japanese; but they are individual and unique to the extent that their author is individual and unique.There is a lot of hype in the West about how "cool" Murakami's books are. This is just publisher hype. What they are is a glorious mashup of unpredictable, confusing, anti-heroic, enchanting, frustrating, bewildering, magical, campy, disaffected, Western, Eastern, creepy, vivid, funny, noir, and quirky, in equal measures.

This book is...different. I got this book because I love Matthew Wood's other writing on herbalism, and because he covers some herbs here that I don't often see elsewhere. However, the basic premise of the book was not clear to me when I bought it--if I had known more about that, I would still have bought the book but there are others I'd have read first. So I will outline the premise here for prospective buyers:The format is based on the pedagogical concept of the Ojibwe Grand Medicine Lodge, where students advance through seven stages or grades, each of which centers around one plant. However, the exact plants and medicinal lore involved are not shared outside Ojibwe culture (Wood is not Ojibwe) and maybe there is no one left alive who even knows all of it. So instead of the original seven Ojibwe plants, Wood provides seven American plants that have emerged as important in his own practice; and instead of the Ojibwe medicinal lore, Wood interprets seven chapters of Genesis and relates these stories to the plant teachings. Another important factor to consider is that this is really a book about homeopathy, not traditional herbalism.If you identify as a Christian homeopath or herbalist I bet you will really dig this book. Even if you don't agree with Wood's take on the scriptures, his views are interesting and you will probably find them thought-provoking.If you are not Christian and/or not especially interested in Biblical literature, you might just want to skim those parts or else be really patient and try to view them as heuristic models.I liked the uniqueness of the approach. This particular work was written almost 30 years ago and I think Wood's approach and understanding of the plants have evolved and become more holistic since then. As I mentioned, at the time this book was written Wood was obviously more a homeopath than herbalist: For example, at the end he insists that of the seven stages discussed, you can only be in one at a time and therefore only need one of those plants at a time. Using only one plant at a time, which is linked to a very specific set of physical, psychological, and emotional characteristics even down to the patient's appearance, is characteristic of homeopathy. However, elsewhere he says that the stages are cumulative as well as sequential and thus all exist at the same time. Hmm. This is not a book that can easily be used to diagnose yourself; at least, I found that more than one of the chapters/plants seemed to potentially apply to me, so I wouldn't self-treat just based on what's in this book.In the final analysis, I think that tying the herbal-medical teachings in with lessons from Biblical literature is a brilliant model IF you assume the audience was raised fully immersed in and conversant with Christian theology (especially of a Protestant variety)--because the particular lessons embodied in those Bible stories are culturally-specific. I don't happen to embrace those particular moral values, and am skeptical that plants do. So I felt like the herbs were being forced to fit the Old Testament exegesis, and that doesn't quite work for me. It was certainly interesting and I will probably keep the book as a reference, but it's not in my opinion one of Wood's better works.

I would actually have given this 3.5 stars if that were possible.What I like about this deck:--It has an "old timey" (mid-1800s) Victorian style and the pips remind me of the playing cards they use in Spain. Not exactly "ancient" in any way, but if you want something that feels vintage, this is a good deck. The images of the Major Arcana are based on Renaissance Italian decks, but are more colorful.--They are a little longer and narrower than my other tarot decks--in fact, they are as long as my small hands can easily handle--but I like the shape.--Another reviewer commented that the back of the cards doesn't fit with the front (while the fronts have a slightly off-white, old paper tone, the backs were green and a very new-looking bright white). This has been fixed. The backs are dark green, sage green, and gold, and fit well with the fronts.--This is my first deck that isn't a Rider-Waite clone, and I specifically sought out a deck that didn't have scenes for the minor arcana. This deck has just the number and the suit, and I like that. For beginners, it might be easier to start with a RW clone.--They have a smooth finish and seem thick enough without being too stiff.What I don't like:--The Little White Book was pretty much useless (as expected). I recycled it. I didn't buy the deck for the LWB, so that's ok.--The cards came out of the box with a *very* strong nasty chemical/plastic odor, and it appears that I am allergic to something used in their manufacture. Every time I use the deck, my nose runs and swells up and I get a headache. I spread the cards out on a table and put a bag of bamboo charcoal in the middle and that seems to have absorbed a bit of the odor, but I've had these cards probably a month and they are still off-gassing like crazy. I can't do more than 2 spreads at a sitting before I have to stop. If it doesn't clear up soon they will have to stay outside until they finish off-gassing. If you have any chemical sensitivity, steer clear of these! (In fact, I would be wary of anything made by Lo Scarabeo, as I have read other complaints online about the smell and having to let the cards air out before using them. This deck came wrapped in cellophane inside the box, and there was no detectable odor until the cellophane was removed, so I think the smell comes from the inks or the coating of the cardstock.) If not for this, I would have given this deck 5 stars, but this seems like a consistent problem with Lo Scarabeo decks, and it makes me wonder what they heck they put on their cards. However many people say it doesn't bother them.UPDATE: The smell did finally go away, and now I enjoy using this deck. I have read that the smell comes from linseed oil used in the printing process but I have no idea if that's accurate. Some people say they actually like the Lo Scarabeo "new deck smell," so your mileage may vary. But if you are very sensitive to smells, be prepared.

I've read some of Josephine McCarthy's writings online, but this was the first book I've purchased so far (there will be more). This book is definitely going on my reference shelf to stay. As is typical of McCarthy's writing, there is just a huge amount of useful information delivered in a succinct, no-nonsense, down to earth style. When you understand the (sometimes negative) effect magic can have on your body and why it happens, you have only to learn some basic techniques to begin taking charge of your health. This is not to say it's easy, necessarily--but it is pretty simple. You will NOT find "cookbook" style spells that sound cute but don't explain why or how they are supposed to work, or worse yet seem to be designed to just make you feel clever and pretty. You will NOT need a fancypants altar or a bunch of tools. Instead you will find a variety of tarot spreads with a real life example to guide you in interpreting them; recommendations for complementary therapies including homeopathy and herbs, among others; and most importantly, visionary magic techniques.My favorite thing about McCarthy's presentation of magic is that she boils it down to the essentials, without any pompous fol-de-rol or attempts to scare the reader. It seems to occupy the space in between esoteric ceremonial magic and the more earthy practices of witchcraft, which I personally adore. For years I steered clear of magic because I couldn't find anyone taking this kind of approach.The methods in the book are as appropriate for relative beginners as for more advanced practitioners. If you haven't taken a magical hit yet, get this book so you can avoid it; if you have, then you probably already know you need a book like this.

I heard about this collection from a friend of mine and was immediately intrigued by the premises of some of the stories. But I ended up reading Throne of the Crescent Moon by the same author first. I enjoyed that, so sought out Engraved on the Eye. I don't generally read short story collections, because when they're good, they're awesome--but usually they aren't. And that's so disappointing. But Ahmed's stories are very creative. He really has some unique ideas. I also enjoy the fact that his writing draws on a generally Middle Eastern cultural context, instead of being yet another medieval-Europe-but-with-dragons kind of fantasy. In this regard I especially liked Mister Hadj's Sunset Ride and The Faithful Soldier, Prompted. The writing does not absolutely wow me, but is pretty good. I expect it will improve as Ahmed publishes more stories, too. Plus--you can't beat the price!

I got this deck (twice, actually--my dog ate the first one) because I enjoy Stephanie Pui-Mun Law's artwork and was able to preview the cards on her website before buying. I like the intricacy and grace of the illustrations. To me they feel very feminine, in a pleasing way. The colors are translucent, soft watercolors. The imagery is what I consider very optimistic and upbeat--for example, The Tower is more pretty than catastrophic, and while The Fool is still precariously balanced, she looks more like she's dancing joyfully in full awareness of her position than about to walk blindly off a cliff. Nevertheless, I have had a good rapport with this deck and have always gotten accurate readings, and they didn't feel too twee or cutesy. It works for me as well as any RWS-clone, with the added benefit that I find the art pretty.As mentioned, the deck is a Rider-Waite clone, and thus easy to interpret if you're already familiar with the RWS symbolism. The card stock is good quality (though delicious to dogs, apparently) and my cards have held up well. I've had my deck for about three and a half years, and as it is my workhorse deck, I use it frequently. I find the size of the cards fits my small hands well.But tarot decks get energetically gunky after prolonged and heavy use, and it's past time to retire my deck. I've decided to try a different one this time around. I am starting to find the RWS-clones to be somewhat limiting. It's hard to keep your interpretation from being influenced to some extent by the artist's interpretation of the card. And while that is also true of the original RWS, if you want exactly those card meanings I guess you have to read with the original. This means that the artist has a lot of power over your reading, and many artists are not tarot readers (I have no idea if Law is) nor are they working with esotericists or occultists in the design of the card. So however beautiful the imagery may be, sometimes it doesn't feel like there's any meaning behind it. I find this to be especially bothersome with the Minors, which really don't need narrative images at all. Inevitably, in every RWS clone deck, there is at least one card where the artist has departed too much from the RWS original, and not for the better, and over time it starts to really bug you. In this deck, The Moon, the 7 of Cups, and the 9 of Wands are those cards for me. (On the other hand, I feel like Law really nailed it with The Star.)I found the book that came with this deck to not be at all helpful, though it might be so for a beginner, I don't know. I would recommend getting a book that's not attached to a specific deck if you need one for interpretation (or use the internet judiciously). This book was a little too-Llewellyn, if you know what I mean. I believe it is now possible to buy this deck without any book.In summary, this is a beautiful deck which is easy to read. It suffers from the same shortcomings of all RWS clones.

I love the artwork of this deck. I tend to like old-fashioned looking decks, and I like medieval and early Renaissance art, so this deck really appealed to me. I also love the soft, earthy color scheme. LIke most of the decks out there, it's an RWS clone, so is easy to interpret if you're already familiar with Rider-Waite. The card stock is nice, durable but not too stiff, the edges of the cards are gilt, and the deck comes in a really sturdy box. In short, with this deck, you get an old feel, but with more colors and detail and a little more luxe quality than with, say, a Marseilles or Visconti-Sforza deck. All of which, on paper, is perfect for me.But (and here is why I took one star off)...For me at least, it's a really grumpy deck. If you're an experienced tarot reader, you may have found that different decks have different "feels" to them. I have heard from other readers who've experienced this, but I don't know if a deck's "feel" is the same for everyone, or varies from person to person. The latter explanation makes more sense to me because everything else about reading is particular to the relationship between the reader and his or her deck. Anyway, for whatever reason, with this deck my readings all seemed to feel gloomy and defeatist.Also--and this is an issue with any of the collaged-art decks based on old images (such as the equally if not even more beautiful Golden Botticelli deck, or the Golden Tarot of Klimt)--the artist is composing their artwork from a limited collection of images, and sometimes the images they choose just don't quite seem to fit the card meaning. It's usually a reasonable interpretation based on the RWS-system, but it always bugs me. With the Golden Tarot, Strength, Justice, and The Chariot just don't quite do it for me, even though they have the right ingredients...they're just not arranged the right way. But I think this is an issue with every RWS clone, really.I haven't looked at the booklet that comes with the deck (the "Little White Book" or LWB) in many moons and don't even know if I still have it. I don't remember anything about it.In summary, it's a beautiful, well-made deck and easy to read if you know RWS symbolism. It has the same drawbacks and benefits of any RWS clone. Yet I almost never use it because it feels so sullen and gloomy. It might be just me. Or not. I don't know. I thought I should mention it so if anyone else has the same issue, they will know they're not the only one.

Maybe it's partly because I like Irish humor already, or that I was about the same age as Martin during the era in which the show takes place (so I get the references), but this is easily one of the funniest shows I've ever seen. I have to watch every episode more than once because I am often laughing so hard at the last line that I miss the next one. I would rank Moone Boy alongside Black Books as my two favorite comedy series. The episode where Martin becomes an altar boy is just not to be missed.

I found this book totally charming and a refreshing take on tidying/de-cluttering. I had a look at some of the negative reviews and in my opinion many of these stem from a shallow reading coupled with unfamiliarity with Japanese culture and living conditions. While I don't claim to be an expert on Japanese culture, I have been there multiple times and visited ordinary Japanese apartments and homes so I am familiar with the typical architecture and home layout. Some things that might help you decide whether the book is for you:Bear in mind that this book was originally written for a Japanese audience. For me, that was one of the most charming things about it. I loved getting a different cultural perspective on organization. The Japanese generally live in very tiny dwellings (by American standards) so I figured if anyone would know how to declutter and organize effectively it would be a Japanese tidying expert.It appears, however, that some other readers are not so comfortable with a non-Western perspective. I see some reviewers mocking the notion that "inanimate" objects have feelings. In Japan, these things are not considered "inanimate." Hence you'll see signs asking that you not walk on the grass because it will hurt the grass' feelings, or not to dispose of cigarette butts in the street for the same reason. I'm not saying every Japanese person believes this (anymore than every American Christian goes to church), but there are those who sincerely believe objects are animate, in accordance with Shinto tradition, and Kondo seems to be one of them. If you don't share that belief, just use it as a psychological or imaginative exercise or something.Some of the basic ideas behind the "KonMari" system have been described in press reports about the book. If all you want are the basic guidelines without any context or explanation of why they should be used, don't buy the book, just search for a couple articles about it on the internet. But the method is quite different from conventional wisdom (an oxymoron if ever there was one) about tidying and organization, so I needed to understand the reasoning behind it. Like many people, I have tidied a zillion times in my life and it never sticks.Most of all, this is not just a book with some handy home organization tips. It is not about the daily (more or less) cleanup that comes with living. It's not Martha Stewart. Note the "Life-Changing" part of the title--that's the point of the book. Bringing your material possessions, your home, and your desired lifestyle into alignment through consciously changing your relationship with stuff. If that sounds good to you, you'll enjoy this book.

So, whenever I'm thinking of buying a book, I read the negative reviews first. They are much more revealing than the positive ones--frequently they are revealing not so much of the book's quality or content as they are of the assumptions readers bring. And so it seems to be with Solomon's books. I know this review is kind of long--the next paragraph plus the last one are my quickie summary review; if you want more specifics read the 3rd paragraph too.If I could give half-stars, I'd give this 3.5. The information is useful (albeit really dense in places...but we're talking about soil amendment recipes here, so, you know) but it's not entirely practical especially if you're low on capital at the outset. What specifically was useful? Solomon's basic argument is that plants contain nutrients derived from the soil, ergo if the soil is low in nutrients so are your vegetables. Plants are more than N, P, and K. They may look ok, you may even have good yields, but wit modern soils they are not as nutritious as they should be. Now this may not be an earth-shattering revelation (although many reviewers are surprisingly resistant to the concept...see below), but Solomon couples it with some suggestions on how to test your soil nutrient levels, how to improve them (this is where the big expense may come in, depending on your situation), and also challenges gardening orthodoxy that suggests that veggies will be nutritionally perfect as long as they're organic. The reason I deducted 1.5 stars is that after reading the book one may not be in a position to apply what they learned; which maybe is not the author's fault, but it could arguably have been addressed in the book...perhaps a chapter on "What to do if you can't access such-and-such or can't afford to shell out hundreds of dollars on amendments or can't wait three years to build your soil."Apparently gardening is a topic like health and diet in that everybody seems to think theirs is the Only Right Way to Do It. (This goes for Solomon too, although I think he's mostly right.) The #1 thing that strikes me about the negative reviews on Solomon is that people base their ideas on a very faulty understanding of the history of agriculture. I keep seeing the claim that people have been gardening for millennia and doing just fine without adding the amendments Solomon recommends (see reviews on Gardening When It Counts for more of the same), but this is simply not true. It is because of the bad methods used in the past that we are now reaping the whirlwind of nutrient-depleted soil. People have always done the best they could, but for most of history humans have not known about things like microscopic organisms in the soil or mycorrhizae, etc. "Put poop on it and keep digging until nothing grows there anymore" was basically the rule, until it was replaced in the 20th century by "put chemicals on it and keep digging until nothing grows there anymore." Analysis of skeletal remains shows that compared to ancient hunter-gatherers, agriculture resulted in people with rotten crooked teeth, stunted growth, crippling arthritis, and yes, major nutrient deficiencies. Remember rickets and scurvy? They still exist, you know. THIS HAS BEEN TRUE SINCE THE INCEPTION OF AGRICULTURE 10,000+ YEARS AGO AND IS STILL TRUE TODAY. Just because we're accustomed to it doesn't mean it's "natural" let alone optimal. Gardening and agriculture should never be compared to "nature" because they are examples of human INTERFERENCE with natural processes for our own ends. (This doesn't mean they are necessarily bad--but we need to be realistic.) Meanwhile, I also see many reviews saying Solomon's method is wrong because so-and-so does something different and their plants produce just fine--but unless they are doing a chemical analysis of the nutrient levels in their food, they can't compare their results to Solomon's, because he's not talking about yield, but nutritional content. It's comparing apples to oranges (har har).Conclusion: I'm a pretty inexperienced gardener. I haven't been able to apply all of Solomon's recommendations. But I accept his basic premises based on my very rudimentary knowledge of botany and my somewhat less rudimentary knowledge of history. if you accept the abundant scientific data, archaeological remains, and historical records that show our soils are badly eroded and depleted of nutrients; if you accept that plants get their nutrients from that soil and therefore soil chemistry is the limiting factor in how nutritious your plants can be; if you want your veggies to be as nutritious as possible; and if you are willing to read a book that is dense and has formulae and stuff, then you'll benefit from this one. If on the other hand you are already convinced your way of gardening is the Right Way, why are you even buying books on the subject? Just go do your thing.

I don't know about you, but when I graduated from hooker school, donning the ceremonial mortarboard, push-up mini-gown, and gold stilettos was a real mark of achievement. But now that just anyone can buy the regalia on Amazon, I don't know...it just doesn't feel as special.

I live in an apartment complex which will not allow any nails or screws to be used on patios. I use these zipties to hang upside down tomato planters (two per planter) and they have held up well. Where I live, it is essential that the ties be UV resistant, and so far only one has broken after 6 or 8 months (and it might have been for a different reason).

My burner arrived broken--one end piece had come unglued. Fortunately it still had the hinge pin so I just glued it back into place. Easy peasy. All the moving parts are fine and nothing is missing. I really like the design, which can burn either cone or stick incense (or loose, if you use charcoal disks and a bed of ash). It collects the ash, has a compartment for storing incense sticks, and the brass inlay and piercings on the lid are attractive. When not in use it looks like a pretty decorative box. Given that it was so inexpensive, I'm happy.

I've noticed my night vision is getting a bit worse and have always been really sensitive to glare, so thought I'd try some of these glasses. I am happy to say that they do what they promise--reducing glare and making colors very distinct so things are easier to pick out. They are especially good during those times when it's too dark for sunglasses but still bright enough to be painful to the eyes. I think they'll be great in the rain.They are very lightweight and feel like they could be flimsy. I'm being very careful just in case.

I'm always interested in books on herbology/herbalism. With this one I flipped to the "Celtic Roots" section on a lark, and it was so full of historical mistakes that I cannot bring myself to read the rest of the book. In just the first 1 1/2 pages of that section, I counted 6 blatant falsehoods and 3 highly questionable statements. If the herbal information is as inaccurate as the "history", you would probably end up poisoned. Example: It says the honking of the sacred geese saved Rome from being pillaged by Celts in 390 BC. Nope, the city was *spectacularly* and famously pillaged and forced to pay tribute, and the fear of future "barbarian" incursions was part of what motivated Rome's expansionist policy into temperate Europe (as a result of which millions of Celts were killed or enslaved, if Caesar is to be believed).This is just one example of MANY. In my opinion, mistakes this elementary are completely inexcusable. As an anthropologist and archaeologist myself, I was horrified to see that the author is or claims to be an anthropologist and a professor! These are not things that only an expert on Celtic archaeology would know--they are basic, introductory-level European history/archaeology. Even Wikipedia could have set Storl right on some of these points.Maybe you're thinking, well, who cares if the author got all his historical details right? Isn't this supposed to be about herbalism? First, it shows that at least on some topics, the author has not done any research at all. If he's going to be this sloppy and careless about the history, how do I know he's put any more effort into any other part of the book? Second, in reading the other reviews, I saw how excited people were about the "history" of herbalism in this book. Clearly, there is great interest in the that history. Is it right for those readers to be mislead by a supposed "expert" whom they should be able to trust? This suggests to me that the author has no respect for his readers.When it comes to matters of health and healing, I cannot put any trust in an author who simply pulls their info out of their hiney.Would give this zero stars if I could.

The good: I give this 3 stars because there is useful information on specific herbs, some of which (cajeput, buchu, guaiacum) I haven't seen covered much elsewhere, and on "chemical-identity" groups such as tannins and alkaloids. Also gives "person pictures" for each herb detailing the symptom profiles, and where applicable, personality characteristics of the person who typically needs that herb.The bad: For almost every herb, the author insists that you don't dare administer it yourself, but see a trained herbalist--even for herbs that are generally regarded as pretty safe these days. I don't disagree that it would be ideal to be diagnosed by a pro, but for many people, the reason they are learning about herbs is precisely because there are no herbalists or naturopaths in their area. I kept wondering what, in the author's mind, was the point of writing a book like this, that allows a person to "diagnose" (within limits) their own and others' herbal "person pictures" if they are then admonished never to apply the information? (I suppose maybe she is just trying to cover herself, legally--I have no idea what sort of regulations there may be in Australia.)The book was written in 1988, and the author implies that she was not young then, so some outdated information is to be expected. But some of it strikes me as quite odd, especially her repeated statements that if people have chronic endocrine imbalances or skin conditions like excema or psoriasis it's because their ancestors had untreated venereal disease. There is a lengthy diatribe about how it's immoral to be promiscuous because you'll inevitably get VD and curse your descendants with disfiguring skin issues. She also talks about the necessity of douching with the implication that it is necessary for cleanliness, when we now know that is more likely to cause a microbial imbalance than leaving a healthy vagina to just do its business.
