I didn't realize how much the router was holding up on the data transfer as I thought it was my internet provider. Swapped it for this D-Link and suddenly my computer's browser sprang to life. So if you have a dated router like I do and with limited budget, now's the time and you could be their target market.Set Up:- Super quick and easy I didn't need the actual manual to get started. You unpack the router to find the base unit and three antennas that you screw into place at the rear. You plug the ethernet cable (provided) from your internet provider's modem port to the rear port of this router that's labeled "INTERNET" which is also color coded yellow.- Plug the power adopter and apply power to the router.- If you are trying to connect wirelessly for the first time to the router then there is a small business card with the default router name and password. Follow that to connect either to the 2.4GHz or 5GHz bandwidth. If you are connecting via wired ethernet cable, then take any of the four gigabit ports to connect directly to your computer.- From there you simply launch your web browser and go to [...]. The set up Wizard will take over where you can finish the setup depending on the type of modem you have as well as change the broadcast name and password to your own liking.- Let the router re-start to save your settings and you sign back on with the new broadcast name and password. Once connected back in, you are now up and running.- For more advanced users, there are more settings that enable you to control the flow of data in a very easy to understand graphic interface.PROS:- Easy set up it's scary how powerful this router is, yet how intuitive it is to turn you into an advance user.- Dual core processing power that enables you to interact with this wireless router with less lag than previous router.- Fast data speeds. It's not the fastest, but it's up there in the top considering the prices of other wireless routers it's competing with.- Smartbeam technology which allows the router to concentrate on the wireless area depending on the demand of the devices in range.- Able to host and stream practically any recognizable file these days - video, audio, photo, etc.- USB port for printer and hard drives- GUI with drag and drop ability for smoothest set up.- Wall-mountable with the included hardware.CONS:- Despite being the most current model of D-Link it's still not the fastest among the other AC1900 players. However, the price of this unit makes up for the lack in speed. For regular users who are upgrading, this is plenty fast enough. For advanced users who need the most control, this may not be their cup of tea.- Odd shape. I've been used to the boxy wireless router. This one has an awkward shape with lots of edges only PC people will appreciate. I don't mind the three protruding antennas, but the footprint of this router demands more space. While the thought of hanging this doesn't really warrant being displayed, but more of hidden.- Typical plastic construction that demands to be tossed once outdated.- Very limited Bridge mode and Access Point mode. I'm glad this has a bridge mod, but it's it's too limited in feature. While it has also been pointed out to me that any router can technically act as an Access Point which after researching online is true. The problem with this router is that it is trying to analyze your input in the settings and is telling you otherwise that there is an error, etc. While trying to do Access Point manually, this router will point out that you are not connected to the internet and is suggesting to repair the settings. It will even tell you that you have no clients connected to the router. But that is not true. In my case, after manually inputting the settings to act as an Access Point all my 9 devices were able to connect wired and wirelessly to this router. They all access the internet as well as communicate with each other with the 10th device on the main router supplied by my cable provider. Despite this successful connection, I am warned I have no internet and the internet light by the front panel is not lit up. This router wants to be a smart router, but ends up being annoying.My out-dated Apple router acts as a Bridge and Access Point altogether. All I need to set is for it to be a Bridge. Then I state whether the connection is wired or wirelessly. From there is determines whether it becomes an Access Point with Bridging capability. This is what I expected from this 2014 router that boasts of it's Wizard capability.As such I am disappointed that although it has Bridge mode and everyone can manually set it as an Access Point, it cannot act as an Access Point with Bridge in the first place. If you choose Bridge, you are forced to connect wirelessly than wired which then slows you networking capability right there. Instead, you are forced to bridge from a wireless signal. If I want to improve my wireless connection I want to take the best possible source which is via the gigabit wired port. The last thing I want is to take an already degraded or reduced wireless connection and feed it into the router especially if the wireless signal is 2.4GHz rather than the latest 5GHz to begin with. This was a major disappointment for a 2014 router.OVERALL:If I was starting from scratch, I wouldn't hesitate choosing this router. It's fast and it has a powerful wireless signal. For those like me who want to expand their existing connection, it's not advantageous to choose this model.I hope D-Link is able to upgrade the firmware to allow seamless Access Point with Bridging capability via wired ethernet cable right from the Wizard setting just like my 2010 Apple router so I can truly use this as a replacement.

This may seem like an unfair comparison, but I need to point out that it somehow reminds me of the Rabbit Air MinusA2 SPA-700/780A air purifier which this Lasko HF25630 unit will give the Rabbit Air a run for it's money. Hold on, you say as the Lasko is a third of the price of the top of the line MinusA2 SPA-780A. Let me explain later in detail.Dimension-wise the Lasko looks huge because it's tall. But it also is thin. This is versus the Rabbit Air which on the other hand looks deceivingly smaller because it's short, but it has a hefty width to house the 5 stages of filters and it's filter housing. The Lasko is thin because it has 3 stages of filters. It also comes with a non-replaceable UV-A LED to aid in killing germs which the Rabbit Air does not have. Both air filters do come with Negative Ion generators which suppose to mimic the air quality in mountains, forests and beaches.I can't complain about the plastic quality. Although I want it to be feel more solid built to the touch so it can feel classy. The lighting on the other hand is a bit not too elegant. It's a nice concept, but needs more finesse in execution. There is a light strip at the top where the flat touch-sensitive buttons are located. Within the light strip are small LEDs that light up at the bottom of the flat buttons to let you know what options have been selected. The quality of the lights look cheap although the blue colour similar to the blue hue of the Rabbit Air is soothing.Set up is easy. You remove the whole unit from the box. Remove the plastic wrapping on the unit as well as on the filters. The filters have sticker markings to let you know which side faces out. These are claimed to last a full year before replacement. Except for the carbon filter which last 4 months. So you have been provided with 3 pieces in the package. Place the filter without the packaging back and turn on the unit.Controls are easy from fan speed, timer, UV-A, Negative Ion Generator, and Sleep Mode for reduced operating noise and lighting. It also comes with a Child Lock button so they don't go playing around with the unit.Now back to the relative cheap pricing of this Lasko HF-25630 air purifier versus the 3X pricing of the Rabbit Air MinusA2 SPA-780A. The Lasko is claimed to have an effective coverage area of 200 square feet of space. The Rabbit Air claims to have an 815 square feet. So you effectively pay a third of the price, but a fourth of the capable cleaning area. What you do save up on with the Lasko is the air filter cost that comes out around 23% cheaper. But then realizing there are only three physical filter stages on the Lasko versus five physical filter stages on the Rabbit Air, it comes out to be more expensive considering there are less elements in the purchase and that the filter kit is designed to filter a fourth of the coverage area.The Lasko has another weakness such that the metal stand is not adjustable or removable. That means it also has no capability to be hung on the wall.Still the Lasko is relatively cheap and does perform well. Not everyone is willing to shell out 3x more or has the need to filter a 815 sq ft of space for their intended need. At which case, this Lasko is your next best bet to do the job.

I didn't realize how basic this router was in today's day and age. For one Benjamin, I didn't expect much but I didn't expect too little.This router is for beginners and that's what the selling point is. It's for people who just want to get on wirelessly without any hassle for complicated settings or features. That's a good thing if you just want to connect via a tablet or smartphone. However if you need multiple wired and wireless combination, then it's best to look elsewhere.Pros:1. Simple setup2. Smartphone app setup and controls3. Multi-voltage power adapter4. Wireless and wired connections5. USB 2.0 printer /  external hard drive capabilityCons1. No Gigabit LAN. Only 10/100 connection2. No Bridge / Repeater Mode to extend a wireless connection3. Two non-detachable antennas4. Decent but outdated speed5. Typical wireless signal strength. Needs to be better for today's standards.I was hoping to use this as a wireless connection and turn off the wireless feature in the cable/modem supplied device.of my home internet provider. It cannot act as wireless bridge.Wireless signal despite the two ugly antennas was not any stronger than my current wireless cable modem.Perhaps as a senior this would be most appealing . All others will need to look elsewhere.

I like this product. I have always trusted 3M for its innovation. I have used a few of their automotive chemicals in the last but not in this form of a complete kit.The product came in a box within a box. The outer box is from Amazon's shipping department which basically places the 3M packed box inside. As for the 3M box, the bottles are packed right inside via a brown crumpled paper to fill in the gap. This however doesn't stop the contents from moving and shifting around when in transit so I understand how spills can occur. My 3M box had a slight spill from one of the bottles because basically each bottle doesn't have an inner seal. And for bottles with chemicals, this concerns me. So if a cap comes loose during transit, the liquid leaks out slowly as what happened to one of my bottles or severely as what happened to the others who reviewed the product.Even at half price it may be expensive but the performance each product gives is satisfying. Don't get me wrong, there is no magic in here. Just effective chemicals and elbow grease to make your detailing time worthwhile.The 3M Car Wash Soap is as I have expected with other car soaps very sweet smelling like cherry. Perhaps it's psychological but it does make washing the vehicle more enjoyable. This preps the vehicle.From there you grab the Lens and Hard Plastic Cleaner to remove any surface contaminants from the aging process.Then into the Wheel and Tire Cleaner that effectively removes grease and grime.If you haven't waxed the paint in awhile then you need to go with the Synthetic Wax Protectant. The chemical binds to your paint to form a protectant while giving a great shine in the process.The Quick Wax Detailer is an in-between wax for the maintenance of your vehicle protection and shine. Do this until you are ready for your next major wax job.Now that your exterior has been taken care of. Time for the Leather and Vinyl Restorer. This is one of the better products I've used. Like I said it's not magic but it does work effectively. The best part like my other favourite interior cleaner is that it doesn't leave an oily residue.Part of the 12-piece pack is actually just 5 pieces of similar micro fiber clothes which if you already care for your car you may have purchased these in bulk quantities like myself. So this isn't really a selling point and doesn't impress me to create a "12 Piece Kit".I wish they went further and equipped the kit with brushes for the wheel and interior. That would help anyone who wants to build a kit or to simply replace their existing ones.Overall highly recommended kit especially if you want to replace your micro fiber cloths.

Wow this was better than I expected for the price it's being sold. I was ready to receive a flimsy device but it's actually a bit more substantial to hold.The body is made of solid plastic and has metal and rubber accents. The former is to add more class. The latter is for better grip. All three components are well put together.It is a simple hand pump. You pump to suck the air out of the bottle with the aid of the supplied stopper. Once it gets harder to pump then most of the air is expelled slowing down the oxidation process.Two stoppers are provided logically for red and white wine. The seal is tight so to release the stopper you simply press down on the grey tab and voila almost fresh wine ready for another round.I wouldn't hesitate recommending this product. Price wise, functionality, simplicity, and build quality makes this a must have.

Amazon really needs to start properly labeling the Fred Perry shirts if it's regular of slim fit. As of this writing, there is nothing indicated on the description so just to let you guys know this is a very slim fitting shirt. The tag on the collar says so. I have another similar shirt with both stating slim fit, but this one is even more slim fitting despite the similar styles.The sleeves are super tight on my arms and the cut on my chest sits very close.I decided to keep because the collar and sleeve accents are different while the Fred Perry Laurel Leaf logo in burgundy colour pops out in a classy way.Recommended especially if you have a very fit body.

Love the textile and love the cut. The contrast pocket and collar is great. It stands out in a classy way.This is a slim fit shirt so it's a bit tighter on the chest and armholes. Overall a good all-around shirt for shorts or jeans.

I like this glass lid. Amazon states it's made in Germany, but the box states it's made in Italy. At least it's not made in China as this lid is quite expensive.I got this to match the WMF CeraDur Profi 8-inch Non-Stick Serving Pan. This glass lid, compared to the pan itself it super heavy. The glass is thick and unlike other glass lids it has no metal ring around where food particles can collect over time.There are no sharp folds so clean up is easier and smoother when using a sponge.The top handle is plastic, but substantial to hold.It's an expensive purchase for what it is, but worth the price it's being sold.

It's a good looking stainless steel polished to a mirror shine 8" pan suitable to cook for 1 person. For the small size of the pan, it's quite expensive. Despite Amazon's claim it's made in Germany, the packaging clearly states it's made in China. I've emailed Amazon about it. Because of this and because of the price, I'm still debating whether it's worth keeping it.I was expecting better packaging and presentation but its just cardboard paper wrapping around the pan.I also got the optional glass lid. At least that one comes in a box and made in Italy. Again Amazon states the lid is made in Germany.I got this for the organic ceramic non-stick coating that's PTFE and PFOA free. Touted by WMF to be long-lasting and can withstand heat up to 400C / 750F.Highly recommended if only it was still made in Germany.

Great in theory. I was replacing my two year old Simple Human in-sink caddy that wax all rubber and stainless steel. I just neglected to clean it regularly and formed too many water residue that made it hard to clean at the end.I thought this was a nice change since I can free up my sink space.THOUGHTS:- Nice design.- Too much plastic making it too lightweight and less elegant in feel.- Footprint is larger but has less practical and useable space than my Simple Human in sink caddy.- Pricing for this plastic is more expensive that the stainless steel caddy. What!- The rectangular bin is useless for bigger bottles. You'll need a small bottle to have something fit in there. While the bin wall is too tall my small bottle barely peeps out for me to grab properly. They should have just included a custom bottle that's tall and refillable.- Then there is the small space for a tiny sponge that mr regular 3M sponge is too big. I'd rather they make it sit up vertically to save space and have a smaller footprint.OVERALL:Joseph Joseph has some few interesting designs for the kitchen that I own. I took a chance on this one. Now I'm wondering what they were thinking to even get this passed the concept stage. It's a bad design that tosses around too easily. And for the same price as the stainless steel Simple Human caddy, they practically are getting away with murder.I'm waiting for Simple Human to make a similar caddy for the kitchen countertop. And when that happens I'm ditching this junk.

I've been a loyal Sonicare user since their original E-series with the big bulky brush heads and magnetic pulsation. Prior to that I was an Oral-B user with their round toothbrush heads but was never happy with the performance.Now on my third Sonicare model I opted for the DiamondClean edition in Black.I can't believe how expensive this model is. The contents are definitely an upgrade with a glass charger and elegant travel case that doubles as a USB charger.Contents:1. 1pc. Black DiamondClean toothbrush.2. 2pcs Black DiamondClean brush heads3. Glass that doubles as a caddy and charger for the toothbrush4. Travel case that holds the toothbrush and two brush heads and also doubles as a charger5. USB cable6. Home charger base7. Travel chargerThe black looks sleek and very cool. The backlit white  lettering and green charging icon are all hidden from view until lit up.USE:Charge for 24 hours upon first use.Press button quickly to select brushing mode.You can press button another time to turn off.PROS:- Lightweight handle versus previous models- Sleek, elegant design from the handle to the charging glass to the charging base- Slippery handle becomes almost rubbery when wet- Quiet operation due to the addition of a rubber ring to dampen the vibrating stalk of the toothbrushCONS:- Expensive- Smooth handle is too slippery- Charging glass as a storage caddy is almost too useless. It's fine for one brush with a brush head to place while charging. However if you add a second brush head to the mix for your partner then you don't have a toothbrush storage place for it. The extra brush head ends up laying around your countertop. Not to mention they eliminated the color coded rings.- Brush heads have no more color coded rings for another person.- Single button for everything just like the low model HealthyWhite series. Why? So much price for too simplistic operation. I want an on/off button as well as a button to change the brushing modes.- No more UV cleaner that doubles as the storage. I don't mind the UV elimination but at least a caddy for two or more brush heads since they can't all go into the glass.- Sticking plastic button when not pressed straight down. I found my toothbrush changes modes by itself because the button can get stuck if not pressed straight down. It needs a better button mechanism.OVERALL:I purchased this "upgrade" if only for the cool black model. Otherwise the previous Premium Edition with two handles, two buttons, a UV sanitizer that doubles as a toothbrush holder is the best value for your hard earned money.If I knew what I was getting into I would think twice until an upgrade comes along that addresses the above concerns.

I really wanted to love this Flat Bumper. I've come to respect Power Support USA since I first saw them on the MacWorld trade show back in 2002-2003 over at San Francisco with their simple, classy product design and solutions towards enhancing Apple products.Here I am still an Apple user and still wanting a simple and elegant solution towards protecting my iPhone without disrupting it's overall design. This Flat Bumper is very much identical to Apple's very own Bumper Case for the iPhone 4, but goes one step further in being very minimalistic such that it's the most inconspicuous bumper people can mistake it for the actual rim of the iPhone.It's a Flat Bumper because there are no protruding buttons. Everything sits flush like one whole plastic with no markings at all. The plastic bumper does have groove marks which basically allows that part of the plastic to bend and therefore enabling you to depress on it and the actual iPhone buttons underneath it.There is great attention to detail on the design that even the tiny speaker and mic hole cut-outs are replicated on the flat bumper case. In fact the only major give-away that it is a bumper case is through the cut-outs on the silent button, which isn't a problem to reach.So with this much glowing review, why only 3 stars?For one the fit towards the power button is not as good such that depressing on that part of the plastic may need some adjustment if you wish a better tactile feedback that you are in fact depressing the power button. Even Power Support has admitted this issue by already supplying you with a set of clear stickers that you can basically overlay on top of each other underneath the flat bumper to add thickness to that area. This will help you tailor the depressing action. Too much stickers and the power button may end up constantly being pressed on it's own. I left it alone with no stickers and got used to pressing the button even harder.This issue is not a problem at all on the volume buttons which provide excellent tactile feedback. I wish they were able to tailor the power button without the supplied stickers which I find tacky.Second and more importantly, I've come to realize the external colour - whether gold, silver or black, is painted. Underneath is a black TPU (plastic). This is very disappointing because unlike Apple's original bumper case that is molded in it's own coloured TPU, Power Support has chosen the very cheap route of molding everything is basic black plastic and just painting everything according to the external colour.The result of which since the flat bumper if your first line of defense, it takes the scuffs and grunts. And even if it hasn't fallen to the ground I find the paint easily gets chipped away. After a month of use I see small black spots here and there looking like pimples for the phone.I purchased a touch up automotive paint to re-paint it back. It's not perfect, but it's way better than the ugly black spots underneath.Recommendation:Skip. Fast forward a few months later and I find Zagg has come up with an exact replica of this flat bumper with the exception that the whole TPU is the actual external colour. So if you have some chips and marks, it's still the same colour underneath. It doesn't look cheap and ugly unlike this flat bumper in the long run. Oh and the Zagg is much cheaper and comes with a Limited Lifetime Warranty same as their Invisishield.Shame on Power Support. Like I said, I had high hopes but being the original doesn't necessarily mean being the better one.

I wish there were three kinds of cut for the Fred Perry polo collared t-shirts similar to their long and short sleeves polo sport shirts. For the polo shirts they have this one which is the regular fit which is the British cut which is a modern straight cut. It's not loose on the body and therefore is not sloppy in appearance. Then they have the slim fit polo shirt version which is ultra super fitted it's busting at the seams for my stocky build. I love the fact that the slim fit has a higher cut at the armholes and shorter sleeves, but my gosh I can barely breathe with the tight fit at the chest. They should have a TRIM FIT version which is in between the regular fit and SLIM FIT. Which means it can be a tad tighter tighter at the chest and have a higher cut at the armholes with shorter sleeves. As I mentioned the Fred Perry polo sport shirts have these three kinds of fit, but surprisingly not on these everyday polo shirts.With that said, I love the quality of these twin tipped polo shirts despite being made in China. The cloth is hefty in weight and the sewing is solid down to the twin tipped accent.The only issue with online shopping is that the colors most often don't translate well to the home user due to the varying degree of monitor brands which are not professionally calibrated. And even if you do professionally calibrate your monitor, I find the hue varies between online stores. One website has theirs a bit darker than the other for the exact polo shirt. I recommend comparing the same shirt on the official Fred Perry website to get a better idea of how dark, light or bright it might look in person.Other than that you will just have to purchase and return it if the color isn't what you expect.I find that the colors on Amazon are bang on in hue, except that whoever processed the photo made the photos too bright. For example the Black/Ochre/Coral Pink combination feels like the black has faded in the photo while the ochre (yellow) and coral (pink) twin tipped accents are lively. In person everything about the shirt is a tad darker. The black is indeed black and the yellow is like mustard. So if you account for that fact, you will get a better feel of the colors.

I have both colors of these Fred Perry Men's Gingham Trim End on End Shirt in Slate (Grey) and Pink.I actually LOVE the fit of this short sleeve polo. I especially love the styling of these "Trim End on End" which is a gingham trim and gives it a notch above the usual plain polos or even the already obvious twin tipped on the collar. It definitely provides an air of class.The reason I gave it only four stars is because I can't for the life of me figure out how Fred Perry determines the fit of it's shirts. And this is NOT a SLIM FIT.They have the regular fit which is a modern straight cut and not loose. Then they have in-between TRIM FIT which is taking the regular fit, but tailoring it closer to the chest and armholes. The third is the SLIM FIT which is the super tight fit for male models with a body I can only envy. The best way I can describe the SLIM FIT is like wearing a size medium TRIM FIT on a body meant for a size large TRIM FIT.I have all the kinds of cuts for Fred Perry for all the kinds of shirt styles and none of them fit the same way. You just have to try it on to know the actual fit on your body. For example my regular fit long sleeve polo in large is too loose almost like a pajama. But my regular fit twin tipped polo shirt in large is a great fit for it's modern straight cut. While my SLIM FIT twin tipped polo shirt also in large is too tight it's busting at the seams. Then my SLIM FIT short sleeve polo sport including these ones is the best cut and considered the TRIM FIT. It's fitted alright, but not too tight. Very decent and very British. The problem is that it's not labeled a TRIM fit. It's simply labeled also as a SLIM fit which I always buy with caution. And since some SLIM FIT are actually a TRIM FIT, I will never know what kind of fit it will actually be without trying it on.Unless there is enough previous user feedback on the fit of each shirt. Each person will just really have to buy and try. Rest assured though that if you find the right fit for your body for that particular style, then obviously a different color choice will have the same fit like these two slate and pink version.

Update 6/22:It's worth noting that other reviewers have received a PRO-642 camera with this kit which is the widescreen version of the PRO-535 camera. Both have a 960H resolution which is DVD quality. The Amazon description states you are receiving 650TVL resolution which is the PRO-535. So if you do receive a PRO-642 then you are very lucky.----------I was just getting started in setting up the Swann, until I reached into the second set of camera box kit and realized they missed packing me a power supply for the camera. Major oops on Swann.In any case, I powered the main unit to get a decent review and see what else could be missing.Everything is straightforward. You connect the unit to a video monitor which in my case is a HDTV via the included HDMI cable that surprisingly has gold connectors. And then connect the supplied optical mouse at the back. From there you can optionally connect the supplied ethernet cable, but this is really for internet function which you may or may not want to use depending on your application. The unit powers up and you are instantly greeted with a simple set up screen that let's you plug in the date, time, format settings. You actually don't need to read the manual as the OSD (on-screen display) is self explanatory majority of the time. The only setback is there are times I want to click on an icon to reveal more information, but it just exits that particular screen altogether. So at times when I thought I had more control over it, the operation reveals to be too limited.It would be best to know your ideal screen resolution for the monitor and camera you are using. This one defaults to a standard definition output and puts black bars to the left and right of my HDTV monitor. So I had to switch to 1,920 x1,800 to get proper resolution which the Swann unit was able to achieve. However, despite the recorder being widescreen capable, the included cameras are not widescreen (just high resolution). So it appears the picture is unnaturally stretched out when in widescreen mode. I will have to play with the resolution setting a little bit more to see if there is a widescreen option without stretching out the picture.Don't expect the GUI (graphic user interface) to be Mac or Windows quality. To have a person be able to jump on (say a security guard or a family member), then custom icons would be useless but text and universal button descriptions is the key to intuitive operation. At this point, yes you can probably figure out the controls faster than going through the manual. But there are a lot of trial and error text/button for me to figure out what each would do or what buttons to press to get to where I want to go. Most of this struggle is in wanting to view recorded video as well as trim, copy and paste it for saving the important ones.I know the unit will overwrite once it gets full, but I couldn't figure out how to delete a specific video which I realize I can't probably for security reasons and to ensure timeline of each recording is accountable. However the only way to erase any video is to initialize the hard drive altogether which is more dangerous because you lose the whole recording. I feel as an admin, you should be able to do in saving/deleting some than an all or nothing approach.For an 8-camera setup, you have a good choice of options on how to view on your monitor. From a single camera view, a 4-camera view all the same size, an 8-camera view with one large video and seven small videos on the perimeter, and finally a 9-camera view with all eight cameras at the same size and a Swann logo to occupy the ninth position.Camera quality of the PRO-535 is as I've come to expect at this price point. It is not a widescreen camera as I pointed above. The recording unit is widescreen capable. So there is a bit of a mismatch in the kit. It's not the greatest, but it's pretty good and clear. Even on low light indoors the video is obviously DVD quality. It is worth noting that the colors are enhanced with over saturation at times. On a cloudy day, my video surveillance looks bright and cheerful.The night video is even more impressive. You can hear an internal click when the camera determines it needs to go into night mode. At this point it switches into Black and White. With the 960H quality, you can see a great amount of detail.NETWORKING:I have not tested out the networking feature, but have to mention that the unit is capable of operating headless. Which means you won't need a video monitor once it's up and running. You can just connect it to your router and operate remotely as well as view footage.It is equipped with their "SwannLink" which you download their app for your smartphone, and then view through your mobile device. Once I have properly set this up with all 8 cameras, I will test and update my review further.CUSTOMER SUPPORT:EXTREMELY POOR! I don't mind that they are from another country. It's globalization these days, but to represent Swann in a terse and stoic way without any actual help at the end of the 50 minute call is a complete waste of time. I requested the missing power adapter. She noted everything and was typing away. Repeated all my information and then said to email their customer support regarding my request. At the end of the call I thought she was going to say "okay we will ship you the power adapter" because God forbid what else can I do with a power adapter? Rule the world? Nope. She said she took note of it all and that I should email their customer support in the USA when they open on Monday with my information and request all over again. What a complete disappointment for this company. I would have wholeheartedly recommended their product. Sure they claim lifetime support 24x7, but if I have to deal with these same people one more time should another issue occur I would just dump this product for a better one that has better after-sales support which could make or break a company in the long run.OVERALL:Everything you need to get started, set up and installed is included including what I already mentioned above - HDMI cable, Optical Mouse, Mounting Screws, BNC + Power Supply cables, Manual/Documentation, and Theft-Deterrent Stickers should you wish to announce to people you do have a video surveillance on-site right off the bat.So why only 3 stars? Like I mentioned, for a company that specializes in "security" I'm disappointed they missed packing the power adapter in one of the box set for the camera. For me that's a major blunder.Second, they provided only one power adapter and a four-way splitter to power the four cameras. If your camera placement are all far apart wouldn't it be more convenient to power them individually than have all these wiring run through the house because you only have one power supply.Third, functions within the unit can be more responsive and more intuitive. For people who don't have time to read the manual, or a security personnel who is jumping in for someone else's shift there should be a quick text that appears over an icon to further describe what action is being performed by clicking it.Fourth, poor customer support. Lack of enthusiasm and unhelpful support. I spend 50 minutes on the phone from waiting in line (25 mins) to the end of our conversation where she took down all my information, address, telephone number, etc.Other than the above, I'm pretty happy with the performance and video quality of this specific package. I would not hesitate to recommend for people needing an 8-camera setup and still on a budget.

UPDATE JULY 03, 2014:Okay so after a month, I am updating my review. My M/L sized hands has gotten used to the thin stalk of the razor versus the beefy handle of the Fusion Proglide Styler.I do find it minutely more responsive, but unlike the commercial for this new razor it's impossible that you don't stretch your skin while shaving. So I still do to allow the closest shave possible. And apart from all these, I still shave everyday.The pricing is the same as the previous model so again, it's a no-brainer upgrade if you're in the market for a new handle.I am still maintaining my 3 star review because of the reasons in my original review. The weakest link of all this is the razor blade that dulls quickly. Yes, you can do so many tricks and maintenance to make it last longer but what's the point of a disposable blade if you have to do all that work to save so little. So within 3 weeks, I toss it out or shaving doesn't become comfortable.I get it they need to make money to have you replace the blade while charging an arm and a leg for it. I've accepted that fact, but can it at least be sharp until the last use. I promise I'll toss it out every month if I have to.I think the next step is to improve the blade sharpness. Make it blow up after a month if it's still in use. That way, we still continue to buy new blades to have Gillette make money. Just saying.-----ORIGINAL REVIEWI thought I was the market for this next step in Gillette Fusion's Proglide series with the introduction of the Flexball, but it seems I am not convinced with this one.I have been a Gillette razor patron for the longest time since the Gillette Sensor progression onto the Mach3 series and finally the current Fusion series.This latest "Flexball technology" no matter how complicated it may seem is just has an addition of a pivot point that allows the whole blade cartridge to rotate left and right (yaw rotation) to a limited degree, of course. The bottom-line of this is to allow maximum contact on skin for a closer shave with less irritation.Just a note that:1. The Silvertouch is just the chrome and silver finish of the razor blade to differentiate it with the current Fusion Proglide razor to signify the additional of the Flexball technology.2. While the Fusion Proglide cartridge/blades itself is still the same carry-over from the Proglide series. Nothing has changed in this aspect so if you still have a stack of cartridges from the Fusion or Fusion Proglide series, you can still use it with this latest razor.USAGE:With this power version, the power button glows bright orange to indicate it is on. Although it is a nice tough I still find it unnecessary because the fact that one is holding the razor and it is vibrating already tells you it is on. You will not have it vibrate on your hand and then check the light to verify it is on, right? Unless one has a really low IQ. I can only hope this does not eat into the battery life.I was disappointed to have experienced hair pulling and a minor razor cut on my first attempt. It seems the razor did not glide smooth enough on my skin than I had hoped. I don't know if it's because of the pivoting cartridge that I have to re-train my hands how to handle this shaver. Still if they want more customers to adapt to this Silvertouch then it should complement their current shaving style with the Fusion Proglide and not re-educate because of the Flexball.It's worth noting that I am presently using Gillette's Fusion Proglide Styler and love it. I love the beefy handle and it's versatility while still using the Fusion Proglide cartridge. With the Silvertouch Flexball, the handles are extremely curvy to allow imaginative razor handling.What I do love about Gillette's razors is that they are able to make it look and feel more expensive that the plastic piece it really is. Kudos to the Gillette team. This comes at a price such that you do have to purchase the razor despite knowing the blade cartridges are even more expensive to purchase similar to the printer and ink business.If you have been a Gillette razor user, this is simply a natural progression with your next upgrade. If you are in no rush, then you don't need to run out and buy on it's first release. Since it still uses the Fusion Proglide cartridge, the only benefit really is the addition of the  side to side flexing motion that I did not find convincing for me to upgrade right now. I usually wait for a sale on the razor handle before I upgrade and this is something I can wait out now knowing how this performs.Lastly with the price of this Silvertouch, I am surprised they haven't equipped this with a full case with stand. More like a half-hearted plastic to protect the blade. With this release they should have designed a cool silver stand as well.Unless you are a first-time Gillette Fusion Proglide user, there is nothing revolutionary that will really make you want to throw your current handle for this one. Three stars overall for this version. I am hoping they can improve the accessories in the long run. As for me, it's back to the Fusion Proglide styler.

SD cards have gone a long way since it was introduced 15 years ago in 1999. I remember paying an arm and a leg for SanDisk's Ducati edition SDHC for over 5X the price it is today at half the capacity.Who would have known Samsung would enter the memory card market and introduce something that looks so elegant and packed with features.This Samsung SDHC UHS-I PRO line card has a theoretical read speed up to 90MB/s and theoretical write speed up to 50MB/s.The "PRO" line guarantees the card to be:- Water Proof- Shock Proof- Magnet Proof- Extreme temperature Proof- X-Ray ProofAnd then backs it up with a 10-year Limited Warranty.Amidst a sea of basic black and blue SD cards slapped with tacky multicolor labels, Samsung has introduced an elegant white SD card with a grey and silver label. They may be late to the game, but they do know how to raise the stakes and make it classy.Who is this card for? If you're a professional or prosumer then it is a no-brainer to invest in the fastest card compatible with your device and protect your data from your environment conditions.Honestly with the prices of memory cards these days, I recommend this card for everyone. Who doesn't take tons of photos and videos and wouldn't want to protect it? In fact pros are more careful with the handling of their data, but consumers tend to take, erase and toss stuff around more without thinking of the consequences.This is an SDHC (high capacity) Class 10 device that is also rated for UHS-I (ultra high speed) capable of sustained writing large full HD 1080P data files.So I say regardless of your professional or consumer status, invest in the best cards and carry it over to your next device.Shortcoming: An elegant plastic protective case should have been included for the price. But not enough to warrant a loss of star.

Since our first child, we have been advocates of swaddling for the first few months to keep the baby calm as she transitions from being constricted in the womb to having her arms flailing freely.Now on our second baby, we feel swaddling helps make her sleep soundly. No reflex waking her up in the middle of the night.Although there are two available sizes - Small/Medium for babies 6-12lbs (0-3 months) and Medium/Large for babies 12-18lbs (3-6 months) - swaddling is useful only until the moment your baby can roll over.Swaddling is purported to regulate the baby's internal temperature. However please be mindful of the room temperature to avoid overheating.PROS:- Very soft terry cotton.- Just the right amount of cloth thinness on the top portion, and a thicker padding at the bottom part- Classy muted colors- Pocket for arms in between the swaddle cloth- Velcro closure for easy closure, removal, and adjustment.CONS:- Packaging does not state there are two swaddle blankets included - Pink and Natural or Blue and Natural- Bottom part for the legs is not detachable which could be useful for layeringOVERALL:People may find this a bit pricy for it's limited use as a swaddle blanket. Yes, I also use a muslin blanket as a swaddle but this is more convenient to use and more structured by keeping hands completely tucked in and feet enclosed. When I use a blanket as a swaddle, the legs are eventually exposed and arms are able to move about until the blanket is loosened completely in a few short hours.Don't fret as there is life after it's intended use. Just like my previous swaddled, as soon as my baby is able to roll over I use it simply as a blanket. All you need to do is wrap your baby from the chest which means the arms are exposed to go about freely. That way the body and legs are still wrapped like a blanket but more secure with no loose clothing article all over the baby.Less one star because the packaging is not clear and the bottom part for the legs is not detachable. Otherwise, a good swaddler I can trust.

I owned this since it was on pre-order. Customer service is pretty helpful at first in sorting out any defects or complaints.PROS:- Nice design.- Unique clasp similar to watches.- Clasp is made of metal.CONS:- Actual bumper border feels like cheap plastic. Only the metal clasp is the winning design. They could have beefed up the bumper material with better plastics.- Power Button is very flimsy and has a design flaw. It is held in place by a thin piece of plastic that needs to be flexible to achieve the up and down pressing of the button. This will eventually snap from use due to stress in the material. At this point there is no other recourse in replacing the button. You have to buy a new case as the thin plastic has now broken into two. Trying to glue the plastic will work, but it needs flexibility so it will only go so far. As a design flaw, the button needs to be taller so it does not bend the thin plastic too much when pressing.OVERALL:When I first received the unit, the volume button had scratches. They were quick to respond and replace the case after showing them photos.The replacement case that arrived had the power button fall off on me even before I installed it. That's when I realized how flimsy this piece is and of the design flaw. I emailed them again with photos and a third case arrived.I was extremely care at this point, but you do need to press the power button so the plastic piece holding this button in place and making it flexible is also it's Achilles' heels. Over time the stress on the thin plastic will make it snap. You will not notice it is broken until you disassemble the bumper case from your phone for occasional cleaning. At this point it will one day fall off.Sadly the apparent elegance and uniqueness of this case via it's metal clasp is marred by the resulting cheap manufacturing of the rest of it's parts. You will love it and then hate it at the end.
