If the secrets became known, serious world wide repercussions would result.Klara Walden had studied law in Sweden and gone to the London School of Economics for a Master's degree before she was accepted to work as an aide in the European Union Parliament. She fell in love with Mahmoud Shammosh in London while he was studying there. They had a three year affair before their paths separated. Shammosh was working on his Ph.D. at the Uppsala University in Sweden when he was invited to be a speaker in Brussels at an international conference on a topic in which he was an expert. Someone knew he would be in Brussels because Shammosh received several emails, the last of which indicated a private meeting by a park near a museum in Brussels, each was signed with three secret code words from the past. Mahmoud followed directions to the letter to avoid being followed and met someone he recognized from the past. The person indicated he had knowledge and evidence from their past of shocking activities, he shared some photos from his cell phone. Even more damaging evidence was available to which he had access. The evidence would cause problems on a massive global  scale. Suddenly, his contact was murdered right before his eyes. Mahmoud Shammosh searched the contact's wallet and personal effects, took what he could and knew he must escape. The only thing he thought to do besides run for safety was to contact the only person he knew in Brussels, Klara.. She trusts Mahmoud and helps him discover the secret evidence, located in a locker in Paris. They are being chased by an unidentified group who want this information badly, enough to murder for it.A spy, living in Virginia and working at a desk job in Washington, DC lived with the guilt of an innocent death that occurred over 25 years ago.  It was not just any innocent death, it was the death of the mother of his infant daughter. The baby's mother died in a car bomb, the spy knew was meant for him. Due to his secret activities in Damascus, Syria, his only choice is to to leave his infant daughter on the steps of the Swedish Embassy, where he knew they would recognize who she was and find her Swedish relatives to care for her. This spy then learns of his daughter's association with what the news media identify as a known terrorist. He recognizes her on the news and feels he must help her unravel and escape from the life-threatening events in which she is accidentally mixed up. He has secretly been following her progress and life from afar, ever since he left her to be cared for by her Swedish grandparents. He feels her only hope for survival is with his expertise and help. She disappeared from sight after a heinous murder which she could not prevent occured.It turns out George Lw, a lawyer and lobbyist for a highly successful American firm, called Merchant and Taylor feels his career trajectory is well on target and even ahead of schedule. He is informed by the CEO of the European branch of the firm, that he was selected for a secret deal with a private company called Digital Solutions. George is initially very flattered to be hired by this company and  very pleased with the recognition given by the CEO for George's special skills. However, very soon George realizes he is involved in a hornet's nest of questionable activity when he is asked, actually told, to place spying devices on certain person's computers in the European Parliament. George fully understands just how high the stakes are in this life and death game of espionage. He was picked solely because as a lobbyist he had easy access and entry to the European Parliament., his comings and goings would not be questioned. By chance he learns exactly why Klara Walden went into hiding. He is held as prisoner when he learns the truth about their activities. The goal of Digital Solutions is to locate Klara and obtain the secret information she possesses at whatever the cost, regardless of who dies.  All parties involved in this life and death game of espionage, converge in an archipelago in the Baltic Sea where the matter is settled - once and for all. This novel is totally spell binding, intense, and filled with surprises, well worth reading. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This book is an artistic and literary achievement on many levels, most certainly foremost because of the writing style and talent of the author, Nancy Huston. She is able to build intrigue and interest based on several factors: first,  her introduction and development of complex subject matter; second,  the intertwining lives of two male filmmakers and third, her exploration and knowledge of different unique cultures which are woven into the fabric of the novel and which become the solid foundation upon which the lives of the characters are built and upon which the main plot and subplots rely. The complex flavors of these different cultures: Irish, French Canadian, German, Dutch, English, Brazilian and last but not least Indian, specifically Cree, are the matrix which constitute the personality and depth of life experiences from which Milo Noirlac's life stories in this book evolve. Milo Noirlac is a man in his fifties at the time the novel begins, as a final tribute to his life achievements, Paul Schwarz, his work and life partner collaborate on writing a screen play which essentially becomes his autobiography, both are award winning film makers. The connections made by the author from the past to the present and relationships between characters are written with a liquid fluidity and lyricism, the stories flow, despite the nonlinear technique of story telling.The reader is immediately drawn into the historical background of Neil Kerrigan, aka, Noirlac, Milo's grandfather who just finished law school and seems bent on losing his virginity in a brothel in Dublin. which happened about April 1910. Many years later, in Canada, Milo's mother, Awinita, happens to be a nineteen year old prostitute who works to provide money to her poor parents and family still living on the Cree Indian reservation. Milo's father is Declan, the seventh child of Neil Noirlac (changed his name from Kerrigan when he came to Canada). In Ireland, Neil was an Irish Catholic patriot and thus volunteered  in the Irish Republican Army, fighting the British rule. His brother Thom, was a student with James Joyce whose novel, "The Dubliners" was later published and won acclaim for depicting life as it really was lived by the poor Irish.  Right before Neil's eyes, Thom was shot by the British for his anti-British activities. Neil Kerrigan was advised by the poet, William Butler Yeats to leave Ireland and start a new life, preferably in Canada, where he could put his writing skills to good use.. Neil had been kicked out of his home by his father, a successful and well respected local magistrate because of Neil's involvement in rebellion and for being defrocked/debarred from practicing law. Neil sailed to Canada and met his French Canadian wife there.  He became the father of twelve children and worked in the lumber business, all the while reading good literature and collecting books, some of them first editions by famous authors. Declan, a seldom working and alcohol loving son of Neil Noirlac, fathered Milo and despite his undependable ways, remained loyal to Awinita, Milo's mother. Milo was given up for adoption, soon after his birth and lived in at least five foster families before being rescued by his grandfather Neil and brought to live with the family. Milo suffered some abuse at the foster homes, and when Declan learned of his son's fate, he often intervened, taking him out of them and had him placed in what he hoped was a better family environment. Eventually, when Neil learned he had a grandson, he took him to their own home. Milo's grandmother died in childbirth with her thirteenth offspring. The female head of the household was Maria-Thrse, his aunt on his mother's side. Needless, to say Milo had a very complicated and dysfunctional upbringing. Despite, the twists and turns of fate, Milo survived and became successful on his own terms. Some of the subject matter in this book sounds somewhat weird but the author manages to create a fascinating and engaging novel filled with unexpected surprises that keep the reader hooked and wanting to learn more about Milo Noirlac's life.Nancy Huston has received world wide attention with several of her novels: Fault Lines, Plainsong, Slow Emergencies and The Mark of an Angel. These four novels have received highly prestigious literary awards in France. The French love existentialism, art, literature, and good food and wine. Black Dance has received high praise from "Elle" magazine and from "Madame Figaro" and will just possibly be another award winning book in France. It definitely has the hallmarks of fine writing with a strong plot and unforgettable characters, along with contemporary subject matter. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This KitchenAid Nespresso coffee machine is for coffee lovers and it will make six strengths of *your* *choice* of specialty coffee to perfection. You can create your favorite specialized brew to one of six settings: 1) 25 ml/ 0.8 oz, (ristretto, which is super strong, 2) 40 ml/1.35 oz (espresso which is very strong, 3) 60ml/2 oz (still quite strong), 4) 90 ml (less strong but highly noticeable), 5) 110 ml/ 3.7 oz (strong enough for but frothy and tasty, better than American style), and 6) 130 ml/ 4.4 oz (closer to American style but noticeable coffee taste). There are 22 coffee capsules available for purchase from Nespresso on-line, other on-line stores, or you might find them at a local store near you. You receive a sample pack of 16 coffee capsules with the machine purchase and a "Coffee Menu" booklet which describes each one by intensity, country of origin, and gives guidelines of how to brew, that is which brewing volume provides the best flavor for that selection.  One thing I learned in this booklet is "a coffee's intensity is not dependent on its caffeine level." "The coffee's intensity is defined by its "degree of roasting, its body and its bitterness." "Intensity is the level of concentration of the coffee, not the amount of caffeine it contains." The instructions on use are easy to follow and I made five cups of coffee in two days before I ran into a major problem which is described in paragraph three of this review.There are two highly important booklets which *must* be read before using your machine.  The first is aptly titled "my machine" which is the instruction manual. It explains the most important features of your machine, complete with a diagram, has safety tips and safeguards, and mandatory steps to be followed for use. One thing which should be emphasized in the booklet is that before brewing coffee for the first time, it is necessary to run water through the machine three times on the "lungo" setting. There are necessary explanations about preheating, brewing the coffee, how to change the setting during mid-brew, how to empty the machine of used coffee capsules,  how to place the machine on automatic stand-by for longer than manufacturer setting of 9 minutes and the all important cleaning and care instructions. The  second booklet is a quick use guide to brewing coffee, titled "Get Brewing". This one important sentence in this booklet is very easy to miss: "To prepare the Espresso Machine for brewing, refer to your "Instructions" manual." It needs to be capitalized and highlighted in a different color, with these additional words: "it is necessary to run water through the machine three times" see page 10 of booklet "my machine".I ran into a major problem making my sixth cup of coffee: I got no coffee. After following directions as usual, no coffee came out after the flashing light stopped. I pressed the *brew* button again, no coffee. Also I noted, no water was missing from the water container. I tried ejecting the capsule, I could not lift the handle which closes the capsule compartment. After five or six attempts at making the coffee, I realized I had a major problem on my hands. I waited about 30 minutes and tried brewing the coffee again several times, same problems! I turned off the machine, reread everything in the operating manual, I reassured myself I followed the steps for brewing coffee correctly.  looked inside the capsule compartment, confirmed the coffee capsule had dropped down. Nothing was visible. I hoped I could simply remove it and then try another capsule expecting the machine would function properly, no such luck. I held the machine tightly (it is rather heavy) and shook it a bit, hoping to dislodge the coffee capsule and eject it. Nothing helped. I called the 1-800 telephone number for Nespresso on Memorial Day, where a nice person decided the problem needed to be reported to KitchenAid. There is a two year replacement warranty on this product. The next day, I called the toll free "Customer eXperience Center" for KitchenAid. I explained my problems, she quickly apologized, took down pertinent information and agreed to have a replacement machine sent free of charge as there is two year warranty. She reviewed the steps I need to follow to return the defective machine as per warranty after I receive the replacement model. All of it is at no charge to the customer, using FedEx for delivery and pick up. I have been reassured this is a rare problem. Everyone I encountered regarding this problem was pleasant, professional and moved into action to resolve this unfortunate incident. I love the coffee machine and realize with all of its complicated mechanical, computerized and technical parts, something could go wrong. Addendum June 25, 2015:  For the record, I received the replacement in three days. I returned the defective model in the same carton as instructed via FedEx prepaid by the warranty. I have used the new machine for a month without difficulties. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This book will help readers decide where to make necessary changes in their lives when they experience work / personal life conflicts. When these two areas in ones life clash or compete it results in emotional upheavals.  A  person feels miserable and dissatisfied. The author points out the cause, which is usually believing  the myth that one can have it all.  The author contends no amount of effort will achieve  this kind of balance.  Deidre  Maloney unequivocally states, it is possible to be happy and satisfied with ones life  but that one must choose  very carefully what is most important to you which is defined as having *your* all.. This book focuses on the comparison and contrasts between ones work and personal life and the authors study of people who have achieved what she calls a blissful life and some who have not.  Choosing wisely is key. Choices are highly individualized and unique to each person. The point is everyone can enjoy the journey called life. This does not mean there will be no problems, it means the good will outweigh the bad and life will be more fulfilling, satisfying and real.The book is written in a chatty, informative manner and not difficult to read. It is well organized into main topics, subtopics and detailed information with conclusions. The author has certainly done her homework on this important subject. She offers some sage suggestions and guidelines to living a more fulfilled and happy life.  While it is not clear what credentials the author possesses in terms of education and background, her book is a thorough discussion  of the subject. She explains her focus, the criteria she used and her approach.The topic of finding your bliss sounds trite and New Agey but this book is anything but that. The topic is treated in a forthright manner but not so seriously that it puts the reader off.  There is no magic formula or step by step approach that works for everyone but  this book will guide  the reader to determine *if* they need to change, it will help them set goals which are achievable. The author uses an interesting  phrase  life is a messy stew.  When she encountered  personal struggles to achieve work/life balance, she felt anxious, was unhappy and was becoming distant from her husband. She chose to examine and study the lives of the blissful people she knew and write this book about what she learned.  While they did not have it all, they were selective in their choices of what was important to them, how they used their energy, effort and time. They defined what was important using their own criteria which is not always how society defined it.This is a descriptive book based on qualitative questions designed by the author. It takes the approach of a study but it is *not* scientifically based because it does not use statistics or validated questionnaires/ tools. The author selected/identified the people for her study based on the characteristics she recognized they possessed: happy, fulfilled and satisfied  lives.  She also selected a few from the other side, unhappy ones, those who were not blissful, who  talked a lot about being overworked and overtired.  What conclusions did the author reach? The blissful group identified the following important values as the basis of their choices: their job was the right fit, they avoided/ would not work for  the bad boss, they made their decisions solely on what was right for themselves regarding the importance of salary, title and personal satisfaction. In their personal lives, they chose their partner based on the right fit which meant unique/individual characteristics/traits, understanding each others roles, choosing priorities together, recognizing and expressing respect, and keeping gratitude as a top priority. The author also discusses these areas: the blissful family, relationships with the others, and ones personal network. The concept of accountability cop as described makes a lot of sense. The issue  called  sticky family dynamic is touched upon with some important high lights but it is not given a thorough analysis. I really do not blame the author, it is very complex area and deserves to be the subject of another book. One section which stood out for me and was particularly well developed was titled Those Sneaky Bliss Busters.  It included the following chapters, The Blissful You, The Blissful Plan , Embracing  the Big C [change], Getting a Hold of that Brain of Yours, Tackling Your Money Issues and  The Science of Bliss.Overall, the author has achieved her objective in writing a most interesting and helpful book. It will be a great resource and guide for anyone to make changes in their life, if they find the ideas and concepts leading to problems apply, as discussed in this book.  The book really makes you think about what is important in life and to examine your choices through the lens of this authors perspective.  This reviewer received a free copy of the book in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This book seems small in total number of pages but it is jam packed, full of valuable information for the motivated person who wants to be successful, productive, influential and rise in status in their job, regardless of the current position they hold within the company. What makes this book so fascinating and outstanding is the promise on the cover and within the title: "unleashing the crucial leadership skills you already have."  The introduction gets immediately to the heart of the matter: most people want to know the secret of great leadership which the authors point out: depends. What does it depend on? The answer seems so obvious: the skills you already possess and most importantly on the skills you have partially developed, what they refer to as "hidden strengths" or those within the middle.The book is written in a matter of fact,  clear, precise and to the point style. It is well organized and does not waste words or time. The authors  let you know up front where most people go wrong, which is by trying to improve their areas of weaknesses and turn them into strengths. Great leadership occurs because of several factors: the skills you already possess, your environment and the goals you are working to achieve. There is no magic formula: it is all about individual learning, improving the hidden strengths meaning those already  partially developed. It is imperative to have a plan, identify one's motivation, set goals, choose two or three hidden strengths to change into learned strengths and lastly to evaluate one's progress.If your goal is to grow and succeed then this book is the key. The authors describe four categories of skills: leading self, leading others, leading the organization and leading implementation. Within each category are seven specific skills that leaders who are successful have developed and use. For example under "leading self"  the specific identified skills are" emotional control, flexibility, integrity, self-confidence, executive presence, and work/life balance. Under "leading others" some examples of skill requirements are: assertiveness, conflict resolution, verbal communication, and team work and collaboration. For the category "leading organization" some of the necessary skills are creativity and innovation, inspirational vision, organizational vision and strategic thinking. In the fourth category "leading implementation,"  the following are a few required skills: coaching and mentoring, customer focus, delegation, effectiveness and thoroughness.There is an on-line hidden strengths assessment tool which needs to be completed to identify which specific skills are your strengths, which are partially developed hidden strengths and which are considered weaknesses. It is best to work on only two or three hidden strengths. The authors advise using resources and help that is easily available to you, such as your manager  or someone you can trust as a mentor within the work place, the human resource department which may offer classes on areas you are working to improve, plus they suggest doing your own research to find books, magazine articles, classes or seminars on your identified hidden strengths. Next it is imperative to practice these new skills at meetings, one-on-one, writing proposals or wherever interactions in the workplace present opportunities. Getting feedback on one's progress can be a little tricky but the authors discuss ways for an individual to measure the progress made toward achieving identified goals. The reviewer received a free copy of the book in exchange for this honest review Overall, this is a  very excellent guide to achieving the goal of developing partially hidden strengths and learning to make them stronger toward on the job success.  Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Joseph Finder has written one of those fast-paced, easy-to-read but difficult-to-put-down suspense filled novels which grabs you on page one and does not let go until the very last page. The story grabs the reader from the first page which has an ad for a Queen Anne style home for sale  located on a large, well proportioned lot with many mature trees plus many other fine features but ends with the words "in need of updating". Rick Hoffman, the narrator adds his unique insights and ideas about the ad and reveals significant details about his lifestyle in a casually humorous and deprecating manner. Needless to say, Rick's income and lifestyle have taken a turn for the worse. A neighbor, and old high school friend,  was a builder. He offered to do some renovations on the house and accept his payment after the sales, with the expectation the house would be worth around 2 million dollars, as others had already sold for 1.5 million after repairs. Rick agreed and asked a contract be drawn up. However,  it is after some walls were demolished and Rick saw large groups of packages which turned out to be  one hundred dollar bills and some of fifties that the story picks up momentum and develops new trajectories. This unexpected discovery is the immediate hook which captures the reader who anticipates a rocky, twisted and winding but fascinating story ahead. No reader will be disappointed with this novel. It has a fast moving, well developed plot that takes the reader into the complex web and underbelly of Boston city business and politics. It provides insights as to how the city used to function (and who knows perhaps on some levels it still does.)Rick realizes that he has discovered a huge amount of cash, in fact 3.4 million dollars and it could only mean one thing: illegal pay offs. He realizes he is in great danger. He is no longer broke but his greatest concern is to discover its source. He hides the money in a storage facility and his quest now becomes to unravel the mystery of its origins. Rick's father, Leonard Hoffman, was a well known lawyer who suffered a stroke about 18 years ago, so asking him would not get any answers.  Rick is suspicious that his father was involved in some nefarious business deals and for which he received cash pay offs. Yet Rick was not convinced that his father could or would do anything illegal, knowing his character and the fact he was a well respected, highly regarded member of the community, He rummaged through some of his dad's old papers and files for leads and clues for the direction of his search. The mystery and suspense in this novel builds with each clue and the action gets more intense. Rick Hoffman is learning much more than he ever could have guessed about the types of businesses his dad represented and the complex deals which were made in the city of Boston 18 - 20 years ago. By pure chance Rick also meets Andrea Messina, a former high school girlfriend with whom he broke up right before entering college. She is much better looking than he remembered and had quit her job at Goldman Sachs to start her own business. It is a nonprofit school called Geometry Partners which helps lower income kids to learn and enjoy math. Rebuilding a friendship and eventual romance with Andrea becomes a priority for Rick along with uncovering the mysterious origins of the money he found.On this quest for the truth, Rick is assaulted, abducted and beaten up to the point of requiring hospitalization. He suffered  a concussion and several fractures. Rick wants to determine the identity of "P",  who turned up often in  a datebook kept by his dad and who had an appointment within days before his father's stroke. He wants to find him and  speak with him if possible. To this end, he meets with Monica Kennedy, a star investigative reporter for the Boston Globe, the newspaper for which  Rick had worked before becoming greedy and taking the executive position with the social magazine. An article written by Monica seemed to have much  promise of revealing a Boston scandal of major proportions but instead it became a human interest story. However, it had some intriguing loose ends which had not been investigated therefore Rick did some private interviews and investigations of his own. Following the loose ends and shady areas associated with the article, Rick not only learned the origins of the millions of dollars of hidden cash, he also  learned who his dad , Len Hoffman *really* was as person, in terms of ethics, values and moral character.  The discoveries Rick made about his  dad's character and values  were much more important to him than finding the money. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Paula McClain has written an epic novel about the life of Beryl Markham which captures the excitement, drama, romance and promise of great opportunities for success (or failure) in a new land which was raw, natural, and undeveloped. It is about life in Kenya in the 1920s which the British were colonizing and is a fictionalized story based on a real person, Beryl Markham. The author incorporates some  stories from Beryl Markham's autobiography, West with the Night, but most of it is fiction. This  novel is filled with charismatic, larger than life personalities, whose strengths and flaws (sometimes obvious other times well hidden) are carefully revealed in a novel filled with adventure, romance and unexpected conflicts and problems, some are resolved, others not. Beryl had married twice, each marriage failed for very different reasons. Each of her marriages occurs within different circumstances, the context of which promises Beryl very different lifestyles and very different conflicts and problems follow. Beryl's life story makes for excellent reading, first because of the exotic location and era but mostly because of the talented writing style, prose and unforgettable moments described by the author. Two failed marriages and one grand but surprising love affair, which is really a love triangle that includes a good female friend, whom Beryl liked and admired, should be enough enticing information about the plot.The real Beryl Markham broke from the conventional role for women at a time when this was unheard of. Perhaps it is more accurate to say, due to her early upbringing which had few restrictions and unbridled freedom, she was never molded into any conventional female role to begin with. She lacked a female role model because her mother could not get used to the hardy lifestyle expected of women in Kenya nor did she appreciate the wilderness or its seclusion and isolation especially from  society. She returned to England with her son, who had frail health, leaving five year old daughter Beryl to be raised by her father. Beryl had natural abilities related to handling horses that she inherited from her father and she also possessed an innate courage which she applied to becoming the first licensed female race horse handler and trainer in Kenya and later was the first female pilot to be granted a professional B license (both actual events in real life), Notably, the real Beryl Markham had the remarkable achievement in 1936 of flying across the Atlantic Ocean, in twenty one hours, which was a record-breaking event at the time. She had received a huge reception in New York where 5,000 people gathered to welcome her but no such reception in her England awaited her. During much of her real life, scandal and gossip plagued her and it is upon this which the author, Paula McClain builds a highly engaging, fascinating, and well written fictionalized story of Beryl's  complex nature. Erika Borsos (pepper flower)

Deborah J. Cornwall takes a difficult and sensitive subject and conveys much needed information in a clear, concise, compassionate manner. This is a fine resource for helping families to cope. It is a great guide to help them live through this highly threatening disease, its treatment and the emotional impact on all members of the family. The author deals with complex issues, such as the initial diagnosis, the impact on one's personal life both within the family structure as well as with friends and school, the possibility of a failed outcome which means the possibility of death, the need for strong pain management and its unintended consequences, side effects. The story which stood out most for me was where the daughter-in-law cared for her husband's father at home while he was dying and how she coached her two children ages eight and five, through helping their grandfather die with dignity. A hospice worker helped the children create a memory box and special windmill. The children placed Grandpa's pillow case into a plastic bag to keep his memory alive and fight over who gets to sleep with Grandpa.The chapters are well organized and clearly written. The author breaks down the chapters as follows: Chapter One: Sharing the News, Chapter Two: Managing Cancer's Impact for Children, Chapter Three: When the Child is the Patient, Chapter Four: When Children Lose a Parent or Sibling to Cancer, and Chapter Five: Other Resources for Caregivers About Children.  In the Preface, the author shares an acronym CHIN which stands for C- Control, H- Hope, I- Isolation, and N- Normalcy. The CHIN concepts are incorporated throughout the book to bring better understanding and management of dealing with the difficulties which arise with a cancer diagnosis.One helpful feature in this book is that the main concepts or principles are boldly printed at the beginning of each chapter. The author then  describes each concept and provides real life examples of interviews with families and children, which are printed in italics making it easy to read and differentiate from the author's own writing. For example in Chapter One - Sharing the News, the author placed six principles in bold print: Be Proactive, Tap Expert's Best Guidance, Consult with the Professional Care Team, Meet the Child's Needs Not Your Own, Level With and Engage Older Children, and Be Direct.  Each principle is given a thorough explanation in a clear precise manner. The  author also lists resource books and websites which support the principles she discusses. This book does an excellent job in helping those affected to cope and manage the complicated issues, emotions and behaviors which may be experienced by the caregiver, communicator or the children involved. The reviewer received a free copy of this book in exchange for this honest review.Anyone interested in this subject is also recommended to view the documentary "A Lion in the House" which shows a six year journey of living with different cancer diagnoses by five extraordinary young people. The film looks at the children within the context of family, the hospital and their individualized treatment and how everyone affected by the disease copes. It shows meetings with doctors, coping with insurance coverage, nurses providing treatments, the difficulty of making decisions related to care and treatment. It is a heart wrenching film but highly inspiring and hopeful as well. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Lonely Planet has created an innovative, colorful and most important of all, a handy, easy to use and very helpful guide to explore the exciting, bustling Asian city: Tokyo. This very useful guide offers many possibilities for experiencing one-of-a-kind, individualized memorable adventures based on personal interests.  A wide range of opportunities are described on small activity cards, in fact there are descriptions of twelve opportunities or activities on each card, that is twelve cards each for morning, afternoon and evening, which allows for many unique experiences. Easy to read maps are included for the visitor to mix and match activities based on region visited or on areas of interest such as, art or historical museums, cultural or historical landmarks, imperial gardens, famous shopping districts and best viewpoints from observation towers in famous high rise buildings. The mass transit system (subway) is described which allows the visitor to navigate and travel from one location to another in rapid time. One very large city map is included which will make locating places of interest and ability to determine distance and time for travel much better.There are uniquely Japanese experiences available such as, Sumo wrestling matches or visit the neighborhoods where they live and train, Shinto shrines, open air markets, famous seafood markets, kabuki theater, vintage neighborhoods, historic geisha quarters, modern shopping districts and the well known East Shinjuku nightlife. The authors provide information about restaurants on each suggested activity card, with a mini-map and instructions for transportation on how to get there. The "getting around" section is very helpful describing the subway system, discount transportation cards and the best means to get to and from the closest airport. Included in the guide are useful tips for shopping for oneself, others and for children. Some assistance is given about the currency, and usual hours of service for museums, restaurants, and bars. Websites are given for Lonely Planet, Tokyo Tourism, and Metropolis which lists arts and entertainment activities. Some useful tips are given for "dos and don'ts when eating and drinking" and an important aspect of bathing which is a ritual in Japan, of interest is that people with tattoos may be refused admittance at some bathhouses. The only thing missing in this travel guide is a listing of hotels which for most people should not be a problem as anyone these days can research their choice of hotels and prices and make arrangements on the internet. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

The title of this book of short stories speaks volumes about the content. Who can resist mayhem in New York City especially if it occurs in Manhattan? The slim volume I received is a sample of four short stories which will be included in the *final* published book that will consist of seventeen or eighteen stories, depending on which information I read is correct. The cover of my "advanced reading sample from uncorrected proofs" names 6 authors and then has this added "and 12 others" which equals 18. The table of contents lists 17 titles of short stories. Whichever is correct, if the four stories I read are any indication of the rest of this book, I can predict, the reader will be sorry if there are only seventeen! The four I read are spell binding, highly engaging, complex stories filled with unforgettable characters that have great depth and well developed personalities. There are suspense-filled plots with twists and turns which lead down paths to places, feelings, situations, and events the reader can not anticipate which make the stories all the more appealing and memorable. There are magnificent black and white photos of New York which enhance the appeal of these stories, presenting the city as a magical mysterious landscape.The first story, "Three Little Words" written by Nancy Pickard engages the reader's emotions from the start, Priscilla, an attractive young woman in her mid-twenties is told by her doctor she has only a few weeks to live. She and her doctor engage in "gallows humor" and he advises she make a "bucket list" of things to do to make whatever time she has to live, worthwhile. She gets note paper from him and writes these words "tell the truth". They decide she should check in with him every day which she does for three days and he does not hear from her the fourth day. It turns out for a good reason, she was murdered on a street near her home where she usually jogged, only her energy lately only permitted her a fast walk, if that. Dr. Sam Waterman decides to attend her funeral, despite the fact she was a patient. The funeral was highly unusual to say the least. Her family, the Windsors: parents, sister and her boyfriend all sat together, stoically without shedding a tear or looking mournful. Just at the close of the service, someone stands up and choses to describe one of Priscilla's last meetings with him. It brought smiles and tears to many attendees faces. It turns out he was offered $5,000 by Priscilla for engaging customers in a different manner than his usual during his business day. A taxi driver told another humorous but heart warming story of his encounter with Priscilla. Dr. Waterman learns some personal matters about Priscilla from her god-mother who took care of her during her teenage years and whose husband bequeathed her $ 3 million dollars. The detective who was investigating her murder shows the doctor a list of items, 6 of which are crossed off and the last one, the word "Dustin" is not. The doctor recognizes it as Priscilla's "bucket list" but denies knowing what the word "Dustin" refers to. However, as the story unfolds more details are revealed about Priscilla's secret past, the *real* reasons for her the broken relationship with her parents and sister become evident. Even more surprising is the greatest revelation of all: the link between the word "Dustin" and Dr. Waterman.The other three stories in my sample volume are just as fascinating and enjoyable. The second story "Chin Yong Yun Makes a Shidduch" author S.J. Rosen is about a Chinese mother, who partakes in a private matter associated with the kidnapping of a young Chinese woman, Valerie Lim. She is the girlfriend of her son, Tien Hua, whose American name is Tim. He is her very successful son who is unmarried and a lawyer. Valerie's mother asks Tim to deliver the ransom money to the kidnapper. Tim asks his mother to notify his sister, Ling Wan-Ju, known as Lydia, who is a private investigator. Tim tried unsuccessfully to reach Lydia and knows his mother is more likely than anyone to get hold of her very fast. He specifically admonishes his mother make sure the police are not notified which is at the request of Mrs. Lim. The kidnapper asked for a ransom of $200,000 dollars and the great fear is he might murder Valerie if his demands are not all met. The story is told from the perspective of Mrs. Hua, a widow, who is the loving mother of five successful Chinese adult children. She also interferes in the personal lives of her children, which often by American standards would be annoying to say the least. It turns out, rather than notify Lydia,  Mrs. Hua does some investigating of her own and uncovers fine details which actually lead to the identity of the kidnapper who is apprehended by the police. In her well meaning and loving manner( from her viewpoint) she resolves another thorny issue in Tim's life and it is yet to be determined how this latest intervention will be viewed by Tim or if it brings about the hoped for results.The third story, "Trapped" written by Ben H. Winters is really about a "play within a play" on multiple levels. There is an investigation of the murder of Mr. Otto Klein,who is the producer of a play titled "Deathtrap.". All the actors and actresses are suspects. The questioning by the investigator, the innuendos, the accusations, the assumptions of "who dunnit" are superbly written and very humorous. The twists and turns of the different people who become suspects and their presumed motive for the deed are enormously funny to read. Even more amusing is the ending which is the ultimate twist in the plot or perhaps more accurately the turn of the screw,  which no reader could possibly predict.The fourth story, "The Day After Victory" written by Brendan Dubois provides new insights into how victory is defined and experienced by different people. Needless to say, justice is done. I highly recommend this book of short stories and look forward to the 13 or 14 other stories which are to be published in the final version of the book. Erika Borsos [pepper flower}

Mia Alvar has written realistic, in depth, thought provoking sensitive and eye opening short stores that provide the reader insights into multiple levels of society, usually of expatriates from the Philippines who emigrated or work abroad, to earn a better living. The stories describe their everyday lives, their joys, sorrows, aspirations, struggles, and successes. The stories examine, explore, and reveal many facets of human nature with precise descriptions and prose. Often there is a twist, turn or revelation that comes out of the blue giving completion or finality to a story. Often it leaves the reader in a state of astonishment but fully satisfied. These are cultural stories therefore the reader is given a glimpse into the values, beliefs, and minds of the people from many walks of life from the Philippines.The following are some outstanding examples of the insightful and excellent stories written by Mia Alvar. "Kontrabida" is a story about a young man, a pharmacist who emigrated to the United States, lives in New York but visits his parents in a suburb on the outskirts of Manila where he grew up. His father is very ill and in pain. The young man smuggles pain relieving narcotic drugs, the newest and latest used in the United States which are unavailable in his homeland. He risks his career for the sake of helping his family. After his father dies, he learns a very dark secret about his mother whom he held in very high regard and loved very much. "Miracle Worker" takes place in Bahrain. A young special education teacher lives in this country with her engineering husband who is helping to develop the oil industry. The young teacher is hired by a very wealthy to teach their severely physically and emotionally handicapped daughter. Sally accepts this high paying job but soon realizes the mother's expecations for her daughter are very unrealistic. Sally faces an ethical dilemma to dispel the mother's illusions or continue to lead her on and receive the high compensation given for the teaching job.  Mrs. Mansour makes trips to London and showers Sally with unexpected bonus gifts. Sally describes breakthroughs in Anoush's development which she shares with Mrs. Mansour. Sally begins to understand the strong bond between mother and daughter and the cultural discrimination which the mother faces having given birth to a handicapped, a "less than normal", "less than perfect" baby and the difficulties she faces raising this child in their culture. Sally makes a difficult decision.There are many complex stories, filled with drama and intensity which makes this a very interesting and fascinating book. The author is a talented writer. It is hard to believe this book is a debut novel. She possesses great writing skills, has a keen understanding of human nature and conveys deep insights into the motivations and feelings behind the behavior of her characters all of which make her stories shine. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

When faith and hope in God are combined with reality, the outcome can result in miracles and that is what this book is about, in fact, it is about four miraculous births and their survival against many odds. When the life of the author's pregnant daughter, Anne was threatened due to serious respiratory distress and failing kidneys, the difficult decision was made to do a Caesarian section surgery to deliver her four highly premature babies, at the age of twenty four weeks and a few days. The reality is the early birth and survival of these premies with the help of  modern medical knowledge and advancements in technology combined with highly skilled professionals, including neonatologists, NICU (Neonatal Intensive Care Unit) Registered Nurses, and Respiratory Therapists plus many others. These dedicated professionals kept vigil and applied all their caring, skills and knowledge to save the lives of these "born before their time" babies, all of whom lived through many challenging events after they came into this world. The surgery brought them out of the womb which was supposed to be their home for proper nourishment, development and maturation for several more months. In this highly personal and dramatic book, Timothy Spillane recounts the difficult decisions, emotional upheavals and many harrowing struggles which occurred after the entry of these very special children into the lives of the Schlender family (Anne, a Dermatologist and Captain in the Army and her husband Robert, an engineer), plus maternal grandparents, Timothy and Donna, Aunts, Erin and Caitlin plus the Schlender grandparents, Gene and Julie.Many stories stand out as particularly well written and outstanding, all of them are about the life-threatening events faced by various babies at their early point of development.  Wyatt Lee one of the premature boys was transferred to a NICU in Christus Santa Rosa where a neurosurgeon placed a ventriculo-peritoneal (V-P) shunt into his brain to deal with his hydrocephalus, a condition not uncomomon among very premature infants. The other very harrowing event to be resolved was the Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), an opening in the heart between the aorta and the pulmonary artery which was a problem for three of the babies, Timmy, Edda and Wyatt. The recommended treatment was intravenous indomethacin, which had some risks but was the first treatment of choice before surgery. While the IV Indomethacin worked for Wyatt, for Timmy it caused a perforation in his bowel which required two drains be placed on the right and left side of his abdomen, to prevent infection, while the tear healed itself. Unfortunately, Timmy developed other complications, where his heart rate rose and blood pressure dropped, a life threatening condition which required an intravenous vasopressor drug, luckily it stabilized his blood pressure. Timmy was transferred to Christus Santa Rosa Hospital temporarily for surgery to close his PDA. Unfortunately, during this surgery, the left side of Timmy's vocal cord was damaged which affected his voice and ability to cry outloud. All the babies had screenings for Retinopathy of Prematurity, three of them needed laser surgery to prevent the abnormal growth of blood vessels in their eyes, only Timmy's eyes were mature enough to not require this intervention. The author does a great job in describing events which eventually led to the discharge home of all four babies and the challenges they faced in development as they grew into becoming toddlers. Especially gratifying are the photographs which allow the reader to view these premature quadruplets during different stages of their lives.Timothy Spillane possesses a rare gift for writing, which gives the reader the sense of being in the midst of the action and events, all the while experiencing the feelings and thoughts associated with the difficulties and triumphs of helping four prematurely born babies to survive. Throughout, the author provides the reader occasional stories about his daughter Anne and her sisters while growing up. We learn about how Anne met her husband, Rob and their decision to have children plus some of their concerns, especially fascinating was Rob's prescient thoughts about this monumental life change. The author shares with us his own story as a new parent when in his mid twenties, he and his wife became parents to identical twins, Anne and Erin who were also born prematurely but by no means as early as Anne's quadruplets The author concludes the book with wonderful descriptions of the milestones achieved by these special children, and how they beat the odds and continue to live purposeful, happy lives bringing joy and fulfillment to their family. In summary, the author's honesty and  great attention to detail, personal and emotional, along with his accuracy in describing medical conditions and ethical dilemmas that arose while the four premature babies hovered between life and death places this book in a category by itself, far above many other memoirs. The reviewer received a free copy of the book for writing this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This is the correct replacement battery for my Aspire One D255E-13639 model and I recommend  this seller and product to anyone who needs a replacement battery. After four years, my original battery wore out. I did a search on amazon and asked a few questions. I received very helpful responses both from the seller as well as customers who bought this item. The best advice was to look at the battery model which was on  a sticker on the computer itself.  It was very reassuring to see my battery model listed on this site so I ordered the product. It was also very reassuring to read the satisfied customers and their reviews here.I replaced the battery in my computer without difficulty but it took a few tries because this battery is somewhat larger than the original one which is no surprise as several reviewers have mentioned this.  I discovered how to slide it in using the grooves and click it in place, an easy process. The larger size is not a problem because it provides a better tilt to using the keyboard and also for viewing the screen.Best of all: this product has more battery power (6 cells) and provides about 5 - 5.5 hours of use than the original which gave only 1.5 - 2 hours of battery use (3 cell battery).  The instruction booklet recommends letting the battery go down to 2% *before* recharging it for the first time to 100%. It also recommends keeping it charged to at least 70% for best use. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Volume V completes this series of reflections on honest, truthful living. Robert Chomany provides inspiring insights into walking the path to create a spiritually fulfilling and satisfying life. In this last volume the author writes about these topics: Let Go, Journey, Be Present, Learn, Dream and Change. With simple but very effective clear prose and verse the author tackles big concepts by illuminating their meaning and message. He gives crystal clear understanding to the manner and means of living these concepts but the realization, awakening and desire must begin from within. With a preliminary discussion, that usually begins with a few questions, the author stimulates the reader to think about each topic and realize the importance of its expression in their own life. The reader is guided to realize everything is a choice and many possibilities of outcome and experience exist based on the insights and expressions of reality one chooses. The goal of living an authentic, honest, fulfilled and satisfying life is within everyone's reach. Robert Chomany, aka "Bawb" provides much food for thought as well as action. It is a matter of choice. Anyone interested in living more fully and completely would benefit from reading this fine series of books. The reviewer received a complimentary book in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower}

In Volume IV of this highly inspiring series Robert Chomany reflects on the important concepts of Confidence, Doubt, Success, Patience, Rest and Gratitude. Bawb provides a general introduction before each topic which makes the reader understand and realize how living and expressing the concept makes one experience a  more satisfying and fulfilling life. The author provides encouraging, inspirational poetry in an easy to follow, flowing style that is crystal clear in its expression of truth. The following are two examples of the simple expressions which are rich in meaning: "A shadow of doubt is simply that: a place where light does not shine. Just by being confident you can make that space divine" (p. 24). Another gem" Life won't always be what you expect, in fact sometimes it's a chore; to give success a chance to knock, you may have to build your own door." (p. 47) Another expression of simple truth: "Don't rush through your life, take time to enjoy it. we all have calm balance once we take time to employ it." While the statements themselves sound simple, living and expressing them in everyday life takes a enlightened awareness and remembrance of what is important right at that moment which is spiritual reality and being true to oneself. The reviewer received a complimentary book for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

In Volume Three, Robert Chomany provides clear guidance and spiritual insights on the journey to self-discovery and how to live a more fulfilled life. In this 98 page book, the author covers his thoughts and ideas on how to live and express these concepts: Strength, Belief, Energy, Positivity, Balance and Renewal. The author provides thought provoking questions or discussions prior to engaging the reader through poetry into awakening the inner guide and spirit to recognizing and expressing the concept in a natural and real manner in one's own life. The author is gentle, sensitive and clear in his poetic expressions which are honest, truthful experiences that are verifiable by anyone who chooses to live within the framework and guidance of these principles. The reviewer received a complimentary book in order to write this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

In Volume II,  Robert Chomany, aka Bawb continues to help the reader open their heart and ability to see life through a new spiritual lens. In ninety three pages the author covers the principles and concepts of Challenge, Perception, Choice, Smile, Opportunity and Being You. Prior to each concept, the author writes his thoughts and ideas which help the reader connect to the importance of how the concept is expressed in his or her own life. Bawb provides encouragement to live and experience the principle, dispelling the feelings associated with fear or failure. In clear, precise and honest verse which are two, four or eight lines each, the author provides stimulating thoughts which build strength and which helps the reader grow in awareness of the truth of living the principle discussed. Robert Chomany provides simple but illuminating truths that help the reader live a more satisfying and fulfilling life. The reviewer received a complimentary book for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

In poetry and prose Robert Chomany provides gold nuggets of truth written for anyone interested in reconnecting with their spiritual nature. In volume one there are 87 pages with a small poetic introduction which sets the mood, to learn how to awaken one's inner self, to open up to whatever is natural, real and fulfilling in life. In this small volume Bawb helps the reader connect to these important concepts: the Moment, Solitude, Simplicity, Serenity, Beauty and Time. BawB provides an introduction to each section which makes the reader think, feel and contemplate about each concept in order to open one's senses and feelings to live and experience life.  After each main section, Bawb has written a four line rhyming verse that clearly expresses a thought, idea, or feeling which helps the reader realize how important it is to become aware of the concept and principle in order to live more fully and completely. As Bawb states, he is reflecting on the simple things in life but anyone who reads this volume will realize he is writing about the most important things in life. The reviewer was given a complimentary book in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

With a great deal of candor and humor Mireya Navarro recounts her captivating, engaging, and occasionally tug-of-war relationship with Eddie, her husband's dog. The dog came into her husband's life four months before Mireya and as such he laid claim to him as master and best friend. He often treated the author as a rival and competitor for her husband's affections, friendship and even territory, as in their bedroom. The dog was a mixed breed, a mutt that had the appearance of an Australian cattle dog, called a blue heeler, When he was taken out for walks, he was admired for his distinctive fur and coloring which consisted of many dark spots of different sizes on white fur. The author had me hooked right from the start with this sentence: " I underestimated the dog."  His personality toward the author remained tolerant but at times became passive-aggressive. The expressions of his behaviors as described in the book are superbly told in three locations. Their relationship began in Los Angeles where Jim, her husband and she lived for about five years after they got married. Next. their jobs required a move to New York to which Eddie adjusted rather well given his proclivities and eccentricities.  It is in Montclair, New Jersey, where the author and her husband bought a house, within relatively easy commute to their jobs in New York that Eddie begins showing acceptance and even affection toward the author. Unfortunately, by this time Eddie is in his declining years and this makes for a poignant and yet very sad but satisfying ending to his life story.Eddie's life is a wonderful story but the fact that it is told within the context of two cultures, the author's which is Puerto Rican and her husband's which is Jewish, adds even more spice to an already promising tale (no pun intended). The story is also told within the context of a second marriage for Jim, her husband, who has two preteen children, a girl and boy who spend half the week living with him and the other half living with their mother who also lives not far from them in Los Angeles. The author is secure in her love for Jim and their marriage but does not realize the challenges she will be facing entering a household where there will be two teenagers and a dog. The author is  in her early forties, a Pulitzer Prize winning reporter, and a single female. She was attending a National Association of Hispanic Journalists convention in Phoenix, Arizona when she met her future husband Jim Sterngold who was there working on a story for the Times. He asked her out for a drink and the rest is history. The author does an outstanding job of weaving her Puerto Rican cultural roots into the book and the emphasis and  importance of being close to family. I enjoyed reading about the author's Latina friends, both in Puerto Rico and in New York. Especially memorable is the description of life growing up in Puerto Rico and her mom's concerns that Mireya would die alone. The reader could easily understand and appreciate her mom's happiness when Mireya got married. This is an outstanding book in which the author shares memorable moments in her life, beginning and ending with Eddie but which grows into a story about what is really most important in any human life. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

I have tried a previous OZ Naturals skin care product, the Super Youth Eye Gel, and was very satisfied with the results in diminishing wrinkles and smoothing the skin below and around the eyes. I have used other skin care products which contained both hyaluronic acid and various botanical extracts and had excellent results: noticeable the same day within 15 - 20 min of use therefore anticipated good results with this product as well. This product lived up to my expectations and it does *exactly*  what is stated on the box: "diminishes surface lines and wrinkles by stimulating collagen." I have used this serum daily over several days and can see a difference initially within 15 - 20 minutes after application (this is the truth).. Exactly what I expected as other products in the past gave me similar results within the same time frame. The smooth skin is even more noticeable within a couple of hours after use and continue throughout the day and for me last well into the next day. The first area of results is where I have smile lines on my cheeks, right below the corners of my nose. The wrinkles are *definitely* less evident, honestly almost gone, much smoother and the skin remains soft. Use the eye dropper applicator to apply a thin layer of the serum over the chosen area, let it dry, but first apply your choice of moisturizer. The ingredients in this product are clearly listed on the box: organic aloe, witch hazel, botanical hyaluronic acid, kosher vegetable glycerin, Organic Jojoba Oil, wild crafted green tea, germanium essential oil, Vitamin C, Vitamin E and a few other ingredients that help stabilize the product. I highly recommend this skin serum for anyone who wishes to reduce facial wrinkles and have the appearance of more youthful skin. Reviewer received a complimentary product in order to write this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

In this book Mohammad Rehman introduces the reader to the main concepts of Islam as written in the  Holy Quran (translated from the Arabic into English by Abdulllah Yusuf Ali) which clearly states what the relationships, beliefs, and intentions of the Prophet Mohammed were toward Christians and Jews, who are regarded as people of the Abrahamic religion to which Islam also belongs. The Quran describes the correct and expected behaviors and actions of Muslims which are acceptable to God, those that promote harmony and a peaceful life and  after death, when judged in the afterlife, it becomes the basis for acceptance into heaven.  What the author does so very well is break down various concepts by chapter and verse, with explanations and analysis that he gives, comparing the correct concepts and behavior with the corrupt, evil behavior of current followers who have created a movement based on false precepts. What needs to be understood is that the Quran was written during the lifetime of the Prophet by his followers and that it is divided into thirty chapters and one hundred fourteen verses or surahs which is entirely complete. The author writes it is the constitution of Islam which therefore can not be changed, added or be bypassed. Mohammad Rehman states "The Quran should not be followed up by any later written laws, such as the Hadith and Shariat, as it is authentic and whole as it was created, as the word of God."The author dedicates his book to all those who suffered either because of their race, religion, ethnic origins or social standing (caste). He lists examples of world conditions and events which led to humanities suffering on a large scale: the killing during the Crusades, the Inca's being conquered by the Spanish, the tyranny of the British Empire, Japanese civilian deaths at Hiroshima and Nagasaki, various murders attributed to ethnic cleansing in the past and recently in modern times, the suffering of the Palestinians who are homeless and conquered in their own land, innocent victims who died during Sept 11, 2001, families and civilians who were killed during the Iraq War, and the war torn country of Afghanistan where ordinary civilians are struggling to live. He dedicates the book to just men who rose to save us. He mentions Gandhi, Dr. Martin Luther King and Sultan Salahuddin Ayubi, a Muslim leader who was a just follower of civil law and even treated prisoners with compassion. The author reviews Prophet Mohammad's life, how he received the revelations from God and how he conducted his life, with simplicity rather than living in riches and wealth.With significant detail, the author writes about four eras of Islam during which times very different emphasis was placed on its expression in the regions where Islam was practiced. The reader is provided a historical review of important Caliphs, the creation of the Sunni and Shi'ite sects, various revolts and rebellions and which sect conquered what region or existing country in the Middle East and Arabic peninsula at the time. Special emphasis is placed on the era between 749 AD and 945 AD when the compilation of the Shariah took place as well as writings associated with the Sunnat (the ways and teachings of the Prophet) as conveyed by his disciples. These two distinct writings took place about one century after the Prophet's passing. The author emphasizes that almost six or seven generations lapsed before the Sunnat was written which means errors of communication could have been passed down. About two hundred years passed when the Shariah laws were compiled in about 800 AD which could lead to mistakes in interpretation. Various important events associated with ruling dynasties and empires are discussed: Ayyubid Dynasty, Ghourid Dynasty, Safavid Shi'a Empire, Timuri Mugal Empire, Ottoman Empire and the Modern, Technical Era with changes in countries, such as Ottoman Empire and Turkey, Arabian Lands, Egypt, Iran,  India, Pakistan, Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya, and Syria. Lastly, the author provides a historical overview of fifty countries in the world where Islam is the major religion. The author does a review of how each country fares in its true expression of Islam related to conduct of everyday life, political expression, wars, and their outcome, treatment of people, and social life. Overall, this is a superbly written book providing spiritual insights into the practical expression of Islamic culture and behavior from the ancient past into present times and just how far it has strayed from the original scripture and intent as written in the Quran. It is a courageous book in that the author dares to point out deficiencies in the practice of this religion in major countries of the world. It is not a highly politically charged and detailed analysis of misbehavior but a gentle overview of the religion, its historical expression in the past and in current times. The reviewer received a complimentary copy of this book in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Leonard Mlodinow has written a highly relevant and easily flowing book about scientific discoveries past and present that shaped the experiences of modern man. The author leads the reader on a great exploration of human development as a whole with questions that remain unsolved in modern physics, specifically quantum mechanics. What makes this book so fascinating and approachable for the ordinary reader is the author does not get bogged down in an inordinate amount of detail to lose anyone's interest.  This book is a great overview of the story of human development from the discoveries of anthropology and how primitive man learned to survive and changed both physically and mentally over two to three million years to become the species we are today. This is why the title of the book  "The Upright Thinkers" is so fascinating because it seems to have a dual meaning, "upright" in the sense of standing on two legs or bent over or on all four appendages and "upright" which is related to the behavior of mankind, its synonyms: honest, honorable, worthy, virtuous, principled, and noble. The author includes some personal anecdotes, memories of growing up and his family history round out the stories and provide glimpses into the author's thinking and love of science which enhance the reading pleasure.The chapters are divided logically and sequentially over time. The author provides a great discussion of the history of civilization where man's "need to know" initially was related to survival which then expanded over millions of years to creating instruments such as the telescope and eventually theories about the orbits of planets.  Eventually the observation of natural phenomenon,  such as  gravity lead to deeper understanding about what makes up our physical world. I enjoyed reading about Mesopotamia, the well known "cradle of civilization" where writing, farming, cities, and laws arose.  From Ancient Greece, philosophy and scientific observation gave us theories about the physical universe and nature. As knowledge progressed, science and religion clashed. Important libraries were developed to house the books written on medicine and astronomy. Interactions and learning were shared by different cultures. European universities were built and became important centers of learning to share scientific discoveries and ideas.The importance of mathematics and Galileo's discoveries opened the path to modern science. The author emphasizes how scientific observations which resulted in the laws of physics affects all change in our lives. It is the comprehensive laws of motion which opened up the field of physics to explore new scientific theories, make observations and create experiments using mathematical formulas to describe and explain quantum mechanics. Ever since the relationships between subatomic matter and energy have been explained and partly understood life on planet earth has not been the same. Needless to say, the author does an astonishing job of describing Newton's discoveries, importance of Rutherford's scientific observations about mysterious emanations (alpha, beta and gamma rays), Planck's quantum, Einstein's photon, the importance of Einstein's theory of relativity, Bohr's observations and experiments which lead to his new atomic theory and several others upon which all this science was built. All previous discoveries became the foundational framework upon which Heisenberg was able to build his revolutionary quantum theory called "Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle" which he explained was not really a principle but rather described the limitation of quantum mechanics. The author includes significant historical, social and world events which affected the lives of important scientists during the discovery of principles associated with quantum physics which provides a well rounded, fascinating context to understand the impact of this new science on the modern world. For those who love science and want to explore the mysteries of the universe this book will help you do it. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

These round shell pearl earrings are the perfect size for everyday use or for elegant occasions. The small cubic zirconia which sparkle around the well centered white lustrous pearls provide the extra touch that makes these earrings special. I selected the 18 Kt yellow gold plated style because the yellow gold contrasts well with the white pearl center and the white cubic zirconia. The design is classic. The earrings are solidly crafted, the post is well placed, and the backing has a secure fit. The earrings enhance any style of clothing worn for any occasion. This reviewer received a complimentary set of earrings for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

These posh, elegant earrings are designed for formal occasions and to leave a lasting impression on whoever views them. The large white cubic zirconia is astonishing in size and reflects an unforgettable brilliance. Above the larger stone is a row of smaller cubic zirconia which enhance the overall appeal and artistic flow of the earrings design. These also possess a captivating sparkle that captures attention. I have the 18Kt white gold plated style and am very pleased with their appearance and craftsmanship. The lever lock backing is an excellent choice as it clasps shut tightly with ease and even has a safety-type hook which is rare and much appreciated. These earrings are much larger and more beautiful in real life than the photo on amazon's page. Despite their size, they do not feel heavy or look too large when worn. This product is amazing in how it helps relax aging lines beneath the eyes, at the corners of the eyes and even on the cheek right below corners of the nostrils. It is easy to apply and is very cost-effective compared to similar products, in other words: it is worth the price! I am familiar with the effects of hyaluronic acid, which is included in two facial skin care products I have used. This is a common ingredient used for overall skin firming which I have used and I know it works. I have been looking for a product to use around the eyes and was very pleased when OZ Naturals offered me this complimentary item to try and then review for amazon. In all honesty I really love it! There is no scent, it has a gel- consistency which prevents wasting and is easy to apply. I do not have dark circles under the eyes and can not address this issue personally but recommend reading other reviews for their results.Another important ingredient is "plant stem cells" which are usually harvested from plants grown in labs. I know that the purpose of plant stem cells is to help renew tissue and regenerate growth of plant cells which means they will likely provide some similar benefit to living human skin cells. Other beneficial ingredients in this product are: various amino acids which are the building blocks of proteins and therefore will assist in repairing tissue and smooth the skin. Vitamin E is included which is an antioxidant. There are several other organic plant ingredients: periwinkle, licorice, eye bright, reishi, frankincense and gotu kola which anyone can research on-line to see what benefits they provide. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This journal is a wonderful gift for yourself to keep and treasure to document beautiful memories, reminders of events, experiences, and people that you love. The journal can also be a gift to someone who has experienced some kind of loss as an inspiration to keep them hopeful in life by recording what they find most important and meaningful. The author Deborah Perdue organized the journal in a manner where she records one spiritual statement for a total of forty nine days. There are twenty pieces of artwork within the journal which are the artists rendition of the meaning of some of the spiritual statements.Some examples of the inspirational statements are: "I am deeply grateful for my spiritual path which keeps me growing, changing and realizing the Divinity of life." " I am so grateful for letting go and letting life flow." "I am in gratitude for love and joy and peace and grace and ease and truth and beauty and wisdom.""I am grateful for the dazzling radiance of the warm sunshine today.' "Thank you Spirit within and all around for all the knowledge and wisdom infusing my mind and soul." "All is well and I am grateful." Occasionally the page for one's personal record is on the page behind the artwork and opposite a spiritual statement. Other times, the spiritual statement is opposite the personal diary page. The personal record or diary page has calligraphy-like words in the right corner for the date and  below that the words, "I am grateful for,"  with ten empty lines to be filled out by the owner of the journal. For anyone interested in reconnecting to their inner spirit, this journal will certainly be a helpful guide to reaching this goal.It would be most helpful to omit the word *date* on each journaling page. This change gives the writer freedom to date each gratitude entry and allows for more than a forty nine day record.  Some reviewers mention "forty days" of pages but I counted forty nine dated pages.. Perhaps they omitted counting the lined pages behind each piece of art. To record on the back of the artwork has pros and cons: the pros are the artwork could be used as a reference to very meaningful entries; the cons are the illustration can be marred by the pressure of the pen showing through. There should be a feeling of balance with reference to location of journaling pages: one page opposite either an inspirational statement or artwork is ideal, with forty nine lined pages and twenty pieces of art, this is not the case. This reviewer received a complimentary book in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Lydia Netzer is a great story teller who has developed her own unique erudite writing style in which she expresses emotions, decisions, and actions through metaphors that literally soar off the page. Her ability to enhance a story and develop a plot using mythical associations and references to astrophysics and the universe is very effective but can be daunting to the reader who is used to less complex techniques of making a significant point or twist in the plot. The author writes with lyricism, eloquence and fascinating phrasing from start to finish. This is an unusual sort of love story which arises through fate, chance or is it by the design of the universe or if one keeps reading each chapter, it may have been another unanticipated plan. The reader needs to  jump right in at the beginning which is the prologue what sets the stage for many surprising, unexpected events, twists and turns in the plot as the story of true love is explored. It begins with a search, meets resistance, and builds into its final climactic conclusion where all the mismatched pieces of the puzzle fit  together and explain the unexplainable.Initially, I was a bit put off by the first chapter, in which the author combines two disparate events: first, a detailed description of how Irene Sparks' mother passed away, Irene who has a Ph. D. in Astrophysics and her mom had been estranged, not speaking for the past few years, Irene lived in Pittsburgh, PA and did research in physics at a highly prestigious university. Second, right around the time of her mother's passing, Irene proved the existence of black holes by an elaborate experiment done in her lab, complete with the flash of violet light which was X-ray energy, absolute proof that was measurable and verified her data. Irene had proven what other astrophysicists had postulated!
