These two events: her discovery and her mom's death brought about one of Irene's secret desires: to return to Toledo and work at the Toledo Institute of Astronomy to carry out new research projects there. The events were realistic enough but a background or build up with some sensitivity toward her mother whom Irene loved in her own way would have improved the start of the novel for me.  A redesign is needed, as later the author provides the necessary background to Irene's life which allows the reader to understand her inner struggles and drive to succeed. Irene is a pure scientist who sees life as a series of rational decisions and lives according to her plans, although she allows herself a boyfriend who designs and develops video games. Her life course is on schedule and a steady course until she meets George Dermont, a professor and fellow scientist at the Toledo Institute of Astronomy whose approach to science and life is entirely different.George Dermont, Ph. D.,  is a third year post doctoral research fellow and favorite instructor of most female graduate students at the Toledo Institute of Astronomy. George is a dreamer and works ancient myths and stories into his science lectures. He is also handsome enough where if the female student is willing, the scientist does not resist his natural urges. His mother is a  well known, logical and successful lawyer, his father is a famous artist. George is looking for his soul mate and visits a psychic who describes some attributes of the woman of his dreams. As a child George was highly imaginative and creative. he developed an obsession with a fairy. His father understood, his mother did not. As an adult, George is obsessed with discovering his future wife and engages in various personal research endeavors in finding her. The author does an incredible job of building suspense, drama, and mystery as the two lives of very opposite people, Irene and George converge. The author introduces unusual elements of human experience the reader can not anticipate which complicates and divides the relationships of characters within the plot. In a most surprising twist of fate, the reader is provided explanations for complex developments within the plot that make this an astonishing, fascinating and intriguing novel that ends on a very satisfactory and joyful note. Due to the erudite writing style of the author, the fast pace, and unusual developments which created twists and turns in the plot, this book can feel overwhelming at times, and for this reason I deduct one star.  However, overall, I found the book very different and interesting. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Barilla Veggie Penne is one of those products to which you are *immediately* attracted when shopping. The package tells you it is made of 25% vegetables and provides one full serving of vegetables with each 3/5 ounce portion. And you are tempted to try it: my advice is go right ahead because you will *not* be disappointed! The taste is really delicious after taking just one bite when you notice a hint of the vegetable flavor which adds to the pleasure of the meal. Besides the wonderful taste, the pasta is very attractive which makes a meal even more appealing! Recently I happened to make a very Italian looking plate of food (just because of what I had on hand): the outstanding Barilla Veggie Pasta (red),  cauliflower (white) and asparagus (green). Needless to say, I was very pleased with the flavor and appearance of this easy to make dish! Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Simon Sebag Montefiore has written an outstanding historical novel which accurately captures the feelings, thoughts, and atmosphere of Stalinist Russia immediately after World War II. The author creates astonishingly realistic characters and a series of events that begin in complete innocence and which crescendo and climax into surreal interrogations at the Lubyanka Prison of several high school aged students and also of two children who are ten years old and six years old respectively. They are accused of a cover up, a conspiracy against the Soviet government and Stalin himself. It all started when two important members of an innocent sounding, exclusive, but very secret Poetry Club reenacted a duel based on Pushkin's poetry and life. They wore authentic nineteenth century costumes and presumably used theatrical firearms. This reenactment took place on a very special day near a bridge when the Victory Parade was held on June 24, 1945 with Stalin in attendance, accompanied on a balcony by the highest Soviet dignitaries. The actors ended up dead as a result of the duel. When the local police investigate and discover who the victims are, they pass on the investigation to higher authorities, The complex nature of the crime that two dead students who are the children of high ranking Soviet officials is most astonishing in and of itself but when  the interrogators begin to round up their friends for questioning and take them to the most notorious prison in the Soviet Union, the parents and those aware of what these special circumstances mean  begin to fear for their lives and for the lives of their children. Most mind-boggling of all is that the interrogators accuse these students of a conspiracy against the government,  a plot against Stalin himself. Past history has demonstrated exactly what serious consequences follow when the role, authority and decisions of the exalted leader of the Soviet Union are questioned.The author created an historical novel,  a great work of literature which is a major contribution to understanding Russian culture, politics and history during the post World War II era. The author is a Russian historian and fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. He engaged in meticulous research and loosely based his work on an actual event that occurred in 1943 at which time two children of Soviet officials were found dead, wearing costumes, which resulted in investigations, imprisonment, and banishment for those who were accused and found guilty. In this fictional novel, the author creates a highly believable, suspenseful plot based on the circumstances and relationships between all those affiliated with the Fatal Romantics' Club, those who attended the best school in Moscow named the Joseph Stalin Commune School, and the parents of the children, many of whom were highly important Soviet officials. The characters are highly developed and most impressive in their respective roles, both in fulfilling their duties and the expectations of family and society as well as expressing their true feelings and natures.The author creates tension, drama, romance, unexpected arrests, and imprisonment with great skill as the plot is gradually developed and explored related to new revelations which clarify how the authorities learned of the Poetry Club and their twisted interpretation of a secret book which came to light in which some thoughts and ideas were recorded by the leader of the club. The author. There are many surprises and a few unexpected twists toward the end of the novel that ties together the diverse pieces of this most fascinating surreal puzzle. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

These are highly desirable and attractive earrings with an uniquely appealing design. The center has a nice sized whitecubic zirconia stone which stands out well from the surrounding five petals which are partial arcs each of which is set with three smaller white cubic zirconia.. The post is set into one of the petals allowing each earring to be properly centered for maximum admiration. Each is solidly built reassuring the customer of many years of pleasure. The 18 Kt white gold is bonded onto brass with a three year warranty for defects in manufacturing and materials. Along with the guarantee of complete satisfaction, no customer can ask for more of any product. These are high quality stunning earrings which would be an ideal gift for anyone of any age group. These are beautifully styled earrings that undoubtedly will stand the test of time and be a highly cherished gift. The reviewer received a complimentary set of earrings for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Chapter Two is a personal and in depth look at the lives of two individuals who have achieved success and are reasonably comfortable in life but who are missing a personal, emotional, and physical connection to the opposite sex which they secretly desire but are reluctant to pursue. James Caan plays George Schneider, a successful author of books, whose wife died within the past year and who went on a world tour, trying to forget his grief but which in fact brought it all the more to the forefront. Jenny McCleod played to perfection by Marsha Mason is a working actress whose best friend Faye wants her friend to find love and romance in her life. George's  brother Leo (played by Joe Bologna) meets Jenny through Faye and believes Jenny would be the perfect date for George. The scene is set for matchmaking which works out much better than either Faye or Leo envisioned or anticipated: a whirlwind romance and marriage within a twenty two day period. As one might surmise, problems arose in the not too distant future and most of the film is devoted to a serious exploration of their emotions, expectations from marriage, and the past events which led to their sudden marriage and the emotional upheavals which accompanied it. Both Marsha Mason and James Caan are perfectly cast in their roles, stretching their acting abilities and skills to producing unforgettable characters.Since George and Marsha are in their early forties, the thought of dating again makes them extremely anxious. However, totally by chance, they  engage in conversation on the telephone for a much longer time than either one intended or expected when  George mixes up his notes with phone numbers and reaches Jenny by mistake. He is intrigued by her responses with their innuendos and double entends while joking. George hangs up, thinks about what Jenny said and calls back several times, each recognizing an interest in the other, and a growing connection they want to pursue. They find each other especially intriguing when the recognition arises that they are speaking to the very person their best friends wanted to introduce to the other.Especially poignant scenes arise on their honeymoon in what looks like Bermuda, where they stay at an ocean front cottage. The viewer anticipates trouble when learning that George and his deceased wife used to visit there in the past. One can only question their judgement as to why they even selected this location for the start of their presumed marital bliss, when any sane person would avoid it recognizing it could release a flood of emotions. It does indeed cause George to become cold and distant from Jenny. Jenny questions herself and her own desires, needs, while they are growing apart. After returning to New York, they agree to live in George's home. George withdraws and Jenny is sent adrift in her sadness. George takes a trip to California to confront himself and his feelings, leaving Jenny to wonder about the state of her marriage. When she goes to visit her home, she discovers Leo and Faye are using it for an affair. George returns and admits his true feelings to Jenny as they each realize the vulnerability and needs of the other and also recognize the strength of their feelings and resolve to build a new life together. This film is definitely long and intense, due to the subject matter it could not be anything else. I found it very engaging and became vested in wanting both characters to understand each other's emotions and work through their problems. I can understand how some people would find the film tedious and too personally dramatic. While some of the film is light-hearted comedy most of the film consists of dramatic, emotionally intense moments and conversations related to processing personal issues and needs. People who love conflict resolution will love this film. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

These 18Kt gold plated earrings are in a class by themselves! They possess a flawless design: a large round cut white cubic zirconia in the center which is surrounded by small white round cut cubic zirconia. Few jewelers with the naked eye could distinguish between these clear shimmering, glittering cubic zirconia and real diamonds. Especially appealing for me is the fact that yellow gold is used which makes the white stones stand out even better due to the contrast in colors. The post is ideally placed in the center (on the back) allowing for the eyes to truly appreciate the classical elegance and romantic appeal of the design. These earrings are beautifully designed, meticulously crafted, and solidly made. The ORROUS and Company Legacy Collection of jewelry are among my favorite designs and I can not imagine anyone who would be unhappy with any of their exclusive earrings. This reviewer received a complimentary set of earrings in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Tyler McMahon captures the essential nature of El Salvador in this highly captivating, engaging, and most interesting novel. El Salvador has unsurpassed natural foliage and unspoiled beaches where huge waves crash onto the shore and possess large curls ideal for surfing. It has mountain villages and in this fictional novel places named Punta Roca, Puerto La Libertad  and Puerto del Diablo. There are dense green forested areas where bananas and mangoes grow. It is a country with poor people who work hard for the essentials and basics in life and some are even willing to sell or trade their home and land for the dream and opportunity to live and work in America. Others are willing to take advantage of the poor and some are willing to exploit the needs and desires of inexperienced young Americans who cross their path. Idealistic American youth, mostly in their early twenties, volunteer for the Peace Corps to work for very little money, to help build  new structures and provide farming techniques to improve the lives of these people and gain a new perspective on this Third World Country.  While most American youth who bring their knowledge, work ethic, and ideals to help this poor society are well rounded and successful, some have additional emotional baggage, personal problems  they are forced to confront and resolve. The vulnerable  are ripe to fall into  traps set by unscrupulous locals. A few El Salvadorans work at night stealthily collecting large crates which arrive on shore, that are disturbed by shady characters who sell the fine white powder to those hooked on the substance and willing to buy it at the current market value. If you are interested in reading about great surfing, romance, adventure, natural disasters, drug deals gone wrong, the culture, climate, and social environment of El Salvador with a great and believable set of characters, plus an interesting twist and surprise ending, you will enjoy this book. This book is most highly recommended. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This may be the best timed book about what it felt like living in Cuba during the late 1950s and early 1960s right before the Cuban Revolution given that President Obama announced opening up diplomatic relations with this one and only Communist country in the Western Hemisphere. Celso Gonzalez-Falla lived during this time and is now in his early eighties, the author left Cuba at age 26 in 1961. Although this book is fiction, I have no doubt the author's life experience is mirrored highly accurately. This book is based on people he knew or fictional characters created out of his imagination based on behaviors and personality characteristics of people he knew.  What is most impressive and appealing about this book is it feels real, is totally engaging and describes realistically an historical era and geopolitical region of the world that is still very important today. The author writes about a thriving pre-revolutionary Cuba, where there was a successful economy based on capitalism which worked, although everyone did not live in the same lifestyle, neither did Communism provide a better quality of life for the majority of Cubans who did not leave the island. The reader gets a feel for the pre-Communist regime where politicians, powerful successful businessmen and the police usually worked in unison, i.e., for the good of society as a whole or at times they were trying to gain some advantage, exploiting the common people, to control some aspect of society. What stands out most in this book is the vibrant culture and the expressive people who helped create the feeling that Cuba was special. This book is highly recommended for anyone who wants to sense and feel the Cuba of the past. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This was the classic Viet Nam era film that was made during the time when the war was dividing the nation. The difference between this film and others produced in this era is this one does not depict war scenes. Instead, this film concentrates on the emotional effects of the war on soldiers who were willing to serve but returned changed men with a wholly different view of what it means to be a patriot. The motivation to serve their country with honor and distinction, to do their duty was the impetus, along with being drafted however the results and outcomes were different: men returned with broken bodies and broken spirits.The film begins when Sally Bender (played by Jane Fonda) and her husband Bob (played by Bruce Dern), a Captain in the Army, are separating as he is sent to Viet Nam. He looks forward to this mission due to his outlook that he is serving his country. Sally has always been a housewife and is bored living alone so she volunteers at the local Veterans hospital. There she meets Luke, whom she recalls was the captain of the football team at her high school when she was a cheerleader. Luke returned from Viet Nam with war injuries which resulted in paralysis. Luke had returned with a different view of the war than when he initially went. There is a highly charged scene in which he gives an "anti-war" speech before an assembly of students which contrasts with the clean cut soldier in uniform, who provides an entirely opposing viewpoint.After Sally and Luke meet, they make an emotional connection based on their past. They also fall in love and have a physical relationship knowing full well it may rock or destroy Sally's marriage. Each is fully aware of the possible problems, consequences, and complications which may arise when Sally's husband returns. It happens that he returns earlier than his tour of duty due to injuries he sustained which are not serious but for which he will receive a medal. Unfortunately, he learns of the liason between his wife and Luke the wounded Viet Nam War veteran through unusual channels. All of them must confront their conflicting emotions associated with the Viet Nam war and also the fall out associated with a potential break up of the marriage. Needless to say, this is a thought-provoking film which sheds light on multiple viewpoints, strong emotions and problems which were prevalent in the era. Most highly recommended, excellent film. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This is a beautiful set of earrings that are stunning and elegantly designed. Most astonishing is they have the appearance of solid gold when in fact they are 18 Kt gold plated. They are a high quality product for a very reasonable price. The pearls are of good size and stably anchored onto the posts. Each earring post is long enough to fit any sized pierced ear. There are baguette cut cubic zirconia which create a petal-like effect of three clusters around the base of the earring which holds the pearl. The baguettes capture and reflect light which resembles real diamonds. The only concern I have is the ability of the 18Kt gold  bonding to withstand the test of time, hopefully the gold bonding will last a life time of wearing without eroding  down to the base metal. Often base metal consists of nickel, if this is the case, I will have an allergic reaction to it. Keep in mind, this concern applies to any jewelry that is gold bonded. Only time will tell and I *promise* to update this review should this occur. Overall, this is a highly impressive, well made set of earrings and I highly recommend buying them as a gift for yourself or someone special. A complimentary set of earrings was provided to this reviewer for this honest evaluation and review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

If you love roller skating and disco music spiced up with a bit of romance, drama and conflict where the underdog wins, you will enjoy this film. Linda Blair stars as Terry Barkley who breaks away from the high expectations of her wealthy parents by roller skating at the Venice Beach in California. There she meets Bobby played by Jim Bray, a former competitive skater whose skill is astonishing. She needs a break from the social pressure placed on her by their plans for her future career as a music major and classical flutist. Her father is a lawyer with a lucrative career in financial law, her mother is a homemaker and socialite. Both seem to take her for granted, Terry breaks free from the social role they envision for her by pursuing her hobby of roller skating which expresses her freedom and individuality.Terry surprises her upper class close friends by socializing with a different crowd and immensely enjoys her new found freedom where nothing matters but the talent and skills of roller dancing. Terry eventually breaks through the restrictive  social barriers and becomes accepted by the "ace" roller skater Bobby. There is a roller disco contest planned at Jammers,  the roller rink which runs into a major problem.  The owner is threatened by a big time businessman mobster and his strong arm men. They force him to sign a contract to sell the rink to the business developer of a mall which they plan to build. Unknown to them, one of the roller skaters inadvertently taped the threatening conversation. Terry tries to enlist her father's help to save Jammers but he refuses. When Terry is performing with the Barkley Musical Quartet at a garden party, her friends show up and recognize the mobster businesssman and his associates, all kind of havoc results. Terry is reprimanded by her father who fails to understand the problems with Jammers and worse, he represents the mobster businessman in the deal.Most viewers will appreciate and enjoy the confusion and conflict which arises when the mobsters chase Terry and her roller disco friends who are trying on their own to save Jammers and hold the Roller Disco contest as planned. The manner in which they help solve this major problem and save Jammers is well executed. Especially satisfying is how Terry's father eventually recognizes and realizes the legal quandary into which his high paying client placed him.and  he had to concede his daughter and her friends were right. It is a pleasure to watch events unfold and how the matter is resolved in favor of the Jammers owner and the Roller Disco skaters. The viewer cheers as Terry and her friends triumph and the Jammers Roller Disco contest is held as planned. It becomes icing on the cake to learn that Terry was accepted into the world famous Julliard's School of music and she will pursue her plans to become a classical flutist. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Today at 1:34 PMIt is a pleasure to view this comedy which creates humor from situations and events that arise from contrasting differences between two cultures which have varying social values and clearly proscribed behaviors between social classes. Best of all, it is amazing how the writers managed to convey respect for the Middle East or Arabic culture  without offending the values which they uphold. Interestingly, this was before it was "politically correct" to do so. Fortunately, this film does not resort to mockery, derision or vulgarity which is highly remarkable as the film originated in Hollywood where in modern times low class behavior substitutes for good clean comedy and writing talent. The plot revolves around a sheik who is staying at the posh Beverly Hills Hotel and when he enters the lobby and makes eye contact with an attractive blonde haired, blue eyed young American woman. It is clear they have an interest in each other and he would love to meet her but his royal position demands he maintain a serious demeanor.  He can not make any overtures to get her attention or socialize with her. Not only because of his social status but because he is accompanied by guards who watch his every move. Along come the parking lot attendants who see the chemistry and want to intervene to help him out. A few, empathize with his situation of desiring someone of the opposite sex who is unattainable. The contrasts between the two social classes makes for great humor and even more satisfying is how the parking lot attendants come to his rescue, create diversions which allow for the "forbidden" contact with the lovely woman.I enjoyed seeing a young Robert Hegyes play Tico, one of the parking lot attendants who takes on the role of "solving" the sheik's problem with this beautiful young lady. Another charming role was played by a young Melanie Griffiths.  Especially enjoyable was seeing Frank Gorshin play Fred Kruger, head of security. He is confounded by the many antics and behavior of the parking lot attendants. It was particularly funny when he made arrangements to have a date in an unoccupied room with an attractive new female desk clerk. It just so happened, the parking lot attendants were using that room for their own purposes and had to clear the room out in a hurry to make it presentable and ready for Kruger and his date. I was most impressed by Kario Salem who played the sheik, he was very handsome and had such a close resemblance to Ben Affleck that it makes me wonder why he never made it into other more well known roles and films. Overall, this was a well made fun comedy which came to a satisfying conclusion. While some scenes were overdone as often happens with slapstick comedies it truly remains a good clean fun entertaining film. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

My interest in this book was piqued due to the high acclaim, awards and recognition it received in Brazil. It won two prestigious awards one even being named 'best novel.'  I expected to admire the writing and love the book. I was seriously disappointed.The book consists of  sixty eight vignettes, unconnected chunks and pieces of life events, information, glimpses into various aspects of people's lives, people who come from all classes and walks of life. The descriptions seem and feel random and are nonlinear, giving the sense of a bustling, high energy city, teeming with life and movement. The collage of information conveyed is tied together by two themes: first, all of it is happening on May 9. 2000 and second it is all happening in Sao Paolo, Brazil.For me, the style of writing does not work: it is disjointed and hard to follow. It is as if, a filmmaker took whatever was odd, unusual or unique in "you tube" videos and pieced them together into one film with the only commonality being, the day and the place. The book feels like a hodge podge of events, some are just descriptions of something unique about the city, other descriptions include some life event of a person or a group. If the author's purpose was to capture the feeling of confusion: he succeeded beyond his wildest imagination. There is definitely the feeling of loss, the loss of sense of self, but as a reader I do not want to be confused or lost when reading a book. I wish a sense of purpose, I read to discover something to enjoy or appreciate within the book and this book leaves me feeling empty and unsatisfied.While, to an extent, I understand the author's purpose, the impetus that drove him to to write in this style, it could have been written better, as a series of short stories where one can get a hook into personal stories and lives. The impersonal nature of city life, the nature of being an impartial observer is known to anyone who has lived in a large city. Anyone who lived in a large city can feel the energy, the  drive, the movement, the differences between classes of people, who engage in a hustle to live and find meaning in the expanse of it all. One can feel lost in the shuffle of everyday activities. I would have preferred stories that describe life, behaviors and expression of values the various classes of people who live in Sao Paolo, Brazil.This book would have been much better if it had been a series of short stories which would have provided a window into the lives of workers, residents, people from all walks of life, to understand  their feelings, their goals, their successes, their losses, to find out what drives them to live. Instead, this reader was left feeling lost, dizzy and disoriented. A one word summary of this book: confusing. A one word recommendation to buy: don't. Yes, I think the author is a highly talented writer but he chopped up the stories into disconnected chunks creating serious discontinuity. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Managing the impossible until now, Prisoner 5995, aka Peanut stealthily maneuvered down dark corridors of the Prison located in Qinghai Province, Western China and evaded detection of the thunder, as the prison guards were called, for their booming voices and lightning speed use of punishment for perceived infractions. Despite the punishment he endured in the past for being accused of gathering state secrets, when he recorded a personal diary of his prison life on any scrap of paper he managed to collect, he took the risk of escape and amazingly succeeded. Peanut walked along a wall in the dark, to a dark gravel pit, where he hid while the dogs searching for him barked and the thunder roared but did not locate him. Adam Brookes paints a realistic picture of the bleak circumstances Peanut endured in prison, the courage it took for him to escape and the subterfuge in which he engaged to bring into reality the plan he hatched and dreamed about while imprisoned: to leave China, get a new identity and start a life in a free country. The author engages the readers attention immediately with his artistic use of words and phrases which capture all the senses, sight, sound, taste, touch, and even the sixth sense of what is about to happen ...Peanut has the ability to access information about China's progress on defense missiles and their transport. His goal is to hook someone who can contact the British Intelligence agency for whom Peanut had spied in the past. He contacted Philip Mangan, a free lance reporter who wrote articles that are original and timely on political and social aspects of China's development. Peanut was certain, Mangan would pass the copies to the correct British authorities, who would immediately recognize the value of the documents. Mangan got more deeply involved and was recruited as a British agent, despite his objections  because the British knew that Peanut trusted him and only him with these secrets. Peanut started the ball rolling in the direction he had planned which was moving at the right speed, he controlled his own destiny at last.I love how the author ties together the past and present circumstances of Peanut's life and the complicated political events which resulted in his imprisonment. The author very deftly creates a novel filled with espionage, intrigue, political tension, and modern global conflicts related to the race for armaments and defense. Peanut learns to avoid detection by authorities as he surreptitiously and skillfully obtains top secret documents, which he knows are the key to his ultimate survival and the ticket out of Communist China. The author writes with knowledge and purpose and keeps the reader's attention engaged as each chapter reveals new complex events and barriers which are overcome to achieving Peanut's ultimate goal. It is hard to believe this is a first novel for the author, he is a natural born writer. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This is a charming romantic comedy which revolves around the friendship and eventual romance that develops between two rival speech writers who are working for opposing candidates vying for the Senate seat in New Mexico. Most of the comedy arises from trying to resolve the inevitable tension and conflicts which arise from this complicated association, where doing a good job means being critical of the rival's candidate and yet not making it a personal matter that could destroys or poison their true feelings for each other. Their respective bosses are running for the vacant Senate seat and each team is doing their utmost to persuade the voters *their* candidate will work harder on issues most important to them. The teams are doing their best to outsmart the opposition in winning votes and use creative techniques which at times are totallly hilarious.Michael Keaton plays Kevin Vallick, a former Hollywood sitcom writer, turned speech writer for the Republican candidate Garvin. Julia Mann played by Geena Davis is the speech writer for Wannamaker the Democratic candidate. They unexpectedly meet at midnight at the hotel's gift shop trying to buy the same box of Nytol, a non-narcotic sleeping agent for their common malady, insomnia. The next day, they meet again and develop a budding friendship which leads to a drive across the border to Mexico on the spur of the moment. At this point they do not yet know each others true roles, Kevin acknowledges his past job as sitcom writer and when he reads Julia's name tag on her jacket, which identifies her as a newspaper reporter, neither corrects the misconception about their current positions. They have a terrific time in Mexico and both are acutely aware that it has become a budding romance, the implications of which are on the minds of each. After they return and are met by members of their candidate's team, both fully realize the true job of the other and the impact it will have on their relationship.Conflicts and tension arise regarding their true feelings because they are required to make their candidate look good at the expense of the other. Add into this mix, the arrival of Julia's boyfriend, Bob Freed, a documentary specialist, who eventually becomes engaged to Julia and yet remains clueless about Kevin and Julia's intimate feelings and their recent fling. Nearing the finish, the race for the Senate seat becomes even more blood thirsty and cut-throat. Kevin is incapacited after a night of revelry with Julia although he was the more aggressive writer is unable to write his speech for Garver. Julia is more idealistic and issue oriented, can not awaken Kevin and cares enough about him to write the script for him; it shows Garver in a whole new light: family oriented, sensitive to creating jobs and overall in touch with what matters most to the voters. After this episode, Garver is in the lead,  that is, until a leak about his accepting bribes is made public  after which Wannamaker jumps ahead and wins the nomination. Needless to say, this becomes the ultimate clash which nearly shatters the relationship between Kevin and Julia beyond repair. .It is a pleasure to watch the resolution to the confllicts between the candidates and even more grat fun to see how Julia and Kevin recognize and acknowledge their true feelings for each other in a very public display. The actors are all phenomenal This was an enjoyable and satisfying film and is highly recommended. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

With great skill, personal knowledge, and detailed craftsmanship, Haggai Carmon creates a riptide effect, a powerful force that pulls the reader into a complex world of deception, traps, and espionage. The author opens up a whole new world where disguises, lies, and stealth are normal. Undercover operations are devised to elicit information about enemy activities, deals and plots, which are threats to the real world. Some men risk their lives to free individuals who chose to defect from the totalitarianism under which they live. The defectors possess specialized knowledge and skills which is shared in exchange for their freedom. This knowledge will be used to stop the enemy from gaining further  information, technology, and control/power over innocent people. The life of subterfuge is loaded with risks, it is a "fight to the finish". Espionage places not only the life of the spy at great risk but also the lives of everyone closely associated with him.In this novel, the lead character, Dan Gordon is a brilliant tactician, a highly trained field agent who works best as a 'lone wolf', he is the ideal candidate to help General Cyrus Madani, aka code name TANGO, escape from Iran and defect to the US. This operation,is a joint effort by the CIA and Mossad, if successful would land on of the biggest blows against the Iranian nuclear race in modern times. This defector would reveal Iran's progress in building a nuclear bomb in exchange for living in the relative safety of the US under a new identity for himself and his family. Two miles from the border of Armenia and Iran, General Cyrus Madani is visible within fifty yards to freedom, when gunfire erupts from all directions and Dan Gordon is told to abort the mission. To his utter dismay, Dan Gordon is ordered to leave the area and return to headquarters. He is stunned but he obeys. He learns that the Iranian Revolutionary Guards must have been tipped off due to the gunfire which arose. Furthermore,  telephoto lens pictures revealed discrepancies between the known images of TANGO and the candidate who was crossing the border. Although they looked very much alike, the descrepancies revealed he was a double, in other words, a fake. This unexpected development sent a ripple effect within the team who worked so tightly to free TANGO from Iran. They were on board with the decision to break all barriers to locate and free the *real* General Cyrus Madani from Iran.TEMPEST was the code name for the new team responsible for identifying, cultivating, and supporting Iranian scientists and key military personnel to defect. The US Consulate in Dubai had received a letter written in Farsi from a "friend" who would act as intermediary on behalf of as yet unnamed Iranian scientist who wanted to defect. Again, the chase was on - to determine whether or not this request was real. Dan Gordon enters the picture, this time in disguise as Mr. Jaap Van der Hoff, who represents his company located in the Netherlands which trades in electronic components for industrial use. The company's goal  is to penetrate the Iranian market, known to be hungry for new technology, but without alerting the Americans. Dubai is known world wide to be a den of thieves, disguised as legitimate businessmen, complete with all the proper credentials to support their claims. This book takes on an entirely new dimension of deception few readers can anticipate or imagine. I totally enjoyed reading about Dan Gordon becoming Alexander Yager, a lingerie businessman visiting Damascus, Syria who made inroads to buying lingerie for his German department store when he was on a mission of an altogether different nature. I loved his chameleon change into Dieter Kraus which provided him access to visiting Tehran, Iran. Especially revealing was the partial Oriental Express train ride from Tehran to Ankara, Turkey where he became Daniel Patrick Leahy, complete with family history, occupation and the new passport to prove it. Let me just say that the gravy, I mean plot, thickens in Turkey, along with a new spicy side dish, a local specialty which will be a complete surprise to the reader! Without hesitation I give my highest endorsement to this espionage novel. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Robert DeNiro plays Frank Goode, the father of four who is trying to emotionally connect with his adult children shortly after his wife passed away. He arranges a get together but each of his children make excuses why they can not attend. Frank realizes life is precious and all too short and he wants to express his true feelings of love to his family which he found hard to do in the past. He realizes his role as head of the household and breadwinner placed him into a distant second to his wife, in whom his children confided. Due to his health problems, he wants to reestablish and strengthen the family bonds. He wants to ensure his family understands how important they are to him before it is too late and with this goal in mind, he ventures forth to visit all of his adult before it is too late. His adult children moved away from home to distant parts of the country to pursue their passions and build their lives, he decides to visit each one to see how they are doing.From Elmira, NY Frank visits New York City to his eldest son's apartment but his son does not answer the door, apparently he is not at home. Frank had called him many times by phone but there was no answer so he resorted to the surprise visit. He placed an envelope beneath the door, with a photo of the family as children and a note to his son. Since he hates to fly airplanes, Frank decides to take a Greyhound bus trip across country to see his other three children, Robert, whom he believes is a musical conductor in an orchestra, Rosie who live in Las Vegas and is pursuing her dream job as a performing artist, and Amy, a happily married mom living out West. The film masterfully conveys emotion and meaning through flashbacks which portray Frank's memories of his children when young and growing up. These film clips highly effectively peel away the layers of time to expose Frank's love and caring tender attitude as a father much more strongly than if described in words.Needless to say, Frank learns that his children were holding back much information about themselves which he recalls was not the case with their mother. They talked to her about their personal lives and revealed themselves, opened up in ways they never did with him. He sees they incorporated the valuable and difficult lessons he taught them about life and they have made their own path in the world, expressing themselves as they discover their strengths and survival skills. After discovering Robert is not the conductor but rather is a percussionist in the orchestra (he plays the drums) which suits him just fine, Frank is told Robert is leaving on tour with the orchestra which cuts the visit with his father short. Frank leaves on the bus to travel further out west to visit his daughter Amy. Amy calls Robert that their dad was not on the bus as expected. A series of phone calls ensues, with messages left back and forth, trying to track down the location of their dad. He had missed the correct bus due to a time zone change and hitched a ride on a truck which got him to the railroad station that had a connection to Las Vegas. Rosie ( played by Drew Barrymore) went all out to impress her dad with her successful career in Las Vegas, she rented a stretch limousine which drove them to her high rise penthouse suite. However, Frank overheard an answering machine message left by the owner of the suite that he was returning early. Again, Frank awakened to the fact that his daughter was not being honest and open with him. Gradually, over a spaghetti dinner,  they had a heart to heart talk about the past and the truth about her life was revealed to him. Frank was not shocked or disappointed. All that mattered to him was that her life was on course and that she was happy.He decided to go back to New York earlier than anticipated and allow his children lead their own lives, satisfied they were doing well, but he had misgivings about David, his eldest from whom he had not heard. Out of character for him, he chose to return to NY by airplane, even though he hated to fly. He did not reveal to any of them a mishap which occurred at the railroad station, where his medication was spilled and crushed. While in fight, he looked out the airplane window and saw storm clouds and lightening. The stewardess reassured him, the pilot would fly around the storm, not through it and that it was safe to do so. During a bit of turbulence, Frank went to the bathroom and experienced what seemed like a panic attack but he was clutching his chest and was short of breath. The stewardess sensed a problem since he did not return to his passenger seat. An ambulance met them as the landed which drove Frank to the hospital.Frank is lying in the hospital bed, surrounded by his children when he awakens. He senses their love and concern but eminently feels the absence of David, his eldest son. He confronts his children and elicits they answer his questions about David, with the whole truth. Amy tenderly and carefully tells him, David died of an overdose in Mexico, around the time he was visiting  his children out west. When Frank falls asleep he experiences a flashback of David as a child receiving instructions from his father. Frank also has a vision of David as an adult, waving good-bye and reassuring him, he was a good father and David's death had was not his father's fault. After he is released from the hospital, there is a poignant scene when Frank visits the cemetery where his wife is buried and he talks with her about the family. The final and last scene is the family reunion Frank had originally planned: a Thanksgiving dinner in Elmira, New York, in the house where they grew up. This time, all three of his children and their offspring are present, with David and their mom there in spirit. Despite all the changes in their lives, the family is together and the bonds are strong if not stronger than ever before. This is a most touching and realistic film about what matters most in life: family, love and acceptance. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This 1972 film is about the inner feelings and personal lives of four policemen working for the LAPD. It is as relevant today as when it was made. It sends a very important message to society. The focus of the film is the emotional impact which the job has on specific individuals. Each of them deals very differently with the unexpected situations they encounter during their work life and therefore the residual feelings which remain hidden or buried is dealt with differently by each individual as well. The lives of these policemen are interwoven, as they are a team, doing a job for society, ensuring laws are followed and society as a whole is kept safe. George C. Scott plays Andy Kivinsky, a veteran police officer with 25 years on the job. He is partnered with Roy Fehler (played by Stacy Keach) who is a rookie. It is department policy to train new guys to this complex job in this manner and it makes sense. Roy is assigned to the Vice Squad which places great strains on his marriage causing it to end. Initially, Roy had planned to attend law school but due to life's twists and turns, he got married and had a daughter and the realities of earning a living led him into law enforcement as a job. The accusations which fly between Roy and his wife as they break up is superbly acted and provides insights into how a marriage with a solid foundation eventually becomes shaken and falters to the breaking point. Kivinsky was retiring after 25 years of service in the police force. At the farewell party, it is evident he has mixed feelings about leaving, perhaps unresolved issues. He was heavily invested in the relationships with his fellow officers. His plan are to retire to Florida where his family resides.In order to mask his true feelings of depression, Roy Fehler began to drink. It became a problem because he even resorted to taking the occasional gulp of courage while on the job. Gus Plebesly, played by Scott Wilson, is his new partner who caught Roy breaking this code of conduct related to his job. Gus is a father and family man who takes his role as provider and family man seriously. He was taking night courses at the academy to qualify for a promotion and become a sergeant. He became Roy's partner after Klivinsky retired. Gus had Roy's back and he supported his partner, trying to help him work through his personal problems more effectively. Klivinsky returns to LA from Florida to visit with his old friends but everyone seems too busy to socialize with him. Klivinsky drops a few hints on the telephone about the difficulties he has living with his family and coping with retirement. It falls on deaf ears. He wrestles with his personal demons and sadly, in the end, the demons won.While on assignment to investigate a burglary, Roy and Gus interview Lorrie the victim of a robbery. Lorrie reads Roy's name tag and recognizes his name but he has no recollection of their having met. She asks him, "How are you?" to which he replies, "Not so good." She reveals that when he was hospitalized, she and the other nurses did not expect him to survive the wounds he sustained on the job. They made an unexpected personal connection that each recognized could lead to something more meaningful. However, just when Roy Fehler feels his life is coming together in a good way, fate intervenes once more. The reader will have to view the film to discover the new twist in Roy's life which changes his life course forever.This film is a rare gem which treats sensitive issues in the lives of policemen in a very respectful and dignified manner, revealing the day to day struggles they face in their chosen profession. The film does not exaggerate their role. It does not portray them as super heroes nor does it vilify them. The impression left on me is that men with different strengths and qualities are drawn into this profession for their own personal reasons and they work very hard to perform their duties for society to the best of their abilities. Policemen come from all segments of society and like all human beings deserve to be respected and treated with dignity, despite what is reported by the modern media, no profession should be judged by the actions of a few. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This small volume is rich in content. It contains stories which will impact the reader in a strong way by illustrating the values and principles of  ancient Jewish teaching via real life experiences of  both ordinairy and extraordinairy people. It stands as a testament to the foundations of Judeo-Christian values which unfortunately are eroding in the modern world.  It is a slim volume which is packed with meaning and important lessons. In the modern world it is too easy to make excuses and explain away one's personal failure to act. These stories show courageous people who stood up for truth, decency and honesty.  These stories show people who built lives based on integrity. They dared to stand up for what they believed worth fighting for even at great risk to themselves. It is getting rare to meet people who "do the  right thing", live up to a high moral code of behavior, and  who do not compromise in the face of  great resistance ... but as these true stories illustrate these kinds of people still *do* exist in today's world. At the core of their being is what in is termed "good character" which is more valuable than money and possessions. In the end it becomes the key to a successful and happy life, where the rest of what generally is viewed as important in a successful life: good health and wealth generally follows. Disclosure: Reviewer received a free copy in exchange for an honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

When you see the words "National Geographic" these words immediately come to mind: high quality, adventure, world travel, ecology, and culture and the traveler using this book will find all this to be true and much more.  The book is well designed and will appeal to the novice and experienced traveler alike. The photos and experiences described in the book are of nine distinctly different unique regions of Peru each provides a very special, exciting, travel opportunity to experience what many only dream about. The authors' expertise is evident in their incredible attention to detail which makes this guide stand out from other travel guides. They provide sections on how to travel wisely giving special precautions to take, list established hotels, hostels and lodges along with recommended restaurants in all the regions. They also give guidance about public transportation such as buses, taxis and trains.Especially helpful is the critically important information they cover about reaching Machu Picchu from Cusco. Unless you are hiking the Inca Trail, the only other way to get there is to take the train from Aguas Calientes which has three levels of service. The practical considerations and guidance given is extremely valuable. Keep in mind, that you will be going up as high as 18,886 feet or 5,750 meters so it would be wise to condition your body *gradually* to this high altitude to  receive maximum enjoyment from this "not to be missed" experience of a lifetime. While the only symptom of altitude sickness most people might feel is a headache, they suggest those who are hesitant or know they will have some difficulty should acclimatize their body first. They can do this by transferring from the Cusco airport to the Sacred Valley town of Urubamba (9,416 feet/ 2,800 meters) or Ollantaytambo (9,187 feet/ 2,800 meters) to stay at any of several good hotels from where they can arrange to visit Machu Picchu and other sites.If this sounds appealing: visiting an off-the-beaten path indigenous markets, viewing a special seabird named "Peruvian booby", observing sea lions in their natural habitat, eating at the largest seafood buffet named in the Guinness Book of World Records located in Costa Verde in Lima, staying at a lodge in the highlands to see how farmers raise alpaca, residing in a guesthouse on a floating island in Lake Titicaca, hiking  the 39 kilometer (24  mile ) long  Inca Trail in the Andes or a portion of it, visiting the Inca ruins at Machu Picchu and viewing  jaw dropping scenery, visiting museums filled with Inca treasures in old historical cities such as Lima, Cusco or Trujillo or magnificent cathedrals dating back many centuries, and witnessing astonishing historically significant architecture then this book is for you! This book emphasizes travel that conserves wildlife, preserves history, enriches culture, gets the most value for your money, respects and appreciates local customs and traditions, and  provides diverse outdoor activities and supports archaeological adventures. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

David S. Brody has written an electrifying, entertaining, and educational fictional novel that combines irresistible topics into a search for the truth. The search involves uncovering the provenance of an ancient bracelet (author's imagination) which eventually leads to discovering how C.I.A. covert operations at one time included brainwashing techniques, i.e. mind  control or more accurately behavioral modification methods which had ties to the Smithsonian Institute (verifiable facts). In this book the author creates a wide range of exciting suspenseful events associated with true archeological findings many of which are about giant bones and bursts of action-packed moments related to C.I.A tactics (verifiable) which enliven the plot all working toward a resolution to the main issue which in this story ends at the Smithsonian Institute. The one and only important question is, why was the ancient bracelet made available to Cameron Thorne and his fianc Amanda Spencer-Gunn so easily? It was found in a white box which came along with the Chinese take- out home order food delivered to Cam and Amanda. In the same box they found an old newspaper article which described the theft of the bracelet and how it was discovered in Tennessee with the Bat Creek Stone which dated around 200 A.D. and had an ancient form of Hebrew etched into it. The myriad of new directions in which this story winds will mesmerize the reader and keep them hooked! The reader will enjoy the great chase to determine the ancient origins of the bracelet which is not without great peril to those who undertake this monumental task.With great precision and skill in just the first thirty five pages the author stuns the reader into full attention. He weaves astonishing subjects into the plot starting first with an amusing lecture at an alternative history conference by a French anthropologist/archeologist conspiracy theorist who takes himself a bit seriously. His topic is the how the genealogy of European monarchies, ancient Israeli and Egyptian royalty and rulers descended from a unique species that will make the reader laugh out loud. Cameron Thorne followed this lecture on an unusual topic of his own but which was more believable: how the Freemasons and Knights Templar influenced European exploration of America before Columbus. A spry, leprechaun-like, well educated, elderly gentleman, Randall Cid, who spoke with an upper class Bostonian accent and showed an understated sense of humor, introduced himself to Cam. He demonstrated a keen interest and personal knowledge of the Freemasons but dropped a bombshell on Cam: Randall was retired from the C.I.A.. He also shared his insider knowledge that Cam was targeted by the C.I.A. for brainwashing or more accurately behavior modification, that is, to influence Cam's behavior in the direction they wanted. Randall's entry into their lives provides new twists and turns in the plot no one can anticipate. In addition to his charisma, extraordinary knowledge and C.I.A. experience, he adds spice, energy and spark to the divergent avenues and new directions that are explored. However, it is Randall's hidden past that comes to haunt him in ways even he could not imagine which results in a highly explosive but most satisfying ending to the book! Another seemingly tangential person within the plot is Webster Lovecraft a 61 year old presidential candidate who has strong views on certain political topics. He has a large physical stature, almost seven feet tall with ancestry that includes Cherokee Indian. Georgia Johnson, who used to be a C.I.A. agent, is now his political strategist in his candidacy bid for president. She is friends with Cam Thorne and his fianc Amanda. They met when the couple adopted their nine year old daughter. They consult Georgia regarding the real or potential C.I.A. involvement in their lives and also when their search for the truth uncovers some distinctively peculiar findings. The author demonstrates his well- honed literary talent and expertise in connecting C.I.A. tactics, mysterious events and discoveries, and key players within the story into a cohesive whole which includes a surprise ending, that most readers do not see coming!The author's major achievement is his ability to weave unusual authentic archeological evidence into the plot which makes reading this book a spell-binding experience. He solves a mystery by threading verifiable evidence into the story. He creates suspense and drama effectively enacting the scenes with multidimensional believable characters who have identifiable personality traits and quirks.  One jaw dropper is the accidental discovery (most often by farmers) in the 1800s of the bones of giants, often associated with burial mounds scattered throughout North America. He included Cherokee Indian legends and oral history which mention ancient explorers of Middle Eastern descent confirmed by writing left on tablets who arrived from across the Atlantic Ocean, some of whom were giants who intermarried with the Cherokee nation. The author provides actual copies of a 1902 New York Times article and one from the New York Tribune dated 1897 about the discovery of giants' bones. There is a photo of the Grave Creek Burial Mound in 1830s where a tablet was found which had letters that appeared to be Phoenician along with very large bones of humans. Another amazing topic woven into  the story is the initiation ceremony of the Freemasons which dates back to the times of Solomon and used to be called the "Oath to Nimrod" who was King of Babylonia over 4,000 years ago ( ~2000 B.C.) however although the same oath is still used today, Nimrod's name was dropped  for historical reasons which are explained in the book. This is one magnificent outstanding book!  Disclosure Statement: Reviewer received a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This plant based product will moisturize and hydrate the skin very nicely provided you follow the directions as written. This means warm the cream in the palms of your hands before applying to your face. Otherwise there will remain a residue that looks and feels like paste until the warmth of your face makes it translucent and absorbs it. This product is ideal for anyone who wants to avoid an oily look and feel on their face. It is ideal for anyone with sensitive skin. It is also ideal for anyone who wants to avoid clogging their pores.The ingredients organic shea butter and vegetable glycerin will moisturize and smooth your skin. The natural oils from grape seed, jojoba, primrose, linseed and meadowfoam will rejuvenate your skin by giving it a smoother appearance and prevent wrinkles. As antioxidants these plant based natural products will prevent skin damage from aging and the sun.The benefits of organic white grape juice (vitis vinefera) and organice aloe vera juice (aloe barbadensis) have been proven to stimulate collagen development and to repair skin damage. Collagen strength in the skin is what keeps it smooth and free of wrinkles. Three vitamins are included in Juice Beauty; Vitamin C, Vitamin B5 and Vitamin E. Vitamin C is essential in building collagen. Vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) helps keep skin smooth. Vitamin E helps skin repair itself and protects against damage. Last but not least is vegetable hyaluronic acid. Sodium hyaluronate helps the dermis attract and hold water which diminishes wrinkles. Some other botanical extracts listed on the package box are: marigold flower, chamomile leaf, linden leaf, algae extract and two exotic ones ylang ylang and may chang which are undoubtedly helpful as well. Erika Borsos (pepper flower)

James Hider has written an original, thought-provoking, adventurous, and entertaining novel that incorporates concepts from religion, psychology, anthropology, genetics, computer science technology and modern common culture (sometimes in a serious, other times amusing manner) to create a futuristic world where there are conflicts between different segments of society. This is a multi-layered book which can be read on a variety of levels and still be fully appreciated. It can be read as a story about the survival of an individual who is unique and faces choices we can not fathom due the new society which evolved. No one can anticipate or guess the next event, challenge or clash with society on his path in life because the world in which he lives is very different from ours.On a deeper level, the the book can be viewed as one man's journey on a search for the meaning of life, providing some answers to what society and life would be like if the soul, mind, personality survived after the body died. Regardless of what depth or layer the reader chooses to ascribe to the novel, it is a very satisfying reading experience. In this new futuristic world, values collide because various classes or segments of society possess different inner drives, desires or abilties to live which affects how they will die.There is a myth or legend which talks about the "Missing Link" a type of human who has survived a very long life but does not quite fit the definition of the usual classes of human genus/species of that era. This book is his life story which is definitely worth reading! The novel is genuinely imaginative and takes a fresh look at the human experience from a totally unique perspective. Reviewer received a free PDF copy of the book in exchange for an honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

The revelations within the type-written manuscript of the book titled "The Accident" sent to literary agent Isabel Reed would destroy the global multimedia billion dollar corporation built by Charles Wolfe. It could also put the lives of anyone associated with its publication into serious jeopardy. One distinct problem associated with the book is its authorship, attributed to "anonymous", which is totally understandable given the content but without some corroborating evidence or eye witness accounts, would it be believable? The author understands the consequences of publication since he clearly states in the Epilogue, "Because if what you are reading is a published book, printed, and bound and distributed into the world, I am, almost certainly dead." The controversy surrounding the revelations alone would sell books but it would also destroy lives and careers. Isabel twice attempted to contact the author via the email on the cover page but the message she sent had bounced back twice. She realizes the book would be the hottest best seller, something any publisher would die for, but the real question is, does one literally want to risk dying - for the opportunity to publish it? The jealousies, competitive nature and potential triumphant successes of the publication industry make it a hot bed of secrets which are promised to be concealed but end up revealed in whispers under the strictest confidentiality.The title of the book alludes to an event that was hushed up, covered up between all participants and witnesses but which clearly points the finger of blame in one direction: Charles Wolfe. Essentially, those who knew what happened remained silent: the dead victim's silence was guaranteed, another key witness was kept quiet with payments that lasted many years. He became a well placed, highly paid executive within the corporation, in far too deep to run around and give it all up. The third witness to "the accident" was allowed to leave the scene and remained at large. Only this one person remained who could verify, corroborate the details.The author's talent lies in the ability to create suspense, drama, and tension by holding the reader's attention as he takes them down meandering paths of escape from the enemy. Key players rise to the occasion in Copenhagen, Zurich Switzerland and the Alps, the Hamptons in New York and Los Angeles, California. Disparate people, places, and past events are tied into a cohesive whole as the plot is developed and the unknown details are gradually exposed and come into focus. As one would expect, the Wolfe pack will do anything to protect their leader and to the reader's great satisfaction, an unexpected bombshell explodes with even more unexpected consequences that can not be anticipated. This is one fantastic, elegantly written novel that is truly "impossible to put down." Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Dimitri Orlov, a former KGB operative, and most recently a former employee of a Russian mafia gangster has serious ambitions to become the second in command of Russia. To accomplish this most lofty goal, he must convince the most powerful man in Russia, President Kuznov to put his stamp of approval on this mission. Gaining access to President Kuznov is nearly impossible through normal channels due to multiple layers of bureaucracy and  because of a cadre of armed guards always surrounding or near him. However, on his fifth attempt Orlov overheard Kuznov's secretary talking about the President's plans to travel to his country home for a weekend holiday. This provided Orlov an unofficial channel of access, a dangerous one which involved great risks, event possibly sacrificing his life if he failed. Orlov successfuly penetrated through the barriers to talk with the President.When President Kuznov heard the plans, he was hooked: the goal of making Russia once more a formidable super power was too difficult to resist,. It was a 'win-win' situation with little or no risk to himself. The President had plausible deniability should Orlov fail.  Orlov would broker a deal with Communist China to become allies with Russia. Orlov had inside knowledge about the highly volatile political climate within China. General Zhou a Maoist  style hard-liner  was exiled in Paris, planned to return and set events in motion to become President of China.  Zhou would ensure the current  President Li would die of a heart attack during bowel surgery for cancer.  President Li suspected he would be the fatal victim of foul play, untraceable and his death attributed to natural causes. He spoke with Mei Ling, the most powerful female within China, who was a member of the Politburo and on the Foreign Policy Advisory Committee. He told her, she would have the backing of highly placed members of China's Communist Party to be his successor, if he did not survive surgery.After this point, the author provides the reader a number of simultaneous events to ponder: the death of President Li as predicted and  the return of General Zhou who becomes the next President with the military's backing, plus due to teh bribes his brother, a wealthy industrialist had spread around to key Communist officials. Mei Ling secretly escapes to Paris. However, prior to President Li's unfortunate demise: Craig Page the European Union's Director of Counter Terrorism had made an unsuccessful attempt on General Zhou's life. Androshka, Dimitri Orlov's sister is President Zhou's mistress, she sets up a  meeting between her brother and President Zhou to discuss their mutually beneficial relationship, an alliance against the United States. As expected, President Zhou has a condition which must be met before agreeing to this mutually beneficial relationship. Orlov must murder President Dalton of the United States. It is a complicated and daring mission which Orlov pulls off  amazingly well and a few hitches. Afterwards, Craig Page is named CIA Director by President Treadwell, who succeeded Dalton. Zhou is furious that Craig Page, his sworn enemy again has such an influential and very threatening position.  Zhou provides the final obstacle for Orlov to overcome before officially engaging in a political alliance with Russia: obtain the detailed plans for PGS (Prompt Global Strike). It is  a highly classified and dangerous weapon created by the United States which has the capability of striking from within the US, any target in any country around the world, Whoever owns the plans and builds the weapon essentially rules the world. The game is on and the stakes are high. The book is most outstanding due to topic/ subject matter, writing style of the author, and  the pure reading pleasure derived from the unexpected twists and turns contained within. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Adam Pelzman has written a deeply moving and emotionally satisfying story about the complexities and multiple layers of love which few authors would dare to tackle and at which even fewer would succeed. The author transforms the personal tragedies as experienced by Julian Pravdin in his early years when an orphan in Russia into protective instincts toward women and a business acumen which results in his becoming an enormously rich man. After attending a party, Julian and his beautiful wife Sophie discuss transportation home. Julian feels buzzed from drinking and wants to walk home, as the party was held several blocks from where they live in New York. Sophie is tired and does not want to walk, despite the full moon and ideal weather, she presuades Julian to drive. Acquiescing to his wife's request, Julian drives them but not before uttering a sentence as a joke which will haunt him for the rest of his life. An accident occurred as Julian swerved the car to avoid hitting a deer. Both passengers survived but only one of them sustained permanent irreversible injuries.While on a business trip to Miami, Julian uncharacteristically stops in a strip club and meets Perla a twenty three year old stripper of Cuban ancestry. What attracts him to her is, she does not look like the average stripper nor does she behave like one. Despite misgivings, Julian and Perla hook up at his hotel after her performance. For six months they maintain this arrangement, whenever Julian is in town. Unexpectedly, Perla is visited by a good friend of Julian's who extends to her an invitation to visit Julian and his wife in New York, complete with a paid airline ticket and expense money. Perla had only recently learned Julian was married, while she had no illusions of marrying him neither did she expect this invitation. Needless to say the story gets far more interesting after this point. The author introduces realistic sounding elements, graphic details, unusual events and activities which no reader can anticipate or guess. The sensitivity with which the author treats Sophie's delicate situation and personal needs is astonishing and totally unexpected. It surprises me that the author is a man, given the empathy displayed by the surprising events described in the book. While this book is not for everyone, I highly recommend it for those who are open to reading about tragic events with unexpected positive outcomes. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Naruddin Farah's talent is fully manifested in his exploration of relationships, feelings, and social or value conflicts which impacted his family after the death, due to a terrorist bomb, of Aar, a UN official stationed in Mogadiscio, Somalia. The individuals in this novel must come to grips with this great unexpected loss. The author demonstrates keen insights and understanding of multiculturalism between African nations, specifically Somalia and Kenya. He also contrasts the upper class lifestyles of modern day successful Africans with those who live in Western Europe. The author has written a realistic sounding novel in which complex social issues are explored with sensitivity and understanding.Bella, Aar's sister, immediately arranges a flight to Nairobi after hearing of Aar's death. She is a highly successful world reknown fashion photographer. Her lifestyle permits her freedom, independence and the ability to meet with her lovers whenever she can arrange a liason. She feels protective of Aar's children, Salif his teenage son and preteen daughter Dahaba. Valerie, Aar's exwife of ten years had left the family to live with her female lover, Padmi She returns to Nairobi with Padmi to claim rights over her children, even though she had not cared for them or been involved in their lives since she her divorce.The book explores the conflicts between these two women who both cared about Aar and now feel responsible for expressing their love for his children by taking over as guardians. While there are no jaw-dropping moments or earth-shattering revelations in the book the author manages to impress the reader with his realistic and sensitive writing style demonstrating a clarity of purpose and message that the world is complex yet family relationships, love and responsibility triumph over tragedy and evil. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Wilbur Smith has written a highly engaging novel filled with intrigues and plots within and outside the borders of ancient Egypt. The author includes adventure, romance, and most important of all strategic alliances related to marriage, politics and war. The story is told in the voice of Lord Taita, who had been a slave long ago but had risen to chief adviser to the Pharoah along with chief protector of his harem and most trusted ally to the two younger sisters of Pharoah, he had been made a eunuch in adulthood. His intelligence, cunning, humor and rise to power are astonishing. Lord Taita provides the reader insights into his past life and current achievements with tangential explanations as asides to the main story. Lord Taita arranged and staged an invasion of Hyksos, a separate nation which had once been part of Egypt but was lost in war. The invasion of Hyksos resulted in a bloody battle in which the Egyptians successfully killed their King and confiscated three large Minoan ships laden with silver  that had docked in a hidden area of Hyksos. Lord Taita's triumph was due to creating an illusion that the Minoan ships were invaded by Hyksosian soldiers (Egyptian soldiers in disguise) which resulted in war between Hyksos and Crete, who had been allies until then. The three ships left Hyksos unscathed, as the Egyptians again alluded detection by wearing the clothes of Crete when sailing through Hyksos. The Pharoah was highly pleased with Lord Taita's stealthy and successful invasion of Hyksos and the immense loads of silver he took as the winner.The illusions created by Lord Taita paved the way for Egypt to become allies with Crete and forge a more lasting alliance through marriage. The author includes an epic journey across the desert to reach a port from which Lord Taita, the Princesses, a large entourage, and high ranking Eygyptian soldiers accompanying them for protection, could sail to Crete. On this journey, one of the Egyptian princesses falls in love with a high ranking but nonroyal soldier, plus she is kidnapped by a desert bandit known as the "Jackal" and is eventually saved. Wilbur Smith proves his story telling capabilities in this book by taking the reader to the land of Ur, the palace of Marduk in Babylon. where ancient myths and stories come alive. It is however in Crete, the final destination of the Egyptian royal princesses, that the twists and turns within this novel escalate with an unexpected surprise ending involving a special ceremony held by the Supreme Minos (as their king is called) for his virginal brides. It is where the gods of Egypt and the magical ceremony presided over by the Supreme Minos clash - one must read the book to see which one prevails and survives. Wilbur Smith captures the reader's imagination with ancient kingdoms, unforgettable characters, astonishing plots and inner court intrigues, tactical battles, and magical ceremonies sprinkled throughout with wit and humor. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

If you are looking for adventure, romance, conspiracy, drama and historical realism- look no further - this book will meet and most likely exceed your expectations! The title "Cossacks in Paris" sounds like a novel about war and while there are some descriptions of clashes in battle and some fighting scenes, the book focuses primarily on relationships between individuals and nations, survival, and narrow escapes. The relationships are between nations and leaders of nations: Napoleon vs Tsar Alexander of Russia, along with Prime Minister Metternich an intermediary from Austria who makes several appearances. Amidst the unavoidable war which ensues, a romance develops and evolves between Kaarina daughter of  Count Gustav Armfelt of Finland and a French engineer Breutier Armande. Another one-sided romance arises between her twin sister Kasia and Major Agripin, leader of the Cossacks,  who is later promoted to Colonel during a successful battle. The Tsar promises Kaarina to Agripin in marriage, just after she demonstrated and proved her love to the French engineer. Agripin falls under the spell of Kaarina's sharp mind and astonishing beauty, and realizes where her true feelings lie: the French engineer, yet he wants to win her over and struggles with his strong desires, despite her resistance. He resists brutalizing her with Cossack rough behavior in the matters of love, yet he wants her very badly. How long he can hold out before his desires overpower his reason, only time will tell. The Tsar undoubtedly seeks to to seal the loyalty of the Cossacks to Russia, with this most unusual gift.
