This creates the enmity between Breutier Armande and Agripin around which much of the plot and events in the story are based. The main characters are so well developed and possess such outstanding personality traits, the reader is glued to each page, wanting to know how they will react to each tension, conflict, separation, and unexpected dramatic twist and turn in the plot.The plot is complex and dense, indicating the author's ability to weave historical figures and imaginary characters into a most adventurous and action-packed plot which takes the reader to such amazing places as Finland, St Petersburg and Moscow in Russia; the Steppes of the Ukraine; Pressburg, Hungary in the Carpathian Mountains; Leipzig, Germany; Zurich, Switzerland; and Paris, France. There are many extraordinairy and, unexpected transitions in the plot making it a joy to read and astonishingly, the Cossacks* do* enter Paris --  they threaten to explode the underground sewers to spread death, destruction and disease among the populace, as one would expect, they were not successful! It is quite amusing and amazing how a Rabbi from the Yeshiva in Pressburg provides help to Breutier Armande and Kaarina and later how a Yeshiva student named dn assists Breutier Armande to save Paris and most importantly the two women they love! The reviewer received a free ebook in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

What I love most about this product is that there are four varieties of  tea flavors in a package of 20 total. The consumer has choices based on mood, desire and taste preferences. One is not stuck with 20 tea bags of any one flavor wondering if the bags will expire before you get around to drinking them all. The liklihood is you will drink the variety pack much sooner and derive pleasure and enjoyment by having more choices.The "pomegranate raspberry" flavored tea also has rosehips and hibiscus added which provides a fine balance between fruit and floral flavors creating an overall sense of well being when drinking this tea. The "orange cinnamon spiced" tea has an unexpected burst of flavor which is a great "pick me up"  during mid-afternoon when a person usually looks forward to an energy boost. "Pure camomile" tea has a soothing effect that promises serenity and calmness. "Nightly calm"  is a surprising combination of camomile, spearmint, lemon grass, with linden, orange blossom, lemon myrtle, rosebuds, and hawthorne berries that is sure to help one relax, sleep and have pleasant dreams. This product by the famous Twinings Tea Company of London is most highly recommended. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Yvette Manessis Corporon has written a charming and engaging human interest story which will appeal to those who love romance, the mystery of the Greek islands, strengthening family bonds and historical realism. The reader is introduced to the island of Erikousa where time stood still, many people live a traditional lifestyle where other than tourism, the main industry is fishing. Daphne is in her early thirties and will be married on Erikousa to her fianc Stephenwho is to be her second husband, a wealthy and successful banking executive. Daphne has arrived on the island and is met by her cousin, Popi who is close to her age and was her best friend, the last time she visited. Daphne's bonds of love to Yia Yia her grandmother were always strong, yet had not seen her for about six years. Despite physical distance, her grandmother always seemed to know and telephone just when Daphne needed her help and emotional support the most. Daphne's family roots are firmly planted in the region - her parents emigrated from here to build a successful life in America. They wanted to provide their only daughter new opportunities and a better lifestyle than possible in this remote area. When attending college in New York, Daphne fell in love with Alex during his oral presentation in class about his insights into the meaning of Christopher Marlowe's famous novel Dr. Faust. Daphne and Alex made eye contact, he discovered she was among the few who understood his interpretation of the book. He sat down next to her and the rest is history. They married after he wore down her parents objections to their only daughter dating a non-Greek. They had a baby daughter whom they named after her grandmother and enjoyed a happy life until he died in an unforeseeable accident. With great difficulty, Daphne summoned courage to carry on for the sake of their daughter Evie. She worked eighteeen hour days after obtaining a bank loan, to open her own Greek restaurant named Koukla. Stephen had influenced the loan on her behalf and became a regular patron at her very popular and successful restaurant. He was fascinated by Daphne with whom he fell in love and also by the great food at Koukla. Over his reservations, Daphne convinced him to be married on the Greek island of Erikousa so she could be surrounded by family. Also, Daphne wanted her daughter Evie to understand and feel the magic of this special place which Daphne loved so much.In this book the author explores complex family and personal relationships amidst unexpected tragedies and problems which arise in life. She shows how a single mother must balance and divide her time between building a successful business and still spend time with her daughter whom she loves deeply and for whom she is doing it all. Daphne had to deal with the pain and grief associated with the death of her first husband and also with that of another tragedy which took the lives of her parents. She built a successful business and became engaged, never expecting to be married again. After arriving on Erikousa, Daphne began exploring the source of her conflicting emotions regarding her pressured New York lifestyle and started appreciating the laid back cycle of life on the island. She noticed a change in Evie, who was a shy reticent child in New York but a more outgoing energetic child in Erikousa. One of the biggest challenges Daphne faced was meeting Yianni, a handsome rugged fisherman who was good friends with Yia Yia. He made observations about modern life, especially New York and conventional success which made her bristle and question her feelings, emotions and decisions even more. He seemed to know a personal secret related to her Yia Yia and her past that even Daphne did not know. The more Daphne learned about Yianni, the more of an enigma he seemd to be. Yet, despite her misgivings, Yia Yia trusted him completely and Daphne knew there was much she had to learn about their relationship and family history. The manner in which the story unfolds is extraordinairy and realistic. The author builds suspense and drama and romance in unexpected ways but the ending is not at all what one would expect. It is a beautifully told story which will appeal to those who love to explore deep emotions and family relationships. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Adriana Trigiani has written a piercingly haunting and beautiful story that will help the reader view family, love and life in a richer and more meaningful way. The deeply hidden layers shatter at the end resulting in an explosive, unexpected revelation of a carefully guarded secret and a wholly unexpected irreversible event. The main plot of the story revolves around love, trust, honesty and true emotions. The story is told from the perspective of Valentina, the context of her life story includes resolving differences and building a successful loving marriage amids conflicts between: old world male Italian traditional behavior versus American female independence, time devoted to personal ambition and success versus family responsibilities and lastly most important of all personal committment to marriage. The issues also include a May - December love/marriage relationship where there is an 18 year gap age difference, and last but not least, dealing with the former wife and adult 'mother-to be' daughter of her husband. And there is the consideration, will Gianluca be happy with his decision to live in New York?The author introduces the reader to an amazing and amusing cast of characters who make up Valentina's family: the Roncallis and Angelinis. Val and her now fianc Gianluca Viacharelli met on the Isle of Capri in Italy when Val was stood up by her then American boyfriend Roman, who was supposed to meet her there. Gianluca, the son of Dominic who married Val's grandmother, was sent to keep Val company. The two familys have had a formal business relationship dating back almost 100 years. The Italian side were tanners who provided the leather for the American-Italian Angelli's who hand made shoes of the highest quality. Val is now the designer for the Angelli Shoe Company located in Greenich Village, New York. As Val and Gianluca merge their lives with a short engagement and then marriage, they discover new, fascinating and challenging aspects about each other which eventually strengthens their marriage bond. They honeymoon in New Orleans, live in New York City, vacation in Tuscany and eventually purchase a building and property in Ohio where they relocate their shoe business factory. Each location reveals unique aspects of their personalities which challenge their love and relationship. Throughout the book, the author's writing style varies from amusing to entertaining to serious as the story unfolds and as each life event requires. The reader is hooked in the first chapter and kept magnetized in the suspense and drama of this couple's life story. The author navigates the reader through hair pin turns and curves on life's highway which leads to a totally unexpected jaw dropping conclusion. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Jam packed with detailed information, Paul Collins reveals the enigmatic nature of Edgar Allen Poe by describing the complex, contorted and problematic events in his life. Yet, despite the difficulties of his life, it is from this unusual mixture that Edgar Allen Poe's imagination grew and from which his genius arose. As a novelist, poet, and artist of the highest order, he confounded his detractors and elevated his status in the eyes of his admirers. His genuine authentic stories have stood the test of time and Poe has earned the titles, "the father of the detective fiction" and "master of horror fiction". This biography sheds much light on the life of Poe, the complexities of his early life, young adulthood and early demise at the age of forty. It shows how Poe had overcome many hardships and built a success of his life despite having been dealt a very bad hand of cards.The author begins his biography by describing a mysterious ritual or tradition enacted for several decades at the gravesite of Edgar Allen Poe in Baltimore, MD, it ended in 2009. Someone dresssed in black, wearing a hat and scarf, would have a toast near the grave,on Edgar Allen Poes birthday. The mysterious stranger would leave three roses and a bottle of cognac there. It was believed the orginator of the tradition had died long ago and others had anonymously taken up the ritual by imitation and then finally it was abandoned altogether. As Paul Collins stated, it is likely Edgar Allen Poe would have approved of such an event. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Matteo Pistono has written a very comprehensive and revealing biography of the Tibetan Mystic Terton Sogyal, who was of the Nyingma Buddhist tradition and lived during the end of the 19th century and turn of the 20th century. He was an advisor to the 13th Dalai Lama during perilous times when Tibet was threatened by war on two fronts, from the east as well as the west. Chinese invasion was a looming possibility due to Tibet's proximity to Mongolia, Tsarist Russia was seeking new territory to rule and the British were building more colonies in the Far East, with designs on Tibet, India, a neighbor to Tibet had already succombed. Terton Sogyal arose out of obscurity into becoming an important spiritual leader who was unassailable as demonstrated by his committment to Buddha's teaching and his one-minded pursuit of peace amidst the changing political landscape surrounding Tibet from outside as well as within the perimeter of her borders. Written on a linear time line, the author makes unfamiliar topics and concepts come alive, providing new territory to explore within each chapter, like revealing a mystery.This book is written on three levels, none of which can be separated. The first level includes the life and experiences of the man, named Sonam Gyalpol. The second level includes time and history, an important transitional era for the country of Tibet and the third level revolves around the spiritual practice and experiences of Terton Sogyal, the Buddhist mystic and spiritual leader. The author has a Master's degree in Buddhist philosophy from the School of Oriental and African Studies at the University of London. From the late 1990s to 2008, he travelled to Tibet for one to three months at a time, visiting nearly every location and pilgramage site where Terton Sogyal lived, taught, and travelled. The author studied the mystical visions and revelations of Terton Sogyal, he read many authentic sources, and researched historical documents related to this spiritual leader. One book in particular, "The Marvelous Garden of White Lotuses" is refered to as the only known biography of Terton Sogyal based on mystical prophecies about him by Padmasambhava (the Indian guru who brought the teachings of Buddhism to Tibet in the 8th century) and other saintly persons.This book is a journey which reveals many experiences associated with one of Tibet's most highly revered spiritual leaders and mystics. It is insightful and educational on all three levels of the contents of this book. The book contains translated Buddhist teachings, predictions, and poems along with historical events and mysterious discoveries which shed greater understanding on the main points about the life of Terton Sogyal. The book is easy to read because despite many unfamiliar concepts it posseses a rhythmical cadence and is told in a manner which builds intrigue and drama. Some events within the life of Terton Sogyal stretch into areas which feel more like myth or imagination than truth but this does not detract from the enjoyment of the book. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This book will keep the reader intrigued and turning every page as fast as the information is absorbed, seeking answers to these puzzling questions, where was Clonmac Bridge's exact location in Ireland, who built it and why did it disappear. Jeffrey Perren has written  a highly enjoyable and thoroughly entertaining , edge-of-your-seat suspense filled mystery that includes romance, murder, and ancient secrets. Discovering the answers, the reader will be astonished and amazed at the deep and winding maze of fierce, jealous competition which exists within the Anthropology Department at the University of Virginia. The ultimate goal is to publish research related to newly discovered archealogy findings in a peer reviewed journal and thus make a name for one's self, gaining more grant money from available sources to continue working in this exciting field. Researching and uncovering monuments, buildings and artifacts related to ancient cultures is an intoxicating and perilous journey as one will discover when reading this book.Dr. Griffiin Clonmac was reading an ancient text in the Special Archives at the University library to uncover references about his latest research, Clonmac's Bridge in Ireland located somewhere along the Shannon River, when he noticed a colleague and rival, Dr. Daley remove an irreplaceable book from the library. Griffin was hooked on uncovering this mysterious anamoly, a bridge built in Ireland in the 9th century, over 1200 years ago. He knew the stolen book was relevant to his research. He did what anyone with protective instincts would do, he snuck into Dr. Daley's office to read the book for himself. This suppressed conflict between colleagues grows exponentially with convoluted, complex layers that promise the reader a fantastic ride into the past as well as into dark secrets related to the the building of the bridge and later its abandonment.The author enhances the plot by deftly weaving several cultures into his book, ancient and modern Irish, modern American both within a University setting and related to corporate business dealings, and also South American, specifically Peruvian. Dr. Mari Quirpe a knowledgeable and expert archaelogist, loses her job in Peru when her assistant dies in an unforeseeable accident on a dig. Her father is a highly placed government official within the Ministry of the Interior who *could* help her obtain a university teaching post in her chosen field but she refuses his help. She is stubbornly independent and knows she would have to make a deal, compromise her principles and marry someone of his choice as the custom. Through a twist of fate, Mari learns of Dr. Griffin Clonmac's research and is selected to work on his project in Ireland. Not unexpectedly, they develop a close bond both professionally and in their personal lives. However, each faces romantic temptations as new situations arise related to the project. This surprise development keeps the reader enthralled, wanting to know *both* the outcome of the archaelogical expedition related to Clonmac's Bridge as well as their personal lives. It is ultimately clear, someone or some group is out to sabatoge the research expediton and its discoveries. In this book, Jeffrey Perren connects the dots from the past to the present in an astonishing and satisfying manner, providing the reader a roller coaster of a ride right to the very end. Reviewer received a free ebook in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Italy is a vacation/holiday destination high on most people's wish lists! This book will definitely help the discerning visitor choose the best places to visit among the top 6 regions of Italy: Rome and the Vatican;Milan, the Lakes and Piedmont; Venice, Veneto and Bologna; Florence, Tuscany and Umbria; Naples, Pompeii, and Amalfi Coast, and Sicilly and Southern Italy. As with most Lonely Planet guides, the book is color coded to each region making it easy to navigate and find whatever interests the reader. The book provides descriptions and photos of 25 highlights or must see cities, locations and sights which are also labelled on a handy map, helping the reader keep proper perspective and determine how realistic it would be to travel to each destination within the timeframe of their vacation. There are helpful sections with travel tips, methods of travel, accommodations, regulations and customs  This book selects *most* of what a visitor would love to see and provides a list of hotels and restaurants within each region that fits within moderate to high end budgets. Descriptions are given of where to locate public transportation, such as bus and train terminals and the metro and how to travel from one important location to another, which is very important for tourists who are unlikely to rent a car and drive around in Italy.However, as the saying goes, "Don't judge a book by its cover" because the cover itself would not entice me to buy this travel book. The background color on the cover, a dark lime green is not attractive. Florence is a great destination but the cover photo, the red roof of the Doumo (cathedral) one of the city's most iconic landmarks just does not do this book justice. There are numerous beautiful photos within this book which would have better served as cover of unforgettable places: numerous historical locations within Rome, various piazzas and fountains; Naples and Pompeii, the Amalfi coast, and the rolling hillsides of Tuscany with vineyards, castles, mansions and farmhouses and breath taking landscapes. Also it was disappointing that Portofino, one of the most picturesque and famous Italian ports was not mentioned in this book. Lastly, although agriturism was mentioned as an option, the book lacked information on the subject nor did it provide an internet link . For these reasons I deduct one star. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

In this book the reader learns much. Boris Pasternak was a man of vision, courage, and uncompromising principles. He was a human being with strengths and weaknesses but most important of all he was a man with a Russian soul. After going through official channels trying to get his novel, Dr. Zhivago, published in the Soviet Union, and meeting with resistance and outright hostility, he stopped his efforts. Instead, he allowed the manuscript, of what he regarded as his life's best work, to be taken secretly out of Russia to be published by a new Italian firm in Milan, owned by Giangiacomo Fetrinelli, an Italian Communist Party loyalist. The authors provide a vast amount of well researched, highly detailed information to help the reader understand Boris Pasternak's personality, education, family background, complicated love life (outside his marriage) and his relationship to the Union of Soviet Writers as well to its most prominent members and last but not least to various authorities. Astonishingly, Boris Pasternak had met with Trotsky in the early 1920s when the leader was trying to understand Pasternak's published work and determine where the author stood in relation to political matters. A few years later Lenin died and a power struggle ensued from which Stalin emerged as the victor. Stalin seems to have developed a grudging admiration for Pasternak's verse and writing. In the early 1930s, Mandelstam a friend of Pasternak had been arrested for writing and reciting poetry critical of the Soviet system. Stalin had telephoned Pasternak about the matter, asking why he had not petitioned to help his friend through the writer's organization. Pasternak's response to this question exemplified his uncanny ability to make a point without direct confrontation or abject criticism.Throughout the book the authors provide comprehensive chapters filled with detailed information which shed light on Boris Pasternak's personal views which changed over time. Most fascinating to read are his relationships with Soviet authorities, the ideological battles within the system and his surprising ability to survive. They describe many examples of his disenchantment with the Communist system and final frustration with censorship and outright official rejection of his writing which occurred later in life. Most enlightening is how copies of Pasternak's novel got secretly published by the CIA and clandestinely distributed at the World's Fair in Brussels in 1958. The hostile reaction by Soviet authorities when Boris Pasternak was selected as winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1958 was unprecedented and very well covered in this book. Sadly, in order to remain living in the USSR, for his own survival and that of his family, Boris Pasternak voluntarily renounced this coveted prize in a letter addressed to Nikita Khruschev. The publication of Dr. Zhivago in the West and the book's popularity worldwide remained one of the worst embarrassments for the Soviet Union. The Cold War was intensely fought on a literary battlefield between two opposing ideologies. Most shocking of all, was Khruschev's documented admission, that during the height of the political battles over the publication of Dr. Zhivago he had not read the book but later during his retirement after reading it, he concluded, "We should not have banned it."  Boris Pasternak fought valiantly and fortunately for lovers of great world literature, he did not fight in vain. This book provides a micro  and macro view of the Cold War as fought on a personal and global scale within a social, political and literary context seldom before revealed. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Like most high caliber espionage agents George Quant prefers his cocktail shaken not stirred, that is he prefers his jobs loaded with excitement and adventure rather than mundane and ordinairy. In this most riveting and impressive novel, the protaganist, real name George Quant, alias Martin Matheson and also known as Agent Ai, is often shaken up from his adventures: his cover job is a journalist which takes him to Southeast Asia, to Russia where he obtains a Russian computer hacker's antiviral program which is the only known antidote against a planned global cyber attack, and his highly complicated associations with Hong Kong's richest businessmen, particularly Mr. Ho and Mr. de Haviland. As a journalist, spy, and double agent, his life is often endangered and threatened but under the most trying conditions he regains his composure and manages to escape, with the help of friends and accomplices. George was recruited as an agent on a trial basis by Amanda, a diplomat for Great Britain. Unexpectedly, he is embroiled in a romance with Amanda, who eventually becomes his handler under her real name, Karen. She procures for him life and death adventures which he could  not possibly have imagined when a student at Oxford University, from where he dropped out after failing a few courses.In a strange twist of fate in Russia, after his infiltration of Trusov Antimalware Corporation, where he obtained the only existing antiviral program against a global cyber threat, the Americans saved his life. George is forced to become a double agent. He is caught between the British and American sides, forced against his will,to share information with presumed allies, each of whom have secrets of their own. As Agent Ai, he is given a mission to learn as much as he can about Mrs. Zhao, the wife of a high ranking Communist Chinese government official. She has a flair for successful business transactions, an acumen for correctly assessing world market conditions which is highly unusual for a Communist official's wife. Under cover as Martin Matheson, Director of Lynbar Infrastructure Investments, Asia LLC, George meets Mrs. Zhao at a high end business party in Hong Kong hosted by Mr. Ho.  Needless to say, she is not who she seems but then neither are several other key players within George's circle of friends and acquaintances.This book is nonstop action, loaded with hair-pin turns and death-defying one hundred eighty degree drops. The author does an astonishing job of providing clues to an imminent world business disaster related to a new computer virus. The plot is thick and complicated and it is a total joy to read each page. The protaganist is a highly likeable adventure seeker, who is successful but not conceited nor overly ambitious, in fact, he does not even realize how good he really is. He is young enough to be daring and also to be surprised by his own abilities. His human fallabilities make the novel more interesting. The book is written in a nonlinear fashion which in some novels detracts from the reading experience but in this novel it has the opposite effect. The nonlinear approach provides insights and details about George's character, past and approach to life. It heightens the current dilemmas which he faces and enhances the enjoyment of the reading experience. Needless to say, the conclusion of the book is totally satisfying. Reviewer received a free ebook copy from the author in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Tom Doyle has written a credible, fascinating book providing insights into Paul McCartney's "dark night of the soul" experiences in the post-Beatles era. It describes the emotional peaks and valleys associated with a meteoric rise to stardom and fame which many would say just did not last long enough. In this book, the author describes what happened to Paul after the lights [on stage] went dim so-to-speak. We read about the struggles and difficulties Paul encountered in creating a rock band from scratch (eventually named "Wings") rather than the natural, organic process of the right people finding each other in an environment at the right time, which seemed to be the case with the rise of the Beatles. Especially interesting was how Paul came to meet and fall in love with Linda Eastman who at some point had said to him, "I can make you a good home." Paul's reliance on her as a wife, best friend, lover and eventually key board player in the band named "Wings" makes for fascinating reading. He credits Linda with helping him out of the darkest moments of his life.Tom Doyle does an excellent job of describing the circumstances associated with the lawsuit initiated by Paul related to the contractual agreements negotiated by Allen Klein, the agent who represented John, George and Ringo but who was distrusted by Paul. Paul felt better represented in business dealings by Lee and John Eastman, a lawyer team who were relatives of his wife, Linda McCartney (maiden name Eastman.) As the old story goes, "the devil is in the details" and the details were contained in a three foot high volume of documents that eventually revealed the monetary deals which were at the heart of the lawsuit. The lawsuit made sense to me and would perhaps make sense to anyone who earned a living/made money by working for it rather receiving an inheritance. The Beatles were sons/lads from working class roots who made it big on the world stage while they were in their early twenties. Their education and backgrounds could not prepare them to negotiate deals to handle the kind of money their fame brought into their lives. Money is a sensitive and emotional topic but hard questions required answers. Questions such as, "What happened to all the money from multimillion dollar world wide record sales?" "Who got the money?" "Where did it go?"This book helps explain the musical phenomenon known as Paul McCartney from a multiangled lens camera. It contains descriptions of his lifestyle, personal views and choices, provides insights into his complex personality, and helps the reader better understand the unusual times in which changing musical tastes in the USA, Britain and worldwide shaped his life achievements. The author sheds light on the "Paul is dead" controversy and explores how it arose and became a media sensation for a time. Tom Doyle addresses the public rift with John Lennon and its effect on Paul. The book is based on interviews with Paul McCartney as well as with many of his close associates and musicians who were part of his inner circle. Especially interesting is the chapter which describes how the band Wings went on a "road tour" stopped in various University towns in England, to play before audiences on a seeming "spur of the moment" decision. The chapter which describes the genesis of the song, "Give Irish Back to the Irish" is also fascinating. Most intriguing are the chapters which dealt with Paul's continuing use of marijuana while on tour with the band resulting in an arrest in Sweden and a court case in Scotland. Yet it did not teach him the necessary lesson to curb this habit. It was in January 1980 that his laissez faire attitude caught up with him, when he unwittingly challenged the Japanese authorities by carrying marijuana into the country, in his luggage, and he was imprisoned. He finally heard the wake-up call that shook him back to reality. In summary, this book is most highly recommended because it is replete with insights, descriptions, and explanations of controversial topics associated with Beatles music and Paul McCartney. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Peter Heller manages to achieve something few writers can: he captures the inner turmoil, thoughts and feelings of an artist, a painter. More than that he creates a portrait of Jim Stegner, a man who in doing the right thing for the right reason, embroils himself in unexpected consequences which lead him to become the prime suspect in not one but two murders. To complicate matters even further, he has become a famous artist, whose paintings can sell for as much as $20,000 each. They are sold by his dealer and good friend of over 20 years, Stephen Lilly who owns a very high end art gallery in Taos, New Mexico. We learn early on, his teenage daughter, with whom he shared a very close bond, died tragically and unexpectedly. The author keeps the reader glued to each page, as the heart and soul of this complicated artist is revealed. Much of the story revolves around the impact of his actions/ behavior along with his strong feelings related to two deaths. He descends down a steep and slippery slope from which there appears to be no escape. Fortunately for the reader, the author provides Jim Stegner, the artist and painter, a most astonishing, amazing and believable escape from what looks like a life-sentence-in-jail type predicament.The story is told in the first person, therefore the reader is given an insider's view of the artist himself, in his own words, he marvels where life has taken him: he shot a man, he became a father, and lived very far from the sea, in fact he bought a house in the desert from a writer. The author very deftly provides details about Jim's personal life, as memories and thoughts, which tie together seemingly incongruent, disparate events in his life. He is twice divorced, the first a love match which dissolved, the second was a rebound attraction after the first divorce. Women play a strong role in his life, the reader gradually learns about the close relationship Jim developed with his daughter Alce. After her death, he sunk into alcoholism and was rescued by Irmina, a fortune-teller, psychic, and spiritual female friend who essentially saved his life. He acknowledges he has faults. After surviving several of life's tragedies, Jim moved outside of Taos, three miles south of town, to paint. He found himself a nude model, Sofia, a young Latina, who is much younger than himself whom, to his astonishement is as greatly attracted to him as he is to her. She sticks by him, through thick and thin as the local deputy and sheriff question Jim about a local murder in which he is the prime suspect. As if one murder is not enough, Jim is connected to a second murder that is closely related to the first. Peter Heller manages to weave a complex story about the inner life and struggles of an artist and super imposes a fascinating murder mystery into the recipe which makes for one fo the most unusual and satisfying books I have read this year to date. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

What makes this book so highly mesmerizing and difficult to put down is the author's ability to convey the strong sense of faith, spirituality, family bonds, and community which permeates all aspects of Dellie Standard's life. The story begins in 1909 - 1910 in Barbados where Dellie is contemplating her future when unexpectedly her world is turned upside down after her mother Caroline Walker Standard, known as Cal to all, dies suddenly. The author manages to beautifully capture the hopes, dreams, joys and sorrows of the Bajans living in Taborvilla, the tenant land and village surrounding Conventry Hall and the sugar plantation on which they work and earn their living.A new, exciting and bright future awaits Dellie or so her mother Cal predicts, *if* Dellie keeps the promise to leave the life she has known on the island of Barbados and use her seamstress and dress-making skills by immigrating to the Bronx in New York. Everyone who left the island, reportedly found a more prosperous and independent life there. Cal wanted to break the cycle of servitude to Coventry Hall and the manual labor associated with the sugar plantation by giving this advice to her daughter. Dellie is faced with a great personal conflict to keep or break her promise to her mother. She wants to marry Pendril, her childhood sweetheart who proposed marriage and had asked her father's permission to marry her. Her father Henry, approved of Prendil's plans, to go off on a ship, work as a cook and save his money to eventually buy land on Barbados and win his freedom from working on the sugar cane plantation. Dellie's skills as a seamstress would ensure their independence and freedom from the sugar cane cyclical life.Dellie's mother had warned her to stay away from the Big House, Coventry Hall and the poison it represented in their lives. Cal's greatest fear was Mr. Chandler would call for her girls to visit him as they approached womanhood. After her sister Lillian and Coleridge's wedding party celebration, Dellie discovered her grandmother left behind a basket of lotions and potions she was planning to give to Mrs. Chandler. While delivering the basket, an unexpected meeting with Mr. Chandler awakened her mother's dire warning about what it meant to continue living in association with the sugar cane plantation and servitude to Coventry Hall. Without hesitation, Dellie Standard abruptly changed her life's course with the decision to board a ship headed for New York city. She anticipated a future that would be bewildering, mysterious and astonishing. She was not wrong it was this and much, much more!The author writes a believable, realistic story filled with rich detail such that the reader can appreciate the sights, sounds, landscapes, and natural beauty of this magnificent Caribbean island. Most importantly Jennifer Davis Carey provides insights about fulfilling a dream to build a new life as an immigrant where opportunities arise for freedom and independence in a way not imaginable for those whose lives are connected to the sugar cane crop. The author includes an heart-wrenching tragedy in her story which threatens to unravel Dellie's entire efforts at finding happiness. Fortunately, a surprise ending awaits the reader to bring the story to an astonishg and satisfying conclusion. This is a most highly recommended book! Reviewier received a free copy of this book in exchange for this honest review. Erika Borsos {pepper flower]

I was very pleased to receive this Vine Review selection, a book written by one of China's most famous and best selling authors. Most pivotal and impressive is the fact that Mai Jai worked for the Chinese Intelligence Services which provided him the impetus to writing about breaking a secret code in global espionage. However, make no mistake about it, what is very clear and *most* evident is that the author's sophisticated imagination and highly admirable complex writing skills are the key to making this novel a sensational, exciting, and mysterious reading experience! Although undoubtedly, his personal and unique insights were enhanced by working in this unusual profession. It took me several readings over a few months to truly appreciate this brilliant and multifaceted jewel of a book.A gem when held to the light disperses a one-of-a-kind signature patterned reflection, such is the impression left on the reader after reading this book. There are layers upon layers of meaning and revelations concerning political, historical and cultural realities associated with various generations of the Rong family. Various political and historical changes resulted in a transformation of what defined success for this highly intelligent, industrious family, all of the family members managed to distinguish themselves in their respective fields of endeavor and profession over several generations.It started with Rong Zilai, also known as John Lillie, the first of the Rongs who broke away from the shipping trade which had been their main source of wealth and which defined their importance at the turn of the century. John Lillie became an academic, he started "Lillie's Academy of Mathematics" which later became the famous N University in Jiangnan, China. It all started due to his grandmother's poor health, he was sent to a University overseas to find her help but as time passed he studied more complex subjects such as math and geometry in which he excelled. After returning home, he opened his academy and amazingly over several generations, the family produced two children who became prodigies in mathematics. This book is the life story of one of these offspring: Rong Jinzhen, also called Zhendi, an autistic genius whose unmatchable skills were recognized and rewarded by his foreign math professor, Dr. Jan Liseiwicz. It is a fascinating read to discover how this professor ended up teaching at N University and the relationship which developed, blossomed and progressed between student and mentor. Later, it would play a central role in Zhendi's future profession as China's most talented and skilled cryptographer. The duo invented new rules in the game of chess, recalling this game of chess, Rong Jinzhen in the future would unravel the most difficult encoded messages in what became known as "the Purple Code". This is a most complex novel which is why I deduct one star but after getting used to the writing style, it is a highly satisfying and enjoyable book to read. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Patrick Ness takes a Japanese myth which had great impact and meaning for him as a child then extrapolates aspects of it to build a mysterious story which crescendos into creating interest and intrigue for the reader who is hooked by the expectations of what is to happen, Unfortunately, the reader gets lost in the mystery which eventually grows into a quagmire of artistic expression that becomes a collage or kaleidoscope which threatens to overwhelm. Although the ending might come as a surprise to some, given the enigmatic nature of George Duncan's mysterious love interest, it came as no surprise to this reader. The truly serious disappointment was that the author could not decide upon a proper explanation for the explosive ending and therefore gives the reader five different possible scenarios that provide a reason for the ending. The fact he did not chose *just* one makes for a great let down. I reread the book, hoping to enjoy it more, looking for what I had missed but three stars is all I can honestly give to this book.Essentially, the main story is about George Duncan, a divorced print shop owner who is in his late forties. He has an adult daughter Amanda, also divorced, who is the mother of a bright and precocious young boy, Jean-Pierre or JP for short. The book begins whenGeorge hears a cry, a keening in his yard, which turns out to be a wounded bird, a crane that has an arrow stuck in its wing. George removes the arrow and saves the crane's life, setting the bird free. The story is told  poetically as if it were a metaphor for something about to happen, a mystery to be revealed in George's life, it is a very effective opening for a book.George is presented as a kind-hearted eccentric whom everyone trusts but whose personality is bland. Into his life enters Kumiko, a mysterious Japanese beauty who requests help with her artwork which consists of elaborate cuttings, that are enhanced  with feathers, creating a spell over those who view the pieces. Uncharacteristically, George falls in love with Kumiko and his life begins to be more meaningful and complicated. New aspects of George's personality are revealed as he and Kumiko continue to create more cuttings decorated with feathers. They become highly desirable and collectible art, that is sought by wealthy clients. George and Kumiko marry, to the surprise of most of George's closest friends and relatives. An unexpected disaster threatens their great love.Sorry to say that at times, I enjoyed reading more about Amanda and her emotional involvement with her ex-husband and his relationship with JP then the mysterious love which kept growing between George and Kumiko which held such great promise. Due to the ending of the book, the author could redeem himself with a sequel, where a relative or someone from Kumiko's past comes searching for her then the reader would at last be satisfied with the revelations about the past life of the mysterious Kumiko. Patrick Ness could also explore George Duncan's failed relationship with his first wife and provide plausible reasons for his reticent and bland personality, which could be the outward surface of a deeply complex emotional inner life. I would also love to read more about Amanda and her ex-husband Henri, why did their marriage not work out? Erika Borsos (pepper flower)

Sherill Tippins has written an astonishing biography of the Chelsea Hotel, a memoir which the hotel itself would have written about the lives and accomplishments of its notable guests over the past 125 years, if (as the saying goes) "the walls could talk." In each chapter, the author provides a vast amount of information, impeccably researched about the artists, authors, would-be-published-authors, singers, musicians, playwrights, and other creative personalities who either met, rented or were residents of the Chelsea Hotel. What is most impressive is how the stories in each chapter flow from one era to the next in such a smooth and seamless manner. Every twenty to twenty five years, the next generation of creative personalities seems to awaken and newly discover the mysterious aura and milieu which attracts similar minded people to this location where they can thrive and produce some of their finest work. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Shohreh Aghdashloo is an Emmy award winning actress and the first Iranian born actress to be nominated for an Academy Award who has made her home in Los Angeles, California. She was a well known actress in Iran starring in plays and films during her early thirties when the Shah of Iran ruled her country. She left her husband and family, fled her homeland to follow her passion for acting and escape the tyranny and terror associated with the Islamic religious government created by the Ayatollah Khomeini. As an outspoken actress, one who had strong personal political beliefs, a person who had attended rallies supporting the Shah's changes toward reform, she was at risk under the new regime. She had some connections in England where she settled, learned the English language, obtained her BA degree in Political Science and worked in retail and fashion, while pursuing her acting career. She ultimately fulfilled her lifelong ambition and dream: to become a Hollywood actress. In this memoir, the author shares her life story, which is filled with courage, ambition, love, hard work, political change and turmoil and overcoming the odds with a strong spirit that ultimately triumphs in the end.We learn of her first love and marriage to Aydin a highly cultured, European educated Iranian man who was liberal-minded enough, despite being twelve years older than she, to allow her to pursue her career of acting. He worked for the Ministry of Culture and Education, during the Shah's government. While the Shah ruled, Shohreh had a group of artistic and intellectual friends and traveled with her husband to Europe and Egypt. Her charmed life came to a halt and developed irreparable cracks after the Islamic Revolution. The concepts of freedom, artistic passion and women's rights eroded and were replaced by tyranny and fear. Some of Shohreh's friends were persecuted, imprisoned and a few even died. She feared arrest. Aydin's first loyalty was to his homeland, he loved Shohreh enough to release her from their marriage and gave her freedom to pursue her passion of acting and build a new life outside of Iran.The author describes a privileged early life in Iran, growing up with her three brothers, in a household where she was protected, cherished and provided a good education. She did not fulfill her father's dream that she become a medical doctor. During her teens, her independent spirit exerted itself, without her parent's consent, she modeled clothes in a fashion show and later starred in a play, which her parents would not attend. Despite her father's disapproval,Shohreh pursued her acting talent and became a well known and influential actress in Iran. Eventually, she won her father's support and acceptance of her chosen profession. Shohreh's move to the USA and Los Angeles is a moving story of challenges and triumphs of faith, hope, and hard work. Eventually she finds a new man, also an Iranian emigr, who fully shares her passion for acting, he is a playwright whose plays win standing ovations in Iranian immigrant communities throughout Europe and the United States. Their love story and marriage, is a fitting conclusion to this most interesting and timely, politically sensitive memoir.Although, I enjoyed this book, I deduct one star because the author's rendition of certain life events are too mildly and neutrally stated. It seems clear that Shohreh had great respect and love for her father but also had to follow her own life path, which meant conflict. She gave the facts but not the depth of emotions associated with these differences. Another example, the emotional depth and searing impact of leaving her first husband, the love of her life, is not well conveyed or explained. The author seems to avoid the feelings associated with the difficulties of starting a new life in England.  She tells us "what happened" but not the strength of the feelings associated with these life altering events. It is possible that these feelings are too strong and painful to explain in words and too personal to convey. I also understand the author is protecting the privacy of her relationship with her father and also that of her first husband. She wants to maintain the respect and integrity of their past relationship. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

This book is one great value, as it is really consists of five books in one. The entire book provides several years of lessons via a system that really works!  How do I know? I received this book in July from the Vine Program and in all honesty, would not review it until I actually put the lessons into practice. Now it is, three months later and I can write I have tested it and found I have fairly well retained the information which I learned from several chapters of Book One.What I like most about this system is that it uses a  common sense approach, they teach useable information right from the start. First you learn, words such as numbers and then phrases and tenses, which  when put together,  become actual sentences used in everyday situations. You have can listen to the correct pronunciation and practice pronouncing the word yourself because included is a CDrom which counts as one of the five-in-one books in the set.Popular expressions and idioms are fun to learn, since many are words in English which makes it easier, as the meanings are already known. There are sections in each chapter, called "Talkin' the talk" which provide actual conversations using the lessons learned. The reader can see and understand how the words are placed in sentence structure in real life situations. For example, two young girls meet and greet each other and discuss a work situation and about shopping, using words and phrases with which the reader has become familiar from the lessons.Overall, the lessons are based on daily life and real situations that you would encounter when visiting Germany. If you want a user friendly book with a common sense approach to learning and pronouncing words, phrases, and sentences, this book will help do it for most readers. Erika Borsos [pepper flower]

Erika Chase brings readers the latest tale from the Ashton Corners Book Club, in her book, Law and Author. This is a great cozy series for readers who love the written word, as the author starts each chapter with a literary quote. It's a nice touch and it shows the care put into each part of the book. This one has a long lost granddaughter. A murder. Wedding Plans. Lots of personal tidbits about the heroine and her love interest and tons of things to keep the reader interested. Another great book in the series!What I liked:Erika Chase is a writer after my own heart. I love the quotes that precede each chapter of her books. It clues the reader in a little bit about what's to come and it shows Chases' love for literature. I find myself almost as interested to see what the quote will be as I am about what clues are going to come out in each chapter. I think that says a lot about how the author plots her stories and her influences. A great idea that a lot readers will appreciate.This book finds the Ashton Corners Book Club in a bit of a mess. Bob Miller, a club member, is being re-united with his grand-daughter, Darla. But not everything about her visit seems on the up and up and when murder comes calling, Darla has some 'splaining' to do. The premise of the book was interesting and I couldn't help but wonder, why all of the sudden this chick would appear. Bob having been estranged from his daughter for many years and never having met said grand-daughter before, was awfully trusting. Readers probably won't be too shocked when Darla turns out to be suspect in a murder. I liked the cat and mouse kind of play with Darla's story. It was like she couldn't tell the truth in spite of herself. Fun to read and ponder over for sure.Erika Chase always gives the reader a great mystery and this one was no exception. I found myself thinking about it when I wasn't reading. Trying to put the clues together in my head, right along with the characters. There was a moment when I considered the possible motive, but threw it out. So when the big reveal came it was one of those boink yourself on the head moments... LOL! The killer wasn't who I expected nor was Darla's story and motivation. It was a great surprise. Those are the best kind of mysteries aren't they?Lizzie and the book club members were once again on the trail of a killer, but we also got to see a lot of the wedding preparations going on. There were some great moments between Mark and Lizzie and it was nice to see their relationship blooming. They are a couple that never seems to grow stagnant. They are always changing and evolving. The way a great relationship should be. I liked the personal growth of the characters and the stories of the other book club members almost as much as the mystery. It's like visiting good friends with this series and I always love going back to it.What I Didn't Like:I felt like Bob and Molly were a little bit naive here. This could have been any girl, posing as Bob's long lost grand-daughter. It just seemed like they would have taken anyone in. It just didn't seem too plausible to me. I would have liked a little bit of skepticism about what she was up to and the like. Probably just a pet peeve of mine and certainly not a deal breaker.Bottom Line:This is another engaging book from Erika Chase. Not only do readers get a good mystery, but the personal moments of the story were also poignant and fulfilling. I wanted to hear more about Mark and Lizzie and I got that in this one. I wanted to learn more about other members of the book club and I got that too. Just an all around good addition to the series!

Jane Shoup brings readers the first book in her Green Valley series, Down in the Valley. This book is set in West Virginia during the 1800's. Readers who enjoy books with lots of characters and storylines will find this one right up their alley. Shoup is not only able to tell a compelling story of a woman who has suffered finding a place for herself and love, but she is able to enlighten the reader about the rights of women during this time in history. A heartwarming tale of second chances and helping others. Potentially, a very good series.What I Liked:I don't live too far from West Virginia and I tend to like historical novels that are set in that area. West Virginia and Kentucky have a lot in common, especially during the era that Down in the Valley depicts. I thought Shoup did a wonderful job of showing the ruggedness of the area and it's beauty. But she was also able to capture the sometimes forgotten picture of poverty and desperation. The town Shoup writes about was not destitute or anything like that, but there were a lot of people in need of a helping hand for one reason or another and I think that was a realistic portrayal of the times. Well done on that aspect of the book.I liked the fact that Shoup was able to shed some light on the rights of women during the 1800's. A woman alone trying to fend for herself was rare. It was difficult on many levels because the men had a great deal of power, while women did not even have the right to vote. Men were supposed to earn the money and provide for the women and turning the tables on those ideals was just not done. I liked the fact that Emeline was independent and strong, especially considering her past. I thought she was a great example of the human condition and I enjoyed watching her grow as a character in such a tough environment.Emeline's relationship with Tommy was quiet and tender and had the makings for a really solid love story. The idea that Tommy along with several other misfits, if you will, came to help Emeline on the farm, gave their romance a chance to bloom. I found Tommy to be a little on the shy side, but he held strong convictions and wasn't afraid to voice them when he needed to. I thought the main characters complimented each other well. Readers who are looking for a romance that is wholesome and sweet will certainly like these two together.What I Didn't Like:Although there were several things I did like about the book, there were many things that overshadowed the potential in this one. There were tons of characters in this book. Far too many to make it easy to follow. It created a lot of confusion and it was hard as a reader to figure out who was important to the story and who wasn't. It think it would have served the writer better to have had a smaller cast that could have been more thoroughly developed. I want to know more than just the name of a character who is being introduced. I want to know why I should care who they are. Why I should want to remember them as the story continues and I felt that was missing here.Errors in grammar are not one of those things that bug me. Spelling errors however, stick out like a sore thumb. There were some errors in both areas with this book but the most glaring issue for me was the terminology and modern language. This was a book set in the 1800's and I felt like Shoup took a lot of poetic license in how she expressed herself and how her characters talked and in some cases acted.Bottom Line:There is a lot of potential here. The plot itself was engaging and there were some ideas that were definitely worth pursuing. I liked the actual love story part of the book but felt it was somewhat confusing to sort it all out. Too many characters and a bit to much modern language. I think the author brought readers a compelling story, with a great heroine, but perhaps needed to reign in how many people the reader needed to keep up with. I will certainly give the next book in the series a nod and see how things progress. One to watch... it could be amazing given a few minor changes.

The author of the Jane True series, Nicole Peeler, brings readers the first book in a new urban fantasy series. Jinn and Juice is the first book in the Jinni series and promises to turn what readers know about this author on it's ear. Having read a few books and seen a few Jinni's in movies and television over the years, I can say that readers are in for something different with this series. This Jinni doesn't blink her eyes and nod her head. A great new read from a well respected author in the genre!What I Liked:This book was totally refreshing. I loved the Jane True books, but I've got to say Lyla, the heroine in Jinn and Juice was really intriguing. I loved the whole Jinni premise of the series and couldn't wait to dive in and see what Nicole Peeler's take on this subject would be. Lyla the heroine is a very old Jinni. She has been under the curse for almost a thousand years and is on the verge of becoming human again. Unfortunately, she has to hide out until the coast is clear and her servitude is over. As luck would have it, she gets bound with only a week to go. That's when the action starts and it doesn't slow down for a second. Readers are hurled into a very new and different landscape. The world building here was intense and very full. Peeler really went out on a limb with this one and I think it pays off for the most part.I expected Lyla to be kind of wise beyond her years. The sage heroine who has been through a lot and ready to be completely unbound. Not exactly, what readers get with her character. She has a kind of 'devil may care' attitude. She's all about belly dancing and burlesque. She didn't come across as particularly worldly wise, but she was still a treat to read about. She liked to have fun and lets face it you need a character like that in most urban fantasy titles to lighten the mood a little bit. Peeler gives readers a Jinni with a penchant for adventure. Nice touch!I admit that I wanted to know more about Lyla. Her backstory was  a little vague, as was most of the other character's stories, but I think we can chalk that up to this being a series. I expect we will find out more and more as the series continues about her and that may be the best way. The way the world of the Jinni's and the Magi worked was interesting and full of surprises. The relationship between Lyla and Oz is captivating, but a little on the weird side, as she is basically his servant. But the dynamic between them nothing if not intriguing.What I Didn't Like:I really wanted to like this one and I did on a lot of levels, but my issues with it all stem from one thing. There were just toooooo many supernatural characters. You had just about every paranormal character you could possibly think of in this book and new ones that Peeler created herself. Too many names, too many descriptions. Way too much to try to keep up with. I could see the potential in having so many but I think it took too much away from the actual story. I think the back stories were vague on the characters partly because there were just too many in every possible way. Yes, it is possible to have too much of a good thing and I think that's what happened here. Doesn't mean it can't be fixed in subsequent books in the series.Bottom Line:This one needed a bit of work. I liked Lyla, but she was not what I expected. The Jinni premise was spot on, but there were so many other supernatural characters it all but got lost in the mix. I can see where Peeler was going with this and I hope she reigns it in a little with the next book because there is a lot of potential here. But you better be ready to take notes when you read this one if you want to keep'em all straight. Almost gave me a headache... LOL!

Victoria Abbott returns with the latest book in the Book Collector Mystery series, The Marsh Madness. This mother, daughter writing team once again brings readers a book based on a highlighted mystery writer from the past. This time it is Ngaio Marsh. These books always have that nostalgic feel to them. It's a story like Miss Marple or Hercule Poirot would be involved in. Abbott doesn't disappoint. It's a page turner from the first to the last.What I Liked:This is a great series for me, because I cut my teeth so to speak, in the mystery genre on the books and stories of Agatha Christie and other greats. I love the fact that these authors focus on different writers from the past and try to educate the reader a little bit while also entertaining them. All of the details on book collecting also add a layer of authenticity to the stories. So, not only goes the writer get a great mystery but they also get an object lesson on some literary greats.Vera's collection is certainly growing under Jordan's guidance and adding a collection of mystery writer, Ngaio Marsh would be another feather in her cap. When Jordan, Vera and Uncle Kev go to check out a prospect they get a lot more than a few first additions. The seller, Chadwick Kauffman ends up dead... but wait a minute, it's not really Chadwick Kauffman at all. It looks like an imposter is a foot and Jordan and the gang or being framed. I loved the plot for this one and they way things all came together. I thought Abbott did a great job with the mystery aspects of the book and kept the reader off balance enough, so that they didn't figure it out too early. The mystery was interesting and elaborate. Liked it a lot.One of the strong things about this series has always been the great characters that Abbott has created. Jordan once again proves why she is such a great heroine for this series. She gets to the heart of matter with a lot of curiosity and some really good instincts. I love the way that she has such great love for good books too. She really is a very good character. Her relationship with Smiley is heating up a little bit too and it was nice to have that break in the action to pick up on Jordan's personal life.As always the secondary characters share the spotlight with Jordan. Uncle's Kev and Mick are right in the middle of the action and Vera is always a treat with her snarky attitude and ways. I think my favorite of the secondary characters is Signora Panetone and her amazing concoctions in the kitchen.Bottom Line:Another great book in this coy series about great books... LOL! I have liked all of the books in this series because of the intriguing plots and interesting characters. These authors prove that two heads are better than one when it comes to writing good mysteries... can't wait for the next one!

Breakout is the series ender for The Dred Chronicles by Ann Aguirre and what a finish it was! Aguirre has created a spin-off series from her Sirantha Jax series, that may actually top the original, a rare feat. This is a science fiction series that has everything from bloody battles to tender love scenes and the sympathetic characters in the story, just happen to be a colony of murderers. Now, if that's not unique, I don't know what is! Fantastic ending to a great series.What I liked:When I first started doing a lot of reading on my own and picking titles that I wanted to read for myself, science fiction was one of my favorite genres. I don't even know why. I think I can see the parallel between reading paranormal fiction and reading science fiction. Aliens versus super natural beings like weres and vamps. But I have really gotten away from reading very much in the Sci-Fi genre. There was something about The Dred Chronicles that drew me in and helped me remember why I used to like it so much. The world building is phenomenal in these kinds of books.Ann Aguirre has created such a unique and different universe for this series. The Dred Chronicles actually centers around a penal colony full of murderers. What's more the reader is expected to like these characters, even love them to some extent. Talk about a hard premise to sell. But Aguirre makes it look like child's play. She draws the reader in with this whole idea of why these people are put in this position and what they hope to gain by getting out. She inspires a sympathy in the reader for them, before the reader even sees it coming. Amazingly done!This is not science fiction for the faint of heart though. Breakout has several very bloody battles and Aguirre does not spare the reader the gore involved. But what's interesting about that is that it seems so natural. Like there was no other way this could have gone differently. Being the final book in the series, a lot of things needed to happen to bring about resolution for those aboard the prison ship Perdition. I think each characters ending was well thought out, planned meticulously and brought to a conclusion that befitted their situations. Not everyone got a happy ending. It's just not that kind of book. But the loose ends were tied up and the conclusion was satisfying.We learned a lot more about Jael in this book than ever before. He started out in Aguirre's Sirantha Jax series, but he has really shined in the Dred Chronicles. Despite all of the mess everyone was going through and some of the gut wrenching scenes there was still time for a little romance. What could be more erotic or sensual to finding love when even you next few minutes were in jeopardy. I felt like Aguirre ended things in a more traditional way with this series. She gave resolution to the questions about Jael and what happened after and that was nice. I didn't want to make up my own ending this time and she didn't make me... it was amazing!What I Didn't Like:The pacing was a little odd at times. Certain things that happened in the story got only a few paragraphs of description and others several pages. I wanted the important things to get more time. I wanted to digest a little bit before moving on to some other soul crushing event. I think my emotions just didn't have time to catch up sometimes with this one. There were also parts that dragged a little bit, but once it all panned out, I can't really count that as a reason to give this book anything less than a 5 apple review.Bottom Line:If you like science fiction you can't miss this one. Breakout was amazing in just about every way. Lots of cool aliens, a ship full of murderers. Battles that will make your head spin and a universe that makes you wish this wasn't the last book in the series. I want more and I think you will too. You don't have to read the Sirantha Jax series to like this one, but you'll probably go back and read it once you figure out what a great author Aguirre is.

Double Vision is the second book in Colby Marshall's Dr. Jenna Ramey series, featuring a heroine with a unique trait for helping solve her cases. Marshall uses the ideas of color and numbers in a very unusual way in this mainstream mystery. Readers who are looking for an uncommon plot and strong characters will love this one. A massive shooting sets the stage for Jenna's latest case involving a six year old gifted child who witnesses a heinous crime. But Molly isn't your average little girl and it's up to Jenna to use Molly's gifts and her own to catch a killer. A very rare book with a fantastic premise!What I liked:Okay, so there were parts of this book that were very well written and parts that came across as a little too logical or too easy. But the overall theme of the series is quite unparalleled in most of the main stream mysteries I have read. Marshall gives her heroine Jenna a very rare neurological condition known as synesthesia, in which the patient's neurological pathways are so closely related that they are almost connected. Put simply, this heroine sees in color. Not like you and I do, but in a way that correlates her experiences and can be used to help in her job as an FBI profiler. This was fascinating and it's a real condition. Marshall does't bombard the reader with too much information about it, but she uses it in a way that makes this story something completely different than anything I've read before. Well done!I don't review too many main stream mysteries because I like a book that is a little less graphic. I don't necessarily like to read about all the guts and gore and thrillers tend to be quite dark in some cases. This book had that type of edge, but it didn't get too messy. Yes, there was a massive shooting in which seven people die, and it is related to another case where more people died, but it didn't give me any cringe worthy moments. I admit to wondering what possesses people to do this kind of thing more than once, but it was the kind of book that was worth reading even if it did deal with some really maniacal minds.Jenna and her boyfriend Yancy were both great characters that Marshall did a great job writing. Jenna has had to learn to see the world in a different way literally. In this book she has to take her way with colors and try to understand Molly's way with numbers. It was almost like they were speaking two different languages, but were able to find a way to fuse the two to find a killer. I like characters who are unusual in some way and Marshall certainly stimulated that avenue with Jenna's ability. Marshall was also about to show how it affected Jenna's personal life, as well as, her professional life. She was a great heroine and the addition of Yancy as her love interest gave readers a new way of seeing Jenna.What I Didn't Like:I seriously wanted to like Molly. And on some levels I did, but I couldn't get away from the idea that she was just too perfect. I know she was written as a gifted child, but she was still supposed to be a child. Even in children who have great intelligence you still have that essence that is still innocent. Molly wasn't like that. She didn't have that quality that made her still seem innocent and childlike. I wanted her to act like a kid, at least a little bit and I didn't get that with her. It seemed like something was missing. She didn't come across as legit, so to speak. Too poised, too adult like and too controlled.Bottom Line:There was a lot of potential here. The mystery itself was captivating. Jenna was an amazing heroine and the premise for the series was top notch. I think the author missed the mark a little bit with Molly's character but that didn't take too much away from my overall enjoyment of this book. Main stream mysteries are a little dark sometimes, but they make up for that with sheer realism and gut wrenching action. This was definitely a good one. If you like a good mystery, this one might be right up your alley.

Shelley Freydont continues the Celebration Bay mystery series with her latest book, Trick or Deceit. Halloween is the perfect setting for murder! Readers who are looking for a great cozy for the fall season will love this one. With everything from haunted houses and witches to preachers and town skeletons in the closet, this book has it all. Freydont's trademark quirky characters and the small town setting give this one all the makings for one haunted read...What I liked:Halloween was always a favorite holiday of mine for more than one reason. Candy, candy and more candy, but more importantly getting to transform myself into a character from my favorite books. I took it seriously when it came to celebrating the season. I had a party once and even made my own graveyard with the names and funny epitaphs for my friends. So when I found out this cozy had a Halloween theme I was totally on board. Celebration Bay was the perfect place for this theme. This small town goes all out when it comes to holidays and I was excited to see how they decked out for the scariest of them all.The haunted house competition was a brilliant idea. I loved reading about the entries and how each person that entered interpreted it differently. The $10,000 prize certainly made things a little intense and somebody was a very sore loser. The mystery aspects of this one centered around the murder of one of the judges. Freydont gave readers plenty of suspects and the motive was pretty obvious, or was it? I thought the clues were plentiful and the red herrings were not too far out of the realm of possibility. Freydont did a great job with the Halloween theme and the murder mystery.Liv Montgomery, the heroine of the series and Celebration Bay's event coordinator is a perfect amateur sleuth. Celebration Bay is looking to get a grant to build a new community center and it's up to Liv to figure out the clues to this murder before a New York backer comes in. I liked that Liv is curious by nature but not necessarily foolhardy or reckless in her investigations. She is a pretty logical thinker and I like that about her. The other secondary characters in the book, add so much to each story. They are well written and always provide a different perspective on each mystery. Great characters all around.What I Didn't Like:There has been a lot of tension between Liv and Chaz for awhile now. They seem to be dragging their feet about whether or not they want to be a couple or not and that's getting a little frustrating, since this is Book 4 in the series. I want them to just pull the trigger so to speak, but that may just be a pet peeve of my own.Bottom Line:This was a good cozy for the season. Halloween is right around the corner and this one really hits the spot of those of us readers who like the creepy factor when it comes to murder. The mystery was believable and not to easy to figure out. The motive seems clear, but there are a lot of factors in this one. Liv is once again a great sleuth and seems to have settled into her role as event coordinator. She and Chaz need to figure it out though! LOL... A very good addition to the series!

Karen Hawkins brings readers the second book in the Princes of Oxenburg series, The Prince and I. Hawkins is a big name when it comes to historical romance and she never disappoints. This book is an interesting take on the "Robin Hood" story that features a female bandit and a warlord prince. Hawkins uses everything from comic relief to intense and almost instant romance to bring this one together and readers will be thrilled with it. A great addition to this wonderful series!What I Liked:First off, let me say that Karen Hawkins is in my opinion a very good historical romance writer. Everything I have ever read from her was unique and well written. I knew what to expect going into reading the Prince and I. Great characters, humor in spades and a plot that would be both entertaining and fun. I got all of that and more with this book. The book starts out fast and furious and doesn't slow down much. There was a slight lull in the middle somewhere, but it didn't matter. When it caught back up it was on fire. Such a great romance and the author's take on Robin Hood was exceptional.Lady Murian is one a mission. Her husband and her home have been taken from her and she's out to get a little revenge. I loved the fact that this book is set in the Highlands and that Murian takes to the ways of the highwayman to thwart her nemesis, the Earl of Loudan. What a unique take on Robin Hood. I loved it. A female bandit was such a great idea and it really worked here. Murian is strong and fiesty and full of vim and vigor. It would take kind of character to stand up to Prince Max. He is a warrior and Murian proves that she is as well when she bests him with her sword. One of my favorite female leads of the year.Max isn't your average prince. He doesn't sit at home and bemoan his daily drudgery of being a prince. He leads his men into battle and he sometimes ends up being the bearer of bad news. When readers meet him, he is in somewhat of a dark place, a little broody and in need of something to fight for. Murian gives him that and so much more. The attraction between them is for lack of a better word, instant. Max knows the Scottish Robin Hood is a woman and he's out to find her again. I liked that he was such a strong character. He had a great sense of duty and intelligence that went well with his handsome features. I liked him a lot, though instant love isn't necessarily my thing.Tata Natasha, Max's grandmother has gotten herself into a bit of a fix and needs her grandson's help to get her out of it. She was a saucy grandma as usual and provided a lot of comic relief for the book. Hawkins has such a great sense of humor and most importantly she is able to translate that into her books. It gives the reader a smile now and then and takes the pressure off of the lead characters long enough for readers to catch their breath. Great humor and comedy in this one.What I didn't like:Like I said, instant love isn't really my thing. Though Murian and Max fall for each other at first sight, there were still some obstacles in their way, so it didn't feel like they were automatically going to fall in love and marry. However, there was that cringey kind of feeling you get when love seems to be trite and predictable.
