I am not over 50, but my doctor said the 'over 50' are higher in certain vitamins critical for older men, but are highly beneficial for men under 50 as well, just not as required as much for younger men.

This is a great heavybag.  There IS a difference in heavy bags, not all 75 pounders are the same.  Ringside is a high quality product.  The bag is frim and consistent all the way around, no hard or soft spots I can find.  The attachment points are incredibly well assembled, no worries about this one ripping free with heavy use.  This is a REAL heavy bag, not that cheap thing that comes with the rack and pullup bar on the other side, this bag is a good one and it will last you a long time.

Once we got it assembled, this is a very nice 5-drawer chest.  Compared to what I can buy locally, it seems it may be a bit overpriced, especially since it is particle board with wood laminate over it.  For this price, I would expect solid wood.  I took 1 star off the review for the price.The second star came off of the review due to the assembly.  Let me start by saying I am a very handy guy, and my ability and tools available is the only reason this was able to be able to put together.  Some of the slots did not line up properly, specifically the cuts that the drawer bottom fits into, which required me to recut some areas in order to be able to assemble the drawers.  The holes for some of the attachment pins were blown out, requiring the area to be glued back together in order to stay assembled.  Finally, the holes on the back of the handles were far too small to accept the screws supposed to hold them in place, requiring significant force or drilling the holes larger to be able to install them.  It took FAR MORE THAN 90 MINUTES as stated in the instructions due to all the repairs required.Once assembled, this is a nice 5-drawer chest.  It is weighty enough to stay stable, drawers open and close smoothly, and it does not wobble.

I thought this would be a fun family game/competition, so I gave it a shot.  It is much larger than I expected, the cars and track are quite large.  The track is 10"-12" across.  The track is basically just heavy construction paper.  The controls are touchy, but simple to use.  Driving the cars is a challenge.  While ON the track they cars drive well, much too fast to be controlled on the confines of the track, but they drive well.  The problem is that when they come OFF the track, they only turn left.  You can still steer them, but they go left like a Democrat, but only slightly veer to the right about 5 degrees.  That makes it nearly impossible to get them back on the track correctly, which turns the "race" into a competition of who can drive the slowest and manage to stay on the track, because as soon as it comes off the track you are going to lose the race.I image with a lot of practice someone can get good at racing these cars on the track, but my family and I got tired of this after one afternoon of racing each other.

This is exactly what I looks like it would be, a coffee cup for people who drink A LOT of coffee.  OK, maybe not, but it is great for transporting food to putlucks or picnics.  We have putlucks at my work every couple of weeks, I have used this to bring bbq sauce, shredded chicken for tacos, chili, and even chilled fruit.  It keeps everything hot, or cold, for hours.  If you rinse it with HOT water before filling it up, it will easily keep a hot food item hot from 6:00am to noon.  Chilled items will stay even longer, assuming you dont leave them in a hot car or somehting silly.The seal is excellent.  I have literally shook it up and down with liquid inside and it does not leak.  The four clamps and the seal make an amazing and secure seal.This is insulated similar to a YETI cup, so it should nto be used to cook with or put on a heat source.  If you want something to easily store and transport food, without worry of it spillling, this is a great choice.

This is a great book to help you follow the diet plans recommended by Mark Lauren.  While Im no expert, it seems like the basics of it is to vary the types of food you eat, and the workouts you do, in order to keep your body from getting into too much of a routine.  Accoridng to Mark Lauren and others, the a routing allows your body to accomodate itself too much and you dont get the same overall benfit.The book is detailed, but easy to get through.  The recipes are great, very simple to follow and most seem tasty so far.  My only complain would be that since they are all a single serving size, the portions are werid.  Too many call for 3oz or 4oz of chicken breast, or similar odd portion sizes, so they you either have all kinds of random 1/3 chicken breast leftovers, or a lot of waste.  If you have a partner to share meals with, they recipes get easier to make as the sizes double, allowing you to use the entire chicken breast for a meal instead of only part of it.

I was very surprised by the quality of this watch.  I honestly wasnt expecitng much due to the price, but I am very happy with what I received.  To start, it is HEAVY, no doubt it is well put together.  This is not a cheap watch that is all flash, it has substance to it.  The finish is excellent, everything mates together perfectly, no odd gaps or corners.This is a large watch, it may look akward on small framed people or anyone with skinny wrists.The chronograph feature is simple to use.  The time is easy to set and adjust.  The only part that is challenging is the band, as you have to remove links to make it fit (it comes very large, so I doubt anyone needs to add links).If you want something that looks nice to modestly fancy (does that make sense?), without spending a lot of money, this is a great watch.

This is an excellent heater for medium sized rooms which need a little extra heat.  Will it work in Northern Alaska if your house heat goes out?  No.  Does it work to keep a room cozy when its in the 30's or 40's outside?  Easily.We keep it in the living room so we can keep the living area comfortable without having to heat the entire house to that temperature.  Our bedrooms are a bit colder, but thats what blankets and cuddling are for.The wood grain finish is attractive.  The design of the unit allows it to be unobtrusive in a room, it doesnt scream "HEATER OVER THERE" when you walk into the room.  There is no funny heater smell, and it doesnt make that weird heater groaning noise when it turns on.  It is simply unnoticed and provides heat.

This is a very comfortable stool.  Put it together in less than 5 minutes.  Feels sturdy, no wobbles, and wheels roll smoothly.  The height adjustmet is simple and easy to use.The blue is very blue, exactly like the photo.  The material is easy to clean.  I can wholeheartedly recommend this for anything that a stool would be required over a chair.  I personally prefer stools to chairs anyway as they help me keep a better posture and keep my back from hurting.

This is a great sound bar.  It is easy to setup and get working.  The sound quality is excellent.  The separate wireless subwoofer works great, really punches out the bass effects when watching action shows or movies.  The remote is simple and easy to use; but just large enough that it wont always be lost between the cushions.  The soundbar itself is a bit long, so you should account for that while figuring out where  you  would want to be putting it.  Overall I can easily recommend this to anyone wanting high quality sound without the hassle and expense of a 5 or 7 speaker surround sound system.

I have boxed for years and been through too many sets of gloves to count.  These are a high quality set of bag gloves, but take some getting used to and breaking in.  I personally prefer to wear sparring gloves for bag work, instead of dedicated bag gloves, but I wanted to give these a try.The run a bit small.  I have LARGE hands and cant event fit in some types of gloves, I could fit in these but not if my hands are wrapped.  They start out tight enough to be uncomfortable after a few minutes, but after my first break in session they loosened up nicely.The velcro closure is secure, if not a bit hard to take off without help or using your teeth.  The padding all all on the front and top of the glove, which allows for a breathable palm section.Overall I would still recomend a good set of sparring gloves instead of bag gloves, but if you are looking at these and dont intend on sparring, these would be a good option.

This is a simple to use and nice sounding wireless speaker.  It is made for outdoors, so you dont have to worry if it gets spashed by the pool or gets a bit of sprinkling rain at the park.  The sound quality is great compared to the many inexpenisve options out there, but not as nice as the high end options like the Bose portable bluetooth speaker.Bluetooth pairing is simple and I only had to pair it once in order to use it regularly.  Battery life is good for a few hours of constant listening before the volume start to drop off.My kids both grab this when they head to the park for play basketball or volleyball with their friends.  It is well worth the price.

This is a nice fire pit for a small yard or medium sized patio.  It is lightweight enough to be moved around but heavy duty enough to contain a decent fire.  It is easy to assemble.The only drawbacks and the reason it gets 4 stars instead of 5 is that there is no way to clean it other than flipping it over.  There are braces along the bottom which keep the wood or logs from resting flat on the bottom and disrupting airflow, which also keep you from easiliy shoveling out ashes.

This is my second set of Henckels nose and ear hair trimmers.  The first set gets used by someone else in my house, and it seems gross to share, so I got another set.They trim hairs cleanly and easily, without pinching or pulling the hairs. There are cheaper copies, but they DO pull hairs as much as they trim, so I recommend getting a good set instead of a cheap copycat set.  They are easy to use and the blades are protected so you do not cut your nose or ears.  Just squeeze and the blade inside rotates to cut, it is very simple.  There is even a small brush to clean them afterward.Assuming you dont have gigantic thick nose hairs requiring hedge clippers to cut, this is a great set to keep your nose and ears furr free.

This was a small gift for my wife.  I missed the mark as she didnt like the size, they were too big.  Although, I did get credit, because she was able to remove the hooks and replace them with a small chain and turn one of them into a necklace that she LOVES.The detail is good and the quality seems above what would be expected for this price.  The oxidized finish gives a nice contrast and makes them very attractive.

I got this as a "just because" gift for my wife, she loves Celtic knotwork jewelry.  She loved this too.  The chain is long, hangs below the neck but not so low that you feel naughty by looking at it.  It has a slightly antiqued look with the oxidized finish, but it is very attractive.  The detail is nice, the clasp is secure, and the chain is thin and attractive.  If this is your style, or your significant other's, this is a great small gift.

This is a great system for security on a budget.  It does not record anything unless you supply your own memory device.  The motion sensor is a bit loud when it detects, most make a 'click' but this is more a 'thunk'.  The speaker is a blast, great way to torment my kids while they're home alone.  The siren can be turned off, and is loud when activated.The install is simple as long as you have wifi.  Just need a plug where you want the system.  Fun to check on your kids and pets with your phone while away.There are better systems, but none anywhere near this price.

This thing is fun.  A bit fast for a "rock crawler" but is a blast to play with.  Our entire family sits around taking turns using this, I never would have thought it would be a family time type toy.  It will crawl up a wall and flip over, bounce over rocks and shoes, and it will chase a cat around the living room like you wouldnt believe!  (Our cat enjoys the chase)It comes assembled and ready to use.  Remote control is simple and self explanitory, no learning curve.  Battery seems to last a long time too.This is great fun for kids and adults.

This is a nice tortilla press.  It is heavy and solid, seems very well built.  There are MANY recipes for tortillas if you do not have one, but my suggestion is always use HOT water and you will have much better results.  The reason this got 4 stars instead of 5 is that while it is a quality press, it leaves the tortillas thicker than I prefer and we still need to use a rolling pin to get them to the final thickness we prefer (restraunt type thickness).

This is a great inexpensive watch.  My wife works as a nurse and wears it to work.  She loves it, says it cleans up easy, is comfortable, doesnt flop around, and is easy to read.  It is fairly small, not an obvnoxiously huge watch like some of the current trendy watches, just small and comfortable.  The buttons are easy to use, without sticking out and stabbing your wrist when you bend your wrist like some other watches.  The clasp is secure,

Great headset.  Very easy to get working, just sync and play, very easy.  Sound quality is great, even has a bit of protection from outside noises.  They are comfortable and fairly lightweight, plus there are no "sweaty ears" like some other headsets.  This is my first headset from PDP, but they are great and well worth trying out.  If you need a good headset for the Xbox One, this is a great option.

I am a fan of Bose products, and these continue to support that.  The sound quality is excellent, outperforming several other high-end brands I own.  They are comfortable to wear, which is rare for most of the better sounding in-ear headphones.  Many companies rely on a crazy uncomfortable fit to ensure a seal around the ear in order to ensure their sound quality, this set sounds great AND is comfortable.I havent tried too many activities with these, but I have worn them at the gym and run on the treadmill with them and have not had any issues.  They stay in place, dont fill my ears with sweat, and sound great.  No more stopping to push my headphones back in place once I get sweaty, these stay where they are meant to.I believe their performance is due to Bose constantly finding ways to make every detail correct, instead of just focusing on bass, or noice cancelling, Bose does it all.I highly recommend these headphones for anyone in the market for a good set, whether you need 'sport' style or not.

I got this as a "just because" gift for my wife, she loves Celtic Knot jewelry.  She likes it quite a bit, doesnt wear it every day, but it stays in the rotation with some other items.  The cubic zirconia are barely noticable, but that's not really the part she likes anyway.  It is just a simple but attractive bracelet.  It is fairly lightweight and doesnt clank on the wrist like a contstant nuesance, but she says its heavy enough to tell you are wearing it.This is not nice enough to qualify as a special occasion gift unless you are in Junior High, but for a "just because" or "thinking of you", it's perfect.

This is really a lot of fun.  It is much easier to use than some of the other remote helicopters/drones I have tried (all under $200).  The little plastic cage allows it to be run around the house on the floor like a car, or flown around the house without worry of breaking.  My 12 year old picked it up almost instantly and was harrassing the cat with it in no time.  He did have an epic crash which broke a propeller, but thankfully there are extras in the box.This is great fun, affordable, and easy to use.  I recommend it without hesistation.

We have used several carpet cleaner and this is among the best of them.  It is built in a noticably more "heavy duty" fashion than others, the plastic is thicker, the cord is heavy duty, and overall less "rattle" to it.  The performance is excellent, it really cleans and does it quickly.  The ease of filling and emptying the resevours is excellent as well.As with all carpet cleaners, it is loud, louder than a vacuum cleaner.  That said, it is not the worst I have tried, but its definately not something you want to use while someone is trying to nap somewhere in the house.

I will blame the cahange in the feel of the phone with the new case, but I dropped my phone as soon as I put the case on....  OOOPS!  Good news, THE CASE WORKS!  Not my preferred way of evaluating a new phone case, but it definately made an impact (haha).  So, now that I knw the case will protect a phone I will say that it is cool looking too.  It is not slippery to hold, which doesnt help explain me dropping it, but I havent dropped it other than that one time.  It adds some bulk, but not so much it is uncomfortable to hold or akward for me to put the phone in my pocket (any more akward than it normally is).  All of the buttons are easily accessable, not wierd changes to how I hold or use my phone.Overall, it is a great functional and attractive case.  I can recomment it without hesitation.

This is a great set of kitchen shears.  They are one of the best Ive used, and they are a great price!  I like the narrow head on the blades, it allows you to easily access cramped angles, especially when working around chicken joints and similar items.  They are durable and powerful cutting, easily cutting through chicken bones when I dissassembled a chicken this weekend.They are sharp with a slightly serrated blade which seems to grab hold of what you are cutting to keep it from popping away from the cut, holding it firmly in place to cut exactly where you intended.  I plan on getting an extra set to keep in the garage, since I tried them out on a project this weekend and they worked just as well there.  I dont want to have to go back and forth looking for them, and they are afforedable, so Im getting another set.Great shears at a great price.  I highly recommmend.

We go through a lot of charging cables in my house so I get to try many different types.  This is a great one, it solves the main problem I believe is behind worn out cables.... the length.  Why do they all seem to be 3 feet long?  How often is 3' from an outlet conventient?  Do you organize your house so you keep a nightstand or table within 3' of the outlet you want to charge your phone?  That is why I like this cable, 4 feet seems to be a much more logical length.  I can plug my phone in AND still use it without having to stand hunched over (Im 6'2" tall).  I can plug my phone in and not have it teetering on the edge of my nightstand because its thethered 3' to the outlet away.  The extra 25% in legth really makes a difference, Im no longer constantly tugging on my cable accidentally or stretching it to the full length, so the cable lasts longer.I also appreciate the flat cable, they seem to avoid twisting and cracking better then the round cables.  Admittedly a little harder to coil if you need to, but they dont tangle and break as easily.Overall this is a great cable at a good price.  If you need a new one, dont hesistate getting this one.

This is a great case for the Kindle Voyage.  One of the great things about the Voyage is its size, so it is hard to find a case that provides more than visual appeal or one that is too bulky.  This case is perfect for us; it is waterproof and offers realistic protection, without having flaps, stands, and supports all over it making it excessively bulky.All of the buttons and items necessary for normal use easily accessable.  The waterproof feature is the great for my wife, as she always want to read while relaxing in a bath but is too nervous she will drop it and ruin her Kindle, problem solved!Great protection, easy use, and waterproof, all without ruining the size benefit of the Kindle Voyage.  This is a great product for your Kindle.

I original saw this and thought it was another crock pot or slow cooker, then I realized it really is a "Multi Cooker" as it is named.  What is the difference?  My previous slow cookers have all had 2, maybe 3 settings; High and Low, occasionally a setting in the middle.  While 'HIGH' is hot, it is not 450 degrees hot.  That is what makes this Mutli Cooker so nice, it will do everything a slow cooker can do and more.Say you want to cook a pot roast, you can brown it in the  Multi Cooker set on 450, then drop the temperature and add the other ingredients and have a tasty pot roast.  There is no need to brown in other pans and then transfer everything into your slow cooker.  The same goes for casseroles, you can cook them in the cooker at a real temerature like your over, but the the added benefit of not burning the top while the food underneath cooks!The controls are simple, cleanup is easy, it is heavy enough to be sturdy and not slide all over the counter but not so heavy that it is a hassle to move or store.This is great, I am incredibly glad I gave it a try.  I cant imagine using a regular crock pot type slow cooker again.

I have several GOAL ZERO items, and they have all performed better than expected.  This is another excellent GOAL ZERO product.  I already have the other power pack which operates on rechargable AA or AAA batteries.  This one does not use those types of batteries, but the trade off is that this one is able to charge more items before it needs recharged and it has a shut down option which prevents battery drain while not in use.This in not waterproof, it is best described as 'rain proof' in my opinion, as you can let it get damp or wet, but no submerged.  Im not sure how important this is to me, as Im not usually recharging electronics in the rain or while swimming, but it is nice not worry about it being ruined if my pack gets wet while I get caught in the rain.The Power Pack is slightly larger than the palm of my hand, and I have big hands.  It is not pocket sized unless you are wearing cargo pants.It charges quickly, retains charge for a very long time, and it quickly charges my phone and iPad at the same time.  It has 'smart' technology so it automatically determines the proper charge speed for devices so you dont have to select various options to match your device like some other chargers require.Overall, if you want a PowerPack which can recharge multiple items, multiple times, and possibly in an outdoor environment, this is your option.

I have been using these for a couple weeks, and now I can see sounds, translate alien languages, understand what my wife is thinking, and program NASA flight systems!  OK, maybe Im exadurating.  Seriously though, this product is hard to quantify.  I havent starting going senile since I started using it, so I guess thats a good sign.I have been in a better mood the past couple of weeks, might be a coincidence, maybe not.  I have just felt 'better', not weirdly better, but I seem to have come out of a funk I have been in recently.  I honestly couldnt say it was these pills, but I cant discount it.  Maybe it is the vitamin B complex I started taking at the same time? Or the combination?  Whatever the reason, I am going to continue taking these to see if I find a tangible correlation other than "maybe they help."The pills smell a little funny, but are mostly tasteless.  Easy to swallow, dont stick to each other.  I dont know how, why, or if they are helping me, but theyre inexpensive and have some natural items supposed to help with brain health, so I plan on sticking with them a while.

I carry a pocket tool every day at work.  I currently carry the Leatherman Skeletool, it has its limitations, but good.  I have several SOG multi-tools (B66 & B61) and I LOVE them, LOVE them, but they are too big and bulky to carry in a pocket and I dont like using the holster type cases.  Based on my love for the other SOG tools, I was excited for this, and utterly disapointed when I tried it.I clipped it in my pocket for its first day as my new pocket multi-tool, by the time I got to work it felt funny.  I tried to take it out of my pocket, and discovered it open.  After I wedged it out of my pocket, I closed it back up and went about my day.  Every time I sat down, bent, or did anything, it opened, what a massive disapointment.  It didnt take long before my Skeletool was back in my pocket and this one was living in the door handle pocket of my truck.  Now, instead of opening in my pocket it opens every time I hit a bump.  Did they not test this before they sent it out?  Somebody had to know this was a problem, who wants a switchblade action set of pliers popping open every time you sit down?To add to the disapointemet, it seems odd that you have to completely open the tool in order to get the knife or other items out.  Most pocket type multi-tools now come with an easy access knife blade so you dont have to unfold the tool to get to the blade.  Regarding the tools, the ONE good point I found for this was that the tools and knife blade inside the handle are the same top quality that come in the other SOG tools, and appear to also be interchangeable with the tools you can buy from the SOG webpage.Aside from just leaving the plyers open all of the time, defeating the whole purpose of a pocket tool, this seems like a massive failure from SOG.  I am a fan of most SOG items; the SEAL Pop knife is one of the best knife deals you can get, I believe the normal multi-tools by SOG are the best in the market, and their hatchets and hawks are also great quality, but I cant recomend this item to anyone compared to the other tools available and the problems this one has.I gave it 2 stars because while I consider its use as a folding multi-tool to be a failure, the actual tools function flawlessly.  When open, the pliers are fantastic, grip well, and easily provide ample force.  The blade, file, screwdriver bits, and other items are all functional and well designed.  USING the tool is a joy, carrying it is a frustrating disapointment.

This is a brilliant idea, so useful.  I have numerous pry bars I use for woodworking, metal working, and mechanical repairs.  All are great on one or two angles or pressures, but none are universal.  While this one is not all encompassing and render all others obsolete, it is incredibly useful.  From pulling nails, alignging boards, or getting into odd positions to apply presure to move a part, this thing can adjust to the job.The adjustment is easy, and locks into position automatically.  I doubt the indexing joint would pry open a bank door, but it is more than strong enough for anything I have tried so far.  No wiggle, locks up tightly.The overall size and weight is great, just right for most jobs where you dont need crazy leverage but you want more than you get with the claw of a hammer.  I am thrilled I found this and gave it a try.

Let me start with saying I am not an expert knife thrower.  I have knowledge and skill with knives, but typically I do not throw them.  That beign said, these are 3 decent knives.  After watching a few YouTube videos, I can stick them in my backyard fence faily well.  They seem to throw nicely and have a good comfortable balance.As knives, not necessarily throwing knives, but just knives, they are decent.  The heat treat is good enough that they are not brittle, yet hold an edge fairly well.  I would not compare them with $200 knives, but they easily beat most of the cheapo imports sold as "survival knife".I agree with the other reviewers that the sheath/holder is poor.  It is not practical to carry the knives, draw them from, and especially replace them into the nylon holder.  I would suggest it is for storage only, not suitable for use of any sort.The shape is comfortable for use as a regular knife, even without the handle.  Overall, I would easily recommend these to anyone wanting throwing knives or inexpenisive outdoor or survival knives.

This is an excellent set of electronic hearing protection.  I have used this type of hearing protector since the late 1990's when I won a set at a match.  Some sets are capable of directional sound, while others amplify sound evenly across both sides equally, losing all ability to tell direction.  This set still allows you to hear the direction of sound, even amplifying surrounding sounds, while cutting out the sounds at unsafe levels.  When it cuts the sound out, it only cuts the sounds which should be, which allows you to hold a conversation while someone is shooting at the lane next to you at the range.These are as comfortable as I have used, the padding is soft and does not absorb sweat.  They are also lightweight, so you dont get a headache wearing them for long periods.  Overall, I would say these are a great set only surpassed by the very expensive inside the ear versions of the elctronic hearing protectors.

There is a reason Proactiv+ is so popular, their products work and they are worth the money.  This product holds true to the quality and effectiveness the other Proactiv+ products have worked for my family in the past.My wife still gets occasional blemishes, and my teenage daughter is in her prime zit fighting years (dont tell her I said that).  They both love the Proactiv+ Skin Purifying Mask, in fact they like it so much they have already ordered another one.  It is easy to apply, works well to dry out zits and blemishes, and washes off cleanly and easily afterward.  It doesnt leave their skin red and burned looking like some other products.My family swears by Proactiv+ products, and this is another one of their favorites from the line.  It comes highly recommended from us.

A most moving horse and girl story set in New Zealand written by a person who has loved and taken care of horses for many years. I highly recommend this book and the others in the White Cloud Station series. I feel united with the characters in this story. As the author points out: "...our love for horses unites us--no matter what part of the world we live in."You can get much more than this book -- you can become a fan of the WHITE CLOUD STATION CLUB -- free! You become part of the family. I feel that way too. I love the HORSE TRANSLATOR section at the back, explaining the words and phrases used in the world of horses, with special ones for New Zealand "speak."  Keep in mind, though, that about half of this book introduces all the other books in the series. You, like me, can be off on a most adventurous horse journey!

Did you dig the author's name -- Cheryl HOT? Or does it sound like: SURE Y'ALL HOT? Well, yes, I want to be hot and look sexier. I want to lose weight--as so many folks in my upper bracket do. So, what's keeping me from doing all that? Well--according to the author, "Here's the magical step." WHERE?I get a pep talk to begin with--ignore the excuses of older ladies...step up to growth...set the excuses aside...more laughter, beauty, freedom, less stiffness, more energy. This "hot" author asks, "What should you do to win the game?" Take in fewer calories than you burn. Rev up your metabolism. Follow the "Top 7 Healthy Eating Tips." Also, "crush" the top 4 physical and mental problems. Get and stay physically fit.All the hints offered in this book are standard and practical. But this book slants them to older folks and that is good.

At least there wasn't a long copyright-and-disclaimer notice. In fact, there was none. With only about 30 lines of copy, it was much the same as the book's description. Read the description, do a little research, and you'll have 5 ways to earn free Amazon gift cards. Headlined (not much more than that) are:1.  Become an Amazon affiliate.2.  Participate in Amazon promotions.3.  Trade in or swap products you no longer need.4  Work with Paid-to-Sites -- I don't understand that one.5.  Earn Bing rewards.

We begin with THE GLAD GAME with the cute picture of a girl swinging. Her name is Beth, lovable and imaginative. She gets lost in a book for hours! How about that? Not an Ipad or some other electronics, but a real BOOK about Pollyanna. Although Pollyanna was an orphan and living with a grumpy aunt, she still played a glad game. And that's what Beth decides to do too. She starts with being glad for her swing which her grandpa had built. Her gladness spreads, first to her little brother, then her teenage sister, then her friends and family.A neat story with character-building lessons. But then the kids will love the "Just for Fun" activities that follow. Next we have Jack's story of his gladness game. There are five happy GLAD STORIES in this book, with endearing illustrations and activities. All are sure to implant seeds of gladness into children's imagination. I highly recommend this book for preschool and early graders.

First, very important for a children's book is correct grammar and punctuation. The title should be: THE DOG WHO SAVED NOAH'S ARK. The  basic facts should be correct. Noah was told to build an ark for animals AND any people who would enter in. Also, the Bible tells us that Adam named the animals -- so I have to assume that they remained named even to Noah's time.But I guess a storyteller has permission to remold a story to suit his theme. Although we begin with the unicorn, the theme become how the dog helped Noah and continues to help people today. Dogs especially cheer up people with their wet noses -- in this way passing on God's love. The illustrations, a mixture of paintings and photos, add color to the story but not unity. Still, overall this book is a good try and I encourage the author to keep at writing for children.

Now, there's an idea for a little boy's birthday present! A toy dragon -- that actually becomes a real live dragon. And friendly to Tom, the little boy. So colorful and alive are the illustrations -- kudos to the artist too. This is not a verse book, and that is good. I think the straight prose with plenty of dialogue works best as it is, without rhyme. The short sentences have flow and appeal to a kid's inner sense of rhythm. If you're reading this "out of this world" book to little kids, make sure to do it with rhythm -- that will bring the listener along into the story.I had a bit of trouble trying to adjust the print on my Kindle Fire. The font was either too small or, when I tapped it, too large for all the sentences to fit on the screen. Maybe others won't have this problem on their e-readers. Best of all were how colorful and lively the illustrations came through.

A dog with wings right on the first page! Well, why not? This writer-artist team really can appeal to a child's imagination and sense of fun. The simple rhymes involve the young readers too with a guessing game. How about: "A dog that rides a bike,/ A dog that sings a song? A dog that dances salsa/ And a dog that is very -- " Fill in the blank, kids!Reminiscent of Dr. Seuss for liveliness, simplicity and joyful rhymes! I know one silly youngster who enjoyed this book -- ME -- only 73!

Blessed are the bonds that bind bereaved family members together! This author binds me to her heart as she relates the loss of her mother at a young age. My wife and I just lost our daughter -- this book touches those tender points that youthful death brings to us, whoever we lost. It's true, as the author says, "the loneliness never stops. You hold on to what once was, and will never be again." We the bereaved hold on to what remains--memories, mementos, photos, letters, other loved ones. What remains most of all? That soft place within us that is at the same time fully empty and fully filled.This book just tugs at those empty-filled places with its tender memories and expressions of enduring bonds. "True love is not without pain," she says. The poetic sentences come so naturally from the author's deepest self: "Raindrops, like teardrops, are known to fall at will, and pay no attention to desires for a sunny outcome." (page 65).This book is a love story between a young child and her mother that continues even after the mother's death. It's about broken hearts, dreams and loneliness through which comes healing. There is a MASTER PLAN, if we will accept it. I personally want to thank Ms. Brougher, the author, for sharing her grief and recovery with me so I too can follow that journey.

This is just what I want -- the basics for a beginner. Even if that beginner is 74 years old like me! Simple, step-by-step good beginning. After I learn these basics presented in this short book, I'll go on to learn how to be a Rembrandt or a Van Gogh! But now -- pencils and sharpeners, blending tools and erasers, how to hold the pencils, use a grid, how to shade and tone. I also will begin to learn how to draw the head and neck, eyes and nose, mouth and ears, hair and have fun with my pencils and paper ANYWHERE!That's why I like this book and recommend it to beginners of any age -- it works!

YOU ARE THERE! The authors rich writing style reminds me of that  TV program with Walter Cronkite. Its through the authors appeal to my senses and imagination that Im transported into the world of Palmyra in the 3rd century, and into the castle and life of Zenobia, her sisters, mother and father. Even the rhythm of the writing has that feel of ancient Arabia and grips me with its near-poetry.EXAMPLE: This is the season when the winds come from the eastfrom Eran and from Indian and beyond, slow and languid and heavy with the odor of spice. What verbal art! And there is much more of it in this book.BUT -- there is also much conflict among family members and tribes of that time. The greatest conflict, though, is within 17-year-old ZENOBIA, a beautiful woman who desires much more than an ordinary marriage, or a safe and luxurious home, and even more than the rich and exuberant trading capital of Palmyra can give her. Can a woman of her time and place achieve greatness, even become a ruler?  Can she experience love that is of her own choosing and not dictated by her family and traditions?AH!WE HAVE GRIPPING AMBITION AND FAITHFUL ROMANCE. We have stories of the lowly rising to glory, and of the glorious falling to ignominy. We have Zenobia and her lover battling the Roman powers. We have heartbreak and loss. And most of all, we have gods that the heroes believe guide their destinies. And yet, the heroes also fight the whims of those gods with will and strength.About one-third of the way into this book, I began to ask how true to history was this bookso I read some articles on her. SHE WAS NOT FICTION! I was so pleased that she actually lived in Palmyra in the third century, that she rebelled against the government and fought to achieve her destiny. And suffered for it. I was intrigued by the Authors Note on how she created this book by seeking to remain faithful to the historical record and to the feel of the characters. As a writer I learned much. As a reader, I was fully drawn into this story.

Sixty years ago I first got acquainted with Canadian humorist Stephen Leacock through his famous book, Pigs Is Pigs. And now Im once again relishing his wit, humor, satire and insight into life. His world was a hundred years or so. But his style is fresh even today, with just a few changes in names and places.Leacocks style can be deceptive, for he is always a gentleman, well-mannered and cultured, as are most of his characters. Yet his impact is irreverent and satirical glimpses into serious lives. Take novellas such as:**  Winsome Winnie; or, Trial and Temptation**  John and I; or, How I Nearly Lost My Husband**  The Kidnapped Plumber; A Tale of the New Time**  Buggam Grange: A Good Old Ghost StorySo often youre taken around corners you never anticipated and to destinations never on your map. What a fine journey!

A warm telling of dog Cinnamon finding a baby squirrel left alone in the yard. Mrs. Morgan rescues it and takes it to the vet for instructions. In all of these sequences we learn some good pointers about taking care of rescued animals. I'm sure it will inspire readers and listeners to take care of nature a little better. But the book lacks dialogue and story-telling techniques that would suit younger readers and listeners. The illustrations are limited also. So it may not attract younger readers and listeners.

The author, one "Uncle Amon," gives free reign to his imagination and to the lovable Jimmy the Giraffe. Of course, the stories are "what if" Jimmy has human feelings and words. Many young kids will be "trapped" into believing that: "Yes, this could happen!" And they will learn some good lessons in doing so. So we have Jayne the Jaguar, the Monkey King, Elmo the Elephant, and "the Knowledgeable Bookworm."Kids will also enjoy the activities suggested, funny jokes for kids, games and puzzles and a few games and coloring book downloads.A good buy -- and good for parents and kids to read and do together.

From childhood, I have loved dogs and had a number of "big dogs." But if I ever decide to have a small dog, I'd highly consider a Bichon Frise. The adorable pictures and the brief but insightful descriptions have convinced me that a Bichon would be ideal in many ways. They are "so sociable and they enjoy being taken on outings and meeting new people" (loc. 49).The author lightens her descriptions with a few puns and humorous description. She refers to the Bichon frise as "An Old Sea Dog." Why? Most interesting. Also, she shows that some famous painters used this dog in their works. These dogs are also little actors, easy to teach tricks to and get to perform. Yet, for their many centuries of being the household dog of choice overseas (including royal castles and ships), this dog wasn't bred in the USA until 1956. The American Kennel Club recognized it as a breed in 1973.

A simple book, and yet one that will serve me well for a lifetime! It's a categorizing of Solomon's proverbs in different areas, such as adultery, deceit, fear of the Lord, joy, love -- about 70 in all. Of course, I found it takes discipline to read all the proverbs in each category and spend quality time thinking about them. But as Proverbs 5:20-23 encourages: "For lack of discipline they will die, led astray by their own great folly."Overall, this book can serve as a God-inspired study in many areas of my life. I recommend it for study, for reference, and for meditation.

This booklet can serve as a good overview but I recommend more reliable resources to learn the facts about diabetes and dogs. Unfortunately, no resources are listed or quoted in this booklet.Medical people hardly ever refer to "sugar diabetes;" rather, it's diabetes mellitus. As I read this short booklet, I got the impression that the author was gathering facts from just a few sources. Thus there was some repetition and wordiness. Skilled editing could've made the material flow better and be better organized.. For example, such phrases as: "It is a well known fact that..." is a lazy researcher's way of trying to be credible.The author loses my credibility with some statements that my further research proved wrong. The author states: "Scientific studies have shown that diabetes in dogs is only Type 1 or insulin dependent...." But a reputable veterinarian site states: "Type 2 diabetes is the most common form of diabetes in dogs. It is due to the bodys impossibility of metabolizing sugar which remains in the blood and harms other internal organs."I strongly recommended that readers use this booklet as a jumping-off point to research further; the internet is very helpful in this. Amazon also has many more complete and reliable books on this subject.

These quotes go DEEP into my psyche -- feeding my longtime love of horses. The horse is perfect for inspirational thoughts. "SOUL HEALING: Two feet move our body; four feet move our soul." Another category is FRIENDSHIP: To be loved by a horse or any animal, should fill us with awe--for we have not deserved it."CONNECTION... FREEDOM... CONFIDENCE... BEAUTY... MIRROR (my favorite)..."Show me your horse and I will tell you who you are." And MORE. But not enough -- the only downside of this book.

This short book is well-structured and to the point, strengthened with apt Scriptures. First, the author asks us to examine the words coming out of our mouths, for "the tongue can bring death or life" (Proverbs 18:21.) That means that "what you say today can change the course of your life forever." That thought really hit home with me as a writer, speaker and a Christian. Just think: What we speak can produce -- life... hope... peace... blessing... healing... restoration. Or their opposites -- death... discouragement.. war... curses... pain... destruction.How do we "speak" good outcomes? The author gives us pointed and practical guidelines. Guard your mouth -- guard your heart (mind) -- think before you speak -- meditate on God's word before you think! That's workable and powerful advice for me -- and perhaps you will think it's good for you. So I recommend this book. I wish it was a little more developed, but as a beginning on this topic, it's excellent.

I like the simplicity of the interfacenot fancy but easy to navigate and supports the main functions I requireradio, recorded music, personal recording or from the radio, photo viewer, games, e-copy (books, notes, etc.) The sound is rather good for such a compact unit and the headphones are better than most earbuds. If youre using a different set of headphones or earbuds, youll still need to have those provided to listen to the FM radio as it also serves as the antenna.The 8 GB of memory is sufficient for me, although its upgradable to 64GBa 32GB will be more than enough for most users. And the playtime can go for days  up to 80 hours of audio playback, the description says. But I havent tested it for that long. I have to keep in mind that this is a low-priced unit, good for everyday use and by youngsters and folks not into the greatest, latest and bestest gadgets!In recent months Ive tried 3 other units in a little lower price range. I found this one to be easiest to maneuver and set up and has some features the others dont. I look forward to more hours with it, listening to French lessons and music as I take long walks. A neat companion, very light, fits well in a shirt pocket.I received this unit free in exchange for my review. My testing time has been brief. Ive read some of the other reviews, and altogether they add up to a lot of good advice and input. Some very dedicated and knowledgeable electronics reviewers here.

In many ways this is a book that the reader (parent, older siblings, etc.) can really make alive for youngsters. For preschoolers and early graders, some of the words and sentences are too complicated. But don't let that stand in the way of TELLING and SHOWING these stories to youngsters. Just interact with them because the stories and illustrations are very imaginative and character-building.For instance, take the story LETTER IN A BOTTLE. Ask the listeners questions such as: "Foxy brushed the crumbs under the carpet. Was that a good idea? What would you have done if you were Foxy?" "How would you help Foxy understand neatness?" I imagine Foxy is much like a four-or-five-year-old boy or girl. They can't write essays! So apply the story to the maturity of the listeners.The next story, OLIVER MEETING JUMPY, is joyful AND dramatic--love it! Again, it can lend itself to imaginative chit-chat between reader and listener. Ask: "How are friends made? How did you meet your friends?"ENCHANTED FOREST is quite an adventurous and imaginative story too. It also can lend itself to interaction between you as reader and the children as listeners. What are "meerkats?" they'll want to know. How come Oliver happened to have his magic wand with him? Was it fair of him to treat the witch as he did? Some good character lessons here. I'm sure that with the kids you'll enjoy these stories. I did.

An author should be more than a compiler. That's why this book needs at least a little copy to tell us what each photo is about -- the breed of monkey or location or SOMETHING. The dictionary defines "pictorial" as: "illustrated by or containing pictures." So technically this is a "photo book," not a "pictorial." The compiler has a sharp eye for interesting and cute" photos, so I'd suggest she write a few lines for each photo and make it HER book. I mean, just photos of monkeys? I can get hundreds, even thousands, of them on web sites.

This is an parable of an ant who needs to learn a very important lesson in her life, just as many youngsters in today's world need to do. NO SHORTCUTS TO SUCCESS. You have to positively contribute to the good for the entire colony (community).But how does Noira the Ant Thief learn this lesson? The author threads a tricky story here between reward and punishment. Of course, having an ant as the central figure makes it an allegory or parable. Just like in Aesop's Fables, some creatures suffer for their bad behavior, or just because life is sometimes unfair. Should Noira be let off the hook for her thieving behavior? Well -- you will make up your own mind by the end of this intriguing story. Young listeners with the help of the reader can have fun discussing the old story of good versus bad.The artwork is simple and pinpoints the action. So both words and illustrations work well together.

This book begins with a general overview of meditation and then gets into effective but uncomplicated techniques. Is it worth learning to meditate well and to do it consistently? After reading this book and practicing just a few of the techniques for a few weeks, I believe so. The last few months I've personally faced some very stressful events and need to connect more with my inner peace.The author points out that for many people the greatest risk is misunderstanding what day-to-day meditation is all about. Often this wrong concept is of some person withdrawing from life and sitting in a lotus position for hours on end. But regular and effective meditation happens in the moments here and there, as well as the 10 or 15 minutes we set aside to quiet our minds. "True meditation," she points out, "is the place of deep peace ...when the mind is calm and silent, but at the same time completely alert."Meditation, when done right and without pressure, provides me with that peace and calm I need. I recommend this book for that purpose to you too.

Photos of wolves in their natural habitat can be inspiring, speaking to some wild within us. That's what I found when I lived in the wolf country of Yukon Territory, Canada. This book vividly brings back some of those feelings and makes my memories quite alive again. Besides the 26 powerful photos of single wolves, packs and cubs, the short facts about each photo focus on the nature of the wolf. This combination makes it a gripping read and should hold a child's interest.

The author's goal is to educate children in a "fun and interesting way." For that, camels is a great topic as they are fantastic creatures, as the author points out. What's the difference, for instance, between one-humped and two-humped camels? And what's in those humps anyway? Readers will get answers to that question as well as a few dozen others.How long can camels go without water? They can drink up to 200 liters, or about 53 gallons, in 3 minutes! Try that at your water fountain or faucet! And have you ever had a glass of camel's milk? You'll find out why this milk is important to nomadic desert tribes. You'll also discover how the camel's eyelids help their survival in the harsh desert, as do their mouths, feet, noses, ears, hide, and every part of their bodies. Most fantastic.Young and older kids will be drawn to the photos that illustrate the "fantastic facts." The author fulfills his goal well in drawing young readers to a fun adventure in education.

Even though this book is a short read, it is well-structured and covers the essentials of WHY MEDITATION and HOW TO MEDITATE. The author promises that her book will help "you learn how to meditate easily and quickly for integrating regular mediation into your life."  That is as big promise. We know already that learning something new is usually easy to begin but harder to continue and perfect. I'm glad that this book is also motivational in that area.WHAT IS MEDITATION? A place of deep peace in your mind, yet alert. Good to-the-point overall teaching here.DIFFERENT TYPES OF MEDITATION. Focused... mindfulness... effortless presence... Buddhist... Vipassana... Loving Kindness... Mantra... Yoga... Third Eye... and others. Good overview.MEDITATION BENEFITS AND BEST PRACTICES. If you tend to lose your motivation for meditation, just review these benefits; there are many of them. When to meditate? Early morning, before bed, short spaces throughout the day. You'll also be briefly introduced to your chakras and meridians. You don't have to know these specifics but knowing a little about them broadens my appreciation for meditation.

The writing and illustrations capture the feel of the world St. Francis lived in. They are simple but rich in color and subject matter. The author positions this story well, helping youngsters go way back in time, tying modern times to olden times. But to do this well is tricky. For a few pages, we are jarred back and forth between today and "back then." For instance, the author mentions "small pigs in brick houses." That distracts from the flow of the story.But then we get into the story of the lone wolf who ate the village's animals and even a few people. What's the solution? How can St. Francis reconcile wolf and people? Ah, that's the story of a miracle! I believe, as I did, you'll enjoy discovering that wondrous event.

This author has done an excellent work in demonstrating that introverts have as much, or more, power than extroverts. He tells the stories of 12 world leaders spanning 2600 years and a diverse mix of countries and religions. Another neat technique he uses is disguising the names of his subjects until the end. This keeps you guessing, or if you've guessed early, then you want to see if you're right.I'd be giving away some of the suspense if I told you the names of these renowned individuals. Several are great military leaders; some statesmen and revolutionaries; some are religious figures who eventually attracted millions to their way of spirituality. And one is a college student who saw a need to meet the needs of foreign college students and acted on it.So, yes, he shows that introverts can be great leaders and reformers. As we see this demonstrated in their lives, we also learn principles by which we can do greater things for others. Introverts have imaginations and visions. They begin with small steps that grow into giant leaps, sometimes in their own lifetime, often over the centuries. So if you're shy, reserved, an introvert, you have much within you that can impact the world around you--and beyond--with a better life.This book is written quite well, considering that the author's native language is not English. But he has been schooled in British schools, at least in college. And he is a talented self-learner. So overlook a few mistakes he might make in the English language; grasp the bigness of what he is doing. I PREDICT that this young author will become renowned throughout the world. His previous books already are read in many countries, thanks to Amazon.

Without it being obvious, this book conveys a lesson so important for children of all ages, as well as older folks. It's done through the actions of a cute cat who thinks herself as most beautiful. She wanders about her neighborhood looking for a friend to play with. She doesn't want just any friend but one who is also as beautiful as she thinks she is. The author's rhythmic lines fit each encounter Kitty has with other animals, and their reactions to her snotty attitude. The illustrator does a masterful job in matching those lines. So we have a wonderful combination of words and colors to make this story roll along.In the second half of this book we see how Kitty pays for her snobby manner. Kids will see this lesson clearly for themselves. I wish, though, that the author had shown the action that Kitty could've taken to redeem herself. Perhaps that would've been by losing that fancy ribbon, roughing up her groomed fur, and mixing in with all the others. Still, the author had a particular goal in mind and she accomplished it very well.

Judaism has brought to us many stories and sayings that illustrate the depth and meaning of life. This author, Anat Umansky so well-versed and revered for her books in Hebrew, now brings us a story by Baal Shem Tov, the Rabbi who founded Jewish Hasidism. But the author relates it for us today, in her unique and warm way. And she also illustrates this and other stories with simple and colorful artwork. That's why this book is a double-winner!"Why did the leaf fall?" the little boy wonders as he picks it up. Whose fault was it--leaf itself, branch, tree, wind? We see that the ultimate reason--the reason for so many happenings in the world--is God and his kindness for all creatures.

EDGAR DEGAS (1834 to 1917) was a famous French artist  paintings, sculptures, prints and drawings. More than half of his works features dancing and dancers. Critics labeled him as Impressionist but he preferred Realist.Degas was obsessed with painting early in his life. In his high school and college years, he had turned a room in his house into a studio. His art teacher gave him this advice: Draw lines, young man, and still more lines, both from life and from memory, and you will become a good artist. Do you think thats good advice? Why or why not?Look at his self-portrait #1. What can you tell about him? What did Degas want others to see? Painting #3 we have a dance class. How does it resemble todays dance studios? Whats different? Besides dancing, what other subjects did Degas love to paint? Look closely at paintings in a category, such as portraits of people and people in common pursuits. How well do you think Degas captured the soul of these people?To observe paintings and think about the whys and hows of the artist makes them more meaningful.

Rembrandt (July 1606  Odtober 1669)How would you like a name like Harmenszoon Van Rijn Rembrandt? No wonder he is almost always referred to as plain REMBRANDT! But in the Netherlands long names were common. He grew up in a large household, being the ninth child in a well-to-do family. I wonder how that would influence his art? Thats a subject that children can considerhow does ones family encourage or discourage art?Religion was another fervent influence in the family. His mother was a Roman Catholic and his father of Dutch Reformed faith. Thus Rembrandts works reveals his deep Christian faith. Rembrandt painted many portraits of people in his land, including self-portraits. He portrayed his subjects realistically, no vanity or disguising faults.Depending on your young observers, you might have them react to the first painting, a self-portrait. Would you like this fellow for a father or grandfather? Do you think hes a pleasant man? Spend a minute or so on all the portraits in this collection and see the similarities or differences.How does Painting #4 strike you, The Storm on the Sea of Galilee? Is it a frightening scene? Who is in the boat? What other paintings have their inspiration in the Bible stories? Then we have the mythology paintings  such as The Abduction of Europa." Does this look real to you? Why or why not? Since this artist painted much of common life of the time, what can you learn about that time and people?As usual in this series of books, you have to consult other sources for information about the artist and his paintings. It's worth the research.

The question is not whether I agree or disagree with this doctrinal position but whether the authors make a solid biblical case for their stand. I think they do explain some scriptures clearly on what the Bible teaches about the "secret rapture." It's worth considering their case from both sides of the issue.This booklet is a transcript of a radio talk, including the 2 or 3 commercials for follow-up material. I think those should've been edited out. In fact, I would have appreciated this being more of a book(let) rather than a radio talk.Still, worth the consideration.

JACKSON POLLOCK (1912-1956) was an influential American painter with his ABSTRACT IMPRESSIONIST style. Heres an intriguing question for young and old: What is drip painting? Thats what Pollock used.Children relate to the childhood of famous people, such as these artists. For instance, young Jackson was expelled at age 16 from several high schools. Then at age 18 he and his older brother Charles moved to New York City and studied at the Art Students League. So you see a determined but independent young fellow here. Do young people need to be rebellious in order to be artists? Theres a question for your young students to consider.ABSTRACT ARThow can young art students learn to understand it? Let them view each painting until they get some meaning or feeling to express. Take Autumn Rhythm, for instance. Are autumn and rhythm expressed here? How? How do the colors make you feel in Convergence? Spend enough time with all 24 paintings in this book and talk about colors, patterns, moods, any discernible subject matter such as in Blue. How do the artists titles for each painting express the feeling or meaning?Wouldnt it be quite an experience FOR the youngsters, and even us teachers, to try some of this DRIP PAINTING? Quite an exciting on-hands experience to get inside artist Pollock!

PAUL CEZANNE (1839-1906) was a French POST-IMPRESSIONIST painter. His work led to the transition from 19th century style into a radically different 20th century art world. He set the stage for the CUBISM of Matisse and Picasso; both credit him as the father of us all.Since these art collections are chosen for kids, it would be inspiring if we got a hint of famous artists as children. For instance, at age 10 Paul entered College Bourbon and made friends with Emile Zola and Baptistin Bailleall three were friends for life ever after. Ask kids: Do you have friends for life? In 1857 Paul began at the Free Municipal School of Drawing in Aix. His father was not in favor of this as he wanted his son to be a lawyer. So Paul attended law school but continued drawing.I think it would help childrens imagination to think about Cezannes paintings as they do not reflect visual reality as much as feeling realityimpressionism. A good exercise for all is to look closely at objects, people or other sights and freely connect to the inner being of those. This is what artists try to do. For instance, Still Life with a Curtain shows what appears to be scattering of cloths, pitcher and fruit. Why did the artist not arrange these objects more harmoniously? Then nature scenes such as Jas de Bouffan and Mont Sainte-Victoire seem soft on details but convey a sense of peace. Or do they? Something for art lovers to consider.The portraits of people are bodily disproportionate, such as The Card Player and Madame Cezanne in a red dress." They have rather long bodies compared to their heads. Others like these also seem unrealistic or unflattering. Id talk with children about what was the artists purpose in this? How does it make you feel to see people like this? Compare and contrast paintings in groupsnature, people, still life. That should draw out some creative thoughts.

This is a painter most appealing to children because of her subject matter  emphasis on the life between mothers and children. She has been classed among the impressionists but her style is very accessible to us because it is also realistic.For instance, The Boating Party captures a mother in a boat being oared by the father. The mother holds her baby. The colors and details are subdued. I suggest letting children look at this painting quietly for a minute or two, and then give their impressions.A number of the selected paintings are of women, some beautiful, some ordinary, in everyday settings. For these Id let children gaze on a painting and then give their impressions  remember, these are impressionistic paintings. Then, after they respond to separate works, have them react to all of them as one. Then they could do the same with the paintings of children  at the beach, girl with a straw hat, little girl with her nanny, girl with pink sash, breakfast in bed, Sara holding a cat.The best learning experience would be for the children to be the painter, Mary Cassatt and draw, water color or paint in her style for a bit. Encourage them to get their impressions into their works, not so much what they see but what they feel.These series of books are mere collections of these various artists. In many cases children will benefit from talking about them with knowledgeable teachers and readers. You can, of course, get vast information on all of these artists on the internet or other books. I recommend that.

When I see those self-portraits of Henry Rousseau, I think it would inspire some youngsters to do the same for themselves. Theyll see impressionism  and they can be instructed to paint impressions rather than try to draw and paint exactly what they see. Thats a great step forward for young artists  older ones too. .This book, like others in the series, is best gazed upon and talked about with those who know a bit about the artist and his/her style. Thats why I wish the compiler of these books wouldve told us a bit more about the artists, their childhood, how they got into art, and how they painted. Thus, these books could be more entertaining and inspirational.Take that Boy on the Rocks. Why is this painting more artistic than what a 10-year-old would paint? A question like that would free up a kids imagination and perhaps make him less critical of himself as an artist. The Sleepy Gypsy could be used for a story  why, where, who, when, what. See details even in what looks like a simple painting. The Mill is also good for that, and for showing simplicity of lines and colors. The Football Players may make the kids laugh  and see.Rousseau said he had no teacher other than nature. Theres a fact from his life that would free us to see how that iinfluenced his art, and how we can learn without formal teachers. We as teachers of young children can make these little collections WORK with a little help from the internet or other books that tell us more about the artists and their lives.

For understanding the basic principles of Buddhism in a short time, this book fits the bill. But it is too short for any kind of in-depth experience. We have a brief history of the growth of Buddhism in the 11th Century CE (AD) in Tibet, a country where Buddhist became very central and remains such today."The greatest wisdom is seeing through appearances," and "the greatest meditation is a mind that lets go." (Loc. 73). To get there, you need to understand the "Four Noble Truths," the distilled essence of Buddhism. This book clearly outlines these. It also deals with handling suffering, reducing attachment, and following THE EIGHT-FOLD PATH.This book helped me better understand the teachings and power of Buddhism. I'm challenged to follow the eight paths -- RIGHT view ... intention ...  speech ... action .. livelihood ... effort .. mindfulness ... concentration. Then it gives me a brief introduction to the central activity to do this: MEDITATION PRACTICE. Although a brief introduction to Buddhism, I found it clear and motivational.

WHY ME, GOD? Ive searched for that answer more so than ever recently, with the loss of a loved one in our family. I didnt think a book would ease the personal grief. And this book didnt do that directly. But it helped me understand.This book begins with a story told by Steve who suffered a great loss, the early death of his wife due to murder. How did he avoid becoming bitter? How did he depend on God to see him through? It does take faith to trust God, Steve said, even when you cant explain your struggles.God does hear you. But what do you do when it seems as if God doesnt hear? St. Pauls experience helps in our hearing Gods will in our lives. Why suffering  where did it come from? We can be assured of this, as this booklet points out: Jesus Christ is the way through our suffering. He personally understands our pain and grief.This booklet is offered free by the United Church of God. They offer more free resources  personal counsel, a magazine, printed aids. I'm thankful for this church.

The author gives us a brief history of an early church reformer, John Hus of Bohemia. But this book is not only about him -- it is about Christians at the end of the 1300s and early 1400s, trying to cope with a tumultuous world, made more so by the Catholic papacy. Or, more correctly, "papacies": at times there were more than one, up to three at one time.John Hus was such a young man when he completed his university studies and became involved in University life, first as a student and then as a professor. He was born in 1373 -- became a priest in 1400, and Rector of the Prag University in 1402. A powerful preacher, a follower of Wiclif (Wycliffe), and a staunch teacher and writer of the true Gospel.Pope John XXIII condemned Hus as a heretic and had him imprisoned. In spite of dozens of pleas made to him, Hus would not recant. He said: "I stand before the judgment of God; He will judge me and you in righteousness, as we deserve it." (Loc. 275). This is just one of a few dozens quotes this book gives us. I found all personally inspiring. These chosen quotes make this book worthy in my collection.I found some lack of clarity in a few sentences, not knowing whom the author was referring to. After all, there were many "actors" and it's tricky to keep them straight. But as a whole this short book is a good read for history of Hus' time and for inspiration in the Christian faith.

The quote by Nobel prize winner  in physics, Eugene Wigner, explains the world that the author invents. The very study of the external world led to the conclusion that the content of the consciousness is an ultimate reality. Other quotes upfront hint at the authors purpose. She takes on the challenges offered: to make real through her characters the nature of the human self, and perhaps understand "the flow of time, or incontrovertible evidence that it is indeed an illusion.In short, although this novel at times is entertaining, it is not meant for easy reading. It is not a genre novel, neither a sci-fi or a murder mystery. THERE IS MORE METAPHYSICS THAN SCIENCE -- more a muddle than a murder mystery. Sci-fi needs science as its basis but the invented world here is DYSTOPIC UTOPIAN. A murder mystery needs characters you can love and hate and events that in the end tie the plot all together. That doesn't happen.At first my senses of imagination and beauty were pleased. People passed over the hidden river, each on his or her way, while down there, the river roared and raged in the darkness. But about one-quarter of the way into the novel, my senses got tired out and bogged down. The beauty did not continue.Yet, I was intrigued by the duality of the main character, Rhein, who recognizes he has another personality. Rhein struggles to maintain his sanity and reclusiveness. He knows he is also "The Artist" but cant quite seem to connect with him or his art. In fact, the main motif throughout the book is Rhein and his "friends" struggle to get a glimpse of the Artist's 31 paintings that are covered up. This is somewhat like Godot who never shows up in Samuel Becketts WAITING FOR GODOT.In fact, I found nihilism to be the dominant underpinning for the plot, setting and all characters. The only meaning in life is to retreat from it, to find meaning by assuming some meaning, and to try to solve problems without solutions.Some reviewers give the author too much credit by holding that she explores quantum physics through her novels. This theory also lets the readers invent alternate storylines. Thats why some reviewers like the book and many dontthey had to interpret what was really happening in a world where nothing was real. Or where the only reality was in Rheins unbalanced mind, or perhaps his doubly-balanced mind. The long segment about his entering the cave and tunnel along with other characters paints a stark picture of this duality. At times Rhein finds pleasure in the exploration, at times he hates it and it threatens his life. At times he has to crawl through narrow passages on his hands and knees, and at other times he can stand up straight. Then there are the murders -- but are there? The characters reappear even though they were killed.I give much credit to the author for her skill in handling very tricky transitions and episodes. Chapter 65 switches to present tense as Rhein faces a final challenge. But it is perhaps reincarnation time! The epilogue hints at that: We travel endlessly down our winding paths through time, and they are always before us: our possible versions. I enjoyed the poetic sentiments here, and that last sentence was a WOW. Id suggest you read this epilogue first as it really anchors the story, as much as nihilism combined with quantum metaphysics can do.My review rating on this book may not be yours. Remember, the storyline for you can be different than for me and others.

Through the poet's eyes and the artist's brushes, you can feel the sights and sounds of the ocean. A very good blend between the two. It's a relief to read the occasional poetry book that has pure descriptive verse rather than some obtuse meanings. Yet, you can spend meditative time with some of these verses and paintings, just relaxing, reflecting, enjoying the simplicity of the words, the pastel portrayal of "the dreams of the turtle king," pelicans, sea gulls, and even those connected to the footprints in the sand.A few word images are striking, or confusing. "A man, staggering,/ pushes a shopping cart/ with a woman upside-down,/ laughing, inside." I can't quite picture that BELIEVABLY! How can a woman be "upside-down" in a shopping cart? Well, just trying to imagine that got be a laugh and a moment of joy.In free verse, sometimes we wonder WHY the poets break lines where they do. Of course, between phrases is understandable. But there has to be more reason than just "it's time to." For instance, we have these two lines: "The seashells cover the/ beach this morning." Why break between "the" and "beach"?Overall, I had a relaxing and enjoyable time with this book of quiet poems and meditative artwork. Both poet and illustration did a very good job.

I am inspired by the author's story of how this story came to be, and how he developed into a faith-based writer. That helped me to FEEL as if he is personally telling me this story. My father was a farmer too, so I can closely relate. But I think giving the year of the story as well as the month would've helped pinpoint the setting better. Also, a little less of the involved descriptive phrases would've made it flow better: "The sun gouged the unclouded sky like the tip of a colossal white sword, wielded by the master of Hades himself..." And how old was "I," the boy storyteller? Need such details upfront.Yet, even though the adjectival phrases are too much at the beginning, I can FEEL the heat and drought and hard work. I can sense the drama in the field as the pair plowed. Then -- the pain of the father's strength disappearing and the son watching. Soon the son has to take over more and assume more responsibilities. Here's a lesson of dedication and courage for all.Then the lesson of a gift of a pocket watch -- so touching and tender. And finally, the Christmas gift that will last forever for both son and his father. This is a short but emotion-filled read, well done and reserved.

Im just another parent-grandparent joining many others in recommending this most helpful book. Its won awards from Moms Choice Gold Award for excellence, Teachers Choice Award, and the IPPY Gold Award (Independent Publisher Book Awards).But why do I recommend it personally? (1) The author has the background for this communications and success stuff and shares it concisely and clearly. (2) Knowing how to communicate and present yourself to friends, classmates, business leaders, etc., is the BIGGEST SKILL anyone, youth or adult, can develop. (3) Social and communication skills have become sadly-lacking for the present and the previous generation, ever since the rise of electronic media and ever-present entertainment.THE SOCIAL SKILLS -- from simple but powerful actions such as smiling, asking questions, displays of gratitude, self-confidence and gaining knowledge.THE BUSINESS SKILLS  from hunting for a job, preparing for an interview, to the interview and follow-up.ENTREPRENEUR SKILLS  starting your own business, volunteering, applying to college, selling skills, customer and client service, standing out from the crowd, becoming a leader.The book says for teens. Well, Im about 55 years past that group  but I benefited greatly and know younger and older folks than I am will too. This seems like a simple book, well-outlined and developed, but its really a step-by-step manual that can direct motivated people of all ages for life!

I wish more of life would award us hot-air balloon rides for good deeds! That's the premise of this cutely illustrated children's books, for about ages 3 to 8. But who decides which deeds are worth a high ride? The "Voice" decides after interviewing each creature. And he's rather arbitrary -- deciding which actions were active good deeds and which were passive, achieved by NOT doing bad deeds. But for young listeners/readers, this distinction might be lost on them. They will wonder WHY "the Voice" makes such selections, not letting certain creatures in even though what they did sounded good.The font is boring -- needs to better match the vibrancy of the illustrations and story. But the story is good, and with an adult reader's help, can make children think about good deeds.

Even after almost two years promoting my e-books on Amazon, I realize I have a lot still to learn. And this book helps. But first, if you're new to this business, then this book gives a simple introduction to the process.Why do you want to publish on Amazon? The book gives brief reasons -- largest bookseller in the world, compatible with many different e-readers, and quick turnaround, both for publishing (12-24 hours) and delivery (immediate). Payment of your royalties, though, could take a month or so. And generally, the more high-rating reviews you have, the more attention you attract. So how do you do that?SEVERAL METHODS. All require some consistent work and long hours. You need to become knowledgeable about Amazon's Reviewers' site -- over 30,000,000 "reviewers" listed and ranked--the highest number have the least reviews and "likes," the lowest numbers have the most reviews and "likes." Actually most of the the reviewers, I'm concluding, in the 100,000+ ranking are not serious and submit few reviewers. So how do you zero in on getting reviews from the serious reviewers, those in the 10,000 and below ranking?The author gives clear and simple instructions how to contact reviewers. But there is a second method which might work better for a publisher--narrowing your niche by key words. The author also gives you two different templates to use -- that's neat. I recommend this book as a good guide in starting your own review process. All the techniques will work but be patient -- and offer the best book you can produce in your category! No shortcuts there.
