In my case, it was the combination of the "CA: P&S" book, the tarot card reading friend, meeting another friend who has similar "powers" as the tarot card reading one, a strong willingness to find out who I was and how to improve myself, a major turmoil in my life, and coming across all the different people I could apply the new knowledge to and share with. All these combined contributed to me becoming who I am today, and I have Suzanne White much to thank for that. My life became better indirectly as a result of her writings.The reason I am giving the review 4 stars and not 5, is that although the book has interesting and entertaining predictions, I cannot at this time endorse their accuracy until the year is actually over. Once 2016 has passed, I will then be able to give a more accurate rating at that time -- perhaps a 5, or even a 3. With that said, with Suzanne White's track record, I am certain that the book will be quite a valuable resource, and I look forward to seeing how the year plays out. Use this book not as a "bible" or rule book, but as a GUIDE to HELP you with your choices.On a personal note, I am not looking forward to some of the things Suzanne mentions may be bad for me this year, but what I have learned over the years: things DO happen for a reason. You only get stronger and better from each experience, especially if you look at life at a more positive angle, no matter how bad things get.

I purchased a Panda coin bank for my wife because she loves Pandas. I found prices online varying from $7 - $30, and that big discrepancy in range gave me cause for concern. Upon reading Amazon reviews and researching other websites, it appears that there are many third party copycats of Shine Itazura, the makers of this product. Apparently, Shine Itazura does not sell these outside of Japan. I wanted to buy a genuine, quality-made product of the panda box just as it is pictured here on Amazon with the biscuits and Japanese wording. I also wanted the product to say "Ni hao" ("Hello" in Mandarin Chinese, just like the original.)Apparently, Hamee is a Japan-based, authorized reseller of the Shine Itazura product, and sure enough, they also charge one of the higher prices on Amazon ($20) compared to the other vendors that sell for half that and ship from China. I have nothing against Chinese-made products, but I'd assume that if the product ships from Japan, it most likely is the genuine one.I sent an email to Hamee after placing the order through Amazon and asked them to ensure they'd ship me the Panda just as it's pictured, and that it would say "Ni hao". They assured me that they are.A few days after the order was placed, I received the item in USPS packaging. The panda coin box was inside a clear, sealed retail box. You can see the panda (peek through the brown box) through the clear box as pictured here on Amazon.There was no instruction manual included, and no AA batteries. I unscrewed the battery compartment, inserted 2 AA batteries, and switched it On. I proceeded to place a coin onto the bamboo-adorned, white placeholder at the top of the coin box. Nothing happened. I slightly pushed it to add some pressure, and suddenly, "Ni hao", and the panda came out to steal the coin. The box then closed and the panda said, "Bye bye". My wife, her mom, and my cousin all immediately fell in love. Indeed, it is a very cute product.In regards to some reviewers and commenters being fine purchasing knock-offs of the Shine Itazura for the lower prices -- their argument is that this is a toy and that the cheaper price is fine for them. However, I have read a lot of reviews where they received either the wrong product, one that broke quickly, or one that made the wrong sounds, such as "Meow" (cat sound). Since when does a Panda make meow sounds? Regardless, I agree that as a toy, the cost probably should not matter much, and it definitely would not matter to young children. As long as a panda steals the coin, that's all the entertainment the kids need.For those of you who want a genuine product to give to your older friends and family, I do suggest spending a bit more and get the real thing. That way, you'll be assured that you'll receive the right product.

Easy to install and quite bright. During the summer months (July), the lights last all the way into the morning (at 6am, they were still lit!) During winter months (January), they only lasted until about 10pm to midnight.

Great game with a nice variety of environments and humor. The final location got extremely tedious moving up the tower 12 levels, each level looking exactly the same -- just with different monsters. Save the game before the final battle so you can see the different endings.

ND filters (Neutral Density), in essence, lower the amount of light that reaches the lens, making the environment appear darker than it is. This allows you to use slower shutter speeds in brighter areas/day time. What does this mean? ND filters help you take silky-smooth ocean wave photos at the beach during a bright, sunny day (which would normally only be possible during dusk/dawn/night time.) Note: unlike GRADUATED ND filters, ND filters (such as this B+W one) darkens the entire scene. Graduated ND filters only darken a portion of the scene (which enables you to balance a bright sky with the ground, for example.)I purchased this item for use with the Canon 24-70mm f/2.8L II lens. Since I own the B+W 82mm XS-Pro Nano UV filter (which is very thin, and as a result, has a very small amount of front threading to attach other accessories/filters), I practically have to stick to the XS-Pro Nano line for all other filters. Case in point: I purchased the B+W F-PRO series Circular Polarizer, and it did not mount onto the UV filter. Getting the B+W XS-Pro Nano version of the CirPol did.The B+W XS-Pro Nano ND Vario filter threaded fine on both the B+W Nano UV and Polarizer filters. I was also concerned about vignetting caused by stacking the Nano UV + Nano Polarizer + Nano ND filters, but thankfully, vignetting was very, very limited at 24mm. There was no vignetting with just the Nano UV + Nano ND filters on.The filter itself is solidly built (like most other B+W filters).The ND Vario filter switched from the various Stops (strength of ND filtering) smoothly and with ease. The ability to change the ND filtering intensity was the biggest selling point.The only issue I found with the filter is that I'm unable to mount the lens hood with it already on (the filter is larger in diameter than the hood opening). I also tried mounting the lens hood first, then threading on the filter, but that was challenging, and even more difficult trying to unmount the filter (since the hood was blocking any ability to grip the filter with your bare fingers.) In other words, don't expect to be able to securely use the hood while the filter is mounted.Pictures came out crystal clear, and though I am fretting over the $300+ purchase price, it was money well spent. I look forward to taking it with me on my upcoming Patagonia trip where I plan on taking slow-shutter photos of ocean waves crashing against the Perito Moreno Glacier walls.

This is by far my favorite hot sauce that I use as one of my secret ingredients to my spicy, home-made beef jerky. It adds heat without changing the taste or flavor of my jerky. It has a slow burn, and many who have tried my jerky initially thought it wasn't spicy at all... until the slow burn creeps in and they are wowed by the extra KICK.Most of my friends and family cannot handle more than 2 drops in their soup bowl -- it's THAT spicy!The only complaint I have is that the eye dropper plastic actually DISINTEGRATED on me the first time I purchased it. I'm not sure how or why, but my best guess is that the sauce ate through the eye dropper when I transported it to and from work on a daily basis. I have since separated the content into smaller glass bottles so that I can leave one at home and one at work. Also, do not leave the item in the refrigerator. Doing so may have contributed to the disintegration of the eye dropper.This second time around, I'm storing the product in a dark, cool pantry.

After owning a heavy-duty, expensive, but very sturdy Manfrotto tripod, I was looking for a lighter, solidly-built solution to take on my travels. I backpack in the wilderness a lot and have an upcoming trip to the windy, icy Patagonia in South America, the southernmost land on our planet. As such, a light, sturdy, affordable solution was sought. I own a Canon 5D Mark III, a SpeedLite 600EX-RT, and the heaviest lens I have is the 70-200mm f/2.8L II. The tripod would need to be able to support all that weight for when I go on a professional shoot, yet be portable for airport carry-on and strapping to my backpack.MeFoto was a brand I had never heard of, but after extensive research, it appeared to be one heck of a strong, versatile, compact, and VERY affordable tripod manufacturer -- and cherry on top: a wide selection of colors. My choices ultimately came down to the MeFoto Roadtrip and the Backpacker. I ultimately chose the Roadtrip, and in this review, I will share with you what my thought process was, and why I ultimately selected it.PROS- Lightweight for tripods of its class- Compact- Beautiful colors- Looks very professional- Converts to Monopod without any tools- Compatible with any Arca-Swiss style quick-release plate- Can be deployed quickly- Fairly inexpensive when compared to other high-quality tripods- Very durable and well-built- Manual is easy to understand- Includes metal spikes for use on slipper surfaces- Carry case included and professional-looking. Zippered pouch on the inside- Ballhead is very smooth and makes for excellent, 360-degree panning- Ballhead locks into position, allowing camera to be positioned at any angle- Center column can be reversed for macro photography- Retractable hook at bottom of center column helps with stability- Separate Drag and pan controls- Deploys quickly for vertical (portrait) shooting- Accommodates up to 17.6 lbs of camera gear- Rubberized legs are solid and can be replaced (cheaper tripods tend to fail in this area)- Extendable up to 61.6" in height, and folds to 15.4"- Legs can be taken apart for cleaning- 5 year warrantyCONS- A bit heavier than I would have liked for wilderness backpacking, but that's what the MeFoto Backpacker is for- Carry bag adds an additional 1/2 lb to the 3.6 lb tripod (Description does not mention this)- Leg angles only come in 2 positions- Legs do not lock in the travel/fold-up position, making carrying it by one leg impossibleWHY I CHOSE THE ROADTRIPBoth models fold very compact and can extend to quite a long height. The Backpacker is the lighter of the two, is more compact, but does not extend in height as much. It also does not feature the option to convert to a Monopod (which is useful for quickly stabilizing your gear without all the extra weight of a tripod), nor does it have a Drag option (which controls how smoothly the ballhead can move, depending on the weight of the camera gear.) I chose the Roadtrip because it can extend higher, can hold up to 17.6 lbs (vs roughly 9 lbs), and comes in the very cool and unique red/blue/white-colored Commemorative Edition.To give you an idea, the Canon 5D plus 24-70mm f/2.8L lens is roughly 5-6 lbs. While this would work very well with the Backpacker, I was concerned that a strong gust (like Patagonia's 70+ mph winds) could tip my gear over, although you could further stabilize the tripod by adding weight to the built-in, retractable hook found at the bottom of the reversible center pole. The slightly extra weight of the Roadtrip would add additional stability and be able to carry 17.6 lbs of equipment, making it more versatile for non-wilderness uses such as wedding photography, though mind you, weddings can sometimes be wilderness in their own right :) The Roadtrip, in other words, would allow me to mount a 400mm Canon lens, should I ever go that route, whereas the Backpacker would not be recommended for such scenario.The extra weight of the Roadtrip was a very big concern for my wilderness adventures, however, where I tend to carry 75+ lbs on my back for 5+ days. The Carbon Fiber version of the Roadtrip would shave off an additional 1/2 lbs, but I did not want to pay the extra premium for that little weight saving. If money was no concern, I'd have certainly chosen the Carbon Fiber one.IMPRESSIONS OF THE ROADTRIPThe tripod can be neatly and quickly folded into a compact 15.4". There are other tripods that provide the same folding mechanism, but based on my research, the quality of those manufacturers are not as good as MeFoto's. The product contains a carry bag, metal spikes (so that it can be used on slippery surfaces, such as Patagonia's ice glaciers), and a hex tool (for tightening/loosening the leg anchors and quick release plate) as accessories. The latter two and manual are found in the inside, zippered pouch of the carry bag.The red/white/blue accent colors look just as nice as shown in the product pictures, and the colors make it look unique enough that other photographers should not mistaken mine with theirs.When the tripod arrived, it felt quite heavy. It actually took me by surprise. As it turns out, the tripod indeed is 3.6 lbs, but the included leg spikes and carry bag make it roughly 4.1 lbs as a package. Keep that in mind if you plan on taking it with you on your wilderness adventures. I'd most likely leave the carry bag at home, and cover the ballhead with a small stuff sack to protect it against dust while hiking.I had never used twist-type leg locks before, though I do have them for my hiking poles. My initial impression is that the twist lock makes for a very rapid deployment, crucial for when I backpack with friends and they don't want to wait too long for me to take my long-shutter shots.The center pole can be extended and also reversed by first unscrewing the bottom, retractable hook. This makes it possible to mount the camera upside down for macro photography. The ability to remove the center pole also allows you to pair it with one of the legs (marked with unlock/lock symbol at the angle anchor) to make it a Monopod. Very cool! The hook allows one to hang additional weight (such as your camera bag) for increased stability.The ballhead is removable (for future upgrades), and the quick release plate is compatible with any Arca-Swiss style accessory, making it possible to attach other types of accessories. I was very impressed by the three, separate knobs that allowed me to control the 360-degree panning (great for panoramic shots) and head separately. The ballhead moved surprisingly smooth and with precision, and can be securely locked into place by the knobs. This allowed the camera to be positioned at any angle, something I could previously not do with the cheap, lightweight tripods I used to carry with me. In fact, without the solid build and lock, I was always extremely afraid of shooting my camera vertically! A little bump or gust, and there goes the camera flying to the ground! With the RoadTrip, I no longer have that fear.The angle markers below the ballhead help make more precise adjustments. I also like that the camera can quickly be switched into a vertical shooting position by moving the head into the groove. The integrated bubble level allows for even pans and head movements.One of the legs has a foam grip, making the tripod more easily maneuverable. Likewise, the two-angle positions allow the tripod to stand firmly in a specific position, or to where all three legs can be horizontal, lowering the camera to a 15.4" height. The legs can easily be taken apart for quick cleaning of sand and other debris.My biggest gripe with the tripod, however, is that the legs cannot be locked when they are in the travel/fold-up position. This makes carrying it by one leg impossible. I resolved this by attaching a velcro loop around one of the legs, and using that to secure all three. This then allows me to hook up the Roadtrip to the side of my backpack.Although the Roadtrip was made in China (indicated by a sticker on mine), it is solidly made, and comes with a FIVE-year warranty, indicating that the manufacturer has very strong support behind its product. It is fairly lightweight and very compact for a tripod of this caliber, and I have absolutely no reservation recommending it to anyone.

I am an IT professional who deals with technology every day, and is very much into gadgets. Over the years, I have played with the HP TouchPad, Google Nexus 7, Samsung Galaxy Tab, Asus Transformer, iPad, Surface, and Surface 2. I now own the Surface Pro 3. Yes, I have used a lot of tablets -- Apple iOS, Google Android, and Microsoft Windows 8. I'd like to preface that among all products, the Surface Pro 3 is my favorite for its versatility: tablet for play and consumption, laptop-like for work. Most importantly: it just plain works with the Windows ecosystem (hardware and software).HP Stream 7 is a surprisingly fluid Windows 8.1-based tablet that comes with a 1 year subscription to Office 365 Personal, a $69 value. More on that later. What makes it surprising is its performance for its price. (Note: I purchased this tablet from the Microsoft Store.)PROS- Holds easily in the palm of my hand and in the back of my jeans pocket- A quite powerful Windows PC in the pocket of your pants!- Fluid performance of the Windows Store apps, helped by the Quad core processor- Traditional Windows app performance acceptable- Very inexpensive- Includes Office 365 Personal for a year ($70 value). Effectively making the tablet cost just $30!- Runs the full Windows 8 OS (not the crippled "RT" version). This lets you install traditional programs like on a regular laptop- Can access every file share that a Windows tablet/PC can connect to- Beautiful, bright screen (1280x800 resolution)- Screen can be seen from any angle!- Has 32 GB storage, expandable by a microSD card (tested with 64GB card)- Throw standard movies/videos onto the storage or microSD card, and watch them on this tablet without any conversion necessary- Bluetooth and Wifi- Battery lasts as much as 8 hours- Front and back cameras make video conferencing via Skype a possibility- Charges via standard microUSB port- microUSB port supports USB On-The-Go (OTG) cables. Allows you to connect hard drives, flash drives, memory card readers (for backing up your camera pictures). Can attach a USB hub to connect even more devices- Can run 2 Windows Store apps side-by-side- Plays videos (including Plex/Netflix) perfectly, including AVI, MKV, MP4, etc.- Despite having just 1GB RAM, I was pleased to be able to launch 8 Windows Store apps and easily switch between them- Supports Miracast wireless display casting (like Apple's "AirPlay", Samsung's "AllCast", Roku, etc). Allows you to project your tablet to a TV/projector -- even use it as a second monitor. This was tested with the MS Wireless Display Adapter. This did not work with Fire TV mirroring- "Signature Edition" is available through the Microsoft Store. That version gives you the Stream 7 without any additional software added by HP- Supports Bluetooth keyboards and miceCONS- At 0.8 lb, it feels heavy. Perhaps I got spoiled by the iPad Mini/Nexus 7/Surface 2, but its heft is noticeable- Speakers are loud enough in a room, but does not produce the best sound quality. What do you expect for a tablet at this price?- Only has 1GB of RAM although it has been able to perform acceptably- Although Miracast display mirroring works, it's not as fluid as the $1500 Surface Pro 3- microSD card slot is accessible after opening the back cover- Spoiled by the Surface Pro 3, the tablet appears thick- There is no Charge indicator light. So, you have to turn on the tablet and look at the battery icon to see whether it is charging or full. Worse, connect a generic charger that may not provide enough power, and the icon shows that it's charging, but... mouse over the system tray's battery icon, and it shows "Connected, but not charging". In other words, check that your non-HP charger works before you walk away- Only has 5-point multi-touch (Surface Pro 3/iPad do 10-point). With a tablet this size, 5-point works well enough- Typing on the on-screen keyboard was sometimes (not very often) laggy. Maybe I typed too fast.- "Signature Edition" is only available through the Microsoft Store- No GPSOFFICE 365 PERSONAL subscription (included for 1 year)- 1TB of OneDrive storage (Microsoft is upgrading this to UNLIMITED at no extra charge soon!)- Full copy of Office for 1 PC or Mac- Full copy of Office for tablets/phones (iPad, Android, Windows Phone)- 60 minutes of international Skype-to-phone calling- Worth $70/year- After the 1st year, you'll have to renew the subscription, but with all the benefits listed above (especially the UNLIMITED cloud storage), I find this a steal- Can upgrade to Office 365 Home after the 1st year, which comes with 5 accounts that you can share with friends/family, each getting the above benefits for their own account[EDIT 11/19/14: I found my OneDrive upgraded from 1TB to 10TB while Microsoft prepares to upgrade everybody to Unlimited storage. You can get on their upgrade waiting list at https://preview.onedrive.com/]The Office 365 Personal subscription is activated by launching the Office app icon from the Start screen. This takes you to the Office 365 website from where you activate the subscription. I was erroneously expecting a voucher in the box. The activation appears unique -- meaning, you cannot have another person log in to the tablet and try to claim another free subscription. Further, if you already have Office 365 Personal, I believe that the activation will simply extend your existing subscription by a year, but I cannot confirm.TIPS- I use Google Chrome all the time. However, just like on the Surface Pro 3 Core i7 (top-of-the-line), it does not play well -- it hogs memory and CPU resources! Further, it also does not scroll very smoothly. As such, use Internet Explorer (Store app version) for best performance. The slow performance is a GOOGLE problem, not a problem with the tablet- Treat this tablet like a Surface RT tablet, not a laptop: use the Store apps whenever you can. Consider the Desktop and the ability to run regular Windows software as a bonus. See this tablet as a laptop, and you'll be disappointed due to its small screen- Enter BIOS mode by turning the tablet off. Then push (and keep holding) the Power + Volume down buttons at the same time. Works the same way as the Surface Pro 3- The Windows Store version of Internet Explorer (IE) has Adobe Flash built in. You can also download Flash and install it for use with your browser of choice: IE, Chrome, Firefox, Opera, etc. However, IE will give you the best performance since Microsoft optimized IE for Windows 8 tabletsNOTES- The installed Windows OS is 32-bit- Since this tablet can run the full Windows OS, I surmise you could turn this into a full-fledged, basic server to use at home. Usage scenarios I can see: 1) torrent server. 2) Server to connect to via Remote Desktop/Teamviewer/Splashtop, allowing you to check on your files or security camera while you're away. 3) Server to control your home automation devices. 4) File server to host your files/movies/pictures (by connecting a USB hard drive via a USB OTG cable).- With the upcoming Windows 10 release, Windows Phone and Windows PC/tablets will be merged into a single system. This means that apps written for the phone should also work for the PC/tablet. This will hopefully encourage developers to focus their apps to run on the Windows ecosystem. Meaning: more, better quality apps! I have high hopes.I purchased this tablet to supplement my Surface Pro 3, HTC One M8 android phone, and my wife's iPad. A tablet so cheap, I can simply lay it around the house for anyone to grab to quickly look things up. At $99 - $69 (I planned to sign up for the Office 365 Personal subscription anyway) = $30, the Stream 7 is extremely affordable. Throw movies onto the tablet and watch them in the car or on the plane. Or, in my case, to launch something on a remote server via Citrix or Remote Desktop, or to move files around between computers (told you, I'm in IT.) I am very pleased with this purchase, and applaud Microsoft for lowering its Windows licensing fees to make inexpensive Windows tablets a possibility.TIP: take a look at the Anker Multi-Angle Portable Stand to use for this tablet (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00N1VDCGO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)--------- 12/10/2014 UPDATE WITH STREAM 8:I recently purchased the Stream 8, and although I bought it for $80 more than the Stream 7, I returned the latter. Here's why.PROS:- Stream 8 is only 1" larger, but it provides a noticeably larger screen. This makes reading easier- A bit thinner than the Stream 7- Comes with a free, lifetime, 200 MB/month cellular data via T-Mobile HSPA+ ("4G")- Cellular data: no credit card, no contract required- Cellular data allows you to quickly check something when no WiFi is available- Feels a bit lighter than the Stream 7 (although it's actually heavier)- Comes with Office 365 Personal 1 Year subscription too- Runs as smooth as the Stream 7. Both tablets are essentially the same specsCONS:- A bit pricier than the Stream 7- Cellular radio can drain battery faster. I keep mine turned off (Settings > Mobile Broadband > Off) until I need to use itTo activate the free, lifetime cellular subscription, go to Settings > WiFi (turn it off). Then tap the "Mobile Broadband" connection. It'll direct you to the T-Mobile page for activation (SIM card is already pre-installed underneath the back cover). Once activated, you may turn back on the WiFi radio.All in all, I am much happier with the Stream 8 than the Stream 7, although the latter is still an EXCELLENT value for its price. You can't go wrong with either tablet!

Meaning: more, better quality apps! I have high hopes.I purchased this tablet to supplement my Surface Pro 3, HTC One M8 android phone, and my wife's iPad. A tablet so cheap, I can simply lay it around the house for anyone to grab to quickly look things up. At $99 - $69 (I planned to sign up for the Office 365 Personal subscription anyway) = $30, the Stream 7 is extremely affordable [EDIT 2/18/15: MS currently sells the tablet for $75 - Office 365 Personal - $25 app store credit, making it practically free!]. Throw movies onto the tablet and watch them in the car or on the plane. Or, in my case, to launch something on a remote server via Citrix or Remote Desktop, or to move files around between computers (told you, I'm in IT.) I am very pleased with this purchase, and applaud Microsoft for lowering its Windows licensing fees to make inexpensive Windows tablets a possibility.TIP: take a look at the Anker Multi-Angle Portable Stand to use for this tablet (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00N1VDCGO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)--------- 12/10/2014 UPDATE WITH STREAM 8:I recently purchased the Stream 8, and although I bought it for $80 more than the Stream 7, I returned the latter. Here's why.PROS:- Stream 8 is only 1" larger, but it provides a noticeably larger screen. This makes reading easier- A bit thinner than the Stream 7- Comes with a free, lifetime, 200 MB/month cellular data via T-Mobile HSPA+ ("4G")- Cellular data: no credit card, no contract required- Cellular data allows you to quickly check something when no WiFi is available- Feels a bit lighter than the Stream 7 (although it's actually heavier)- Comes with Office 365 Personal 1 Year subscription too- Runs as smooth as the Stream 7. Both tablets are essentially the same specsCONS:- A bit pricier than the Stream 7- Cellular radio can drain battery faster. I keep mine turned off (Settings > Mobile Broadband > Off) until I need to use itTo activate the free, lifetime cellular subscription, go to Settings > WiFi (turn it off). Then tap the "Mobile Broadband" connection. It'll direct you to the T-Mobile page for activation (SIM card is already pre-installed underneath the back cover). Once activated, you may turn back on the WiFi radio.All in all, I am much happier with the Stream 8 than the Stream 7, although the latter is still an EXCELLENT value for its price. You can't go wrong with either tablet!

I installed this patch panel in my new home with Cat6 wiring, Cat6 keystone jacks, and Gigabit capable endpoints. It was easy to use (there's not much to it -- punch the wires down by following the color chart printed on each jack for the appropriate standard 568A or 568B) like most other patch panels.In speed tests, I have observed Gigabit speeds on my network, although a couple ports only perform at 100 Mbps. I have not yet found whether this was due to a faulty keystone jack, fault in the wiring going through the house, bad punch down at the patch panel, faulty jack at the panel, or faulty jack on the D-Link Gigabit, unmanaged switch. As some reviewers have pointed out, some had difficulty getting the patch panel to certify for CAT6 performance. Nonetheless, I am fairly happy with my purchase -- it was very inexpensive, and nearly every port has been performing at Gigabit speeds for the past 7 months with no problems.This product is good value, but would I use it in an enterprise setting? Most likely not. I'd probably get Panduit for enterprise/critical business settings. For home use, this product is more than sufficient for my needs.

I have been using the Varidesk Pro for about a month now. I realize that this product listing is for the Single version, but since I was unable to find a Pro listing at the time of this writing, I thought that I'd share my thoughts here anyway as both products are practically identical.The Pro version is designed to be able to hold TWO monitors.I have been suffering with lower back pain since February 2013 that was caused by an unfortunate car accident. One of my spinal discs slipped slightly, causing enough pain not to be able to move much, not to mention getting in or out of bed. After half a year of physical therapy, and having my workplace provide me with a $1,000 ergonomic chair, my back was still hurting from the all-day sitting in front of a computer.I had heard about standing desks, but the only ones I was able to find were cost-prohibitively in the $1,000+ range. One day, I saw an article mentioning the VariDesk product line, and the price was just right. Instead of a furniture that could be lifted up and down (standing/sitting position), this product would utilize an EXISTING desk to accomplish something similar. I mentioned to contact Varidesk for a trial, and after using it for a couple weeks, I felt some relief for my back, but it would still hurt at the end of the day. Further, I also found that my neck became stiff due to the way I was now sitting in an effort to be ergonomical. Regardless, I preferred the desk over the standard desks provided by the company, and managed to get my HR department and manager to approve me the purchase of the Varidesk Pro.After using the Varidesk for about half a year, I remembered my therapist telling me that sitting for prolonged periods of time was bad for the body. She stated that standing would be preferable because your core muscles would be engaged at all times. So, I decided to stand practically all day with the Varidesk in a higher position, but careful to have the keyboard still at a 90 degree angle with my arms/elbows. The first few days, it felt uncomfortable -- tiring even. I hated it, and switched back to sitting in the chair for the majority of the day.About three months ago, I decided to once again try to stand all day, and shoved my chair to the side. The result? After the initial adjustment period, I no longer felt the need to sit down, and my back pain stopped becoming noticeable! My knees sometimes need a rest, but a few minutes of sitting down (and feeling very good and relaxed in doing so!) resolved that issue. Nowdays, I go home with hardly a thought about my back. I was recently able to participate in my second Tough Mudder race event, and came home with minor soreness of the back. It appears that my core muscles have indeed been engaging more often, providing relief to my back.With that said, my coworkers have been noticing the oddity on my desk. The Varidesk Pro is a big piece of furniture, and it sure is to turn heads either by its size, or simply by the fact that I'm standing at my desk with the monitors raised high beyond my low-walled cubicle. As colleagues started asking questions about the desk, they too started inquiring to HR whether they could have one -- they were also suffering from back pain. Two other employees received one, and they have been very, very happy. One exclaimed that the product has been one of the best things for his back. Another employee is waiting for budget to allow him to purchase one too sometime this month.My manager has been contemplating about getting himself one too, but because this desk is a bit big, he decided not to get it. This is the biggest negative with the Varidesk Pro: its size. Perhaps the Varidesk Single is smaller, but you would lose the ability to have 2 monitors on the desk.This product is good for those suffering -- or not even suffering -- from back pain. It's a much better, ergonomic alternative to an under-desk keyboard, ergonomic chair, and what not. Use it while standing on your feet most of the time, and get yourself a stress mat to help alleviate the pressures on your feet and knees (I have yet to get one myself -- its cost is about $18 last time I checked). As a side effect of standing most of the time, I also found my eyes looking away from the monitor more often, helping them get a break from staring at the computer screen.

I purchased some cheap respirators from Home Depot, and found them to be lacking: I had a hard time keeping the mask's shape, having to toss them after just a few uses. Further, my nose was runny most of the time due to my exhaled air staying within the mask.I decided to purchase this particular one since safety is of a big concern for me. It addresses all the issues I had with the cheaper brand: holds its shape very well (and can be reused many, many times), and the filter at the front of the nose helps keeps the airway flowing.It protected me very well from dust/saw dust. It also protects better against Fiber (attic insulation) than the cheap ones I used.

This product fit my face (and dad's) very well, protecting all around (top, sides, bottom) without fogging up. It also looks pretty good (and not dorky.)With that said, I can also see myself wearing this while snowshoeing through the snow in the winter, helping me keep snow off my eyes. Why not use snow/ski goggles? Ski goggles are just too restrictive and bulky.

I tried this particular brand and product from our local, Italian market (Cortina's Anaheim, CA), and have been a fan since, purchasing 1lb every now and then to have with Italian basil, provolone cheese, olive oil, shredded iceberg lettuce, and a toasted, white bread.I like this product because unlike regular salami, this one has a nice, spicy kick to it. I also like the manufacturer's Hot Sopressata meat. With that said, the Calabrese Hot Salami is available at about $12/lb at the local market.

This review is written after having used the keyboard with the iPad Air (for which it was designed), and for seeing if it can be used with other products, such as the iPad Mini Retina, iPod Touch, Apple TV, and the Microsoft Surface 2.In short, it performed remarkably well as a keyboard for the Apple products, and decently for Windows-based devices. I especially liked the fact that the same keyboard I use for the Air can be used with the Apple TV (some keyboards don't work with it.) Now on to the details.I have been purchasing New Trent products for several years, and I've consistently found that they have pretty well-made products, and most importantly, listen to customer feedback extensively. As such, I was pleased to see the company release a dedicated keyboard/cover combo for the iPad Air.When the product arrived, I noticed that the packaging looks better than their past products. It's minimalist, clear, and the white color reminds you that it's for the iPad Air - as if floating lightly on clouds. Photo: http://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/permalink/mo3AR50QXEVMHQV/B00GP4BVTO/ref=cm_ciu_images_pl_linkThe case/keyboard was encased in a see-through wrapping, and to its left, the charging cable can be found inside a smaller, white box. The finish of the product is smooth, feels sturdy, solid, and premium. Equally important, the iPad Air fits snugly in the case, and the overall weight is negligible.After I switched the On/Off switch to the ON position, I hit the WIFI-symbol button, indicating to the keyboard that I'd like to sync it with the Air. On the iPad, go to Settings > Bluetooth, and you'll see "Keyboard" available for pairing. The iPad will ask you to type in a certain code on the keyboard, followed by Enter key, and the pairing is made. That was easy. With that said, here are some Pros and Cons in a list format to make it easier to read:PROS- Case folds on top of the keyboard, making it easier to use the iPad as a tablet- Case can be pushed back in a laptop-like format- Case turns 360 degrees, allowing for landscape/portrait orientation in upside and downside positions- Product can be used on the lap- Keyboard works extremely well:o Keys are spaced comfortably aparto Gives a nice, audible feedbacko Gives tactile feedbacko Responds quickly on the screen - there was no lago Has battery/Bluetooth indicatorso Brightness, Volume, Media Playback (Play/Pause/RWD/FF), and Volume keys are conveniento Has dedicated Lock button (invoked by pressing Fn-Lock)o Home/Task Switching (Square symbol) key works just like the Home button: single push = Home. Double-push = Task switching. Hold the button = Sirio Shuts itself off when not in use for an extended period to save battery life- Sturdy, solid, premium-feeling finish- Metallic, silver logo makes the case feel a bit more premium and executive. I wouldn't be embarrassed to take it to work.- Gloss above the function keys adds to the premium feel- Bluetooth was easy to sync- Battery life of keyboard is excellent - lasted over a week (and still haven't had the need to charge)- Product is fairly light in weight- Packaging and manual are clean, clear, and free of grammatical errorsCONS- Even though case folds on top of keyboard to allow iPad use as a tablet, the hinge side is a bit bulky, making it awkward to read a book in portrait mode. Horizontal mode is acceptable.- Case cannot be detached from the keyboard (for times when I want to use the iPad without the keyboard attached)- Fn-Globe key (on spacebar) did not do anything. I expected it, based on the Globe, to launch an app, such as the web browser- Has no Caps Lock light indicator when the key is On or Off- Rubber Nubs (below the spacebar) designed to protect the iPad from scratches may get in the way of typing whenever you hit the Spacebar. You can feel them there.PRODUCT COMPATIBILITY- I was pleasantly surprised to find that the keyboard works with the Apple TV (ATV). This beats having to use the Apple TV remote control to type in passwords and the such. I've tried some other keyboards that did not work with ATV.- Keyboard also worked the same way with iPad Touch and iPad Mini Retina.- Keyboard worked with the Microsoft Surface 2, although the Square (symbol) key did nothingI understand that the product was designed for the iPad Air, but I'm always happy when something works with other products too - saves me from having to buy another keyboard, such as for the Apple TV.Overall, this product was well-designed, has a smooth, premium feel, and is not flashy/ugly to be used in a business setting. If New Trent can figure out how to make the case be oriented at various angles (to allow for different eye level heights), that would make the case even better. As Microsoft showed with the Surface 2, one angle does not fit all, and the introduction of a 2nd angle made the product much more useful to use in a wider range of situations.

I waited for a long time for some sort of protection for the Surface 2 that would not add much bulk, yet allow for uninterrupted access to the kickstand, and for the design of the product to stand out.I first waited for the Incipio Feather cover, but it is only available for the Surface RT -- trying it on the Surface 2 resulted in very poor fitting. I have used a Neoprene case to protect the tablet in the meantime, and when I came across the Skinomi full-body protection for Surface RT, my interest was lit. I finally found that they make it for the Surface 2 as well, and this is what the review addresses.The packaging stood out -- it was received in a cardboard tube similar to ones you would use to mail out posters. Inside it were instruction guides, microfiber cloth, a spray containing a water and mild detergent solution, a squeege, and, of course, the screen protector films. The latter was on two, glossy sheets instead of being in individual, plastic bags like other screen protectors I have purchased in the past. The entire content inside the tube, by the way, was inside a sealed, plastic bag.After reviewing the instructions, which included washing your hands, removing dust particles from the tablet, and spraying your hand with the spray solution, I continued with the installation. The guide states to first watch the installation video Skinomi made available, but I ignored that tip. Before we go on, I would like to also add that you should put the tablet on a clean, dust-free table with excellent lighting, and to turn off the tablet to prevent any water damage. Also make sure that you have adhesives available, such as Scotch tape (more about that later.)The below procedure can be repeated for each film part:1. I sprayed the solution onto my fingertips (this was not mentioned in the instructions) to help keep fingerprints off the protective films, and proceeded with the biggest film: the screen protector. You should start with the biggest film first to help align the smaller ones.2. Turned it upside down with the adhesive side facing me, and sprayed the liquid onto it (never spray onto the tablet itself, specially where there are openings/holes!) as evenly as possible. Do not spray too much -- a thin layer is fine. The trick is to distribute the liquid as evenly as possible. Next, I double-checked that there were no dust particles or lint on the screen, and placed the film onto the tablet, carefully aligning the edges and camera opening.3. Used the squeege to softly smoothen out the surface, drawing out bubbles and larger air pockets. There's no need to remove the tiny, tiny bubbles ("micro bubbles"), as they will disappear on their own after 2-5 days.4. When I found dust particles or lint on the screen, I taped one Scotch tape onto the film to lift up the section closest to the particle, and used another Scotch tape to remove that particle from the screen or film. Repeat until all particles are gone, and use the squeege to smoothen out the film once more.5. After waiting for a few minutes, the film will dry, and will start sticking to the tablet's screen. If it does not stick, or if you have to repeat the process, remove the film, let it dry, then start over.Next, I applied the protective film at the upper half of the back. I wanted to apply the bottom one last so that I could rest the tablet on the desk without having to worry about the film being shifted while it was drying.Next, applied the smaller film of the upper back, the one for the back camera. This one was trickiest to install. I had to do this one twice. The first time, I applied the film to the back side, then folded it to cover the top portion of the tablet. However, the top portion would not stick since it was still wet. I struggled for a while, and it eventually stuck, but I noticed bubbles at the edge of where the top and back meet. I decided to remove the film from the top of the tablet, let the back portion (back camera side) dry and stick (be sure the power button opening is still aligned with the button). Once that was dry and was no longer shifting, I then applied the spray to the top part of the film, bent it, and held/smoothed it until it, too, was dry. Now the top and upper back portion are flush.Finally, I applied the two side films, followed by the larger film for the bottom back.Let the tablet dry for a few hours. Better yet, leave it alone (and still powered off) for 5+ hours, or overnight. This ensures the film has had proper time to adhere, and that no liquid may still be lingering that could short the tablet's electrical circuits.With the above procedure described, note that I installed the films in the evening with not as good of lighting as I had hoped. This morning, I discovered small bubbles (not the tiny/micro ones) in a few areas of the screen. Tonight, I will be removing the film, and try to re-install it with the remaining spray liquid, being more careful about bubble removal this time.I decided to knock this product's 5-star rating down to just 4, because it does not come with a protective film for the side UNDERNEATH the kickstand. The installation instructions also did not address how to install the tricky back-camera/top's film. To address the former, I cut and used my old screen protector for the back underneath the kickstand instead.I really do like the product, but will continue to wait until some manufacturer creates a tight-fitting case that does not obstruct the kickstand. Note: the Incipio Feather for the Surface RT does hinder the kickstand even for the product it was designed for.Hope this helps you with the installation of the product, and if it does, please be sure to click the "Helpful" link at the end of this review.UPDATE 1/8/2014: I was able to successfully re-do the screen protector portion. First, I wet my hands, removed the film, sprayed it, and laid it on top of the screen. I then slowly pushed out the bubbles by going diagonally across the film (bottom-left of screen and towards top-right) and slowly working my way to the opposite corner. Once all the water was pushed out, I took my fingers and slowly ran across the film to ensure there are no small bumps (they were the ones that caused the bubbles to stay on the previous try). Whenever I found a small bump, I lifted the film closest to it, and pushed out that bubble. Continued this process until I found no more bumps, bubbles, or lint anywhere on the screen. After letting it dry overnight, my tablet now looks perfect. Lots of compliments have been received for the tablet -- hardly anybody knew that there was any sort of protective film all over.

This review was originally posted for the PLAY:1, but I'm modifying it for the BRIDGE since the review applies to both products.I just purchased a home and was looking into having it wired for whole-house audio. Looking into multi-room systems on Amazon, it was apparent to me that it wouldn't be cheap: cost of the speakers, controllers, PLUS cost of running wires throughout the house. When I saw the SONOS PLAY:1 and BRIDGE promotions, I found its wireless solution to be more cost effective, and with better speakers to boot. Below are the pros and cons that led me to decide for the Sonos system.NOTE: a Sonos BRIDGE is NOT needed to use the PLAY:1/3/5, etc. See the INSTALLATION section of this review. The BRIDGE is primarily used to extend Sonos' wireless range at lower cost than additional speakers.PROS- Hi-Fi. Speakers sound better than the multi-room, wired systems I looked at for less than $500.- Resale Value. Wired speakers don't add much resale value to your house. So, why spend $1000s, only to leave the audio system behind when you sell the property or move? With wireless, I could take my expensive speakers with me to my new home.- Freedom to move around.With wireless, you are free to take the speakers anywhere you want throughout the whole house. For neighborhood block parties, I could even hook up the speakers to an extension cord out to the street, and stream music from my home. Or take it outside to your backyard. They are moisture-proof, but I wouldn't use them as permanent outdoor speakers unless you enclose them in protective casings.NOTE on wireless: each SONOS component is its own wireless client and repeater. Sonos wireless is a private, wireless "mesh" system, separate from your home WiFi. What does that mean to you? It routes music through its own wireless, leaving your home WiFi untouched. There's an additional benefit for that, as I'll explain after the installation note below. Most of the Sonos components (PLAY:1 is NOT one of them) have 2 network ports. This means, you can plug in the component into the network jack, and use the 2nd one on the speaker to connect your laptop.INSTALLATION: First, the tech talk. You need 1 Sonos component to be plugged in to your home network (any of the PLAY speakers, Soundbar, Bridge, etc.) So, as an example, you must plug in either the BRIDGE or the PLAY:1 to your network with a network cable. This turns that component into a wireless access point (or as consumers tend to call it, a "Wifi router".) All other Sonos components will now be able to wirelessly talk to that plugged-in device. No other Sonos component has to be plugged in, as long as it's within wireless range of the plugged-in one. Should a component in your house be too far away (say, your garage) from the plugged-in one, you can connect it to your network via cable, if available, or set up a Sonos BRIDGE (or any other Sonos speaker) wirelessly somewhere between the plugged-in one and the Garage speaker. The BRIDGE or other speaker strengthens the wireless from the plugged-in one, and extends the range to the one in the Garage. Each Sonos component is both a wireless client, and a wireless access point/repeater. Each component talks to each other in a mesh network. Think of a spider net. Any part that is touched vibrates to the rest of the net.Tech-talk aside, think about this: One person (Person 1) is at a corner of the house. When he shouts, the person in the garage (Person 2) can't hear Person 1. The only way Person 1 can talk to 2, is to pick up the phone (talking over a wired connection, or plugging a distant Sonos component to the wired network) or having Person 3 stand between them (having a Sonos component physically be between both speakers) and relaying the information back and forth (what WiFi mesh would do). So, with each Sonos component/speaker, the Sonos wireless range gets extended.With the Sonos wireless mesh, you could humorously place a few speakers into each house in the neighborhood, and suddenly play the same music through each home. Try that with Bluetooth speakers. You wouldn't be able to.WiFi mesh TIP: if you have an Android device, you can Google "Android devices on SonosNet", and you will see instructions on how to use your Sonos wireless network ("SonosNet") to connect your Android phone/tablet. This allows you to use your mobile device further away from your home WiFi. This has disadvantages and advantages out of the scope of this review. I decided not to use SonosNet for my tablets.NOTE: a Sonos BRIDGE is NOT needed to use the PLAY:1. Just plug in the PLAY:1 to the wired network (ie your router), and it will work just fine. You still control it with the Sonos App from your mobile device. Once the PLAY:1 is plugged in, you can add other Sonos components to the system. A BRIDGE is NOT needed for that either. It's only needed if you want to extend the Sonos wireless range to a farther part of your house or yard for $50 vs buying another PLAY speaker for $100+)- Small size. The BRIDGE is about the same size as an Apple TV/Roku/WD TV Live.- Ease of Pairing. To pair other Sonos components (or with the Sonos Controller App), simply hit the Play/Volume Up button on the speaker, and the same combination on the other speakers. If pairing with the BRIDGE, hit the pair button on that component.- LED. The Bright LED can be configured to turn on/off via the Sonos app.- Ease of music sync.You can use the free Sonos app for your Android, iOS (iPhone/iPad/iPod), Windows Phone, Mac/Windows laptop/tablet (sadly, no Windows Store app yet) to control how the speakers play: you can easily choose which speakers to pair/unpair into groups. Grouping the speakers allows you to play the same music on those speakers. You can have up to 32 separate groups. You can also individually control each speaker from the app. Each group's volume is controlled by the Sonos app. So, if Speaker 1 is set to 50% volume, and Speaker 2 is set to 25%, lowering the volume by 5% will lower Speaker 1 to 45%, and 2 to 20%.Once music is playing, you can leave the house, and it will continue to play -- as long as the music source is not coming from that mobile device (meaning: if you're playing MP3s from your phone, and your phone leaves, it will stop playing. But if you started Pandora from your phone, or you told the speaker to play music off one of your network shares, it will continue playing since the source is coming from a device that's still at home.)PARTIES: one cool feature is that once you download the Sonos Controller app and pair it to one of the Sonos speakers (which authorizes the app/phone to talk to your Sonos system -- this prevents unauthorized people outside your home from controlling your speakers), each device can control the playlist. So, if you have guests coming over, and each guest downloads and authorizes the Sonos app to your system, each guest can now add/remove songs from the queue. Everybody can now be a DJ.- Expandability.Sonos did a smart thing. They released the less expensive PLAY:1 to wet your/my appetite, and gave away BRIDGE for free, too. As you use the system, you will likely buy more Sonos components to expand your sound system, resulting in more revenue for the company. You can add any Sonos component to your system, and they will all work in harmony. You can set up a complete home theater system that way too. I know, sounds pricey. It is. But it still is cheaper than having your whole house wired with nice speakers.- Alarm/Sleep timer.You can set up each speaker (or Group of speakers) to play music at a specific time, day, and volume (Alarm) from a specific source for a specified amount of time. Or you can also set a Sleep timer to play music for a specific number of minutes to ease you into sleep. I love getting waken up by mellow music (ie. Norah Jones) in the morning, and when I leave the home, I don't have to worry about turning off the speakers. It'll automatically turn off after the 45 minutes I set up for the alarm.- Sound. Sound quality is quite good. I will leave you with the reviews by others to read more about that. With the Sonos app, you can control Bass, Treble, and volume. I have the speakers play between 15% to 25% volume in each room -- they are plenty loud enough. Setting them to 100% can be heard through the whole house -- and the potential for your neighbors to complain. Even at low volume, the sound is very good. It's definitely better than most Bluetooth speakers. If you put the PLAY:1 in the corner of a room, the sound seems a bit more muffled due to the amplification of the Bass by the walls on both ends. You can fix this by adding more Treble, or by moving the speaker away from the corner.- Design. The PLAY:1 and BRIDGE are beautiful devices. They don't look out-of-place in my home. I bought the White ones.CONSI couldn't find many cons with the PLAY:1. But here are some that have annoyed me.- Cost. The Sonos system is expensive. Just look at the price of the other components. Holy moly. Still, if you were to wire your house with Bose speakers, the Sonos system is comparatively inexpensive. Again, I chose Sonos because wiring the house won't add much resale value. I like the idea of being able to take my Sonos with me to my new home.- Sonos App Interface. The app is clunky and looks outdated. It took me a while to figure out where to go to do what (and I love gadgets/toys. I'm a technology tinkerer!). It's not very user friendly.- Music sources. Not all apps can play to the Sonos speakers. You have to use the Sonos App, add the approved source to it, then you can play from that source. I wish you could re-route any audio from any device to the speakers. Pandora, network shares (NAS), iTunes, TuneIt Radio (built-in), iPod/iPad/iPhone, media files on your own Android/Windows device are all possible sources. At one point (if I remember correctly), my not-so-tech-savvy dad was able to beam his iPad's YouTube sound to the speakers without using the Sonos App. I didn't get a chance to verify how he did it, but I did see the PLAY:1 being available as a target on his iPad. Perhaps it was playing via the DLNA protocol. Either way, that was neat.- Input source. I wish that the PLAY:1 had a Line-in/Aux port so that you can connect any music source to it for playback, such as your TV or existing home entertainment system. Yes, the Sonos CONNECT takes care of that, but look at the price of that component! Even then, the CONNECT doesn't support SPDIF/Optical input.Weren't it for the Amazon/Target promotions on Black Friday, I would have been EXTREMELY hesitant to buy these expensive speakers. I bought two PLAY:1 during the promotion. With that said, overall, I'm quite pleased with the purchase. It came out cheaper than wiring the house, and I get to control my music from any of the mobile devices. That's neat. Lower the prices of your other components, Sonos! I hope for increased competition in the market to drive the prices down -- as of today, I'm not aware of any good, alternate, wireless HiFi solution.I have the BRIDGE installed downstairs in a 2-story home. One PLAY:1 is upstairs, and one PLAY:1 is downstairs. I may purchase more PLAY:1s in the future. The BRIDGE is not needed at all for my home since one of the PLAY:1 can act as the wireless access point for the other.------EDIT 5/12/14: Almost half a year later, and I'm still enjoying the PLAY:1. By the way, Sonos is working on making it unnecessary for any Sonos component to be connected to the wired network/router. From their blog post, titled, "Our Vision for Rock-Solid Wireless, Evolved" (April 17, 2014), "We've found a way to deliver all the benefits of SonosNet without a product directly connected to your router... Start with a speaker and your smartphone, enter your WiFi password and Sonos takes care of the rest."I've also updated my review with the clarification, "Most of the Sonos components (PLAY:1 is [NOT] one of them) have 2 network ports." (Thank you, JOEKC, for pointing out the original review's error)EDIT 6/16/14: Clarified that SonosNET is a proprietary wireless network. (Thanks, Kerton)

Easy to install (hook up white wire with white, and black wire with black. Be sure to turn off power first, if you're uncomfortable with electrical work. Just make sure you separate the black and white wires from one another at all times. Don't even think about touching both at the same time.)Timer works flawlessly. There was nothing to set or configure since it's a mechanical timer. The metallic look makes the timer look higher-end, and it's fairly quiet.I installed this unit in one of my coin-operated laundry rooms for my tenants.

After I read that Time Warner Cable was going to raise their modem lease to $8/month, I looked into whether it's possible to buy and use your own. Sure enough, the SB6141 was one of the approved modems. Instead of paying $8/mo to lease their clunky, old modem, I went ahead and bought the SB6141 -- it pays for itself after less than a year. The saving I get from it is now used to subscribe to Netflix's $7.99/month plan. Check your cable bill -- I went as far back as 2008, and wow, I've been paying Time Warner for leasing their modem for the past 5 years! That's at least $300!The SB6141 modem has worked reliably and rapidly in Orange County, CA, for both Time Warner Cable and Cox. Despite other reviews I have read, Time Warner actually did upgrade the firmware to the modem a few days after I installed it myself. I noticed the upgrade when I checked the logs. Nonetheless, Time Warner Cable in my area has had periods of slowdown (going from 15 Mbps down to 1 Mbps at times!), and it didn't matter if I rented one from them or used the SB6141.The Web Interface/Logs can be accessed by going to [..] with your browser. In case Amazon edits the link, the URL is [...]I have moved to a Cox area recently, and purchased a second SB6141 (I gave the 1st one to my brother) instead of leasing one from Cox. It worked right out of the box. Speeds have been usually consistent at 18-24 Mbps (I'm on the 18 Mbps plan), sometimes dropping to 5 Mbps. I haven't been using the Internet long enough yet to see how reliable the modem is with Cox, but from the logs, there haven't been any disconnects. I also have a very strong signal coming to my home, as verified with the Cox-employed cable installer.[UPDATE 4/2/2014: I have been using this modem for the past 7 months with Cox Irvine, CA, and have been experiencing consistent, 32 Mbps speeds for the past 3 months in speed tests. Considering that I'm only paying for the 18 Mbps plan, getting 32 Mbps is wonderful. The modem has been working very well, and I am very happy with the purchase.]Purchase this modem. Save yourself the cost of renting it from your cable provider. Check with your cable provider's website which modems are compatible before you do buy one.Once you get the modem, write down the MAC address that's usually printed at the bottom or side of it. Call your cable provider's support line (in my case, Time Warner Cable), and tell them that you bought a modem. They'll need to update the MAC address associated with your account with the one you just wrote down. A few minutes later, it should work. Doesn't require a very tech-savvy person to get this going :) Time Warner Cable also requires you to return the leased modem to one of their TWC Stores (it can't be mailed in.)

I previously owned an IDEAL crimper, and after crimping hundreds of RJ-45s, my hand eventually tired. I decided to buy this Paladin one because it can crimp RJ-45 and RG6 (coax). I no longer saw a need to crimp any RJ-11s (phone) (which the IDEAL one had.)This crimper performs very well. It made it easier to crimp with less effort.Further, the head can be changed -- this modular design allows you to buy an RJ-11 template, if you so desire, and crimp RJ-11s with this same crimper. Possibilities are endless. Good job, Paladin, with a modular design.

I just purchased a home and was looking into having it wired for whole-house audio. Looking into multi-room systems on Amazon, it was apparent to me that it wouldn't be cheap: cost of the speakers, controllers, PLUS cost of running wires throughout the house. When I saw the SONOS PLAY:1 promotions, I found its wireless solution to be more cost effective, and with better speakers to boot. Below are the pros and cons that led me to decide for the Sonos system.NOTE: a Sonos BRIDGE is NOT needed to use the PLAY:1. See the INSTALLATION section of this review.PROS- Hi-Fi. Speakers sound better than the multi-room, wired systems I looked at for less than $500.- Resale Value. Wired speakers don't add much resale value to your house. So, why spend $1000s, only to leave the audio system behind when you sell the property or move? With wireless, I could take my expensive speakers with me to my new home.- Freedom to move around.With wireless, you are free to take the speakers anywhere you want throughout the whole house. For neighborhood block parties, I could even hook up the speakers to an extension cord out to the street, and stream music from my home. Or take it outside to your backyard. They are moisture-proof, but I wouldn't use them as permanent outdoor speakers unless you enclose them in protective casings.NOTE on wireless: each SONOS component is its own wireless client and repeater. Sonos wireless is a private, wireless "mesh" system, separate from your home WiFi. What does that mean to you? It routes music through its own wireless, leaving your home WiFi untouched. There's an additional benefit for that, as I'll explain after the installation note below. Most of the Sonos components (PLAY:1 is NOT one of them) have 2 network ports. This means, you can plug in the component into the network jack, and use the 2nd one on the speaker to connect your laptop.INSTALLATION: First, the tech talk. You need 1 Sonos component to be plugged in to your home network (any of the PLAY speakers, Soundbar, Bridge, etc.) So, as an example, you must plug in either the BRIDGE or the PLAY:1 to your network with a network cable. This turns that component into a wireless access point (or as consumers tend to call it, a "Wifi router".) All other Sonos components will now be able to wirelessly talk to that plugged-in device. No other Sonos component has to be plugged in, as long as it's within wireless range of the plugged-in one. Should a component in your house be too far away (say, your garage) from the plugged-in one, you can connect it to your network via cable, if available, or set up a Sonos BRIDGE (or any other Sonos speaker) wirelessly somewhere between the plugged-in one and the Garage speaker. The BRIDGE or other speaker strengthens the wireless from the plugged-in one, and extends the range to the one in the Garage. Each Sonos component is both a wireless client, and a wireless access point/repeater. Each component talks to each other in a mesh network. Think of a spider net. Any part that is touched vibrates to the rest of the net.Tech-talk aside, think about this: One person (Person 1) is at a corner of the house. When he shouts, the person in the garage (Person 2) can't hear Person 1. The only way Person 1 can talk to 2, is to pick up the phone (talking over a wired connection, or plugging a distant Sonos component to the wired network) or having Person 3 stand between them (having a Sonos component physically be between both speakers) and relaying the information back and forth (what WiFi mesh would do). So, with each Sonos component/speaker, the Sonos wireless range gets extended.With the Sonos wireless mesh, you could humorously place a few speakers into each house in the neighborhood, and suddenly play the same music through each home. Try that with Bluetooth speakers. You wouldn't be able to.WiFi mesh TIP: if you have an Android device, you can Google "Android devices on SonosNet", and you will see instructions on how to use your Sonos wireless network ("SonosNet") to connect your Android phone/tablet. This allows you to use your mobile device further away from your home WiFi. This has disadvantages and advantages out of the scope of this review. I decided not to use SonosNet for my tablets.NOTE: a Sonos BRIDGE is NOT needed to use the PLAY:1. Just plug in the PLAY:1 to the wired network (ie your router), and it will work just fine. You still control it with the Sonos App from your mobile device. Once the PLAY:1 is plugged in, you can add other Sonos components to the system. A BRIDGE is NOT needed for that either. It's only needed if you want to extend the Sonos wireless range to a farther part of your house or yard for $50 vs buying another PLAY speaker for $100+)- Small size. The BRIDGE is about the same size as an Apple TV/Roku/WD TV Live. The PLAY:1 is about 2-3 of them stacked on top of each other. The PLAY:1 has a fairly hefty weight, a good sign of the good sound coming from its components.- Ease of Pairing. To pair other Sonos components (or with the Sonos Controller App), simply hit the Play/Volume Up button on the speaker, and the same combination on the other speakers. If pairing with the BRIDGE, hit the pair button on that component.- LED. The Bright LED can be configured to turn on/off via the Sonos app.- Ease of music sync.You can use the free Sonos app for your Android, iOS (iPhone/iPad/iPod), Windows Phone, Mac/Windows laptop/tablet (sadly, no Windows Store app yet) to control how the speakers play: you can easily choose which speakers to pair/unpair into groups. Grouping the speakers allows you to play the same music on those speakers. You can have up to 32 separate groups. You can also individually control each speaker from the app. Each group's volume is controlled by the Sonos app. So, if Speaker 1 is set to 50% volume, and Speaker 2 is set to 25%, lowering the volume by 5% will lower Speaker 1 to 45%, and 2 to 20%.Once music is playing, you can leave the house, and it will continue to play -- as long as the music source is not coming from that mobile device (meaning: if you're playing MP3s from your phone, and your phone leaves, it will stop playing. But if you started Pandora from your phone, or you told the speaker to play music off one of your network shares, it will continue playing since the source is coming from a device that's still at home.)PARTIES: one cool feature is that once you download the Sonos Controller app and pair it to one of the Sonos speakers (which authorizes the app/phone to talk to your Sonos system -- this prevents unauthorized people outside your home from controlling your speakers), each device can control the playlist. So, if you have guests coming over, and each guest downloads and authorizes the Sonos app to your system, each guest can now add/remove songs from the queue. Everybody can now be a DJ.- Stereo pairing for PLAY:1.You can take two PLAY:1 speakers and set them up as Left & Right channels for stereo output.- Expandability.Sonos did a smart thing. They released the less expensive PLAY:1 to wet your/my appetite. As you use the system, you will likely buy more Sonos components to expand your sound system, resulting in more revenue for the company. You can add any Sonos component to your system, and they will all work in harmony. You can set up a complete home theater system that way too. I know, sounds pricey. It is. But it still is cheaper than having your whole house wired with nice speakers.- Alarm/Sleep timer.You can set up each speaker (or Group of speakers) to play music at a specific time, day, and volume (Alarm) from a specific source for a specified amount of time. Or you can also set a Sleep timer to play music for a specific number of minutes to ease you into sleep. I love getting waken up by mellow music (ie. Norah Jones) in the morning, and when I leave the home, I don't have to worry about turning off the speakers. It'll automatically turn off after the 45 minutes I set up for the alarm.- Sound. Sound quality is quite good. I will leave you with the reviews by others to read more about that. With the Sonos app, you can control Bass, Treble, and volume. I have the speakers play between 15% to 25% volume in each room -- they are plenty loud enough. Setting them to 100% can be heard through the whole house -- and the potential for your neighbors to complain. Even at low volume, the sound is very good. It's definitely better than most Bluetooth speakers. If you put the PLAY:1 in the corner of a room, the sound seems a bit more muffled due to the amplification of the Bass by the walls on both ends. You can fix this by adding more Treble, or by moving the speaker away from the corner.- Design. The PLAY:1 and BRIDGE are beautiful devices. They don't look out-of-place in my home. I bought the White ones.CONSI couldn't find many cons with the PLAY:1. But here are some that have annoyed me.- Cost. The Sonos system is expensive. Just look at the price of the other components. Holy moly. Still, if you were to wire your house with Bose speakers, the Sonos system is comparatively inexpensive. Again, I chose Sonos because wiring the house won't add much resale value. I like the idea of being able to take my Sonos with me to my new home.- Sonos App Interface. The app is clunky and looks outdated. It took me a while to figure out where to go to do what (and I love gadgets/toys. I'm a technology tinkerer!). It's not very user friendly.- Music sources. Not all apps can play to the Sonos speakers. You have to use the Sonos App, add the approved source to it, then you can play from that source. I wish you could re-route any audio from any device to the speakers. Pandora, network shares (NAS), iTunes, TuneIt Radio (built-in), iPod/iPad/iPhone, media files on your own Android/Windows device are all possible sources. At one point (if I remember correctly), my not-so-tech-savvy dad was able to beam his iPad's YouTube sound to the speakers without using the Sonos App. I didn't get a chance to verify how he did it, but I did see the PLAY:1 being available as a target on his iPad. Perhaps it was playing via the DLNA protocol. Either way, that was neat.- Input source. I wish that the PLAY:1 had a Line-in/Aux port so that you can connect any music source to it for playback, such as your TV or existing home entertainment system. Yes, the Sonos CONNECT takes care of that, but look at the price of that component! Even then, the CONNECT doesn't support SPDIF/Optical input.Weren't it for the Amazon/Target promotions on Black Friday, I would have been EXTREMELY hesitant to buy these expensive speakers. I bought two PLAY:1 during the promotion. With that said, overall, I'm quite pleased with the purchase. It came out cheaper than wiring the house, and I get to control my music from any of the mobile devices. That's neat. Lower the prices of your other components, Sonos! I hope for increased competition in the market to drive the prices down -- as of today, I'm not aware of any good, alternate, wireless HiFi solution.I have the BRIDGE installed downstairs in a 2-story home. One PLAY:1 is upstairs, and one PLAY:1 is downstairs. I may purchase more PLAY:1s in the future. The BRIDGE is not needed at all for my home since one of the PLAY:1 can act as the wireless access point for the other.------EDIT 5/12/14: Almost half a year later, and I'm still enjoying the PLAY:1. By the way, Sonos is working on making it unnecessary for any Sonos component to be connected to the wired network/router. From their blog post, titled, "Our Vision for Rock-Solid Wireless, Evolved" (April 17, 2014), "We've found a way to deliver all the benefits of SonosNet without a product directly connected to your router... Start with a speaker and your smartphone, enter your WiFi password and Sonos takes care of the rest."I've also updated my review with the clarification, "Most of the Sonos components (PLAY:1 is [NOT] one of them) have 2 network ports." (Thank you, JOEKC, for pointing out the original review's error)EDIT 6/16/14: Clarified that SonosNET is a proprietary, wireless network

This is a beautiful light fixture, especially when coupled with LED bulbs. It was easy to install (connect black with the black wire, and white with white wire.) The motion detection worked great (it does, like other lights of its kind, have a blind spot directly below the fixture.) In my testing, motion was detected 5' from the fixture.NOTE: DualBrite is, disappointingly, NOT a feature of this lantern, despite what the Amazon description states. Even the box does not mention DualBrite. In other words, there are only two states available: ON (motion activated or manual) or OFF. With that said, it's still a great light. The manufacturer's website also has no mention of DualBrite for the White model: [...]Summary of the various modes available:TEST - use this to test the light. It allows the light to turn on even in daylight. The first time you turn on the switch, the light turns on for a minute while it calibrates, then it turns off. Now you can walk around to activate the motion detection -- it turns on instantly, and turns off again after about 10 seconds or so.The same switch for TEST can then be set to 1, 5, or 10. Each number corresponds to the number of minutes the light will stay on after motion is detected. These modes are considered "AUTO" mode. AUTO mode only turns on the light at night time (when motion is detected.) During daytime, light turns itself off.MANUAL mode: manual mode allows you to override the motion detection portion. To activate it, turn off the switch for a second, then back on. The light will now stay on until daylight, after which it will turn itself off and revert back into AUTO mode. This is a great feature -- I use it to keep the light on for when guests are visiting, and in case I forget to turn it off, rest assured, it will be off automatically in the morning.If you don't want the light to stay on until the morning (when it's set to MANUAL mode), simply turn the switch off for 1 minute, then switch back on. The light will turn on to calibrate itself, then it goes into AUTO mode.I wish that the DualBrite mode came with this lantern so that it would be on all night long at a low level.This is a great light, and I'll be ordering another one in a few days.

I am a professional photographer who owns 2 Canon 5D Mark III and several, very pricey lenses. For my upcoming honeymoon, however, I did not want to lug around such expensive gear and having to constantly look over my shoulders to not get robbed. The Sony NEX-7 became my camera of choice to take on the trip for its small size and DSLR-like abilities. Furthermore, a smaller camera -- instead of a big DSLR with a big lens -- would help make the photo subject feel a bit more at ease getting photographed.The Kit lens that came with the NEX-7, the 18-55mm, unfortunately shoots horribly when compared to my professional, Canon L lenses, and I started my search for a replacement lens. I was saddened to find a very small selection of available lenses for the NEX series (E-Mount lenses) that were of the quality I was looking for. Granted, the NEX-7 with its interchangeable lenses were far superior over the PowerShot S95 point-and-shoot, an excellent camera for its class, I previously used.Carl Zeiss makes excellent lenses, and so I took a look at this Sonnar T* E 24mm F1.8 ZA.Aperture of f/1.8 would enable great bokeh (background blur), as well as better low-light performance. I hardly shoot with Flash when I travel, and this was an important plus.The 24mm length, coupled with the NEX-7's 1.5x crop factor, would turn the lens into an equivalent 36mm lens on a full-frame camera, such as the Canon 5D. As my go-to lens for everyday shooting is the Canon 24-70mm f/2.8, the 36mm falls nearly right in the middle of that range. It is also just shy of taking pictures at a 1:1 life-size ratio (which 50mm lenses do on a full-frame camera, or 33mm on the NEX-7, should Zeiss release one in the near future, as has been rumored.)Being forced to shoot at 36mm (with no ability to zoom in or out) would require you to adjust the way you photograph. Not an impossible task, but something to be aware of. You'll have to learn to move forward or backward to "zoom" in and out. Be careful when you back up before you fall into a pool!This lens is only slightly longer than the kit 18-55mm lens, and as such does not add any more bulk.Pictures taken were very sharp, and when compared with those taken of the same subject in the same condition with the kit lens, the Zeiss is far, far superior in sharpness and color.The bokeh (background) blur is creamy smooth, and what pleasantly surprised me is this lens' ability to shoot macro.
