For those who notice these things (probably most, though not all people) the CyberLink Power greatly improves DVD video and audio, turning standard into high resolution, adding a pretty good 3D to 2D, enhancing vibrancy and resolution, and adding Dolby sound (quite an improvement over standard computers.)  Rips CDs too! There's lots of organizational features (bookmarking, tagging, etc.), as well as storage capabilty.  The only thing I don't like is that storage must be renewed later for a fee.

My consumer products review head, the underpaid and overworked Nicolas Turner, dropped off the followed memo at my London Flat (along with a 99% full bottle of this product.Hey MAG,SInce you stiffed me for the PROs and CONs format of my last consumer review, I'm going to attempt something more, as they say, "integrative," this time. This stuff isn't bad at all, and would make a nice shower or bridegroom gift for someone who needs a hint.  It certainly works well; the refreshed feeling lasts for a long time (or til you swill your next big cup of coffee), and there's no alcohol, unlike those that popular amber-tinged mouthwashed named after Dr. Lister that seems like it *must* be working because of its medicinal look and drying, puckering feeling in the mouth.SPeaking of alcohol, someone put too much aloe or chamomile or glycerin, or ammonium glycyrrhizate (derived from licorice) in this, because it has a taste which, if it were in tequila or scotch, could only be described as vegetal or "green."  In fact, the taste recalls tequila; that is, if one *can* recall tasting tequila.  That was a big downer for me.  I'd rather drink some quality tequila, then brush my teeth really well, including the tongue, like that woman advises Leonard to do in "Super Sad True Love Story."  The ingredients seem mostly natural, although some of them were so unnatural -sounding I had to look them up in Wikipedia.  My paraphrasing (don't want to plagiarize!) follows the symbol ~ below, and I couldn't always tell exactly the purpose of these chemicals. Overall, it seems thoughtfully formulated, but I'm returning 99% of the bottle to you, in accordance with Vine rules (although I suspect you're just too cheap to give anything away), and that unfortunate more-than-a-hint of green tequila.Catch you later,-NicIngredientsPurified Water (Aqua)SorbitolAloe Barbadensis Leaf Juice,PVP ~Polyvinylpyrrolidone, several chemical properties and usesOXYD-8 (Dr. Katz's patented version of Cl02) ~CIO-2 is chloride dioxide, a disinfectantChamomilla Rectutita (Matricaria) Flower Extract,Avena Sativa (Oat) Kernal Extract,Allantoin ~anti-irritant, protects skinGlycerin (from vegetable sources)Sodium CitrateXylitol ~oral hygienist recommended thisPolysorbate 20 ~a surfactant or wtting agent (like Sodium Laurel Sulfate) which may help the taste spread more evenlyTatrasodium Pyrophosphate ~a tartar control agent that removes calcium and magnesium from saliva, thus preventing them from being deposited on teeth.Disodium EDTA-Copper  Used by dentists and other oral health professionals  to remove inorganic debrisAmmonium Glycyrrhizate~ natural material isolated from the licorice plant, Glycyrrhiza glabra for flavor, Menthol, Citric Acid, Sodium Bicarbonate, Sodium BenzoateDoes not Contain: Alcohol, Saccharin, Sodium Lauryl Sulfate, Benzalkonium Chloride (an allergen)

I love this "nutritional powder" for so many reasons.  It tastes great-not so chemica as others because of the food-based ingredients-, it mixes much more easily than other brands (I like adding it to soy or milk-based juice/vegetable smoothies), it has excellent nutritional value, and you're dealing with an ethical company. One 46 gram scoop (serving per container, approximately 10) has 170 calories, 6 grams of total fat, no  trans fat, no cholesterol, 30 mg of sodium, and 13 grams of carbohydrate, of which 7 grams are dietary fiber!.In addition it has 20 grams of protein (40% of the DV) and 50-90% of Vitamins A, C, D, E, K,the B vitamins( thiamine, Riboflavin, B6 (15% of B12 and 50% Folate as well), Biotin, and Pantothenate. There's 20-30% of Calcium, Iron, Phosphorus, and Magnesium.The ingredients are vegan, non-genetically modified, and include pea protein, whole flaxseed, cocoa powder, maca root, broccoli, spirulina, kale, calcium from organic marine algae, a fruit and vegetable blend, probiotics, and much more. (A reprint of the label can be found at their website, http://myvega.com/product/vega-one-nutritional-shake.At the current sale price, each serving costs about $3.00, higher than we might like, but competitively priced with products that pack this much nutritional value and with this ingredient "pedigree."  And, again, the rich chocolate flavor is delicious, and the products textures lends itself to mixing.As I usually do, I advise people to consult a doctor or professional nutritionist, dietician, or related health professional before making dietary changes.  At $3.00 per serving, it's comparable to the cost of a fast food meal, and it's far better for you.  Highly recommended.

Neutrogena has long been a favorite company, having used their skin and hair products for many years. I found that this product did as well as others, and the company notes that Cool Dry Sport is sweat and water resistant (not sweat and water proof).  Since resistant is a fairly vague word, I would follow their directions about re-application, or better, yet, ask a doctor or related professional.An important subjective consideration is whether you prefer sprays or lotions.  Sprays, in general, go on and feel "lighter," may dry faster and work quicker; however, I find that lotions give me more sensory feedback about whether I've covered everything, and that's why I sometimes prefer lotions. However, I've used both "delivery" systems and feel fine with a spray (some adults or kids may not prefer it).  As noted by others, this is very lightly scented, and not labelled as hypo-allergenic, but I had no unpleasant sensations or reactions.  The Neutrogena website offers more information about the non-active ingredients, as well as some nice tips about augmenting sprays/lotions protection with hats and other clothing, and limiting exposure. This is serious stuff, and if you have any doubts about whether this product is right for you....yes, please consult a doctor.I like this product (and the packaging), and would buy again.

For those who have loved their old Interplak, all I can say is make sure this is the identical model to what you used before.  I don't know what Conair was thinking, but this is the worst toothbrush I've ever used, with the possible exception of some completely flimsy manual one the dentist hand out when we were kids.  There's just too little power.Now, it's true that the brushing action is more important than the POWER, per se.  We're not talking horsepower here.  However, when an electric toothbrush is so weak that it stops when it accidentally rubs against your  inner mouth, when it's so weak that it barely moves when used with toothpaste, when it's so weak that you don't feel you're really getting your teeth clean...well, there's not much point in buying it.The best part about this toothbrush is the eight-bristle brush-one of the best I've used. It does, indeed, reach down between your teeth.  Although probably not a substitute for flossing (as with all consumer health products, ask your health provider for her or his recommendations), they're very well designed.  Too bad they're saddled with such a bad motor.  Even worse, I can find a place to buy substitute brush heads The ones pictured here on Amazon.com aren't the same as the 8-bristle brush that comes with this.  A month or more ago, I did see replacements, but they cost more than twice the price of the entire toothbrush, and I didn't see them for sale at the Conair website.If for some reason you want an extremely gentle toothbrush that may not brush your entire mouth without stopping a few times, and you don't want to replace the only thing good about the product (the brush heads), you might want to purchase this. However, there are much better toothbrushes out there, many of which have "low" vibration mode for gentle brushing, and I'd recommend those instead.  As said above, your dental health provider may be able to recommend something better.

This is the first time I've worn this shape in a helmet; I've had those sleek, racing-style ones with a little color and design (though I don't even come close to racing).  When I first saw it, I thought, 'this is gonna weigh a ton,' and I really had my doubts about comfort and style.I'm happy to report that everything about the Commuter BIke and Skate Helmet was a pleasant surprise.  If I had weighed it and my usual helmet, perhaps I would have discovered that it's heavier.  However, it just feels solid and secure and just safer, without added weight; at least, not enough to bother me. It's superbly balanced, perhaps that why it felt so good.  As I said, it feels safer, and makes me feel much more secure.  Whether it actually *is* safer than those lower profile, pointier helmets...well, consult your local bicycle (or skate) services professional.Other things I like about the helmet:  The strap is, of course, adjustable, and there's a good loose-to-tight range. It take a tiny bit of effort to adjust the strap (something I'm sure I"ll get better at), but it stays in place and is well-designed. I like the simple design, the ventilation, and the comfortable velcro-held interior padding, as I've seen on other helmets.  The color is a light matte grey, very nice, not boring white, and not cliche black. That, of course, is very subjective, but the somewhat retro style has its own flavor of rebellion against the trendy, trying-too-hard style of some.  It comes with some nice safety tips for those not up on the limitations of the helmets (i.e., they can't protect against everything).  Great design, and a must for those who want some head protection while they bicycle or skate-and that should include everyone.

A relatively fun way to learn the database manager/statistical software "R." the authors take the novel approach of teaching the language within the context of baseball statistics.  Become a sabermetrician and become the envy of your neighborhood!Those who favor the "learning R" aspect will be reawarded more than baseball aficionados.  The latter will be satisfied with some of the fairly arcane learning examples (how well did Warren Spahn pitch in the post-war era; what are the relatively trajectories by age of the home run totals of Bonds, Ruth, and Aaron; predicting post-season performace with Markov chain probabilities-we'll have to try that with the 2014 Giants sometime), but the focus is on learning R, not learning baseball lore. For example, the baseball problems don't containa lot of context:  Bonds' probably steroid use is not mentioned; it's irrelevant to the main topic."R" is not an intuitive language. though moreso than SQL.  In my experience it is increasingly used as either a first-line or adjunctive statistical programming language alongside the most popular (social science) packages: SAS, SPSS, Mplus, and, for database construction, SQL (which is also part of SAS using Proc SQL).  It uses elements of SAS /SPSS with a few of the more manageable conocepts from SQL (NO, I'm not a fan of SQL, but then, I came rather late to it.).While certainly not a "Book for Dummies" (and really, must beginners put up with that...), some experience with databases will bevery helpful.  You'll also get more out of the book with some statistical knowledge, but that's not necesary.  It seems like most languages have their own nomenclature for the same methods and concepts, and the authors excel at presenting R's vernacular in a slow, patient style that will help you grasp the fundamentals, and they use screen shots and drawings to help guide you through the R graphic interface. Here's an example of their pedagogy from page 32:Type directly into the console window (they xshow where this is, Spahn's games won for his 7 seasons with the Boston Braves.  L < -(5,10,12,14,17,14,10) to create what R calls a "vector."  (No, not all examples concern the great Spahn!).The R "vector" is simply the SAS/SPSS "variable" and the SQL "column!"  Five pages later, we're introduced to the concept of matrices so that we can save our data rather than repeatedly entering it (like a SAS datastep or an SQL table or view), and on page 41, they introduce the concept of "scripts" (a tool which seems similar to a SAS macro.)Not only is this well organized, logical, and generally clear, but the book explains where to download a free "R" program and how to import some web-basedbaseball-oriented datasets (with actual data; this *will* fascinate baseball people!) on which to practice. There are practice exercises (although I didn;t see any ranswers), a dual index (one for commands and one for topics), and over 53 refences for further exploraion of R and related material.  Statistical heavyweights can practice logistic and linear regression (R uses a General Linear Model), exploring moving averages and moving average plots (the book has a large amount of material on R graphics), quadratic model fit, how to calculate a wqeighted on-base percentage, and slugging percentage.Although some of this may sound rather daunting, it's still an excellent book for the relative beginner, and you don't need to understand every concept to benefit.  If you're completely new to statistical and database concepts, you should probably go with something simpler, but others will learn a lot from this refreshingly interesting and well-written book.  When you get bogged down in it, go out and play some ball; it'll help clear your head.

This is a fun retelling of "Little Red Riding Hood," with a post-modern bent.  I say "post-modern" because it not only comments on itself (our protagonist points to a large textbox on the first page and asks what it is...) but it also neatly deconstructs the old story to its essentials (in this excerpt, a young dog tries to summarize the plot he just heard from Cat, a parental/guardian figure):"So let's see if I have this right. The Red Hood is on her way to help an old lady when she meets the Wolfman. He has an evil plan.  He likes to dress up in girls' clothes and eat people.  He and Red have a big battle, and Red's father puts an end to Wolfie."That's not exactly how Cat told the story to the 4-or 5ish year-old Dog, but Dog interrupts with so many questions and neatly ignores so many answers that it's no surprise he can't repeat the plot verbatim.  And that's the fun of the story, the questioning dog and the increasingly exasperated Cat turn story-time into a verbal wrestle, and if the ending has is mildly violent (Cat, fed up with one more question, throws the book at Dog. "Ouch" he exclaims as it lands on his head); well, the book should not be read by the literal minded.The story stays fairly close to the traditional telling (although the handsome woodsman is changed to Hood's father, thus neatly dodging any sexual angle), but Dog has an extraordinary logic that strips away some of the fantastic claims of the original. When the wolf first encounters the girl in the forest, Dog asks, "Hang on...why doesn't the wolfman try to ear Hood Girl then and there?"  later, the dog observes with a scowl, " She's not very bright, is she?  I mean, if there were a wolf dressed up as MY grandma, I might have noticed right away."  (Somehow, dog knows to use the subjunctive "were" instead of "was"!).  There's also some clever interior humor, as he notes that the book's endpaper does come at the end of the book, contrary to cat's explanation that it comes at the beginning (they're at both places.)The book shines with a modern sensibility as dog expects superpowers and exploding eggs, a wry comment on a lot of children's entertainment these days.  The jokes trade on these clashes: Traditional vs. contemporary, questioning child/dog and initially patient adult/cat, naive, age-appropriate dog vs. a wise beyond years "Peanuts" mentality. (Soon after hearing the rather gruesome detail that the father "arrived and CHOPPED OFF THE WOLF's HEAD WITH AN AXE!", the dog asks whether Cat is absolutely sure this is a children's book.  Actually, I found this a little too explicit myself, but that's for the potential buyer to decide.  The book is just a little flat towards the end, but dog not only gives that great summary of the plot, but has one more sensible question about whether grandma is still hiding in the closet. Cat is so fed-upWIth small, simple pencil and water-color drawings, the informal pictures and loads of white space lightens the mood. A book that will appeal to perceptive kids and to their book-reading parents, it could become a little favorite.  Amazon.com offers the book at a nice (and fair) discount as well.

Yes, this really is damask, and yes, it is polyester,  If the polyester seems a bit declasse for your social circles, consider this from the unassailable authority on these matters, Wikipedia:"Damask weaves are commonly produced in monochromatic (single-colour) weaves in silk, linen or synthetic fibres such as rayon and feature patterns of flowers, fruit, and other designs."The key words here are "synthetic" (polyester!), "monochromatic" (the wine-red), and "other designs" (sort of a scroll pattern that might remind you of a light, open paisley).  Therefore, this is authentic damask, even if it's not meant for the heirloom collection.Function follows price, and the DII (a company with over 1,200 products on Amazon.com) tablecloth performs admirably.  It's festive rather than gaudy, and could be used for almost any celebratory occasion, kids or adults.  It sheds stains and wrinkles, and, at worst, you can even wash and dry this 60 by 104 inch fabric in a washing machine and dryer.  SInce it fits tables seating 8-10 people ( or holding 5 feet by almost 8 feet, 8 inches worth of punch bowls, cups, saucers, casseroles, silverware, decorative animals, veggie burgers, etc., it's probably going into a large room where it won't overpower other decorative touches.For anyone who hosts a semi-big event once in a while, and who doesn't want to risk the emotional turmoil that accompanies a ruined expensive tablecloth (say, when wine or punch is spilled on it), this is a solid, attractive, practical alternative.  Available in several colors and patterns, as shown here on Amazon.com.

The best feature here is the silky smooth, rich and natural bass; it's neither timid nor gimmicky - it's just a fine performance for bass lovers. (If you're not a bass lover, and you're used to cheaper earbud style phones, it may feel like too much: Earbuds often don't transmit bass very well. I really love the bass, but if you can't get used to it then hopefully you have an equalizer on your audio device.)  The sound is satisfying throughout the spectrum (although those who really like a lot of treble may find it lacking), not surprising given the 3Hz - 27kHz frequency response and the more-than-adequate 40mm dual diaghragm speakers. The lack of buzz and other iatrogenic noise is superior to many other speakers. Bravo, as they say.The unit is designed fairly well except for one flaw.  The weight is moderate (way more than your buds, but not as much as the big cans from Sony, for example), the cushioning at the ears and on the surface that touches your head, the size is adjustable (look closely and you can see where the earpiece can slide down).  They're comfortable, although comparable to other headphones in the $100 and up range (in my admittedly limited experience). However, for the performance, the overall weight and comfort level is fine. (At first, the tension of the phones is not as "lightly sprung"  as claimed, but I expect this will loosen with time (or my hands slightly stretching it).There is a slight problem with the in-line volume, pause play, skip tracks, etc. controller:  It's too high to comfortably see or use when the controller is connected close to the headphones.  However, the line is detachable!  Just plug the controller end into your audio device and the other side into the phones, and now the in-line controller is more like bent-arm's lengh away.  I really appreciate having the in-line controls (I don't see them very often on cheaper phones), but at this price, one might expect left/right balance or maybe treble/bass control.  Perhaps I'm expecting too much.Being able to fold these up, and then pack them in an astonishingly lux case makes up for some of the deficits.  (I wonder how much this would cost with a cheapo pouch, or none at all.)  It's surprisingly light, well-padded, and has a half-case mesh compartment for storing the cord or whatever.  Very nice.Overall, I'm very pleased with the sound and overall quality.  Unfortunately, I haven't had the time to go out and compare other phones to this one, but it compares very favorably to the various Sony closed-end phones I've in the past.  You don't need huge headphones or "boost" features to get a great-sounding bass and full sound at the high end and middle.

I used to make up little drawing games when I was a YOUT, so the appeal of this was immediate.  Fortunately, a six-year old shared my enthusiasm.  Blue Orange designers created  an entertaining way for kids to practice motor skills, coordination, math, and many other cognitive abilities, all through playing a game with an adventure motif.  While story-telling is tangential to the object of the game, the different scenarios add to the fun and may encourage interactive play.  However, I also like that the game may be played alone as well as with others, in competitive or non-competitive play, and that kids of different ages seem to adapt it to their own level. Doodle on, and have fun!

Please, let's remember what this is not before casting aspersions.  It is not made of stain steel, it is not metal, not a thermos, nor is it dishwasher or microwave-safe.  It's your basic one-handed mug with double-walled plastic insulation, which will keep your coffee hot for maybe 30 minutes, after which it begins to cool.  It is best for a short commute, not for camping or even a 90-minute drive.It is also not a maggot habitat, contrary to the experience of one reviewer.  I don't doubt the veracity of that report, but I'm not sure the mug is at fault.  Yes, you should hand wash within a few hours of use, and then turn it upside-down to dry.  I've even left it a few days before washing with no ill effects. If you want to wash inside the lid (I don't think you have to), just press the raised circle under the lid and twist.This travel mug has a very nice grip, is sized well both in diameter and height, and does NOT spill if you turn the lid on tightly.  You may need to experiment with what makes for a tight seal; my one complaint is that several times it has felt sealed, but was not. SPILLAGE.  The problem is that you need to make sure that you've screwed the lid on evenly with the threaded top. If you don't, it may feel tight, but you've accidentally left a small gap. This should be easier than it is, but practice helps.  When the lid is on properly, you can turn this over and not spill a drop.It holds over 13 ounces, and is a bit taller than some containers.  You might want to test whether you'll have problems by placing a similarly sized container in your vehicle's beverage holder.  Mine tips over a bit, but has never fallen out.I love the true one-hand operation: Push down the orangy-red button in the center, and you've opened a passage for your coffee or tea or whatever.  That button stays down until you push it again; this closes it up.  That button closes very solidly; I don't get the feeling it's going to break any time soon.  The flow rate is also compatible with driving (but try not to drink while you're driving) because the liquid flows into your mouth at a reasonable rate.  Again, a little practice may help, but you're not likely to either splash your face, or raise the bottom towards the ceiling because the flow is too sloooow.You can (and maybe should) pay more for a higher standard of performance, or if you really have your mind set on the "Coffee Makes Me Poop" logo on one of the travel cups sold at Amazon.com.  However, for everyday use for short trips around town, you won't be investing much in another solid OXO product.

Watts Beauty Moisturizing Hyaluronic Acid is a "serum" of several popular pro-skin ingredients* that, according to the company, "works great pn aging skin, uneven skin tones, dry skin, blemishes and more." Those popular ingredients include  a blend of unspecified organic herbs ( as an infusion), Aloe Vera, Hyaluronic Acid, Witch Hazel, MS), Organic Jojoba Oil, Green Tea, Geranium Essential Oil, and Vitamin C (as sodium ascorbyl phosphate.A quick search of Wikipedia cites two studies in which a minimal surgical procedure using Hyaluronic Acid reduced neck wrinkles, two cites on the use of Arginine in treating wounds, and that Vitamin C acts as an anti-oxidant (although it also acts as a pro-oxidant).But, this is NOT a scientific analysis, just as there has been no scientific double-blind studies of this product ( to my knowledge anyway).  Watts, at least, knows enough science to package this in a dark-colored bottle, to prevent oxidation.I suspect that results, both positive and negative, will vary, and that your experience may be the best predictor of whether this will work for you.  That, and perhaps your expectations (this will may me look 10 years younger vs. lower expectations). My own experience was as follows: This is quite light, although minimally oily upon first application, this dries after a short time. I experienced a slight pulling sensation as well, perhaps due to the witch hazel; again, not really noticeable after a while.My "takeaway" is that one should use this very sparingly, and certainly in a smaller dose than comes using the bottle's sprayer (although the spray is surprisingly precise).  I recommend spraying the hand, and then dipping one's finger into it for application.  A dropper would have been worth the extra time it takes to apply compared to the spray.  That's the primary reason I've given this a 4 instead of a 5 rating.As I said, I'm reluctant to offer a testimonial about dermal outcomes (I think I just made up a word).  The organic, cruelty-free (not tested on animals-great!) ingredients should perhaps be compared to what you've used in the past.  If this is new to you, I suggest getting the 1 ounce size.  It's less economical than the larger, but you won't risk as much money upfront in case this either has undesired results, or does not produce the results you expect. Not odor-free, there is a mild (and to me, pleasant) scent from the geranium oil,*Ingredient List.  Organic herbal infusion, Organic Aloe Barbadensis Leaf Juice (Aloe Vera), Hyaluronic Acid, Hamamelis Virginiana (Witch Hazel), Methylsulfonymethane (MSM), Organic Simmondsia Chinensis (Jojoba Oil), Carbomer, (2s)-2-Amino 5-guanidinopentanoic Acid, Wildcraften Camellia Sinensis (Green Tea), Pelagonium Graveolens (Geranium Essential Oil), Sodium Ascorbyl Phosphate (Vitamin C) Ethylhexyl Glycerin, Phenoxyethanol.

Remington's "Hyper Flex" technology is a bit gimmicky sounding, but it's basically a version of the floating rotary heads found on other electric razors, notably the Norelco "Senso-Touch" system.  Some Don Draper type really used indulged in his or her imagination for this hyperbole , but it's really no worse than the Norelco.It'c comparable to the Norelco as well.  Although not quite as sleek looking, you may prefer the monochromatic greys and black to the flash of Norelco's iridescent blue.Performance is fine.  Although electric razors will almost never shave as closely as the cheap throwback plastic safety razors, the floating heads do a good job of maintaining close contact with the skin.  Still, you may find that you  spend a lot of time on, say, your neck, only to discover that a cheapo BIC razor does it better.As others have mentioned, there is a plastic feeling, but my personal lab technicians feel that's quite possibly due to the plastic used.  If you want to spend $200, you can probably get away from this.  More importantly (for most), the Remington gives a close and comfortable shave, the features function as they should (e.g., the trimmer, the battery use indicator, wet/dry shaving, etc.), and placed where you'd expect themErgonomically, it feels balanced and light in the hand, with a solid grip.  It's cleaned with water, although a brush is provided as well. Some of my vast staff (not their weight, but how far-flung across the country they're located) felt that the charger/holder was *not* so intuitive, but others didn't have a problem.  In any event, you might want to test whether the balance of the razor when charging it inside the unit; you wouldn't want it tipping over.Overall, a very good shaver for the price that works well. It would be great for travel as well as home/office use.  And no, I'm not a beard for Remington....

With 61 out of 92 people rating this a 4 or 5 out of a maximum of 5, I can'thonestly say that this is a bimodal distribution of those who love the Binder vs. those who Hate it, but there *is* quite a divergence of opinon on this product, the most serious of which seems to center on California's Prop. 65 law requiring labelling of products containing carcinogenic materials.  I didn't get this label, but apparently it's aimed at those who are pregnant, and this is quite discomforting to many, even those who are not "with child."  Let's go review this and other features and contrasting opinions.Stylish Beauty vs. Health Risk.This is one of the most stylish Binders I've seen at this price.  It's a rich blie with leather-like texture, and a stiched beige somewhat leather-like interior.  It's not a high-tech monochrome or black/silver combo; it has a warmer appearance that says, " I care about how I present myself, but I'm not pretentious, and I don't need something ultra-modern or cooly understated. YET, that material (at least the exterior) is made from PVC-free polyproplyene ("polypro)" and I believe it's the polypro that earns the Prop 65 warning.  It's true that you wouldn't know about the potential danger (here, according to the warning label that I didn't receive, to expectant mothers), but that's the whol epoint of Prop. 65: To warn you of potential toxicity that you wouldn't otherwise know about.  We see this all the time on glasses that may contain lead, some types of faux leather clothing, and many other products.  Unfortunately, I have not found a good website that explains why materials are on the list, and, especially, what kind of exposure is dangerous (e.g., is it dangerous if I nerely hold it or do I have to lick it, bite into it, does it leech out into the laundry, are there dangerous fumes, is the toxicity limited to it's manufacture rather than its use....etc.)  My own feeling is that this is certainly NOT an advantage. because, while not pregnant, these are the sort of questions that naturally occur to me.  A call to Wilson/Jomes might clarify all this.Design and Durability.  Part of the beauty is that this is a "soft-shell" binder, not one of those clunky, rigid notebooks that we lugged around at school. It's lighter, and has can stylishly conform to your grip and curve as you place it on a table.  Yet, this also means (probably) that it's not as durable as those rigid, somewhat clunky notebooks, such as Wilson-Jones' own Heavy Duty 3-ring binders.  Because of this, I recommend rhis more as a portfolio for short-term storage and presentation of documents, rather than a more permanent storage product.  In addition, the storage capacity is limited compared to other binders.Another durability issue:  The nice-looking cord that keeps the binder closed has already, after a very short period of time, produced creases where it wraps around the folder exterior.  This begins to detract from the elegance.Function:  As said before, this might be best to think of as a portfolio that can accomodate plain and hole-pinched papers.  There are two nice pockets for non-punched papers, and a 3-ring set-up for punched.  However, the 3 rings are small are not D-rings, this limits how much paper they can hold, and may affect durability (more pressure to open the rings).  With a small amount of paper stored for temporary use (before, say, moving to a more permanent storage product, this is probably not a problem; however, this is a limit of which one should be aware.The pockets are tightly sewn and come up about 1/3 or so up the vertical plane of the front and back covers.  Unlike others, I've seen no "bubbles" indicating poor manufacturing. The pen holder and ID (or other) holder are nice features, that give it a somewhat more expensive pedigree.Bottom Line. Putting aside the warning label for the moment, I might buy this Binder.  The drawback is the small size, some questions about durability, and the possibilty that for just $10 or $15 more, I might find something that I liked much better. The arguument for purchasing is the beautifully blue textured cover, the light weight, and a certain relaxed sophistication.  For some, the deal-breaker will be that pesky warning that the materials might have a health risk.  If Prop. 65 doesn't have a site that more readily describes the specifics, perhaps WIlson-Jones could add an insert explaining the risk (especiallywhat type of exposure creates it).  Otherwise, I recommend calling the company.  Personally, I'm not so bowled over by the overall product that I could practice some denial, and buy this figuring what I don't know won't hurt me.  Wilson Jones...tear down the information wall!

Best reason to buy this water bottle:  It keeps water cold, colder than any other water bottle I've owned (and I own/have owned several for general health and for outdoor activities).  It's steel, non-BPA, and vacuum-insulated, as others have noted. If you look forward to a refreshing cold drink of water, this is the one for you. And, yes, it is rugged, and doesn't "sweat" water from condensation, but most bottles don't.My enthusiasm is tempered by a few important design problems.  Most importantly, there is no sipper, unlike the Camelbak Eddy Bottle and other Camelbak products.  Not only do you have to tip the bottle up to let gravity do its work, but you have to press a release button (it's grey, you can see it in the photo) at the back.  This lets the water out (and keeps the cold in), but it's not easy to do this while you're engaged in some other activity (walking or kayaking, for example). Even though it doesn't get slippery and the shape is well-designed, there's no handle or rubberized grip; this compounds the difficulty.  I'm not saying it takes great dexterity to use the bottle, but these qualities are important to consider for this not inexpensive product.  Personally, I also wish it came in different sizes (like a 32-ounce), and overall, I prefer the one liter Camelbak, but the latter just can't compete with this one for keeping your water.... COLD.

"I'm not sure how much more she can take!""Give her all you got, we're almost there!""You only have a narrow 2-3 second window to pull down the lever!"~And those were just from the adults in the room! Three adults (including myself) recently made one of the Hot Wheels cars with the 5-year old son of our friend. It was a HUGE hit, and both the cute little boy and the (somewhat cute) adults were excited and pleased with the end result.The product comes with OK instructions; we had to go to the hotwheels.com/carmaker site listed on the package to figure out why the door to the mold-making machine would not stayed closed, resulting in the annoying repetition of a computerized voice repeating "Error... error... error..."  Fortunately, the website (listed in the instructions) helped us resolve the problem (take out the wax stick, unplug it, and start over again).  Other than that, assembly was easy, fast, and without missing or non-fitting parts.You probably get the idea of how this works from the description and other reviews, so I'll be brief.  One places wax sticks at the top of the machine and waits for it to heat up (about 6-7 minutes), all the while watching lights flash and sound effect repeat.  This held the boy's attention for about 3-4 minutes; the adults tried to liven things up with the dumb jokes quoted above.  Once the mechanical voice announces that the machine is hot enough, depress the lever (within 2-3 seconds or who KNOWs what will happen! *smile*), and the waxy sticks melt into the car mold at that you've inserted at the bottom of the machine.  WAIT another eight or so minutes, and you'll hear that the cooling is complete and the door opens automatically.  This is VERY exciting after that waiting, but one still has to scrape off excess wax with the included plastic "tool" (if you lose this, many other objects will accomplish the same thing), loosen the now hardened car from the mold (not difficult), and then (easily) press it onto a prebuilt chassis, complete with working wheels. The waxen vehicle is richly colored (the purple has a very deep, almost metallic look; the finish does not look waxy or "cheap") and one finishes by adding decals onto the finished product. Oh, and then you get to play with it, too!The boy loved it, and held it in his arms when he left to go home.  HIs mom had to encourage him him to just lay it on the seat beside him as they drove home!A FEW THINGS YOU SHOULD KNOW.1. DEMANDING. This 5-year old, a very intelligent boy with precocious small motor skills, could NOT have done this himself.  Even after memorization of the instructions, the manual dexterity required (ESPECIALLY with the decals) is beyond his capabilities, and so Mattel is right: Suggested minimum age is 8, and even at that age, someone may need assistance.  Not that our "test subject" minded, he enjoys playing with adults, but you should take into account your child's need to do things "all by myself."2. PATIENCE.  Just making the mold requires about 15 minutes, minutes that go by very slowly when you're so anxious to see the finished product. Mattel  tried to accommodate this with the flashing lights and sound effects, but even this was not enough to distract our budding engineer.  The answer is...COOKIES!!!  I think the best way to play with this is to have a distraction/alternative activity going on while you're waiting... a book, a plate of cookies, etc.Adding the decals is fun, but adds another 35-35 minutes of focused effort. We let the boy try his hand at selecting and placing the decals, but ultimately it was the adults who put them on.  A 5-yearold might not mind; an 8+ year old might.3. MORE ABOUT THOSE DECALS.  They're tiny, they're not keyed to the different molds (figuring out which window decal, as just one example, fit which car model was something the adults had a lot of difficulty with), and Mattel could have easily printed some extra material on this.  We relied on the pictures on the package, but there was a problem here too:  Not only were just a few decals shown on the two car models, but decals were shown that are NOT included in the set! (It showed a white spoiler, for example, and there is no such decal included). What a shame-this was an unnecessary problem.4. What's Included. Despite these flaws, the toy makes beautiful hot wheel vehicles (one of them is a little more like a truck). You have enough wax to  make up to 10 molded cars, but can play with only three at a time because that's how many chassis are included. However, if you tired of one model, just snap it off, and replace it with one of the others. Additional wax can be bought (of course) if your youngster wants a fleet of vehicles or is a budding entrepreneur.5. Quality and Performance. The machine worked, the cars look excellent, and the decals (when finally applied) make them look exciting and realistic. The wheels are solid and the car rolls around well. For younger kids that don't mind getting help (and for parents and adult friends who don't mind giving it), you'll get fine results (but remember, patience and/or alternative activies will help!).6. Value. Too expensive, as are most toys. Even with the current $10 dollar discount it seems overpriced by 5-10 dollars. However, the fact that it works, that there's nothing quite like it (that I know of, anyway), and that individual hot wheels can cost quite a bit add to the value, as does the safety of the machine. Adult supervision will be necessary in most cases (in my opinion), but the machines was NOT hot to the touch.  Mattel, in its heartfelt concern about kids' safety (and equally since desire to not get sued) has a list of safety precautions about as detailed as if this were a chemistry set.7. Bottom line.  There's a LOT to like about this set, and few problems with getting it to work. The big issue is whether the manual and psychological (e.g., patience, cooperating with older peers or adults) demands will mesh well with your child's skill level and personality. I'd also like to see the price come down a little more, but our sample boy sure did love this!  Now, if they could make a similar set that makes other toys, perhaps include an activity while you wait, and have better guidance on those decals, Mattel would make a lot of kids happy, and have a new hit toy.

270+ reviews on Phospho-Omega, a fish oil supplement derived from krill! For humans, there's little debate that fish oil is a potent source of Omega 3's polyunsaturated fatty acids, rich in anti-oxidants EPA and DHA, substances that help with the cardiovascular and perhaps other systems.  I've gathered that there's some debate over just how many conditions may be helped, but the current debate rages over the merits of krill (a kind of crustacean, like shrimp) vs. fish-derived forms.  I'm just glad that the whales, seals, fish, and birds who feed on krill are not similarly consumed by this controversy.My brief review (very brief, PLEASE consult your health care provider for accurate and thorough information) shows two primary camps. There are those (Dr. "OZ" is a popular proponent for this side) who claim superior benefits of krill-based products such as  better absorption and delivery of DHA to the brain (admittedly, in animal models), the additional antioxidant, astaxanthin, equal performance but at much lower doses ,better bio-sustainability and reduced toxins (because it's extracted at the bottom of the food chain and is harvested in cleaner oceans. This view is summarized at (among other website): [...]Not so fast say proponents of a more cautious view, who note that one of the most quoted studies was funded by a Krill Oil company(!). They note the uncertain state of current findings about the superiority of krill oil; indeed, both "sides" agree that there is far less research on krill than fish-based Omegas.  A Medscape article ([...]) notes that "Preclinical animal research suggests that fish oil is more digestible and more efficiently incorporated into tissue than krill oil[5]; however, preliminary clinical research suggests that krill oil might have better bioavailability than fish oil," and that "the comparative bioavailability of omega-3 fatty acids from krill vs. fish oil is uncertain."Even the more enthusiastic krill oil supporters use words like "may benefit" and "seem to have beneficial effects."  At least they're not claiming perfect knowledge.Other factors to consider wit areh either krill or fish oil gastrointestinal and other types of tolerabilities, although tolerability may be improved by strategies suggested in the Medscape piece.  The Medscape article states that krill oil "long-term safety and the drug interaction profile are unknown," but that, in any case, those with shellfish allergies should not take krill oil.Tolerance will vary both within people (because of some of the adaptations one may use in consuming it) and between people, so it's probably not too informative to hear that I had no side effects (not even minor ones) with krill oil.  They were easy for me to swallow, but then, I'm an inveterate pill swallower (prescription only, of course). Krill oil capsules may be more expensive than fish oil, but the current Amazon.com price is more than 50% off list, and some people may be willing to pay more anyway.Perhaps the best thing you can do is to read literature that offers different perspectives, and, most importantly, to consult with a qualified health professional (not Amazon.com reviewers)!  If all this start to seem like too much work, I suggest taking a break by listening to "Diamonds are a Krill's Best Friend," "I Enjoy Being a Krill," or jazz pianist/singer, Diana Krill.

This is an excellent electric toothbrush priced between the better budget models (S40-$75) and the higher-end complete bells-and-whistles, retractable cord, auto-sanitizing, warning if you're using too much pressure, etc. models. Compared to those in the former category, this has much more power (yes, the brush does revolve faster, 31,000 RPM), has a wonderfully lightweight, ergonomic handle (for example, it's slimmer, with a longer reach to easily access all parts of your mouth), holds a charge for weeks and weeks (I really appreciate this feature when traveling; the manual states that a fully charged brush "should provide 42 2-minute brushings," or about 3 weeks), and has several "modes."That last feature is somewhat questionable because Phillips does not specifically explain how the modes differ in their product manual. (see [...] )All we're told is that the user has a choice of five modes:"The five modes include a clean mode for an outstanding clean in two minutes. A sensitive mode for gentle yet thorough cleaning of the gums. A refresh mode for those quick one minute touch-ups. A massage mode to stimulate the gum and a gum caremode that helps improve gum health."So what's the difference between massage mode to stimulate the gums and gum care mode?  As stated above, the clean mode runs at 31,000 rpm; what's the rpm for the sensitive mode? WHAT quick one-minute touch-ups, and why not just turn the brush on again after the automatic 2-minute shut-off, and run it for as long or as short as you want?Not that you'd necessarily want to do this, but you cannot change brushing modes in the middle of a brushing. That's not a drawback to me.  Like many models these days, the toothbrush breaks the 2-minute timed brushing into fourths by basically stopping every 30 seconds and immediately accelerating to full speed. IT's nice in theory (equal attention to all areas of the mouth) but after many weeks of using I still am reminded of the auto-shut off at the dentist's office, when your mouth accidentally grasps the hygienist's brush.  When the Phillips stops and starts, I keep thinking I've locked my mouth around it, when I haven't. This *is* annoying, and at least has improved with time. I'd prefer a design that slowed down very briefly.Buy this for these useful features:1. Power (31,000 RPM)2. Wonderfully slim, lightweight handle, and long well-designed brush.3. Relative long battery life.4. Whirring sound rather than jarring LOUD sound of some other toothbrushes.5. Battery indicator showing how much charge is left/how much more re-charging is needed, solid portable case.6. Results that you may notice, improved removal of surface stains, good "mouth feel" afterwards.As for the modes...I think it's over-rated.  At least try to sell it to me, Phillips, by telling me exactly how the speed and motion differs among them.  In my opinion, if you can get features 1-6 in a cheaper model, you might prefer that. Overall, and despite my ranting about the modes, this has been my favorite (well, and most expensive) of the several electric brushes I've owned.Bottom line, ASK YOUR DENTIST or trusted HYGIENIST if this is the right brush for you.

I can't vouch for the Iphone capabilities of these phones (I dare not call them by any modern slang, like cans), but others have written about a rather impressive lineup of features that (microphone input to phone, music pause, etc.) that seem to function very well.The look is either gonna completely turn you off (unless you love white accessories--belts, polo shirts, buckskin shoes--or you have a sense of humor about them; sometimes something can be so blatantly uncool that it becomes hip in its defiance of trends. At any rate, that's how I prefer to think of these.It should be a foregone conclusion that these will be more comfortable and produce better sound than those awful earbud "headphones" that do nothing but fall out of one's ear. Perhaps others like earbuds (EWWW, even sounds like earwigs, the bug) because they stay in their ears and they're certainly lightweight.  These are lighter than some of the non-earbud designs; I found them comfortable and stable.  I happen to like the "old school" two lines descending from the phones; it's consistent with the unconventionality of the look.The sound is very good, not as good as a pair of $80 speakers without all the ipod/iphone interfaces that these have.  You also sacrifice some quality versus the closed ear phones, but that may be a personal preference, and, of course, that would add to the weight. I do think these headphones cost a bit too much at full price, if you can, wait until a sale.  Right now, for example, they're selling at a hefty discount.  Overall, a good, original effort with multi-functionality and decent performance.

I have to agree with the majority of reviewers here, the basic elements--the camera and the speakers---work well, not premium "boardroom" quality (whatever that is) but well enough for most conference and personal uses. Note: If you have an actual boardroom chances are price is not an issue and you'll likely buy something even more expensive. As noted by "Nerd" this is optimalized for conference because of the depth of field and sound features. However, it also works fine with Skype for person-to-person communication.  The price is probably not worth the features, however, if that's all you're going to use it for.  The 4 months of free OmniJoin Web conferencing is a nice pitch to those considering the full subscription, but at $500 annually (approximately), you shouldn't let that sway your purchase decision unless you have some direct (or word-of-mouth) experience, and feel fairly sure you're going to subscribe.  In other words, if you already like and need OmniJoin Web Conferencing, it's great to have four months of free service that basically pays for the device itself.

The Fire is not "below," perhaps, but at least very securely between the two sleek and smooth black front and back covers of this sturdy, high quality storage and carrying case for the Kindle Fire HD 7".THe product does exactly what it should.  It holds your Kindle securely at the four corners with some triangular shaped elastic that you lift and stretch over the four corners. The last corner will be a tight fit and will take more effort (think of putting the last corner of a fitted sheet over a mattress), but the resulting hold power is worth it. (In fact, I tried my much smaller Kindle paperwhite reader and the fit was so tight that it usually held, despite very little coverage of the tips of the Paperwhite. However, do NOT rely on this product to secure the Paperwhite reader, the dimensions are for the Fire). As other reviewers did, I gave the case several shakes while open and the Fire did not move.The case acts as a stand in a very simple manner, just arrange the covers to form a V (with the Fire pointing outward, of course!) and rest the cover along the two edges. The edges have a rubbery-type fabric that hold the case up well. It would have been nice to have this same material along the spine of the Fire cover for added grip: I think it's probably safest to carry this, if a purse, bag, or briefcase is not handy, with the "open side" up (i.e. not the binding side, as in a book) to take advantage of the grip surface along the edge.THe outside is a beautiful combination of traditional and modern styles; the overall effect is a dark black with a very subtle mosaic in darn brown crosshatch. It is NOT loud or garish; neither is it sleek and techno,  The cover is nicely secured by an elastic band that fits into a smooth inset so that it is more flush with the cover.I had NO problem with any ports being covered by the elastic corner binding (unlike another reviewer here).  All ports, on-off buttons, slots for recharging, etc. were available for use!Overall, this is a very useful and well-built cover.  I think the price is high by about $5.00, so buy something else if you can find something that costs less but with the same quality and functionality (or, if having a cover that can act as a stand is not important, you might want to look at other products).  However, given the cost of your Fire and the features of this cover, the slightly high price is probably worth it.

This is a feature rich FM clock radio that plays Apple devies with far richer sound than, for example, the Philips AJ7030D/37 30-Pin iPod/iPhone Alarm Clock Speaker Dock.  Although about twice the size as the amaller Phillips, the sound (paritularly the bass and mid-range) is mull fuller and richer sounding, while still at a relatively budget-mided price point. It's so laded with features that I'll enumerate and evaluate them below:1. Plays FM radio, although with an externnal antenna (i.e., a wire( that must be stretched and pointed in an optimal direction for best reception.  Even so, FM reception is only passable (but will depend greatly on your location). In my experience , perhaps the weakest feature.1a. There's six radio presets, nice if you'r ein the mood for something different, or if you r station isn't comin in well.2. Charges Ipds, Ipads, Iphones.  These devices fit easily on the device (I've had some trouble with others) and they're recharged quickly.  Functions well.3. Equalizer, THis feature will affect both the FM radio and your docked device with independent settings ranging  from -5 to -5 for treble and for bass. Unfortunately there's no midrange, so turning up the treble or the bass will not solve all sonic problems. Still, a nice feature to have (although the 3D Sound feature doesn'--im my opinon, do a whole lot.4. Clock and alarm.  The clock will synch to an attached device, OR you can naually set the time yourself.  There are two alarms and these havve "snooze (let me sleep a little while longer!)," and sleep functions. Yu can deploy the "bedtime button" to gently lower the volume of your device as you drift off to sleep. This is incremental, not continuous( i.e., it will play for 120.90.60.30 or 15 mintes).  A nice feature is that you can independently adjust the sleep mode and the alarm volume.  In addition to the two alarm customizations (which can be set to precisely the time at which you want to wake, there's a "Nap" feature that wakes you by the default buzzer alarm. Like the sleep feature, this is set incremnatlly rather tha n continuously *your choices -- 5, 10. 15, 20, 40,45. 60, 90, or 120 minutes.5. There is an audio output line to connect the radio to exteranl speakers!6. Please note that the unit does NOT run on batteries, although it has battery backup.A good unit, especially for MP3 nd other music players with a nice complement of clock (includes a calendar, by the way) and alarm features.  The main drawback is the not-so-impressive FM reception.With better FM reception

My Kindle and Ipod type devices have limited storage (just didn't want to pay more) and the Seagate Wireless Plus 1 TB Mobile Device Storage (with Built-In Wi-Fi Streaming) is perfect for storing a tremendous amount of media (one full terrabyte of storage,; "500 movies or thousands of songs, photos and documents."), and bringing it along with your media your player of choice (for me, several Kindle devices and an Ipod touch).  Not only do you have this great storage capacity in a compact, lightweight, and rather handsome device, but its user friendly interface with your computer (either drop-and-drag or use USB connection to transport computer-stired files to the Seagate) makes it easy to move media from its "permanent location to a mobile one. Wi-fi capabilities become irrelevant, you have a vast amount of content that can "stream" to your to your device--up to 150 feet away. By the way, the whle system is more user-friendly now that Seagate has posted (see other reviews to which Seagate has responded--gtoota love whe n a company does that) links to instruction and various topics within it. A little pricey, but you're getting a storage unit and "streamer" in one; if that fits you needs, you'll probably use it many times.I'll repeat the important System Requirements and Contents in case you missed it above: "Wi-Fi enabled devices with a Web browser, iOS 4.3 or higher, Android 2.3 or higher, or Kindle Fire Computer: Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows XP, Mac OS X 10.6 or higher."Contents: Seagate Wireless Plus mobile device storage USB-to-DC cable, USB 3.0 adapter with detachable USB 3.0 cable, Quick start guide, Compact USB wall charger..."  There's also a 3-year limited warranty (that you may be able to extend or double depending on your credit card terms--provided you buy the device with one.Lightweight, innovative (at least, for now!), holds a lot of media, and useful.

This not-so-little shaver must sing the praises of the Schick Hydro 5 Disposable Razor, (3 Count).This was one of the closest and most comfortable shaves I've had in the disposable razor category . (I also own electric razors and s Merkur safety razor--I keep getting these as gifts!)Rather than just another gimmick, the 5 blades work very effectively in removing facial and neck hair; I do feel all that copy about 'pulling up the hair' so that he next razor can cut it has vailidity.  This is a very close shave.Other positives. The grip and feel are comfortable and--dare I say it--ergonomically designed. For difficult to reach places, one can place a thumb just beinf the protected razor for added pressure and precision. The gel-lle hadnle covering is easy on the hand, and some well-placed grooves prevent slippng. The raxor glides smoothly over the face, but--make no mistake--this raxzor takes no mercy either.Cons.  This is a little more difficult to clean than other razors because of the five blades, Additonally, removing the blade for cleaning can be quite challenging--better to use a force water flow, and perhaps a toothpick to remove hair found behind the blade.Bottom line. A razor that actaully makes a difference!  Definitely recommended!

Let's see, this product's tile includes the following descriptors:1. GREAT2. ULTRA3. SMOOTH4. CLEARFOr starters, I would hope that a screen protector is smooth and clear ("only slightly bumpy and opaque!"); I did not see any evidence of the product's deserving the ULTRA accolade.  This is pretty much the same as any non-junky  screen protector (identifiable, in most cases, by an extremely low price).PROs1. Went on easily, did not even have to smooth out any "bubbles" (pockets of air between the screen protector and the Kindle Fire).2. Includes 3 screen protectors, a cloth wipe to clean the Kindle, and a little "smoother" tool to take out any bubbles (which I did not even have to use--see above).CONs1. Directions for removing the protector from its protective covering are confusing; however, once you remove one protector you won't need to refer to the instructions again.2. CON # 1. THe screen protector DOES NOT STAY ON THE SCREEN. The protector just doesn't adhere to the screen.  When I used it the protector slid around as I tried to scroll to the next page; I had to TAPE the protector down (tape not included) to use this product.BOTTOM LINE.  I do not recommend the GreatShield Ultra Smooth Clear Screen Protector Film.

Although a little pricey (hey, take off ANOTHER five dollars and it'll be fairly proced), this is a very well-made, compact yet roomy, highly water resistant velcro-sealing pouch for your Kindle. In my experience, I've had no problem fitting the Kindle into the "jacket"; in fact, I can just stuff the power cord into the extra pocket. (There's one pocket with a clear screen into which one places the Kindle, and another pocket with no screen into which one can place a stylus, pen, post-its, whatever--even the power cord (although with difficulty). Yes, it could have been bigger, but then you trade off some of its easy portability and slim profile for storing, packing, etc.A reviewer stated that the Kindle does not fit well into the jacket if you already have a protective skin around its back.  I suppose if the skin is thick enough (for example, those with textured backs) this might be a problem. It is not insurmountable, however.  If you MUST use both a skin and the jacket while traveling; for example, you could probably take the skin off and store it in the second pocket.  This is perhaps a minor hassle, and thick skins may not fit, but it's worth the rick of having to return it. (Amazon.com has a fantastic return policy. I recently returned an item and customer service answered quickly, answered all questions thoroughly and courteously, and promptly sent me a postage -paid label via email.)BOTTOM LINE. This works well and delivers what it promises (don't take it underwater).  If you're concerned about whether your skin-protected Kindle will fit; either remove the skin or return the product.  The slim profile and ease of use (it has a built-in "handle" with some utility) make this a worthwhile accessory for the Kindle owner--now, if only they'd lower the price to around 25-27 dollars.  Overall, I recommend it.

Yes, it's true, there are NO BUBBLES when you place this on top of your Kindle Fire (non High-Definition models), mostly due to its weight and amazing adhesive qualities.  It attaches and can be removed with equal ease.On balance, however, I think the Moshi iVisor Anti-Glare screen protector does not deliver all it claims. I can't really recommend it. Let's get to the usual PROs and CONs and I'll tell you on what I base this opinion.PROs.1. Attaches and removes easily from your KINDLE screen.2. No bubbles (between the screen amd the Moshi protector) when you place the screen protector on your Kindle.3. Fits over entire screen and made of sturdy material.A PRO and One Big CON3. Cuts down on reflective glare, but not "OVERALL GLARE."  A glaring (pun completely intended) problem with the Kindle is the great difficulty with reading text on it when outside. I'm referring to two types of glare: OVERALL GLARE (glare that washes out the contrast of the text on the background so that text on the entire screen is difficult to read), and SPECIFIC REFLECTIVE GLARE (SRG; reflected images that interfere with reading text in some parts of the screen.As an example of "specific reflective glare" imagine that you're reading from your Kindle on a bright day outside. Very likely you will see the reflection of your face bouncing back at you from the screen, obscuring much of it.  The Moshi does a good job of cutting down this type of glare.HOWEVER... The Moshi Screen Protector does not do much to cut down "overall glare," --the non-specific glare that reduces the legibility of the entire screen.CONs.1. The biggest problem is the unresolved problem with "OVERALL GLARE" (see above). It's fine that the product reduces specific reflective glare (SRG), but it is not sufficient to make text easily visible.2. Reduced Visibility.  This is another problem with the product; it reduces contrast and how bright the text appears on the screen. I feel that any reduction in SRG is offset by reduced visibility--and I tested this with the BRIGHT feature up to 90% capacity and a larger-than-usual font.3. Perhaps the most annoying problem is DA--"Dust Attraction."  Sure, with the supplied cloth you can clean your Kindle screen and the protector, but then you must act fast to place the protector before dust and other airborne thingees adhere to the side which sticks to the Kindle.  I could manage this with practice, but those same airborne thingees stick to the outside of the screen protector as well!  Even if you begin with a clean screen, the DA will eventually leave an annoying amount of dust, animal hair, whatever, on top of the screen.BOTTOM LINE.Look elsewhere, unless you absolutely cannot find a screen protector that leaves no bubbles, and if you plan to use your Kindle indoors primarily, and if you have limited dust, etc. flaoting around. I was quite disappointed; perhaps the next iteration of this product (assuming there is one) will show improvement.

How this product can be so strong on dirt and stains and yet be eco-friendly is a mystery to me, but, they've done it!  There's a variety of products in the pack, but I found the spray particularly useful for removing fresh stains off of upholstery, etc., and the apres-gasoline wipes are generously filled with liquid and work well to remove odor, etc.My spouse didn't like the pull-up/jerk method of dispensing the towelettes; it takes a little practice if ou;re not used to it.  She also felt that they might be somewhat too strong for general hand-cleaning.  However, I think you'll find plenty of more heavy-duty uses for these products, and they're both strong and wonderfully portable: I keep wipes and the spray cleaner handy when I'm on a trip, for example. Soy--an excellent source of protein AND a great base ingredient for cleaning!

After going through many electric razors in the $30 to $100 range, I have now found a new favorite, and it's not even a rotary!This Panasonic gives me the closest shave I've experienced, around ALL areas of the face and neck, and with no burn, snags, or other problems. It's loaded with USEFUL featuresm including a percent power remaining indicator, a pop-up trimmer that actually works, a lock,a razor head that detaches for EASY cleaning and re-attaches firmly and easily, and extremely quick recharging (I went from 0 to full power in less than one hour).I previously liked the Philips Norelco 1150x/40 SensoTouch 2d Electric Shaver, Metallic Blue, it also works smoothly and efficiently, but there's no question that the Panasonic gives a closer shave, and includes much better features.  The Phillips has a pop-up trimmer, but it's not part of the shaver, you have to store it until ready for use.  Besides the closer shave (the sine non quo of shaving), the Panasonic is much easier to clean, and is moreforgiving of user error (I accidently broke the head of the Philips when trying to clean it for the first time).ONE complaint.  This is one LOUD shaver.  Not motorcyle or electric mower loud, but I suppose all that power comes at a price.  If you shave in the same room with someone who's trying to sleep or read or otherwise concentrate, they will NOT share your enthusiasm for this shaver.  I close the bathroom door or shave while driving (I know, EWWWWW....), and I don't consider it a "deal-breaker," but you should know there is a trade-off.  At least it's not a broken-shaver sound with rattling and the sound of loose parts, just a loud BUZZ. To me, it's worth it!

Yes, it's feature-loaded, but so are Leggo's and Playskool tool kits. If you're not the superficial type, the somewhat cheap, plastic-looking (OK, it's not technically plastic, but very snthetic and looks it)housing and dayglow colors beg one to not take this watch seriously.However, that would be a mistake, because the features *are* useful, especially for those who want to use the multi-function stopwatch/lap (up to 49 laps). Other functions I appreciate are TWO dependable alarm settings (not too loud, not too soft), "regular" and miltary ("Roger, that's 14 hundred hours, Captain!") displays, light watchband with venting holes (yes, polyurethane does have its advantages...), two watchband keepers (those things a belt or band goes through to stay put) data display capability--this just means you can review your lap/split times.The other MAJOR problem (inherent to some extent in multi-function watches) is related to the instructions, printed in relatively small print on a cardboard inset.  The instructions are somewhat complex, they're condensed because of space limitations, and more diagrams would have helped. Over time (no punintended...) AND if you use it enough, eventually you'll memorize how to actually *use* the functions; until then, make a photocopy and keep it in a safe place!I feel it's only fair to ding this product for its high price/appearance ratio and challenging instructions. Perhaps it's not realistic, but this looks like a 30-35 dollar watch, rather than a $50 and up watch (depending on whether there's a sale).  If money is not an object anyway, I'd prefer a more "professional" looking watch, but perhaps years of living in a suburb have made a snob out of me...

Hate to spoil the love-fest here, but I had nothing but trouble with this.  Most annoyingly, I couldn't get it to fit my Kindle Fire. Second most annoying?  It didn't charge my Ipod Nano.  Now I'm not so vain that I would discount human error (i.e., mine), but I tried several times and had the same frustrating result.  It is also possible, of course, that I simple received one of the few units that was defective.Aside from that, I didn't particularly like the design: It's fussy and not the connections are not as intuitive as they could be.  Based on the other reviews, this is probably a good purchase--and certainly a VERY useful product--but, based on my experience, I would recommend buying this only if you're syre it can be returned. Fortunately, I believe that is the case with Amazon! : )
not really free and limited. mobility. but it's. free.well--free with sub-optimal equipment. if you add the extras-you'll wind up paying more than it's worth.

"Lock and Lock" really did it right with these food storage containers--they have most of the qualities that consumers want and sometimes get--but not all in one product.  The resume for the Lock and Lock Containers is impressive.PROs:1. BPA-free, a chemical you'd probably prefer to stay away from.2. Airtight, thanks to the small blue silicon tubing that fits neatly on the underside of the lid.3. Waterproof, EACH side has a single or double-latch that holds firmly, yet is EASY to unlatch; round containers also have 4 latches, at the 12, 3, 6, and 9 'o clock positions (go on--hold it upside-down!)4. Washable, by hand or machine (best if you do fairly soon after (like any dish or container).5. Solid, attractive look.  These are NOT flimsy looking, and feel solid and well-constructed. The appearance is slightly "fogged," so that it softens the appearance of the food inside, although you can see the contents clearly.6.Microwave safe, but only for warming, not cooking from a raw state. You'll notice that solid construction when you see that the containers don't seem to melt or soften in the microwave.CONs:1. They're stackable, which means they're not as likely to topple over in your cupboard, but they do not fit inside of one another (which would save more space).2.  With foods that stain, this is less stain-resistant than the more expensive "Lock and Lock Bisfre" line Lock&Lock 77.8-Fluid Ounce Bisfree Rectangular Container, 9-1/2-Cup The Bisfre is more expensive, but you might want to add one or two to your collection for two reasons, 1) To add a larger capacity container (this collection should lit most individual needs, or a small side dish for2-4 people, but lacks a huge capacity container, and 2) If you have a heavily-staining food, use the Bisfre instead. This collection would be better with a little more variety in container shape and size, but--other than the humongous capacity category--it covers most of what you'll need, especially for families needing extra containers for lunches, etc.3. OK, I'm really quibbling here, but when they say 28-piece, 14 container in the product title, concentrate on the 14 containers. Those extra 14 "pieces" are merely the 14 lids for the 14 containers!Overall, an impressive, feature-rich collection of food storage containers that should meet almost all of your needs. Excellent sealing and solid construction!

This copier-scanner-FAX machine performs all functions well and has come WAY down in price, making it a solid purchase for one needing all three functions. For those not needing a scanner, I recommend the Canon PIXMA MG6120 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-in-One Printer (4503B002) which also has a much lower price than a year or so ago. Like the Canon, this is a six-color printer, only here it's  regular cyan and light cyan, regular magenta and light magenta, yellow, and black mix. Copy reproduction is excellent, and even photos excel relative to the price. (You might want to look at pricier, photo-specialized copiers for optimal quality).Like the aforementioned Canon, the Epson has two paper trays (a slide-out, and a convenient top-loader. You can scan to your own computer in JPG or PDF format, and send scans, but ONLY if the receiving computer that has Espn drivers. Wired and wireless modes work well, and set-up was relatively easy (it always takes me longer than I think it will). My biggest complaint (and again, this applies to my comparison model, the Canon PIXMA MG6120 Wireless Inkjet Photo All-in-One Printer--without scanner--that I owned before this) is that you can't print once one of the ink colors has run out. So, if you're out of magenta, and you just want to print in black and white--you're out of luck!  I can't think of any reason why printers are designed this way other than to force you to buy all the colors in a timely (to the company) fashion.Lastly, this is a rather big and heavy machine. The weight isn't as much a problem (you're only going to lift it once, probably) as the dimensions: Make sure it will fit on whatever surface you plan to place it. AN excellent multifunction printer!
